title: TRACING THE LOSS OF 15,000 JOBS
description: Why, an official of the American Iron and Steel Institute moaned, do cities like Cleveland and Johnstown and Trenton have to be ''sacrificed'' for the sake of Brazil and the Chase Manhattan Bank? Framed this way, the question overstates the links between aggressive international lending, immense world overcapacity in steel and the increasingly grave plight of United States producers.

title:
GARDENING;
A CONSERVATION GOAL FOR THE NEW YEAR
description: LAST year was not a terribly kind one to the gardener and his garden. A wet spring made getting on with the gardening chores difficult. Six consecutive weekends in May and June were washouts. The wet weather set the stage for such problems as the continued spread of dogwood and anthracnose, that dread fungus disease that is decimating our flowering dogwoods. It also favored mildew at the expense of the rose.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Park Restaurant

title: JUST A HINT OF SCANDAL
description: THESE days the opera isn't over until the critic has performed, as well as the fat lady. Notices in the daily or weekly press appear before most consumers have had any close encounter with the original book, show or exhibition under consideration. But there were books long before there were literary reviews, concerts before music critics, show business before a show-biz industry. In the 20th century, to publish without getting any public reaction is to flop. It was not always like this.

title: LOWER OIL REVENUE A FACTOR IN NIGERIA COUP
description: Lower oil revenues have compounded Nigeria's difficulties in keeping up with payments on $14 billion of foreign debts and may have been a contributing factor in the seizure of power by the military, financial specialists said today.

title: LACK OF TURNOVERS A REDSKIN ASSET
description: Two of the many things that the Washington Redskins have done well this season are to cause turnovers and to prevent them. They may be the best pro team ever in those categories.

description: Less than an hour after he had signed a one-year contract with the Detroit Spirits of the Continental Basketball Assoication, Larry Demic , the former Knick forward, severely sprained an ankle in practice.

title: ON-THE-JOB TRAINING
description: IT IS 6:30 A.M. AND MY WIFE JUST LEFT for work. Three months ago, she launched a new career as a stockbroker. Together we concluded that it was a good idea. It would boost our income; perhaps more importantly, it would provide a creative outlet for her talents. ''We have a solid marriage. You are young and capable. Look around,'' I advised, ''there are all kinds of opportunities.''

title: Q&A
description: RIGHTS TO A NEW LEASE

title: IF THE REAGAN PATTERN CONTINUES, AMERICA MAY FACE NUCLEAR WAR
description: For three years, I have refrained from directly criticizing the President of the United States. I have been reticent because I believe that America must stand united before the world, particularly in the face of our foremost adversary, the Soviet Union. I also believe a President should be given fair time to pursue his goals and test his policies. In this sense, politics should stop at the water's edge. But this cannot mean that all criticism should be muted indefinitely, no matter how wrong a President may be or how critical the world situation may become.

title: 2 WOUNDED IN BEIRUT AS SMALL)ARMS FIRE HITS A FRENCH PATROL
description: Two French members of the international force were wounded in an ambush here late Friday, a French spokesman announced today.

title: BORENO SULTANATE NOW INDEPENDENT
description: This tiny Islamic sultanate on Borneo's northern coast, whose oil and natural gas resources have made it one of the wealthiest countries in the world, became fully independent from Britain today.

And here in New Jersey, local theaters are having their expected share of switching, delays, postponements, cancellations and fill-ins for ''to be announced'' productions.

title: A NEW DIVORCE, A NEW BEGINNING
description: THERE is perhaps nothing as poignant as being newly divorced at the holiday season. Especially if the marriage was a relatively long one, amassing its own history of tinsel and garlands. And especially if there are children.

title: WILL DISKS STILL SPIN IN 2020?
description: Now that 1984 has fallen upon us, we pat our collective backs and tell ourselves that it isn't really all that bad. So maybe it's safe to play Orwell again and take another look ahead. Back in 1948, the story goes, George Orwell hit on 1984 by mistyping the final digits of the date. That put his cautionary tale 36 years into the future. Taking the same span as a runway for projection, we might venture a guess about the state of audio Anno Domini 2020.

title: Mother on Court
description: Twelve-year-old Robert Peterson and his 16-year-old sister, Janet , are having the rare experience of yelling, ''Way to go, Mom!'' at Nazareth College basketball games. Their mother, Regina , 40, is a member of the team, squeezing her athletic activity into a schedule that includes nursing courses at the Kalamazoo, Mich., college four days a week, a weekend shift in a pediatric clinic and caring for her family. ''Basketball has provided an added dimension to my life, and I feel good physically and mentally about it,'' Mrs. Peterson said, explaining that athletic opportunities for women were limited during her high school and college years.

title: A GAGGLE OF HANDMADE DECOYS ARE LURING COLLECTORS
description: Decoys, once a clever device employed by hunters to lure birds, have achieved the stature of floatable sculptures. Collectors of what is now regarded as an American folk art are somewhat divided, however. There is the decoy collector, often a hunter himself, who focuses on works in pristine condition and those by name carvers; and there is the folk-art collector who concentrates on the esthetics, a weathered appearance notwithstanding, and who, in fact, insists on what is called pedigree in a decoy's original paint.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: U.S. Steel's chairman , David Roderick, shook the steel industry, announcing plans to shut down one-fifth of the company's steel-making capacity. The retrenchment will result in a $650 million after-tax writeoff, the loss of 15,430 jobs and a reduction in the company's annual steel capacity, to 26 million tons from 31.3 million. The move by the nation's largest steel company is part of a continuing effort to bring its break-even point down to 50 percent, and analysts said the writeoff could give the company a $900 million loss for 1983. U.S. Steel also broke off talks with the British Steel Company over a joint venture to import raw British slab steel and finish it at a modernized plant in Fairless, Pa. The retrenchment was welcome news on Wall Street - U.S. Steel stock rose on the day of the announcement - but grim news for the steelworkers' union, which had seen its membership fall from 1.4 million in 1979 to less than 700,000 currently.

title: OFFSHORE RACERS EXPAND SLATE FOR 1984
description: Offshore powerboat racing enters 1984 alive and well and with an expanded 11-race schedule. This was not the case a year ago when the sport was thrown into a crisis after three race sponsors withdrew, threatening to curtail the national circuit, which then numbered 10 races.

title: COMPARING THE MERITS OF THREE VCR'S
description: On the heels of a recent column outlining the broader criteria for selecting a VCR, let's leap from the general to the specific and take a closer look at three current models in different price brackets.

title: A DISPUTE OVER BROKERED FUNDS
description: ON Oct. 19, Merrill Lynch began offering some of its customers the latest twist on money market funds: Government insurance on their accounts. By last week, Merrill had attracted some $216 million. ''It's the fastest-growing money fund account we've ever introduced,'' said Michael O. Sanderson, head of Merrill's Cash Management Group.

title: THE LASTING POWER OF THE POLITICAL NOVEL
description: SOMEONE said the other day that the American novel was, of course, not political: By comparison with the European novel, say Zola and the Russians, our home product was primarily domestic, unconcerned with public affairs. It was a surprise to me to learn that this strange notion was taken for granted - a truism - by common opinion; to me it was a new idea. At once a contrary list sprang into my mind, ''The Bostonians'' and ''The Princess Casamassima'' lining up with Henry Adams's ''Democracy''; behind them Mary McCarthy, the novelist and essayist, most recently published ''Ideas and the Novel.'' marched ''Uncle Tom's Cabin'' (''did much to hasten the American Civil War'' - Oxford Companion to English Literature) and ''The Blithedale Romance,'' Hawthorne's satire on the Brook Farm experiment in communal living; ahead were Dos Passos' ''U.S.A.,'' ''For Whom the Bell Tolls,'' right up to Norman Mailer's ''Why Are We in Vietnam?''

title: HE MAY BE NO CHARMER, BUT HE IS FUNNY
description: 20As producer and a writer for the situation comedy ''Buffalo Bill,'' which has returned to NBC's schedule on Thursdays at 9 P.M., Dennis Klein has explained that with a show about a ''Buffalo, N. Y., talk-show host whom critics have called a coward, a misogynist, a self-centered creep and a raving hypocrite, I have at last found a television hero I feel is real.'' Whatever might be argued about the show's reality quotient, it must be admitted that its comedic ambitions are unusually fresh. On top of this, its lead character, Bill Bittinger, is one of the oddest and most hilarious creations that television has concocted in recent years. He is the perfect yin-yang object. You can love him and hate him, most of the time simultaneously. He is not the lovable bigot that Carroll O'Connor's Archie Bunker turned into an art form. He is more the irresistible rat. Making things more complicated, he is played at a virtually perfect paranoidal-murderous pitch by Dabney Coleman.

title: YOUNG CELLISTS EXCEL IN VARIED REPERTORY
description: Over the last three or four years, Yo-Yo Ma has been exploring the peaks of the cello repertory in a quickly growing series of LPs. Those disks, in turn, have helped establish him not only as one of the finest cellists of his generation, but as one of the most promising young instrumentalists before the public today. At 28, Mr. Ma is highly regarded for an ideal combination of qualities - namely, his glowing, warm tone, his extraordinary fingerboard facility and his careful attention to stylistic detail. And with the exception of an ill-advised recital of Kreisler and Paganini transcriptions, released last year, each of his disks has proven more rewarding than the last.

title: FOR HIM, MUSIC IS HIS OWN COMPENSATION
description: Leon Kirchner, 65 years old this month, is a large, rumpled, soft-spoken man who gives the impression of having just lost his way. Not a prolific composer, he is generally late with deadlines. In fact, he is probably the epitome of what the non-musician thinks of as the serious composer. Self-denigrating and grandiose at the same time, poetic, moody and emotional, his conversations avoid references to technical aspects of music theory and are peppered instead with allusions to Flaubert, Balzac, Artaud and Brahms. Still, however audibly he sighs, however pained or bumbling he may appear to be, Mr. Kirchner has moved steadily upwards in his career throughout his adult life. As a composer he has always been his own man; using an advanced 20th-century vocabulary, he has managed to make music that is both lyrical and rhapsodic, a feat that sets him apart from the rest.

title: 2 SPIES JAILED IN SOUTH AFRICA

description: Paul Theroux's essay brings to mind my own athletic rites of passage - bombardment.

title: MAJOR NEW LAWS TAKE EFFECT IN STATE
description: For the drunken driver, 1984 means new laws to get him off the road and make highways safer for New Yorkers. To the artist, the new year means veto powers over the display of his works in public places. And for the consumer, Jan. 1 brings more protections and regulations. Following are some of the major new laws that take effect Sunday.

description: From the uncertainty of football unemployment to the status of most valuable player in a Super Bowl game, Jim Plunkett has long understood the realities of his game. ''If I don't play well, I'll get replaced,'' he said. ''That's what it boils down to.''

title: HEADLINERS Omega Man?The Federal Government might not strenuously object to Omega 7's war against the Castro regime if the terrorist group fought its battles in the streets of Havana instead of those of New York City and Miami. A man said to be the Cuban exile group's leader,
description: Eduardo Arocena , was indicted last week on charges of attempting to murder Cuba's chief representative to the United Nations, and conspiring to bomb the Cuban U.N. Mission, Avery Fisher Hall and several Latin American consulates in Miami. Authorities said other crimes attributed to the group were still under investigation. Mr. Arocena, whose lawyer described him as ''a proud, honest freedom fighter,'' could get life in prison.

title:
ANTIQUES;
OFF THE BEATEN TRACK TO LAFAYETTE
description: LAFAYETTE THE Lafayette Mill Antiques Center in this Sussex County community has the positive and winning attributes of a quality country show placed on permanent exhibition.

title:
STAMPS;
FIRST 1984 ISSUE MARKS ALASKA'S ANNIVERSARY
description: The first issue of this new year from the United States is a 20-cent commemorative to mark the 25th anniversary of Alaska's statehood. It is being put out Tuesday in Fairbanks, Alaska.

description: PHOTOGRAPHY

description: Le Bourgogne fait penser a des b^etises.

title: Soviet Press Says Iran Is Ruled by Fanatics
description: The Soviet press said today that the rulers of Iran were influenced by blind fanaticism and warned the Iranians to halt what it called a growing anti-Soviet campaign.

title: NAKASONE GETS WINNING CARDS
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone seemed to be in trouble two weeks ago when the Japanese electorate wiped out the majority that his Liberal Democratic Party had enjoyed in the House of Representative since 1955. But backroom bargaining last week helped to turn a minority into a majority again and to insure Mr. Nakasone's re-election by the House.

title: BEARS END TURBULENT SEASON
description: -- The 1983 season was not among the most successful in the history of the Chicago Bears, but it certainly was one of the more tumultuous.

title: TRAFFIC OFFICIALS WARY ON BRIDGE PROJECT
description: ADDITIONAL repairs on the Mianus River Bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike in Greenwich are scheduled to begin Thursday, and officials in the county and in Connecticut say they are preparing for the worst while hoping for the best.

title: Kenya
description: To the Editor:

title: CHANGING THE GUARD
description: At the beginning of the fourth year of any Administration, strange things happen here, particularly to Republicans. They begin to long for home, which in the Reagan Cabinet and White House staff usually means California.

title:
GARDENING;
A CONSERVATION GOAL FOR THE NEW YEAR
description: LAST year was not a terribly kind one to the gardener and his garden. A wet spring made getting on with the gardening chores difficult. Six consecutive weekends in May and June were washouts. The wet weather set the stage for such problems as the continued spread of dogwood and anthracnose, that dread fungus disease that is decimating our flowering dogwoods. It also favored mildew at the expense of the rose.

title: DANCE: MUNA TSENG IN 1942 'MEDUSA'
description: There were a few moments when ''Four Way Split'' came to crackling life Thursday at the Theater of the Open Eye. They occurred in Muna Tseng's crisply intense performance of ''The Transformations of Medusa,'' one of seven dances in the second of the theater's two holiday dance programs.

title: HEADLINERS Crash SurvivorsWe were just going to sit there and survive as long as we could,''
description: Tony Mink said. ''And then we were going to be dead.'' Mr. Mink and his 14-year-old son Brian were rescued last week after surviving in sub-zero temperatures for five days in the cockpit of their single-engine plane, which crashed in the mountains of northern New Mexico.

title: CLARK FACES PRESSURE TO UNDO WATT'S PARK POLICIES
description: In the first policy move of his tenure at the Interior Department, Secretary William P. Clark confirmed reports last week that he would end the Reagan Administration's moratorium on buying land for national parks. The freeze adopted by his predecessor, James G. Watt, had been one of the great sore points between the Administration and conservationists, despite Mr. Watt's efforts to improve existing park property.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: BAYSIDE
description: JOE Friscia has vivid recollections of

title: France
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER RATES
SO THAT YEAR IS HEAR
description: THIS new year, 1984, the year of my 40th birthday, has quite suddenly arrived. Startled by the numbers and facts, I recall reading George Orwell ages ago with incredulity and anticipation. At that time, it was also difficult to believe that in the year of the title, I would be an ''older woman of 40.''

title: COMPANY'S NEW VENTURE
description: SINCE last January, the Southern New England Telephone Company has spent millions of dollars in advertising and hiring professional consultants to enter new businesses in the communications field.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ZURICH
description: Skiing enthusiasts have long been flying to Zurich at this time of year because of the celebrated Alpine slopes and resorts nearby. However, Switzerland's biggest city is now a winter attraction in itself because of its lively cultural season.

title: IOWA TOWN CONTEMPLATES PITFALLS OF BEING MEDITATORS' UTOPIA
description: Several thousand followers of the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi have followed him here in recent days to meditate and emit positive unity force fields to cut the world's crime rate, reduce traffic accidents, raise the stock market and generally ease global tensions.

title: ELECTRIFICATION PROJECT NEARS COMPLETION ON HARLEM LINE
description: BREWSTER METRO MAN has been visiting schools talking to the students about it. People driving on the Saw Mill River Parkway have been watching it. A dozen villages along the route have seen it change the local scenery. Commuters have seen it happening out their windows. It's the electrification of the railroad, from North White Plains to this Putnam County village. And now, after more than two years, the time for it all to be over is getting close.

THE GROWING POWER OF THE PACIFIC BASIN;
THE FUTURE OF AMERICAN TRADE
description: FOR the United States, the Pacific

title: ENCHANTED EVENINGS
description: WE don't spend New Year's Eves together any more. Some of us have moved, some have died and some go away on vacation now, avoiding the trauma of celebrating the rapidly diminishing years.

title: THE WHYS OF REMAKES AND THE HOWS OF ONE
description: L ess than a decade ago, Hollywood directors, hellbent on debunking movie conventions, demystified every genre from horrors to Westerns. In films such as Mel Brooks's ''Young Frankenstein'' and Howard Zieff's ''Hearts of the West,'' movie mystiques were dissected, mocked and analyzed in Hollywood's version of Oedipal revolt. Now, the mystique seems to be back - and so are new versions of old classics or personal favorites that have tickled contemporary directors' fancy. Among Hollywood's Christmas offerings, three - ''The Man Who Loved Women,'' ''Scarface'' and ''To Be or Not To Be'' - are remakes of earlier movies, and they're only the swell of a wave that has already included ''Breathless'' last year, and that promises to crest in the coming weeks with ''Unfaithfully Yours,'' ''Against All Odds'' (''Out of the Past,'' updated), ''Where the Boys Are,'' ''Crackers'' (''Big Deal on Madonna Street'' redux) and, soon, ''The Razor's Edge.''

description: AS Wall Street moves into 1984 on the wave of a

title: '84 OUTLOOK: A REAWAKENING ABROAD
description: THE recovery in the United States has spurred a

title: Taylor Has Signed Pact With Generals
description: A source in the New Jersey Generals said yesterday that Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' all-pro linebacker, had signed a contract, to take effect in 1988, with the United States Football League team.

title: IS MIME MOVING CLOSER TO DANCE?
description: Mime has emerged as a major and creative art form in America in the last 10 years and not everybody has noticed. In part, this is because the practitioners of mime have always had trouble defining the art itself. Certainly, the affinity between mime and dance performances has been one of long standing. Today, the young North Americans that go under the label of new mime have usually studied some form of dance. Moreover, dance critics, accustomed to nonverbal theater, have been more open to reviewing mime than drama critics. In New York, it is a dance organization - Dance Theater Workshop - that has taken the lead in presenting the new mimes, who include Bill Irwin, Bob Berky, Daniel Stein, Thomas Leabhart and the United Mime Workers. Even the National Endowment for the Arts, until now, has funded mime artists and projects under its dance program.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN MY friend Mike was complaining about the problems in finding a nursery school in Greenwich Village for his daughter, Moorea. She is named for the island off Tahiti, for reasons too delicate to dwell on.

title: THE DON, THE DOCTOR AND THE DUKE
description: MAD HATTER SUMMER By Donald Thomas. 310 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $16.95 THE PRIVATE LIFE OF DR. WATSON By Michael Hardwick. 298 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $13.95. EXIT LADY MASHAM By Louis Auchincloss. 169 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $13.95.

description: Diane McWhorter is a Boston-based journalist and critic. THE WORDS TO SAY IT An Autobiographical Novel. By Marie Cardinal. Translated by Pat Goodheart. Preface and Afterword by Bruno Bettelheim. 308 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: VanVactor & Goodheart. $16.50.

title: Auburn Star Can Pick His Sport
description: As the first bus pulled out of the station in Auburn, Ala., in the fall of 1982 on its way to the town of Bessemer, some two and a half hours away, Vincent (Bo) Jackson sat alone and watched it pass, wondering why he was not aboard.

The new family in town discovers the horrors that lie in a neighboring cemetery. 3328 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 4418

title: U.S. TRAINING IS UNDER WAY FOR WINTER OLYMPIC SPORTS
description: Though the Winter Olympics will begin in 37 days in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, the trials to pick the United States athletes to compete there are only beginning. In five of the eight Winter Olympic disciplines, trials have started or are about to start in Lake Placid, N.Y.; Steamboat Springs, Colo., and West Allis, Wis.

description: A BOOK OF RIDDLES By Monika Beisner. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. (Ages 6 and Up)

title: NEW YORK FARMERS MAY GET TAX CUT IN '84
description: New, lower values for agricultural land were proposed this week by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment. If the lower figures are adopted, they could result in a substantial 1984 drop in property taxes paid by many upstate and Long Island farmers.

title: HOPES FOR 1984: AN L.I. SAMPLER
description: THE LONG ISLAND WEEKLY asked a number of prominent Long Island residents what improvements they would like to see in the quality of life on the Island in the new year and beyond. Here are their replies: Walter B. Kissinger

title: Movable Waste Burner Cleared for Use in U.S.
description: A mobile incinerator designed to burn the nation's most toxic wastes has been given the final go-ahead to be used this spring, Federal officials said.

title: SYRIANS TAKE JACKSON T SEE CAPTURED U.S. FLIER
description: Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr., the United States Navy flier being held captive here, met today with the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, the Democratic presidential aspirant. Mr. Jackson arrived Friday on what he said was an humanitarian mission to gain the flier's release.

title: NEW COMPLICATIONS IN AGENT ORANGE TRIAL
description: Seeming almost as convoluted as the Vietnam war itself, a landmark lawsuit by Vietnam veterans against makers of the herbicide Agent Orange has survived more than five years of legal battles to face a jury trial set to begin May 7.

title: WHAT'S PROPER IN POLICING THE JUDICIARY?
description: Like Abscam before it, Operation Greylord, the undercover investigation of the Cook County Circuit Court, has sparked debate over what is appropriate in the investigation of suspected corruption. It has also focused attention on local disciplinary boards that are supposed to police the judiciary in all 50 states and the District of Columbia.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE LAST JEWS IN BERLIN, by Leonard Gross. (Bantam, $3.95.)

title: MOBILE CLASSROOM WITH 22 COMPUTERS TOURS THE COUNTRY
description: THE converted touring bus parked behind the Ardsley High School does not bring students to learn in the school. It brings students out of the school to learn on the bus.

description: -24, and

title: EXTREMITIES Urban Alarms
description: Six desperately depressed New Jersey cities needed $5 million in emergency aid for public safety while the Legislature offered an unrestricted $14 million for 334 municipalities, most of them well-off suburbs. Governor Kean tried to mediate and invited the neediest mayors to join him and legislative leaders to resolve the dispute.

title: DANGER IS ROUTINE FOR SCUBA TEAM
description: THEY risk their lives on rescues in freezing water, or diving into dark, polluted places that no one else would even put a toe into. Their expensive equipment can be destroyed on a mission, and they are not reimbursed for it or for any other expenses.

title: THE STRUGGLES OF A CELL SCIENTIST
description: BLACK APOLLO OF SCIENCE The Life of Ernest Everett Just. By Kenneth R. Manning. Illustrated. 397 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95.

title: Animal Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: BEST HAND OF 1983
description: Depending on how you count, the number of deals played in major tournaments around the world each year is somewhere between five and 10 million. Many of these feature brilliant play, so the task of selecting the best of them is formidable - eased somewhat by the fact that many brilliancies are unreported, wasting their sweetness on the desert air.

title: Elephants Kill 10 in India
description: Wild elephants trampling through tea gardens and villages have killed at least 10 people in the past month in Assam State in northeast India, local officials said today.

title: Polish President Urges National Reconciliation
description: President Henryk Jablonski appealed today for national reconciliation in Poland as an amnesty for political dissidents and underground Solidarity activists expired.

title: MameKennedy, Victor Schrager To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Preston Kennedy of Cincinnati have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Ellen Kennedy, to Victor Alexis Schrager, son of Anne Connolly Schrager of New York and Rensselaerville, N.Y., and the late Victor Leland Schrager of London.

title: PRISONER OF CONSCIENCE
description: -1859. By Joseph Frank. Illustrated. 320 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $25.

title: Lisa Christenson To Be the Bride Of Anton Barth
description: Dr. and Mrs. William Christenson of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Ann Newcome Christenson, to Anton Barth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lothar Barth of Stellenbosch, South Africa.

title: CUOMO AS LEADER: DO ACTIONS FOLLOW WORDS?
description: GOVERNOR CUOMO sent his pollsters out this fall to take the public's pulse. When they asked 1,000 New Yorkers how they viewed his on-the- job performance, 67 percent responded favorably. Then they asked how they viewed Mr. Cuomo as ''a person and a leader,'' and 85 percent replied favorably. ''That was the first time,'' said Mr. Cuomo's counselor, Timothy J. Russert, ''I became attuned that the public rates his performance as Governor separate and apart from 'how do you rate him as a leader?' ''

title: Headliners Fit to Fly
description: An airline pilot who has flown competently for 12 years doesn't lose that ability simply because of a sex change operation, a Federal district judge ruled in Chicago last week. Judge John F. Grady said that Eastern Airlines would not have firedKaren F. Ulane in 1980 if she had remained Kenneth Ulane, who had flown for Eastern since 1968.

title: THE REGION
description: City GettingJail Space atBrooklyn BrigNew York City acted to ease the housing shortage for one segment of the population last week. The Board of Estimate approved a $277 million plan to provide additional space in city jails for nearly 4,000 inmates during the next five years.

title: 'A BITTER YEAR' ENDS BITTERLY IN LEBANON
description: While Washington debated the past and future of the Marine Corps contingent in Lebanon last week, the peacekeeping force still found little peace to keep. It watched the Lebanese Army exchange fire with Shiite Moslem and Druse fighters, listened to bombs go off in shops in Christian East Beirut and heard President Amin Gemayel lament that ''1983 was a bitter, difficult year.''

title: DARK SIDE OF JOB ENDS ON BRIGHT NOTE
description: ''I'M STUCK in a chimney somewhere and unable to answer

title: Barbara Hasselman Marries
description: Barbara M. Hasselman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis D. Hasselman of Bridgeport, Conn., was married there yesterday to Charles B. Ward, son of Rose Warhaftig of Irvington, N.J., and the late Harry L. Warhaftig.

title: St. Louis Paper's Staff To Vote on Pay Cuts
description: The staff of The St. Louis Globe-Democrat has been asked to agree tentatively to pay cuts that the new publisher says he needs for the newspaper to survive.

title: A CLUBHOUSE OUTSIDER WITH SURPRISING POLITICAL SAVVY
description: RATHER than climb rung by rung up the party organization, Mario Cuomo came to political prominence under the sponsorship of one man, Hugh L. Carey. Still, there is general agreement, even among Mr. Cuomo's political foes, that in his first year he has been a better politician than his predecessor, or for that matter than any Democratic Governor of New York since Franklin Roosevelt. ''I have to give him high marks, much more than could have been expected,'' said David Garth, the media consultant on two of Mayor Koch's campaigns against Mr. Cuomo, with a .500 batting average.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ATTACKS ANGOLA
description: South Africa called it a pre-emptive strike aimed at defusing an offensive planned by Angolan-based guerrillas; the Organization of African Unity expressed ''horror'' at reports that it included the ''wanton killing of women and children.'' Whatever it was, South African military authorities announced last week that it had been going on since Dec. 6, when troops and fighter planes from South Africa began attacking positions in Angola.

title: Big Brother's War
description: In a fitting inaugural for Orwell's year, Kabul Radio announced last Sunday that 100,000 Afghans were demonstrating against the invasion - of Grenada. If so, doublethink really reigns in the capital trampled by Soviet legions four years ago. The pretext, you may recall, was a plagiary from Orwell: an ''invitation'' from a Communist chieftain who was murdered as the invasion began.

title: TRYING TO QUIT TV
description: CONCERNED with television's influence on children and family life, residents in Farmington today will embark on a monthlong campaign to cut down on television viewing.

title: NEW LOOK FOR CAMDEN
description: CAMDEN THE prostitutes were working the corner of Auburn Street and Broadway again, so Lois Teer leashed up her dog, Pearce, and marched out of her brick town house.

title: SAMPLING THE VARIED WORLDS OF JAMAICA
description: What's a dedicated traveler to do about the Caribbean? The restless breed of vacationer who needs more than a beach, a bar and a book - the one who likes to move around, change scenes, discover things and kibbitz with strangers - hears boredom and claustrophobia alarms ringing in the names of little islands. Give us sun and sea, of course, but also give us space and choice, a few open roads and a couple of general stores that don't stock suntan oil, postcards or pastel T-shirts.

title: No Headline
description: ORANGE BOWL

title: BELL SYSTEM BREAKUP OPENS ERA OF GREAT EXPECTATIONS AND GREAT CONCERN
description: A new era for American telecommunications and for American business begins today as the once-unified Bell System begins life as eight separate companies. It is a time of great expectations and great concern for both the telephone industry and the nation as a whole.

title: Sara Lynn Pearl Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Sara Lynn Pearl to Arthur H. Amron has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Pearl of Skokie, Ill., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Amron of New York and New Milford, Conn.

title: S.E.C. INVESTIGATES OFFICIAL'S FRIENDS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is examining whether friends of Paul Thayer, the Deputy Secretary of Defense, purchased stock in Campbell Taggart Inc. of Dallas on the basis of privileged ''insider'' information, according to Government officials.

title: Rebecca Wentz To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Wentz of Forty Fort, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Davis Wentz, to William Howard Wood, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Frank Wood of Buck Hill Falls, Pa., formerly of New York. The wedding is planned for May.

title: CORPORATE WORLD IS HIRING MORE WOMEN AS PILOTS
description: Patricia Dennehy says that when she visits the pilots' lounges in out-of- town airports these days, she sees more and more female pilots relaxing there. ''Not long ago,'' she said, ''a woman who walked through these lounges was thought of as a lost passenger.''

title: THERE REALLY IS A WORLD BEYOND 'DIAPER DRAMA'
description: Afew weeks ago I was mildly deploring American dramatists' apparent inability to pull open the shutters and look out into the big world beyond the emotional hothouse within whose clammy confines they and their work would seem to have become terminally trapped. But the theater has not stood still since then, and neither has my mailman. It may already be time to update the argument.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'BEDROCK' AT HARTMAN

title: HE HAD GENIUS FOR THE THEATER-AND FOR SELF-DESTRUCTION
description: Very early in his career as a theatrical producer and director, Jed Harris had earned a reputation as a wunderkind - a 28-year-old who turned out four consecutive Broadway hits in the space of 18 months, among them ''The Royal Family'' and ''The Front Page.'' Just as quickly, he became a controversial figure whose reputation for ruthless and eccentric behavior followed him to the grave. The following article has been adapted from a new biography, ''Jed Harris: The Curse of Genius,'' to be published this month by Little, Brown and Company. Del Hughes had gone from stage managing for Jed Harris to a similar job with Kermit Bloomgarden, a young producer who was earning a reputation for doing important plays. Hughes was on West 45th Street when Bloomgarden hailed him from beneath the marquee of the Morosco Theater. Hughes crossed over and said hello to the producer and the tall, skinny, bespectacled young man with him. It was the playwright Arthur Miller. Hughes had stage managed his ''Death of a Salesman.'' Tennessee Williams and Arthur Miller were then the reigning kings of the American stage. Williams's ''The Rose Tattoo'' was a success of the current season. The New York theater now impatiently awaited Miller's next work. ''We're thinking of hiring Jed Harris to direct Arthur's new play,'' Bloomgarden said to Hughes. ''You worked for him. What do you think of the idea?''

title: Nora Joffe Plans September Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Joffe of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nora Joffe, to Harold David Elish, son of Herbert Elish of Brooklyn and Leslie Elish of Manhattan. The wedding is planned for September.

title: American Labor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bowl Game Amid the Ruins of War
description: THE first, and I hope the last,

title: A Historian of Ideas
description: ''The Idea of Poverty'' is the latest in a series of books that have made Gertrude Himmelfarb one of the most widely discussed historians of ideas in present-day America. She established her reputation in 1952 with a study of the great liberal historian Lord Acton, at a time when he had fallen into neglect, and followed it up with two books displaying major Victorian thinkers in a new social and biographical light - ''Darwin and the Darwinian Revolution'' and ''On Liberty and Liberalism: The Case of John Stuart Mill.''

title: HAS THE FLIGHT OF THE NETWORKS' AUDIENCE HALTED?
description: Afrequent point of discussion among people in the television industry is just how much damage cable television will wreak on the three broadcast networks. While everyone agrees that the networks' share of the nation's viewers has and will decline as more people get cable television, there is still considerable conjecture as to the extent of audience drain the networks have to look forward to.

title: IF YOU HAD YOUR FONDEST WISHES FOR THE ARTS
description: With the arrival of the new year, The New York Times asked a number of prominent citizens and leaders in the arts what they might wish - if all their wishes could come true - to happen in their particular art, or the world of the arts in general during 1984. Here are some of their replies: Edward I, Koch, Mayor, New York City: ''What I would really like to see is a greater appreciation for the display of art in our parks and public places, free of vandalism and graffiti.'' James Levine, music director and principal conductor of the Metropolitan Opera: ''I wish we could change our need to make detailed and complete plans five years in advance. While working so far ahead helps insure the presence at the Met of as many great artists as possible, it also forestalls our ability to use our artistic imagination spontaneously, to engage an artist who bursts suddenly on the scene, or to revive a work that turns out to be more popular than we expected. Opera is the victim of its own success and artists are in demand as never before. It would be so great to have the luxury to rework next year's plans, or even next month's if we wished. Right now, my head is in 1988. This is crazy!'' James Rosenquist, painter: ''Few people recognize what artists happen to do for others. The artist provides a mental garden for people to think, live, work and invent in.

title: Barn Falls, Killing 400 Sheep
description: About 400 sheep at Rhode Island's largest sheep farm were killed early Thursday when 45-mile-an-hour winds blew the roof off a barn, the police said.

title: Benefactions
description: To the Editor:

title: AND USED AGAINST YOU
description: In the matter of the secret taping of telephone calls by United States Information Agency director Charles Wick:

title: Death-Seeking Paralytic Declines an Offer to Help
description: Elizabeth Bouvia has rejected an offer to starve to death in the home of a festival producer.

title: POLICE PALAZZO
description: The old First Precinct station house - a designated landmark designed in 1909 by the architectural concern of Hunt and Hunt as a New York version of an early Renaissance Florentine palazzo - is undergoing a major restoration and will soon become a commercial property. The cost is conservatively put at $2 million by Old Slip Associates, an affiliate of the Androse Corporation.

title: THE DANCE: THOMPSON AND TROUPE
description: ''I didn't know Staten Island had dance this good,'' someone said as the audience cheered at the close of a performance by the Clive Thompson DanceCompany on Friday at Alice Tully Hall, when Lincoln Center's Community Holiday Festival brought the two-year-old company to Manhattan in a salute to the troupe's home borough.

title: Julianne Hanavan To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Taylor W. Hanavan of Wilmington, Del., and Northfield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julianne Hanavan, to Kevin Patrick O'Brien, son of Mrs. Joseph D. O'Brien of Norwell, Mass., and the late Dr. O'Brien.

title: POSTINGS ; DOCTORS' SPECIAL
description: The Progress Development Corporation has broken ground for ''Medical 55,'' a six-story condominium designed and built for physicians and dentists, at 152 East 55th Street.

title: IN THE PINKISH
description: The look of the University Club, at 1 West 54th Street, was prized from its creation in 1899, even before the appearances of other good buildings from that era that have since been razed to make way for skycrapers. Its aesthetics resulted from a turn-of-the-century fascination with Italian Renaissance architecture in general and Florence's Strozzi Palace in particular, filtered through the sensibilities of the renowned firm of McKim, Mead & White.

title: THE WHYS OF REMAKES AND THE HOWS OF ONE
description: P art One - The Meetings: ''The Nazi Follies of 1939''? No. ''Greasepaint and Swastikas''? Terrible. ''Polish Hams''? Uh-uh, forget it, no Polish jokes. ''However much we change it,' I suggest, ''we should remain faithful to the spirit and the style of the original.'' ''I've got it,'' cries Mel Brooks, ''we'll call it 'To Be or Not To Be.' ''

description: The Big Push to Save

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: ON Jan. 10, Leanna Brown will be sworn in as New Jersey's first Republican woman State Senator in 200 years.

title: Future Events
description: New Year Views.

title: SALVADOR TERROR REPORTED CURBED
description: State Department officials said today that El Salvador appeared to be carrying out its pledge to curb the activities of death squads. As a result, they said, the Administration intends to live up to its pledge to the Salvadorans to ask Congress for a substantial increase in assistance.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: WRITERS, REFORMERS AND PAUPERS
description: THE IDEA OF POVERTY England in the Early Industrial Age. By Gertrude Himmelfarb. Illustrated. 595 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: CAN UNCLE SAM BE BIG BROTHER?
description: IN HIS novel ''1984,'' George Orwell described a totalitarian

title: REAGAN EXPECTED TO PRESENT PLAN TO FIGHT CRIME IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: President Reagan plans to announce a new program soon to fight school crime and violence, including trying to limit the legal rights of children facing suspension from school.

title: THE NONDISCLOSURE CLAUSE
description: SAN FRANCISCO THE most deceiving development in pro football now does

title: LIONS' MURRAY KNEW KICK WOULD MISS
description: When the ball boomed high toward the goalposts on Eddie Murray's 43-yard field-goal attempt, several members of the Detroit Lions leaped into the air at the sideline, thinking they had erased the San Francisco 49ers' 24-23 lead with 5 seconds remaining in today's National Conference playoff game. But out on the field, Murray knew better.

title: WANTED: AN OVERLORD FOR THE UNDERGROUND
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is running behind schedule in its effort to name someone to run New York City's subways and buses. To some, including Robert R. Kiley, the new M.T.A. chairman, the delay just reflects the difficulty of finding the proper person. To others - including one candidate who apparently rejected the job - the holdup reveals as much about the transit system's condition as graffiti-lined subway cars or derailed trains.

title: NEW YEAR'S WAS INVENTORY TIME
description: ON some British islands New Year's Day is known as ''recovery day,'' an aptly named holiday designed to give people time to get into reasonably sober shape before going back to work.

title: NEW TECHNOLOGY DOES NOT TEACH
description: WELL, they are at it again. After a ''year of study,'' a Joint Committee on Educational Technology last fall reported to the State Board of Education and the Board of Governors for the universities and colleges.

title: THE NATION
description: One thing about being a legal aid lawyer under the Reagan Administration: There's plenty of experience to be had litigating against Washington. Attorneys representing nearly a dozen legal aid branch offices are due in a Washington courtroom this week to ask for an injunction against what they say is the Reagan White House's latest shot.

title: EDGEMONT TEACHERS LEARNING JAPANESE
description: RON DROPKIN, a fifth-grade teacher at the Greenville School in the Edgemont District of Scarsdale, cannot claim fluency in Japanese. But he is able to greet his Japanese students with at least a ''Good morning'' or ''How are you today?'' in their own language.

title: The Male Myth
description: It is good to see that men are questioning traditional gender stereotypes and the severe restrictions they imply (''The Male Myth,'' by Paul Theroux, About Men, Nov. 27). If we can bring our society to the point where each person is accepted as a unique individual with particular talents, then gender identification will become simply part of the growth process and not a factor that is emphasized to the point of unhealthy obsession. NANCY DUBOIS New York City

title: Business Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: O'ROURKE OUTLINES GOALS FOR 1984
description: ONE year ago, when Andrew P. O'Rourke was sworn in as the first Republican County Executive in nearly a decade, he promised that he would run a ''reasonable, responsible, compassionate and efficient government,'' pledging also ''not to build Ozymandian monuments,'' a reference, from a poem by Shelley, to the vanity and futility of a tyrant's power.

title: POST FAMILY FINANCES SUPPERS FOR THE NEEDY
description: About 75 needy people are to be given supper six nights a week at a center that is to open Thursday in the Bedford- Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: KEAN TO MEET WITH LEGISLATORS ON URBAN AID
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN is scheduled to meet Tuesday with legislative leaders to discuss some way to break their deadlock over a special urban aid bill designed to prevent layoffs of police officers and firefighters.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: What promises to be one of the most unusual - and upbeat - dance events of the new year will occur on Saturday, when some 35 dancers, choreographers, dance companies and composers take part in a benefit for Carey Erickson at St. Mark's Church, Second Avenue and 10th Street. Mr. Erickson has performed with a number of New York-based modern-dance companies and was a Warner Communications Choreographic Fellow at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in 1982. He was injured last August in a swimming accident that left him paralyzed, with a severe spinal cord injury.

title: ATLANTA ORDERS NEW WORKS
description: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra has announced the creation of an American Music Project designed specifically to allow Atlanta audiences the opportunity to become familiar with music by American composers. Sponsored by a $200,000 grant from Mr. and Mrs. M.G. Woodward, both Atlanta Symphony board members, the project will commence on Feb. 2 with the world premiere of a composition for jazz trio, mixed chorus and orchestra by Billy Taylor. Entitled ''Peaceful Warrior,'' this new work was inspired by the late Dr. Martin Luther King.

title: IN MOSCOW, MORE QUESTIONS THAN ANSWERS
description: For anyone trying to penetrate the obscurities of the Kremlin, two occasions each year offer a harvest of clues. But the winter meetings of the Communist Party's Central Committee and the Supreme Soviet last week offered little more than further mystery about the state of health of Yuri V. Andropov.

title: EFFORT UNDER WAY TO RESCUE CANDLEWOOD LAKE
description: TO combat the severe weed problem choking Connecticut's largest lake, Northeast Utilities in early November began lowering the water level at Lake Candlewood in Sherman. The utility wants to draw down the water level six feet, which, officials hope, would kill the exposed weeds.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've got a pretty good-sized room. I've got my own bed.

title: Out of the Market
description: Manager Chuck Tanner of Pittsburgh said the Pirates had dropped out of the bidding for Rich (Goose) Gossage .

title: THE RETURN OF ENCHANTMENT
description: I read Kathleen Agena's bold overview of world cultural history and the contemporary drama with a thought- cloud over my head, rapidly filling with astonished question marks. Can gnomes and Filippo Berio and ''Ancient Evenings'' and neo-expressionism really be parts of any single ''phenomenon''? Are the novels of John Irving really ''allegorical'' in some way that Dostoevski's and Melville's are not? Isn't Superman (like Flash Gordon and Conan the Barbarian) a myth of the 1930's? What trend did he echo back then?

title: CLASS REUNION: MILESTONE OF ADULTHOOD
description: THERE is no known cure for a deflated high school spirit. It is a degenerative condition that persists beyond high school. I found that out recently when symptoms I hadn't known for 10 years recurred after an invitation came by mail for my high school reunion: facial tiks, sweaty palms, rapid breathing. All these years, I suddenly realized, I had only been in remission.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TRAIN TALK An Illustrated Guide to Lights, Hand Signals, Whistles, and Other Languages of Railroading. By Roger Yepsen. Illustrated. 85 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $9.95. (Ages 8 to 11) THE RAILROAD BOOK Written and illustrated by E. Boyd Smith. 55 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $12.95. (Ages 6 to 10)

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: -TWO acres of land at Liberty State Park in Jersey City have been chosen from among 100 possible sites for a $40 million science and technology center that is expected, its sponsors say, to rival the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia.

title: AMERICA LOOKS TO FUTURE IN HOPE, POLL FINDS
description: In sharp contrast to their gloomy mood four years earlier, Americans approach 1984 optimistically, feeling that the present is as good as the recent past and that the near future will be significantly better.

title: In the Ruff Triumphs In Display Handicap
description: Albert Davis's In The Ruff, ridden by Robbie Davis, came from behind along the rail to post a 1 3/4-length victory over Nice Pirate in the $85,950 Display Handicap, the year-end feature at Aqueduct.

title: NEW YEAR PROMISES AN EXCITING SCHEDULE OF CONCERTS
description: AS always, we enter the new year with high hopes; musically at least, we should see many of them realized. All signs point to an especially exciting cultural season, with expansion under way for a number of major county organizations and highly attractive musical plans for most of the others. In the months ahead, for example, look for the first Westchester series by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center (at the State University of New York at Purchase in February, March and April; call 253-5900 for details) and county debuts by the Gewandhaus Bach Orchestra of Leipzig (Jan. 28 in Tarrytown; 631-3455) and the celebrated Vienna Octet (March 4 in Ossining; 271-4657).

title: Arctic Air Brings On More Snow and Rain By United Press International
description: Arctic air chilled parts of the West and the South yesterday, with freezing rain in Utah and snow in North Carolina.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: SHOULD IT INSTITUTE PLAYOFF SYSTEM?
description: With No. 1 Nebraska and No. 2 Texas going into tomorrow's bowl games - the Cornhuskers facing the No. 5-ranked Miami Hurricanes in the Orange Bowl and the Longhorns hosting the No. 7 Georgia Bulldogs in the Cotton Bowl - the talk of establishing a playoff for a college football championship has been a major topic on a national level. Both Nebraska and Texas could finish the season with undefeated records.

title: GEORGE CLINTON BUILDS FUN EMPIRE
description: George Clinton is up to his old tricks again. In the late 1970's, Mr. Clinton was the kingpin of a music empire - the producer, songwriter and ringleader of more bands than anyone could keep track of. He has just released two albums on two different labels, his own ''You Shouldn't-Nuf Bit Fish'' on Capitol Records and ''Urban Dancefloor Guerrillas'' by the P-Funk All-Stars, on his Uncle Jam division of CBS Records.

title:
LEISURE;
GINGER ROOTS YIELD DOUBLE-DIVIDENDS: BEAUTIFUL PLANT PLUS FRESH FLAVOR ;
description: Bonnie Fisher specializes in growing culinary herbs.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: RUTGERS, the State University, is revamping its Institute on Aging because, university officials say, it has been functioning not like a research center - which would generate Federal funds - but like a continuing-education center for professionals.

title: 'COME BACK, LITTLE GIRL, COME BACK'
description: 6, maybe 7, years old - with long golden hair, smiling eyes and that clean, open, innocent expression that children usually lose as they get older.

title: REAGAN TIRES TO LIMIT THE DAMAGE OF LEBANON
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. PRESIDENT Reagan's decision in 1982 to deploy United States marines in Lebanon, which some aides describe as a cornerstone of the Administration's Middle East policy, was never popular politically. Last week, it became obvious that the American military establishment itself continues to harbor deep misgivings about using the marines to advance political and diplomatic objectives in the region.

description: The Presence of DiMaggio

title: A TOWN'S FIREHOUSE BECOMES A MUSEUM
description: THE town of Manchester's first firehouse, built in 1901, has now become a gathering place for firefighting enthusiasts.

title: ; ROOTS OF TERRORISM THAT ALLOW FOR MORAL DISTINCTIONS
description: To the Editor:

description: In his cautionary novel ''1984,''

title: CIVIL LIBERTIES FOR SOME
description: DIMENSIONS OF TOLERANCE What Americans Believe About Civil Liberties. By Herbert McClosky and Alida Brill. 512 pp. New York: Russell Sage Foundation/Basic Books. $29.95.

title: SELLING SUNSHINE ON LONG ISLAND
description: New York-area residents who want to move, retire or just escape to Florida will be able to learn what developers in that state are offering at a ''Florida Real Estate Showcase'' Thursday through Sunday at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I.

title: Q&A
description: Question:

title: Catherine
description: Dr. and Mrs. Murray Stewart Peyton of Pennington, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Craft Peyton, to Pvt. Steven Dale Hahn of the Army, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dale Phillip Hahn of Chesterfield, Mo. A spring wedding is planned.

title: TIDYING UP A FEW MATTERS AS '83 FADES FROM THE SCREEN
description: This morning, as we get ready to push on into the unknowns of 1984, there are some matters relating to the already dim 1983 calendar year that should be discussed before it's too late. It's a mixed bag of thoughts. I'm thinking of ''Silkwood'' (and of the film's virtues that were overlooked in sober discussions of the fictional uses of fact), of opera movies (is that a contradiction in terms?), of screen writers (God bless at least some of them), and of the world of haute couture, which is beyond mine.

title: PANEL WEIGHS PLAN TO INCLUDE MORE PEOPLE N F.B.I.'S FILE
description: An advisory group for the Federal Bureau of Investigation is considering recommending a major expansion of a national computerized file to distribute information about people who are considered suspicious but are not wanted for crimes.

description: TRENTON FEW things undermine the foundations of the American family more effectively than

title: Sally Grafstein to Marry David Blinken in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Grafstein of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Grafstein, to David Blinken, son of Alan Blinken and Jane Overman, both of New York.

title: CASINOS PUSHING FOR 1 PERCENT TAX
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE casino industry here is conducting a determined campaign to convince state legislators that it is better at arithmetic than the Kean administration.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Package Bomb

title: Miss Seltzer, a Nurse, To Be Wed to a Rabbi
description: Rabbi Laurence Alan Kotok, spirtual leader of the North Country Reform Temple in Glen Cove, L.I., and Merrill Beth Seltzer, a registered nurse at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan, plan to be married Feb. 19.

title: MISS PATTON EYES CAMPAIGN
description: ASSEMBLYWOMAN BARBARA PATTON, Long Island's first black state legislator, represents a Nassau County district with a constituency that is just about half white and half black.

title: INDIAN POINT 3 REACTOR RAN FOR ONLY 10 DAYS IN 1983
description: The Indian Point 3 reactor operated for only 10 days in 1983 because of mechanical problems, and for only 3 months in the last two years.

title: Pakistan Quake Kills 12 Along Afghan Border
description: An earthquake in the Hindu Kush mountains shook northern Pakistan today along its border with Afghanistan, and officials said at least 12 people were killed and 38 injured in the collapse of houses.

title: SALVADOR'S LOSSES HIGH IN REBEL ATTACK
description: Military authorities said today that two Salvadoran officers were killed and dozens of soldiers slain or captured in a guerrilla attack Friday on an army base in northern El Salvador.

title: HEADLINERS Line to MoscowTo hear the prosecutor tell it,
description: Commodore Dieter Gerhardt , a key member of the South African defense establishment, spied for the Soviet Union long enough to draw a pension check in rubles.

title: Ftorek Scores 2 As Rangers Win
description: Robbie Ftorek scored a pair of goals 4 minutes 47 seconds apart in the third period tonight to lead the Rangers to a 3-2 victory over the Buffalo Sabres at Memorial Auditorium.

title: WOMEN CITE REWARDS OF 'NETWORKING'
description: ''WOMEN are not as accustomed to pooling information and planning strategy,'' suggests Marie Rossi, a marketing executive who founded the professional association Women in Sales. Men have always done it, she added, ''probably because they've grown up expecting team participation.''

title: In Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: Why a 99-Year Lease For Robert Martin?
description: Many people reading the article in the Westchester section of the New York Times (''99-Year Lease Weighed,'' Dec. 11) regarding the leasing of 21 acres of county-owned property to Robert Martin, probably do not realize that this parcel of land is in a prime commercial area.

title: CHANGES ARE PLANNED FOR STATE'S 'LEMON' LAW
description: CONNECTICUT forged a new path 15 months ago when it became the first state to enact a so-called ''lemon law,'' and on Tuesday, State Representative John J. Woodcock 3d, the sponsor of the original bill, will begin to introduce amendments to the law.

title: Calla Blumenthal Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mary Blumenthal of White Plains of the engagement of her daughter, Calla Blumenthal, to Todd L. Samuels, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Samuels of Johnstown, Pa. Miss Blumenthal, daughter also of the late Louis Blumenthal, is an associate with the New York law firm of Reavis & McGrath. Her fiance attends the Pennsylvania State University College of Medicine at the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center.

title: ITALY TO CUT MILITARY UNIT IN LEBANON BY HALF
description: Italian officials have told Lebanon and the other nations with troops in the multinational force in Lebanon that they are planning to reduce the size of the Italian contingent from 2,200 to 1,100 soldiers, but that they remain committed to staying in Lebanon.

title: NIGERIA ARMY SAYS IT HAS FORCED OUT THE CIVIL REGIME
description: President Shehu Shagari of Nigeria was overthrown today in a military coup, according to Nigerian broadcasts monitored here.

title: Holder of Credit Card Finds Joy Is Fleeting
description: Scott Grant will have to get used to leaving home without his American Express card. Embarrassed company officials are canceling it.

title: CONVERSATIONS WITH PHILIP
description: David Plante is an American writer from Providence, R.I., who has lived abroad since 1966. His recent books include ''The Woods,'' a novel, and ''Difficult Women,'' a memoir of his friendships with Jean Rhys, Sonia Orwell and Germaine Greer. He met the novelist Philip Roth in 1975 in London, where Mr. Roth and the actress Claire Bloom live half the year. Mr. Plante, who lives there with the Greek poet Nikos Stangos, is collaborating with Mr. Roth in adapting the Jean Rhys section of ''Difficult Women'' for film; they would like Miss Bloom to play the role of Jean Rhys. What follows are excerpts from David Plante's diary that record hisfriendship with Philip Roth. June 6, 1981

title: THE NATION
description: When time comes to buy expensive arms, the military services rarely take the economical route and shop together, the General Accounting Office said in so many words last week, because of swelled heads under all those brass hats.

title: 300 YEARS OF HISTORY, AND MAYBE A GHOST
description: THE Peace and Plenty Inn, nestled in Huntington's West Hills area, has been a silent witness to 300 years of history. Now, for the fourth time, the house is up for sale.

title: SETTING IS ROMANTIC AT NIGHT
description: WE have observed that a restaurant's day and night personas can differ dramatically. This is exceptionally evident at a relatively new restaurant called The Inn at Oakdale, in Wallingford. Its large dining rooms are in a rambling white-frame building that dates back to 1769 and has been a restaurant or tavern since 1810. Its location next door to the Oakdale Playhouse insures a thriving business during the theater's June-September season.

title: Margaret Shukur To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. D. K. Shukur of Bayside, Wis., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Ann Shukur, to Robert Harris Ruxin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold A. Ruxin of Cobleskill, N.Y.

title: THE GIARDINIERA CAPER
description: Mimi Sheraton, the former restaurant critic of The New York Times, is currently at work on a book about food with the entertainer Alan King.

title: Julie Bennett Evrard Plans to Be Wed To James Silcock, Executive, in March
description: Dr. and Mrs. John R. Evrard of Providence, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Bennett Evrard, to James Silcock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth M. Silcock of Birmingham, Mich. A March wedding is planned.

title: Letters ; Thankless Task
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHEDULE CHANGES IN MID-SEASON
description: THE beginning of a calendar year is the midpoint of the theater season, by which time ''to be announced'' slots are usually filled in and some switching of originally scheduled plays has taken place, as well as cancellations and postponements.

title: Jamie Glashow Plans A March 31 Wedding
description: The engagement of Jamie Lynn Glashow to Randy Ian Pardell has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Jules L. Glashow of Upper Saddle River, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Pardell of Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

title: SUNDAY, JANUARY 1, 1984;  International
description: A military coup in Nigeria toppled the Government of President Shehu Shagari, broadcasts from Lagos said. An army officer, Brig. Saleh Abacha, announced that a military government had been set up to replace the civilian administration, which he said had been ''inept and corrupt.'' It was announced that the 1979 Constitution had been suspended, all political parties banned, and a nightly curfew imposed. (Page 1, Column 6.) A pullout of the U.S. marines from Beirut was called for by Walter F. Mondale. He urged President Reagan to begin the withdrawal of the 1,800 marines immediately. The former Vice President, considered the front- runner among the eight Democrats seeking the 1984 president nomination, made the call in statement that also criticized the Reagan Administraiton's overall policy in Lebanon and the rest of the Middle East. (1:4.)

title: ; FRANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: CREIGHTON BEATEN BY DEPAUL, 59-57
description: Tyrone Corbin made an off-balance jump shot with three seconds to play to give DePaul a 59-57 overtime victory over Creighton today.

description: To the Editor:

title: Math Opportunities For Gifted Students
description: I am concerned that the article, ''Gifted and Talented Tell of Frustrations'' (Nov. 27) may convey a distorted picture of the opportunities available for gifted children at Central Junior High School in Greenwich.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: The American travel industry is predicting a bright year for vacationers - and itself - in 1984. If the optimism is borne out, there will be more options for travelers and minimal increases in prices.

title: Streets Forced to Close By Water Main Leaks
description: Two leaking water mains in separate areas of Manhattan forced the closing of icy streets early yesterday and left hundreds of people temporarily without water.

title: POLICE 'CASTLE' MAY BECOME CONDOMINIUM
description: ATURRETED gray architectural anachronism that has been a mystery to passing motorists for 53 years will ''in all probability'' be converted into condominiums, according to the developer who acquired it at auction with a bid of $960,000.

title: Patricia Marty Hall to Become Bride Of Ian Murray Smith Jr. in September
description: Mrs. William Worth Hall of Bronxville, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Patricia Marty Hall, to Ian Murray Smith Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Smith of Grosse Ile, Mich. The wedding is planned for September.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dance review last Sunday misidentified the narrator in Hope Gillerman's ''Gardener A Learns to Cook,'' performed at the Kitchen. He was John Hagan.

title: THE RETURN OF ENCHANTMENT --
description: The current craving for fairy tales and fantasy is not necessarily unhealthy. To a large extent, this phenomenon is a legacy of the 1960's counterculture, which was itself a striking manifestation of the ''child archetype'': a group of young people living out the myth and celebrating the virtues of eternal childhood, in opposition to an adult society obsessed with materialism, militarism and technological ''progress.'' ''E.T'' is very much a hybrid of the 1960's and 1980's mythologies - a high-tech fairy tale about a flower child from outer space - and the extraordinary success of that film, along with all the other evidence assembled by Kathleen Agena, suggests that the myth of the Eternal Child has, over the past decade or so, spread throughout American society.

title: A BUBBLY NEWCOMER DEBUTS AT LITCHFIELD WINERY
description: AS corks popped for New Year's celebrations across the state, some revelers got a taste of Connecticut's first sparkling wine.

title: FLORIDA'S SUCCESS STORY
description: In five years, Coach Charley Pell has taken the University of Florida from the worst to the best.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: New GravityLenses Detected

title: THE NATION
description: Uneven FlowGood news and bad were involved in another economic report last week, the United States merchandise trade deficit. A drop in imports helped narrow the merchandise trade deficit to $7.4 billion in November, but it was still the second highest monthly gap ever, the Government said.

title: THE REGION
description: Devastation in BuffaloA city where nature's wintry wrath is the order of the day coped with a man-made tragedy last week. A 16-block area of Buffalo was devastated by a propane gas explosion that left six people dead, five of them firemen, and nearly 100 injured.

title: U.S. ENVOY IS FACING HARD TESTS
description: When Thomas R. Pickering was asked to take over the United States embassy in El Salvador, he was reported to be unenthusiastic and the embassy staff and Salvadoran officials skeptical.

title: Donna P. Cerutti To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Cerutti of Southampton, L.I., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Patricia Cerutti, to Richard Lawrence Storatz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gottfried J. Storatz of Sun City, Ariz.

title: PLATFORM TENNIS PLAYERS TO MEET IN RYE
description: THE 42d annual Rye Invitational Tournament in platform tennis opens this week, and according to Stephen Baird of Harrison, president of the American Platform Tennis Association, the sport continues to be popular in the county.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS January 1, 1984FICTION 1
description: CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) A car that kills is at large among a Pennyslvania town's high school set.

title: J. Thomas Scharf And Andrew Johnson
description: In my article of Dec. 18 (''A 1,665 Page County History for 'Dippers' and Scholars,'' Opinion Page), there is a misprint. Andrew Jackson did not pardon J. Thomas Scharf.

title: OPERETTA: GILBERT AND SULLIVAN'S 'IDA'
description: ''Princess Ida'' is not one of Gilbert and Sullivan's more popular operettas for obvious reasons. William S. Gilbert's patter songs lack his characteristically tongue-twisting verbal wit, and Arthur Sullivan's melodies are comparatively formulaic. But when decently produced, even less- than-great Gilbert and Sullivan is guaranteed some moments of outright hilarity.

title: FRANCES FOSTER TO WED IN APRIL
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Wheelwright Foster of Needham, Mass., and Palo Alto, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter, Frances Hoar Foster, to Laird Hardcastle Simons 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simons Jr. of Wynnewood, Pa. An April wedding is plnned.

title: Think Back, Too
description: If you are already weary of 1984 and all that, think back, to 1884. Politically, it was nothing special. A woman - Belva A. Lockwood - ran for President for the first time; she didn't make it. But it was an epochal year for American culture, producing an extraordinary work by a writer who called himself Mark Twain.

title: THE MESSAGE FOR TODAY IN ORWELL'S '1984'
description: ''IN a free society,'' wrote the French philosopher Montesquieu, ''it is not always important that individuals reason well, it is sufficient that they reason; from their individual thought, freedom is born.''

title: Americans Reported Safe
description: The State Department said today that the coup in Nigeria had cut off normal transportation and communications, but that it had been determined that the 7,000 Americans there were apparently safe.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: SCARSDALE NOT long ago, William Allen was hospitalized with a mysterious fever of 106 degrees. ''We thought he was going to die,'' his wife, Jeanette, said. ''Then one day he looked at a full- page newspaper ad for the wine store we use, and started making a list of what he wanted me to buy. Instead of the mortician, we called Zachys.''

title: FOSSILS BOLSTER A THEORY ON MAN'S EARLIEST ANCESTOR
description: Recent discoveries support previous findings indicating that a tree-dwelling, housecat-size primate that lived in Africa more than 30 million years ago was the earliest known ancestor of apes, monkeys and man, a Duke University scientist who found the fossils reported yesterday.

description: Everything From Art To Knickknacks Somerstown Studios and Gallery, about one-half hour north of White Plains in Somers, ordinarily shows sculpture, painting and sometimes ceramic works - much of it by local or regional artists - and it has a year-round gift shop with glassware, stationery, jewelry, wooden clocks, dulcimers, children's knickknacks and soft sculpture, with prices from under one dollar to hundreds of dollars.
