title: THE ISRAELI-AMERICAN HONEYMOON IS OVER, AGAIN
description: The flush of strategic accord between Israel and the United States lasted about two weeks, from the harmonious talks in late November between President Reagan and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir in Washington to the discord in mid-December over the evacuation of Yasir Arafat and his faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization from Tripoli, Lebanon.

title: THE SILENT CHASE
description: Thomas B. Allen and Norman Polmar are the co-authors of ''Rickover,'' a biography of Adm. Hyman G. Rickover. THE LARGEST SUBMARINE IN THE WORLD, A DARK mass longer than the Washington Monument is high, rises through the frigid depths below the Arctic ice pack. The Typhoon-class ship, the newest entry in the Soviet underwater fleet, has almost half again the tonnage of the biggest American submarine. Beneath the double row of hatches on its forward deck nestle 20 intercontinental ballistic missiles. Slowly, carefully, the captain guides the Typhoon upward until its stubby superstructure nudges against the jagged ice ceiling.

title: ROCK: THE GO-BETWEENS
description: If not for their Australian accents and their timing - some seven years after the fact - the Go-Betweens could almost be a band from the first burst of New York's new-wave rock.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Football
description: Raiders vs. Pittsburgh Steelers, at Los Angeles, 4 P.M. American Football Conference playoff semifinal. The Steelers lost four of their last five regular-season games.

title: MIDEAST RADICALS FURTHERING SOVIET ARMS
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE WORLD;
WASHINGTON PUTS UNESCO ON NOTICE
description: The United States gave formal notice of withdrawal from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization last week but hastened to say that this was not the start of a general pullout from world organizations.

title: Staying With Cowboys
description: Describing himself as ''a fighter'' who wanted to stay in Dallas and ''fight this thing through,'' Ron Fellows said that he would sign a three- year contract in a few days and remain as cornerback with the Dallas Cowboys, for whom he has played the last three seasons. After a season in which he played primarily on obvious passing downs and on special teams, Fellows said he had considered jumping to the United States Football League, along with two other Cowboy players.

title: A DRAFT FROM THAT OUTSIDE DOOR? TIPS ON WEATHERSTRIPPING
description: IN many homes the arrival of cold

title: VOICES THAT REFLECT A RETURN TO SIMPLICITY
description: For several years, one of my favorite singers has been an Irish woman named Triona Ni Dhomhnaill. Miss Ni Dhomhnaill used to sing (and play the clavinet, a harpsichord-like electric keyboard instrument) with an Irish folk-rock group called the Bothy Band. She now does the same thing with an American country-Irish outfit called Touchstone, investing the Appalachian-style ballads of that group with the same plaintive Celtic flavor that suffused her singing with the Bothy Band. None of her records seems to be in the domestic catalogue at the moment. But she does crop up occasionally at Folk City, with Touchstone or on her own, and some Bothy Band material should still be obtainable as imports.More recently, I have developed a parallel enthusiasm for an English - at least British - singer named Emma Kirkby. Miss Kirkby is a specialist in early music, that term meaning not Celtic ballads but classical music of the Middle Ages to the Baroque. She can be heard on any number of recent early-music albums, among them Hyperion's disk of the music of the 12th-century Hildegard of Bingen, the Chandos Records' release of Purcell's ''Dido and Aeneas,'' Christopher Hogwood's interpretation of Handel's ''Messiah'' on Oiseau-Lyre and imported copies of the same label's ''Portrait of Emma Kirkby.''

title: HANDSOME SETTING, WITH POTENTIAL
description: VILLA PORTOFINO in Mineola is a small and rather elegant-looking Continental restaurant. The dining room is handsomely paneled in wood with decorative accents provided by dusty rose provincial print fabric used as chair cushions. Because the food can be quite appealing, this new place has definite potential, but at this time the quality of the service militates against gracious dining.

title: RABBI'S CHALLENGE
description: TEANECK LIKE many people at this time of year, Rabbi David M. Feldman finds himself preparing lists of 1984 priorities, personal and professional.

title: SEVERITY OF THE COLD HAS SURPRISED SOME FORECASTERS MORE THAN OTHERS
description: The extreme cold that struck much of the country in recent weeks caught the nation's official long-range weather forecasters by surprise, but medium-range forecasts were closer to the mark.

title: Amy E. Phillips Plans To Be Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Bernard Phillips of Shaker Heights, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Ellen Phillips, to Harry Ginsburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Ginsburg of LaDue, Mo. A March wedding is planned.

title: 4 More Executed in China
description: The Yangcheng Evening News of Canton said three men were executed in Sihui County on Thursday for raping 23 women. In addition, The Workers' Daily said Gu Longxi was executed in Shanghai on Wednesday for stealing 70 tons of iron and steel and shipping it to factories in Zhejiang Province. Mr. Gu and his accomplices made $11,000 profit, the paper said. Thousands of people have been sentenced to death in a drive against crime that began in August.

title: TWO DANGEROUS MYTHS
description: AMERICA'S HIDDEN SUCCESS A Reassessment of Twenty Years of Public Policy. By John E. Schwarz. 208 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $12.95.

title: A Correction
description: An article in The Week in Review of Dec. 18 incorrectly stated the outcome of a vote at the United Mine Workers' convention. Richard L. Trumka, the union president, was given the authority to call selective strikes.

title: 3 STATES SAY OSHA RULE ON CHEMICALS WEAKENS THEIR LAWS
description: New York, Connecticut and New Jersey have filed suits challenging a new Federal regulation that their officials say would weaken existing state laws protecting workers against toxic chemicals.

title: HAPPPY NEW YEAR?
description: New Year's Day is always a depressing holiday, and for good reason. For one thing, it comes in January, and to those who ask, ''If January comes, can spring be far behind?'' my answer is yes, two months and three weeks behind, including February, a month that never fails to last at least nine years.

title: A DISPLAY OF FOUR ILLUSTRIOUS FAMILIES
description: ''THREE American Families: A Tradition of Artistic Pursuit'' appeared last fall at the Whitney Museum of Art's Philip Morris Branch in Manhattan. It comprised paintings by the Duyckinck, Peale and Weir families and covered approximately 200 years.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: EVEN though he spent Christmas in the hospital, Thirman L. Milner , the Mayor of Hartford, said his was the ''best Christmas ever.''

title: BEHIND THE SCENES OF ABSTRACT EXPRESSIONISM
description: HOW NEW YORK STOLE THE IDEA OF MODERN ART Abstract Expressionism, Freedom, and the Cold War. By Serge Guilbaut. Translated by Arthur Goldhammer. Illustrated. 277 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $22.50.

title: FOND FAREWELL IS WISHED FOR MA BELL
description: MA BELL is having a litter of little Bells, I hear. I have not been following her pregnancy very well, I must confess; I never have been too clear about who exactly manufacturers my telephone, who owns it, whose lines I use, that sort of thing.

title:
DINING OUT;
POOR SERVICE CAN SPOIL THE BROTH
description: SOME restaurants change their names or owners so frequently that it is difficult to keep up. The latest is the Park Savoy, formerly known as Freckles and, before that, as the Florham Park Country Club.

title: Never a Letup In Yankeeland
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Phantom Character
description: To the Editor:

title: PICASSO IN PROCESS
description: Even for die-hard Picasso buffs, ''Picasso the Printmaker: Graphics From the Marina Picasso Collection,'' a traveling exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum through Jan. 8, may be a surfeit of riches. Since the Picasso retrospective which filled the Museum of Modern Art in 1980, the mercurial and prolific Spanish artist has loomed over the New York art world like a ubiquitous giant. In the last 15 months his reach has been extended by major New York gallery shows of his sculpture and drawings. There may be too much weariness from trying to keep up with him the last time he came to town for another visit to be greeted with get-up-and-go spirit.

title: MOTEL CONVERSIONS FOUGHT ON EAST END
description: AS 1984 begins, conversions of motels to cooperative apartments in Montauk and elsewhere in the resort town of East Hampton have hit a record pace. But the environmentally minded Democrats who gained control of town government with the new year want to end the trend as one of their first orders of business.

title: FOR PHILADELPHIA, A DAY OF SPECTACLE
description: The finery and fantasy lay dormant tonight, the plumes and giant fans, the radiant frames, floats and costumes of greens and golds, blues and purples and silvers now dim in dark lofts and warehouses and hallways, the banjos, horns and glockenspiels silent.

title: M. J. Worne, Miss Chace, Plan to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dean W. Chace of Princeton, N.J., and Canada Lake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Latham Chace, to Michael John Worne, son of Gerald B. Worne of Amersham, Buckinghamshire, England, and the late Mrs. Worne.

title: HOT-DOG LOVERS PROTEST THREAT TO SHUT L.I. STAND
description: Limousines and tractor-trailers park side by side at one point in this Suffolk County community, where the drivers run up to a hot-dog stand to place their orders.

title: GOOD YEAR PREDICTED FOR STATE BUSINESSES
description: HARTFORD WHILE there are differing opinions on why it happened, Connecticut economists generally agree that the state's economy pulled out of the recession in 1983 with a rapid and robust recovery.

title:
CAMERA;
OUTDOOR PORTRAITS FOR AM ORE NATURAL EFFECT
description: Harvey L. Bilker is a freelance photographer who often writes about photography.

title: Remark Brings Penalty
description: Bret Lerner, assistant general manager of the Houston Gamblers, was placed on 30 days' probation by the United States Football League team today for having said publicly that Billy Sims of the Detroit Lions had an I.Q. of 20. The Gamblers' chairman, Alvin Lubetkin, said that Lerner, who later apologized for the remark, had offered to resign but that the club had chosen ''not to accept it'' and would weigh further action after the 30-day period.

title: IN SEARCH OF '1984'
description: Even though Jura, a brown stringbean of an island, sits only 16 miles off Scotland's west coast, no one ever ''happens'' onto its shores. A casual glance at a map is deceptive. There is the island, 30 miles long, 7 miles wide, indisputably one of the Inner Hebrides, as opposed to the Outer Hebrides, considerably farther off the coast. On the map it looks so handy to Glasgow and Greenock and all the ferry routes that fan out westward from the Argyll coast. But the trip to Jura requires finely tuned advance planning, patience plus a deep-rooted indifference to all those goodies with which the Scots so cannily lure thousands of tourists.

title: THE PERSON TO SEE ON ENERGY
description: NEW ORLEANS SEVEN years ago, in the frigid

title: Lobbying for Japan
description: In the article ''Lobbying for Japan Inc.'' (Dec. 4), David Osborne states that the former Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs Richard V. Allen ''accepted $1,000 for arranging an interview wih Nancy Reagan for a Japanese magazine'' and that this ''$1,000 forced Allen out of the Administration.'' This same language appears in the caption beneath a photograph of Mr. Allen. These statements are incorrect and misleading. After a thorough investigation into the circumstances of this highly publicized matter, the Department of Justice concluded: ''In this matter, the money was not given to Allen for anything he had done; rather, it was intended as an honorarium for Mrs. Reagan and simply intercepted by Mr. Allen. It was neither given nor received to benefit Allen or to influence him in any way. Indeed, he was not even aware of the contents of the envelope until after the meeting was completed. . . . In sum, when the uncontradicted facts are analyzed in the context of possibly applicable criminal laws, it is clear there was no criminal violation by Allen regarding the $1,000.''

title: RECENT RELEASES A Hard Day's Night Starring the Beatles. Directed by Richard Lester, 1964 Maljack 90 minutes. $69.95
description: It was 20 years ago today (or very nearly; it was August 1964) when the first Beatle movie opened to audiences like no others. Fans actually screamed in the theaters while the movie played, making it almost as inaudible as their concerts. And the enthusiasts were not the only ones who were impressed. Even The New York Times film critic, Bosley Crowther, a non-Beatlemaniac who claimed he couldn't stand ''the frequent and brazen yah-yah-yahing of the fellows when they break into song,'' had to admit he found this movie great fun. ''It is done with such a dazzling use of camera that it tickles the intellect and electrifies the nerves,'' he wrote.

title: BUSINESS ETHICS
description: To the Editor:

title: 'La Plume' Long A Part of the Past
description: I found the article entitled ''Languages Take New Direction'' in the edition of Sunday, Dec. 11 very surprising and shocking. I taught French in the nearby Mamaroneck school system from 1940 to 1966 and was chairman of the foreign language department for the last two of those years.

title: Rosalind La Roche Is Wed to a Pastor
description: Rosalind La Roche, founder and director of Earth House Inc., a residential treatment center in East Millstone, N.J., for major mental disorders, was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to the Rev. Greer Sharp Imbrie Jr., pastor of the the Osceola Mills (Pa.) Presbyterian Church.

title: GREGG CHARTING PACKERS' COURSE
description: -- The Green Bay Packers, a struggling franchise since the departure of Vince Lombardi after the 1967 season, once again have turned to one of Lombardi's former stars to try to return the team to glory.

title: A CHALLENGE FOR MISS LAREDO
description: RUTH LAREDO, the internationally acclaimed pianist who has made numerous appearances in New Jersey, will start the new year by performing the Samuel Barber Piano Concerto six times this month with the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra.

title: HIGH TECH HAS A RESPONSIBILITY
description: THE increasing centrality of the role that the high-tech industry plays in our state demands that we recognize the urgency of certain problems that such a phenomenon has created.

title: PRINTS BY BOWERY ARTISTS ON DISPLAY
description: THOSE with long and happy memories may associate the Bowery with Sammy's Bowery Follies, although for most of us the Bowery is synonymous with the granddaddy of Skid Rows. Elizabeth Galasso Fine Art Leasing in Ossining is currently commemorating that historic New York City thoroughfare. However, neither of those two popular images finds much room.

title: 4 REPORTED KILLED BY BOMBS IN FRANCE
description: At least four people were reported killed and scores wounded when bombs went off tonight in this city's railroad station and aboard a speeding train 120 miles to the north.

title: THE NATION
description: Charles Z. Wick, who directs the United States Information Agency and is thus largely responsible for shoring up Uncle Sam's standing abroad, could, it seems, use a little help with his image on the home front. The New York Times reported last week that Mr. Wick, ignoring the advice of the U.S.I.A.'s general counsel, had from time to time recorded his office telephone conversations and apparently didn't always tell people that their words would wind up on agency transcripts.

title: WOODRUFF WALLNER FORMER U.S. ENVOY, DIES AT 74 IN FRANCE
description: Woodruff Wallner, a diplomat who witnessed Francisco Franco's victories in the Spanish Civil War and who was interned by the Germans for two years in World War II, died Monday at his home near Caen, in Normandy, after undergoing surgery for a digestive ailment. He was 74 years old.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bethany, Conn. $89,000 *2*12 Emerald Lane, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 4-year-old *2*contemporary; fenced-in yard for horses, 1.5 acres; *2*taxes $1,407. Gilford, Conn. $109,000 *2*66 Still Meadow, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*4-year-old colonial; finished basement, near *2*schools and shopping, 1 acre, taxes $2,047. Mount Vernon, N.Y. $124,250 *2*341 Claremont Avenue, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*50-year-old Tudor/Norman; eat-in kitchen, *2*sunroom; taxes $2,540. title: EXPECTED SURPLUS POSES COAST ISSUE
description: Legislators will return to California's State Capitol Tuesday facing precisely the opposite problem from the one they faced a year ago. Then their problem was a projected $1.5 billion deficit; now the problem is how to spend a projected surplus of $2.7 billion.

title: Water Leaks Close 2 Streets
description: Two leaking water mains in separate areas of Manhattan forced the closing of icy streets early yesterday and left hundreds of people temporarily without water.

title: MORE REPAIRS SET FOR I-95 BRIDGE
description: ADDITIONAL repairs on the Mianus River Bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike in Greenwich are scheduled to begin Thursday, and officials in Connecticut and New York say they are preparing for the worst while hoping for the best.

title: NEW YORK AREA ECONOMY ON THE MEND AS '83 ENDS
description: The economy of the New York metropolitan area, after a ''shaky start'' in 1983, moved toward recovery from the recession at the end of the year, according to the the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: UNRESOLVED ISSUES POSE TEST FOR ISLAND
description: AS it did last year, news about the unfinished Shoreham nuclear plant seems certain to dominate on the Island in the new year.

title: WHO'S NO. 1? PLAYOFF COULD ANSWER THAT
description: ''WE'RE No. 1, we're No. 1.'' That is a chant heard every fall on several campuses during the course of the season. It is also the battle cry for all people opposing a college-football playoff system, those who believe that it's not bad to have several teams shouting, ''We're No. 1.'' However, this logic does not follow, because usually once a season is over one team is ranked No. 1, but several other teams are now shouting, ''Why aren't we No. 1?''

title: UPKEEP CAN BE KEY TO A SALE
description: HOMEOWNERS forced by personal or professional circumstances to vacate their house before they have found a buyer face the problem of making the house look appealing once pictures are off the wall, furniture is gone and floors are bare.

title: June Nuptials Set By Miss McGrath And Brian Dunn
description: Dr. and Mrs. Terence J. McGrath of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Anne McGrath, to Brian D. Dunn, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Norton Dunn of White Plains.

title: WHAT THEY'D LIKE TO DO WITHOUT
description: EACH year around this time, many people take a few moments to reflect on the things that either enhance or aggravate their lives. In this spirit, a number of Long Islanders were asked: What are three things you could do without in 1984?

title:
GARDENING;
A CONSERVATION GOAL FOR THE NEW YEAR
description: LAST year was not a terribly kind one to the gardener and his garden. A wet spring made getting on with the gardening chores difficult. Six consecutive weekends in May and June were washouts. The wet weather set the stage for such problems as the continued spread of dogwood and anthracnose, that dread fungus disease that is decimating our flowering dogwoods. It also favored mildew at the expense of the rose.

title: SOME REMEDIES FOR RICH FOOD: WARM AND SUSTAINING FARE
description: HEARTBURN seems to be a perpetual condition at this time of the year. But now that the holidays are almost over, it is time to think of an antidote to all that rich food. The weather is too cold for salad; what is needed is meals that are not too heavy, but warm and sustaining.

title: ROUNDING UP AMERICANS
description: JUSTICE AT WAR By Peter Irons. 407 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $18.95.

title: Lisa Mai Shear to Wed Eric H. Shawn in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter John Shear of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Mai Shear, to Eric Henry Shawn, son of Lieut. Col. Gilbert S. Shawn, U.S.A.F., retired, of New York and the late Melba Rae Shawn.

title: THE ELECTION IS MORE THAN THE SUM OF ITS RITUALS
description: WASHINGTON A glance at the campaign calendar encourages a concentration on nuts-and-bolts questions. On the Republican side, can President Reagan get the Democratic votes he needs for re- election? On the Democratic side, can Senator John Glenn invigorate his campaign in time to become a factor in the Iowa caucuses? Or will former Vice President Walter F. Mondale score a runaway victory by sweeping the South on ''Super Tuesday?'' Can one of the consensus long-shots - Senators Gary Hart, Alan Cranston, Ernest F. Hollings, former Governor Reubin Askew or former Senator George McGovern - bolt into contention with a galvanizing performance in the series of debates that begins on Jan. 15? Will the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson shake up the Democratic contest with his challenge of the delegate-selection rules, just as his trip to Syria last week was shaking up traditional Middle Eastern diplomacy?

title: A VISIT TO FRANCE'S CAPITAL OF FOIE GRAS
description: The two principal foie gras regions in France are Alsace and the Perigord in the southwest, each with its own traditions and jealously guarded secrets. In these areas, every farmer's wife has her own truffled goose livers, and country roads are dotted with signs directing one to farmhouses where foie gras is sold on the spot. In town, the butchers offer their own versions.

title: An Appeal to Mussolini
description: Desperate to work in his field, Ernest Everett Just left the United States and exiled himself to Europe. In 1936 he wrote a letter to Benito Mussolini, the Italian dictator, seeking an audience.

title: 4 Killed in Bangladesh In Election Violence
description: Violence between supporters of rival candidates in rural elections killed 4 people Friday, raising the death toll to 10, the newspaper Dainik Bangla reported today.

title: SUSAN MARREN TO WED WILLIAM J. WHELAN 3D
description: Mrs. Bernard Marren of White Plains has announced the engagement of her daughter, Susan Hellen Marren, to William James Whelan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Whelan Jr. of New Rochelle, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS
description: Rights of AgingPolice OfficersTo Stay on DutyPhysically demanding jobs may seem more compatible with youth than old age, but Federal age-discrimination laws do not allow employers to presume it. Last week, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed a suit against Massachusetts to overturn a rule that requires state troopers to retire at 50.

title: THE WALLS HAVE EARS
description: ''As soon as there is a whiff,'' said Felix Rohatyn, the financial savior of New York City, ''a whiff of anything remotely relating to money, everybody goes off the wall.''

title: THE MALE MYTH --
description: I applaud Paul Theroux's essay. But when he writes, ''The Hemingway personality is too tedious to go into here, but certainly it was not until this aberrant behavior was examined by feminists in the 1960's that any male writer dared question the pugnacity in Hemingway's fiction . . . ,'' he overlooks ''Tea and Sympathy,'' which I wrote in 1953, in which the leading character, Laura, makes one of the points of the play when she says, ''Manliness is not all swagger and swearing and mountain climbing. Manliness is also tenderness, gentleness, consideration.'' ROBERT ANDERSON New York City

title: Letter: On School Budgets The Chancellor Claims His Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Tell Takes Final in Tennis
description: Eileen Tell of Aberdeen, N.J., defeated Rene Mentz of South Africa, 3-6, 6-3, 6-1, and won the girls' 18 title in the Rolex International junior tennis tournament today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Elevator Stalls, ManFallstoDeath
description: A 31- year-old Syracuse man who had been celebrating New Year's Eve at the Hilton Tower fell 100 feet to his death when he jumped from an elevator stuck between floors, the police said.

title: Vietnamese Guns Shell Cambodian Rebels
description: Vietnamese soldiers occupying Cambodia heavily shelled Cambodian guerrilla bases along the Thai border today, Thai military sources said.

title: FLUTES IN LIBRARY OF CONGRESS CALLED NEGLECTED
description: The greatest collection of flutes in the world, the Miller Collection in the Library of Congress, has been neglected ''to the point of irresponsibility and even theft and vandalism,'' according to its former curator, Tula Giannini.

title: HOSPITAL GROUP ASKS STRONGER SAFEGUARDS FOR MEDICAL RECORDS
description: The nation's hospitals need new safeguards to protect patients' computerized medical records in light of increased demands for information by the Government and insurance companies, according to the American College of Hospital Administrators.

title: LIFE-OR-DEATH DECISIONS NOT FOR DOCTORS TO MAKE
description: To the Editor:

description: T HE volume of trading in commodity and financial futures

title: Soviet Line Delivers Gas MOSCOW, Jan. 1 (AP) - The first natural gas pumped along the Soviet pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe has been delivered to France, Radio Moscow reported today.
description: In an English-language news broadcast, the radio said, ''The Soviet Union has started exporting natural gas to Western Europe'' along the pipeline from the Urengoi Peninsula to the Czechoslovak-West German border via the Soviet border town of Ushogorod.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, JANUARY 2, 1984
description: Companies

title: REAGAN PLANS BIGGER BUDGET FOR U.S. LAW ENFORCEMENT
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to seek a $200 million increase in the Justice Department's budget for next year, according to department officials.

title: LATIN AMERICAN UNREST TIED TO SOCIAL PROBLEMS IN NEW STUDY
description: An eight-month study by the University of Miami has concluded that critical economic and social problems rather than Marxist subversion are principally responsible for revolutionary strife and political discontent in Latin America.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: DEADLY DEADLINE IS OVER, BUT BEIRUT STILL HASTHE JITTERS
description: The other day a Lebanese couple was invited to a New Year's party at the hotel in Beirut at which the majority of Western reporters stay.

description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN TRUTHS-CRITICS' ERRORS-ON SOUTH AFRICA AND VIETNAM
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Hunters Drown Trying to Save Dog
description: Two hunters trying to rescue a dog that had fallen through a thin layer of ice on a frozen pond drowned today after the ice broke beneath their own feet.

title: AN INTERVIEW WITH SENATOR GARY HART, DEMOCRAT OF COLORADO
description: Following are key questions and answers from an interview with Senator Gary Hart by Frank Lynn:

title: TWO NEW STARS MAY HELP THE GOLF TOUR
description: Seve Ballesteros of Spain and Greg Norman of Australia are finally joining the PGA Tour this year as regular, card-carrying members who must play in at least 15 tournaments in this country. These two proven winners could make quite an impact upon the men's tour, which did not have a dominant player in 1983.

title: Utah Road Shut by Mud Reopens After 9 Months
description: The road over Billie's Mountain, a major link between northern and southeastern Utah that has been closed since April because of a mudslide, was opened to motorists Saturday.

title: NEW RAIL WELDS FOUND CRACKED IN THE SUBWAYS
description: The program to repair New York City's deteriorated subway tracks has encountered a problem that transit officials say raises questions about work already performed and still to be done.

title: HART LISTS KEY ISSUES AS WORK AND EQUALITY
description: The New York Times today publishes an interview with Senator Gary Hart, another in a series of interviews with candidates for the Presidency.

title: PBS SEEKS $10 MILLION FOR CONVENTION COVERAGE
description: The Public Broadcasting Service has begun a campaign to raise $10 million to enable ''The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour'' to provide gavel-to- gavel coverage of the Presidential nominating conventions, according to Lawrence K. Grossman, president.

title: JUDGE REFUES TO OVERTURN CONVICTION IN WESTCHESTER THEATER CASE
description: An executive of Warner Communications has lost an effort to overturn his fraud and racketeering conviction involving the purchase of stock in the Westchester Premier Theater.

title: 49ERS TO COUNT ON QUICKNESS
description: According to Coach Bill Walsh, his San Francisco 49ers do not match up well with the Redskins, whom they meet next Sunday in the National Conference championship game at Washington.

title: CULTURES COLORBLIND TO A 'WINE-DARK SEA,' HOMERIC OR NOT
description: To the Editor:

title: Get Moving on Photo Licenses
description: New York and Tennessee are the only states that still issue a driver's license without a photo. Why is New York so far behind? Because of bureaucratic infighting and indecision.

title: THE BRITISH REPORT FIRST CRUISE MISSILES ARE ALL OPERATIONAL
description: The first 16 American-made cruise missiles based in Europe became operational today, four years after the North Atlantic Treaty Organization pledged to deploy them to counter growing numbers of Soviet SS-20 missiles.

title: A CRUSADE FOR AUBURN FANS
description: NEW ORLEANS BOURBON STREET was impassable on New Year's Eve, and instead of glittery paper hats the merrymakers wore the navy blue and burnt orange of their alma mater, and instead of singing ''Auld Lang Syne,'' they chanted, ''Hey, it's great to be an Auburn Tiger.''

title: CO-WORKERS JOIN IN DONATING TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: Many contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund come from groups of co-workers who have joined together to help those who are less fortunate.

title: JACKSON EXTENDS SYRIA VISIT TO HOLD MEETING WITH ASSAD
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who arrived here Friday seeking the release of a captured American bombardier-navigator, said today that he was extending his stay another day in order to meet with President Hafez al-Assad.

title: A GLOVE STRATEGY THAT FITS
description: ''These aren't made in a bakery, you know,'' Hans Fischer, president of Aris Isotoner Inc., the glove producer, found himself stubbornly repeating on the telephone the last two weeks of the Christmas season. ''It's a fine, highly labor-intensive product,'' he insisted, ''and production is limited by the number of skilled workers we can get in the Far East.''

title: 2 Crewmen Lost as Train Falls in River in Oregon
description: River currents today thwarted a search for the bodies of two crew members missing after two Burlington Northern locomotives ran off an open swing bridge in a heavy fog and plunged into the Willamette River.

title: POP: PABLO MOSES PERFORMS
description: On his records, Pablo Moses is a gentle reggae singer who insinuates desperate, defiant messages into sweet phrases. But when he performed Friday at Irving Plaza, there was a fierce look in his eyes and a steely edge to the songs from his new album, ''In the Future.''

title: Washington Watch; Fed Fights Shift Of Its Bank Role
description: RECENT proposals to streamline the financial regulatory system have garnered unexpectedly strong accolades from the savings and loan and banking industries, and from important aides to the Congressional banking committees.

title: REAGAN'S DECIDING; LET'S ALL LISTEN IN
description: So, this is the draft of the announcement! Looks good. I'm really excited about running again. Before I get it put on the Teleprompter, why don't I, just for the heck of it, run over the arguments against running?

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Reunion on Slopes

title: Hundreds of G.I.'s Brawl in Frankfurt
description: Hundreds of American soldiers brawled in a Frankfurt bar district Saturday night and early today.

title: SIGHTING THE SEALS ON SHORES
description: The summer tourists are long gone from the shores of Massachusetts. But this winter has brought another migration to the isolated beaches and rocky ledges from Gloucester to Provincetown: herds of seals.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Avant-Garde Improvisation

title: Stray Bullet Hurts Virgil of Phillies
description: Ozzie Virgil, the Philadelphia Phillies' catcher, suffered a gunshot wound of the hand in Puerto Rico during New Year's Eve celebrations in his hometown of Mayaguez, a spokesman for the team said today.

title: G.M. SAID TO WEIGH REVAMPING
description: The General Motors Corporation is considering a realignment that would consolidate its five automotive divisions into two groups, one to produce small cars and the other for larger models, according to sources in the company and the auto industry.

title: Castro Asserts Cubans Are Prepared to Fight
description: President Fidel Castro declared tonight that Cubans, in the first 25 years of their revolution, ''did not tremble'' at Washington and remain ''ready to die and to win'' in any showdown with the United States.

title: SENATOR TOWER OFF TODAY TO THE MIDEAST
description: Senator John Tower, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, plans to leave here Monday for the Middle East on a hastily arranged trip in which he intends to see whether American marines should be withdrawn from Lebanon, Congressional officials said today.

title: FTOREK, THE HERO, TO STAY A RESERVE
description: The praise could be heard outside the Ranger dressing room.

title: A FIASCO IN FRANCE: PLANES THAT CAN SNIFF OUT OIL
description: A secret petroleum prospecting plan that turned into a fiasco has given France a glimpse of a scandal involving its former leaders' fascination with so-called sniffer aircraft, designed to divine oil deposits as easily as pigs detect truffles.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: From Rent Control to Court

title: NEBRASKA AIMING TO STAY NO. 1
description: For Nebraska, the 50th Orange Bowl game Monday night against Miami is an opportunity to finish the 1983 season as the No. 1 team in the nation. For the Miami team and for the City of Miami, the game is a focal point for rallying round local success.

title: Two Resident Theaters Receive Exxon Grants
description: Two grants of $25,000 each have been awarded this year by the Exxon Corporation to the Actors Theater of Louisville and the Magic Theater in San Francisco, ''in recognition of the outstanding records of both theaters in nurturing the talents of American playwrights.''

title: STRIFE OVER AIMS AND LEADERSHIP STALLS PUERTO RICAN LEGAL GROUP
description: The Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund has, over the last dozen years, fought politicians, educators, police officials and bureaucrats over issues ranging from bilingual education to voting rights to legislative redistricting.

title: TANGLED $500 MILLION OIL ROYALTY SUIT TO GO TO COURT IN TEXAS
description: A huge, bitter and tangled lawsuit over oil royalties goes to court Wednesday, newly complicated by the Exxon Corporation's surprise entry into the case. Exxon's move has at least temporarily blocked a settlement that would have channeled extra oil royalties into the Texas public school fund.

title: ALFONSIN INSPIRES OTHER LATINS
description: The inauguration of Raul Alfonsin as President of Argentina and his bold moves against those responsible for the military repression of the last seven and a half years have inspired new hopes for democracy in several countries in the region.

title: No Headline
description: City's Parking Rules

title: TwinsYears
description: A Long Island woman gave birth to twin boys - one in 1983 and the other in 1984, Huntington Hospital officials said today. Delia Pace of Northport gave birth to Thomas Vincent, weighing 6 pounds 5 ounces, at 11:59 P.M. Saturday, and to Canio Michael, weighing 5 pounds 10 ounces, at 12:01 A.M. today, a hospital spokesman said.

title: REAGAN TRUTHS-CRITICS' ERRORS-ON SOUTH AFRICA AND VIETNAM
description: To the Editor: One of President Reagan's ''docu

title: PEKING-STYLE OPERA AT TULLY HALL
description: To Kuo Hsaio-chuang's admirers in her native Taiwan, she is an innovative stage director, bubbling with creativity. To her detractors, she is a menace, trying to destroy a grand and exotic tradition that has survived 200 years.

title: Susan Moskowitz Is Bride
description: Susan Sabina Moskowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Moskowitz of Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Peter Gary Waldman, son of Herbert S. Waldman of New York and the late Mrs. Waldman. Rabbi Howard Herman performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ludel, in Bedford, N.Y.

title: SALVADOR REBELS BLOW UP BRIDGE, NATION'S BIGGEST
description: Leftist guerrillas destroyed El Salvador's largest bridge today after routing several hundred Government troops assigned to guard it.

title: Military Tax Review Due WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) - The Internal Revenue Service is considering eliminating a tax break enjoyed by military personnel.
description: The I.R.S. said Thursday that military personnel who receive tax-free housing allowances may not in the future be able to deduct mortgage interest payments from their yearly taxes.

title: LAND USE DEBATE GROWS IN WIDE-OPEN COLORADO
description: From her window over the kitchen sink, Susan McDanal can see the vanguard of Denver's urban sprawl crowding up against County Line Road barely half a mile away, tract and row houses under construction marching south under a winter pall of pollution.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Hidden Victims

title: Historical Hair Snipped
description: Someone has snipped about two inches from the hair of the Civil War abolitionist John Brown, on display at the Capitol, the police say.

title: Bomb Blast in Hamburg
description: A remote-control bomb exploded in the Hanseatic State Statistics Bureau here before dawn today, causing heavy damage but no injuries, the police said. Authorities said no one took responsibility for the bombing. Statistics officials have come under criticism recently from opponents of the national census planned this year, who contend that the census violates the privacy of West German citizens.

title: NIGERIAN GENERAL ASSERTS HE LEADS NEW ARMY REGIME
description: A Nigerian Army general announced today that he had assumed authority in the aftermath of the military overthrow of the country's civilian Government on Saturday.

title: HART WILLINGLY TACKLES ISSUE OF 'CAN HE WIN?'
description: Senator Gary Hart is known for his public ''cool,'' but he warms up to the subject of many politicians writing him off early as a serious Presidential contender.

title: ARSON SUSECTED AS FIRE KILLS 4 IN NEWARK ROOMING HOUSE
description: Four men were killed in a fire of suspicious origin in a two-story rooming house in the South Ward, the authorities said today.

title: Salmon in Peril
description: The Atlantic salmon has been hunted to the verge of extinction. A treasure to anglers and gourmets, and commercial fishermen on both sides of the ocean, the species is running out. The only hope is a program of severe self-denial.

title: Michigan's Smith Turns Boos Into Cheers
description: ''Maybe it was the boos,'' said Steve Smith, the senior quarterback for Michigan, who was trying to explain why he had removed the brace from a shoulder that was injured in last January's Rose Bowl.

title: RESOLVING TO DO LESS CAN WORK
description: IN a rash moment you probably

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A ball hit high into center field, and easily catchable, lands untouched, equidistant between the left fielder and the center fielder. Who is charged with the error?

title: Shelley Mason Named Poetry Center Director
description: Shelley Mason, who has been managing director of the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y for three years, will become the center's director on June 1.

title: Soviet Satellites Launched
description: The Soviet Union launched three satellites from one rocket Thursday to test equipment for a new communications control system, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported. It said the satellites, Cosmos 1519, 1520 and 1521, were testing parts for an orbiting navigational system that would pinpoint the locations of all Soviet civilian planes, merchant ships and fishing vessels.

title: A RESTLESS ALLY
description: Over the three decades of the Atlantic alliance Britain has been among the least fretful members - the least given to questioning policies of the alliance leader, the United States. But that is true no longer. Today there is a profound restlessness about American leadership.

title: The Number Of the Truck
description: WHEN you take a 51-7 beating in a football playoff game, you might as well consider that you lost to a terrific team. It's the least painful way to go, and in the case of the Los Angeles Rams, a legitimate way to go.

title: Lawyers Being Enlisted For Grenada Detainees
description: The interim Government is recruiting Caribbean legal experts to help speed the legal process for at least 35 Grenadians detained after the United States invasion two months ago, an official said Saturday.

title: FRENCH BLASTS: CALLERS CLAIM ROLE
description: Newspaper and railroad offices received a half-dozen calls today claiming responsibility for the bombings Saturday night of a Marseilles station and a passenger train that killed 4 people and wounded at least 40.

title: ILLINI COACH'S PLAN ISN'T 'NUTTY' NOW
description: Four years ago, in a corridor at Point Pleasant Borough High School in New Jersey, a lineman named Bob Stowe listened to a college coach talk of his plans for the future.

title: Same Subway Token Despite Fare Increase
description: After keeping the fact a secret until almost the last minute, the Transit Authority decided at 11:30 last night to keep the present subway and bus tokens despite the fare increase to 90 cents from 75 cents that occurred at 12:01 this morning.

title: SPOTLIGHT OF TV SERIES ANNOYING NAPA VALLEY
description: Fans of the prime-time series ''Falcon Crest'' are swelling the wave of tourism in Napa Valley, California's wine-making capital, and local officials say the new popularity is threatening to disrupt the area's small-town way of life.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Revised Timetable

title: SLAYING OF BOY STUNS REFUGEE FAMILY
description: Chrysanthemums and red carnations lay frozen on the ground where the snow was cleared last week in Ottawa, Ill., to bury 12- year-old Aly Thao. He had died violently in the country to which the family had fled to leave a violent war behind.

title: LARGENT FINALLY RECOGNIZED
description: It is probably no coincidence that the same wide receiver caught the most important passes in each of the playoff victories that put the Seattle Seahawks in the American Conference championship game next Sunday against the Raiders in Los Angeles.

title: I.M.F. GIRDS TO MEET BIDS FOR AID
description: Argentina's new Economics Minister, Bernardo Grinspun, will be among the first of 1984's official visitors to Washington, and one of the first places he will head is the International Monetary Fund, a couple of blocks from the White House.

title: U.S.F.L. Schedule

title: CONFETTI UNDERFOOT AND QUIET PURSUITS: A NEW YEAR IN NEW YORK OPENS SOFTLY
description: As 1984 dawned, the city belonged to the stragglers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Corrupt and inept leadership is the source of immorality and impropriety in our society. We shall remain here and salvage the country together.'' - Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari of Nigeria. (1:6.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cage on Cactuses

title: Defaulter's Hot Seat Carl M. Halvorson took over as chairman of the executive board of the Washington Public Power Supply System in December 1982, ''as I felt I had some background that would be helpful.'' But, he says, he has found himself ''cursed and reviled'' by rate payers and bond holders.
description: They are angry at the power system for allowing plans for five nuclear plants, costing $24 billion, to spin out of control, for terminating two plants in January 1982, and for defaulting last July on $2.25 billion in bonds for the scrapped plants.

title: UTILITIES STRIVE TO FINISH NINE MILE 2 UNDAUNTED BY COST AND LONG DELAYS
description: The Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear reactor under construction here is a decade behind schedule, is almost three years from operation and has a price tag 12 times the original estimate.

title: BRADSHAW PONDERS HIS FUTURE
description: Terry Bradshaw, the 35-year-old quarterback who led the Pittsburgh Steelers to their record four Super Bowl championships, spoke vaguely about his football future today after having stood on the sideline throughout a 38-10 loss to the Los Angeles Raiders in the American Conference playoffs.

title: OUTDOORS: COLD CLOSE TO THE DUCK SEASON
description: IF in your salad days you steeped

title: STAY IN UNESCO
description: President Reagan's decision to withdraw the United States from Unesco has been defended on political grounds, with little or no reference to the educational, scientific and cultural value of our participation in the United Nations organization. Whatever its political merits, withdrawal will deal a serious blow to the scientific community of the United States.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: FACES EAST The Soviet Union has one of the largest Jewish populations of the world. Yet, except for news of dissidents and emigres, the world gets little sense of the diversity of these 2.5 million Jews or of the way they lead their lives in a country that is at the same time changing and changeless. A window, in the form of two photography exhibitions, looks in on their communities at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street (860- 1888).

title: Patrick Talks to Ex-Ranger
description: The Rangers left here this morning for Washington without their general manager, Craig Patrick, who went to Toronto, where he had a meeting planned with Chris Kontos.

title: BUTCHER SEES COLLAPSE OF A $3 BILLION EMPIRE
description: For Jacob F. Butcher, the flamboyant Tennessean whose banking empire crumbled in 1983, the year could hardly have been worse.

title: FOR RECOVERED ALCOHOLICS, SUPPORT ON VACATIONS
description: The brilliant sun has set, and Philipsburg, the capital of the Dutch half of this Caribbean island, is crowded with tourists meandering from one ''happy hour'' to another, sampling the various bartender specials. The concoctions have alluring names - Paradise Punch, Island Fantasy, Sea Breeze.

title: MUSIC: ST. LUKE'S GROUP PRESENTS 'AGE OF JOSQUIN'
description: It is impossible to know what the greatest composer of the High Renaissance, Josquin des Prez, would have made of the scene at Times Square on New Year's Eve, or what sort of music he would be composing were he alive to welcome in 1984.

title: FIXING THE BLAME
description: President Reagan has accepted the responsibility - and well he might - for the Marines' lack of preparedness in Lebanon and for the many resulting casualties. At first glance, this may look like a magnanimous Presidential gesture; in fact, it places the blame precisely where it belongs.

title: VOLCKER KEEPS JOB, CRITICS, INFLUENCE
description: For two months last spring, Paul A. Volcker was more than ever the talk of the financial community. Rumors swirled about the possible reappointment of the man who, as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, was blamed by many for the recession of 1982 but also credited for last year's economic recovery.

title: U.S. PRESSES JAPAN TO HALT ITS WHALE HUNTING
description: The Reagan Administration is applying heavy economic and diplomatic pressure to persuade Japan to end commercial whaling.

title: HOLIDAY PARTY INSPIRED 'HUMAN COMEDY' OPERA
description: Fittingly enough, for a story whose themes revolve around the shared bonds of family and community and the transcendent power of love, it all began at a family Christmas party two years ago. As part of the celebration, Galt MacDermot's brother-in- law, who is an English professor, gave each of the children something to read aloud. Mr. MacDermot's son was to deliver an excerpt from William Saroyan's ''Human Comedy.''

title: BRITISH MOVE FAST IN HOME BANKING
description: While American banks have been cautiously testing consumer interest in electronic home banking, a British savings bank has decided to bypass pilot programs and has plunged into a full-scale effort, offering a wide range of banking and nonbanking services.

title: The F.A.A. Enigma and Imperative
description: J. Lynn Helms has been a highly competent administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, His decision to resign comes in the wake of a highly unfavorable article about his private business activities. That he should have succeeded so well in his public duties but left such an apparently murky trail in his private business matters is a paradox that awaits resolution.

title: SOVIET BLOC IS REPORTED TO INFLATE AID FIGURES
description: A British Government study of foreign aid contends that the aid given to developing countries by the Soviet bloc is actually far smaller than the amounts the Soviet Union and the Eastern European countries claim to give.

title: POP: MANHATTAN TRANSFER
description: In its 11-year career, The Manhattan Transfer has refined a four-part vocal blend that is as stylistically adaptable as it is precise in pitch and inflection. As the group's mastery of different styles of vocal harmonizing has grown, its shows have lost the air of theatrical preciousness that initially suggested an ironic camp nostalgia.

title: LATE RALLY FOR WORLD STOCKS
description: Foreign stock markets, which began 1983 lagging behind the fast clip of the New York exchange, turned decidedly bullish in the last half of the year and outpaced the market strength in this country.

title: ISLANDERS WIN, 7-3
description: For Coach Al Arbour, the Islanders' 7-3 victory over Minnesota North Stars Saturday night was one of their most important.

title: Pitt and Ohio State: A Kind of Reunion
description: Although Ohio State and Pittsburgh meet in football for the first time in 30 years in the annual Fiesta Bowl here Monday, the schools have been ongoing rivals in recruiting. And both coaches said that trend would continue.

title: Yellow Fire Trucks Rejected
description: This city plans to paint all its fire trucks red again. Firefighters here found the fluorescent yellow trucks, adopted five years ago on experts' advice, did not show up well against snow and were difficult to see under the yellowish glow of sodium street lights.

title: Florida Growers to Use Pesticide Banned for '83
description: Florida citrus growers plan to apply the pesticide Temik to more than 85,000 acres now that a ban on its use has expired, state officials say.

title: CULTURES COLORBLIND TO A 'WINE-DARK SEA,' HOMERIC OR NOT
description: To the Editor: No doubt every Greek scholar within 500 miles has written to advise you that ''wine-dark sea'' is not Homeric.

title: SERVED IN CONGRESS 20 YEARS
description: Former Representative Byron G. Rogers, who served 10 terms in Congress and was regarded by colleagues as a champion of civil rights, died at the Rose Medical Center here Saturday. He was 83 years old.

title: PANEL SEEKS RISE IN COMPUTER JOBS
description: An advisory panel has recommended that Governor Cuomo adopt an ambitious plan to use the Urban Development Corporation to help spur growth in high-technology industries in New York State.

title: Howard Shire, Lawyer Wed to Miss Eisenstat
description: Howard Shire, a lawyer, and Sharon Eisenstat, a law student, were married yesterday at the Emanu-El Jewish Center in Mount Vernon, N.Y., by Rabbi Philip M. Weinberger.

title: JOB FUNDS UNIT BARS BERKELEY IN DISPUTE OVER PLEDGE TO FLAG
description: An agency handling county job-training funds has voted to keep the City of Berkeley off its governing board as punishment for the City Council's refusal to salute the American flag before its meetings.

title: Sahara Rebel Force Says It Killed 154 Moroccans
description: The Polisario Front said today that its guerrillas had killed 154 Moroccan soldiers and destroyed 40 vehicles in a new, large-scale offensive in Western Sahara.

title: CULTURES COLORBLIND TO A 'WINE-DARK SEA,' HOMERIC OR NOT
description: To the Editor:

title: Markets Closed Today
description: All United States stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of the New Year's holiday, as well as banks, government offices and many businesses. Foreign stock exchanges will also be closed.

title: DEFICIT FIGHTERS UNITE!
description: To the Editor:

title: TORIES FEAR THEY'VE LOST THEIR ZIP
description: Despite the continuing popularity of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, her governing Conservative Party has begun to slip in the opinion polls and a number of party leaders say they are starting to fear that the Government is running out of steam.

title: Ski Meet Shifted For Lack of Snow
description: The World Cup men's ski meet Saturday will be transferred from a French to a Swiss slope because of insufficient snow, the French Ski Federation said today.

title: A DEAL MAKER TURNS TO GETTY
description: J. Hugh Liedtke, the chairman of the Pennzoil Company who made news last week by offering to buy 20 percent of the Getty Oil Company for $1.6 billion, is ranked by many in the oil industry as one of its most creative deal makers. But he is reluctant to say just what he wants to achieve in his biggest adventure yet.

title: Erica Hickman Marries Winfield Scott Downs 3d
description: Erica Delius Hickman and Winfield Scott Downs 3d, assistant vice presidents of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Edward Alley Downs, uncle of the bridegroom, and the Rev. Charles C. Green, both Episcopal priests, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Hampton Hickman 3d, in Geneseo, N.Y.

title: Space Mountain Wins at Aqueduct
description: Oak Manor Farm's Space Mountain, ridden by Tony Graell, squeezed through along the rail in a late rally yesterday to score a three-quarter- length victory in the $70,900 Paumonok Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: Blue Is Starting His Prison Term
description: Vida Blue, the former Cy Young Award winner, began serving tonight a three-month prison term for possessing cocaine.

title: A MOSCOW NEW YEAR: CHAMPAGNE AND ILL-GOTTEN FIRS
description: At the stroke of midnight from the chimes of the Kremlin's Spassky Tower, fresh sentries took their places at Lenin's mausoleum and bedlam broke out on Red Square.

title: A NATIONALIST FOR NIGERIANS
description: Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari, who announced today that he had assumed power in the aftermath of Saturday's military coup in Nigeria, is described by diplomats as an ardent nationalist who is tough, self-assured and somewhat austere. ''If anyone was going to take things over, it would have been him,'' said an American diplomat who knows him. ''He has a lot of drive and a lot of interest in doing something for his country.''

title: MONDAY, JANUARY 2, 1984 International
description: Nigeria's takeover by the army was confirmed by a general. Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari announced that he had assumed authority following the military coup Saturday that toppled the country's civilian Government led by President Shehu Shagari. The general, who served as Nigerian oil minister in the 1970's, said a new ''federal Government'' had taken over in order ''to save this nation from imminent collapse.'' He said that Nigerians had been living under ''difficult and degrading conditions.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) El Salvador's major bridge was destroyed by leftist guerrillas after they had routed several hundred Government troops assigned to guard it. The quarter-mile long Cuscatlan bridge was the last suspension bridge open to motorists traveling to the eastern part of the country, but motorists could still cross the river using a nearby dam. The loss of the bridge was a serious economic setback, the Defense Ministry said. (1:4.)

title: Bridge: A Pan-American Title Goes To a Team From New York
description: A New York team went a long way to win a title last week: Marty Bergen of White Plains and Brian Glubok, Ethan Stein and Joel Friedberg, all of New York, were victorious in Sao Paulo, Brazil, at the Maccabi Games.

title: CUOMO SIGNS BILL TO LET THE CITY REGULATE ITS 35,000 GYPSY CABS
description: Governor Cuomo has signed a bill strengthening New York City's regulatory power over more than 35,000 nonmedallion cabs.

title: Boris Schwarz Is Dead; Violinist and Teacher
description: Boris Schwarz, who followed early success as a violinist with a distinguished career in musicology, died Saturday night in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Long Road to a Baptism

title: Four People Are Killed InSeparateCityBlazes
description: Four people were killed early yesterday in separate fires in New York City, the Fire Department said.

title: REAGAN HOLIDAY: GOLF, PARTIES, A BIRTH AND A DEATH
description: It has become such a tradition for President Reagan to spend his New Year's holiday with friends at this resort community that White House aides have come to take a relaxed attitude toward it.

title: Cartoonist Killed By Stolen Truck
description: Frank Baginski, a cartoonist, was killed early yesterday when a stolen telephone company truck crashed into the car he was driving in Greenwich Village, the police said.

title: Magellan's Top Picker Of Stocks Wall Street's hottest hand these days works out of Boston, from his office at Fidelity's Magellan Fund. He says he lets others worry about the market - ''I worry about what stocks to buy.''
description: He is Peter Lynch, the 40-year-old portfolio manager of the nation's best-performing mutual fund. In the first nine months of 1983, shares in the Magellan Fund increased 41 percent in value, well above the 16 percent rise of the Standard & Poor's 500- stock index.

title: POLITICAL PRISONERS HELD BY CUBA STIR U.S. DISPUTES
description: The 25th anniversary of the Cuban revolution today comes at a time when there are sharp disagreements in the United States about how to help Cuba's political prisoners.

title: College Football
description: Texas vs. Georgia, Cotton Bowl, at Dallas. The Longhorns (11-0), making their 18th Cotton Bowl appearance, could claim the unofficial national title if they win and Nebraska loses tonight in the Orange Bowl. Georgia (9-1-1) lost only to Auburn, 13-7, and had a 16- 16 tie with Clemson. Terry Hoage, the Georgia roverback, led the nation in interceptions in 1982 with 12. Texas has standout defensive backs in Mossy Cade, who led his team with 6 interceptions for 114 yards, and the free safety Jerry Gray, who led the team with 116 tackles. (Television - Channel 2, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 1:30 P.M.).

title: Japan Is Rocked By a Strong Quake
description: A powerful earthquake deep beneath the earth's surface rocked Japan today, swaying high-rise buildings and disrupting air and rail traffic, but no damage or casualties were reported.

title: Finance Minister Leads Mexico Through Crisis On Aug. 12, 1982, Jesus Silva Herzog, Mexico's Finance Minister, told the United States Government that his country would run out of money in four days. Since then, despite foreign debts outstanding of about $86 billion, Mexico's financial health has improved markedly.
description: Last year, Mexico signed no fewer than 27 agreements with international banks to help restructure its public sector debt. Just last week, it completed negotiations to raise $3.8 billion, on more favorable terms than a previous loan in March, to cover its financing needs for 1984.

title: RAIDERS ROUT STEELERS
description: Parity in the National Football League? For today, at any rate, it disappeared behind one of the most commanding team performances in the history of the playoffs as the Washington Redskins routed the Los Angeles Rams by 51-7.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Closing Gender Gap

title: AMID MANY DAIQUIRIS, A CLUB CLOSES
description: When they built it in 1912, the members of the Army and Navy Club predicted that their Italian Renaissance-style clubhouse would ''stand forever'' as the legacy of men who fought Indians on the frontier, introduced the daiquiri to the United States and planned the mission to send the famous ''message to Garcia'' in the Spanish- American War.

title: PHILADELPHIA AWAITS ITS NEW MAYOR
description: W. Wilson Goode was looking beyond Monday, when he will become the first black Mayor of this 301-year-old city. William J. Green, the Mayor he will succeed, could afford to reminisce.

title: TEXAS COACH WINS IN LOW-KEY STYLE
description: There are romantics who would like to envision Dallas as still being part of the old West, where cowboy boots and 10-gallon hats were a necessity rather than fashion and where the bars were called saloons and someone would be tossed out the swinging doors before the day was over. Fred Akers, the Texas football coach, can identify with the problem of overcoming stereotypes.

title: WESTERN EUROPE ENDS INDUSTRIAL TRADE CURBS
description: The last barriers to complete industrial free trade between 17 West European nations disappeared today.

title: Marie Eichelberger, Ex-Head O
description: Marie E. Eichelberger, a former executive director of the Institute for Intercultural Studies, died last Thursday at the Isabella Geriatric Center in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 89 years old.

title: Books of The Times Murdoch in London
description: GOOD TIMES, BAD TIMES. By Harold

title: ; CULTURES COLORBLIND TO A 'WINE-DARK SEA,' HOMERIC OR NOT
description: To the Editor:

title: Truck Inspections Resume in Jersey
description: With the arrival of the new year, owners of light trucks registered in New Jersey lost their exemption from annual state inspection.

title: HELP FOR SIBLINGS OF YOUNG CANCER VICTIMS
description: At times they are neither seen nor heard, the brothers and sisters of children who are cancer patients. ''Sometimes so much attention is paid to your sick brother or sister,'' said Dr. Aaron R. Rausen to the hushed circle of children about him, ''that you feel ignored, and almost left out.''

title: Dr. Steven Greer Is Wed To Elsie Levin in Florida
description: Elsie Levin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Levin of Miami, was married yesterday to Dr. Steven Greer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Greer of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Michael B. Eisenstat performed the ceremony at Temple Judea in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Oklahoma Prison Suit Is Dismissed by Judge
description: A Federal district judge, ruling that Oklahoma's prison system was constitutional, has dismissed a civil rights lawsuit that had led to more than a decade of major penal reforms that cost the state more than $200 million.

title: Illness Traced To Lab Rats
description: AVIRUS disease that can be carried by rodents has made its first confirmed appearance in laboratory rats outside the Far East and produced the first known rat-to-human infections outside that region, according to a report in the Dec. 24 issue of The Lancet, a medical journal published in London.

title: FRANCE IS MOVING 25% OF ITS TROOPS AWAY FROM BEIRUT
description: France announced today that it would remove about 25 percent of its troops serving with the four-nation force here.

title: REAGAN 'HOSTILITY' TO RIGHTS CITED
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has accused the Reagan Administration of demonstrating ''an unprecedented hostility'' toward civil rights and freedom of speech in 1983.

title: Listed below are the planned release dates for major economic indicators to be reported this week
description: Tuesday

title: Chess: Two Finish in First-Place Tie In Copenhagen Tournament
description: The Politiken Cup Tournament in Copenhagen was won by Istvan Csom, a Hungarian grandmaster, and Sergei Kudrin, a Russian emigre international master from Stamford, Conn. Each scored 5 1/2-3 1/2, a point less than the grandmaster norm Kudrin was aiming for.

title: NO LEBANON REFUND
description: The pressure to withdraw U.S. marines from Lebanon is building strongly. It is understandable. They are doing nothing more in that unhappy country than trying to protect themselves.

title: Moving the Disabled
description: While 88 New York City subway stations linger in disrepair, the money to fix them lingers unused in the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's account. A court decision, based on state law, forbids their reconstruction unless they are simultaneously made usable for people in wheelchairs.

title: DATED SLANG
description: To the Editor:

title: More Unidentified Bodies Discovered in Argentina
description: More unidentified bodies were reportedly discovered in cemeteries throughout Argentina over the weekend as an investigation of the activities during military rule continued.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Change of Scene

title: BULLDOGS, IN RALLY, UPSET TEXAS
description: The ovations that greeted the Texas defense every time it stopped Georgia were going to be mere rehearsals for the roar that would greet the players when the game ended. The Longhorns had staked their national reputation on the defense; they had won all 11 regular-season games because the defense gave up ground grudgingly.

title: Unexploded Shell Lands On Suburban Patio
description: A dud shell of World War II vintage whistled through the sky and landed with a ''resounding crash'' on a back- yard patio, leaving a crater four feet deep, officials said today.

title: EULOGY FOR MA BELL
description: To the Editor:

title: Peron in 1953 Tried To Buy the Falklands
description: Juan Domingo Peron, the Argentine dictator, tried to buy the Falkland Islands from Britain in 1953 but was told the sale would cause the overthrow of the British Government, according to newly published state records.

title: Arrows Triumph
description: Doc Lawson and Michael Collins scored fourth-period goals within 48 seconds to give the New York Arrows a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Steamers in a Major Indoor Soccer League game tonight at Nassau Coliseum before 5,437 fans.

title: A Bitter Latin Coup
description: The Reagan Administration's effort to wreck a small but esteemed nonpartisan operation in Latin America proves how desperately it prefers doctrinal purity to effective policy. The Inter-American Foundation has been a highly useful aid agency whose nonpartisan character was prescribed by Congress and respected by three previous Administrations. That concept was finally scuttled when the foundation's board, with Congress away, voted on party lines to fire its respected director, for slight and suspect reasons.

title: El Nino Onslaught Is Reported Ended
description: The latest onslaught of El Nino, a Pacific Ocean warming phenomenon blamed for widespread weather disruptions, has disappeared with a return of cold water, a Duke University scientist says.

title: WILLIAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
UNBEATEN DEPAUL SCORES 10TH VICTORY
description: Unbeaten DePaul, led by Tyrone Corbin's 14 points, rolled past Biscayne College in basketball today, 78-50, for its 10th victory. It was also their 16th straight at home over two seasons and their 98th triumph in the last 101 home games.

title: MAKING ROUNDS: AIDS ROOMS
description: THE doctor suffered what, strictly speaking, was a minor accident, the kind that is surprisingly common in hospitals and offices. While suturing a patient, his hands slipped and he jabbed himself with the needle. But this accident could not be taken lightly. The patient had the deadly disease known as acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). And the physician nearly panicked.

title: 121-YARD DAY HIGHLIGHTS ALLEN'S SEASON
description: The significance of Marcus Allen's moment was there for the crowd of more than 90,000 at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum to see. He had just carried the football for a 49-yard touchdown run, his longest in a season that has been, all at once, successful and disappointing.

title: Rose Kennedy Condition Fair
description: Rose Kennedy's release from St. Mary's Hospital was delayed today and she will continue to receive treatment there for a viral infection in her chest until at least Wednesday, the family said.

title: Advertising; Winning Accounts At Ogilvy
description: IT gave Kenneth Roman special pleasure when Investors Diversified Services decided last fall to move its account into Ogilvy & Mather, U.S. It meant another vote of confidence by American Express, whose credit card had long been handled by the agency. American Express was preparing to acquire I.D.S. and was calling a number of the shots.

title: STOCK ANALYSTS SEE GAINS IN '84
description: WHAT is in store for stocks in 1984? As they peer ahead, analysts are generally optimistic about the outlook for equities.

title: Kentucky 68 Mississippi 55
description: Kentucky stayed unbeaten, breaking open a tight Southeastern Conference game in the second half for its ninth triumph.

title: OHIO STATE DEFEATS PITT WITH 0:39 TO GO
description: Mike Tomczak's 39-yard touchdown pass to the split end Thad Jemison with 39 seconds remaining gave Ohio State a 28-23 victory over Pittsburgh in the 13th annual Fiesta Bowl today.

title: Suits Against Power Supply System SEATTLE, Jan. 2 (AP) - Utilities and investment companies had doubts about the Washington Public Power Supply System's plans to build two nuclear power plants - now suspended - even before the first of $2.25 billion of bonds were sold to finance the plants, suits on the behalf of bondholders charge.
description: Details of the two suits were disclosed in amended complaints filed last week, charging that more than 200 defendants violated Federal securities law. The suits were begun after the power system, in the largest municipal bond default ever, said in July that it could not repay the bond debt.

title: RAYMOND HOOD AND HIS VISIONS OF SKYSCRAPERS
description: THERE is not much that cools the blood more than the phrase ''visionary scheme'' except possibly the words ''architect's dream.'' A lot of this disdain for great, sweeping visions is based on the fact that large-scale planning has only rarely served us well, that it has all-too-frequently been conceived in arrogance and resulted in disaster. But at least some of this current mood must be written off as just simple cynicism - an unwillingness to trust, or even respect, any kind of broad vision at all.

title: SUPER RITE FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
3 Youths Arrested In Subway Attack
description: Three teen-agers suspected in a string of subway robberies were arrested yesterday and charged with robbing and assaulting a deaf-mute aboard a Manhattan train, the Transit Authority police said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: City Lights

title: PAGODA IN BERKSHIRE HAMLET BURNS AFTER ANTI-VIETNAM PHONECALLS
description: An anonymous caller said he and other angry veterans of the Vietnam War were responsible for a suspicious fire that razed a small Buddhist temple in this rural Berkshire town.

title: To Regulate or Not to Regulate
description: With the ''deregulation'' of some basic services, the citizen is being implored to think well or ill of regulation as such. How to think about that?

title: IRAQ AND IRAN CLAIM SUCCESSES IN BATTLES OVER PERSIAN GULF
description: Iraq and Iran fought sea and air battles over the Persian Gulf today in which five Iranian vessels were reported sunk and two Iraqi warplanes were shot down, according to communiques.

title: QUEEN CHIDES BRITISH PRESS FOR 'HARASSMENT'
description: Queen Elizabeth II said today that the British press had been ''harassing'' the royal family and asked editors to withdraw reporters and photographers from her Sandringham estate.

title: STRAINED SESSION EXECTED IN ALBANY
description: News Analysis

title: CENSORSHIP RISES IN THE NATION'S PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: MANY Americans who condemn the burning of books as a virulent form of totalitarian thought control close their eyes to the evil of banning books. Censorship, many people believe, is something that happens in faraway, undemocratic countries.

title: CHINESE PARTY DEMANDS PUNISHMENT OF ITS AIDES WHO ABUSE THEIR POWER
description: China's Communist Party issued a new directive today calling for punishment of party functionaries who have used their power to advance themselves and their relatives.

title: STRONG DOLLAR STIRS NEW CONCERNS
description: Economic Analysis

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Missi*g Li*k

title: Debt Issues
description: * Dicomed Corp., Minneapolis, has arranged $7.5 million in financing, through the issuance of 12-year, 12 percent unsecured senior notes.

title: Miss Bunge Out In First Round
description: Bonnie Gadusek, an unseeded player from Largo, Fla., upset third-seeded Bettina Bunge today, 6-1, 6-4, in the opening round of the Virginia Slims of Washington tennis tournament.

title: Dollar, Gold Rise Abroad LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP) - The dollar gained ground in Europe today, the first day of trading for 1984, but activity was limited because most markets were closed.
description: Gold rose to $383.82 an ounce in Frankfurt, the only major European bullion market operating, from $379.99 Friday.

title: 2 Held in Boy's Death Reportedly Try Suicide
description: Two of the three teen-agers charged with killing the son of a Laotian missionary in a highway robbery tried to hang themselves with bath towels in their jail cell, officials said today.

title: O'ROURKE INAUGURATED IN WESTCHESTER
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, pledging to ''vigorously'' pursue solutions to the problems of Westchester's troubled cities, was sworn in today to a two-year elected term as the County Executive.

title: VOWS ARMED FIGHT
description: Yasir Arafat today repeated his longstanding criticism of President Reagan's Middle East peace plan and vowed to continue an armed struggle for an independent Palestine.

title: THE BAR WILL STAND BY ITS JUDGES-IF ASKED
description: To the Editor:

title: THIS PARLIAMENTARIAN COULD SET A PRECEDENT
description: In the history of the United States Senate, only four persons have held the job of parliamentarian, all men. But with perserverance and luck, Gail M. Cowper might become the first woman.

title: JACKSON SEES ASSAD, THEN IS ASKED NOT TO LEAVE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met for nearly an hour and a half with President Hafez al-Assad today but received no answer to his request that Syria free a captured United States flier.

title: Change for Petty
description: For the first time in 25 years, Richard Petty this season will be driving a stock car that hasn't been prepared by Petty Enterprises, the family business, which will be run by his 23-year- old son, Kyle. Instead, the elder Petty will be racing for the Rahmoc team of Kannapolis, N.C., and the new setup has him enthusiastic about 1984.

title: Stuart N. Updike Dead at 79; Ex-Counsel to The Daily News
description: Stuart N. Updike, former counsel to The Daily News and the Publishers Association of New York City, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Old Saybrook, Conn. He was 79 years old.

title: Industry Gain Seen by U.S.
description: Most of the nation's industries will improve in 1984 as the economic recovery spreads through more businesses, according to a Commerce Department report released today.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Los Angeles Lakers , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar pays his only Garden visit of the season.

title: AUBURN, GEORGIA WIN
description: In one of the most stunning and exciting reversals in the history of bowl games, Miami raced to a 17-0 lead in the first quarter and then had to stop a 2-point conversion attempt with 48 seconds left to upset previously undefeated Nebraska, 31-30, in the Orange Bowl tonight.

title: FRENCH BOMBINGS: 2 MORE CLAIMS MADE
description: Two more groups claimed responsibility today for New Year's Eve bombings in Marseilles and aboard a high-speed train en route from Marseilles to Paris.

title: NIGERIAN GENERAL DELIVERS WARNING
description: Nigeria's new military ruler said today that his regime would jail dishonest civil servants without bothering with the ''nonsenses'' of trials, according to a Lagos radio broadcast monitored here.

title: SOME FIRST-TIME DONORS TELL WHY THEY HELP THE NEEDIEST
description: Among the many people who are contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund for the first time are some who wrote letters explaining why.

title: ELECTRONIC GAMES THAT CHALLENGE VERBAL SKILLS
description: MODERN electronic technology is still making inroads on such traditional leisure-time activities as reading. As television once did, now home computers are leading the eyes of the nation away from the printed page and toward the ubiquitous screen.

title: COCAINE SURVEY POINTS TO WIDESPREAD ANGUISH
description: AN extensive new survey indicates that the use of cocaine continues to increase dramatically in the United States and that the problems associated with it are far worse than many people had believed.

title: A Better Game
description: Jo^ao Havelange , the president of soccer's world governing body, the Federation Internationale de Football Association, says the quality of play at the Olympic Games next summer will be higher than in previous Olympic tournaments, thanks to a rules change. ''Now teams can have players who receive a payment within the profession as long as they can prove they have a second occupation, be it as a student or a job,'' he said.

title: OPOSSUMS SHOW A MEMORY FOR POISONS
description: THE experimenter watched as the young opossum sniffed warily at the mushroom that had been placed in front of him. The mushroom, Amanita muscaria, was a less toxic cousin of Amanita phalloides, the ''destroying angel,'' one bite of which could kill a man. But opossums love mushrooms, and the animal quickly chewed and swallowed the fungus, which, though not fatally toxic, contained a small amount of naturally occurring muscimol, a noxious chemical.

title: NEW HAVEN THEATER IS BIDDING TO REVIVE ITS ONETIME GLORIES
description: Fenno Heath stood on a near- empty stage and addressed the hundreds of volunteer singers seated in the audience.

title: NEW YORK ; SURROUNDED BY GIVERS
description: I've been away from this post since August, recuperating from heart bypass surgery. There was much time to think. I felt it might be appropriate to share some of those thoughts with you.
