title: China Says Emergency Steps Cut the Crime Rate by 40%
description: The Chinese Government said today that it had cut the overall crime rate in late 1983 by just under 40 percent through emergency measures enacted to end a nationwide wave of lawlessness.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Easing the Pain

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Point of the Poster

title: LIBRARY DISPLAYS THE POET'S SEARCH FOR PERFECTION
description: In the exhibition called ''Exaltation of Poetry,'' now on view at the New York Public Library, there is a page of scrawled verse by Walt Whitman. Nearly every line is scratched out or interlineated. It is hard to tell how many starts and stops went into ''Come, Said My Soul,'' the poem he used as the title-page epigraph for several editions of ''Leaves of Grass.''

title: MORE JUDGESHIPS URGED BY BURGER
description: The nation needs more Federal judges to prevent backlogs and delay in its judicial system, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger says.

title: 7 Frenchmen Killed in Crash
description: Seven French workers were killed near here today and another was seriously injured when the bus they were riding in collided with a truck whose driver failed to yield the right-of-way, the police reported. The Frenchmen, who all lived in France, were traveling to a construction site near Stuttgart, the police said.

title: FOR OLD UNION STATION, A 2D CHANCE TO BE NEW
description: It was built to be one of America's grandest and busiest train stations, a Beaux Arts structure of gleaming granite and marble, of soaring columns and cavernous halls that was one of the most distinctive buildings in Washington. There was a time when the powerful and famous - legislators, Cabinet secretaries, generals, even Presidents - passed through it routinely.

title:
TALKING BUSINESS/WITH GUTFREUND OF SALOMON BROTHERS;
Bond House's Push on Stock
description: In 1980 Salomon Brothers Inc. charged ahead of the competition on Wall Street by issuing more debt than anyone else, but it barely made the top 10 list of underwriters of common stock. However, last year Salonom Brothers jumped to third place in stock offerings, while keeping its No. 1 position in debt underwritings, according to Abrahamsen & Company, a statistical research firm.

title: QUADRIPLEGIC'S EFFORTS TO DIE STIR DEEP LEGAL AND ETHICAL ISSUES
description: Elizabeth Bouvia appears to be mentally competent to decide her own fate. Having chosen death, however, the 26-year-old quadriplegic is not capable of acting on her decision.

title: SCOUTING
description: Dancing Devils

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Tricky Card

title: 4TH-QUARTER PROFIT JUMP IS FORECAST
description: Reflecting the growing economy and severe cost-cutting, corporate profits for the fourth quarter are expected to show another solid advance, economists and industry analysts say.

title: Nicaragua Reports 40 Rebels Were Killed in Raid on Town
description: Nicaragua said today that 40 rebels were killed in an attack on a town during a visit there by Adolfo Perez Esquivel, the Argentine Nobel peace laureate

title: AND NOW, THE 'MINIMAL' LOOK
description: After many seasons of snug, clinging clothes, the pendulum has swung to fashion with a relaxed look. ''Minimal'' is a word used repeatedly to characterize next spring's clothes. Jackets come without collars. Necklines of blouses or sweaters are gently scooped. Skirts flow easily.

title: GREEKS ARE SEEKING U.S. HELP OVER CYPRUS
description: Greek and Greek Cypriot leaders are looking to the United Nations to come up with a solution to the political problem in Cyprus and to the United States to persuade Turkey to comply with it, Greek and Greek Cypriot officials say.

title: REPORT URGES STEPS TO SLOW DOWN CLIMATE WARMING
description: AGLOBAL strategy to reduce a potentially dangerous increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide has been outlined by engineers and economists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Stanford University.

title: PENNSYLVANIANS' ILLNESS MAY BE CAUSED BY BEAVERS
description: -BARRE, Pa., Jan. 2- Contamination of a reservoir is forcing 110,000 people in 17 northeastern Pennsylvania towns to boil water for drinking and cooking, and the state says it appears beavers are responsible.

title: HOUSE LEADERS URGE NEW STUDY OF BEIRUT POLICY
description: Democratic and Republican leaders in the House said today that a reassessment of United States policy in Lebanon was vital.

title: ILLINI EMBARASSED BY U.C.L.A., 45-9
description: This Rose Bowl was supposed to be different. Twenty years had passed since Illinois represented the Big Ten Conference here at the start of a new year.

title: Dance Official Named
description: Igor Youskevitch, former premier danseur of Ballet Theater and the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, has been named artistic director of the first New York International Ballet Competition. Mr. Youskevitch succeeds Richard Thomas, who resigned from the post in November. Mr. Yoskevitch will head the competition with Ilona Copen, its executive director. The competition, one of five international competitions for young ballet dancers that are held around the world, is to take place in late June at City Center.

title: FROM A LOLLIPOP TO A PUMPKIN: SUBWAY DELAYS
description: A subway train got stuck on a lollipop the other day.

title: NUCLEAR POWER INDUSTRY'S SCAPEGOAT
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: There's Always Some Room For Another Significant Idea
description: In the nearly 60 years since contract bridge became popular, one might suppose that all basic bidding situations have been thoroughly explored. But significant ideas are still introduced from time to time. A description of one of them received the 1983 Precision Award for the best article, or series of articles.

title: DESIGNER OUT FOR A CHANGE
description: -name interior designer with big- name clients and a romantic style of work reflecting the understated elegance and charm of English country houses. Even so, he's ready for what amounts to a furnishings revolution.

title: Cairo Party Wins Legal Fight
description: The only opposition party believed capable of winning enough votes to enter Parliament won a long legal battle for survival today. The victory of the New Wafd Party came when Egypt's Supreme Administrative Court ruled against the argument advanced by the Government that the party's existence was illegal because it disbanded itself in 1978. It said last August that it was resuming political activity.

title: Police in Tunisia Open Fire on Rioters
description: Policemen and national guard units opened fire on rioters in the southern Tunisian town of Gafsa today, causing several casualties, witnesses said.

title: STRANGE ALLIANCE: LEGIONS OF BACTERIA CREATED TO SERVE MAN
description: WITH every new feat of genetic engineering, it becomes increasingly clear that mankind has made one of the strangest and most complex alliances ever achieved with another form of life.

title: AMERICAN AGRONOMICS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
AN INTERVIEW WITH REUBIN ASKEW, EX-GOVERNOR OF FLORIDA
description: Following are key questions and answers from an interview with Reubin Askew by William E. Farrell:

title: 2 Cancer Researchers Are Slain in Laboratory
description: Two cancer researchers have been stabbed to death in a hospital laboratory where they worked, and robbery may have been a motive, according to the police.

title: AMERICAN PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a $1.1 million loss from discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $1 million. c-After a $1.6 million loss from discontinued operations. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: TIGERS SET BACK MICHIGAN BY 9-7
description: For Auburn's coach, Pat Dye, and his players, the easy part is over. Behind three field goals by Al Del Greco, the last one a 19-yarder with 23 seconds left, Auburn defeated Michigan, 9-7, in the 50th Sugar Bowl game tonight.

title: Discord on Browns
description: Robert D. Gries is a 43-percent owner of the Cleveland Browns and a longtime nemesis of the team's majority owner, Art Modell. In fact, the two men are in court now over lawsuits in which Gries accuses Modell of refusing input into decisions affecting the Browns and making business deals that have had adverse effects.

title: SAHARA RESORTS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Revenue figures for both years have been restated to eliminate complimentaries. Sahara Resorts was formerly Hacienda Resorts Inc.

title: NEW CURFEWS ON YOUTHS DUE IN JERSEY
description: Officials in two of New Jersey's largest cities are taking steps to impose new curfews that they hope will keep youngsters off the streets at night. The intent of the ordinances, they say, is to curtail vandalism and petty crime by juveniles.

title: MEMORABLE '83 MARKET MOVES
description: While 1983 was a good year for stocks in general, it was an extraordinarily good year for a few stocks, and an unspeakably bad one for several others.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: THE behavior of the snow leopard, the handsome great cat that lives secretively in the rugged crags of the Himalayas, is being systematically studied for the first time in the wild by a British wildlife biologist.

title: Paris Disputes Gas Report
description: France's state-owned gas company questioned today the accuracy of a report from the Soviet Union Sunday that the Siberia-to-Europe natural gas pipeline has begun delivering gas to France.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''IHATE to go shopping, I can't

title: EDUCATION ISSUES AND ENERGY HIGH ON ALBANY AGENDA
description: The 207th session of the New York State Legislature convenes in Albany tomorrow amid an improving economy and the increasing contentiousness of an election year.

title: SCOUTING
description: Generals Active In Marketplace

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Barry J. Galt, the new chairman and chief executive officer of the Houston-based Seagull Energy Corporation, grew up 12 miles from the Healdton Field, an oil bonanza in south-central Oklahoma that is still producing. His great uncles owned a big piece of it, but his grandfather did not.

title: Boxer in Coma Dies in Italy
description: Salvatore La Serra, an Italian

title: SCOUTING
description: One More Time

title: Tucker to Start for Knicks
description: Trent Tucker, who has played in only 1 of the last 10 games, seeing just 6 minutes of action, moved into the Knicks' starting backcourt yesterday as Coach Hubie Brown carried out his promise that ''something will be done.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Toshio Komoto, who was named last week as director-general of Japan's Economic Planning Agency, thinks there is little wrong with Japan that faster growth will not cure. In a nation that is first and foremost an economic power, Mr. Komoto's view is surprisingly controversial.

title: CIVIL DEFENSE IS CRUCIAL
description: About 40 million Americans are likely to survive a worst-case large-scale nuclear attack, even without any protective measures. The total absence of civil defense preparations, the public's all but complete ignorance of the realities of nuclear war and the consequent potential for an exacerbation of a nuclear tragedy are among the most dangerous characteristics of our present defense effort which neglects one thing - protective defense.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CHARLES DE GAULLE: A Biography. By Don Cook. 437 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95.

title: A PLAY AND ITS AUTHOR MATURE
description: THE two heroines of Wendy Wasserstein's comedy, ''Isn't It Romantic,'' are both uncommon women. Janie Blumberg, a novice writer, is a tad overweight, a little lazy and far too witty for her own good. She knows what her mother wants to hear - ''This morning I got married, lost 20 pounds and became a lawyer.'' She knows what her sweet, nerdy boyfriend wants her to do - buy a co-op in Brooklyn with him. But of her own aspirations, she's a bit more uncertain.

title: Leningrad Swamped By Heavy Floods
description: A major New Year's storm whipped by winds of 75 miles an hour pounded the Soviet Republic of Estonia and flooded Leningrad, inundating 13.5 square miles of the city's seafront, official Soviet reports said today.

title: Stabler Will Stay a Saint
description: Ken Stabler of the New Orleans

title: Examination for Virgil
description: Ozzie Virgil of the Phillies is on his way back to Philadelphia, where team doctors today will examine his wounded right hand, hit by a stray .38-caliber bullet during New Year's Eve celebrations in his native Mayaguez, P. R. The 27-year-old Virgil, the regular catcher for first-place Mayaguez in winter baseball, was standing in a carport outside a relative's home just after midnight Saturday when ''I suddenly felt a blow as if someone had hit me with a hammer.'' Virgil said yesterday that there was no fracture and that the swelling was subsiding.

title: Philadelphia to Hire More Hispanic Officers
description: The Police Department has agreed to hire 70 Spanish-speaking officers in the next two years, tentatively settling the last of a series of discrimination lawsuits.

title: CITY, AWAITING MONEY FOR A DIANA ROSS PLAYGROUND, IS TOLD THERE ISN'T ANY
description: Five months after Diana Ross said she would pay for a playground in Central Park with television proceeds from her concert there, her production company has sent New York City only a financial statement showing no revenue and no profits, according to park officials.

title: ANTITRUST: WHEN LAW CLASHES WITH A 'TRUTH'
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR FILM, 'BEAR' DEFECTS TO GEORGIA
description: Gary Busey stalked to his desk. Pausing, still standing, his tie loose, he shook out a Lucky Strike and jabbed it into his mouth.

title: Many Memories
description: H. P. Hazelrigg, a retired automobile dealer, has missed just two of the Illinois football team's home games in the last 60 years and, at the age of 85, may well have been the oldest Illinois alumnus at the Rose Bowl yesterday for the big game against U.C.L.A. ''I think I've outlived them all,'' he says. But, although he loves both football and the Illini, Hazelrigg describes himself as a calm fan.

title: Eleanor F. Francke, 77, Dies; Former President of Y.W.C.A.
description: Eleanor F. Francke, former president of the Young Women's Christian Association of Greater New York and a former vice president of the Junior League of New York City, died Friday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital after a long illness. She was 77 years old and lived in Bridgehampton, L.I., and New York City.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 3, 1984

title: GAMING & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S.C.'s Streak Is Ended at 28
description: Texas defeated Southern California, 77-68, tonight and ended at 28 the nation's longest winning streak in women's college basketball.

title: 13 Die in Jordan Plane Crash
description: A small transport plane crashed east of here today, killing the two-man crew and all 11 military men aboard, the Jordan radio quoted an armed forces spokesman as saying. The report cited a ''technical fault'' in the crash, which occurred in El Qatrana, 38 miles east of Amman, during a military transport mission.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 2, 1984:

title: TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter loss includes writedowns of $5.3 million related to terminated operations, idle facilities held for sale and inventories adjusted downward to current market values. The loss was partially offset by a gain of $2.1 million to be recognized by Texfi from the planned termination of its overfunded retirement plan.

title: ASKEW WELL FINANCED TO RAISE HIS VISIBILITY
description: Reubin O'Donovan Askew calls himself a ''different Democrat,'' and in the weeks ahead he will be working to overcome the obscurity of his candidacy and to sort himself out from the field of seven other major Democrats seeking their party's Presidential nomination.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: GROWTH OF 'KIDDIE LIT'
description: EACH year at the University of Connecticut about 600 undergraduates, majoring in fields ranging from business administration to zoology, take an English course in which they write rhymes to be recited while skipping rope, compose one-act plays for youngsters and read some of the best literature written for children.

title: Some Mixed Figures On Higher Education
description: The newsiest tidbit the authors of the 1984 edition of ''Where Should I Go to Study Advertising?'' found in their survey of the 85 colleges and universities that offer degrees in the subject is that, although the number of graduate degrees received in 1983 fell 23 percent, to 271, the number of graduate students inched up to 1,060 from 1,047.

title: Strike by Clerks Shuts Roosevelt
description: The harness-racing card at Roosevelt Raceway was called off tonight when the parimutuel clerks walked off the job. The track's chief negotiator, Vincent McDonnell, said the main issue was wages, and the decision when to reopen would be made on a daily basis.

title: LEBANON'S OLD POLITICS MUST YIELD TO THE NEW
description: Carnage has stolen the headlines, but the real story in Lebanon is social change. Vast numbers of Lebanese who were once politically mute have now found their voice and are no longer content to accept a political system that ignores their demands. The Lebanese Government's failure or unwillingness to recognize this change is the most important explanation for the country's continuing susceptibility to meddling by foreign powers.

title: 7 IN OTHER FIRES
description: Five people, four of them children, died in a two-alarm fire in their row house in Trenton last night, fire officials said.

title: DEFEATS SAID TO HURT MORALE OF SALVADOR ARMY
description: United States officials said today that two major defeats for the Salvadoran military in the last three days had dealt a serious blow to its morale.

title: A GROWING PRESENCE IN LAUNDRY ROOMS
description: The late John Sussman started Coinmach Industries in 1948 with a washer, a dryer and an old sock. The sock was used to collect the dimes from the coin-operated machines, which Mr. Sussman had put in the basement of an apartment building on Fulton Street in Hempstead, L.I.

title: RATE RISE SEEN IF DOLLAR FALLS
description: The strength of the dollar throughout 1983 attracted strong foreign demand for dollar-denominated securities and helped keep interest rates and inflation lower than they would otherwise have been. Many analysts, however, say that may not continue through 1984.

title: Vivian Blaine in ''Zorba''
description: Vivian Blaine will return to the Broadway stage for the first time since ''Company'' 13 years ago when she replaces the vacationing Lila Kedrova in ''Zorba'' for three weeks, Jan. 10 through Jan. 29.

title: FRITZ ROSENTHAL
description: Fritz Rosenthal, vice president of the Aluminum Smelters of New Jersey, died Saturday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y., after suffering a heart attack. He was 78 years old and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: PRIEST ASSESSES NICARAGUAN TRIBES' LOT
description: A United States priest who has spent 36 years in Nicaragua says the Government's efforts to impose a revolutionary society on all the people of the country, including about 50,000 Miskito, Sumo and Rama Indians, has transformed thousands of once-peaceful Indians into rebels fighting for their traditional culture.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN FORCE FIGHTING IN ANGOLA MAY TOTAL 10,000
description: Angola said today that South Africa had nine regular army battalions and two companies fighting inside Angola. Such a force could number up to 10,000 soldiers.

title: DR. FRANZ STIEGLMAYR
description: Dr. Franz Stieglmayr, an assistant professor of neurology at the New York University Medical School and chief of neurology at La Guardia Hospital in Queens and the Veterans Administration Hospital in East Orange, N.J., died of cancer Friday in La Guardia Hospital.

title: REDSKINS' LINEMEN ARE ALMOST PERFECT
description: On Monday mornings, the Washington Redskins' offensive linemen, who proudly call themselves the Hogs, gather around to view the grades posted by Joe Bugel for all to see.

title: SPINOFF SUITS MOUNT IN SILICON VALLEY
description: Last April 22, two engineers at the International Business Machines Corporation's research center in nearby San Jose were summarily dismissed after I.B.M. discovered they planned to start their own company to make the same kind of product they were working on. The same day, I.B.M. sued them, charging theft of trade secrets and breach of fiduciary duty.

title: NEW AGE OF PRECISION BROUGHT TO NAVIGATION BY MODERN GYROSCOPES
description: THE quiet revolution in the navigation of planes, submarines, spacecraft and missiles is picking up speed as internal guidance systems become smaller, cheaper, more versatile and more accurate, according to industry experts and scientists working in the field.

title: Reagan Helps Get Approval For Musician's Burial at Sea
description: President Reagan used his influence so that Dennis Wilson, the late Beach Boys drummer, could be buried at sea by the Coast Guard, the President's spokesman confirmed today.

title: 55 M.P.H. Speed Limit Said To Have Saved 45,000 Lives
description: On the 10th anniversary of the national 55 mile-per-hour speed limit, conservative estimates place the number of lives saved on highways in excess of 45,000.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES ; MIAMI EARNS IT
description: MIAMI

title: NEW MAYORS AND NEW OUTLOOKS FOR 2 MAJOR CITIES
description: Raymond L. Flynn, the son of a longshoreman and a former cleaning woman, was inaugurated as Boston's 46th Mayor today, pledging to make ''the people'' his only special interest group.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Atlantic Richfield Co. has elected Howard L. Edwards corporate secretary.

title: GOULD JEWELS TO BE SOLD
description: The jewelry collection of the late Florence J. Gould, a patron of the arts and a daughter-in-law of the railroad magnate Jay Gould, will be auctioned at Christie's on April 11.

title: PIONEER IN FLUOROCARBON USE
description: Dr. Joseph H. Simons, a chemist who discovered one of the first practical ways of making fluorocarbons, died Friday at his home in Gainesville, Fla. He was 86 years old.

title: JAPAN PAUSES FOR BREATH BEFORE THE '84 RAT RACE
description: It was one of those rattle-in-your-boots earthquakes, and had it occurred on land instead of safely out in the Pacific Ocean, there might have been fewer people here to talk about it.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company's results for the latest quarter reflect the impact of a substantial decline in coal traffic during the quarter following strong coal traffic in the January-September period which was partly offset by additional cost-cutting efforts and natural resources earnings.

title: AS THE WORLD READIES FOR MASS SUICIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: ; ARMS-CURB IDEAS WORTHY OF U.S. RESPECT
description: To the Editor:

title: Couple Charged In Death of Baby
description: A man and a woman were charged yesterday in connection with the death of their 6-month-old son earlier in the day in Manhattan, authorities said.

title: Lebanese Militia Commander In Serious Condition in Israel
description: The commander of the Lebanese Christian militia, Maj. Saad Haddad, was in serious condition today in an Israeli hospital, a spokesman said.

title: FEW ISSUES ARE SCHEDULED FOR WEEK
description: Few new bond issues are scheduled this week, giving dealers in tax-exempt and Treasury securities a chance to distribute the heavy supply of government issues brought to market during December.

title: MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
TUESDAY, JANUARY 3, 1984 International
description: France announced a redeployment of about 25 percent of its troops serving with the four-nation force in Beirut. Paris said that within a month 482 troops from the 1,750-man French contingent would leave Beirut and return to French positions with the United Nations force in southern Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 6.) The French troops in Beirut have become prime targets for terrorist groups, and 82 French soldiers have been killed there. France, like its partners in the four-nation force, would prefer to leave Lebanon, but regards a total pullout now as politically impossible. (A13:1-3.)

title: BRIEFING
description: Of Percy and Israel

title: McKinney, Silver Wins Fannie Mae Account
description: In competition with about 15 agencies, including some of the biggest, McKinney, Silver & Rockett of Raleigh, N.C., has won the Federal National Mortgage Association account, which bills more than $5 million.

title: TV: A YOUNG COUPLE AND AN OLD TENEMENT
description: ONE of the first scenes in ''Last of the Great Survivors,'' tonight's made-for- television movie on CBS at 9 o'clock, features an orangutan named Max watching a report about President Reagan and the nation's farmers on public television's ''MacNeil/Lehrer'' report. Jim Kouf's script clearly has possibilities. Unfortunately, because of television's chronic addiction to being overly cute, only a few of them are realized.

title: SCOUTING
description: A Tennis Town

title: CAB AND LAND MEASURES REQUIRED 6 MONTHS' TALKS, CUOMO AIDE SAYS
description: A spokesman for Governor Cuomo said yesterday that concerns over the impact of bills that tighten the regulation of nonmedallion taxis and restrict land development led to delays of more than six months between legislative passage and the Governor's signature.

title: ASKEW TERMS DEFICITS CRUCIAL DOMESTIC ISSUE
description: The New York Times today publishes an interview with former Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida, another in a series of interviews with candidates for the Presidency.

title: REPORTERS WHO HID IDENTITY OF SOURCES WIN LIBEL RULING
description: A California Superior Court has ruled in favor of two reporters in a libel case made unusual by the defendant newspaper's decision to try to make its reporters reveal their sources.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're just so darned boxed in, how can we influence anything?'' - Representative Robert H. Michel, Republican of Illinois.

title: CASTRO DENOUNCES REAGAN IN SPEECH
description: Fidel Castro, marking the 25th anniversary of the Cuban revolution, used unusually strong terms to denounce the Reagan Administration in a speech here Sunday night.

title: The Calendar ;  Tuesday
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale begins the National Press Club's new year with a political address. 12:30 P.M., Capital Hilton.

title: IRANIANS IN SYRIA: SIGN OF CLOSE TIES
description: On Thursday afternoons, the Iranian jetliners land at the international airport here. The passengers, most of them women shrouded in black chadors, descend carrying huge bags of pistachios.

title: 2 Saved After Breaking Ice
description: Two teen-agers studying a frozen creek for school in Brooklyn fell through the ice yesterday and were rescued by firefighters who extended ladders to them, the authorities said.

title: MAN DIES AFTER BEATING WITH BAT IN VIDEO ARCADE ON THE EAST SIDE
description: An 18-year-old Manhattan man was beaten with a baseball bat in an Upper East Side video arcade Sunday night and died of his injuries yesterday, the police reported.

title: DR. DAVID S. PRICE
description: Dr. David S. Price, former vice chancellor for personnel of the State University of New York, died last Thursday while traveling from Bermuda, where he had been on vacation, to his home in Loudonville, N.Y. He had been ill with cancer and was 64 years old.

title: JetWith3PassengersMakes Emergency Landing in Jersey
description: A chartered jet plane carrying three passengers skidded off the runway after making an emergency landing today at Teterboro Airport when a set of landing wheels did not work, officials said. No injuries were reported.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: PORTER PIECES There are performers who become associated with the work of certain composers or authors. Julie Wilson fits one of these slots. Miss Wilson, who has been out of the nightclub spotlight for more than three years, returns tonight to appear through Jan. 21, in homage to Cole Porter, at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street (758-2272).

title: Ex-Representative's Parents Killed by Blaze in Mississippi
description: A weekend fire killed the parents of former Representative Jon Hinson, Republican of Mississippi.

title: Show on Plains Indians Set for Cooper-Hewitt
description: ''Circles of the World: Traditional Art of the Plains Indian'' will open at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, on April 24 and continue through July 15.

title: RANGERS AND CAPITALS TIE, 2-2
description: The Rangers reached the midpoint of their National Hockey League schedule this afternoon, playing a 2-2 tie with the Washington Capitals at the Capital Centre.

title: Moon's Son, 17, Dies After a Car Accident
description: One of the 13 children of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the founder of the Unification Church, died early today in a hospital here, a hospital spokesman said.

title: FRANCE VIEWS ITS SOLDIERS AS PRIME BEIRUT TARGETS
description: France's announcement today of its plan to redeploy a quarter of its troops in Beirut represents a decision to reduce its physical presence in the Lebanese capital at a time when French troops have become prime targets for terrorist groups.

title: TV: ROONEY AERIAL VIEWS AND AMERICA
description: ''ANDY ROONEY TAKES OFF'' is an aerial picture postcard, accompanied by a good deal of talk. Mr. Rooney, a resident humorist and philosopher for CBS, flies over America in a helicopter, while a camera crew films everything he sees. Much of the landscape is beautiful, although by and large you will wish you were in Charles Kuralt's bus. An aerial photograph is an aerial photograph, and Mr. Rooney doesn't find much interesting to say about very many of them. The one-hour program will be seen on CBS at 8 tonight.

title: Grounded Tanker Refloated
description: A Greek-registered tanker carrying 550,000 barrels of crude oil was rescued Sunday after being stranded on a sand bar in Delaware Bay since Friday, Coast Guard officials said.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THEATER: KEY WEST IN DECLINE
description: ROBERT HEIDE, whose plays were first done in the formative days of Off Off Broadway, has returned with a matching pair of related one- acts about decaying Key West society. The plays, grouped under the title, ''Tropical Fever in Key West,'' are running at Theater for the New City. The tenseness of the author's early work has been replaced by a leisurely circumnavigation of a predictable landscape.

title: Flying Tiger
description: Tiger International Inc. said its Flying Tiger Line Inc. had signed a final agreement with lenders providing for a stretch-out of payments on some of its debt. The agreement also provides new two-year revolving credit convertible to a five-year loan for up to $45 million, the company said. Tiger International, an air cargo, trucking and rail car leasing company, said its Flying Tiger Line expects to report a pretax profit for the fourth quarter of 1983, which would be its first quarterly pretax profit since the second quarter of 1981.

title: U.S. TO SIGN ACCORD WITH PEKING FOR CLOSER INDUSTRIAL COOPERATION
description: The United States and China will sign an agreement on industrial cooperation next week and are making ''good progress'' on a treaty to define the rights of investors in each country, Administration officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a production error, some copies of Business Day on Saturday carried page 33 twice and omitted page 36, which included stock option tables. Any reader wishing a copy of the missing page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: NEW POLICE STATION IN QUEENS, A NEW APPROACH FOR THE CITY
description: At 0810 hours yesterday, the new police precinct in Queens had its first case. At 1150 hours, the Police Commissioner brandished a symbolic key at the station house in Jackson Heights. The 115th Precinct was formally open for business.

title: S. & P. Rating Money Market Funds
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday that it would now assign ratings to money market mutual funds that paid a fee and requested the rating. The rating agency announced ratings for 14 funds and said that more of the approximately 300 different money funds were expected to apply.

title: SCOUTING
description: Trying Again

title: 4 Soviet Climbers Die
description: An avalanche killed four Soviet mountain climbers on Mount Elbrus, the highest peak in Europe, the Government daily Izvestia reported today. It gave no date for the avalanche, but said it was the latest in a series of tragedies on the 18,481-foot peak caused by unqualified climbers getting into difficulty in bad weather.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Virtuoso on 'Beowulf'

title: ROUNDABOUT MAY MOVE
description: The Roundabout Theater, an Off Broadway institution for 18 years, may be forced to move from its Chelsea quarters, possibly by Feb. 28.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: North Side of White House Now Protected by Barriers
description: While President Reagan was vacationing in California, the Secret Service extended the concrete barriers surrounding the White House to include its entire north side.

title: 'THERE ARE PLENTY OF DARK CLOUDS AHEAD OF US'
description: Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, former soldier and diplomat, has been involved in military and foreign-policy questions for nearly half a century. A former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Ambassador to South Vietnam and Presidential counselor, the 82-year- old general still retains a voice in Washington, testifying from time to time on Capitol Hill and writing occasional pieces on military and foreign affairs. This morning, in a conversation in the living room of his home on the capital's Embassy Row, he talked about some of the military and diplomatic initiatives the United States has under way around the world, discussed command responsibility and took a strong stand on the way the press should be handled in wartime.

title: OTTINGER PLANS TO RETIRE POLITICAL COLLEAGUES SAY
description: Representative Richard L. Ottinger, a popular and virtually unbeatable Democratic Congressman from Westchester County for nearly two decades, has decided not to run for re-election in November, political colleagues said today.

title: SALVADOR FAILS TO ACT ON DEATH-SQUAD OFFICERS
description: The Salvadoran armed forces have announced end-of-the-month military changes without meeting United States demands for the exiling of officers suspected of taking part in death-squad activities.

title: Repair the New York Bench
description: The courts of New York are poorly staffed, horribly organized and starved for funds. Most judges are ''elected,'' which means they're picked by political chieftains for mock elections. The state has 11 tiers of trial courts, including one misnamed ''Supreme,'' which defy comprehension and baffle even the lawyers trying to find out where their cases go. Legislators won't pay for clean, decent courthouses.

title: Another Gretzky Record
description: Wayne Gretzky scored a goal

title: Docutel/Olivetti Offers Computer DALLAS, Jan. 3 (Reuters) - The Docutel/Olivetti Corporation said it had started marketing the Olivetti PC, a personal computer available in desktop and portable versions that is compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computer.
description: The company said the computers are made by Corona Data Systems. The suggested retail price is $2,895 for units with a single floppy disk drive and $3,295 for dual-drive systems.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Borg-Warner Names New Operating Chief C. E. (Red) Johnson, vice president of transportation for the Borg-Warner Corporation's automotive equipment group, was named president and chief operating officer yesterday by the big maker of automotive components, chemicals, industrial and agricultural equipment.

title: Blazers Lose Valentine
description: Darnell Valentine , the Portland Trail Blazers' point guard, has broken a finger and will be out several weeks. Valentine suffered the fracture to the middle finger of his left hand during Monday's 115-103 loss to the Philadelphia 76ers. . . . Johnny Moore , the San Antonio Spurs' starting point guard who has missed several games after breaking his right index finger, has been placed on the injured-reserve list.

title: Counsel Resigns in Yonkers
description: The city's Corporation Counsel, Peter Davidson, has resigned his post and has been replaced by an attorney who formerly held the job, the Acting City Manager, Nick DeSantis, said today. The resignation was effective Monday. Named to succeed Mr. Davidson was Arthur Doran, who served as Counsel from 1980 to 1982.

title: TURKEY, IN A GESTURE , WILL TRIM ITS CYPRUS FORCES
description: The Government announced today that it would withdraw 1,500 of its troops from Cyprus over the next two months as a good-will gesture to open the way for a resumption of peace talks between Turkish and Greek Cypriots. Turkey is estimated to have 25,000 troops on the island, which it invaded in 1974.

title: BANKERS EXPRESS CONCERN ABOUT NIGERIA'S DEBT
description: Although Nigeria's new military leader has a reputation for austerity, leading bankers in the United States said yesterday that they were worried about how last Saturday's coup might affect the West African nation's attitude toward or ability to pay its foreign debt.

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball New Jersey Nets vs. Hawks, at Atlanta. The Nets were held to their second-lowest point total of the season when they lost by 98-87 at Atlanta on Dec. 20.

title: Economic Scene; U.S. vs. Soviet Forecasting
description: OFFICIAL economic analysis and forecasting in the United States and the Soviet Union have certain similarities. Both are shaped by politicians eager to prove the success of their economic stewardship. Both are marked by internal battles among policy makers. Officials in both systems hate leaks of information, since information is power.

title: U.N. CHIEF REJECTS SOVIET DEFECTOR'S JOB PLEA
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has rejected a request from a Soviet defector, supported by the United States, that he be allowed to stay on his job in the United Nations Secretariat while he awaits American citizenship.

title: THE TRANSLATORS VS. ADAPTERS
description: WHEN the ''The Sea Gull'' played recently at the Circle Repertory Company, the credits listed Jean-Claude van Itallie as the translator. Yet Mr. van Itallie, by his own admission, does not speak Russian, the language in which Anton Chekhov wrote the play.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Tire Stocks, Pro and Con
description: P RODUCTION is booming in tire plants and, after a lackluster year for tire equities, logic would indicate that prospects for market appreciation should appear bright in 1984.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Kissinger Denial

title: CHINA'S ECONOMIC GROWTH IS PICKING UP
description: China appears to have fulfilled the overall targets of its current five-year plan in three years, but without having solved some basic economic problems.

title: FirefighterLayoffs Bring Bias Charge
description: An association of firefighters from minority groups today urged a Federal judge to prevent Newark from laying off more black and Hispanic firefighters than whites because of the city's budget crunch.

title: OPERA: NEW CAST IN 'HANSEL'
description: AT the Metropolitan Opera's Monday evening presentation of ''Hansel and Gretel,'' the last of the season, a new and generally praiseworthy cast brought Engelbert Humperdinck's charming work to vibrant life.

title: REPORT CITES DROP IN PRENATAL CARE
description: There has been a marked decrease in early prenatal care for pregnant women over the last three years, a private nonprofit group reported today.

title: FOR THE FLIER'S FAMILY, HECTIC DAY IN SPOTLIGHT
description: ''Oh God, it's unbelievable,'' Marilyn Goodman said early yesterday on learning that her son, Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr., was being released in Syria. ''I just need more details.''

title: Mugabe Reduces Size Of Zimbabwe Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe reduced the size of his Cabinet today and demoted the powerful Minister of Home Affairs, who is in charge of the police.

title: BUSINESSMEN GIVE TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: Among many important contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are leaders of the business and professional enterprises in the area who seek to ease the hardship of the city's poor that they see around them.

title: Joseph Levinoff, 73, Is Dead, A Ballet Teacher and Dancer
description: Joseph Levinoff, a ballet teacher, dancer and choreographer, died of cancer Monday in Greensboro, N. C. He was 73 years old.

title: 7 PRINTING CONCERNS BUY A BUILDING ON VARICK ST.
description: A letter from the landlord three years ago brought troubling news to the owners of the C. E. Finck Indexing Corporation, which makes looseleaf tab dividers. It told them of the large increases in base rent they could expect at 145 Hudson Street if they renewed their lease, which was expiring in 1984.

title: MUSICAL FUN, 'BASILEUS QUARTET'
description: ''BASILEUS QUARTET,'' written and directed by Fabio Carpi, a film maker new to me, is a witty, intelligent little film about the dead-end of a certain kind of art. Like ''Reuben, Reuben,'' this Franco-Italian co- production is an entertainment for people who prefer a sort of literate decency of feelings to shocks provided by the unknown.

title: Ulster Farmer Slain; I.R.A. Claims Deed
description: A part-time militiaman was killed near the border with the Irish Republic Monday night, and today the outlawed Irish Republican Army took responsibility for the killing.

title: FABERGE IN TALKS ON BUYOUT
description: Faberge Inc., the fragrance and shampoo company, said yesterday that it was holding preliminary discussions with Gibbons Green Van Amerongen Inc., a private New York investment banking firm, about a possible leveraged buyout of the company by private investors for $30 a share, or a total of $168 million.

title: IN STYLE AND IN COMFORT: LOW-HEEL SHOES
description: ONE of the pleasantest aspects of the spring fashion season is that it won't be necessary to totter about on high heels. The choice of low or even flat-heel shoes will be far greater than usual.

title: GULL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1983 and computed to reflect higher numbers of shares outstanding for the latest periods.

title: Craft Retrial Starts Today
description: Christine Craft, the former television anchor whose $500,000 award by a jury against Metromedia Inc. was thrown out by a Federal judge, will resume her court fight Wednesday.

title: ISRAELI JETS STRIKE LEBANON IN 2D STRAIGHT DAY OF RAIDS
description: Israeli war planes today bombed targets of the militant Shiite Moslem organization in the Bekkaa, Lebanon's eastern valley, in the second Israeli air attack in Lebanon in two days, according to Beirut state radio.

title: TOUGH SPOT FOR PLACE KICKER
description: Late during every Auburn practice since the end of the regular season, the place-kicker, Al Del Greco, and an assistant coach played a game of their own in preparation for Monday's Sugar Bowl game against Michigan. It was not a long game, nor did it do anything for Del Greco's kicking style. But it prepared him for the most difficult aspect of field-goal kicking - waiting. Ultimately, it gave Auburn a 9-7 victory and what the Tigers believed was a chance for the No. 1 ranking in the final news- agency polls.

title: ISLANDRS STOPPED BY HARD CHECKING
description: The Islanders' home winning streak was ended at nine games tonight by their nemesis from Boston. The Bruins showing why they are leading the Adams Division, broke out of a 2-2 tie and went on to a 4-2 victory at Nassau Coliseum.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Rise Slightly;  3-Month Bill Goes to 9.04%
description: Interest rates increased slightly for short-term and long-term Treasury issues yesterday. In a day of modest trading activity, securities dealers said relatively few notes and bonds were sold to investors.

title: Steel Accord Is Sought
description: The United States Export-Import Bank, searching for a compromise in a conflict with the Reagan Administration over financing sales of equipment for a South Korean steel mill, may decide to guarantee only a portion of the loan rather than provide a direct credit, Administration officials said today.

title: PRESIDENT THANKS THE SYRIAN LEADER
description: President Reagan thanked President Hafez al- Assad of Syria today for releasing Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr. and declared that the flier's return presented ''an opportune moment to put all the issues on the table'' between the United States and Syria.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: AFRICAN pop music has attracted a substantial following in Britain, where such African stars as King Sunny Ade and Fela Anikulapo Kuti record for major labels, and white imitators such as Adam Ant and Bow Wow Wow have consistently reached the top of the sales charts. But African pop's myriad forms thrive principally on small independent record labels.

title: Ex-French Premier Protests Disclosure on Sniffer Plane
description: Former Prime Minister Raymond Barre of France called his successor ''irresponsible'' today for making public the details of a bogus sniffer plane that would find oil.

title: Yield Paces Differ
description: Interest rates at the start of 1984 are clearly higher than a year ago.

title: 'CLEVER' REACTION TO A MILITARY FAILURE
description: To the Editor: President Reagan believes Marine commanders ''should not be punished for not fully comprehending the na

title: CAMPAIGN TO RECALL MAYOR OF ATLANTIC CITY FALLS SHORT
description: An effort to recall Mayor Michael J. Matthews has failed, City Clerk Adelaide Deane said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 4, 1984

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Battle Against Noise

title: SCOUTING
description: A Point of Pride

title: MIAMI IS CHOSEN AS NO. 1 AFTER UPSET OF NEBRASKA
description: The Miami Hurricanes, who upset previously undefeated Nebraska, 31-30, in the Orange Bowl on Monday night, were selected today as the nation's No. 1 college football team for the 1983 season in the final polls of both The Associated Press and United Press International.

title: YONKERS BAN: STATE'S ROLE IN SPORTS
description: MICHAEL WINERIP

title: Kennedy in Capital Hospital
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy was listed in good condition today after being admitted to George Washington University Hospital with a mild case of hepatitis, intestinal influenza, a stomach ulcer and dehydration. Mr. Kennedy, a 51- year-old Massachusetts Democrat, is expected to be released in a few days, his office said.

title: TAVIANIS WIN FILM AWARD
description: ''The Night of the Shooting Stars,'' the impressionistic World War II fable set in a small Italian village, has been voted best film of 1983 by the National Society of Film Critics, a 43- member group representing critics from New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and other cities.

title: Changes in Argentina Prompt Timerman to Hasten Return
description: Jacobo Timerman, the exiled Argentine writer and former newspaper publisher, said yesterday that he would fly to Buenos Aires on Friday, advancing his return by about three months.

title: Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said it had been granted a state charter to operate a bank and trust company unit in New Jersey. Merrill Lynch said, however, that the subsidiary would not take demand deposits, but would offer other banking services, including trust services. The trust company is to be located at the Merrill Lynch facilities now under construction in Plainsboro Township.

title: ; TO MAKE STATES CRACK DOWN ON DRUNK DRIVING
description: T o the Editor:

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: U.N. Council to Meet On Fighting in Angola

title: Northeastern Air Adds City Service
description: Northeastern International Airways said today that it would acquire two jumbo jets and expand service between several Florida cities and New York with fares of $75 in the evening and $89 in the daytime.

title: British Press Heeds Royal Plea for Privacy
description: British newspapers bowed today to a royal request for privacy and withdrew their reporters and photographers from Queen Elizabeth's vacation estate in southeastern England.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AT this time of year, there are few things I crave more than a steaming bowl of soup. It could be a clear, full-bodied consomme, a substantial and thick creation along the lines of an Italian minestrone or a hearty meal-in-itself potee from my childhood in Tonnerre, France, made with pork shoulder, cabbage and a generous number of other vegetables.

title: OHIO MATTRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago results include a gain of $394,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and year from the partial settlement of a lawsuit and a gain of $343,000, or 4 cents a share, for the year from the sale of stock of the company's licensor. The Ohio Mattress Company was formerly the Ohio-Sealy Mattress Manufacturing Co.

title: JONES INTERCABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includng an extraordinary gain of $167,400 from the sale of stock.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * A. H. Belo Corporation, a Dallas- based media company, has appointed Robert W. Decherd, executive vice president, to the additional post of chief operating officer; James P. Sheehan was promoted to executive vice president; Robert G. Norvell, vice president and treasurer, was named to the additional post of secretary, and Michael D. Perry was promoted to vice president, controller.

title: A PUBLIC OFFICIAL WHO GARNERS SUPERLATIVES: STANLEY BREZENOFF
description: People who know Stanley Brezenoff agree that he seems to embody so many good qualities that try as they may they cannot find anything negative to say about him.

title: VOTERS OUT OF U.S. HAVE DIFFICULTIES
description: An American who is away from home on Election Day must get forms notarized as many as four times to vote as an absentee, a nuisance for visitors to another state, but nearly impossible for those in a remote corner of the world.

title: Farm Bond Sale Due Next Week
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks yesterday announced plans to sell about $1.3 billion of new bonds next week.

title: Peugeot Unit Stays Closed POISSY, France, Jan. 3 (AP) - Brawling broke out between strikers and nonstriking workers today at the giant Peugeot Talbot auto plant in this Paris suburb as hundreds of workers protesting 1,900 layoffs barred others from returning to work.
description: Several people were reported injured, none seriously, when 600 to 700 men swarmed over the plant's assembly lines and metal works, occupying at least one shop.

title: IT'S JANUARY AND THE PRICES ARE DOWN
description: MARKING down fresh foie gras with truffles from $10 an ounce to $5 is ''just like what they do with clothing,'' says Andrew Balducci, a partner in the Greenwich Village food store bearing his family's name.

title: Officer Arrested In $200 Robbery
description: A police officer who accompanied the victim of an attempted robbery to a Brooklyn hospital for treatment of a gunshot wound was arrested yesterday on charges that he stole $200 from the wounded man.

title: NEW WARNER TRY BY MURDOCH
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher, has filed his intention with the United States Justice Department to acquire at least 25 percent, and up to 49.9 percent, of Warner Communications Inc. At the current stock price, such an acquisition could amount to nearly $900 million.

title: Bullets 103, Pistons 102
description: The rookie Jeff Malone made a 3-point shot from the corner with a second remaining to give Washington a victory over Detroit. The Bullets who trailed by 9 points early in the fourth period, got a chance to win after Ricky Sobers sank another 3-pointer with 8 seconds remaining and John Long missed 2 free throws for Detroit.

title: THAYER EXPECTED TO RESIGN
description: Paul Thayer, the Deputy Secretary of Defense, is expected to resign within days so that he can defend himself against civil charges being drawn up by the Securities and Exchange Commission, an Administration official reported tonight. At issue is whether Mr. Thayer illegally passed on inside information about a stock in 1982, when he was a corporate executive and director.

title: Transactions; BASKETBALL
description: SAN ANTONIO (NBA) - Placed Johnny Moore, guard, on injured list because of broken finger and signed Robert Miller, center, to 10-day contract. FOOTBALL HOUSTON (AFC) - Named as head coach Hugh Campbell, a former head coach in Canada and the head coach of the Los Angeles Express of the U.S.F.L. EXPRESS (USFL) - Named John Hadl, the former all-pro quarterback and an assistant coach of the Denver Broncos, as head coach to replace Hugh Campbell.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS ARE STEADY
description: Spending for new construction held steady in November after declining the previous month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Richard H. Jahns Dies at 68; Earth Science Dean Emeritus
description: Dr. Richard H. Jahns, dean emeritus of the Stanford University School of Earth Sciences, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: Match Play Defended By Colbert
description: After Jim Colbert eliminated Dave Eichelberger, 8 and 7, in first-round action today, he defended the format of the $1 million Seiko-Tucson match- play championship.

title: LINE-ITEM VETO: A SURRENDER, OR DEFICIT REMEDY?
description: At just about every meeting with Congressional leaders, President Reagan asks the legislators to give him power to veto portions of appropriations bills instead of having to accept or reject measures in their entirety.

title: THE POLITICAL DROPOUTS
description: At the beginning of this Presidential election year, both major political parties are asking their computers to analyze why so many Americans don't bother to register to vote.

title: ELECTRONIC RACLETTE GRILL
description: WITH the ski season upon us, I can't think of a more pleasant way to spend an evening after a vigorous day on the slopes than enjoying a traditional Swiss raclette with a robust bottle of red wine in front of a glowing fireplace. The term raclette is derived from the French word racler, meaning ''to scrape.'' The traditional Swiss raclette dinner is made by placing locally made cheese next to the fire and letting it soften.

title: KOCH NAMES HEAD OF HOSPITAL CORP. AS DEPUTY MAYOR
description: Stanley Brezenoff, president of the City Health and Hospitals Corporation since 1981, was named a deputy mayor yesterday by Mayor Koch. Mr. Brezenoff succeeds Robert F. Wagner Jr., whose resignation will take effect at the end of the month.

title: ADVERTISING
description: People

title: Harriman Breaks Leg
description: W. Averell Harriman, a former Ambassador, Governor and adviser to Presidents dating back to Franklin D. Roosevelt, broke his right leg Christmas Eve while swimming off Barbados, his office said Monday.

title: SCREEN: 'THE HORSE,' HARDSHIP IN ISTANBUL
description: ECONOMIC hardship forces a father and son to leave their small Turkish village and seek work in Istanbul in ''The Horse,'' a bleak examination of living conditions in that city. As the father and son struggle to become fruit peddlers, living in an outdoor courtyard with a group of other workers, the film explores the wretchedness and hopelessness of their plight.

title: FROM JAPAN, A PEPPERY SPROUT AND MORE
description: AMONG the noteworthy arrivals in local markets, shops and restaurants in the city recently are a number of Japanese items, the most interesting of which is a new kind of sprout, a peppery radish seed sprout called 2-Mamina. These sprouts are sold in rectangular plastic containers with roots intact for about $1 for just under two ounces. Cut off the roots and you have slender stems topped with pretty double-lobed dark green leaves. They can be used in salads, sandwiches and sushi preparations.

title: KNICKSS SNAP 3-GAME SLIDE
description: The Knicks shook up their starting backcourt, but it was the second-half scoring and rebounding of the intact front line that led to a 117-105 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: KEAN AND LEGISLATORS AGREE TO ALLOT $7 MILLION IN SPECIAL URBAN AID
description: Governor Kean and legislative leaders agreed today to appropriate $7 million to help New Jersey's six largest cities and smaller communities avoid laying off policemen and firefighters.

title: REAGAN PLANNING MORE AID FOR SALVADOR
description: In the face of stepped-up guerrilla attacks in El Salvador, the Reagan Administration is preparing a request for roughly $100 million in additional military aid to expand the Salvadoran armed forces, Administration officials said today.

title: U.S. TELLS OF '54 GUATEMALA INVASION
description: After a six- year delay, the State Department today published the official documentation on American policy toward the overthrow of the leftist Government in Guatemala in 1954. But all material on the covert role of the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Department was omitted.

title: Trial in New York Suit On the Census Begins
description: A trial began yesterday in a lawsuit seeking to show that the 1980 census ''disproportionately undercounted'' the population of New York City and State.

title: DURALITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago third quarter results include approximately $38,000 in tax adjustments.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: Who's afraid of 1984? Not us. Why, we've been dealing with Doublethink for years here at Metropolitan Diary. Doublethink, you may recall, was defined by Orwell as accepting ''two contradictory beliefs in one's mind simultaneously.'' He must have been reading our mail. For example, Jim Douglass reports on a sign he saw on a door on the main floor of the Manhattan General Post Office: This door 1018 is not to be used as an entrance or exit

title: DOLLARS AND SCENTS
description: An advertising come-on for a certain perfume boasts that it is the most expensive perfume in the world. It does not promise to make hair glossier, improve skin tone, create insight into the stock market, reduce men to groveling imbeciles or even make women smell better than they would after a bath with pine-tar soap. Its sole claim to superiority is its extraordinary price.

title: 'CLEVER' REACTION TO A MILITARY FAILURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Noll Takes Blame
description: Chuck Noll , the coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers, and Dan Rooney , the club's president, haven't talked since the Steelers lost, 38-10, to the Los Angeles Raiders in the National Football League playoffs last Sunday, but when they do get together there will apparently be agreement on one point - Noll's offensive strategy was poor.

title: MINISTRY EMPLOYEES IN ISRAEL GO ON STRIKE TO PROTEST AUSTERITY TEL AVIV, Jan. 3 (UPI) - Thousands of Israeli civil servants disrupted services today to protest austerity measures, including a 15 percent increase in the prices of bread, meat and dairy products.
description: Histadrut, the labor organization, accused Finance Minister Yigal Cohen- Orgad of ''acting dishonorably and indecently'' in pushing plans to cut spending and reduce inflation, now running at 160 percent a year.

title: MITCHELL-LAMA LAW SPONSER
description: Alfred A. Lama, a former New York State Assemblyman who was co-sponsor of the 1955 Mitchell-Lama middle- income housing law, died of complications from pneumonia yesterday in St. Francis Hospital-The Heart Center in Roslyn, L.I. He was 84 years old and lived in Oakdale, L.I.

title: Roosevelt Strike Cancels 2d Card
description: A strike by parimutuel clerks continued at Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L.I., yesterday, forcing the cancellation of the harness-racing card for a second straight night. But the head of the striking union said he expected to resume negotiations today with Roosevelt and the Offtrack Betting Corporation, which is also involved in the negotiations.

title: TV: THREE COMEDIES
description: -year-old son who is pondering a serious affair with an aggressive young woman his own age. Then, there is the corporation run by an icy chief executive who tells his trembling vice presidents ''anxiety breeds excellence.'' Finally, there is the Manhattan court where the new judge is a young man partial to blue jeans and jogging shoes. We are, in other words, in the special world of situation comedy.

title: PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Pickens Offers Details on Gulf
description: T. Boone Pickens Jr., the

title: NETS BEATEN AGAIN AS OFFENSE WILTS
description: The Boston Celtics awakened after a lethargic first half tonight and defeated the Nets, 105-103, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: DEMOCRACY CAN'T FEED LATIN AMERICA'S HUNGRY
description: To the Editor:

title: RISK OF WAR RISES, MONDALE ASSERTS
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale delivered a sweeping attack on the Reagan Administration's arms control and foreign policies today and said the ''risk of nuclear war'' had increased in the last three years.

title: CURB ON WAJDA STIRS FILM MAKERS
description: The Polish film makers' association may have been been forced into a compromise that some directors feel leaves them open for future repression. In return for the continued existence of the organization, the Government is said to have asked for the resignation of the association's leader, the renowned director Andrzej Wajda.

title: GESCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $940,000. c-Net loss including a gain of $559,121 on the sale of a division.

title: CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE THAT COMPELS RESPECT
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS ZAYAK IS FIT AND EAGER AGAIN
description: Two weeks before the national championships that will determine America's figure-skating team for the Winter Olympics, Elaine Zayak appears to have regained the form and fitness that brought her a world title.

title: Dorriet Kavanaugh, 38, Dies
description: Opera Singer and Actress

title: Advertising; A More Creative Compton
description: EDWARD L. WAX celebrated his 47th birthday yesterday doing what he likes to do best: running an ad agency. It is an acquired taste.

title: Prank Pays Off
description: One of the two students who put prank messages on the Rose Bowl scoreboard will get course credit for the feat, a California Institute of Technology spokesman said yesterday. The prank had been approved by Dan Kegel 's instructor as a project in a course called ''Experimental Projects in Electrical Circuits,'' said the spokesman, Dennis Meredith .

title: JUDICIAL APPOINTIVE PLAN POLARIZES PENNSYLVANIA
description: The structure of Pennsylvania's judiciary system has come under attack from many quarters and has divided the state's legal profession.

title: Pilot License of Survivor Of Air Crash Questioned
description: A man who survived five days in snow with his teen- age son after a plane crash had no pilot's license, the authorities said today after cocaine and $19,200 in cash were found at the accident site.

title: KICKOFF CLASSIC SEEKS MIAMI
description: Miami, which finished as the No. 1 team for the 1983 season in the two news-agency, polls and Auburn, which finished No. 3 in the polls, are expected to meet in the second Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium on Monday night, Aug. 27.

title: INTERNATIONAL KING'S TABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 17
TO MAKE STATES CRACK DOWN ON DRUNK DRIVING
description: To the Editor: As a former executive of a wine and spirits company and a member of a society of automobile en

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.*Walking in Style

title: GRADUATE EDUCATION: NEEDS BEYOND U.S. AID
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IF you yawned at a party, your

title: OIL TRADERS FEARFUL OF AN OIL PRICE RISE BY NIGERIA
description: The overthrow of the Government of Nigeria, a major oil-producing nation, has made already skittish international oil traders even more doubtful that a decline in crude prices can be avoided.

title: Comshare, I.B.M.
description: Comshare Inc. said it had reached an agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation to supply I.B.M. with software that would be jointly marketed by the two companies. The so-called decision- support software, which allows managers to perform such functions as budgeting, statistical analysis and information retrieval, runs on I.B.M.'s mainframe and personal computers.

title: League Hears O'Callahan CaseBrian O'Neill, the executive vice president of the National Hockey League, held a hearing in Toronto yesterday on Jack O'Callahan, the Black Hawk defenseman who was assessed a match penalty in Chicago Wednesday night for attempting to injure the Rangers' Dave Maloney.
description: O'Neill had no comment after the hearing, in which he met with O'Callahan and the Black Hawks' general manager, Bob Pulford. According to a spokesman, he will make his findings known today, at which time he will also announce any further suspension of O'Callahan, if any.

title: Miss Jaeger Gains
description: Top-seeded Andrea Jaeger scored a 6-2, 6-3 victory over Sharon Walsh tonight in the first round of the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Washington tournament. In another first-round match, Carling Bassett of Canada, was upset by Sandra Collins, 5-7, 7-5, 7-5, after Miss Bassett held a 4-1 lead in the third set.

title: Robert Benowicz Memorial
description: A memorial service for Robert J. Benowicz, author of ''Non Prescription Drugs'' and other books, will be held at 7 P.M. Jan. 25 at St. John's-in-the-Village, 224 Waverly Place. Mr. Benowicz, a teacher at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn and Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan before he turned to writing full-time, died of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan Nov. 16.

title: AMNESTY PLAN FOR ILLEGAL ALIENS SEEN AS COSTLY
description: Illegal aliens now in this country cost the American public $25 billion a year, and that cost will become permanent if legislation to grant amnesty to those aliens is adopted, a study by a Rice University economist asserts.

title: Dow Off 5.90 in Lackluster Trading
description: The stock market began the new year yesterday with a lackluster performance. Most equities ended slightly lower in sluggish trading.

title: SYRIA FREES FLIER, ATTRIBUTING STEP TO JACKSON'S TRIP
description: The Syrian Government today released Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr., the United States Navy flier its forces captured in central Lebanon a month ago after shooting down his plane.

title: R. M. Gilmore, Whale Expert, Dies on Brink of Expedition
description: Raymond M. Gilmore, an expert on whales, died, apparently of a heart attack, as he was about to board a whale-watching boat Saturday.

title: CHINA PREMIER BIDS U.S. KEEP PLEDGE ON TAIWAN
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang said today that when he visits the White House next week he will not press President Reagan to halt ''immediately or completely'' the sale of United States military hardware to Taiwan.

title: November Orders Up by 2.2% 812WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) - A big jump in orders for military goods pushed total orders to American manufacturers up 2.2 percent in November, the Commerce Department reported today.
description: With manufacturers increasing their shipping even faster, stockpiles of goods stayed about the same - leaving the shipment-to-inventory ratio at its lowest level in 33 years, the department said.

title: Repair of Bridge Slows I-95 Traffic
description: Traffic on the Connecticut Turnpike will be slowed for the next five days as the State Department of Transportation installs a permanent bridge over the Mianus River.

title: PENNZOIL, GETTY PACT IS REPORTED
description: In a venture that would give them 100 percent ownership of the Getty Oil Company, the Pennzoil Company and Gordon P. Getty have joined forces to buy the 48 million Getty shares they do not control for a reported price of $112 a share, or $5.4 billion, Wall Street sources said last night.

title: Scholastic Break
description: ''I'm so happy for the kids of New York,'' Fred Thompson, the meet director for the Colgate Women's Games, said after learning that a rule prohibiting the city's high school athletes from participating in outside competition during the school season was waived yesterday. Thompson credited Angelo Aponte of the Board of Education for pushing through a vote of high school principals to waive the rule in time for the 10th Colgate Games, which begin Friday.

title: HEAD OF U.S.I.A. SECRETLY TAPED TOP REAGAN AIDE
description: The following article is based on reporting by Jane Perlez and William Safire and was written by Miss Perlez.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HERSELF DEFINED. The Poet H. D. and Her World. By Barbara Guest. Illustrated. 360 pages. Doubleday & Company. $18.95.

title: Diplomats Report Iraqi Deal With Kurds
description: President Saddam Hussein has signed an agreement with a Kurdish rebel leader, Jalal Talabani, for a cease-fire in the Kurdish region of Iraq and broader autonomy for the 2.5 million Kurds in the area, diplomats said today.

title: SCOUTING
description: Anxious Time

title: U.S.F.L. Draft at Glance
description: Place and time - The Terrace Room of the Roosevelt Hotel, Madison Avenue and 45th Street, 10 A.M. today and 9 A.M. Thursday. Rounds and time limit - The 18 teams will have eight minutes to make a selection in rounds 1 and 2, five minutes in rounds 3 through 5 and two minutes in rounds 6 through 19. Number of players - A total of 824 will be chosen - 420 in the territorial phase, 404 in the open phase, including two supplementary choices after the final round. The two choices will be made to accommodate two trades made before the draft was shortened to 19 rounds from the originally planned 24.

title: U.S.F.L. SEEKS STARS IN DRAFT
description: One agent calls it a ''Wild West shootout,'' and another contends that a million-dollar bonus will go to the lucky winner.

title: 2-Alarm Fire at Essex House
description: A two-alarm fire on the second floor at the Essex House hotel on Central Park South forced hundreds of guests to leave their rooms and go to the lobby for about an hour early yesterday. Seven people suffered minor injuries.

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Art for Food

title: Church Groups Linked To X-Rated Film House
description: Ten religious and charitable groups have found to their embarrassment that some of their good deeds are being paid for by X-rated movies.

title: BLACKMUN BLOCKS 4 EXECUTIONS
description: Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court rebuked Missouri officials today for preparing to execute four murderers before they had a chance to appeal their sentences to the Court.

title: Georgia Success Unexpected
description: Essentially the biggest difference between Georgia and Texas was one not of style or substance but of expectations. At the end of a season in which Herschel Walker was a spectator instead of No. 34 in the silver britches, the Bulldogs were gratified and perhaps surprised to be in the Cotton Bowl game. Texas, on the other hand, had made its New Year's reservations well in advance.

title: SUPPORT WANING FOR BEIRUT ROLE
description: The chorus of discontent with President Reagan's policy in Lebanon grew even louder in Congress today, as lawmakers from both parties urged greater diplomatic efforts to broaden the base of the Beirut Government and to extricate marines from a country where 250 Americans have already died.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Darryl Sutter , the captain of the Chicago Black Hawks, underwent treatment yesterday for a fractured cheekbone and an eye injury suffered when he was hit by a puck fired by a teammate during Monday's game against the Minnesota North Stars. Dr. Frank Sidell said Sutter would probably be sidelined for six weeks. . . . Willie Aikens of the Toronto Blue Jays surrendered at a Federal prison in Fort Worth yesterday to begin serving a 90-day sentence for attempted possession of cocaine. . . . Kim McQuilken , the quarterback who helped the Washington Federals to their only four victories last season, has announced his retirement at the age of 32 to enter business.

title: DEPOSED NIGERIAN PRESIDENT IS UNDER ARREST
description: Nigeria's deposed President, Shehu Shagari, has been placed under arrest, the Lagos radio reported today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Success in Gloves

title: A Lotto Victory For Christmas
description: A Clifton woman whose husband hid a winning lottery ticket for almost two months to present it to her on Christmas Day showed up with her spouse today to pick up the first installment of her $993,405 prize.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss. Results for fiscal 1983 include a nonrecurring gain of $159,000 on the sale of a plant and a $325,000 reversal in the fourth quarter of tax reserves provided in prior years which are no longer deemed necessary.

title: NEBRASKA ALSO WON
description: MIAMI The University of Miami football players did

title: Debt Issues
description: * CMI Corp., an Oklahoma City distributor of automated roadbuilding equipment, said it was continuing negotiations with its lenders on a plan to restructure $80 million of short-term debt, and that it expected to reach a tentative agreement by the end of the first quarter.

title: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 4, 1984 International
description: Syria freed the American Navy flier its forces captured in central Lebanon a month ago after shooting down his plane. The Syrian Foreign Ministry said the release of Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr. was in response to ''the human appeal of the Rev. Jesse Jackson'' and demands of the United States. The ministry expressed hope that Washington would now take steps ''to end its military involvement'' in Lebanon. (Page A1, Col. 6.) President Reagan thanked Syria for releasing Lieutenant Goodman and suggested to President Hafez al- Assad that the flier's return presented ''an opportune moment to put all the issues on the table'' between Washington and Damascus. Mr. Reagan praised Jesse Jackson for succeeding on a mission that he had expressed doubts about. (A1:5.)

title: Bodies of Train Crew Found
description: The bodies of two Burlington Northern crew members were recovered early today along with the locomotive that carried them into the Willamette River as it sped off an open railroad bridge, the authorities said. Paul Horan, a deputy medical examiner, said it was not immediately determined if the engineer, Douglas Richardson of Portland, 36 years old, and the brakeman, Terry Brothers of Vancouver, Wash., 34, drowned in the accident.

title: WINE TALK
description: Let's just suppose for a minute that you'd been asked to set up a wine tasting here in Paris, a tasting for about 30 Americans and Britons who live here and who would like to know something, or at least more than they already do, about French wine.

title: FACING WORLD AFTER 31 SILENT YEARS
description: David Tom listened to the train rumble by outside his new home. He picked up a newspaper, glanced at it, and looked at the Chinese characters on the wall. Then he sat and put his head in his arms.

title: Litton to Acquire Core Laboratories Litton Industries said it would acquire the approximately 90 percent of Core Laboratories Inc. that it does not already own, paying $33 a share, or about $176.2 million. Litton, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., said the acquisition was part of its strategy to expand services to the petroleum industry.
description: Litton bought 606,180 Core shares, or 10.2 percent of the 5,945,000 shares outstanding, for $9.4 million in November.

title: JAZZ: 'BILLIE HOLIDAY FESTIVAL'
description: CARMEN McRAE calls the program that she and Zoot Sims are doing at the Blue Note through Sunday ''a Billie Holiday festival'' rather than a ''tribute,'' which is the term customarily used when performers try to bolster their own reputations by leaning on Miss Holiday's songs.

title: New Mexico Sale
description: The Public Service Company of New Mexico said it had sold its 28.8 percent interest in the San Juan IV coal-fired generating unit to the M-S-R Public Power Agency for about $171 million in cash. M-S-R is a California organization composed of the cities of Santa Clara and Redding as well as the Modesto Irrigation District. Public Service said some proceeds from the sale would be used to pay off its short-term debt, which totals about $97 million.

title: CABARET: BUDDY BARNES SINGS
description: BUDDY BARNES is a pianist and singer who is known best for the years he spent as accompanist to Mabel Mercer. On his own, as he is Tuesdays through Saturdays at La Vert Galante, 109 West 46th Street, Mr. Barnes plays and sings a provocative mixture of songs by the basic supper club songwriters - Cole Porter, Cy Coleman, the Gershwins - along with a seemingly endless array of other sources, such as Alec Wilder, Murray Grand and the repertory of Miss Mercer.

title: OAKLAHOMA LAWMAKERS TRY AGAIN ON BUDGET CRISIS
description: A little more than a year ago, Gov. George Nigh of Oklahoma was the envy of his peers at the National Governors' Conference. His biggest problem was deciding how his oil-rich state would spend its budget surplus.

title: AULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Ex-Officer of Time Unit Joins Maritime Data
description: Larry T. Pfister, who was a vice president at Time Inc.'s Video Information Services, has joined the Maritime Data Network Ltd. in the newly created posts of president and chief executive.

title: 2 SEIZED IN BEATING IN A VIDEO ARCADE Two young men were arrested yerterday and charged with the fatal beating of another man in an upper East Side video arcade. the 18-year old victim, John Habib, was repeatedly struck with a baseball bat sunday night at the March toys arcade, on First Avenue near 77th Street and died of his injuries Monday.
description: Detectives of the 19th Precinct said that the attack, which took place while the arcade was crowded with video-game players, was the result of a ''petty dispute.''
