description: ''You Can't Take It With You,'' by Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman, closed after the Saturday evening performance at the Royale Theater. Directed by Ellis Rabb, the comedy ran for 312 performances and 7 previews. The cast included Eddie Albert, George Rose, Frances Sternhagen and Colleen Dewhurst.

title: Klaus Mehnert Dead; A Specialist on Russia
description: Klaus Mehnert, a leading West German expert on the Soviet Union and China, died Tuesday in a hospital in nearby Freudenstadt. He was 77.

title: JACKSON COUP AND '84 RACE
description: In the first days of the 1984 Presidential race, the Democratic candidates have abandoned the infighting that occupied them through the fall and have suddenly turned in unison to blistering assaults on President Reagan's foreign policy. For the Democrats, the culminating event was the Rev. Jesse Jackson's successful completion of a freelance diplomatic mission to Syria, where he won the release of Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr., a Navy flier held prisoner there.

title: ABC Unit to Buy Stake in ESPN ABC Video Enterprises Inc. plans to acquire 15 percent of ESPN, the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network, from the Getty Oil Company for between $25 million and $30 million, sources familiar with the deal said.
description: ESPN is a cable channel that offers sports and other programming to more than 23 million households.

title: Verbatim Corp. Sees Profit Drop SUNNYVALE, Calif., Jan. 3 (Reuters) - The Verbatim Corporation said results for the fiscal second quarter, ended Saturday, will not be as high as had been forecast Dec. 2. The company said that sales for the quarter, while up substantially from last year, will be below those of the first quarter, and that earnings will trail those of the period a year earlier.
description: Verbatim, which develops, manufactures and sells removable magnetic data-storage products, had forecast that profits for the quarter would increase 30 percent. The company said the principal reason for the expected drop in sales was a large product return from a major customer. Verbatim was the most active issue and biggest percentage loser on the American Stock Exchange today, plunging $3.25, to $13.75, on a volume of 730,500.

title: Saab's Sales At High in U.S.
description: Saab-Scania of America said today that it sold a record 25,833 Swedish-made Saab cars in the United States last year, up 42 percent from 18,179 sold in 1982, the previous high.

title: NEW FARM FORECLOSURE RULES
description: The Farmers Home Administration said today that it had temporarily modified its foreclosure rules so it could resume taking action against delinquent farm borrowers.

description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed Aug. 16, 1983.

description: SOMETIMES, almost as an afterthought, a wide-ranging survey unexpectedly turns up trends that are hard to explain.

title: Bridge: Exotic Australian Animals Are Joined by the Crocodile
description: There are many strange beasts in Australia: the Tasmanian devil, the wombat, the echidna and the duck- bill platypus, for example. But there are not supposed to be any crocodiles.

description: At least a million American children are abused or neglected every year. More than 50,000 of them are known to live in New York City, but there may be many more - 10 times as many, in the estimate of Dr. Vincent Fontana, chairman of the Mayor's Task Force on Child Abuse.

title: WALTER B. HAMLIN
description: Walter B. Hamlin, a former chief justice of the Louisiana Supreme Court, died Sunday after a brief illness. He was 86. Justice Hamlin left the court in 1973 at the mandatory retirement age of 75.

title: Citicorp Rates Off
description: Shearson's Down Interest rates fell slightly at yesterday's auctions of commercial paper by Citicorp and Shearson/American Express Inc.

title: Favorite-Son Slate Planned
description: Mayor Harold Washington announced today that he would support a favorite-son slate of uncommitted delegates to the Democratic National Convention. Mr. Washington said he had not decided whom he would support in the March 20 Democratic primary, but he said his slate of delegates would be asked to cast their Presidential votes in the direction he chose.

title: RULES DRAFTED FOR CONCERTS IN CENTRAL pARK
description: Guidelines on the use of Central Park for concerts are now being drafted by city officials that ''at a minimum'' would require some performers to pay for security and cleaning up.

title: What Was Lost in Nigeria

title: EATING IN HARLEM: PLACE THAT SERVE 'DOWN HOME' FOOD
description: AS many longtime residents of Harlem will tell you, the dining scene is a far cry from what it was years ago. People still reminisce about old favorites that have disappeared, places like Wells, where you could wander in at 4 A.M. and have Joe Wells rustle up his famous culinary combination, fried chicken with waffles. Or Frank's on 125th Street, which was elbow to elbow after big shows at the nearby Apollo Theater, and Obie's on 135th Street and Seventh Avenue, a small storefront shop that opened at 11 P.M. and served grits, sausages, eggs and chops until dawn.

title: T.W.A.'S CHALLENGE TO UNIONS

description: Dwayne Washington, with 28 points, and Gene Waldron, with 18 of his 20 in the second half, led Syracuse past Villanova tonight, 79-70, in a Big East Conference game.

title: WHERE NEOLIBERALS STAND
description: In recent years, some liberals who have found themselves unhappy with the conventions of their faith have begun to form a movement of renewal and reform that has come to be called neoliberalism. Most of the reports about the new movement that have appeared in the press have described it as conservative, a part of a general trend toward the right, as were neoconservatives who came before us.

title: One American Out, 1,800 to Go

description: SEY

title: ARGENTINE PIONEERS: HIGH TECH AT TIP OF THE WORLD

title: ARAFAT THE DIPLOMAT
description: Yasir Arafat's trip to Cairo last month to speak with President Hosni Mubarak has been widely dismissed in the United States and Israel as a meaningless gesture by a desperate man. Nothing could be further from the truth. In fact, Mr. Arafat's trip can be seen as a turning point - a decision to emphasize diplomacy rather than armed struggle - that now poses important choices for Israel, Egypt and the United States.

title: Text of Statement By Syria on Flier ;
description: Following is the text of a statement on the release of Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr. that was issued today by the Syrian Foreign Ministry and translated by The Associated Press from the Arabic: Answering the human appeal of the Rev. Jesse Jackson to President Hafez al-Assad during their meeting Monday and also the demands of the U.S. Government to release the American pilot Lieutenant Goodman and in a contribution of the Syrian Government to creating circumstances that would facilitate the withdrawal of American troops from Lebanon, the Syrian Government has decided to release the American pilot.

title: THE 3 PROTAGONISTS
description: The struggle for control of Warner Communications Inc. will provide an arena for three of the country's toughest and most closely watched entrepreneurs.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SAMPLING The Riverside Dance Festival is one of Terpsichore's more enduring New York operations, housed in the Theater of the Riverside Church, 120th Street and Riverside Drive (864- 2929). It aims to present a broad spectrum of what is going on in that world, a goal summarized in its third annual ''Sampler'' program that starts tonight at 7:30 with a half-dozen examples.

title: IF WIND CHILL IS -51,o IOWANS KNOW THE POLITICIANS CAN'T BE FAR BEHIND
description: On a recent night here, a thick glaze of frost formed on the insides of the windows, a pile of puffy down coats and furry boots reached halfway to the ceiling by the front door, and the wind whistling over the chimney quickly sucked all the fire out of the stout log that Mel Wilson had tossed into his fireplace.

title: President Quits At Wyly Corp.
description: J. Allen Hufft has resigned as president and chief operating officer of the Wyly Corporation, a Dallas-based computer services company, Wyly said yesterday.

title: WHITE HOUSE REPORTED NEAR '85 BUDGET PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration is near the final decisions on a 1985 budget that will propose $9 billion in domestic spending cuts and show a deficit of $186 billion, Congressional and Administration sources reported today.

title: Express Coach to Oilers
description: Hugh Campbell , the former Canadian Football League coach, who led the Los Angeles Express in the first United States Football League season last year, left the Express to become head coach of the Houston Oilers, and John Hadl , the former star quarterback, was named as his replacement at the Express. By signing Campbell, a former coach of the Edmonton Eskimos, the Oilers may have improved their chances of signing one of his former stars, Warren Moon , the free agent quarterback who led the Eskimos to five consecutive league championships. Moon, who has been talking with several clubs in the National, the Canadian and the United States football leagues, has said he would find Houston more attractive if the Oilers hired Campbell.

description: b-Net income.

title: Lambert Trophy To
description: Boston College, which had a 9-3 record, including a late-season 27-17 victory over Penn State, today was named the winner of the Lambert-Meadowlands Trophy, symbolic of the best Division I-A football team in the East. It was the first time since 1942 that the Eagles were named the top team in the East.

title: PROCESSORS OF FOOD USING MORE CORN
description: An industry report says Americans are putting more corn in their supermarket shopping carts, and it is not all corn flakes or snacks to go with bean dip.

title: Kerr-McGee Corp.
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation said it expects to take a nonrecurring charge of $24.7 million in the fourth quarter, which would reduce its full- year earnings by 40 percent to 50 percent from 1982. The company earned $209.8 million, or $3.98 a share, in 1982. Kerr-McGee said $8 million of the total charge would reflect additional provisions for possible losses arising from the company's deep-well drilling programs.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Iona vs. Louisville , followed by St. John's vs. Rutgers , at Madison Square Garden; first game, 7 P.M. Among the starters for Coach Denny Crum's visiting Cardinals are Billy Thompson and Milt Wagner, both from Camden, N.J. Thompson, a 6-foot-8-inch forward, was erratic as a highly touted freshman last season, when he played behind Rodney and Scooter McCray, but has turned much steadier.

title: ROME OR ROMA? CHINA OR ZHONGGUO?
description: To a small band of Federal workers, name- calling is serious business.

description: OUTDOOR space is one of New York's precious commodities, and those New Yorkers fortunate enough to have some - whether a sliver of terrace or a full backyard - are missing months of garden pleasures if they have not factored winter into garden design.

description: The GAF Corporation, whose board was ousted last month by dissident shareholders, said yesterday that it planned to close three of its roofing materials plants.

description: With a strong display of troops and armor, the Government appeared tonight to have halted a wave of rioting that broke out in several cities last week and engulfed Tunis on Tuesday.

description: Angola appealed to the Security Council today to try again to halt military actions against Angolan targets by South African troops.

title: Brazil Lifting Juice Prices RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 4 (AP) - Brazil, which expects to export more orange juice this year because of frost damage to United States citrus crops, will raise its minimum export price for orange juice by $150, to $1,250 a ton, the Government said today.
description: Brazil is the world's biggest exporter of orange juice. Its biggest customers are the United States and the European Common Market.

description: Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile ordered the military today to stop its own inquiries into the killing of the opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., after complaints that witnesses were being intimidated.

title: ON GRENADA, SOUNDING OFF AGAIN IN PRINT
CARE FOR FAR-OFF ELDERLY: SOURCES OF HELP
description: FOR the growing numbers of Americans engaged in the long-distance care of elderly relatives, stress can be a way of life. According to social scientists who have studied them, caretakers may be beset by staggering financial burdens, by the frustrations inherent in making medical or housekeeping arrangements at a distance and by confusion about the services that are available from government bureaucracies and social agencies. Frequently, too, there is the toll of emotional strain arising from dealing with elderly relatives' illness or incapacity.

title: POLITICAL SNUB IS INFURIATING SWISS WOMEN
description: Swiss women refer to Dec. 7 as Black Wednesday, the day the Swiss Parliament soundly rejected the first woman ever to stand for the country's seven-member ruling Federal Council.

title: Rose Kennedy 'Improving'
description: Rose Kennedy was said to be ''improving'' from a viral infection today, but hospital officials said she would probably stay there until the weekend ''as a precautionary measure.'' Mrs. Kennedy, 93 years old, was admitted to St. Mary's Hospital last Thursday when she became ill after swimming at her oceanside home in nearby Palm Beach.

title: DR. DOROTHY M. DOHEN
description: Dr. Dorothy M. Dohen, professor of sociology at Fordham University's Lincoln Center campus and an authority on spiritual and ascetic literature, died of cancer Tuesday at her home in Manhattan.

description: This should be the Year of the Homemaker. Political party platforms could provide a port of entry for ''family policy'' ideas that reward a parent for staying home and rearing children.

title: Switch in Rate Index
description: The interest rate index for municipal bond yields has been changed to the Kenny Index, compiled by the J. J. Kenny Company. The index, which is regarded by market participants as the most accurate measure of long-term tax-exempt bond yields, is based on the average price and yield of 250 issues. The previous index was based on the current yield, after sales charges, of unit investment trusts offered by John Nuveen & Company.

title: MONDALE, CAMPAIGNING IN THE SOUTH, APEALS FOR SUPPORT OF BLACKS
description: Outside the Bethel Baptist Church, a dozen demonstrators carried placards and noisily chanted, ''We want Jesse.'' Inside the church, the folding chairs had been cleared away and the standing, predominantly black audience listened quietly as former Vice President Walter F. Mondale asked for their support.

title: POLAND'S POSTPONEMENT IN RAISING THE PRICE OF FOOD IS NOW OFFICIAL
description: The Polish Government has put off food price increases scheduled for the beginning of the year until at least February.

title: Venezuela Debt Delay CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 4 (AP) - The Venezuelan Government will ask its creditor banks for a new moratorium on payment of its $35 billion foreign debt, Finance Ministry sources said today.
description: The most recent grace period, granted in 1983, expires Jan. 31, two days before Social Democratic President-elect, Jaime Lusinchi, assumes office.

description: Officials of Dr Pepper, who have signed a definitive agreement to merge with the New York investment firm of Forstmann Little & Company in a transaction valued at $512.5 million, declined to comment on the DPCC deadline extension.

description: The British Petroleum Company said that it had completed the sale of 9.75 percent of its interest in the Forties oilfield in the North Sea.

description: Only a last- minute dive prevented a collision by two Pan American World Airways passenger jets carrying 496 people, officials said today. They said air traffic controllers mistakenly directed the two planes to intersecting flight paths.

title: PENTAGON RESISTANCE ON PARTS CITED

title: Indiana Names Mallory
description: Bill Mallory , the head football coach at Northern Illinois, has been named head coach at Indiana University, replacing Sam Wyche , who resigned last week to coach the Cincinnati Bengals. Mallory, a graduate of Miami (Ohio) University, has a 14- year coaching record of 99-52-1, including stints at his alma mater, Colorado and Northern Illinois, where he had a 25-19 record over four years, including a 9-2 mark last season. Wyche, who took over at Indiana after the dismissal of Lee Corso last year, had a 3-8 record in his season there. . . . Joe Kapp , coach at the University of California, has signed a new five-year contract.

title: Technology; Audiotex: Data By Telephone
description: MOVE over videotex. Here comes audiotex. Videotex, in which people retrieve information using computers or specially equipped television sets, has not really caught on, partly because most people do not have computers. But virtually everyone has a telephone. So now many companies are trying to offer information services using electronic voices.

title: Cable Company Buys Roughnecks
description: Tulsa Cable Television has taken over ownership of the Tulsa Roughnecks, the champions of the North American Soccer League, the company's president, Mark Savage, said today.

title: Envoy Says U.S. Seeks Talks By North and South Koreans
description: Ambassador Richard Walker of the United States said today that Washington would continue discussions with China, and possibly the Soviet Union, to bring about a dialogue between North and South Korea.

title: NIGERIAN RULER TELLS DIPLOMATS WHY HE TOOK OVER
description: Nigeria's new leader, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari, met with foreign diplomats today to give the reasons for the military coup Saturday that overthrew the elected Government of President Shehu Shagari.

title: Sicily Arrests 8 in Murders
description: The police said today that they had arrested eight people here who are suspected of belonging to the Mafia and of being involved in 17 murders and 15 bombings in the Palermo area.

title: Adults Upset by Milk May Tolerate Yogurt
description: Yogurt could be a good source of protein for millions of adults around the world who cannot drink milk, because the sour food digests itself in the body, researchers have found.

title: BIG BEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
Comings and Goings
description: Len (Truck) Robinson , the Knick forward, had X-rays of his painful left wrist taken yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. Although the X-rays showed no fracture, Robinson did not practice with the team later in the day at Upsala College in East Orange, N.J. . . . Marvis Frazier , the heavyweight boxer, tore a tendon in his right leg while sparring and will face surgery. He will be out from three to six months, forcing the cancellation of a series of bouts tentatively scheduled through April. . . . Ken Riley , who has retired after 15 years as a Bengal cornerback, was named defensive backfield coach of the Green Bay Packers, rejoining Forrest Gregg , his head coach at Cincinnati until Gregg accepted the head coaching job at Green Bay Dec. 24. . . . Mary Alice Hill was named athletic director at San Diego State, making her the first woman to run a mjor college program. . . . Steve Scott , American record-holder in the mile, has joined the field for the Wanamaker Mile Jan. 27 at Madison Square Garden's Millrose Games. . . . Ozzie Virgil , a Philadelphia Phillies catcher, has a franctured right hand, the result of an accidental gunshot wound that he suffered on New Year's at a party in Puerto Rico. Virgil was examined in Philadelphia yesterday and a team doctor said he should be ready to play in spring training. . . . Woody Wienhofer , the 40-year-old veteran defensive coordinator of the Pittsburgh Steelers, has taken the head- coaching job with the Oklahoma Outlaws, an expansion team in the U.S.F.L.

title: TEEN-AGE CHASTITY IS THE WRONG PRESCRIPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: $1 Billion Issue For Fannie Mae The Federal National Mortgage Association announced plans to price $1 billion of new four-year debentures today for sale tomorrow.
description: The debentures will be dated Jan. 10 and will mature on Jan. 11, 1988, with the first payment of interest on July 11, 1984. The minimum purchase will be $10,000 for the issue, which will be used to redeeem $500 million of 14.05 percent debentures maturing Jan. 10 and to finance operations.

title: THAYER QUITS AS DEFENSE DEPUTY OVER EXPECTED CHARGES BY S.E.C.
description: The Deputy Secretary of Defense, Paul Thayer, resigned today, saying that the Securities and Exchange Commission plans to charge him with illegally passing along ''insider'' stock trading information to others.

title: A BLEND OF OLD AND NEW SHAPES A LIVE-IN BARN
description: THAT the barns were not for sale never bothered Mariette or Raymond Gomez. Nor did the fact that a large portion of the roof had collapsed or that there were still dirt floors. ''The minute we saw the barns we knew they had to be ours,'' Mrs. Gomez said. ''Even as a wreck they were beautiful.''

title: THE WICK TAPES (II)
description: ''By the time we get specifics,'' said Charles Wick, Director of the United States Information Agency, speaking on the telephone from Palm Beach, Fla., ''we won't have anybody come up with money.''

title: CONWED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

Continental Court Case HOUSTON, Jan. 4 (AP) - A Federal judge taking testimony on Continental Air Lines' request for protection from its creditors under the bankruptcy laws is expected to rule within two weeks on a union motion to dismiss the company's petition, filed last September.
description: United States Bankruptcy Judge R. F. Wheless took the case under advisement Tuesday after 11 days of testimony in which union lawyers said Continental had used the bankruptcy proceedings to force lower wages and longer working hours. In response, Continental's counsel, John Donovan, said the airline was a ''classic'' candidate for the reorganization process because it had five-year losses of $521.9 million and a negative net worth last September of $51.4 million.

title: FLAME INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income including tax credits of $152,000 for the quarter and $733,000 for the year.

title: OF BEN-GURION, BEGIN AND AN IMPROPER DIFFERENTIATION
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO PROPOSES A BROAD AGENDA IN ANNUAL SPEECH
description: Transcript of address, page B8.

title: AMERICA'S OWN SOVIET ARMY FIGHTS LASER 'WARS'
description: A chilly morning wind raced through the gullies of the Mojave Desert 120 miles northeast of Los Angeles as Lieut. Col. Joe Stull radioed instructions to his Army regiment from a shotgun post on his command jeep.

title: ELECTIONS BACKED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A proposal for early elections for a new chamber of Parliament to represent South Africans of mixed race was approved unanimously today by the Labor Party.

title: RAIDER WHO STILL BATTLES ODDS
description: LOS ANGELES As he strolled through the hotel

title: SCOUTING
description: Talks to Open

title: OUTSPOKEN CRITIC OF COST OVERRUNS
description: In his year in office, Paul Thayer has helped bring to public attention the sometimes-shoddy work of military contractors and tackled the problem of overpricing of spare parts. Within the Pentagon, he sought realistic pricing to prevent overruns and more interservice procurement programs to cut costs.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The 1982 share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect 5-for-4 stock split in April 1983.

title: Five-Part Film Series Offered on Holocaust
description: The 92d Street Y will present ''The Holocaust: Guilt and Responsibility,'' a five-part film series, beginning Jan. 26 and running each consecutive Thursday through Feb. 23 at 8 P.M.

title: 4 Subway Lines Reshuffle Service
description: The New York City Transit Authority has adjusted the service on four subway lines in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn to allow track and structural repairs, authorities said yesterday. The affected lines are the Nos. 1, 2 and 5 and the M.

title: Militiaman Allied With Israel Has Lebanese Rank Restored
description: Maj. Saad Haddad, the pro-Israeli south Lebanese militia leader who is in a Haifa hospital reportedly suffering from leukemia, officially got his Lebanese rank and rights restored today, the Israeli radio reported.

title: RETAIL SALES IN CITY UP 12.9%
description: Retail sales in New York City rose 12.9 percent in December from a year earlier, the second-biggest monthly gain last year, a spot-check found yesterday. The increase far exceeded the December 1982 gain of 4.8 percent over December 1981.

title: THIRTY FILE IN FIRST PRIMARY
description: Claude Kirk Jr., a former Governor of Florida, beat the filing deadline by a few minutes Tuesday and became the 30th and final Presidential candidate to enter the Feb. 28 New Hampshire primary.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Nostalgia Brings A Name Change

title: ISRAELI ARABS TAKE COMPLAINTS TO PRIME MINISTER
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir met today with a group of Israel's Arab citizens who complained to him of unequal treatment by the Government and violence by militant Jews.

title: Sinus-Lung Ailment Is Found To Cause Infertility in Men
description: An obscure sinus and lung infection called Young's syndrome appears to be a relatively common cause of infertility in men, a study has found.

title: PANTRY PRIDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 19
description: b-After a gain of $255,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $1,460,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $112,000, a tax credit of $835,000 and $1 million from Chapter 11 debt reduction.

title: POPULARITY OF PETROLEUM GAS ADDS TO CONCERNS FOR SAFETY
description: The increasing use of petroleum gases in homes and factories has provoked a rise in concern about the safety of people using the highly explosive chemicals, according to Federal agencies and some environmental groups.

title: NEW CASES WIDEN VIEWS ABOUT AIDS
description: New evidence was reported yesterday that acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, can be spread heterosexually and transmitted even before a person shows outward manifestations of the disease.

title: Trial Opens in Suit Against Pistol Maker
description: An attorney for a man paralyzed from the neck down by a gunshot told a jury hearing a $43 million lawsuit today that the makers and sellers of a .22-caliber pistol should be held liable. The trial opened today.

title: Lawyer for Top Labor Figures Files Petition for Bankruptcy
description: Morris Shenker, a millionaire lawyer who is chairman of the Dunes Hotel in Las Vegas, has filed for bankruptcy, court documents indicated today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Savings Bank has promoted Cheryl Bell, John H. Kraus and Harold W. Wissing to vice president.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: RAREFIED Anyone who has ever felt that once you have seen one mountain, you have seen them all should be brought immediately to the second floor of the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street (860- 1777), where there are hundreds of them on view in photographs.

title: CHICAGO DEBATES BAN ON LEADED GAS
description: The poison is spewed along city streets and expressways thousands of times each day. It settles in the teeth and bones of children, causing anemia and in some cases nerve and brain damage, critics say.

title: CHANGES AT 'NEW' GETTY OIL OUTLINED
description: Gordon P. Getty, 49-year-old son of the late billionaire oilman J. Paul Getty, is to become chairman of a newly reorganized Getty Oil Company, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: AROUND THE NATION Mistaken Alert Sent To Pennsylvania Offices
description: A military attack warning was accidentally sent to county emergency officials across Pennsylvania today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The 21st century is now so close, we can almost reach out and touch it.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN a door refuses to close properly because it sticks or binds or won't latch shut, the solution that usually comes first to mind is to take off the door and plane the edges. Often, however, such drastic measures are unnecessary.

title: Lower Airline Losses Seen GENEVA, Jan. 4 (AP) - The world's troubled air transport industry will report lower losses for 1983 than had been predicted earlier, according to a statement released today by the International Air Transport Association.
description: The association's Director General, Knut Hammarskjold, said it now appeared that the organization's 124 member airlines made an operating profit in 1983 of $1 billion, leaving a net loss of $700 million or less after interest payments.

title: U.S. Says a Contractor Overcharged Pentagon
description: The Government filed a civil suit against a military contractor today, saying it overcharged the Air Force and Navy for jet parts.

title: 14 Are Killed as Europe Is Pounded by Storm
description: Winter's first major storm hammered Europe today for a third day, disrupting transportation, cutting power and causing at least 14 deaths.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Prices of U.S. Issues Advance
description: Prices of some Government securities rose sharply yesterday in active trading. Interest rates fell as professional dealers purchased securities to repackage them for retail clients.

title: THREE VIETNAM VETERANS ARRESTED IN BURNING OF A BUDDHIST TEMPLE
description: Three Vietnam veterans, patients at a Veterans Administration hospital here, surrendered today and were charged with burning a small Buddhist temple in the remote Berkshire hamlet of Hawley.

title: Rise in German Jobless
description: West Germany's unemployment rate climbed to 9.5 percent in December from 8.8 percent in November, the Government said today.

title: A JURY IS SELECTED IN RETRIAL OF CRAFT CASE
description: A six-man, six-woman jury was selected in Joplin, Mo., yesterday for the second trial involving Christine Craft, the former Kansas City television news anchor who charged in a $3.5 million fraud suit that her employer demoted her because she refused to alter her appearance.

title: AUSTRALIAN COVERED THE WARS
description: Richard Hughes, a Far East expert and flamboyant foreign and war correspondent for Australian and British publications for more than 40 years, died yesterday of a liver ailment in Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Hong Kong. He was 77 years old and lived in Hong Kong.

title: TENTATIVE FEDERAL BUDGET PROPOSES 17% RISE IN MILITARY SPENDING
description: The Reagan Administration has tentatively decided to project a 17 percent increase in military spending in its 1985 budget. The substantial one-year rise reflects both the President's commitment to a continued military buildup and added spending for programs Congress has already authorized.

title: Newark Council Revises Curfew
description: The City Council today voted 9 to 0 to revise a curfew to keep youngsters under 13 years old off streets at night.

title: China Trade Surplus Cut
description: Chinese exports rose four-tenths of 1 percent in 1983, but imports rose 6.6 percent, to cut the country's balance of trade surplus, according to figures reported today. The official New China News Agency did not cite specific trade figures, but the percentage changes indicate that China's trade surplus fell to about 3.46 billion yuan, or about $1.8 billion, from 4.66 billion yuan a year earlier.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Computers Ahoy

title: HOME BEAT
description: ACCORDING to Donna Pettick, who, with Anne Mele, owns the Able Child, a lower-Manhattan educational-toy store, Multigrip cutlery ''gives a person the option of grasping the pieces from the outside like large handles, or grasping them through the holes if their grasp is weak.'' The dishwasher-safe utensils, right, have knife, fork or spoon extensions that can be angled in any direction and will suit right- or left-handed people.

title: Rumsfeld Is in Beirut For New Mideast Tour
description: Donald Rumsfeld, the special United States envoy, arrived in Beirut tonight at the start of a Middle Eastern tour expected to take him to several capitals, including Damascus, the Beirut radio said.

title: ; TV NEWS SUPPLY AT THE PUBLIC'S DEMAND
description: To the Editor:

title: THURSDAY, JANUARY 5, 1984 International
description: Heavy casualties were reported as 16 Israeli fighter-bombers, flying in four-plane formations, struck targets in the eastern Lebanon town of Baalbek. The Beirut radio said the hourlong raids left nearly 100 dead and 400 wounded. The International Committee of the Red Cross said most of the casualties were civilians. The Israeli command said the targets were two bases used by Iranian-supported guerrillas. (Page A1, Column 6.) The situation in Lebanon shows signs of improvement, according to Reagan Administration officials. They asked Republican Congressional leaders to withhold any drastic action that could undercut that movement. The Republican leaders, in turn, warned that members of Congress and their constituents are rapidly losing patience with Administration policy in Lebanon. (A1:5.)

title: No Headline
description: N.C.A.A. Charges Sent to Illinois

title: Reversal Sought of Bell Order
description: A group of telephone equipment suppliers formally asked the Federal Communications Commission late today to set aside an order that allows the Bell System companies to refer customers who need a telephone to their own subsidiaries.

title: PLIGHT OF NEGLECTED CHILDREN STIRS MANY TO HELP NEEDIEST
description: Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are moved by the thought of lonely, neglected children deprived of the holiday season gaiety around them.

title: Ecuador Satellite Station
description: The United States today formally handed over to Ecuador a National Aeronautics and Space Administration satellite tracking station located on the Cotopaxi volcano, 50 miles south of Quito. Eduador's Defense Ministry will administer the station to process information obtained from satellite photographs, such as an inventory of natural resources. The ministry will also offer information to nations in the northwestern sector of South America, in Central America and in the Caribbean.

title: INDIANIA NEW CENTER FOR JEWISH BOOKS
description: Bloomington, a small community in southern Indiana, scarcely seems the sort of place that one would go for bagels and lox or to find an outpouring of Jewish literature. But Indiana University Press has embarked on an ambitious program of publishing books of Jewish interest that is quickly offsetting the incongruency of the location.

title: Hoyas Beat UConn In Big East Opener
description: Pat Ewing scored 18 points and Bill Martin contributed 13 points and 10 rebounds tonight to lead Georgetown to an 81-69 victory over Connecticut in the Big East Conference opener for both teams.

title: GENERALS PICK DEOSSIE
description: In an unfinished room with an exposed ceiling and a picture-window view of smoke stacks and oil tanks, the Generals continued their building process today - more with cement blocks, fittingly, than with glamour.

title: Nigeria Gives OPEC Pledge
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has received a pledge from Nigeria's new rulers that the African member country will support OPEC's price structure, the organization's news agency reported today.

title: INTERCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
HOME SAFETY FOR AGED
description: A task force of older people will be dispatched next year to check on safety hazards in housing for the elderly, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commissioner, Sam Zagoria. In remarks delivered to a forum on elderly consumers, organized by the Better Business Bureau, Mr. Zagoria said the task force will study about 2,000 residences for possible hazards.

title: American Plan Corp. Appoints a President
description: Robert C. Hall, who has had careers on Wall Street, in merchant banking and in international grain trading, will now try his hand as the president of an insurance company.

title: DIRECTOR OF 92D ST. Y NAMED A.T.& T. FOUNDATION
description: The executive director of the 92d Street Y, Dr. Reynold Levy, has been chosen president of a foundation being established by American Telephone and Telegraph that may rank among the six largest company-sponsored philanthropies in the country.

title: ADVERTISING ; Hakuhodo Signs Pact With Glendinning
description: A ''sales promotion assistance agreement'' may sound like something new in the area of foreign relations, but it happens to be a description of the concordat entered into by Glendinning Associates of Westport, Conn., and Hakuhodo, second only in size to Dentsu among Japan's ad agencies.

title: NEW EDITOR IS CHOSEN FOR VANITY FAIR
description: Tina Brown, the former editor of The Tatler magazine in London, has been named the third editor in chief of Vanity Fair. She replaces Leo Lerman, who was appointed to the position last April, less than two months after the first issue of the glossy monthly was panned by most critics.

title: N.C. STATE DEFEATED BY MARYLAND, 59-55
description: Herman Veal and Adrian Branch sank two free throws each in the final minutes tonight to lead Maryland to a 59-55 victory over North Carolina State in the Atlantic Coast Conference opener for both teams.

title: Carter Hawley Names Head of New Division
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. announced yesterday that it would establish a new division in New York City to do the buying for its store divisions. Francis H. Arnone, 44, chairman and chief executive of the Broadway-Southern California unit, becomes president of the new division Feb. 1.

title: STOCK CHOICES FROM MIDWEST
description: O NE increasingly popular approach to investing is to pick companies doing a substantial amount of business abroad. The expectation is that the strong dollar will eventually weaken, and that this, in turn, will increase corporate profits after adjustments for currency translations.

title: Strikers in Bangladesh Call for a Democracy
description: A dawn-to-noon strike was widely observed here and in several other parts of Bangladesh today in response to a call by opposition parties to force President Hussain Mohammed Ershad to restore democracy.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF CUOMO'S ADDRESS TO THE NEW YORK LEGISLATURE
description: Following is a transcript of Governor Cuomo's State of the State address to the Legislature, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Hudson Oil Files For Protection KANSAS CITY, Kan., Jan. 4 (AP) - The Hudson Oil Company, which operates gasoline stations in 31 states, and seven of its subsidiaries have filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
description: Mendel Small, an attorney who filed the petitions, said that seven of the eight corporations involved in the filing, including Hudson Oil, owed $9.3 million to banks and that the companies had many unsecured creditors. The Hudson Oil Company of Delaware Inc., which is based in Wichita, Kan., was not involved in the filing, he said.

title: Arson Suspect Asks New Status
description: A judge ordered an inquiry today to determine whether a 17-year-old youth was eligible to be tried as a youthful offender in four arson attacks in a Jewish community.

title: PANDICK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Pandick Inc. was formerly Pandick Press Inc.

title: GROMYKO COOL TO RENEWED ARMS TALKS
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko reiterated the Soviet position today that the West was trying to mislead public opinion by suggesting that ''nothing special has happened'' in the Geneva talks on medium- range missiles and that the Soviet Union might agree to resume them.

title: Coleco and Banks In Debt Accord WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 4 (Reuters) - Coleco Industries said that its lenders had agreed in principle to modify certain financial covenants affecting its $150 million line of credit with American banks.
description: Coleco said the agreement includes elimination of a prior requirement that Coleco be clear of debt for a 30- day period between November 1983 and late February 1984. Had the agreement not been reached, Coleco said, it would have been in default.

title: NU-TECH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
CORRECTION
description: A headline Dec. 23 on a dispatch from Washington about commitments for mortgage loans incorrectly identified the Federal National Mortgage Association. It is a private company.

title: Rewards for Coddling South Africa South Africa now pays the Reagan Administration the cheeky compliment of using the invasion of Grenada to justify its aerial bombardment of Angola. ''As little as the United States can afford a Grenada sitting on its doorstep,'' says the chief of South Africa's defense forces, ''so little can we allow in our bordering territories the enemies of the people that we are protecting to have a carte blanche.''
description: One needs to sort this out to grasp the logic. What South Africa is ''protecting'' is Namibia, a territory that it holds illegally.

title: Books: Illegal Aliens
description: THE TARNISHED DOOR: The New Immigrants and the Transformation of America. By John Crewdson. 354 pages. Times Books. $17.95.

title: Families May Be Evicted From Public Housing
description: Ten Vietnamese refugee families who were placed in public housing by an official accused of accepting bribes will be ordered out of the apartments, officials said today.

title: A Franchiser Sued by F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission charged in a suit today

title: ADVERTISING ; Fortune Confirmation Of Y. & R. Resignation
description: Fortune magazine confirmed yesterday that Young & Rubicam, its ad agency since 1967, had resigned the account rather that participate in an agency review.

title: Gretzky Scores 8 Points
description: Wayne Gretzky scored four

title: THE DANCE: CITY BALLET
description: The New York City Ballet reopened its repertory season Tuesday night at the State Theater with a program of extremes. George Balanchine's ''Mozartiana'' received its first performance of the season, while the Balanchine ''Episodes'' and Jerome Robbins's ''Concert'' featured different casts and debuts.

title: COOK SPARKS NETS TO VICTORY
description: Throughout his team's month-long slump, Net Coach Stan Albeck has been searching - sometimes pleading - for one of his players to display leadership in the crucial final minutes. In a 91-88 victory over Atlanta tonight, he finally received it, but not from a source he intended.

title: ADVERTISING ; Levine, Huntley to Run Airline's Ad Campaign
description: At a press conference yesterday Northeastern International Airways announced its plans to initiate inexpensive air service between Kennedy International Airport and Florida on Feb. 9, and to promote it with a $6 million ad campaign through Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver.

title: ADVERTISING ; Aide at Woman's Day Takes Post at Parade
description: Jay Burzon, who split on Oct. 31 with Woman's Day magazine, where he was vice president/associate publisher, starts work today at Parade Publications, where Carlo Vittorini, the president and publisher, has created a special job for him.

title: PHILADELPHIA MAYOR LISTS HIS CRITICAL OBJECTIVES
description: Philadelphia's new Mayor laid out an ambitious series of goals for the first 100 days of his administration today, saying they would ''permit us to begin laying a solid foundation for the future growth and development of this city.''

title: Generals' Selections
description: The New Jersey Generals' choices in the open and territorial phases of the U.S.F.L. draft. Open Phase

title: Britain Reacts Coolly to Offer From Argentina on Falklands
description: The British Foreign Office gave a cool reception today to an offer by Argentina's new civilian Government to negotiate on the future of the British colony in the Falkland Islands.

title: SCOUTING
description: Analyzing Moses

title: CHURCH COALITION ASSAILS UTILITY ADS FAVORING NUCLEAR POWER
description: A major religious coalition announced today that it would use church stock holdings to put pressure on utility companies to stop financing the nuclear industry's $20 million advertising campaign.

title: Topics Getting the Message
description: In Labels Veritas

title: East German Officer Flees
description: A uniformed East German police sergeant escaped to the West German state of Lower Saxony early today by scaling a border fence, the West German border police said. It was the second escape in two days.

title: RANGERS WIN IN OVERTIME
description: Pierre Larouche had the first shot, but that failed.

title: Mikan Heads Search
description: George Mikan , a pro basketball hall of famer, has been named by Rudy Perpich , the Governor of Minnesota, to head a 20-member task force to try to get a National Basketball Association franchise for the state. Mikan, 59 years old, starred for the Minneapolis Lakers before the team was moved to Los Angeles in 1958.

title: ELECTRO-CATHETER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
C.D. Rates Are Steady For the third consecutive week, average interest rates on money market accounts nationwide were unchanged at 8.49 percent, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.
description: Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, called the rates ''surprisingly stable. This is the longest period of little or no movement since we began tracking rates more than a year ago,'' he said.

title: Swiss Sex Ads an Issue
description: Swiss justice authorities charged the Blick newspaper today with violating new morals laws by publishing classified sex advertisements. The suit was the first brought under laws on pornography and prostitution that went into force Jan. 1. Blick officials said the advertisements, mainly for ''massage and sauna parlors'' with such names as Salon Tropical and Lolita, would continue pending a court ruling.

title: Drug Figure's Son Gets 5-Year Term
description: The son of a key figure in the French Connection drug case was sentenced yesterday to five years in jail for his role in a heroin ring said to have been run from his father's prison cell, Federal prosecutors said.

title: PRESERVING RARE LABELS ON FURNITURE
description: IN the so-called golden age of

title: FDP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THE DEMOCRATS' PATH TO A MAJORITY FORCE
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. MOVE IN VIDEO CAMERAS
description: Three of America's biggest names in electronics and photography are joining with Japanese manufacturers in an effort to take over the home movie market. Over the last two days, all three announced that they would offer their versions of a new generation of small, lightweight videotape cameras.

title: REAGAN BUDGET SAID TO INCLUDE MEDICARE SHIFT
description: President Reagan will again ask Congress to revise the Medicare program so that elderly people would have to pay more for the first weeks of hospital care, with the Government providing greater protection against the costs of long illnesses, Administration officials said today.

title: Crocker Calls Loan
description: The American Resources Management Corporation said that Crocker National Bank had declared it in default on a $34 million loan and had called for immediate repayment of all amounts due. A company spokesman said directors would meet soon to consider alternatives, including a petition for reorganization. The company, which is involved in oil and natural gas exploration and production, said it earned $5.9 million from continuing operations in 1982 on revenues of $24.4 million.

title: Magic Is Back
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson, playing his first game in

title: COALITIONS OF BLACK AND HISPANIC VOTERS STILL RARE
description: Despite highly visible advances in Chicago, Boston and a few other cities, coalitions between blacks and emergent Hispanic voting blocs appear to be both rare and fragile, with competition for the same economic and political base breeding hostility more often than cooperation.

title: HART GOES STUMPING, ONE ON ONE
description: Standing in front of the deli counter and leaning against a rack of potato chips, Senator Gary Hart answered questions today about arms control, nuclear plants, equal rights for women, Pershing missiles and acid rain.

title: NEWSWEEK'S EDITOR IN CHIEF RESIGNS
description: William D. Broyles Jr. resigned yesterday after only 16 months as editor in chief of Newsweek magazine. He was replaced by Richard M. Smith, the executive editor, who has supervised the magazine's international coverage for the last six years.

title: MEETING IN CAIRO A 'SURPRISE' TO ARAFAT'S FATAH ASSOCIATES
description: The Central Committee of Al Fatah, Yasir Arafat's faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said here today that it had been ''surprised'' by Mr. Arafat's recent trip to Cairo, but it refrained from criticizing him.

title: PAKISTAN'S RULER LOOKS UNBEATABLE
description: Quietly, the main opponents of Pakistan's martial-law Government have called off their often-violent uprising in the province of Sind after 19 weeks and at least 60 deaths. They appeared to be conceding a defeat that politicians and diplomats believe has buttressed the position of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.

title: Woman Killed at Disneyland
description: A woman visiting Disneyland was killed Tuesday when she fell off a car on the Matterhorn Bobsleds ride and was struck by another sled, officials at the amusement park said.

title: HERS
description: The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For the next several weeks it will be written by Joyce Maynard, whose most recent book is the novel ''Baby Love.''

title: The Difficulty of Not Being Watt
description: William Clark, the new Secretary of the Interior, has a duty that seems at first not to be enormously taxing: the duty not to be James Watt. If he can hold that posture through Election Day, the voters may even forget that President Reagan's Interior Department was for three years run by a man who wanted to lay open every national park, wilderness and wildlife refuge for exploitation.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: AMINIATURE system designed to provide a concentrated light source for professionals operating a sound system or a turntable or reading at a lectern is now available for home use.

title: GAS ARRIVING IN FRANCE
description: The Soviet Union has begun exporting some additional Siberian gas to Western Europe, saying that the shipments are flowing through a showcase pipeline project that has been vigorously opposed by the Reagan Administration.

title: A PORTRAIT OF A LADY RETURNS
description: Among the four-letter words to be found in Shakespeare's plays I have a longtime favorite. ''Gage'' has echoes of that most delicious of English fruits, the greengage. It has echoes of chivalry, honor and trust. Coincidentally it is the name of an ancient land-owning family in Sussex. Many in fact are the American visitors to Glyndebourne Opera who have passed in wonderment before the gates of Firle Place, the family seat of the Gages, which lies a mile or two from the opera house.

title: Daily Fighting Reported In an Afghan City
description: Moslem insurgents are battling the Soviet- backed regime daily in Afghanistan's second largest city, where a Dec. 22 assault on an army headquarters left 31 Government soldiers dead, Western diplomats said today.

title: No Headline
description: Accounts

title: DCNY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: China to Purchase Deere Equipment Deere & Company said it had received contracts to supply China with about $25 million of agricultural equipment. The equipment purchase, to be financed by the World Bank, includes 400 large tractors, 500 grain drills, 60 planters, 200 cultivators, rippers and spare parts, and 100 combine harvesters. Most of the equipment is due for delivery this year.
description: The company also said it had signed a separate agreement to sell China technology for the manufacture of several models of farm tractors. A spokesman for Deere, which is based in Moline, Ill., would not disclose financial terms of the deal.

title: CUOMO MESSAGE A RESPONSE TO CRITICS
description: News Analysis

title: BRIEFING
description: Shultz and Dobrynin Meet

title: SOVIET REVAMPING SCHOOL SYSTEM
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it would overhaul the nation's school system to improve the quality of education in the 142,000 primary and high schools.

title: AMERICAN IN BONN FINDS CLOUD IN NATO'S FUTURE
description: Ambassador Arthur F. Burns conceded to an audience in Hamburg last year that he found diplomacy ''a universe inordinately filled with gossip, emotion and even suspicion - a world in which perception of facts often obscure facts themselves.''

title: OF BEN-GURION, BEGIN AND AN IMPROPER DIFFERENTIATION
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE COLLECTED PROSE. By Elizabeth Bishop. Edited, with an introduction, by Robert Giroux. 278 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.50. ''RUNNING along the edges of different countries, looking for something'': This is how Elizabeth Bishop described her life in 1976, three years before she died. She lived, as Robert Giroux says in his introduction to ''The Collected Prose,'' in such dissimilar places as ''Nova Scotia and Paris, Ouro Preto and Worcester, London and Key West, Poughkeepsie and Cape Cod, Petropolis and San Francisco, Mexico and Boston, North Haven and Greenwich Village, Seattle and Rio de Janeiro.'' Her books of poems bear geographical titles: ''North & South,'' ''Questions of Travel'' and ''Geography III.''

title: BARNARD COLLEGE DISMISSES BURSAR AND REPORTS 'SOME IRREGULARITIES'
description: Barnard College has ''uncovered some irregularities'' in its bursar's office and has dismissed the bursar, an official of the college said yesterday.

title: COURTS STUDY LINK BETWEEN VICTIM'S RACE AND IMPOSITION OF DEATH PENALTY
description: With more executions likely to take place as death row inmates exhaust their appeals, opponents of the death penalty are increasingly focusing on the argument that imposing the death sentence tends to be related to the race of the victim.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
FRANKLIN AND APPLE SETTLE SUIT
description: The Franklin Computer Corporation agreed yesterday to pay Apple Computer $2.5 million in damages for copying crucial elements of Apple's most popular personal computer. The settlement marks a victory for computer manufacturers battling inexpensive copies of their own designs.

title: DOUBTS ON THE SOVIET PIPELINE
description: After one of the most highly publicized crash projects since the days of Stalin, the Soviet Union has announced that the first quantities of natural gas have begun moving down the 2,800-mile pipeline connecting the Urengoi field in Siberia to Western Europe.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE TO ENTER C.I.A. DEATH CASE
description: A Federal appeals court on Tuesday reluctantly permitted a Senate committee to intervene in the case of a widow of a former official of the Central Intelligence Agency who was trying to find out how he died.

title: 2 INQUIRIES BEGUN INTO LEGALITY OF WICK'S TELEPHONE TAPING
description: The General Services Administration here and the State Attorney in Palm Beach County, Fla., have begun separate inquiries into whether the director of the United States Information Agency, Charles Z. Wick, broke a Federal regulation and Florida law by secretly tape- recording his telephone conversations, officials said today.

title: NO PHONES OR UTILITIES, JUST PLENTY OF SOLITUDE SINKS OF GANDY, W. Va., Jan. 4 (AP) - Electricity comes from a gasoline-fueled generator instead of a power line, and communication with civilization is by Citizens Band radio instead of by telephone.
description: For utility companies, Sinks of Gandy simply is not on the map.

title: Donald Glenne Currie Dead; U.P.I. Arts Editor Since '75
description: Donald Glenne Currie, an arts critic for United Press International, died of a heart attack Tuesday. He was 57 years old.

title: Financial Problems
description: The Willie Stargell Foundation, an organization founded by the former Pittsburgh Pirate star to aid in the research of sickle cell anemia, has been scaled down drastically after 20 years because of financial problems.

title: JAZZ-ROCK: LEROY JENKINS
description: Leroy Jenkins's Sting, the violinist's jazz-rock fusion band, performed Monday to open Sweet Basil's series, ''Music Is an Open Sky.'' Every Sunday and Monday through March, the series will feature groups that are infrequently heard in clubs.

title: BOY SCOUTS MUST LET WOMAN BE SCOUTMASTER, PANEL RULES
description: A Connecticut human-rights panel ruled yesterday that the Boy Scouts must allow a Milford woman to become a scoutmaster.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Allen I. Questrom, chairman and chief executive of the Rich's department store chain, has taken a leave. The parent company of Rich's, Federated Department Stores Inc., said he had been granted ''a sabbatical to pursue personal interests.''

title: ALGAE GIVING CITY WATER FISHY TASTE
description: Hundreds of thousands of New York City residents are getting tap water with a fishy or metallic taste because of algae in some upstate reservoirs, city officials said yesterday.

title: Strike Ends At Roosevelt
description: Officials at Roosevelt Raceway reached an agreement on

title:
GARDENING;
FLOWERING PLANTS: BEAUTY THAT LASTS
description: DURING the dead of winter, blooming indoor plants are worthy substitutes for flower-filled vases. Unlike cut flowers, which have no root systems to absorb moisture, potted blossoms tend to stay fresh for weeks.

title: Prices Steady For Eurobonds LONDON, Jan. 4 (Reuters) - The Eurobond market was steady today in lackluster trading, dealers said.
description: Fixed-interest dollar bonds were little changed and trading was very quiet, although some Swiss retail buying interest was seen in short- term maturities.

title: MUSIC: DEBUT BY VIOLINIST
description: Sharon Smith Polifrone, a member of the Audubon Quartet, made her New York debut as a solo violinist at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night. David Oei was at the piano, and the program included Schubert's Sonatina in D (Op. 137, No. 1), Schumann's Sonata in A minor, and the first New York performance of Jon Polifrone's Sonata (1982), along with the Paganini-Kreisler Caprice No. 13 and works by Brahms and Ysa"ye.

title: BRIEFS
description: Allis-Chalmers Corp. said it had received a $30 million order from Elkem A/S of Norway for an ore-processing system.

title: ADVERTISING ; United Jersey Banks Takes to the Airwaves
description: In order to set itself apart from other banks in a highly competitive environment, United Jersey Banks of Princeton, N.J., has taken to the airwaves with an advertising effort by its new agency, Trout & Ries of New York, the ''positioning'' agency.

title: Summit Talks June 7-9
description: This year's seven-nation economic summit meeting will take place in London June 7-9, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's office announced today. The meeting is part of a series of annual conferences involving the leaders of the world's top industrialized nations - the United States, Britain, France, Canada, West Germany, Italy and Japan. The 1983 meeting took place in Williamsburg, Va., last May.

title: 46 FROM MINORITIES ORDERED REINSTATED IN NEWARK FIRE JOBS
description: A Federal judge today ordered city officials to reinstate immediately the 46 black and Hispanic firefighters who were among 76 in the Fire Department laid off last month.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Norfolk Hospital Bonds Are Priced by Kidder

title: Indonesia Gas Earnings
description: Indonesia's earnings from export of liquefied natural gas will slip to $2.55 billion this year, the state-owned oil corporation, Pertamina, said today. That compares with sales of $2.64 billion in 1983. Pertamina predicted, however, that such earnings will increase to $3.55 billion next year and $3.8 billion in 1986 because of recently signed long-term sales contracts with Japan and South Korea.

title: DOW UP BY 16.31, TO 1,269.05
description: Stock prices surged yesterday in a dramatic turnabout fueled by heavy buying from pension funds and other large institutions. All three major market indicators posted impressive gains.

title: Murdoch Opposes Move by Warner WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UPI) - Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher, said his holding company, News International Ltd., has filed a petition with the Federal Communications Commission challenging a deal between Warner Communications Inc. and Chris-Craft Industries.
description: The petition charges that the proposed transaction, under which Chris- Craft would get control of 19 percent of Warner's stock in return for 42.5 percent of Chris-Craft's broadcasting subsidiary, would violate F.C.C. regulations.

title: THE DEMOCRATS' PATH TO A MAJORITY FORCE
description: To the Editor:

title: AS FOR EL SALVADOR, IT'S THAT TIME OF YEAR AGAIN
description: The political process in Washington often moves according to seasonal rituals, especially when the Reagan Administration must seek more funds or more patience from Congress for its programs or policies.

title: MACHINE TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss The revenue figures are corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Cards Dropping Hart
description: He has thrown and completed more passes for more yards than all but two other quarterbacks in the history of the National Football League, and now, after 18 years with the St. Louis Cardinals, Jim Hart may have reached the end of his career. Hart, who appeared in only four games last season, was told yesterday that the Cardinals would not exercise their option of first refusal when his one-year contract expires next month.

title: Diagram Bridge: Directors of the Cavendish Are Seeking a New Home
description: The world's most celebrated bridge club - the Cavendish in New York - made a decision a decade ago that in hindsight seems to have been an error.

title: FOR TINY LAND'S RULER, HOME IS 1,788 ROOMS
description: Sultan Muda Hassanal Bolkiah of Brunei rules one of the smallest independent countries, but his new 1,788-room palace on a partly manmade 100-foot hill overlooking this capital is believed to be the largest royal residence in the world.

title: O'CALLAHAN'S SUSPENSION SET FOR 8 GAMES
description: The National Hockey League yesterday gave Jack O'Callahan of the Chicago Black Hawks an eight-game suspension for deliberately using his stick to attack Dave Maloney, the Ranger defenseman, in a game last Wednesday night at Chicago Stadium.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: MUSIC: PEKING OPERA
description: Alice Tully Hall was jammed Monday for a free performance of a Peking opera. While people sat on steps and stood in the aisles, the Ya-yin (''melodic'') Ensemble from Taiwan performed ''The White Snake and Hs"u Hsien,'' featuring Kuo Hsiao- chuang as the White Snake.

title: THE SCRAMBLE TO PREPARE THE SPEECH
description: Governor Cuomo delivered his State of the State address today - despite a stolen briefcase, a broken Teleprompter and a sudden case of hoarseness.

title: DIXON-TICONDEROGA CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest year include operations of Joseph Dixon Crucible which was acquired on Sept. 21, 1983.

title: Italian Police Arrest 5 In Bulgari Kidnapping
description: The police arrested four Sardinian shepherds and a man from the southern region of Puglia today and charged them with the kidnapping of two recently freed members of the Bulgari jewelry family, the authorities said.

title: 8 U.S. Legislators Leave On Trip to Study Heroin
description: Eight members of Congress began an 18-day fact-finding mission today into heroin smuggling in Europe, Asia and the Middle East and drug abuse among American servicemen in the Pacific.

title: THE RULE OF LAW (I)
description: An odd thing happened here shortly before Christmas. The trade union movement decided to obey the law.

title: Fannie Mae Offer
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association said its offering of $1 billion in four-year notes would carry an interest rate of 11.55 percent. The notes, to be offered Friday, are priced at par and will mature Jan. 11, 1988. Fannie Mae said proceeds from the sale would be used to redeem $500 million of 14.05 percent debentures maturing Jan. 10, 1984, and to finance operations.

title: Tanzania Says 20,000 Fled Homes in Uganda
description: The Tanzanian radio said today that 20,000 ethnic Rwandans had fled into western Tanzania from their homes in Uganda.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ON Thanksgiving weekend in New York, the Exterminator married Private Benjamin. Then Robert Ginty (who had been in the city shooting ''Exterminator II'') and Lorna Patterson (hapless G.I. of the now defunct television series) went home to Los Angeles. Where they didn't stay long.

title: CUOMO RIGHTS PLAN AT ODDS WITH TACTIC OF WOMEN'S GROUPS
description: Governor Cuomo, who called this week for a state constitutional amendment on equal rights for women, did so even though leaders of the women's movement had urged him not to.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Includes a loss on sale of an asset of $400,000. c-Includes a gain of $3,500,000, or 41 cents a share, from the sale of Tyco's interest in the Mobil Tyco Solar Energy Corporation. The year-earlier periods include foreign exchange gains, after taxes, of $400,000 for the quarter and $800,000 for the 6 months.

title: RADIATION RISKS AT 3 MILE ISLAND ARE FOUND HIGHER THAN EXPECTED
description: Workers cleaning up the damaged nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island could be exposed to six times more radiation than previously thought, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

title: MINNEAPOLIS MAYOR VETOES PLAN DEFINING PORNOGRAPHY AS SEX BIAS
description: Mayor Donald Fraser today vetoed an amendment to the city's Civil Rights Ordinance that would have defined pornography as a form of sexual discrimination against women.

title: TEXAS SWIM MEET TO TEST AMERICANS
description: For much of the last 20 years, swimmers from the United States have been the best in the world. In the last few years, the rest of the world seems to have caught up. Just how much it has caught up may be determined today through Sunday in the third annual United States Swimming International.

title: DETROIT CLOSES OUT A BANNER YEAR
description: For United States auto makers, 1983 was a year when rebates ended and sharp cost cutting combined with solid sales to produce a financial turnaround that analysts said was little short of spectacular.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: The share earnings for the year-ago periods were restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effected in April 1983.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Sorrow After Joy
description: Two sophomore stars who helped Georgia defeat Texas in the Cotton Bowl have flunked out of school and will not be eligible to play next fall.

title: Honor for Jerry Lewis
description: Jerry Lewis will be made a commander in France's Order of Arts and Literature, a Culture Ministry official said today. The American comedian will be presented with a medal and a ribbon by Minister Jack Lang on Jan. 13 as a tribute to Mr. Lewis's achievements as a director and actor, Mr. Lang added.

title: Beethoven by Guarneri
description: The Guarneri String Quartet will perform three Beethoven quartets tonight at 8 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (570-3949), Fifth Avenue at 82d Street. On the program are the quartets in C minor (Op. 18, No. 4), in F Major (Op. 18, No.1) and C-sharp minor (Op. 131). Stage seats are $14.

title: Grenadian Disavows Bishop Death Certificate
description: A Grenadian doctor said today that under pressure from the army he made up a cause-of-death certificate for Prime Minister Maurice Bishop without seeing the body.

title: Basketball Player Arrested in Theft
description: Greg Mack, a standout forward for the College of Charleston basketball team, defending champion of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics, was arrested today on charges of burglary and grand larceny.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Comings and Goings
description: Fran Healy , the former major league catcher and a member of the Yankees' broadcasting crew since 1978, will join Tim McCarver and Ralph Kiner on the Mets' SportsChannel, which will do 60 pay-TV cablecasts in 1984. . . . Nate (Tiny) Archibald , the Milwaukee Bucks' guard, will miss at least five games after aggravating a pulled hamstring in a game against the Cleveland Cavaliers Tuesday. . . . Charles (Stump) Merrill , the manager of the Yankees' Class A farm club in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for the last two years, was named manager of the Columbus Clippers, the club's AAA farm team in the International League. . . . Dan Marino , the Miami Dolphin quarterback, will undergo minor knee surgery today, but he said he expected to recover in time for the Pro Bowl Jan. 29. . . . The Cosmos have signed the Italian striker Ferdinando DeMatthaeis to a contract for the remainder of the North American Soccer League's indoor season. He played for the Cosmos during their 1981-82 indoor season.

title: A VIDEO ARCADE THE CITY FOUGHT SUDDENLY CLOSED
description: City officials said yesterday that they had been trying for more than two years to shut an unlicensed East Side video arcade where a high school senior was beaten to death Sunday night.

title: TRACK STARS ARE BOBSLED NATURALS
description: Strands of gray were sprinkled throughout Lee Evans's beard, and the news that his younger brother had just died in a boating accident weighed more heavily on his mind than trying to qualify for a spot on the United States Olympic bobsled team.

title: AIR FLORIDA GETS NOTICE OF DEFAULT
description: Air Florida Inc. announced yesterday that one of its major creditors had placed the company in default, but that it would be able to continue normal operations.

title: Egyptian Official in France
description: Egypt's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Boutros Ghali, arrived here today for talks on the Middle East situation with President Francois Mitterrand and other officials.

title: THE CITY
description: The Police Blotter

title: ISRAELIS CALL AIR RAID ON LEBANESE CITY 'SURGICAL'
description: An Israeli Army spokesman said today that Wednesday's air strike in eastern Lebanon was a ''surgical'' operation against terrorist bases and that any civilian victims were in the target areas at their own risk.

title: COST RISE AND CORRUPTION CHARGES SNAG MODEL HEALTH CARE PROGRAM
description: An innovative program of medical care for the poor that the Reagan Administration hoped would serve as a model for the nation has been dogged by large excess costs and charges of corruption and mismanagement.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. 76ers, at Philadelphia. The Nets, fresh off a close, badly needed victory in Atlanta, pay a visit to Moses Malone and Company.

title: DEVELOPMENT ON NANTUCKET SPURS ACTION
description: In the evolution of one family is the story of Nantucket, an island in a quandary, engulfed, like Cape Cod, Martha's Vineyard and Block Island, by the popularity of its isolated charm.

title: Miss Jaeger Bows
description: Lisa Bonder needed only 33 minutes to upset the top-seeded Andrea Jaeger, the world's No. 3 player, 6-0, 6-1, in a second-round match today in the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Washington women's tennis tournament.

title: Court Blocks Getty Deal
description: A granddaughter of

title: MUTUAL FUNDS: PITFALLS IN 1983
description: Investors who loaded up on high- technology mutual funds when the market boom started 18 months ago made a killing in the first half of 1983. But those who failed to bail out by summer very likely suffered heavy losses that often wiped out their earlier gains.

title: Kennedy Leaves Hospital
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, was released from George Washington University Hospital today and is resting at home in Virginia, his aides said. Robert Shrum, Senator Kennedy's press secretary, said the doctors had confirmed that the Senator was suffering from hepatitis- A, which he described as a mild liver inflammation.

title: TUNISIA REPORTS MANY ARRESTS IN WAKE OF RIOTING
description: The Tunisian Government said today that it had arrested ''a great number of criminals and professional agitators'' in the wake of the rioting that led to the declaration of a state of national emergency on Tuesday. It said that they would be tried but gave no details of the arrests.

title: PROBLEMS ARE PILING UP FOR HUDSON OIL'S CHIEF
description: Three years ago, she won the Horatio Alger Award in recognition of her entrepreneurial feats. In 1982, Forbes magazine listed her as one of the 400 wealthiest Americans.

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
JULIE WILSON'S RETURN: HOW IT HAPPENED
description: JULIE WILSON'S return to show business and New York after eight years of what she has called ''semiretirement'' in Omaha has the kind of plot twist - a casual encounter on a bus - that might have come out of a musical by Cole Porter, whose songs she is now singing at Michael's Pub.

title: SCOUTING
description: Talent Scout

title: ART: 35 STONE WONDERS OF INDIA, SOUTHEAST ASIA
description: THE Metropolitan Museum of Art has just rolled out a few more stones of silence from the vast and seemingly inexhaustible quarry of its permanent collection. The 35 stone Buddhas, lingams and fertility goddess that will occupy the Sackler Exhibition Hall through May are from India and Southeast Asia. Two-thirds were acquired by the museum in the last 10 years; many have never been shown. ''Selection From the Permanent Collection of India and Southeast Asian Art'' is, therefore, the first public opportunity to see the results of a decade-long effort to develop a part of the collection in which there had been litte interest.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 6, 1984

title: HOUSTON DEFEATS S.M.U., 60-59
description: DALLAS, Jan. 5 (AP) Michael Young scored 24 points, including the game-winning basket with 57 seconds left, tonight to give Houston a 60-59 Southwest Conference victory over Southern Methodist.

title: Dancers in Benefit
description: More than 30 dancers, musicians and dance companies will participate in a benefit performance for Carey Erickson, a dancer-choreographer, who was paralyzed in a recent accident.

title: JERSEY LEGISLATURE APPROVES NEW CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICTS
description: The New Jersey Assembly gave final passage today to a bill drawing new boundaries for the state's 14 Congressional districts.

title: FESTIVAL TO CELEBRATE NEW ROCKLAND ARTS CENTER
description: The new Cultural Arts Center at Rockland Community College in Suffern, N.Y., leaps into its Inaugural Festival tomorrow with Edward Villella in ''A Day of Dance.''

title: SOME SHOPS AT SEAPORT SAY IT'S A STRUGGLE TO SURVIVE
description: Several South Street Seaport fast- food merchants said yesterday that business was so bad they were unable to pay their rent and feared they might have to close.

title: D.& H. Line Sold
description: The sale of the nation's oldest transportation company, the Delaware & Hudson Railway Company, to Guilford Transportation Industries has been completed. Guilford Transportation, based in Guilford, Conn., acquired the D.& H. following an agreement on a series of Federal and state subsidies. The purchase of the D.& H., formed in 1823 as a canal company, will make Guilford the biggest competitor to the federally subsidized Conrail system in the Northeast.

title: RARE GULL FROM SOVIET PACIFIC IS SIGHTED NEAR ST. LOUIS
description: A bird from the Soviet Union's northern Pacific coast has taken up residence on ice floes near the Chain of Rocks Bridge on the Mississippi River north of here.

title: NEW CITY JAIL AIDE LEFT EARLIER POST UNDER FIRE
description: A prison administrator who resigned as the head of a county jail in Maryland last March after complaints of lax management has been appointed a deputy warden in New York City's Correction Department, a department spokesman said yesterday.

title: FINNISH PRESIDENT FEUDS WITH PRESS
description: A public feud has erupted in Finland between President Mauno Koivisto and the Finnish press.

title: Polls Find Most in U.S. Want the Marines Out
description: A majority of the American public wants the United States Marines pulled out of Lebanon, according to two national polls conducted by ABC News and issued last night. Those results were the first in any major national public opinion surveys to record a clear public desire for withdrawal.

title: Books: In the New Land
description: THE AMERICAN JEWISH ALBUM: From 1654 to the Present. By Allon Schoener, 352 pages. Rizzoli. $45.

title: WALGREEN COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
CSX Profit Down 42.3%
description: The CSX Corporation, noting the absence of extraordinary gains, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 42.3 percent, to $104 million, or 76 cents a share, from $180.3 million, or $1.43 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 72.7 percent, to $1.9 billion, from $1.1 billion.

title: ELECTRONIC SYSTEM TO GUIDE THE BLIND MEETS SOME OPPOSITION
description: Blind students at the University of New Mexico have started testing a new electronic travel system that its inventors say could significantly improve the mobility of people with little or no eyesight.

title: EXPLORING ALBANY WHEN LEGISLATURE IS IN SESSION
description: AS a new session of the Legislature opens, Albany again takes center stage, the focus of attention for returning lawmakers and people intent on doing business with New York State. But there is more than state business in the capital, as visitors willing to explore just a few steps beyond the legislative halls can discover this weekend.

title: A Lotto Winner Promptly Retires
description: A self-employed Queens bachelor and a Staten Island doctor appeared yesterday to collect $3.35 million each from the largest Lotto jackpot in New York history.

title: THEATER: TOM STOPPARD'S ''REAL THING''
description: HENRY, the hero of Tom Stoppard's ''Real Thing,'' is an English playwright of unbeatable intellectual prowess. He knows how to make words ''go on replicating themselves like a spiral of DNA'' and how to ad lib a brilliant rejoinder to any question. Both in life and in the theater, he can always get the last word and the smartest laugh. But there's one question Henry can't so easily answer or write about or joke away: What is this thing called love?

title: SCREEN: YACHTSMEN VS. KAISER IN 'RIDDLE'
