description: ''THE RIDDLE OF THE SANDS'' is not a camel movie, in spite of its title. In fact, much of it takes place on water. This is a film version of Erskine Childers' popular and prophetic 1903 novel, which told the fanciful story of how a couple of adventurous English yachtsmen stumbled upon a German fleet off the northwest coast of Germany, and thereby thwarted a German invasion of England. When, on the eve of the first World War, Lord Brassey strayed on his yacht Sunbeam into a restricted German harbor filled with U-boats, the novel took on an additional prescience.

title: STOCK TRADING PATTERN IS OUTLINED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission complaint against Paul Thayer and eight other defendants charges a pattern of illegal stock trading among a group of people who knew each other socially and professionally and who parlayed information about mergers and other secret corporate data into profits of $1.9 million.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A NEW SUCCESSION AT GREAT NORTHERN
description: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, a paper company, has switched signals on which executive will head the company later this year.

title: FROM KAROLE ARMITAGE, A MODERN-CLASSIC BALLET
description: For some choreographers, classical ballet has been a restricting tradition to break away from. It has offered others a discipline to experiment with. For Karole Armitage, the very promising young choreographer, whose new ''Paradise'' will be performed tonight through Monday at the La Mama E.T.C. Annex, the technique and discipline of classical ballet have provided both a departure point and an ordering frame of reference.

title: ECLIPSE AWARDS TO 10 HORSES
description: Devil's Bag, Slew o' Gold and All Along, the leading candidates for the 1983 horse-of-the-year title, were among 10 thoroughbreds, four people and a farm who were certified as champions yesterday by winning Eclipse Awards.

title: Drummer for the Beach Boys Given Sea Burial He Wanted
description: Dennis Wilson, the drummer for the Beach Boys, has been buried at sea by the Coast Guard as his widow and other relatives looked on.

title: 5 RESEARCH TEAMS RECORD POSSIBLE EVIDENCE OF PROTON DECAY
description: Five experimental groups, with detectors in India, Ohio, Japan, Switzerland and Utah, say they have recorded phenomena that could possibly be interpreted as occasional decaying of protons, the building blocks of all matter.

title: MUSIC: JUDY KAYE AT FREDDY'S
description: JUDY KAYE has indicated her range as a singing actress by playing the blond and flamboyant Lily Garland in ''On the 20th Century'' on Broadway a few years back and, four weeks ago, going to an opposite extreme as the demure, dark-haired heroine of Victor Herbert's ''Sweethearts'' at Town Hall.

title: 4 'Test Tube' Babies Born to Australian
description: A 31-year-old Melbourne woman gave birth today to the world's first quadruplets to be conceived in a laboratory, doctors here said. The mother and the four ''test tube'' babies, all boys, were reported healthy and in good condition.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Costly Admission
description: Acknowledging a lesbian relationship with her former secretary has cost Billie Jean King more than $2 million in commercial endorsements, according to the tennis star. Mrs. King, who acknowledged the relationship in 1981, told Parade magazine that as a result of the disclosure she had lost endorsement contracts for tennis clothes, jeans and hosiery and expected to lose her tennis racquet endorsement contract when it expires.

title: German Steel Output
description: West German raw steel production fell to 39.3 million tons in 1983, down four-tenths of 1 percent from 1982, the Statistics Office said today.

title: PHILHARMONIC: MAHLER AND SANDERLING
description: IF ever a composer felt a cold

title: REDIDENTIAL RESTORATION FOR SOUTH STREET SEAPORT
description: For some people, the restored South Street Seaport Historic District is more than a vacation stopover or a lunch time diversion. It is home.

title: PROPERLY BLINDSIDED
description: In football terms, President Reagan has been twice ''blindsided'' in the rising controversy over his adamant insistence on keeping the Marines in Lebanon. First, a Pentagon commission bluntly urged a ''reassessment'' of this position; then, the Rev. Jesse Jackson's ''moral appeal'' rather than military power secured Syria's release of Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr.

title: MIXED-UP PRIORITIES IN A WAR ON DRUGS
description: To the Editor:

title: S.&P. Rating Cut By Reuters
description: Standard and Poor's said yesterday that it had lowered its rating of the senior debt of the Commercial Credit Company, a unit of the Control Data Corporation, to BBB from A. It also reduced Commercial Credit's subordinated debt rating to BBB- from A- and its commercial paper to A-2 from A-1. S. & P. said the downgrading reflects concern over the company's continuing decline in earnings, increasing losses in its small businees services segment and rising debt leverage. Loan portfolio quality has also deteriorated, particularly in the energy-related loan sector, the rating agency added.

title: A DISASTER AGENCY'S IMAGE DISASTER
description: When ABC television aired the movie ''The Day After'' in November, about how a Kansas community would fare under a nuclear attack, officials of the Federal Emergency Management Agency had extra workers on duty to handle the anticipated barrage of requests from people suddenly concerned about surviving a nuclear assault.

title: Jaruzelski and Glemp Hold Warsaw Meeting
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, and Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate, agreed today in a meeting to condemn the arms race and to strengthen church-state relations.

title: Ex-Counsel Heads Hospitals Corp.
description: The board of directors of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday named John L. McLaughlin acting president. He replaces Stanley Brezenoff, who was appointed Deputy Mayor for Human Services.

title: Harriet Fitts-Ryan, Mother Of the Former Congressman
description: Harriet Fitts-Ryan, mother of the late William Fitts Ryan, who represented Manhattan's West Side in Congress from 1961 until his death in 1972, died Wednesday in the Lutheran Medical Center, Brooklyn. She was 92 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: WARD SWORN IN, AND TOP POLICE CRITIC IS GUEST
description: Benjamin Ward was sworn in yesterday as New York's 34th Police Commissioner at a City Hall ceremony attended by 350 well-wishers, including Representative John Conyers Jr., one of the department's severest critics.

title: Argentine Ex-Sailor Quoted on Role in Terror
description: A former Argentine Navy petty officer was quoted in an interview published today as saying that he had taken part in the kidnapping of 200 political detainees and witnessed their torture in the late 1970's.

title: CONDUCTRON CORP reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $605,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $746,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the discontinued operations of Jamestown Metal Manufacturing Co. and Middco Connectors, which were sold during 1983.

title: DOWNED AIR FORCE PLANE FOUND
description: A searcher found the wreckage of a camouflaged Air Force jet today when he said he ''slipped on a piece of the metal'' in snow-capped mountains. Searchers also found the remains of at least one of the two crewmen.

title: PAINTING A 320-FOOT WALL IN MIAMI
description: In mid-March, near the Florida site of Christo's ''Surrounded Islands'' extravaganza of last May, the Israeli artist Yaacov Agam will begin supervising the painting of a wall 320 feet tall and 310 feet wide at the Villa Regina, a 205-unit condominium complex overlooking Biscayne Bay in Miami. The painting will be done by teams of painters working from the artist's model, each assigned a specific area of the wall. The event is scheduled to take 13 days.

title: PUBLISHING: CHANGES FOR VIKING PENGUIN
description: IN a major reorganization, Alan

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Foreign Visitors
description: Jarmila Kratochvilova , the Czechoslovak runner who won both the 400 and the 800 meters at the World Track and Field Championships last year, is one of more than a dozen top foreign athletes who plan to compete on the?North American track and field circuit this year. Miss Kratochvilova's schedule includes the Millrose Games

title: Potters and Sculptors
description: Wall pieces, earthenware, and other ceramics by Raul Acero will be featured through Jan. 20 at the Greenwich House Potters and Sculptors' Invitational Exhibition, 16 Jones Street.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 6, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: '82 INQUIRIES ON AIDE SAID TO RAISE NO QUESTIONS
description: Top Administration officials were unaware until two weeks ago of the questions about Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Thayer's personal and business conduct that led to today's complaint by the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to a White House official.

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $2,718,000. c-After a tax credit of $237,000. There were no common share earnings for the year-ago quarter because the net did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SUCCESS IN ANGOLA LIMITED
description: By its own account, South Africa's newest drive into Angola, now in its fourth week, has not had the dramatic success South Africa has claimed for earlier forays.

title: Socal Proposes Change in Name SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 (AP) - The Standard Oil Company of California, the nation's fourth-largest oil company, said it would ask shareholders to approve changing its name to the Chevron Corporation. Company officials said the name change would be voted on at the annual stockholders meeting May 1. The change, to take effect July 1, would cost about $100,000, the company estimated.
description: Socal already sells its products under the Chevron brand name. Its main domestic operating subsidiary was renamed Chevron U.S.A. Inc. in 1977. ''The confusion over the years in the mind of the public over the relationship between Socal and Chevron has been tremendous,'' a company spokesman, David Young, said.

title: 76ers Triumph On Malone Shot
description: Moses Malone made a 3-point play with seven seconds left in overtime to give the Philadelphia 76ers a 103-102 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight. With the 76ers trailing, 102-100, Malone slipped under the basket, made a scoop shot and was fouled by Sidney Moncrief. Malone hit the free throw for his 28th point.

title: CORPORATE BOND PRICES FIRM
description: Flush with funds, the insurance industry yesterday gobbled up $425 million of 10-year bonds that were offered by three major financially oriented companies.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: -distance care of elderly relatives incorrectly quoted Dr. Robert N. Butler, Brookdale Professor of Geriatrics and Adult Development at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York, on the increase in life expectancy since the turn of the century. It is 26 years.

title: Clark Gets Euclid From Daimler STUTTGART, West Germany, Jan. 5 (Reuters) - Daimler-Benz A.G. said it had reached agreement with the Clark Equipment Company of Buchanan, Mich., under which Clark will acquire Daimler's wholly owned Euclid Inc. unit. Daimler will receive about a 5 percent stake in Clark as part payment.
description: According to a Daimler statement, Clark will transfer its construction machinery activities into a new wholly owned company.

title: Fishy Water Odor Is Gone, Not Taste
description: The fishy odor of tap water being piped to hundreds of thousands of people living in Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island has been removed, but the disagreeable taste remains, city officials said yesterday.

title: 15 ACTRESSES TO CATCH ON STAGE NOW
description: ON stages all over town actresses are sharing the taste of success. More than a dozen of them are currently making a vivid impression on New York audiences. Of these women, who can all be seen in performances this weekend, some are new to New York; others are new to the theater. A few are familiar faces trying to make a dracommon, these actresses are appearing in starring or featured roles in musicals and comedies, and on stage a number of them, at least covertly, are making statements about the pressures and possibilities of women today.

title: Taxes: Change 'Em or Lose 'Em
description: Cattle Feeding for Profit and Tax Shelter - 8-to-1 Potential . . . Medical Equipment Leasing Opportunity - 275% Write-Off in '83 . . . Entrepreneur's Tax Shelter - 95% Leverage . . .

title: JACKSON URGES U.S. NOT TO 'SHUN' DIRECT TALKS WITH SYRIANS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, continuing to press his views of United States policy in the Middle East, said today that he had told Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that the Administration should not ''shun'' direct talks with Syria on easing tensions in the region.

title: PARIS PLANS TO REDUCE HUGE DEBT
description: France, one of the most heavily indebted nations in the world, will begin reducing its huge foreign debt by the end of 1985 or in 1986, Finance Minister Jacques Delors said today.

title: LEMMINGS IN SPACE
description: A little-noticed bill before Congress holds the seeds of a military commitment that could be as momentous for the fate of the United States and the world as creation of the vast nuclear arsenals.

title: POLICY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in October 1983.

title: MANATT'S PROBLEM: NOT THE GAME, JUST THE RULES
description: When Charles T. Manatt became Democratic national chairman in early 1981, the party was operating out of rented quarters with a computer list of 50,000 contributors and 15 electric typewriters, 12 of which were not working. Republicans had routed the Democrats from the White House and won control of the Senate. Party morale was at a new low.

title: ART: A JOYOUS MEMORIAL TO RICHARD STANKIEWICZ
description: IT is always a shock to see a memorial show of an artist whose

title: F.C.C. APPROVES NEW PBS EDUCATIONAL NETWORK
description: The Federal Communications Commission cleared the way today for the Public Broadcasting Service to construct an educational television network using microwave transmitting stations.

title: S.E.C. SAYS THAYER GAVE STOCK DATA ON 'INSIDER' BASIS
description: William Howard Taft 4th, the Pentagon's counsel, was nominated to succeed Mr. Thayer. Page A13.

title: SCOUTING
description: All That Glitters

title: THE BOROUGHS GIVE CITY HALL THEIR PRIORITIES
description: Above all else, Brooklyn and Queens want more police. The Bronx would rather have the city take care of parks. Manhattan is most concerned about its old people. And Staten Island wants better sewers.

title: Shoemaker Guilty In Student's Death
description: A Superior Court jury today found a 34- year-old shoemaker guilty of torturing and murdering a Montclair State College student last February.

title: STOCKS SET A RECORD IN VOLUME
description: The stock market had one of its most spectacular days ever as record trading volume yesterday propelled the Dow Jones industrial average to within five points of its record close.

title: 12TH NIGHT: THEATRICS AND ROAST PIG
description: On the 12th day of Christmas, according to European tradition, the three Magi came, laden with gifts, to visit the Christ child. Early Christians memorialized Jan. 6 with the feast of the Epiphany. And in Latin countries today, as in the England of yesteryear, Twelfth Night, rather than Christmas day, is the time of feasting, gift giving, and celebration.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Drug Charges
description: Alexander Harthill , a veterinarian who is a consultant to the president of the Fair Grounds in New Orleans, was arrested at his apartment at the track and charged with possession of illicit drugs and ''drug horse paraphernalia.'' Only licensed veterinarians are allowed to possess such drugs and equipment at a race track, according to the police, who noted that although Dr. Harthill has attended several Kentucky Derby winners, he is not licensed to practice in Louisiana. Dr. Harthill had no immediate comment.

title: Insider Case Guilty Plea James V. Pondiccio Jr., former assistant head trader for Lazard Fr eres & Company, the investment banking firm, pleaded guilty yesterday in United States District Court in Manhattan to violating insider trading regulations.
description: Mr. Pondiccio, 37 years old, pleaded guilty to acting on insider information regarding a tender offer by Joseph E. Seagram & Sons for the St. Joe Minerals Corporation in March 1981.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Who would have believed there would be a Jewish Mayor who would replace two Irish commissioners with a black man?'' - Benjamin Ward, Police Commissioner and former Corrections Commissioner. (B4:3.)

title: MONDALE BACKED BY A BLACK MAYOR
description: The first black Mayor of Alabama's largest city today endorsed Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination. The move buoyed the Minnesotan, who faces a challenge from the Rev. Jesse Jackson in his quest for black votes.

title: Undone at the Pentagon
description: Whether Paul Thayer is guilty or not, his resignation as Deputy Secretary of Defense casts disgrace in several directions - and credit in one.

title: ART: MILTON AVERY, COLOR HARMONIST
description: AS everyone knows by now, Milton Avery was a resourceful and innovative colorist. But ''harmonist'' might be the better word for the ways in which he got colors to work together. His new show - ''Milton Avery: Major Paintings'' - opens tomorrow at the Grace Borgenicht Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, where it can be seen through Feb. 1. Anyone who looks at an Avery as if he had never seen one before may be struck, I think, by the fact that although Avery was not a great draftsman, he was a marvelous positioner.

title: 'THE DEAN' OF JAZZ RADIO
description: When he was 6 years old and a child of Queens, Phil Schaap made a deal with his babysitter. He would keep quiet if she would take him to ''the hip record store'' in Jamaica on his birthday.

title: BEHIND THE LAG IN PRODUCTIVITY
description: I S the long downtrend in the rate of productivity

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Money Award
description: The San Francisco Police Commission has voted to pay Lynn Swann , the former Pittsburgh Steeler wide receiver, and three of his relatives $220,000 in damages and interest stemming from a decade-old police- brutality suit. They brought the suit after they were stopped for driving through a red light in 1974.

title: REAGAN PICKS PENTAGON LAWYER TO REPLACE THAYER
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate William Howard Taft 4th, general counsel of the Defense Department, to succeed W. Paul Thayer as Deputy Secretary of Defense.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: DOZENS of restaurants in New York serve Peking duck, but few can match the one prepared at Beijing Pavilion, 220 East 46th Street, for sheer showmanship, as well as flavor. The performance is put on by one of 14 chefs from China who came to work at Beijing Pavilion three months ago, an arrangement similar to that at Sichuan Pavilion on East 44th Street.

title: DROPOUT RATE IS UP SHARPLY IN U.S. SCHOOLS, SURVEY SAYS
description: The Education Department said today that the number of students dropping out of high school had risen sharply from 1972 to 1982.

title: Yonkers Gets Sports Approval
description: The Yonkers school district's winter sports program has complied with state requirements and can continue, state education officials said today.

title: ROCKCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CITY'S RENTAL HOUSING MARKET STILL TIGHT
description: The market for middle-income rental housing in New York City was just as tight in the year just ended as it was in 1982 and 1981, and the mismatch of very strong demand and limited supply is not likely to change much in the near future, according to city housing officials and industry spokesmen.

title: LEBANON DISENGAGEMENT PLAN ACCEPTED
description: Lebanon's warring factions have approved in principle a plan for separating their forces, a Government official reported tonight. He said, however, that the Druse were still seeking clarification on some points.

title: A TEXAN TURNS CHEERLEADING INTO BIG BUSINESS
description: Dorothy Herkimer has no complaints, but even after 35 years of marriage she gets a little tired of explaining exactly how her husband earns a living.

title: JORDAN MOVES TOWARD ELECTIONS
description: King Hussein, apparently looking for popular support to enter the Middle East peace process, summoned Jordan's long-suspended Parliament into special session today. The move signaled that Jordan might hold its first parliamentary elections in 16 years.

title: Oklahoma Budget Cuts End a Rape Case
description: A man charged with first-degree rape has gone free after state budget cuts left a District Attorney's office without money to try the case.

title: H.B.M. AND CREAMER MERGING
description: C REAMER Inc., based in New York and billing some $200 million a year, is in the process of merging with Humphrey Browning MacDougall of Boston, which bills $100 million. It is the biggest agency merger so far this year.

title: HAVING IT ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: Kenny index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SCOUTING
description: Honored Guests?

title: CHINA OPENS HER ARMS TO EMIGRANTS WHO MADE IT
description: A bronze statue of Chen Jiageng, larger than life with his Panama hat and cane, was unveiled amid great ceremony some months ago in this southeastern port city. Mr. Chen started no revolutions, led no armies, wrote no masterpieces. He is revered because he left China and made a lot of money.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST GIVE THEIR THANKS FOR CHANCES TO HELP
description: ''My husband and I do not take our many blessings for granted. We would feel remiss if we did not share our good fortune, in some way, with others in need.''

title: BRIEFING
description: 'Tough Questions'

title: SENATE PANEL SEES MEMO ON WICK PHONE TAPING
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today was shown a memorandum, written in 1981 by the general counsel to the United States Information Agency, that advised the director of the agency, Charles Z. Wick, to ask the permission of other parties before tape-recording telephone conversations.

title: BROADWAY
description: WITH his flamboyant life style, celebrated romances, rags-to-riches success and extraordinary flair as a stage and film producer, the late Mike Todd had all the color and drama you would want for the subject of a Broadway musical. Which is what he is about to be. The librettist Thomas Meehan (''Annie''), the composer Mitch Leigh (''Man of La Mancha'') and the lyricist Lee Adams (''Applause'') have just signed contracts and are beginning what is known in Shubert Alley as the collaborative process. ''We are hoping for next season,'' Cyma Rubin, the producer, says. ''It depends on how fast they write.''

title: Levi Strauss Lifts Profit
description: Levi Strauss & Company, the apparel manufacturer, reported today that its fourth-quarter profit expanded 12 percent, to $51.6 million, or $1.22 a share, from $45.9 million, or $1.10 a share, a year earlier. Sales climbed to $705 million from $686.5 million. ''Domestic operations were strong throughout the year, but the international businesses suffered from the strengthening U.S. dollar and economic disruption in several major markets,'' said Robert T. Grohman, the company's president and chief executive officer.

title: NEW NIGERIAN LEADER ASKS CREDITORS NOT TO PRESS HARD
description: The leader of Nigeria's new military Government, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari, said today that he hoped international lenders would help ''in bailing us out of our ailing economy.''

title: NEW DIRECTOR OF U.S. RIGHTS PANEL CALLS FOR MAJOR CHANGE OF COURSE
description: The new staff director of the United States Commission on Civil Rights today recommended major changes in its programs. She said the changes could show possible adverse effects of affirmative action, racial quotas, court-ordered busing and bilingual education.

title: VIOLENCE ERUPTS IN PARIS AS AUTO PLANT IS STRUCK
description: More than 55 people were injured today, some of them seriously, as strikers and nonstrikers battled each other at a Peugeot-owned automobile factory at Poissy, an industrial suburb west of the French capital.

title: IMPORTS THAT THREATEN A VITAL TOOL OF NATIONAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: U.S. and Japan Eurobonds Up LONDON, Jan. 5 (Reuters)

title: DOLLAR EXTENDS ITS RALLY
description: The dollar extended its record- breaking rally in major foreign exchange markets yesterday.

title: A HEART TRANSPLANT IS DELAYED IN BOSTON AS STATE SEEKS ROLE
description: A man who needs a heart transplant has touched off a dispute between Boston's New England Medical Center and the State Department of Public Health, which wants to regulate development of heart and liver transplant programs in the state.

title: GENERALS USE DRAFT TO SHORE UP DEFENSE
description: Walt Michaels said he was hoarse following two days of picking and choosing.

title: CLARK, J L, MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Man on Coast Ordered To Trial in Slaying of 4
description: A judge today ordered Kevin Cooper to stand trial in the murder of four people in a ranch house early last summer.

title: SCOUTING
description: Hernandez Seeks Richest Met Deal

title: MILOT FILLED OUT, THEN FIT IN
description: With success come nicknames. The Washington Redskins, who won Super Bowl XVII last January and are one victory away from playing in Super Bowl XVIII, are loaded with them.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: THE AMERICAN JEWISH EXPERIENCE
description: It was just 330 years ago that the first Jews, 23 of them, landed in what was to become the United States, inaugurating a history that, while short for an ancient people, is long for the New World. This American episode in Jewish history is still being played out, often in ways that are dramatically, even exotically, different from the Jewish story elsewhere. An account of it, from the beginnings to the present, is being told in an ambitious exhibition that opens today at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

title: Raybeats and Rodeo
description: Two New York rock bands, the all- instrumental Raybeats and Steve Almaas's Beat Rodeo, will perform tonight at Irving Plaza (477-3728), 17 Irving Place at East 15th Street. Music begins at about 11:30 P.M., and tickets are $8.

title: Hospital Will Shift Quadriplegic's Room
description: A cerebral palsy victim who wants to starve to death with medical help will be moved out of the only private room in Riverside General Hospital because she ''is not sick'' and the room is needed to isolate infectious cases, officials said today.

title: Execution Stayed For Biegenwald
description: A judge today stayed the execution of Richard F. Biegenwald to give the convicted murderer's attorneys time to appeal to the State Supreme Court.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Apple Computer misstated the name of a company that was ordered last month to stop selling computers that infringe on Apple copyrights. It was the Extra Computer Corporation.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Pause for Celebration

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Richie Hebner, free agent infielder, to two-year contract. TORONTO (AL) - Signed Rance Mulliniks, third baseman, and Mark Eichhorn, right-handed pitcher.

title: Roy M. Stelle, Former Chief Of New York School for Deaf
description: Roy M. Stelle, a former superintendent of the New York School for the Deaf in White Plains, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Wednesday at the Tucson (Ariz.) General Hospital.

title: U.S. REACTION COOL
description: Lebanon has asked that some of the United States Marines in Beirut be shifted to the south along the coast to help the Lebanese Army extend its authority, White House officials said today.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ROCK FOR SHAKESPEARE

title: Vermont Governor Says He Won't Seek 5th Term
description: Gov. Richard A. Snelling of Vermont surprised the State Legislature today by announcing he would not seek re- election to a fifth term. Mr. Snelling, a Republican, was first elected in 1976 to a two-year term.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Schweppes U.S.A. To Ammirati & Puris

title: MOBIL AGREES TO MULTIMILLION DOLLAR OIL RIGHTS ACCORD WITH
description: TEXAS By WAYNE KING

title: Great American
description: Great American Industries of Binghamton, N.Y., has acquired almost one-fifth of the stock of the International Seaway Trading Corporation of Cleveland.

title: DANCE: SEASON OPENER AT RIVERSIDE
description: THE winter dance season at the Theater of the Riverside Church got under way Wednesday night with a gala called ''A Riverside Sampler'' that emphasized the diversity of the organization's programming.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined in the week ended Wednesday, but short-term yields on the funds rose sharply, the Investment Company Institute and Donoghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday.
description: The institute said that total assets in 316 money funds fell $954 million, to $163.5 billion. Assets were $164.94 billion the week before.

title: 2 SAXOPHONISTS AND THE DOUBLE LIVES THEY LEAD
description: -jazz musician is likely to lead a double life - or maybe a triple one. Instead of leading one regular group, he may lead two thoroughly different outfits, as does the alto saxophonist Arthur Blythe, who has brought his In the Tradition quartet to the Village Vanguard this week. Or like the saxophonist Oliver Lake, he may lead an electric dance band Saturday and a jazz quintet Sunday.

title: SLAIN WITNESS'ACCOUNT ALLOWED IN MURDER TRIAL
description: A Manhattan man on trial for murder was involved in the slaying of a key witness against him, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Robot Called In at City Hall

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE cocktail party, Mario Buatta

title: LAROUCHE FINDS A WAY TO SCORE
description: At first, Glenn Resch made the

title: ADVERTISING
description: New Top Management At Scientific American

title: 'Salute to Hank Jones'
description: The pianist Hank Jones will perform tonight at 8 in ''A Salute to Hank Jones,'' a ''Highlights in Jazz'' program at New York University's Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place at Washington Square South.

title: REAGAN, IN A RADIO SPEECH, APPEALS TO PEOPLE OF CUBA
description: President Reagan, in a radio speech broadcast by the Voice of America, appealed to the people of Cuba tonight to realize that their leaders had betrayed them and that Cubans were not being told the truth about their country's actions around the world.

title: ISLANDERS LOSE FOURTH IN LAST 6 GAMES
description: Coach Al Arbour was mildly annoyed when the Islanders lost to the Boston Bruins, 4-2, Tuesday night. With the third- best record in the National Hockey League, the Bruins are expected, at times, to beat the Islanders.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. announced that it had signed a letter of intent with a joint venture formed by Leo D. Phillips & Co. of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and a unit of JMB Realty Corp. of Chicago for the sale and partial leaseback of Allied's Bendix Center property in Southfield, Mich.

title: Pratt & Whitney
description: The Dutch Air Force has grounded about 30 of its 93 General Dynamics Corporation F-16 fighter planes because of a defect in the engine cooling system, the Defense Ministry said. A spokesman said a team of experts from the United Technologies Corporation's Pratt & Whitney group, makers of the engines, arrived here today to inspect the planes.

title: Man Who Helped In Cold Wins Case
description: A man who broke into a locked railroad station to let 50 people in on the bitter cold day after Christmas has been cleared of criminal charges.

title: Manville Case Hearing Held Sixteen months after the Manville Corporation filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws, the bankruptcy court finally heard arguments yesterday on whether the proceedings should be dismissed.
description: Although Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland said he would not issue his decision until later this month, it seemed clear from the tone of his questions that he will not throw Manville out of bankruptcy court, even though the company is neither insolvent nor theatened with immediate insolvency, but went into bankruptcy to try to deal with a continuing flood of lawsuits by thousands of workers with asbestos-related diseases. Manville, based in Denver, is a manufacturing, mining and forest products company.

title: Phil Niekro Signs 2-Year Yankee Pact
description: Phil Niekro, the 44-year-old knuckleball pitcher and the oldest player in the big leagues, signed a two-year contract with the Yankees yesterday after 19 seasons with the Braves in Milwaukee and Atlanta.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ILL-REASONED CALL TO PUT SHOREHAM ON LINE
description: To the Editor:

title: SHORT INTEREST: BULLISH SIGNAL
description: M OST people yawn at the mention of short interest figures on the New York Stock Exchange, but perhaps they should have paid closer attention lately. Although no technical indicator related to the stock market is infallible, short interest data have been flashing some unabashedly bullish signals.

title: Grain Elevator Rule Proposed
description: After months of internal battles, the Reagan Administration today unveiled a proposed regulation intended to reduce grain elevator fires and explosions.

title: Preview of 'Giselle'
description: Dance Theater of Harlem will offer a sneak preview of its forthcoming Creole version of ''Giselle'' on Sunday at 3 P.M. at the company's monthly open-house performance, at 466 West 152d Street.

title: Concert Replacement
description: The violinist Ida Levin will be soloist in the American Symphony Orchestra's concert Sunday at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall, replacing Charles Treger, who is ill.

title: Sale by Arco Set
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said it plans to sell certain aluminum facilities and as a result will report a one-time net book loss of $200 million to $300 million.

title: Indonesia Denies Killing 3,000 Criminal Suspects
description: The Government denied responsibility today for the killing of more than 3,000 reputed criminals and members of underworld groups since April.

title: ROZIER EXPECTED TO SIGN WITH MAULERS OF U.S.F.L.
description: Mike Rozier, the Nebraska running back who won the Heisman Trophy this season, is expected to sign a contract soon to play with the Pittsburgh Maulers, an expansion team that made him the No. 1 choice Wednesday in the United States Football League's draft.

title: Article 158151 -- No Title
description: A Presidential commission is moving toward agreement on a recommendation that the United States give $1 billion a year in economic and military aid to Central America over the next 10 to 15 years, commission officials said today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Gulf United Redemption Of Debt Securities Set

title: ADOLFO: ELEGANCE WINS APPLAUSE
description: In winter, they are in furs and boots. In summer, they are in sandals and suntans. But whatever the time of year, they usually wear Adolfo suits as they contemplate fashion choices for the next season.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Record Won't Count
description: Zola Budd , a 17-year-old South African, ran nearly 7 seconds under the world record in a women's 5,000- meter race last night in Stellenbosch, South Africa, but her time of 15 minutes 1.83 seconds. will not be considered for world recognition. That's because South Africa's apartheid policy has caused the country to be barred by the International Amateur Athletic Federation, the world gov=?erning body of track and field. The world record in the 5,000 is 15:08.26, set by Mary Decker of the United States in 1982.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Show for Men's Shelters

title: Memorial for Dee Victor, 57, Scheduled at Actors Chapel
description: A memorial service will be held for Dee Victor, a featured actress with the Association of Producing Artists Repertory Company, on Jan. 28 at 1 P.M. at St. Malachy's Actors Chapel, 239 West 49th Street. Miss Victor died Dec. 18 in her Greenwich Village apartment, apparently of a heart attack.

title: FEWER AIDS CASES FILED AT END OF '83
description: Fewer new cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, were reported in the United States in the second half of 1983 than in the first half of the year, Federal health officials said yesterday. However, they cautioned that it was too soon to draw conclusions about a long-term trend.

title: BRIDGE AND DAM REPAIRS PROPOSED IN CONNECTICUT
description: A task force appointed by Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed today that Connecticut spend $1.7 billion over the next 10 years to repair its bridges and dams.

title: PESTICIDE IS FOUND IN FOOD SAMPLINGS
description: New spot checks by Federal agencies have found residues of a cancer-causing pesticide in samples of some foods around the country, officials of the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Continental Insurance Company has named Alan Siskind president of its Travelsafe Insurance division.

title: CANAL-RANDOLPH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring capital gain of $6,878,000, or $4.45 a share, for the quarter and year.

title: ASSEMBLY PLANT FOR THE OLYMPICS
description: One day in 1979, shortly after the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee set up a few desks in its first headquarters, a stranger arrived and handed a cardboard box to Peter Ueberroth.

title: Newark Rehires 76 Firefighters
description: Fire officials today reinstated 76 firefighters they laid off two weeks ago.

title: TO KISSINGER COMMISSION: HISTORY WARNS AGAINST THREATS TO INVADE NICARAGUA
description: Is a United States invasion of Nicaragua a possibility that our Government should wish to keep open? As the Kissinger commission gets ready to report, there are alarming indications that bad history may be about to produce bad recommendations on this point.

title: FRIDAY, JANUARY 6, 1984 International
description: A wider role for the Marines in Beirut is sought by the Lebanese Government, according to White House officials. They said Lebanon had asked that some of the American marines be shifted along the coast south of Beirut to support the Lebanese Army as it extends its authority. Administration officials said they doubted that the proposal would be accepted. (Page A1, Column 6.) Lebanese factions have approved in principle a plan for establishing 700- yard-wide buffer zones to separate their warring forces, according to a Government official. But he said the Druse were seeking clarification of some issues. (A6:1-3.)

title: Deficit Business, Sigh, as Usual
description: Does Budget Director David Stockman feel depressed about submitting yet another Federal budget with a multibillion-dollar deficit? ''You get used to it,'' he says.

title: REDMEN, LOUISVILLE WINNERS AT GARDEN
description: With its game against Rutgers at Madison Square Garden two minutes old last night, St. John's lost its starting center. As Dr. Irving Glick, the team physican, examined Bill Wennington in front of the St. John's bench, Coach Lou Carnesecca paced nervously.

title: QUITTING UNESCO WILL SOLVE NOTHING
description: To the Editor:

title: 15 Die in Nepal Bus Crash
description: Fifteen people were killed today when a minibus skidded off a road near the township of Butwal, 125 miles southwest of Katmandu.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Credithrift Financial Corp., an Evansville, Ind., financial services company, said its $100 million issue of 12 3/8 percent senior notes due in 1994 had been priced at 99.56 percent, plus accrued interest, if any, from Jan. 11, 1984. Underwriters are led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Wills Enters Plea
description: Maury Wills, the former Los Angeles Dodger shortstop and Seattle Mariner manager, pleaded not guilty today to one count of cocaine possession. At his arraignment in Compton Municipal Court, Wills denied that he possessed the .06 gram of cocaine the police say they found in the car Wills was driving when stopped by the police Dec. 27.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE decor at Cabana Carioca II is reminiscent of a style that was considered the height of elegance in our small towns during the 1950's. With its bare brick walls and timber-and-stucco ceiling, the setting is especially appropriate, because the restaurant's prices are similar to those of 30 years ago.

title: ; BEIRUT: IF THE U.S. WITHDRAWS ITS MARINES
description: To the Editor:

title: AUCTIONS
description: NO New York museum has been more involved with auction houses than the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Over the years, the Met has bought at auctions such major works as Rembrandt's ''Aristotle Contemplating the Bust of Homer'' and Velazquez's ''Juan de Pareja.'' Last month the museum bought a pack of 15th-century hand-painted playing cards for $143,000 from Sotheby's in London.

title: TRW in Trico Bid
description: The TRW Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Trico Industries and is offering 0.1375 share of TRW common for each Trico common share held, subject to possible adjustment to reflect market fluctuations.

title: 'JERK TOO,' 'BLUE THUNDER'
description: IN his role of executive producer,

title: A LOOK AT THE ICED-AGE HUNTER
description: Most of the hunters in the world are motivated by a curious blend of tradition and an urge to participate in something that was once essential to man's survival.

title: LESSON FOR DEMOCRATS DON'T BE CONSERVATIVE
description: HE SPECTER OF the 1980 election continues to haunt the Democrats as they search for a strategy against Ronald Reagan. Congressional leaders and Presidential candidates seem unable to press their party's natural issues of fairness and peace out of fear of moving too far to the left of the voters.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE TRUE ADVENTURES OF JOHN STEINBECK, WRITER. By Jackson J. Benson. Illustrated. 1,116 pages. Viking Press. $35. JOHN STEINBECK was one of those unclassifiable American novelists that our century seems to have turned up in surprising numbers. As Jackson J. Benson pictures him in his interminable biography, ''The True Adventures of John Steinbeck, Writer,'' Steinbeck appears to have been awkward, half-educated, sentimental and naive, a man who wrested an insecure fame for himself out of his determination, his unalloyed sincerity, his belief in himself and his immersion in time and place. In other words, he had all the virtues traditionally associated with the term American by those critics, like Mary McCarthy, for example, who disliked his work.

title: Judge Rules Out Schoolboy Limit
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Erie County has issued a restraining order against a state rule that limits competition by athletes in public high schools.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: What a Restoration Can Do

title: Bulgaria Upset by Air Base NATO Is Building in Turkey
description: The Bulgarian newspaper Otechestven Front said today that Balkan security was threatened by a military air base the Atlantic alliance was building in European Turkey.

title: Bridge: A Surprising Bid Can Result When a Novice Learns Fast
description: An expert who was invited to examine the bidding of the diagramed deal would probably conclude that North- South were using the Brozel convention: Two hearts promised both major suits and South gave preference.

title: The Worm and the Apple Park Concerts Make Dubious Gifts
description: Big-name entertainers who perform ''free'' in Central Park think they bestow a gift on New York. That's plausible: At a concert by Simon and Garfunkel, 400,000 people were able to attend a show that cost the city only $200,000 for police and cleanup - 50 cents a head. Tickets to the same event in a stadium would easily have sold for $15 or $20.

title: NRBQ and the Casuals
description: NRBQ, an eclectic rock-and-roll band, will appear tonight and tomorrow at the Bottom Line (228-7880), 15 West Fourth Street at Mercer Street. Double bills, with the Incredible Casuals opening the shows, begin at 9 and midnight; tickets are $8.50.

title: Books: Deregulation By Martin F. Nolan;
description: DISMANTLING AMERICA: THE RUSH

title: MARTIN STERN
description: Martin Stern, an advertising executive who was the account group head for the ''I Love New York'' and the ''Made in New York'' campaigns for the New York State Department of Commerce, died Dec. 29 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Creditor Aids Air Florida
description: Air Florida officials said yesterday that they had reached an agreement with a major creditor that, when carried out, would cause the creditor to withdraw a notice that put the airline in default. Although the airline refused to name the creditor, a source said that it was Interfirst Bank of Dallas, which holds about 30 percent of Air Florida's long-term debt of $141 million.

title: PHYSICIAN'S TEAMMATE
description: * To the Editor: Your Dec. 28 news article noted that, despite the projected surplus of physicians, many areas within our state remain medically underserved. The rising cost of medical education, increasing malpractice premiums and cutbacks in Federal aid have markedly reduced the ability of a medically underserved area to provide the economic base to support additional physicians.

title: TEXAS STOCKBROKER WITH TIE TO THAYER
description: For some 12 years, Billy Bob Harris has enjoyed local celebrity status in this sprawling metropolitan area through his daily radio and television broadcasts of the news from Wall Street.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Space and 'Sesame Street'

title: DRIVER WHO HIT CAMDEN BOY, 7, GIVEN 25 YEARS
description: A man convicted of manslaughter for fatally running his car into a 7-year-old boy on a bicycle was sentenced today to 25 years in prison.

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
FABERGE APPROVES LEVERAGED BUYOUT
description: Faberge Inc. said yesterday that its board in a letter of intent had approved a leveraged buyout of the company for $30 a share, or a total of $168.6 million. The members of the investment group organized by Gibbons Green Van Amerongen Inc., a private New York investment banking firm, have not been announced.

title: CUBA CALLS REAGAN DESPERATE
description: Cuba said today that President Reagan used ''lies'' and the ''arguments of a desperate man'' in a broadcast addressed to the Cuban people.

title: Challenger Gets Parts From Another Shuttle
description: The space shuttle Challenger is being outfitted for its flight Feb. 3 with three power steering units taken from the new shuttle Discovery. The swap is a result of fires that damaged a third shuttle last month as it landed after a 10-day mission.

title: Bridge: Should Dummy Be Sloppy? There Are Times, It Seems
description: Dummy players come in two varieties.

title: A.T.& T. SEES BIGGER RATE CUTS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, newly divested of its local operating subsidiaries, said today that it could cut prices of long-distance service by more than the 10.5 percent it proposed in October if Congress did not block or modify proposed monthly ''access'' charges.

title: TUNISIA ROLLS BACK PRICE OF BREAD, ENDING CAUSE OF 15 DAYS OF RIOTING
description: President Habib Bourguiba announced today that he had ordered a rollback in the cost of bread, reversing a measure that had doubled prices and set off five days of rioting.

title: OTB--A WINNER; LOSSES AHEAD
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation, faced with escalating expenses and flat revenues, will clearly have to change the way it does business if it is to survive. Proposals such as expanding into betting on professional sports, while worthy of serious study, are not a panacea.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, JANUARY 7, 1984
description: Companies

title: EXERCISES FOR THE VERY YOUNG
description: The youngsters, seated in a circle on mats or laps, began mimicking Suzy Prudden's gestures as she wiggled her fingers energetically. Then, while their mothers helped them to remove their shoes (''You've got 10 toes; you've got to use them,'' Miss Prudden told them) their uncertain voices joined her - sort of - in singing, with appropriate motions, a tune whose lyrics went: ''The wheels on the bus go round and round all over town/The money on the bus goes jingle jangle jingle all over town.''

title: PADRES SIGN GOSSAGE TO FIVE-YEAR CONTRACT
description: The competition for Rich Gossage ended last night when the San Diego Padres announced that they had signed the former ace of the Yankee bullpen to a five-year contract reportedly worth more than $5.5 million.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Kontos Goes to Tulsa
description: Following recent discussions with Craig Patrick , the Rangers' general manager, Chris Kontos , the team's top 1982 draft choice, joined its Tulsa farm in the Central Hockey League for last night's game against Billings, Mont. Kontos, a 20-year-old center, had 8 goals and 7 assists in 44 games with the Rangers last season.

title: MURDOCH WEIGHS WARNER PROXY BID
description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation Ltd. may begin a proxy fight for control of Warner Communications, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Judge Who Played Part In Court Inquiry Resigns
description: A judge who helped the inquiry into the Cook County court system by working as an undercover agent said today he would resign March 31 because his involvement in the investigation had reduced his effectiveness.

title: CORRECTION
description: The listing of Events and Openings in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect time for a recital tomorrow by Fred Sherry, cellist, and Ik-Hwan Bae, violinist, at Bargemusic Ltd., Fulton Ferry Landing, in Brooklyn. The time is 4 P.M.

title: SCOUTING
description: Taylor's 2 Deals

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: There is nothing more intriguing than the challenge to finish a work created by someone else who, for one reason or another, could not finish it in person. Many have had a crack at ending Schubert's ''Unfinished'' Symphony, for instance and the New York Philharmonic is in the midst of a run of six performances of the established Deryck Cooke version of Mahler's Symphony No. 10 at Avery Fisher Hall (tonight at 8 and on Tuesday and Jan. 20 and 24).

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Reagan Plans Paid Message
description: President Reagan's nationally televised announcement from the White House Jan. 29 of whether he will seek re-election is expected to be a paid broadcast, spokesmen said Thursday. Larry Speakes, the White House chief spokesman, said the political address would be made at 8 P.M. The Reagan- Bush Committee will probably pay the cost, a campaign spokesman said.

title: 4TH IN ROW FOR CELTICS
description: Larry Bird scored 19 points, and five teammates also hit in double figures tonight as the Boston Celtics defeated the Cleveland Cavaliers, 115-97, for their fourth consecutive victory.

title: DEVELCON ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NIGERIA'S UNHAPPY PROSPECTS
description: Nigeria's fifth military coup, which ended more than four years of civilian rule, was virtually bloodless, apparently popular and may even produce some short-term economic and administrative benefits. But it is a backward step in Nigeria's political development and a sad omen for democracy in Africa.

title: Cost Is Estimated In Alcan-Arco Tie MONTREAL, Jan. 6 (Reuters) - Alcan Aluminium Ltd.'s acquisition of the Atlantic Richfield Company's aluminium assets could cost up to $1 billion , but several analysts think it is a bargain.
description: Alcan said Thursday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Atlantic Richfield's 163,000 metric tons a year aluminium smelter at Sebree, Ky., three rolling mills in Indiana and Kentucky, a 25 percent interest in an 800,000 metric tons a year alumina plant in Ireland and United States packaging operations. Atlantic Richfield said the transaction would result in a one-time net book loss of $200 million to $300 million.

title: State to Pay Costs At Brink's Trial
description: The state will pay for security personnel at the Brink's robbery-murder trial of Kathy Boudin and Samuel Brown next month, the Chairman of the Rockland County Legislature said today.

title: South Africa Asserts It Killed 324 in Angola
description: South Africa reported today that its forces killed 324 guerrillas and Angolan and Cuban soldiers in a three-day battle in southern Angola this week. It said seven South African soldiers had been killed.

title: CONTROL BOARD FINDS THE CITY MET '83 GOAL TO INCREASE PRODUCTIVITY
description: A Koch administration goal to improve productivity in the last fiscal year was achieved, according to a report issued yesterday by the State Financial Control Board.

title: HEALTH COST CURB ASKED BY MONDALE
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, calling the costs of medical care ''shocking'' and ''unbelievable,'' today proposed Federal spending limits for hospital care and physicians' services.

title: PRESERVING DIET WHILE DINING OUT
description: CONSUMERS who have been advised by physicians or nutritionists to restrict their diets or who have discovered for themselves that changes in diet have improved their health may have found at the same time that dining out has become more complicated.

title: MASSACHUSETTS' OPPOSITION TO HEART TRANSPLANT EASES
description: The Massachusetts Department of Public Health tentatively agreed today to allow a Boston hospital to perform a heart transplant on a 45-year-old man who is seriously ill.

title: TELEDYNE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter and year net were reduced by $314,000 in writeoffs. The latest year net also includes a gain on sales of equipment of $74,000 against $139,000 a year earlier.

title: Chrysler Rehiring
description: The Chrysler Corporation plans to add up to 900 workers at its Missouri assembly plant and 350 at its minivan plant in Windsor, Ontario, officials said. The 350 employees at Chrysler Canada Ltd.'s Windsor plant will be the first hired since 1979, and will be joined by 1,400 laid-off workers, according to a company spokesman, Walt McCall. Between 800 and 900 new workers will staff a second shift at the Fenton, Mo., plant where Chrysler builds large, rear-wheel- drive cars such as the Dodge Diplomat, Don Woemmel, president of Local 110 of the United Automobile Workers, said.

title: Veterans Collect Funds To Build Ruined Temple
description: Vietnam veterans nationwide began donating money today to help veterans in Massachusetts rebuild a Buddhist temple.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Lotto Prize Makes Wedding Possible
description: An unemployed handyman from Westchester County who said he could not afford to get married will get $3 million over the next 20 years for winning the state Lotto drawing Wednesday. He is Bernard Rowinski Jr., 28 years old, of Crugers.

title: Coastal Corp. Acts To Bar Takeovers HOUSTON, Jan. 6 (Reuters) - The Coastal Corporation said stockholders at a special meeting had approved additional antitakeover amendments to the company's charter designed to discourage any hostile attempt to acquire control of the company in a transaction opposed by the board. The amendments divide the board into three classes, each elected for a three-year term, eliminate a provision that permitted removal of directors without cause and assure that stockholder action can be taken only at meetings in which all stockholders can participate and vote.
description: Oscar S. Wyatt, company chairman, told stockholders the current market price of the stock is substantially less than its intrinsic value, leaving Coastal open to a possible takeover attempt. Coastal closed today on the New York Stock Exchange at 33 1/2, down 7/8. Mr. Wyatt said the company expects to reach its forecast of 1983 earnings of $3.85 to $4 a share, against $2.65 in 1982. Coastal is involved in the exploration and production of natural gas.

title: BURGER KING EXTENDING PRICE CUTS
description: The Burger King Corporation plans to announce the latest challenge in its war with the McDonald's Corporation on Monday: It will cut the price of its regular hamburger about 35 percent, to 39 cents, nationwide.

title: FERGUS WINS TWO, GAINS ROUND OF 16
description: Dave Stockton missed an eight-foot putt on the 16th green and fell two holes behind Keith Fergus in their fourth- round match today at the Seiko-Tucson match play tournament.

title: U.S. Reduces Its Publications
description: The Presidential counselor, Edwin Meese 3d, surrounded by trash bags stuffed with documents, announced the elimination today of 1,800 Government publications, including such pamphlets as ''Controlling Bedbugs'' and ''Living with Radiation.''

title: Saturday Gala to Open Eckard Hall in Florida
description: Peter Martins and Suzanne Farrell of the New York City Ballet will dance tonight at a gala that will open the new Ruth Eckard Hall in Clearwater, Fla. Mr. Martins made his last appearance with the City Ballet in December and has said that he will retire from dancing after the gala.

title: ; M.D. DISTRIBUTION: WHERE THE DOCTORS AREN'T
description: To the Editor:

title: TENTATIVE OPERA LABOR PACTS
description: The Metropolitan Opera has reached tentative agreements with its chorus and ballet for a new three- year contract following the expiration of the current pact next July 31.

title: SALVADORANS BEGIN FAST AT CHURCH IN MANHATTAN
description: Seven Salvadorans and two Americans began what they said would be a two-week hunger strike in Manhattan yesterday to protest United States policy in Central America and regulations denying legal residence to Salvadoran refugees in the United States.

title: RENOVATION PLANNED FOR BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN
description: Three octagonal glass pavilions and a sleek new greenhouse will be added to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden as part of a $16 million renovation scheduled to begin in the spring.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Keeping Tabs

title: PatentsStacy V. Jones A.T.& T.'s Conference Call Unit
description: WASHINGTON

title: TALKS OF JEWISH STRUGGLES
description: The novelist Cynthia Ozick will moderate ''The Shattered Tables: Jewish Spiritual Struggles With Modernity,'' a series of six discussions beginning Tuesday at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

title: U.S. IS EASING RULES ON BIRTH-DEFECT INFANTS
description: The Reagan Administration will announce new regulations Monday for the treatment of newborn infants with severe birth defects who are in hospitals that receive Federal funds, Administration officials said today.

title: A WEE GIFT IN RETURN
description: The debate over whether Central Park should be used as the setting for mass audience concerts is on again, and the rhetoric this time is very spicy indeed.

title: TONEY LEADS 76ERS PAST NETS
description: Playing without Julius Erving, their all- star forward, the Philadelphia 76ers got a dynamic lift from Andrew Toney, their all-star guard, during a scoring spurt late in the third quarter tonight and defeated the New Jersey Nets, 108-104, at the Spectrum.

title: CLASSROOM DRAMA: STORIES OF HUMOR AND PAIN
description: Fifteen sophomores sat in a classroom at Martin Luther King Jr. High School yesterday, ready to write a play for the first time in their lives. Only a few had even seen a play before, and most had never created anything more literary than a book report. But like the greatest dramatists, they had stories to tell.

title: CHEFS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Suit Against Jaycees Dismissed in U.S. Court
description: A Federal district judge today rejected a lawsuit filed by the national Jaycees against a chapter that violated the national organization's rules by admitting women.

title: PATENTS
description: Exercise Devices

title: NEW PROBLEM IDLES ALL OF CITY'S 850 GRUMMAN BUSES
description: The Transit Authority ordered all 850 of its Grumman-Flxible buses out of service yesterday for a weekend inspection of their steering mechanisms.

title: OTTINGER, RETIRING, CITES FRUSTRATIONS
description: Representative Richard L. Ottinger today formally announced his decision not to seek another term, citing ''the incredible frustration of being in Congress and still feeling as powerless as the average citizen'' in affecting major issues.

title: REAGAN WEIGHS MAJOR SPEECH ON SOVIET
description: President Reagan, sensing the Soviet Union is in a period of ''introspection,'' is considering a major speech to invite an improvement in East-West relations, Administration officials said today.

title: ALPHA MICRO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
INTERPROVINCIAL STEEL & PIPE LINE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Ellen Knowles Harcourt, 94; Book Editor, Philanthropist
description: Ellen Knowles Harcourt, the first childrens-book editor for Harcourt, Brace and Company, died in New Milford, Conn., on Jan 1. She was 94 years old.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Money Supply Off $600 Million
description: The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply fell by $600 million in the week that ended Dec. 28.

title: NEW YORKER IS A RARITY IN SWIMMING
description: In a world of sleek, blond, 6-foot-3-inch California swimmers with shoulders from Malibu to Bakersfield, Tony Corbisiero seems to have dived into the wrong pool.

title: JOBLESSNESS DROPPED SHARPLY IN THE NEW YORK AREA IN 1983
description: The unemployment rates in New York State and New Jersey dropped sharply over the last year, marking a turnaround from recession to recovery, the Federal Labor Department said yesterday.

title: CHER HOPING 'SILKWOOD' IS HER TURNING POINT
description: She surprised everyone with her well-received appearance in Robert Altman's film ''Come Back to the Five and Dime, Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean.'' And now she has given a supporting performance in Mike Nichols's ''Silkwood'' that has won her glowing notices. But Cher says she doesn't quite feel like an overnight sensation. Her recent acting successes, she says, were preceded by ''eight years in which I couldn't get a job in film.''

title: McDonnell Unit
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had completed the previously announced acquisition of Hughes Helicopters Inc., an asset of the estate of Howard Hughes, for about $470 million. It said Hughes Helicopters, with principal facilities in Culver City, Calif., and Mesa, Ariz. and about 5,000 employees, would be operated as a McDonnell Douglas subsidiary.

title: SLAYER OF COAST MAYOR RELEASED FROM PRISON
description: Amid great secrecy, Dan White, the man convicted of killing Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk in 1978, was released from prison today and began serving a one-year parole in Los Angeles County.

title: CUOMO SETS UP COMMITTEE TO REVIEW YONKERS FINANCES
description: Governor Cuomo named Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello yesterday to head a state panel to examine budget problems in Yonkers, which faces a deficit of up to $40 million in the next 18 months.

title: FISHY DEVELOPMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: KNICKS, MINUS ROBINSON, FALL TO PISTONS
description: In a game that exemplified their inconsistency, the Knicks were beaten, 118-107, by the Detroit Pistons at the Silverdome tonight, just three days after their romp over the strong Los Angeles Lakers.

title: TIMKEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company did not release share earnings figures.

title: U.S. ISRAELIS MAY QUIT LEBANON BEFORE SYRIA DOES
description: Israeli officials have told the United States that they are willing to remove most of their troops from Lebanon without waiting for a simultaneous pullback of Syrian forces, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: U.S. to Fine Makers Of Polluting Motor Fuels
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced its first major crackdown on companies that blend gasoline that causes smog.

title: TREATING PRESS FREEDOM LIKE GRENADA
description: If this is the year that United States troops go into El Salvador, will the Reagan Administration keep the news media away, as in Grenada? It doesn't take a key to the secret war-plans locker at the Pentagon to know that the most luscious dream of the Joint Chiefs must be an antiseptic surgical strike with no television cameras or reporters snooping around until the triumphal march up Pennsylvania Ave.

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $300,000. c-After a tax credit and a gain on an insurance policy totaling $7,147,380.

title: GEM TRADE, LEGAL AND ILLEGAL, BLOOMS IN BOMBAY
description: Almost every evening hundreds of men gather on a street in the crowded, dusty, yet enormously rich diamond and gold business district of this bustling city to conduct a most unusual bazaar.

title: TEXACO INC. MAKES $10 BILLION OFFER TO BUY GETTY OIL
description: Texaco Inc. offered to buy the Getty Oil Company yesterday for about $10 billion, in what would be the biggest merger ever.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEIGHBORS WELCOME FLIER FREED BY SYRIANS
description: Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr., the Navy flier freed after a month of captivity in Syria, returned to his home today amid a joyous, banner- waving welcome from neighbors and fellow airmen.

title: INTERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
Greek Cypriot to Visit U.S.
description: President Spyros Kyprianou left on a trip to the United States and Europe today with hopes of reversing the move by Turkish Cypriots in November to declare an independent state. He plans to confer Monday with Secretary of State George P. Shultz in Washington.

title: Sharing Space
description: Does it matter that there are peregrine falcons nesting on two New York City bridges and a few rooftops in Atlantic City? That the world now boasts 148 whooping cranes? That the American alligator is flourishing in the south and the California condor may soon be soaring over the Pacific coast again?

title: Teacher Arrested As Cocaine Seller
description: A Queens schoolteacher was arrested yesterday in the principal's office on charges she twice sold cocaine to undercover police agents, once in the school building, detectives said.

title: S.E.C.'S THAYER ACTION MAY BE SHAD'S FIRMIST
description: The insider trading case filed Thursday by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Paul Thayer and eight others may be the most important enforcement action the agency has brought during the tenure of its current chairman, John S. R. Shad.

title: SYRIANS' ARMED FORCES: PLAYING WAITING GAME?
description: Western intelligence analysts say Syria's military prowess, while potentially threatening to Israel, Lebanon and Jordan, is still far from being as formidable as the country's military leaders or the Soviet Union would like. A key factor, the analysts say, is the inability of many soldiers to use high- technology weapons systems effectively and to maintain them properly.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Indiana Pacers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., live, and 2 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.) Nets vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Sports Channel, 10 P.M., tape. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.)

title: Kidnapper Wins Rights Suit on L.I.
description: A convicted kidnapper was awarded $35,501 in damages today in a civil rights suit because Nassau County jail officials failed to promptly fit him with eyeglasses, did not segregate him from smokers in cells and did not deliver a magazine fast enough.

title: SCOUTING
description: Queens Complex?

title: What's Been Happening at Getty
description: The Getty Oil Company, its two principal shareholders and two companies bidding to take over Getty have been caught up in a swirl of activity in the last three months, caused mostly by disputes among family members over management of the company.

title: ROLE OF SOVIET EMPLOYEES AT U.N. QUESTIONED
description: Each morning scores of Soviet citizens arrive in front of United Nations headquarters in a small convoy of buses. Late in the afternoon, the buses reappear and take the Russians back to a housing compound in Riverdale owned by their Government.

title: FLORIDA MAN GUILTY IN HORSE-DRUG CASE
description: A Florida man was found guilty in Federal District Court here Thursday of importing and selling illegal drugs to more than 200 harness and thoroughbred horse trainers throughout the nation.

title: OTB Clerks End Roosevelt Strike
description: Offtrack betting on the harness races at Roosevelt Raceway resumed yesterday after a job-security dispute involving mutuel clerks there was tentatively settled in the early morning.

title: THOMPSON DEALS WITH HIMSELF
description: In recent seasons John Thompson, the head basketball coach at Georgetown University, has come to terms with the conflicts that have accompanied his success.

title: Officer Suspended For Fleeing Crash
description: A rookie New York City police officer who was charged yesterday with leaving the scene of an accident on Long Island has been suspended without pay, authorities said.

title: Anti-Mafia Campaigner Is Found Slain in Sicily
description: Giuseppe Fava, a newspaper editor, author and playwright who was regarded as one of Italy's most outspoken campaigners against organized crime, has been slain, the police said today.

title: 4 RESIGN POSTS AT CHICAGO PAPER
description: The publisher, the editor and two other top executives of The Chicago Sun-Times announced yesterday that they would resign Monday, when the paper becomes the property of Rupert Murdoch.

title: Your MoneyLeonard Sloane Nonprofit Units And Pensions
description: U NTIL recently, there has been one key distinction in the rules governing the so-called salary reduction plans under which employees may turn over a portion of their pay for investment by their employers: those working for profit- making enterprises could have one type of plan and those working for nonprofit organizations could have another.

title: New Suriname Strike Blacks Out the Capital
description: Striking electricity workers blacked out Paramaribo today, shutting down most offices, schools and government communications in spreading labor protests against the regime of Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse.

title: GUILD REJECTS OFFER BY PROSPECTIVE BUYER OF ST. LOUIS PAPER
description: Employees of The St. Louis Globe-Democrat voted overwhelmingly today to reject a proposal that would have permitted the 131-year-old newspaper to continue publishing, the executive secretary of the Newspaper Guild of St. Louis said.

title: New York's Other Nuclear Elephant
description: Nine Mile 2, the big nuclear power plant under construction in Oswego, N.Y., looks like another Shoreham in the making. It too is far behind schedule and far over budget. Its owners, like Shoreham's, would probably be happier if they'd never started the project. But there are some important - and reassuring - differences.

title: NATO Maneuvers in Norway
description: Norway announced today that it would act as host to military maneuvers above the Arctic Circle in March in which more than 25,000 troops will take part.

title: ISRAELIS SAY REDEPLOYMENT ISN'T WITHDRAWAL
description: Israel is planning to thin out its forces in southern Lebanon and redeploy them away from large urban headquarters as a way of presenting less of a target to guerrillas, well-placed officials said today. But they denied reports that the Israeli Army was prepared to withdraw entirely without a reciprocal Syrian pullout.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Boagni Quits Kansas
description: Kerry Boagni , who was named to the Big Eight Conference's all-freshman team last season, has left the University of Kansas basketball team, apparently unhappy with being removed from the starting lineup.

title: DEALER FOR NEW U.S. ARTISTS
description: Eleanor Ward, an art dealer noted for her shows of controversial new American talents in the 1950's and 60's, died yesterday at the Hotel Volney, where she had lived in recent years. She was 72 years old.

title: Seahawks Seek a 3-0 Sweep
description: According to the Seattle Seahawks' strong safety, Kenny Easley, beating the Los Angeles Raiders comes down to three simple things.

title: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Ex-Dolphins Rebuffed
description: A state appeals court in Tallahassee, Fla., ruled yesterday that three former Miami Dolphins were not entitled to receive worker's-compensation benefits for injuries they received in preseason training camps. But the court said the players might be able to receive the equivalent of those benefits by pursuing a clause in the National Football League player's contract.

title: Andropov Improving, Top Soviet Aide Says
description: A top Soviet official said today that Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, is recovering from his illness.

title: ACID RAIN IS THEME OF GATHERING IN NEW HAMPSHIRE POLITICAL TEST
description: One of the first political extravaganzas of the 1984 Presidential campaign opened here today, and its theme was an environmental issue: acid rain.

title: RESTAURANTF HAS RECIPE FOR MULTIMILLION-DOLLAR COMPUTER DEALS
description: First Nolan K. Bushnell invented video games in a garage with a $500 investment. Then he sold his company for $28 million. What to do next? Mr. Bushnell, the founder of Atari, did the only sensible thing: he opened a bar and restaurant.

title: Fierstein Back in 'Trilogy'
description: Harvey Fierstein, author of the Tony-award winning show ''Torch Song Trilogy,'' will return to the leading role in his play for three weeks, beginning Tuesday.

title: Pittston to Take A Pretax Charge GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 6 (Reuters) - The Pittston Company said it would take a fourth-quarter 1983 nonrecurring pretax charge of about $110 million as a result of plans for the closing, abandonment or sale of certain coal mining facilities and reserves. The after-tax effect is expected to be about $70 million.
description: The company said the move was necessary because of the unexpectedly severe deterioration in the coal market and the further phase-in of the company's continuing program to improve the efficiency of its coal operations.

title: SCOUTING
description: King for a Day

title: JOBLESS RATE IN U.S. FELL TO 8.1% IN DECEMBER AS ECONOMY GAINED
description: The nation's unemployment rate dropped last month to 8.1 percent from 8.3 percent in November, the Government reported today.

title: NBC AND ABC BATTLING CBS'S THURSDAY RATINGS
description: In the continuing war between the television networks for prime-time viewers, an intriguing thing is taking place Thursday nights.

title: German Factory Orders
description: West German manufacturing orders rose a seasonally and price-adjusted 2 percent in November from an upward- revised October result, the Economics Ministry said today.

title: RULING MAY BE HUGHES GO PUBLIC
description: Chancellor Grover C. Brown, Delaware's highest-ranking judge, said today that he would soon appoint a new board of trustees to lead the Howard Hughes Medical Institute because the institute's executive committee had not been empowered by the late billionaire, Howard R. Hughes, to act as trustee.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sitzberger Is Linked To Coast Cocaine Case
description: Ken Sitzberger, the 1964 Olympic gold medalist who died Monday after suffering what an autopsy report described as a traumatic head injury, was to have been a Federal witness in a major cocaine-trafficking case set for trial Feb. 14, according to court documents.

title: SALVADOR GUERRILLAS SAID TO FREE 162 SOLDIERS CAPTURED LAST WEEK
description: Guerrillas who overran an army base have released 162 of the soldiers they captured, according to religious workers and other residents of this village north of the installation.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Comings and Goings
description: John Ziegler and the late Art Ross were named winners of the Lester Patrick Award for their contributions to hockey in the United States. Ziegler has been the president of the National Hockey League since 1977 and Ross, who died in 1964 at the age of 78, was a player, a referee and the coach of the Boston Bruins.

title: MITEL CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,325,000. c-Net income.

title: Roy Meredith Is Dead at 70; Writer and Producer for TV
description: Roy Meredith, a writer and television producer, died of a heart attack Thursday at Victory Memorial Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 70 years old.

title: Hitachi Develops New Memory Chip
description: Hitachi Ltd. said it had developed the world's first computer memory chip capable of storing more than one million characters, or one megabit.

title: Two Teams Tied In Boblsled Trials
description: Brent Rushlaw and Jim Tyler, of Saranac Lake, N.Y., led from start to finish here today to win the second Olympic-trials race for two-man bobsleds.

title: China Becomes Member Of World Atom Agency
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency announced today that China had become a member of the 112-nation group.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 40.

title: HOW THE INSIGNIA STRATEGY BACKFIRED
description: For years, whenever the Defense Department needed a supply of sergeant's stripes or colonel's eagles or campaign ribbons, it turned to a tiny band of manufacturers that had made military insignia for more than a century.

title: Dresser-Terex
description: Dresser Industries declined to comment on reports within the United States construction machinery industry that it might soon submit a bid for the purchase of the bankrupt assets of the Terex Corporation, a subsidiary of IBH Holding A.G. of West Germany.
