title: STUDY DISPUTES LINK BETWEEN ATOMIC TESTS AND LEUKEMIA DEATHS
description: Three experts at the National Cancer Institute say evidence linking childhood leukemia deaths in southern Utah with fallout from atomic bomb tests in Nevada is ''slight or nonexistent.''

title: SOME LITTLE SOMETHING
description: Jesse Jackson's successful venture into Middle Eastern diplomacy had shaken the foundations of American politics. Before Jackson, Presidential campaigning had consisted of making a national tour of motels while emitting a wide variety of sounds. After Jackson, talk and automatic check- out service could no longer assure victory.

title: REAGAN SAYS WICK IS SECURE IN HIS JOB DESPITE PHONE TAPES
description: President Reagan today strongly supported Charles Z. Wick, the director of the United States Information Agency, who has acknowledged that he tape-recorded some of his telephone conversations without asking permission.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Broadway at Aqueduct

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Watching at the Green

title: From the Andes to SoHo
description: Grupo Aymara - which performs music of the Bolivian Andes on pipes, wooden flutes, charanga, guitar and drums - will give two concerts this weekend at the Alternative Museum (966-4444), 17 White Street in TriBeCa. The group will perform tonight at 8 and tomorrow at 6 P.M.; admission is $8 (Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted).

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch Wednesday from Northampton, Mass., on three arrests arising from the burning of a small Buddhist temple incorrectly reported the temple's origins. It was built in 1976 by followers of the teachings of Guru Rimpoche, a leader active in Tibet centuries ago.

title: ELEVATE THE TIMES SQUARE PEDESTRIAN
description: To the Editor:

title: PATENTS
description: Hunting Aid

title: PITTSBURGH BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $108,950 for the quarter and $719,200 for the year. c-Includes tax credit of $117,600.

title: BALLET: 'GOLDBERG VARIATIONS'
description: Jerome Robbins took on an awesome task when he set Bach's Goldberg Variations to dance. Never one to avoid a challenge, Mr. Robbins felt he wanted to work with bigger, more formally architectural music. He got it in the 30 variations of the Bach score - in the same key and played on a single instrument. Mr. Robbins's ''Goldberg Variations'' looked just as awesome Thursday, when the New York City Ballet danced it in the New York State Theater, as it did in its first performances in 1971.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Answers to questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 40.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Ruth Laredo in Newark
description: Ruth Laredo will be the soloist in Samuel Barber's Piano Concerto in two concerts this weekend with the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Sixten Ehrling. The concerts will include Berlioz's ''Corsaire'' Overture and Brahms's Symphony No. 2, and will take place tonight at 8 and tomorrow at 3 P.M. at Newark's Symphony Hall. Tickets are $9.50 to $16.50, and the box office numbers are (201) 624-8203 or (800) 631-3407.

title: Kennedy Escorts His Mother Home From Florida Hospital
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, recovering from a recent bout of hepatitis, today escorted his mother home from St. Mary's Hospital, where she was treated for a viral infection, hospital officials said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Then There Were 10
description: The Rutgers football schedule for 1984 includes Miami, the final No. 1-ranked team, and four other teams that competed in bowl games this past season. But if the opponents look tough, preparing for them has been even tougher, especially because the Scarlet Knights do not have a head coach.

title: SCOUTING
description: Lynn Considering Jump Back to Jets

title: WARSAW AND THE CHURCH EASE STRAIN
description: Roman Catholic Church sources said today that Jozef Cardinal Glemp had agreed to try to curb outspoken priests while expecting that the Government would free political prisoners and end political trials.

title: Dow Up 4.40, to 1,286.64; Trading Is Still Heavy
description: The stock market rally lost some of its vigor yesterday but trading continued to be heavy. Prices closed moderately higher.

title: WARD SAYS FORCE TOOK A 'BAD RAP' ON BRUTALITY
description: Benjamin Ward, New York City's new Police Commissioner, said yesterday that the city's police force had taken ''a bad rap'' on the issue of police brutality. He said that there was no ''pervasive'' brutality in the department and that neither Mayor Koch nor Mr. Ward's predecessor, Robert J. McGuire, had condoned brutality.

title: No Headline
description: THE SALT LINE. By Elizabeth Spencer.

title: NASA Scrubs Release On '86 Space Mission
description: Four scientists were told by NASA Thursday that they had been selected as trainees for a space shuttle mission, but the space agency called again today and took it all back. Maybe next week, the scientists were told.

title: QUESTIONS ABOUT THE PENALTY FOR FLOUTING CITY ZONING LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST BLACK CHIEF JUSTICE OF A STATE
description: Justice Robert N. C. Nix Jr. of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court was formally inaugurated today as Chief Justice of Pennsylvania in a ceremony marking his accession as the first black to head any state's highest court. As Chief Justice, Mr. Nix heads both the juridical and administrative sides of the state's judicial system, from the municipal level to the Supreme Court.

title: BRIEFS
description: Adams-Millis Corp., High Point, N.C., said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire privately held Silver Knit Industries, including its subsidiaries, for $25.3 million in cash and notes.

title: APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: BIG GIFT IN JAPAN: CALENDARS
description: From Japan's biggest corporations to the smallest retail shops, a bewildering array of calendars in all imaginable sizes and themes rains into the nation's offices and households at this time of year.

title: BALLET: KAROLE ARMITAGE
description: The unequivocal and incredible pounding sound that throbs through ''Paradise,'' a new dance work by the experimental choreographer Karole Armitage, is not your everyday music, even by current we-are-living- in-a-violent-time standards.

title: TOP LABORITE FAVORS RETURN OF ELGIN MARBLES
description: Greece's Minister of Culture, Melina Mercouri, said today that the British opposition leader, Neil Kinnock, had endorsed her effort to bring the Elgin Marbles back to Greece from the British Museum.

title: HELPING THE POOR AND LONELY INSPIRES GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: The motivation behind many contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is a desire to lift the spirits and give some material support to the poor and lonely during the holiday season.

title: MEDIFLEX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Comparable year-ago results are not available because the company was part of a subsidiary.

title: ABUSED TRUST
description: * To the Editor: Your Dec. 23 editorial ''Building Fudge Out of Fudging'' correctly pointed out that builders who flout New York City's building and zoning laws can suffer costly consequences. However, you undermined this appropriate warning with your suggestion that somehow the Department of Buildings shared responsibility for permitting the problem to arise.

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 7, 1984 International
description: Removal of most Israeli troops from Lebanon without a simultaneous pullback by Syria would be approved by the Israeli Government, the Israelis told the Reagan Administration. But, according to American officials, the Israelis stressed that they would not withdraw until security arrangements for northern Israel are guaranteed and there is political coordination with Lebanon. The stress on coordination, the Americans said, is to avoid the the problems that arose when the Israelis redeployed their troops from the Shuf mountains last September, setting off fighting between the Lebanese Army and Druse forces for control of the area. (Page 1, Column 6.) Moslem Druse objections delayed a new security plan that would separate Lebanon's warring factions, but Government officials said they were confident the dispute would be resolved. President Amin Gemayel canceled presentation of the plan at a meeting of diplomats. (1:4.)

title: SPIRIT AND DEPTH IN BIATHLON
description: Don Nielsen crossed the finish line of the 10-kilometer biathlon race at the United States Olympic trials today, spotted Lyle Nelson, the winner, and gave him an affectionate hug.

title: COURT PANEL BARS DICLOSURE OF DATA FILED IN MOBIL CASE
description: A Federal appeals court here ruled today, apparently for the first time, that corporations had ''constitutionally protected privacy interests'' that could negate the usual rule that documents filed in court cases are open to the public.

title: The Decline and Fall of Union Station
description: Our nation's capital has few monuments more expressive than Union Station. Built in 1907 to be the world's greatest train station, the once-grand edifice stands two blocks from Capitol Hill, where Congress's attentions have humbled it to a mildewed ruin. A colossal failure as a National Visitors Center, it is now to be turned back into a railroad station - but with a shopping complex thrown in.

title:
PATENTS ;
Solar-Powered Laser For Space Applications
description: A method has been devised to beam laser light, drawn from the sun, between spacecraft or to a point on the earth. Patent 4,424,592 was obtained this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration by Ja H. Lee of Vanderbilt University, Nashville; Willard R. Weaver of Langley Research Center, Hampton, Va., and the late Frank Hohl.

title: NEHEMIAH SITS AND WONDERS
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: OBJECTIONS BY DRUSE DELAY A PLAN TO SEPARATE FACTIONS IN LEBANON
description: A plan to separate Lebanon's warring factions was delayed today by Moslem Druse objections, but Government officials said they were confident the dispute could be resolved.

title: STUDY SAYS CITY'S PSYCHIATRIC SERVICE ARE IN CRISIS
description: A report today to Governor Cuomo concluded that psychiatric services are in a chronic state of crisis throughout New York City and are able to work with only the most sick, violent and suicidal patients.

title: BRIEFING
description: Return to Normandy

title: DEVILS END 7-GAME SKID, 3-1
description: The Devils ended a seven-game losing streak with a 3-1 victory tonight over the Pittsburgh Penguins, who had defeated the Devils in the three previous games between the teams with the poorest records in the National Hockey League.

title: OMEGA OPTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't think that Charles Wick is a dishonorable man in any way.'' - President Reagan. (1:1.)

title: Smoke Bombs Ignited, Forcing Evacuations
description: Someone ''playing a very deadly game'' detonated an Army surplus smoke bomb and a Vietnam era rocket, creating a dense, noxious cloud that drove 100 people from their homes, the authorities said today.

title: GLENN SAYS HIS RIVAL HAS 'SECRET PLANS'
description: Senator John Glenn, stepping up his attacks on former Vice President Walter F. Mondale in their race for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said today that Mr. Mondale had ''secret plans'' to address economic and environmental issues and challenged him to ''tell the voters where he stands.''

title: INTERNATIONAL TERRORISTS LINKED TO FRENCH BOMBINGS
description: A French Government spokesman said today that the international terrorist known as Carlos had sent a letter taking responsibility for two fatal New Year's Eve bombings in the south of France.

title:
PATENTS ;
New Patent Awards Seen Increasing in '84
description: The issuance rate of patents in recent weeks indicates that 1984 will be an active year for the patent and trademark office. A projection of the total in the fiscal year to end next Sept. 30 is 71,830, an increase of more than 12,000 over the year before.

title: La. Tech Goes to 10-0
description: Janice Lawrence, the all-America center, and Pam Gant scored 18 points apiece, and Debra Rodman grabbed 15 rebounds in leading unbeaten Louisiana Tech to a 73-57 victory tonight over Long Beach State.

title: THE READERS REPLY: FROM SCHOOL FOODS TO 'DUNCH'
description: No column in recent months has drawn as many positive responses as the one about the perils of ordering decaffeinated coffee in restaurants. And none drew as many negative responses as the one about the quality of food in the national school lunch program.

title: THEIR WIT'S END
description: This is the season when the sky is rent

title: No Headline
description: CORRECTIONS

title: Genscher Hurt in Accident
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher is recovering from injuries received in a car accident this week, a spokesman said today. Mr. Genscher, 56 years old, fractured his breastbone when his car skidded and overturned near Saarbr"ucken on Tuesday. He was treated briefly in a hospital before being flown to his home here.

title: WilliamstoReport To Prison Monday
description: Harrison A. Williams Jr. is scheduled to report Monday to the Federal prison at Danbury, Conn., to begin serving his sentence for his conviction in the Abscam case, his attorney said today.

title: TEXACO CHANGES CHARACTER
description: For more than a decade, Texaco Inc. has been known as the most conservative, slow-moving, and tightfisted of the nation's major oil companies.

title: OPERA: 'MAHAGONNY'
description: John Dexter's production of Kurt Weill's ''Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny,'' revived by the Metropolitan Opera Thursday night, was one of the representative hits of the ''new Met'' when first seen in late 1979.

title: PANEL SAID TO URGE SALVADOR TALKS AND U.S. CONTACTS IN NICARAGUA
description: A bipartisan Presidential commission was said today to be close to approving a report that urges stepped-up United States diplomatic contacts with Nicaragua and a major new effort to bring about talks between the Salvadoran Government and leftist guerrillas.

title: Letter: On Docudramas What 'Silkwood' Is - and Is Not
description: To the Editor:

title: BUDGET PLAN HINTS U.S. SPACE STATION
description: Preliminary 1985 Federal spending projections confirm that the Reagan Administration has apparently decided to build a permanent orbital space station where men and women would work months at a time.

title: Jersey Is Eager for Indy Race
description: The sport that made Indianapolis famous is coming to the New York metropolitan area this summer. The Meadowlands sports complex in East Rutherford, N.J., is spending $3 million to put on a 200-mile race with Indy cars on July 1, according to Loris Smith, general manager of the complex and the race director.

title: BRINGING THE VASTNESS OF THE SMITHSONIAN TO THE SMALL SCREEN
description: How long does it take a serious television series to go from an idea to an image on the picture tube? It took ''Smithsonian World,'' financed with one of the largest grants ever made to a public-television project, seven years.

title: Car Buying Myth
description: To the Editor:

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A SOLDIER'S FLAG HEALS OLD WOUNDS
description: THE return of the bodies of the American Marines killed in Lebanon set off for Jerry Baron memories of the days in 1944 when, as a 24-year-old Marine medic, he was involved in fighting the final battle for Saipan.

title: SEAHAWKS TRYING FOR 3 OF A KIND AGAINST RAIDERS
description: By the end of the weekend, when the Seahawks or the Raiders will plan for a trip to the Super Bowl and the other team will think of what might have been, the two midseason meetings of Seattle and Los Angeles will come into sharper focus.

title: Wadkins Reaches Semifinals in Golf
description: Lanny Wadkins defeated Ben Crenshaw on the first extra hole by the margin of a missed four-foot putt today and became the last semifinalist in the Seiko Tucson match-play golf tournament.

title: ALONG BROOKLYN'S FIFTH AVE., A TRANSITION
description: ACROSS the street from the green canopy

title: EVALUATING TEACHERS: HOW NOT TO
description: THERE were so many bad teachers in Nebraska in 1963 that then Gov. Warren G. Sorenson launched what was to become known facetiously among the pedagogues of the plains as the Grin and Merit Program, or ''GaM'' for short.

title: AN AWAKENING INDEPENDENCE
description: ''I REALLY wanted to have some kind of nest egg. I did not want to become a bag lady in my old age,'' said Lynne Jergenson Pashkoff, a vice president of Federated Department Stores' Ready-to-Wear division, as she sat in her comfortable high-rise apartment in Queens. Though spending her older years on the streets of New York seemed a remote possibility indeed, Mrs. Pashkoff was describing a kind of investment awakening that took place three years ago.

title:
ANTIQUES;
YEAR'S FIRST SHOW IS IN STRATFORD
description: THE year's first show of authentic American antiques and accessories will be held Jan. 20, 21 and 22 at the Stratford Armory. The January Antiques Show, directed by Betty Forbes, will include 49 exhibitors representing shops not only from Connecticut, but also from all the other New England states, New York and New Jersey.

title: FACADE LAW ACHIEVING ITS GOALS
description: AT the New York Stock Exchange, Yeshiva

title: McEnroe No. 1 for Year
description: In the closest finish since computer rankings began in tennis in 1973, John McEnroe edged out Ivan Lendl as the top-ranked player of 1983. In the final weekly rankings, McEnroe had 129.92 points and Lendl 129.60. Jimmy Connors was third with 106.67. . . . Martina Navratilova, who has been taking time off after winning 85 of 86 matches in 1983, has withdrawn from the Virginia Slims tournament in Houston that begins Jan. 30 and been replaced by Hana Mandlikova.

title: REAGAN HOPES FOR A BREAK IN TWO FOREIGN PREDICAMENTS
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT REAGAN'S talents for making the best of adversity were being tested last week. Like a man pulling rabbits out of his hat, he was trying to show a skeptical public and Congress that Administration policies in the Middle East and Central America were better than they looked.

title: MARGIOTTA TO BE FREED EARLY ON 'MITIGATING FACTOR'
description: Joseph M. Margiotta, the former Nassau County Republican leader in prison for arranging insurance kickbacks, is being granted early parole from his two-year sentence because of a ''mitigating factor'' in his case, according to the Federal Parole Commission.

title: 2 Councilmen Reject Pay Rise in Houston
description: Two members of the Houston City Council are rejecting an automatic $3,439 pay increase that took effect this week because 20,000 other city workers have not received a raise in two years.

title: A CHALLENGE FOR CARNEY?
description: SUFFOLK Republican leaders are privately skeptical about Republican Assemblyman John L. Behan's saber-rattling against Representative William Carney of Suffolk's First Congressional District, the only Conservative and only nonmajor party member of the House of Representatives.

title: AGAINST COMFORTANLE DOCTRNES
description: Donald Thomas is the author of ''Robert Browning: A Life Within Life'' and ''Mad Hatter Summer.'' THOMAS CARLYLE A Biography. By Fred Kaplan. Illustrated. 614 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $35.

title: Louise L. Stanton Marries in Jersey
description: Louise L. Stanton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Stanton Jr. of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter M. Shuchter, son of Lillian Maurice of Irvington, N.J., and Jerome P. Shuchter of Los Angeles. The bride's uncle, Judge R. Reginald Stanton of the New Jersey State Superior Court, performed the ceremony at her parents' home.

title: 17 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 17 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: USAir
description: To the Editor: I would like to report the excellent response I received from USAir concerning an improper bumping from one of their flights. Re

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Junior Walker and the All Stars are soul music perennials in the best sense. The rise and fall of pop music fashion, from rock-and-roll to soul to disco to funk, may affect their popularity for better or worse, and their albums and singles often drape them in whatever costuming is currently fashionable.

title: KNOX HAS NEW WAY TO WIN
description: IN bringing the Seattle Seahawks to

title: ABOUT MEN
description: DAD BY ANDREW H. MALCOLM Andrew H. Malcolm is chief of The New York Times Chicago bureau.

title: Texaco-Getty Merger Delayed Over Weekend
description: Texaco Inc. and the Getty Oil Company are tentatively prepared to close the largest merger in American history, but a judge is delaying the estimated $10 billion agreement so that heirs of the oilman J. Paul Getty can study it.

title: Nuptials for Miss Amaturo
description: Elizabeth Marie Amaturo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Amaturo of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married there yesterday to James Scott Eisenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Lee Eisenstein of New York. The Rev. Vincent Kelly and the Rev. Charles Mallen officiated at St. John the Baptist Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Eisenstein graduated from Georgetown University, as did her husband, who is in his last year at the University of Pennsylvania School of Law.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: DEEP inside every restaurant piano player I know on the Island there dwells a little devil, a jazz musician. The proprieties of playing soft music, to digest one's dinner by, for the most part keep the imp quiet, but there are moments the devil will out. The pianist, tinkling respectably through the interminable ''Memory'' or ''Evergreen,'' will toss in a flatted fifth or a brief, swingy riff.

title: IN SHORT
description: SEXUAL PRACTICES: The Story of Human Sexuality. By Edgar Gregersen. (Franklin Watts, $18.95.) If Terence had read ''Sexual Practices,'' he might have been less certain nothing human was alien to him.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a sentence in the review of ''Metropolitan Corridor'' by John R. Stilgoe (Dec. 18) read incorrectly. It should have read, ''By the 1880's, interregional rail systems had become, as the historian Alfred Chandler said, 'the nation's first big business,' introducing modern methods of finance, corporate management and consolidation.''

title: THE MEANING OF CELEBRITY
Church on East 118th Street Is Heavily Damaged by Blaze
description: A three-alarm fire heavily damaged an East Harlem church yesterday, sending smoke and flame through the roof, five stories up, authorities said.

title: GERANIUM SEEDING MAY CURE THE WINTER DOLDRUMS
description: Raymond S. Rusak, who gardens as a hobby, is a supervisor for a manufacturer.

title: Iran Says It Killed 230 In Drive Against Kurds
description: Iran said today that it killed 230 rebels and captured 30 villages in a weeklong offensive in Kurdistan on the Iraqi border.

title: Record Argentine Inflation
description: Inflation in Argentina, already the highest in the world, reached a record of 433.7 percent in 1983, the National Statistics Institute said today. The previous record was 347 percent in 1976.

title: Death of Soviet Envoy in U.S. Is Attributed to Asphyxiation
description: The Medical Examiner of the District of Columbia said today that a Soviet Embassy attache who was found dead on Friday died after ''a rope, belt, piece of cloth or something was placed around the neck to cause asphyxia.''

title: TEACHING OF WRITING GETS NEW PUSH
description: SO much attention has been lavished in recent decades on two of the three R's - reading and arithmetic - that the third, writing, has seemed all but forgotten in the nation's schools. But as evidence mounts that students at all levels in the educational cycle are doing very little writing and are deficient in the reasoning ability and critical-thinking skills that go hand-in-hand with good writing, the situation is beginning to change: the teaching of writing is assuming fresh prominence.

title: CONGRESS ACTIVE IN 1983 By States News Service
description: WASHINGTON NEW JERSEY'S 14 Representatives and two Senators were among the most active in Congress last year, introducing 348 new laws and resolutions.

title: HAYNES MAKES RAIDERS TOUGHER
description: NEARLY a year ago, at the end of the football season, the idea first occurred to Lester Hayes, cornerback for the Los Angeles Raiders and observer of the human condition, that he may have made a remarkable discovery.

title: BRUINS STOP RANGERS
description: Dave Maloney's words bordered on envy. Moments after watching his team's five-game unbeaten string end in a 5-2 loss to the Bruins today at Boston Garden, the Ranger defenseman sat back, exhausted, and praised the victors.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: PLANS are being made for the expansion of the Smith Haven Mall in Lake Grove, with the mall owners, in an effort to win local government approval for the proposal, agreeing to conduct a traffic impact survey.

title: ANTIQUES ; BUTTONS, BUTTONS WHO HAS BUTTONS?
description: ''There's not a subject that has escaped being a button,'' said Diana Epstein, co-owner with Millicent Safro of a shop called Tender Buttons (143 East 62d Street) that is a haunt of button collectors. (The shop's intriguing name was inspired by a slender little book of that title by Gertrude Stein who was inspired, in turn, not by buttons at all, but rather a sign in a French vegetable market accompanying a display of baby mushrooms marked ''tender buttons.'') Bearing out Miss Epstein's words, there is a dizzying array of buttons - nonedible - at the shop, with motifs ranging from the tiniest of insects to the heavenly firmament.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The Mauritshuis is one of those small European museums that is probably remembered with lasting affection by every visitor. Located in the heart of the Hague, this private 17th-century palace houses an extraordinary collection of 17th-century Dutch painting.

title: LARGE QUESTIONS IN SMALL PLACES
description: TAKE a boy who grew up in Blue Point, where he liked to fish for flounder and fluke. Let him become a teen-ager made aware of social distinctions by rapid transfers from the middle-class student body of Bayport High School to the social elite of Phillips Andover Academy to the working-class milieu of North Babylon High in the mid- 1960's. Add to that an affinity for Irish literature, and the result is an anthropologist named Lawrence J. Taylor, whose research so far has focused largely on those whose lives and communities center on harvesting the resources of the sea.

title: IONA FREE THROWS TOP FORDHAM, 59-52
description: Iona scored 13 of its final 15 points from the free-throw line and defeated Fordham, 59-52, today at the Mulcahy Campus Center.

title: V.A.T.
description: To the Editor:

title: LET'S PUT A CAP ON HATS IN THE RING
description: -campaign spending and financing practices must be reformed if we intend to preserve democracy in the United States against the rich and special-interest groups.

title: Hopeful Concern for the Salmon
description: CANADA'S commercial Atlantic salmon fishermen have, as expected, voiced strong opposition to a recent proposal by the Atlantic Salmon Federation for a five-year moratorium on the netting of the species while at the same time allowing sport fishing to continue.

title: Long Branch Program For Elderly Explained
description: In the Dec. 18 article about the Junior League, the Family and Children's Service of Long Branch was not properly identified. The Abused Elderly Program is ours, and we are partly financed by the Monmouth County Office on Aging.

title: 'GOING, GOING, GONE'
description: DOVER AUCTION enthusiasts maintain that almost anything can be bought at auction. A glimpse at history reveals that the statement is true.

title: BABY DOE: HARD CASE FOR PARENTS AND COURTS
description: LAST September, the parents of Baby Jane Doe put the finishing touches on a new room designed for their first baby. They never dreamed, they said, that their newborn would be so severely ill that in all likelihood she would never come home. Nor were they prepared for the fact that their daughter, born Oct. 11 in Suffolk County, would become the subject of an unusual Federal suit by the Justice Department that may yet be decided by the United States Supreme Court.

title: RECOVERING FROM THE ERA OF SHOCKS
description: THE two decades after World War II have been

title: Casualty at Yale
description: When 18-year-old Margaret Cimino entered the Yale Bowl with friends for the 100th Harvard-Yale football game on Nov. 19, she was a vibrant Harvard freshman, a member of the swimming team. Before the crowd had left the stadium, she was almost totally paralyzed.

title: OVERSEEING INSURANCE REFORM AT LONDON'S VENERABLE MART
description: -generation Lloyd's of London broker who took over as chairman of the famous insurance exchange last week, fretted a bit when invited to pose for a photograph with lanky Ian Hay Davison, Lloyd's chief executive.

title: New Yorker Stars On Michigan Ice
description: Western Michigan University's hockey team is in its second year of a building program under Coach Bill Wilkinson. The Broncos are trying to break a losing tradition that spans nine years without a playoff appearance, but Wilkinson is confident that he'll succeed largely because he has Dan Dorion, New York City's best college hockey player since the Mullen brothers.

title: David B. Vietor Weds Megan Williams
description: Megan Lewis Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Williams of Boston and Beverly Farms, Mass., was married yesterday to David Butler Vietor, son of Mrs. Alexander Orr Vietor of New York and Edgartown, Mass., and the late Mr. Vietor. The Rev. George Westerberg performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Marblehead, Mass.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: WHAT'S SINGULAR OF CATTLE?
description: Calvin Trillin is on the staff of The New Yorker and is the author of ''Uncivil Liberties'' and the forthcoming ''Killings.'' A WORD IN YOUR EAR By Philip Howard. 126 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $12.95.

title: NIGERIA'S DEMOCRACY FAILS A SURVIVAL TEST
description: During Nigeria's first civilian-run elections last summer, diplomats, professors and others frequently asserted that the success of the democratic experiment in Africa's most populous country was vital not only here but to the entire continent. If democracy failed in this most open and pluralistic of African societies, the analysts said, it probably stood little chance elsewhere.

title: Easements
description: To the Editor:

title: Oilers 5, Whalers 3
description: Wayne Gretzky scored three goals - ending with his 50th of the season - and extended his consecutive-points streak to 42 games in leading Edmonton to its 11th straight victory.

title: PRETORIA SAYS IT FOUGHT CUBANS
description: A significant widening of the fighting appears to have taken place in South Africa's four-week campaign in southern Angola.

title: UNBEATEN NORTH CAROLINA ROUTS N. CAROLINA STATE
description: He does not receive the publicity that Michael Jordan gets, or play with the flair of Kenny Smith, but if Coach Dean Smith has a favorite among his talented Tar Heels, he is Sam Perkins.

title: Getting Help For Alcoholics
description: It is gratifying to see the consciousness of the public raised in respect to the alarming incidence of injury and death due to driving while impaired (''Moving Against the Drunken Driver,'' Dec. 18).

title: PISTOL LIABILITY IS ISSUE AT TRIAL
description: David Clancy was a 15-year-old ninth-grade student in Amarillo, Tex., six years ago when a pistol being handled by a fellow student in a high school parking lot accidentally discharged. A single bullet severed Mr. Clancy's spine and left him a quadriplegic.

title: KNICKS CRUSH PACERS, 140-103
description: When Brook Steppe, the Indiana Pacers' guard, drove past Marvin Webster of the Knicks to hit a running, one-handed bank shot with 14 seconds left last night, the few remaining fans at Madison Square Garden groaned. Was the shot a game- winner? Hardly.

title: ONE WAY TO BUILD A GOOD FIRE IN THE FIREPLACE
description: FOR those homeowners who are fortunate enough to have a wood-burning fireplace, the arrival of cold weather should mean some pleasant evenings and lazy weekends of sitting in front of a crackling fire while basking in its warmth and staring dreamily at the flames. However, all too often this dream is shattered by frustration as difficulty is encountered with starting the fire and then keeping the wood burning - or when the hoped-for pleasant fire turns out to be either a roaring inferno or a stubbornly smoking stack of wood that just won't burn properly.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: The GovernorFires at Will

title: STATE MAKING PLANS FOR SURPLUS FUNDS
description: NEW JERSEY'S economic recovery is expected to create a surplus in the state's $6.8 billion budget when the 1983-84 fiscal year ends June 30, and legislators are already devising ways to spend it.

title: NEW LONDON NOTRES A BICENTENNIAL
description: NEW LONDON kicks off a yearlong bicentennial celebration of its incorporation at 1 P.M. today, when churches and chapels within city limits begin ringing their bells for five minutes to mark 200 years of ''freedom of the sea.''

title: PIONEERING IN THE EARLY DAYS OF A NEW MEDIUM
description: Dance and television grew up together, side by side, in both the United States and Britain after 1930. Perhaps there is something significant if not symbolic about the fact that the 1930's saw the infancy of a native theatrical dance tradition in both countries and television's own infancy. It was a decade in which ballet companies were founded and finally took root (securely enough to grow into the Royal Ballet, Ballet Rambert, the New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater, among others). It was in the 1930's that a new American art form - modern dance - made itself felt through its pioneering dancers and choreographers.

title: Record by Clinton Star
description: Seven meet records were set, and Stephen Edden of DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx posted a national indoor freshman mark for the 600-yard run today at the 15th annual Dartmouth Relays in the Leverone Fieldhouse.

title: GETTING PRESIDENTS MORE INVOLVED IN COLLEGE SPORTS
description: MANY problems in contemporary society cannot be resolved without structural change. Such problems are by their nature relatively immune to the efforts of individuals and institutions.

title: CORRECTION
description: In some copies of the Arts and Leisure section today, a picture caption on page 29 with an article about Philip Johnson misidentifies a building he designed. It is the RepublicBank Center in Houston.

title: SUSAN CAROL SEITZ, NURSE, TO MARRY PAUL P. MANOS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Douglas H. Seitz of River Vale, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Carol Seitz, to Paul P. Manos, son of Mrs. Arthur Carota and Philip Manos, both of Wilmington, Del.

title: 500 PROTEST PLANNED CLOSING OF POWER MEMORIAL ACADEMY
description: Nearly 500 parents, students, teachers and alumni gathered yesterday to protest the planned closing of Power Memorial Academy, the Roman Catholic boys high school that has become over the years a tradition among some families.

title: GROUP IN HOUSE STRESSES 3 ISSUES FOR DEMOCRATS
description: Deficits and Central America are stressed by eight Democratic Presidential aspirants. Page 26.

title: FRESHMAN ORIENTATION: NO LONGER A 3-DAY RUN
description: THE process is repeated many times on Thursdays and Fridays at Montclair State College: eight or nine freshmen find a quiet place in a dormitory lobby or student lounge on the Upper Montclair, N. J., campus, move some chairs into a tight circle and spend an hour or so talking about themselves and their new lives. A specially trained upperclassman guides the discussion.

title: TEVEVISION WEEK
description: Drunk driving has been responsible for the deaths of more than a quarter-of-a-million people in the last ten years, and kills more Americans between the ages of 16 and 24 than any other cause. These grim statistics tell only part of the story, however, for 90 per cent of all physical assaults, half of all homicides and a quarter of the suicides in the United States are related to alcohol.

title: THE SECRET TRAFFIC DEPARTMENT
description: IAM in sales and I travel around

title: A POPULAR WATERING PLACE
description: IF it hadn't been for an advertisement claiming that Peter Pastor's served ''American

title: Westminster Show Receives 2,647 Entries
description: The entry for the 108th annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, to be held in Madison Square Garden, Feb. 13-14, has closed with a total of 2,647 canines, representing 138 breeds or varieties.

title: Lisa H. Hooker, Executive, Wed
description: Lisa Hortense Hooker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Williamson Hooker of Nashville, was married there yesterday to John Palmer Campbell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Robert Campbell of New York. The Rev. Dr. William Bryant performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: PHILIP JOHNSON DESIGNS FOR A PLURALISTIC AGE
description: Several years ago, as it started to rain at an architects' picnic in Princeton, one of those present suggested that the group call Philip Johnson and ''ask him to have it stop raining.''

title: FOR SOME PROSPEROUS STATES, THE PARTY'S OVER
description: For three decades after World War II, growth of Federal grants mitigated the differences in the quality of public services among states, and among regions. Now that money and regulation from Washington are declining and the economy has become more erratic, some of the diversity that existed during most of the nation's history is returning.

title: PORTUGAL'S REVOLUTION HITS ROCKY TIMES
description: The news from the Hotel London was eye- catching and funny in a way. The hotel, in a resort area of Estoril that used to be called the playground of kings, announced it would charge guests according to their height. A night's lodging would cost three escudos a centimeter (or about 70 cents a foot), which is quite a bargain. Children under 12 years old would be charged 50 percent of what their mothers paid.

title: THE JOINT IS JUMPIN' AT THE CROSSROADS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK WITH six tables at ringside and two on a platform above stage level, all against an Art Deco design with Tiffany-type lampshades on high, the Crossroads Theater Company's production of ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' looks as intimate and inviting as the revue did during its modest Off-Broadway cabaret origins.

title: Dr. Grosso Is Wed to Richard Brown
description: At Grace Episcopal Church in Madison, N.J., yesterday, Seena Henschkel Grosso of Chatham Township, N.J., widow of Judge Marius Grosso, was married to Richard Lindley Brown by the Rev. Hayward Levy.

title: Why Jayhawk Quit
description: Kerry Boagni, the sophmore forward who quit the Kansas Jayhawks' basketball team after having been demoted from his starting position by Coach Larry Brown, said it was not the loss of his position but Brown's style of coaching that had prompted his decision. ''He's a great coach and a great person,'' said Boagni. ''But we just didn't mix as player and coach.''

title: MUSIC: MICHAEL SHAPIRO
description: While programs devoted entirely to the work of one young composer are fairly commonplace in downtown loft spaces, they are decidedly rare in New York's established concert halls. On Thursday night, however, a group of performers, including the pianist Jerome Rose, the sopranos Stephanie Cotsirilos and Florence Levitt, the bass Harris Poor, and members of the Odyssey Chamber Players joined the pianist and composer Michael Jeffrey Shapiro for a program of his music at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Cowboy Departing
description: Butch Johnson, unhappy as a backup wide receiver for the Dallas Cowboys, is now in accord with Coach Tom Landry.

title: WINTER ON L.I.: NOT LOVING IT BUT NOT LEAVING IT
description: WHEN we first moved to the Island from the city in December of 1957, a sudden thaw following a bad snowstorm had left the shoulders of the roads knee-deep in sticky mud. As luck would have it, we pulled off to the side of the road for one reason or another, and our heavily laden car promptly became stuck fast in the goo. It was an auspicious beginning.

title: DE KOONING'S MASTERY OF LINE
description: DRAWING is such a seminal activity for Willem de Kooning that to consider his drawings separately from his paintings seems somehow a travesty. Yet that is just what has been done in the artist's current 60- year retrospective exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art, and it works very well.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE VINGANANEE AND THE TREE TOAD A Liberian Tale. Retold by Verna Aardema. Illustrated by Ellen Weiss. Unpaged. New York: Frederick Warne & Co. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 8)

title: ART FROM A STONE
description: Jacob Kainen, a former curator of graphics at the National Museum of American Art, is a painter and printmaker. AMERICAN LITHOGRAPHERS 1900-1960 The Artists and Their Printers. By Clinton Adams. Illustrated. 228 pp. Albuquerque: The University of New Mexico Press. $65. LITHOGRAPHY 200 Years of Art, History & Technique. Edited by Domenico Porzio with Rosalba and Marcello Tabanelli. Translated by Geoffrey Culverwell. Illustrated. 280 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $49.50.

title: Nigeria Regime Stepping Up Search for Former Officials
description: Nigeria's new military Government is stepping up searches for former politicians and officials of the civilian Government that was overthrown in a coup a week ago.

title: Miss Koehler Is Betrothed
description: Pamela Lynne Koehler, confidential assistant to the United States Under Secretary of Energy, and Douglas Gregory Elmets, executive assistant to the director of White House communications, plan to be married in June.

title: LANGUAGE STUDY GETS A COMPUTER ACCENT
description: IN the Bronx, near Fordham Road, adolescents manipulate computer creatures of multicolored graphics in an arcade of videoscreens. It's a familiar sight in neighborhoods, but there is a difference between this video arcade and others. This is a language arcade - the adolescents are high school students learning classical Greek, Latin, French, and other modern languages on Atari computers at the Fordham Preparatory School.

title: DRAMAS FROM THE PAST THAT SPEAK TO THE PRESENT
description: The New York theater is not so lavishly endowed just now with alternating repertory companies or with American plays of classic or near-classic status that we can afford to ignore the appearance of either, let alone examples of each under the same roof. Mark you, the roof, stairs, seats, stage, in fact all the physical circumstances of Mirror Theater are almost ostentatiously modest, even by Off Off Broadway standards. Some spectators sit at such an oblique angle to the action they should really be provided with periscopes; and the off-stage clunks and bumps at a quiet climax of Susan Glaspell's ''Inheritors'' made me wonder if the company shouldn't also invest in one of those electric sound-suppressors you can buy at upscale hardware stores. A supposedly naturalistic set for the same play includes a sky-drop of stark, unvarying orange, suggesting that the Iowa climate is similar to the one astronomers tell us prevails on Venus. And space on the stage is so tight that, especially in Clifford Odets's ''Paradise Lost,'' you may sometimes be reminded of one of those student attempts to break the world record for cramming people into a Volkswagen. At one point a large motorcycle is added to the domestic crush, creating something perilously close to gridlock in the slightly expanded doll's house within whose paper-thin walls Odets's play appears to occur.

title: FLORIO WOULD CURB MILITARY'S DUMPING
description: REPRESENTATIVE JAMES J. FLORIO, Democrat of Pine Hill, said last week that he would ask the Senate to require military installations to conduct inventories and investigations of all hazardous waste dumped on the bases in the last 30 years or more.

title: Jack Adnerson DANCE
description: Ruby Shang likes to choreograph dances for specific outdoor sites. Just last season she staged a dance in the upstairs windows of a building on Seventh Avenue and placed her audience on the streetcorner opposite it.

title: CEDAR RAPIDS DEBATING POLITICS AND THE ECONOMY
description: New Year's is behind them and the Iowa political caucuses are just six weeks away, so the Republicans and the Democrats are looking back over three years of Ronald Reagan's Presidency and debating the economic and political signs of the times.

title: SECOND-GENERATION SPOOK
description: David Quammen's latest novel is ''The Zolta Configuration.'' BERLIN GAME By Len Deighton. 345 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: WHAT IS A TRUE RECORDING?
description: Questions are raised from time to time about what might be called the morals of the microphone. A coterie of radical critics complain - mostly in arcane journals - that modern recording methods are dishonest and violate the ethics of music.

title: THE HEALTHY WAY
description: hat better wrap for winter's chill than thoughts of warmer weather ahead? And with those thoughts - of bathing suits and beaches - come more serious concerns - of health and fitness.

title: Filth on 89th St.
description: To the Editor:

title: NIGERIAN MERCHANTS WELCOME COUP
description: The merchants of the Oke-Arin market, one of the best places to shop for most anything here, are a varied lot. They include members of all the country's major ethnic groups. There are old men in traditional dress, teen-aged boys in U.C.L.A. T-shirts, and nursing mothers. There are some who speak fluent English with a lilting accent and others who know only the language of their own tribe or region.

title: CAUTION: BIG WORDS MAY BE HAZARDOUS TO YOUR HEALTH
description: IWANT to be a writer. Outside of

title: REAGAN ASKS DRIVE ON UNRULY PUPILS
description: President Reagan, opening a new Administration campaign against ''unruly behavior'' in schools, announced today that the Justice Department would file court briefs to help expand the rights of teachers and administrators to enforce school discipline.

title: Pamela A. Page To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Pamela A. Page to Dr. Raul A. Lopez has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Gerald D. Page of Westport, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Raul E. Lopez of Kensington, Conn.

title: SOVIET SEEMS TO FAULT PILOT WHO DOWNED JET
description: A Soviet Air Force magazine published an article today that was implicitly critical of the fighter pilot who shot down a South Korean airliner four months ago.

title: CAUTIONS FOR THE ADULT COLLEGE-PICKER
description: ''IWAS in the wrong place,'' said Yvonne Stahr, a 31- year-old New Yorker of her first college experience directly after high school. ''The college I chose was too business-oriented. I'm a humanities person.''

title: SOVIET SAYS ORWELL VISION IS A REALITY IN U.S.
description: A Soviet political journal claims in its current issue to have pinpointed the real-life version of George Orwell's novel ''Nineteen Eighty-Four'' - in the United States, under a ''Big Brother'' named Ronald Reagan.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS January 8, 1984Fiction 1
description: CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) A car that kills is at large among a Pennyslvania town's high school set.

title: FILM: SOVIET 'NOSTALGHIA' SET IN ITALY
description: ''Nostalghia'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review that appeared in The New York Times Oct. 5. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza Quad, Broadway between 62d and 63d Streets.

title: PUPILS DISCOVERING ART, AND THEMSELVES
description: Danziger brought her art students an old, broken bicycle that she had found on the street, the students did not want anything to do with it. But as soon as she showed them that parts of it could be transformed into musical instruments, they took to it ''like bees to honey,'' she said.

title: Gossage Joins 'Happy Family'
description: The San Diego Padres acknowledged yesterday that they had wooed and won Rich Gossage with more than money. During three weeks of heavy pursuit, they surrounded the 32-year-old pitcher with the one thing he apparently did not get from the Yankees: a happy family.

title: Education in Texas
description: In Robert Reinhold's article ''The Education of the University of Texas'' (Dec. 4), it was brought out that the university's munificent endowment derives largely from the state's oil wealth. Robert Reinhold writes, ''During the 1800's the Legislature gave two million acres of almost worthless West Texas land to the university.

title: COMMISSION INTENDS TO REASSESS RIGHTS
description: When new members of the United States Commission on Civil Rights say they will be ''independent,'' the word has a special meaning.

title: SCHOOLS PUT CREATIVE WRITERS TO WORK
description: -TV television special broadcast locally in New York City, ''We Don't Act Our Age,'' won a recent Emmy Award for its presentation of poetry, songs, a play, monologues and writings on the process of aging. More remarkable than the program itself was the fact that it was written by a group of fifth- and sixth- grade students at Public School 75 in Manhattan - an ordinary group of youngsters, according to their teachers, but lucky enough to be working with Alan Ziegler, a professional writer.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Ups and DownsIn Salvador

title: THE UNMAKING OF AN EDITOR
description: R. W. Apple Jr. is the London bureau chief of The New York Times. GOOD TIMES, BAD TIMES By Harold Evans. Illustrated. 430 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95.

title: K. B. Noble Weds Lorna McFarland
description: Lorna McFarland, a member of the class of '84 at the University of California at San Francisco School of Medicine, and Kenneth B. Noble, a reporter in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times, were married in Washington yesterday. The Rev. Henry C. Gregory 3d, pastor of the Shiloh Baptist Church in Washington, performed the ceremony at a private home.

title:
GARDENING;
NEW FASHIONS AND SPRING CATALOGUES
description: -order seed and nursery companies manage to have their catalogues arrive at just the right time to gain the greatest psychological advantage for their products? It never seems to fail that, when one shovels one's way to the mailbox through the season's first snowdrifts, the mail will contain one or more catalogues with eye-catching photos of lush gardens filled with masses of beautiful flowers and mouthwatering vegetables.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Doug Padilla, the American indoor recordholder who has won the 5,000 meters at the Wanamaker-Millrose Games for two years in a row, will try to win the event a third time Jan. 27 against a field that includes Henry?Marsh, Geoff Smith and Filbert Bayi . . . . Frank A. Polozola, a Federal judge in Baton Rouge, La., has rejected a plea by Billy Cannon for a reduction of his five-year sentence for counterfeiting. Judge Polozola said that reducing the sentence for the 1959 Heisman Trophy winner ''would only encourage a belief that people with fame and fortune receive preferential treatment.''

title: Margaret Workman Plans To Wed Edward Gardner
description: Margaret Lee Workman, a circuit judge for the 13th Judicial Circuit of West Virginia, and Edward Tytus Gardner 3d, president of the Cambridge Research Group and Jefferson Software in Charleston, W. Va., plan to be married Feb. 11.

title: Data Bank; January 8, 1984
LEBANESE REPORT ISRAELI TANK FIRE
description: Witnesses said that Israeli tanks and armored vehicles raked a main street in the Lebanese port city of Sidon with machine-gun fire three times today, wounding three people. Israel denied the report, saying that the only shooting had been by an army patrol.

title: 'MEDEA' AS A COOPERATIVE VENTURE
description: THE first time the Classic Repertory Theater of Long Island took its production of ''Medea'' out on the local Sunday afternoon library circuit, there were heavy rains; the second performance was offered on the final Sunday before Christmas. On both occasions the audiences were sparse.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Medical DataNeed Protection

title: Headliners; Timerman's Return
description: The recently elected Argentine government has moved to prosecute former members of the country's ruling junta, and Jacobo Timerman is going back to get in his licks. Mr. Timerman, the publisher and author who was forced into exile by the generals in 1979 after they imprisoned him for 30 months and seized his newspaper, said last week he planned to return to Buenos Aires ''to reclaim my property and sue those who tortured me.'' In exile, Mr. Timerman became an Israeli citizen and recounted his Argentine experience in the book, ''Prisoner Without a Name, Cell Without a Number.'' The junta never proved its charge that he was linked with leftist guerrillas.

title: SCHOOL TO BE SOUNDPROOFED FOR JET NOISE
description: THE Lawrence School District has been granted $450,000 to soundproof its early childhood center at the No. 4 school against jet noise.
