title: Miss Mooney Is Bride Of David Keville Pryor
description: Katherine Veronica Mooney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Mooney of Floral Park, Queens, was married yesterday to David Keville Pryor, son of Ellen Ach Pryor of Forest Hills, Queens, and Hubert C. Pryor of Long Beach, Calif. The Rev. Charles K. Quinn performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: COMEDIANS FORMING AN ASSOCIATION
description: Never have so many comedians been so serious.

title: SHOWS TO WARM THE WINTER SCENE
description: TWO shows that are warming the January scene are an exhibition of artists' books at the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery in the Rockland County community of Sparkill, N. Y., and an installation of large kimonos and small collages by Christine Martens at the Newark Museum.

title: ; THE MEANING OF CELEBRITY
description: The Meaning of Celebrity

title: MEXICO'S REVERENCE FOR THE PAST
description: Mexico does not just nod to its past; it bows to it. And Mexico City - once Tenochtitlan, capital of the Aztec empire - has more of a past to bow to than most cities. While officials elsewhere decide whether to tear down historic buildings to make way for new ones, Mexico City's planners must sometimes decide whether to tear down old buildings to uncover still older ones.

title: PLAYBOY SHOW A TRIBUTE TO CARTOONISTS
description: IT used to be that intellectuals

title: 80'S GRADUATE: COMING OF AGE IN BRAVE NEW (COMPUTER) WORLD
description: BY the time I graduated from college in the spring, I realized that if ''The Graduate'' were to be remade for the 1980's, at least one script change would be required: the key word to occupational success, solemnly delivered to a bewildered Dustin Hoffman, would not be ''plastics,'' but ''computers.''

title: ASTRNOMICAL HIGHLIGHTS OF 1983--A STELLAR YEAR
description: Earth's rotation is erratic, usually slowing, rarely speeding up. As a result, scientists must insert ''leap seconds'' every few years to keep world clocks in step. An extra second was added last year on June 30. The minute beginning at 7:59 EDT that evening was 61 seconds long. It was the 12th such second to be added since these kinds of adjustments began in 1972, when two leap seconds were added to the year. The variability in the rate of Earth's rotation is believed to be caused by a number of factors, including friction in the planet's atmosphere, in the oceans and in the core.

title: HOW TO SAIL THROUGH COLLEGE COURSES
description: ATHENS ONE of the world's most unusual learning experiences, combining university lectures with the broadening aspects of travel, steamed into Athens last month for a scheduled stop, affording a view of perhaps the world's only floating campus in operation today. The ''campus,'' known to the world's harbormasters as the S.S. Universe, has established itself in its three years of operation as a highly sought-after if expensive change of pace on a student's way up the undergraduate ladder.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT HAWKS, 5-3
description: The Islanders ended their two-game slump with a 5-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, but for Ken Morrow there were multiple pleasures.

title: CHESS ; THE KEY TO DEFENSE IS KEEPING ONE'S COOL
description: If you can keep your head while a

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: BEN JONES is a Jersey City visual artist whose career has spilled over into another artistic area: the dance. He was recently named board chairman of the Sulaimaan Dance Company, a Newark-based African dance group.

title: DR. ALFRED KASTLER, 81, NOBEL PRIZE-WINNER, DIES
description: Alfred Kastler, whose Nobel prize- winning research helped set the stage for invention of the laser, died yesterday at Bandol, on the French Riviera, at the age of 81, according to an announcement by his family. The family did not specify the cause of death.

title: Nuclear Regulations: Some Expectations
description: I would like to comment on the article ''Hearings Recall Indian Point'' by Matthew Wald (Dec. 18). As a participant in the Indian Point safety hearings, I was both gratified and saddened to read the comparison of two similar proceedings. Both Indian Point and Shoreham are placed in densely populated areas (which include New York City) and neither has roads that can keep daily commuter traffic moving at a reasonable rate, let alone hundreds of thousands fleeing radiation exposure.

title: Mayor of St. Louis Sues 2 Papers for $200 Million
description: Mayor Vincent Schoemehl has filed a $200 million lawsuit against the owners of The St. Louis Globe-Democrat and The St. Louis Post-Dispatch charging that they conspired to put The Globe- Democrat out of business.

title: WAS THIS UNHERALDED AMATEUR NEW YORK'S ATGET?
description: Wouldn't it be wonderful to discover, amid the mildewing millions of pictures from the past, an American Atget - an as-yet- unheralded photographer, that is, who could claim to have documented our premier native city, New York, with the same zeal and purpose with which Eug ene Atget recorded Paris at the beginning of this century? Wonderful, yes, but also highly unlikely. Yet, beneath our jaded eyes there has appeared a photographer who can be considered a contender for just such a title: Robert L. Bracklow, a turn- of-the-century amateur whose love of New York City is very much in evidence in a 160-print exhibition of his work now at the New-York Historical Society (170 Central Park West, at 77th Street).

title: FERTILE TIME FOR CREATIVE WRITING: MORE COLLEGE COURSES EVERY YEAR
description: ON a bright, cold day recently at the Johns Hopkins University campus in Baltimore, the novelist John Barth - a tall man with a bald head, a blue beret and a vocabulary the size of The Oxford English Dictionary - steered his graduate class in creative writing through what he perceived to be a ''rather supportive'' literary post-mortem of a student's short story, while the author hugged her sides. His blue-jeaned students, a baker's dozen sporting thermal undershirts, wool hats or neorevisionist Farrah Fawcett hairdos, chewed over details in the piece. Is the character of the photographer using his equipment correctly? Do the leaves on a sugar maple really turn these colors? Are the two main characters sleeping together or just flirting?

title: WINTER IN L.I.: NOT LOVING IT BUT NOT LEAVING IT
description: AT least once a week, sometimes twice a day, my husband raises his voice, slams his fist on something and announces - as if he had just thought of it - ''We've got to get off Long Island!''

title: 6 WRITERS WIN AWARDS FROM G.E. FOUNDATION
description: Six writers whose poems, essays and fiction have appeared in small literary publications will receive the first General Electric Foundation awards of $5,000 each. The magazines where their work was printed in 1983 will be given an additional $1,000, the Coordinating Council of Literary Magazines said.

title: THE NATION
description: NEWARK COUNCIL ADOPTS CURFEW

title: COLLEGES ALL OVER THE COUNTRY TURNING TO REMEDIAL ENGLISH
description: JOAN BAUM was reviewing the semester's work before giving her class its final exam - a 350-word essay, about five paragraphs: She talked of how an essay should start with an opinion, not a statement of fact. Fact, she said, left no room for development. She gave an example of a poor beginning: ''I come from a family with nine children.''

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: FORT LEE
description: LIKE the spires of some titanic steel

title: SHORTCOMINGS OF A 'COMMAND' ECONOMY
description: AS Soviet party leader Yuri V. Andropov struggles to improve a

title: HOUSE DEMOCRAT ASKS A PULLOUT
description: Representative Robert T. Matsui, chosen by the House leadership to give the weekly Democratic radio address, called today for the immediate withdrawal of United States troops from Lebanon, saying President Reagan's ''ill conceived'' policies had ''turned deadly.''

title: GIRL IN CALIFORNIA HELD IN CONTEMPT
description: In a court case that has attracted national attention, a 12-year-old girl, held in isolation in the Solano County Juvenile Hall here since Dec. 30, was released to a foster care home tonight on a writ of habeas corpus.

title: MUSEUM AT STORRS STILL GROWING
description: DESPITE not having a building of its own and suffering from low membership, the Connecticut Museum of Natural History, at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, continues to add to its collections as it reaches the second anniversary of its founding this month.

title: FICTION THAT'S GLOSSIER
description: Frederick Busch's novels include ''Take This Man'' and the forthcoming ''Invisible Mending.''

title: BALLET AND COMEDY ON NEW CASSETTS
description: No Time for Sergeants and Patterns ''Sergeants'': Starring Andy Griffith. Written by Ira Levin, based on a novel by Mac Hyman.

title: DOWN-TO-EARTH PASSIONS
description: Wendy Lesser is the editor of The Threepenny Review. PLACES IN THE WORLD A WOMAN COULD WALK By Janet Kauffman. 132 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: HUMAN EMBRYO TRANSPLANTS
description: Harris Brotman is a Chicago-based writer with a doctorate in genetics. By Harris Brotman

title: IN SHORT
description: AMERICA II. By Richard Louv. (Jeremy P. Tarcher, $15.95.) Richard Louv examines the new national ethos he sees emerging as more and more Americans question assumptions and values that have been dominant in the United States for much of this century.

title: 8 DEMOCRATIC RIVALS EMPHASIZE DEFICITS AND CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Although they differ on many questions, the eight major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination appear to be moving toward a consensus that Federal budget deficits and the United States involvement in Central America are the political issues on which President Reagan is most vulnerable.

title: Court in Idaho Rejects '82 Redistricting Plan
description: The Idaho Supreme Court has struck down the state's 1982 redistricting plan, but the court has given lawmakers another chance to come up with a plan for the State Legislature that meets state and Federal requirements.

title: Ellen Kessner and F. M. Shortz to Marry in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kessner of White Plains and East Falmouth, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Barbara Kessner, to Frederick Michael Shortz, son of Mrs. Robert Edwin Shortz of Dallas, Pa., and the late Mr. Shortz. A May wedding is planned.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: YOLANDA KING TO SPEAK

title: CITY BAR 'ROASTS' 2 LAWYERS, SHEA & GOULD
description: The City Bar Association's Annual Twelfth Night program is generally a festive occasion, a chance for lawyers to let down their guard and have a good time. The affair this year, held Friday night, tried something more.

title: ON TELLING THE REAL KAREN SILKWOOD'S STORY
description: To the Editor:

title: IT'S COMBAT, BUT IT'S ONLY A GAME
description: IN a scrubby wood of paint-besplattered trees in Coram, adult

title: YOUNG LEADS WEST IN THE HULA BOWL
description: Steve Young of Brigham Young passed for one touchdown and ran for another to lead the West to a 21-16 victory over the East in the annual Hula Bowl game today.

title: THE ACCENT IS PARTICULARLY FRENCH
description: AT Peche Mignon, a small and very particular restaurant in Huntington, dishes from the classic French repertory are lightened in nouvelle cuisine style. At the same time, some emphasis is placed on the ingredients, especially when they have been obtained from local suppliers and are of high quality.

title: THAYER RESIGNS TO FIGHT S.E.C. SUIT
description: Paul Thayer, Deputy Secretary of Defense, resigned his post one day before the S.E.C. filed an insider trading suit against him and eight other defendants. The former chairman of the LTV Corporation was charged with disclosing inside information about profits, dividends and takeover attempts by LTV, the Allied Corporation and Anheuser-Busch to two of the defendants - a woman with whom he had a ''private, personal relationship'' and a broker with the Dallas office of A.G. Edwards & Sons. The S.E.C. charged that the two in turn passed the information on to the other defendants. In all, the group is charged with making some $1.9 million in stock trading profits. However, the suit did not charge Mr. Thayer with any monetary gain from the stock tips. Mr. Thayer called the charges ''entirely without merit,'' but said he had decided to resign so that he could devote all his time to his defense and could save the Reagan Administration political embarassment.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: New & Noteworthy THE YOUNGEST SCIENCE: Notes of a Medicine- Watcher, by Lewis Thomas. (Bantam, $6.95.) Calmly, informatively and eloquently, the author of ''The Lives of a Cell'' and ''The Medusa and the Snail'' affirms ''the passion, joy, honor and dignity of the healing profession'' in this memoir, Willard Gaylin said in his review. ''Dr. Thomas's implicit thesis is that despite its dramatic change from a diagnostic to a therapeutic occupation, the medical profession remains an ideal enterprise for the questing and concerned.'' UNKNOWN MAN N89, by Elmore Leonard. (Avon, $2.95.) Jack Ryan, formerly a drifter and now a process- server, gets involved with a young lady who's about to be fleeced by an oily and dangerous crook in Elmore Leonard's 1977 novel. ''The plotting is remarkably ingenious,'' Newgate Callendar said, noting that Mr. Leonard has a wonderful ear . . . avoids artiness, writes clear expository prose and has the ability to create real people,'' including ''some of the most vicious, slimy villains that ever horrified a spellbound reader.''

title: BOOK BY ORWELL IS A SELLOUT
description: AYOUNG man in a bookstore in West Hartford was interested in buying a copy of George Orwell's ''Nineteen Eighty-Four.'' But he was told last week that the store, B. Dalton Bookseller, had sold every copy it had of the book.

title: Miss Boles Plans To Marry June 30
description: Dr. and Mrs. Russell Sage Boles Jr. of Osterville, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Borden Boles, to Thomas Patrick Fitzgerald, son of the late Maurice Francis Fitzgerald of Shelton, Conn. and the late Nancy Fitzgerald Smith of Detroit.

title: FOLLOW-UP: THE LITTLE INVESTOR
description: Though big institutions still account for most of the volume in the stock market, the ''little guy'' - excited by the bull market and emboldend to take more risk through tax- sheltered Individual Retirement Accounts that mitigate tax bites - has flocked back to equities. And that ''little guy,'' more likely than not, is a woman.

title: THE WIDOW: A SOCIAL OUTCAST
description: IWOULD like to raise my voice

title: JEWISH LIFE ON THE UPSWING IN HOBOKEN
description: HOBOKEN THREE years ago, the congregation of this city's last remaining synagogue comprised only about 40 families, and no more than a handful of the members were under 50 years old.

title: PATRICIA GROGAN IS TO WED JOSEPH CONWAY IN SUMMER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Grogan of Garden City, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Grogan, to Joseph Conway, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Conway of Bethpage, L.I. A summer wedding is planned.

title: DESIGNER OF POTTERY MOVES TO INTERIORS
description: PAMELA HOCHSTETTER, a firm believer in the merits of persistance and hard work, seems a bit surprised nonetheless by the success that has followed her efforts to carve a small niche for herself in art and design.

title: Miss Mayer, C. H. Finnie Plan to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Walter Brem Mayer Jr. of Atlanta and Highlands, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Penelope Walker Mayer, to Charles Holt Finnie, son of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Finnie of New Canaan, Conn.

title: MANAGING A BUILDING IN-HOUSE
description: SMALLER cooperatives around New

title: LOADING THE NO-LOAD MUTUAL FUNDS
description: PURCHASERS of some mutual funds are finding that less of the money they put up is being invested for their benefit and more is being used to defray the funds' own marketing costs. Taking advantage of the big run-up in the stock market last year, many of the hottest funds have instituted a variety of new charges.

title: RECITAL: EDWARD HAUSMAN
description: The largest work on Edward Hausman's Friday evening concert of piano music at Carnegie Recital Hall was Serge Prokofiev's mammoth Sonata No. 6 in A (Op. 82). Mr. Hausman convincingly captured the sonata's panoramic sweep - its mixture of the harsh and the lyrical, the graceful and sardonic. Mr. Hausman is a sober pianist, and some of Prokofiev's grimacing humor eluded him; in addition, he does not have the crystalline technique required for a truly monumental performance. But his comprehension of the music was not to be doubted.

title: THE BATTLE FOR SURVIVAL AT WARNER
description: THE saga of Warner Communications and its flamboyant chairman,

title: L.I.U.'S SPECIAL WAY WITH THE DISABLED
description: -year-old junior at Long Island University's Brooklyn Center, plays a strong game of table tennis, enjoys swimming and bowling, and has a green belt in Shotakan karate techniques. Eventually he wants to work as a physical-education instructor, specifically as an instructor of the physically and mentally handicapped. The fact that he is physically disabled has not deterred him from his goal.

title: THE NATION
description: Taped TalkersInclude a HighReagan AideCharles Z. Wick's catch of Washington voices appears to have included that of at least one major White House figure - James A. Baker 3d, the chief of staff.

title: AMERICA'S NEW BONUS BABIES: TEACHERS
description: -grade teacher in one of this city's rougher neighborhoods. Barbed wire- topped fences stretch across the yard in front of his school and across the street, vagrants regularly congregate around a run-down liquor store.

title: U.S. Gives $33 Million For African Food Relief
description: The Agency for International Development has announced the approval of $32.7 million in food aid to seven African countries to combat malnutrition and starvation resulting from drought.

title: DEFECTIONS FEARED AS RAIL FARE RISES
description: -North began paying the new higher fares last week and, judging by their comments, were not liking it one bit.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE State Capitol's lavishly decorated indoor Christmas tree has been a tradition for just three years, but its popularity was proven this season, when the 25-foot artificial tree failed to be set up on schedule in the Capitol's Hall of Flags.

title: NEW YORK'S HIGHWAY PATROL MAY SOON BE SHIFTING GEARS
description: Motorists on the alert for New York State troopers patrolling the highways may spot fewer of them, because the state police are after bigger fish. Under a new superintendent and a mandate from Governor Cuomo, reiterated last week in his State of the State Message, troopers have begun spending less time at speed traps and more on snaring criminals.

title: GROUP SAYS U.N. NUCLEAR ARSENAL WILL EXPAND TO 29,000 WARHEADS
description: A new, private study of the United States nuclear arsenal estimates that the present stockpile of 26,000 warheads will grow to 29,000 by 1990, with most of the current warheads being replaced by new ones.

title: DOODY ASSAYS SUPERVISOR JOB AS A DEMOCRAT IN EASTCHESTER
description: DURING the 1970's, James T. Doody recalled, he was a young lawyer with Mudge, Rose, Guthrie, Alexander & Ferdon, the Manhattan law firm that once had Richard M. Nixon as a partner. He remembered that the ''standing joke was you didn't have to be Republican to work there.''

title: The President in the Classroom
description: President Reagan wants to restore ''good, old- fashioned discipline'' in the nation's schools. Fine: It's an important issue and it's good to hear the President sound an alarm. But in the process, Mr. Reagan distorts his education priorities and wrongly inflates what should be a matter of quintessential local concern. What is the man who wants to get national government off local backs doing with the ruler in his hand?

title: CUOMO AND THE GARDEN'S OWNERS DISCUSS ALTERNATIVE USES FOR SITE
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he had met several times with officials of Madison Square Garden and the Gulf & Western Corp., the Garden's owners, to discuss a suggestion by the company that its two sports teams, the Knicks and the Rangers, move elsewhere so the Garden property could be used more profitably.

title: LONG ON CONFIDENCE
description: FELIX FLORES has one overriding principle about stock market investing - go short-term. It's hard to argue with him, because such a strategy paid off handsomely last year. The business manager for KMGG- FM, a Los Angeles radio station, he turned a $3,000 investment into $6,000 between March and June. It was the first time the 27-year-old Mr. Flores ever bought stocks and thus he fits into the New York Stock Exchange's category of new young investors who have entered the market recently with modest portfolios.

title: THE REGION
description: Facing the MusicIn Central Park

title: Q&A Notifying Tenants Question:
description: As treasurer of a tenants' group in a rental building, I am obliged to send dues notices and other related information to building tenants. Is the building manager under any obligation to supply a list of tenants to our group? . . . D. P. R., Manhattan

title: SHOULD SINGERS CALL THE TUNE AT THE OPERA?
description: On Jan. 14, 1879, in Chicago, a visiting company of internationally renowned singers gave an extraordinary all-star performance of Mozart's ''Le Nozze di Figaro.'' Extraordinary, because one of the stars, Minnie Hauk, declined to put in an appearance as Cherubino until midway through the second act, by which time a good half of the pageboy's contributions to music and story had passed by.

title: PHILADELPHIA TRANSIT SYSTEM REAWAKENS FROM DARK DAYS
description: Four years ago smoking buses and half-century old subway cars were a way of life on the nation's fourth-largest public transit system, causing riders to flee and officials to lie awake at night.

title: CABLE'S SHOWTIME BUYS FILM PACKAGE
description: Two developments within the past couple of weeks could dramatically alter what millions of Americans pay to see on cable television. Showtime and The Movie Channel, the jointly owned national pay TV services, have taken two giant strides in an effort to catch up with Home Box Office and its premium adjunct Cinemax, the country's most prominent - and popular - pay TV services.

title: TANDOORI ARTISTRY IN DELHI
description: Perhaps the only good thing that can be said for the bloody struggle that followed the partition of Pakistan and India in 1947 is that it forced the great tandoori cooks, who were Hindus, to flee from places like Peshawar, near the Afghanistan border, where they were throwing away their tikkas and kebabs on British air force officers, to the Indian capital of Delhi, where they set the food- loving world on its ear.

title: Work and Pleasure
description: To the Editor:

title: AGGRESSIVE STOCK TRADING IN AN I.R.A.
description: CYNTHIA ANAIPAKOS made a career switch three years ago, from jewelry design to paralegal work in trusts and estates at the Wall Street law firm of Reynolds, Richards, LaVenture, Hadley & Davis. Around the same time, her sister became a retail broker at Shearson/American Express. Thus, it was only a matter of time before Mrs. Anaipakos began to test the investing waters herself.

title: POLAND
description: To the Editor:

title: Rozier Says Money Is Key to His Signing
description: Mike Rozier, the Nebraska tailback and Heisman Trophy winner, denied published reports that he is close to an agreement with the Pittsburgh Maulers and said today that if the United States Football League expansion team had ''the right kind of money,'' he might not wait for the National Football League draft next spring.

title: MIAMI BEACH WEIGHS NEED FOR CITY KOSHER FOOD INSPECTOR
description: This resort and retirement enclave, where Jews make up half the city's population, is astir over the fate of a city job whose holder must assure that kosher foods sold here are indeed kosher.

title: NINE MILE 2 ADDS STRAIN TO LILCO'S PROBLEMS
description: SCRIBA, N.Y.

title: BROTHERS AND SISTERS AND KILLERS
description: From Scottish Crimes to Egyptian Mysteries Brothers and Sisters and Killers

title: THE NATION
description: As the election year dawned, there were clues aplenty that crime, a staple of most recent campaigns, was being readied as an issue for yet another Presidential race.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find particularly appealing. Gentleman With a Guitar

title: Miss Hoover To Be Bride
description: The engagement of Sarah Ellen Hoover to Stowe Bayles Boyd has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Hoover of Summit, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Drs.

title: WE MUST ALL SEEK A SOLUTION ON TOXIC WASTE
description: NEW JERSEY has reached a critical decision point with regard to hazardous-waste management. We have acknowledged the problems caused by the illicit and improper disposal of hazardous waste and we are moving aggressively toward a solution. However, illegal dumping and abandoned sites can be prevented only through the siting of new, safe, carefully controlled treatment and disposal facilities.

title: ; THE IMPORTANCE OF AN UNEASY NUCLEAR BALANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Jonathan Brenner Wed To Barbara D. Roslyn
description: Barbara Diane Roslyn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Roslyn of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Jonathan S. Brenner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis R. Brenner of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Sidney Solomon performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

title: BETTY HANSON, 7TH AVE. FIGURE
description: Betty Hanson, the head of the sportswear manufacturing business that bears her name and a prominent figure on Seventh Avenue for more than 40 years, died of cancer yesterday at White Plains Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: Robin Ruderman Is Wed to Richard Landsberger
description: Robin Dale Ruderman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Ruderman of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Bruce Landsberger, son of Mrs. David Loventhal of Roslyn, L.I., and Maurice Landsberger of Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, assisted by Cantor Kurt Silverman, performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel,

title: JUDICIAL NOMINATION: LAWYERS SEEK ROLE
description: THE presidents of most of New Jersey's 21 county bar associations believe that a substantial majority of lawyers will support efforts this year to have gubernatorial nominations to the judiciary selected only from lists of candidates suggested, screened and submitted by the associations.

title: Rosalind Moore Is Wed to Jeffrey Carter, Lawyer
description: The marriage of Rosalind Jeanne Moore, a freelance researcher in New York, to Jeffrey Calhoun Carter, a partner in the New York law firm of Henderson Koplik & Carter, took place in Santa Barbara, Calif., yesterday. The Rev. Karl Tuttle performed the ceremony at the First Christian Church.

title: Vanessa B. Reed To Marry in June
description: Vanessa Benton Reed, daughter of Dr. Robert Jeffrey Reed 3d of Wheeling, W. Va., and Jeannie Reed of Santa Barbara, Calif., is engaged to marry George Marsman Drysdale, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Drysdale of Manila and Honolulu. A June wedding is planned.

title: Breaking the Medicare Taboo
description: Whatever the merits of Walter Mondale's plan for rescuing Medicare from bankruptcy, he deserves credit for declaring it ''a major issue in the 1984 campaign.'' The $60 billion program of health insurance for the elderly has been setting off fiscal alarms for nearly a year but most political leaders averted their eyes.

title: LOOKING BEYOND MARCOS
description: Colin Campbell is The New York Times's bureau chief in Bangkok. By Colin Campbell HE BUSINESS district that has grown up on the south side of Manila since President Ferdinand E. Marcos came to power in December 1965 is as opulent as vast tracts of the Philippine capital are shabby and hopeless. Makati's gleaming office towers, clubs, hotels and shopping centers make it indistinguishable from its counterparts in the palmy Sun Belt of the United States. For years, its conservative business leaders supported Mr. Marcos and his regime. One of the biggest surprises of the last few turbulent months was the way they turned against him.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE TEDDY BEARS' PICNIC By Jimmy Kennedy. Illustrated by Alexandra Day. With record. 30 pp. La Jolla, Calif.: Green Tiger Press. $14.95. (Ages 3 to 6)

title: COMPUTER SYSTEM AIDS CONSERVATION
description: A computer system to keep track of endangered plant and animal species in Connecticut has been established by the state and a national conservation group.

title: TAXTER'S FIRST TWO
description: As one of its first development projects, Urbco Inc., the real-estate arm of Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, is building a 340,000-square-foot office park in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Nuptials in Larchmont For Elizabeth Forbes
description: At St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday, Elizabeth Anne Forbes, daughter of Mrs. James Caryl Forbes of Larchmont and the late Mr. Forbes, was married to Peter Igoe Tracy, son of Virginia Tracy of Short Hills, N.J., and William Irwin Tracy of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. William V. Reynolds performed the ceremony.

title: CHINESE PREMIER ON U.S. VISIT
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China arrived in the United States today to begin a long-awaited visit that both Peking and Washington hope will ease nagging tensions between them and strengthen trade relations.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: The Skinny On Skinny

title: CONCERT HALLS CAN DO MORE
description: New York offers a panoply of classical music greater than any city in the country and perhaps the world. The quantity and, often, the quality, are dazzling, and generally celebrated as an unabashed blessing. Yet there are problems amid the plenty; New York's concert life may be hyper-active, but it is not equally rich in all areas. To be sure, some unusual and interesting events do take place all over the city in halls both major and minor, centrally located and on the fringe. But too often, our major midtown concert halls seem sometimes to have become interchangeable emporiums for the dispensation of warhorse classical repertory. The same artists, the same ensembles, the same composers, all crop up week after week and season after season, from one hall to the next.

title: SELECTION OF CLASSES FOR GIFTED CHILDREN
description: ENRICHMENT programs available to county residents offer courses to gifted students of varying ages. Some classes begin in January, others in February and March. In the selection below, classes are taught by teachers experienced in the education of gifted children.

title: THAT WAS NO FUMBLE, IT WAS 'MOTHE GOOSE'
description: ''HOLY cats!'' (or words to that effect) I screamed. ''Now what?'' my wife said, unemotionally.

title: NOW WHAT?
description: A few weeks ago, the Denver School Board asked the Federal court to declare that after 11 years of court-ordered busing the city schools were integrated. Such a ruling would close the books on the suit that put the school system on trial and end more than a decade of court-supervised school operation.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Detroit Pistons vs. Bucks at Milwaukee, (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.); Houston Rockets vs. Los Angeles Lakers at Inglewood, Calif. (Television - ESPN, 10:30 P.M.) Football San Francisco 49ers vs.

title: CHINESE-U.S. RELATIONS TAKE A MORE REALISTIC DIRECTION
description: If China's rhetoric can be believed, two of its fondest friends are the North Korean President, Kim Il Sung, and the ousted Cambodian guerrilla leader Pol Pot, whose notoriety has isolated them elsewhere. By contrast, the United States gets lumped with the Soviet Union as hegemonistic superpowers who pose the real threat to the peaceloving world.

title: V.A.T.
description: To the Editor: Margot Slade's article ''How to Stalk and Capture a V.A.T. Refund'' (Travel, Nov. 6), was most interesting and informative. As she did not cover Austria, I would like to report on the procedure practiced there.

title: ARTILLERY BATTLES ERUPT IN LEBANON AS TALKS PROCEED
description: Heavy shelling between the Lebanese Army and Druse militiamen broke out near here today as negotiators in Damascus tried to reach final agreement on a plan to disengage forces in the Lebanon war.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES

title: NONESUCH OBSERVES ITS 20TH BIRTHDAY
description: Next month - on Valentine's Day - Nonesuch Records will be 20 years old. Is that remarkable? In a way, quite remarkable, for just a few years ago those who follow the classical recording industry were wondering whether Nonesuch could survive in the wake of the dismissal of Teresa Sterne, the woman who had become identified with the label's reputation for quality, originality and integrity. She apparently built a firm foundation, however, for now, four years after that traumatic occasion, Nonesuch's reputation remains intact and the records consistently win high praise from the critics and even sometimes become best sellers. All this at a time when many classical companies seem devoted to nothing but endless reissues. (Nonesuch doesn't reissue things; everything in its catalogue stays in print.)

title: A BUSINESSLIKE BON VOYAGE
description: As an executive who has traveled around the world for close to 25 years - from Chiangmai in northern Thailand to Juba in southern Sudan, from Guilin in China to Ouro Pr^eto in Brazil - I have loved it, all of it, all the time. There were, inevitably, some rough spots, such as tossing in my bed in a hotel room in Nairobi with a 104-degree fever, while a desk clerk downstairs who had promised to summon a doctor subordinated his pledge to other priorties. From that experience, I learned that, almost anywhere, the local United States embassy or consulate is by far the best reference source for emergency medical service.

title: HEADLINERS
description: A Post Well Earned Catherine Pollard was determined to teach the Boy Scouts of America a thing or two about being prepared. The 65-year-old grandmother has been fighting to win the designation of scoutmaster since 1976, when the scouts turned down her application despite the fact that she had periodically been the unofficial leader of a Connecticut troop since 1953. Mrs. Pollard called it sex discrimination and got her evidence ready for the state Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities. Last week, the commission ruled that her experience as a ''de facto scoutmaster'' made her ''well qualified'' for the volunteer job, and ordered the ''clearly erroneous'' scouts to give it to her.

title: A First Novelist at 73
description: In her moment in the literary spotlight, Harriet Doerr is concerned that too much attention is being paid to her rather than to her novel, ''Stones for Ibarra.'' Of course, she recognizes the reason behind all the fuss: She's a first novelist at the age of 73. Although she is a native Californian, Mrs. Doerr and her husband lived in Mexico for 15 years and, like the fictional American couple in her novel, spent time in a small Mexican village. ''But,'' she said, ''this is not an autobiographial novel and it is not about one place, though I have seen mining towns like Ibarra. All you can write about is what you know, but then you have to put your imagination to work.'' Was it difficult to enter the minds of Mexican villagers? ''It's hard to say that you know another people well,'' Mrs. Doerr said, ''but I feel that I do have something in common with the Mexicans. They are so human and wise - they take adversity as if they expected it to happen.'' Several years after becoming a widow, Mrs. Doerr decided to return to school. She had gone to Smith for a year in 1928 and to Stanford a year later. In 1977, she got her B.A. at Stanford, majoring in European history. And, then, she began taking graduate courses in fiction with John L'Heureux, director of Stanford's creative writing program. The program included such visiting lecturers as Donald Barthelme, Grace Paley, Robert Stone and Eudora Welty - ''She's older than I am,'' Mrs. Doerr noted.

title: THE COLLEGE BOARD JOINS PUBLISHERS OF S.A.T.'S 'CRAM' BOOKS

That's the first step - but by no means the last - toward decent cab service throughout the city.

title: POINTS ON THE AMERICAN COMPASS
description: John Herbers is a national correspondent in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. THE BOOK OF AMERICA Inside 50 States Today. By Neal R. Peirce and Jerry Hagstrom. 910 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $25.

title: MANY TOWNS RESIST HOUSING FOR THE ELDERLY
description: BARBARA B. ANDREWS was a commissioner on the Norwalk Housing Authority eight years ago when the panel held hearings to determine who on the authority's waiting list of 500 elderly people was most in need of better housing. After months of listening to the impassioned testimony of many low-income elderly, the authority abandoned the hearings and went back to choosing people from the waiting list on a first-come, first- served basis.

title: IN SHORT
description: * ANASTASIA: The Riddle of Anna Anderson. By Peter Kurth. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) Did Anastasia, the youngest daughter of Czar Nicholas II and Empress Alexandra, survive the execution of the Russian imperial family in 1918? In ''Anastasia'' Peter Kurth thoroughly retells this much told story and convincingly argues that Anastasia was not killed by a Bolshevik firing squad.

title: THE YUCATAN'S TRIPLE APPEAL
description: When an American traveler recently approached the taxi dispatcher at the airport in Merida, capital of Yucatan state, he was somewhat disarmed by the dispatcher's rapid, and accurate, assessment of him. ''You want a colonial hotel with a courtyard in the old part of town, no?'' said the dispatcher, even before the traveler had spoken.

title: INGRES SAW HIMSELF AS THE SAVIOR OF FRENCH PAINTING
description: LOUISVILLE

title: JACKSON IN FLIER'S HOMETOWN
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson got an enthusiastic welcome today in the hometown of Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr., the Navy flier released by Syria.

title: THE WORLD
description: Soviet UnionPerfectly ClearOn MissilesSoviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko last week hung icicles on hopes for a thaw when he meets Secretary of State George P. Shultz in Stockholm on Jan. 18. In preparing for such meetings, the Russians frequently avoid public accusations, thus suggesting they are ready for serious negotiations. This time, Mr. Gromyko seemed to have other priorities. Speaking at a luncheon for East German Foreign Minister Oskar Fischer, he attacked United States policies around the world.

title: Airline Decontrol
description: To the Editor:

title: SCIENCE-FICTION READINGS UNFOLD ALIEN WORLDS
description: Paul Kresh writes frequently about recordings.

title: BANKS START TO ACT ON CONVERSION LAW
description: IN the six months since Governor

title: THE SECRET WORLD OF OPUS DEI
description: Henry Kamm is The Times's bureau chief in Rome. N AN IMPOSING MANSION NEAR THE VILLA Borghese park in Rome, Msgr. Alvaro del Portillo y Diez de Sollano - the head of the international religious society known as Opus Dei - basks in his new title of Prelate, which Pope John Paul II bestowed on him a little more than a year ago. The 69-year-old Spaniard, who now wears a golden bishop's ring along with his silver pectoral cross, was so affable as to make me almost forget that I had been put off for nearly a year before being granted the rare privilege of a meeting. Opus Dei is not anxious to be written about by nonmembers.

title: Dorr Moves Up
description: After 13 years as an assistant coach under Don James, first at Kent State and more recently at Washington, Ray Dorr thinks he's qualified to move up to a head coaching job. So does Southern Illinois, the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-AA champion, which named Dorr to replace Rey Dempsey, who resigned to take over at Memphis State.

title: WHEN ONE INSPIRED GESTURE ILLUMINATES THE STAGE
description: An actor's ultimate success or failure in a part probably has very little to do with the ordeal of rehearsals, the ministrations of a director, the out-of-town agony of turning the play upside down. Everything is most likely determined long before, when the performer is struck all of a heap by what seems a blinding flash of inspiration (and by what may well

title: A BATTLE IN BANKING: NORTH FORK VS. SOUTH
description: ORDINARILY, on the East End, it is the South Fork that is thought to be hurtling, for better or for worse, toward the 21st century, more modern, attuned to the marketplace and Manhattan-oriented than the North Fork, which remains change-resistant and steadfastly rural. An unusual bank battle, however, has reversed those roles.

title: LOSS OF SMELL TERMED SIGNAL OF BRAIN TUMOR
description: Brain tumors are rarely diagnosed in time but often could be if people recognized and reported to doctors one ofthe first signs, a loss of sense of smell, a doctor says.

title: R. D. Solomon to Wed Margeg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence L. Suttenberg of North Andover, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marge Judy Suttenberg, to Robert Donald Solomon, son of Dr. and Mrs. Mortimer D. Solomon of Rockville Centre, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: A THEATRICAL ENSEMBLE MAKES ITS FOND FAREWELLS
description: It was New Year's Eve, and the

title: NATIONAL PROJECT HELPS TEACHERS OF WRITING
description: AT the Berkeley Teacher's Center, 25 elementary-school teachers listened to a colleague's confession on teaching good writing practices. ''It sounds terrible, but I'd never been taught how to teach writing,'' said Mary Hurdlow, an elementary-school teacher for 27 years. ''When writing was mentioned it was almost always handwriting or grammar or punctuation,'' a matter of thinking up good assignments and going through student papers carefully with a red pen, checking for spelling mistakes and punctuation.

title: TRYING TO CLOSE THE BOOK ON WILLOBROOK
description: For families with retarded children or other relatives there, or for those who merely viewed the squalor on television, Willowbrook's name alone recalls unutterable horrors - retarded children in pens covered with their own filth, bedridden patients pocked with untended sores, broken toilets, vermin.

title: Poland
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: AS THE State Lottery embarks on its 14th year, officials are celebrating its success so far, reporting that $1.6 billion of $3.7 billion in ticket sales has been turned over to institutions and education, an average of $125 million a year. Hazel F. Gluck, executive director of the Lottery Commission, enthusiastically announced that more than $1.8 billion had been given to winners since the first lottery prize was awarded. In those days - the lottery started as a 50-cent weekly event - tickets had six digits preselected by machines rather than customers, and the winning numbers had to be matched in the exact order in which they were drawn.

title: VINTAGE 1957: A NIGHT OF DANCE WITH THE DUKE
description: On a June night in 1957, Duke Ellington's orchestra pulled into Carrolltown, Pa., a small agricultural community in the Alleghenies about 200 miles west of Philadelphia, to play for a dance. Several hours later, the musicians climbed back into their bus and moved on toward their next one-night stand.

title: COLMAR ENJOYS A GOOD BOUQUET
description: Most European cities have signs pointing the way to their old town. In Colmar, a city of 67,000, in the lower Alsace region of France, that's not necessary. The old town occupies much of Colmar and is the heart of the city. It's where business is transacted, where people go to have a good time, where the hotels, restaurants and museums are.

title: SCOPE OF PROPOSAL FOR HOSPITAL LAND IS FOCUS OF DEBATE
description: THE size of a proposed development in White Plains - office buildings, stores, 1,800 apartments, a hotel and six theaters covering a stretch of land 25 percent larger than the city's entire urban-renewal district - has stunned its opponents and some of its supporters.

title: Davenport Is Ready
description: He hasn't competed in a track meet since 1977, but Willie Davenport, who won the gold medal in the 110-meter high hurdles at the 1968 Olympics, is ready to try again. The 40-year-old Davenport, who was a member of the Olympic bobsled team in 1980, has entered the 55-meter hurdles in today's Dartmouth-Saucony Relays in Hanover, N.H., the first of a series of indoor meets for him.

title: OF PORCUPINES AND SNOWMOBILES
description: Patti Hagan is a contributor to The New York Times editorial page. THIRD PERSON RURAL Further Essays of a Sometime Farmer. By Noel Perrin. Illustrated. 188 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $13.95.

title: CALIFORNIA PATROL IS SADDLING UP ON HARLEY AGAIN
description: The Harley-Davidson motorcycle, the beloved big bruiser to earlier generations of motorcycle enthusiasts, is making a comeback this year with the California Highway Patrol after 11 years of losing out to Kawasaki of Japan.

title:
HEALTH;
FITNESS
description: are addicitive, and withdrawal is often painful.

title: A BEAUX ARTS PLAYLAND ON HOUSTON ST.
description: In 1900, New York City opened the gates to an extravagant four-acre park and recreation center designed by the prominent architectural firm of Carr ere & Hastings and built especially for the youngsters who lived in the densely populated Lower East Side.

title: OPPOSITION PAPERS FOR NOVEMBER
description: David E. Rosenbaum is the enterprise editor of The New York Times. ON REAGAN The Man & His Presidency. By Ronnie Dugger. 616 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Co. $19.95.

title: International
description: While talks were held in Damascus on a final agreement on a disengagement plan for the Lebanon war, heavy shelling between Druse militiamen and Lebanese soldiers broke out in the mountains east and south of Beirut. Despite the renewed fighting, Lebanese officials remained optimistic that the disengagement plan would soon be put into effect. Two United States Marines were slightly wounded when a shell exploded near their base, but they did not fire, a Marine spokesman said. (Page 1, Col. 6.)

title: IN OTTINGER'S WAKE, A CROWDED FIELD FORMS
description: IT was a growing sense of frustration, ''feeling as powerless as

title:
STAMPS;
BLOCK OF FOUR TO MARK THE WINTER OLYMPICS
description: The United States is continuing its many 1983 philatelic tributes to the Olympic Games in the New Year by issuing a block of four commemoratives for the Winter Olympics being held next month in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia.

title: BIG BROTHER IS CATCHING
description: -three was a very good year for ''1984,'' and it looks as if 1984 will be, too. Written in 1948, George Orwell's grim tale of a society in which Big Brother is all and individual freedom nothing is selling faster than you can say doublethink.

title: Favored Morning Bob Wins Tropical Park Derby
description: Woody Stephens says he thinks that a gray colt named Morning Bob is only the fifth-best 3-year-old in his stable, but the son of Blushing Groom was good enough to score an easy 1 1/2-length victory today in the $148,850 Tropical Park Derby at Calder Race Course.

title: IMPROVING THE WEARY TRAVELER'S LOT
description: IF I had not so desperately

title: CHINESE AT THE MALL
description: CHINA DELIGHT, a new restaurant on the seventh floor of the Stamford Town Center, has a fresh, modern, contemporary look, thanks to the use of light woods, cane-seated chairs and bright lighting. It is a small, informal place, with a staff eager to accommodate and expeditious in service - good signs in a restaurant in a mall.

title: THE NATION
description: A study released last week by the Education Department suggests that, while politicians and educators have been concentrating on the quality of American education, quantity may count, too. The high school dropout rate was higher in 1982 than 10 years before, the study showed, and college entrance exam scores were down.

title: Mindy Stolpner Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eli Stolpner of Brooklyn have announced that their daughter, Mindy Stolpner, will be married Feb. 19 at the Hebrew University Mount Scopus campus in Jerusalem to Chaim Meir Kornberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chil Kornberg of Toronto.

title: BLAME MOSCOW,TOO
description: The Kremlin appears to be in no mood to make a serious effort to accommodate the United States.

title: Swiss Skier Tops Klammer
description: Urs Raeber of Switzerland won his second straight World Cup race today, enhancing his ranking as the world's No. 1 downhill racer. The 25- year-old Raeber beat Franz Klammer of Austria by 11-hundredths of a second down the 3,230-meter Crap Sogn Gion course. The vertical drop was 960 meters.

title: Carey Wins 100 Backstroke
description: Rick Carey of Mount Kisco, N.Y., won impressively tonight in the United States Swimming International from an East German who may be his major Olympic rival this summer.

title: Alicia C. Shepard Wed in California
description: An 84-foot schooner in the harbor at Sausalito, Calif., was the site of the marriage yesterday of Alicia Cobb Shepard, a reporter for The San Jose (Calif.) Mercury News, and Paul Robert Hodierne, associate news director at KRON-TV in San Francisco.

title: Georgetown Beats Seton Hall
description: Georgetown, relying more on pressure defense than offense, defeated Seton Hall, 74-63, today in the second game of a doubleheader at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: THE WORLD
description: A Reagan-CastroDialogue of Sorts

title: Cooperation Needed, Not Lawsuits
description: I am writing in response to the article ''Ruling on Hospitals Facing Challenge.'' The article concerned the decision by the Connecticut Hospital Association (C.H.A.) to sue the Connecticut Department of Mental Health (D.M.H.).

title: Death Penalty Ordered In Stabbing at Arcade
description: A 19-year- old man accused of plotting the robbery of an amusement center in which four former co-workers were slain was sentenced today to death by injection.

title: FARMS ON INCREASE
description: THE number of farms in Connecticut increased over the four years ending in 1982, but the amount of land involved in agricultural production decreased because of a trend to smaller farms, a survey by the United States Department of Agriculture shows.

title: Lee Daniels Wed To Anne Kenney
description: Anne Kathleen Kenney, an advertising sales representative for People magazine, and Lee Arthur Daniels, a reporter for The New York Times, were married yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York. The Rev. Sandra A. Wilson of St. Marks Episcopal Church in Bridgeport, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: Two Are Found Slain At a House in Astoria
description: A woman was found stabbed to death in her bed and a man was found bludgeoned to death in a shed behind their house yesterday morning in Astoria, Queens, the police said. Both were 70 years old.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: -THROATED SPARROW Zonotrichia albicollis

title: WHAT'S DOING IN HONG KONG
description: Political uncertainty in Hong Kong - China has announced that it will take the territory back from Britain in 1997 - is providing a windfall for tourists. The Hong Kong dollar has plunged to historic lows in the last year while Britain and China have been conducting diplomatic discussions on the colony's future. The Hong Kong Government has been forced to intervene and has in effect pegged the local currency at 7.80 Hong Kong dollars to one United States dollar. The result has been bargains galore for American visitors, and hotels are often full.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
CARTTER SALE SHAPES UP AS FIRST BIG EVENT OF '84
description: Coin collectors won't have to wait long for the first blockbuster auction of 1984; it will take place Jan. 18-21 when Stack's of New York sells the Amon G. Carter Jr. family collection of United States and foreign coins.

title: Ex-Mayor Rejoins Law Firm
description: Former Mayor William J. Green has rejoined the Philadelphia law firm of Wolf, Block, Schorr & Solis-Cohen, it was announced Thursday. Mr. Green was associated with the firm for three years before he was elected Mayor in 1980. His term ended earlier this week.

title: THE RECYCLING OF CHEMICAL WASTE
description: IN place of landscaping, huge and

title: THE WORLD
description: Tunisian StormComes and Goes

title: Disaster Status Is Granted
description: President Reagan declared a disaster for freeze-ravaged South Texas today, clearing the way for Federal aid sought by state officials.

title: A NEGLECTED HUDSON RIVER PAINTER
description: MORRISTOWN ALTHOUGH painters of the Hudson River School are not as well known as, say, the author of ''Moby Dick,'' they did as much to define and shape the American experience in the 19th century.

title: NEEDIEST CASES GET $2 MILLION FOR FIRST TIME
description: Donations to the annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $2 million mark yesterday for the first time in the history of the 72-year-old campaign to help the poor and the distressed of New York City.

title: Foes of Marcos Propose New Philippine Charter
description: A group led by former President Diosdado Macapagal has completed the draft of a constitution that is to be the basis of a shadow government aimed at ousting President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: CONSUMER RATES
PROSPECTS
description: Retailers Watch the 'GAF'

title: HEADLINERS
description: Royally IndignantThe gentlemen of Fleet Street were reminded once again last week that what they deem a free press sometimes seems hog wild to Queen Elizabeth II .

title: FAMILY-LIFE EDUCATION, NEW JERSEY STYLE
description: To the Editor:

title: FLAT 'CHAMPAGNE' DESPITE THE STAGING
description: LESLIE STEVENS'S comedy, ''Champagne Complex,'' currently being presented by the Arena Players Repertory Company in East Farmingdale, is a play whose time for production is long past. Even here, where all the components of acting, direction and design are strong, the play sags like a shrinking balloon.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
TO DREAM, PERCHANCE TO SLEEP
description: YOU don't have to read this whole story to find out the moral. The moral of the story is: when the salesman says your beds will be delivered in three weeks, it's a lot of bunk.

title: David C. Brofsky to Marry Miss Bernstein, a Teacher
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Bernstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ruth-Ann Bernstein, to David C. Brofsky, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Brofsky of Ardsley, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: CAN COMPUTERS IMPROVE WRITING?
description: ANDREE RUBIN, who has spent two years working on computer programs that help students in writing, still remembers the sixth-grader in a Hartford classroom who ran away from home last January. He was gone for several days. Then, of all places, he turned up at school. ''He said, 'I came back because I want to write on the computer,' '' Miss Rubin recalled recently. ''We were astounded.'' Almost immediately the boy, who had never before showed a particular interest in writing, sat down and typed out an essay about a youngster who ran away to an island and was saved by a dolphin.

title: A LICENSE TO DELIGHT IN MOTHERHOOD
description: AS I drove down the Hutchinson River Parkway, anxious to keep an appointment in Bronxville, the license plate on the dark blue Pontiac in front of me caught my attention. Boldly, for all to see, it read ''MIKESMOM.'' This merging together of MIKE and his MOM, this flaunting of the role of caregiver and nurturer, so blatantly on the back of a woman's car, disturbed me greatly. How could she dare?

title: EATING SENSIBLY
description: President Reagan has endorsed the Federal Dietary Guidelines for the United States, which may have come as something of a surprise to his Secretary of Agriculture, John R. Block.

title: THE STRANGE CASE OF E. M. FORSTER
description: SELECTED LETTERS OF E. M. FORSTER Volume One. 1879-1920.Edited By Mary Lago and P. N. Furbank. Illustrated. 344 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $20.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IT may bear the name the ''Elephant Hotel,''

title: Deborah Morgan Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Morgan of Tamarac, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Morgan, to Thomas F. Prince, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton S. Prince of New York. Miss Morgan is in the international marketing department of Paramount Pictures in New York. Her fiance is a principal in the Brooklyn Heights real-estate company of Prince & Prince Inc. The wedding is planned for May.

title: WHATEVER BECAME OF PALMER?
description: FRANCIS BACON once said: ''Writing maketh an exact man.'' Apparently, many educators agree with him because, despite years of neglect of penmanship, they still devote attention these days to teaching it.

title: A LONDON MUSEUM
description: If, as they say, youth is too precious a

title: SLAVONIC ORTHODOX BISHOP IS FOUND HANGED
description: The Most Rev. William Anthony Prazsky, Bishop of New York of the Slavonic Orthodox Church and pastor of the Eastern Orthodox Monastery of St. Andrew in the Bronx, hanged himself in his church on Friday, the day celebrated in his religion as Christmas, the police said yesterday.

title: CROSSROADS OF REVOLUTION
description: Stephen W. Sears is the author of ''Landscape Turned Red: The Battle of Antietam.'' THE DAY IS OURS! November 1776-January 1777: An Inside View of the Battles of Trenton and Princeton. By William M. Dwyer. 426 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $22.50.

title: OLD SUBWAY IN NEWARK GETTING A NEW LOOK
description: NEWARK THE last remaining trolley line in the metropolitan area - the Newark City Subway - is undergoing a $20 million renovation that is expected to be completed in the fall.

title: WRITING SPREADS ACROSS THE CURRICULUM
description: -graders study the westward expansion, they chronicle the movement of an imaginary family through history. Susan Rabin teaches health by reading aloud students' letters to an imaginary publisher of a sex-education text. And when Ann Sevcik's psychology students write up a research project, they write it for publication in the school science journal, ''Science Etc.,'' which publishes student research on everything from peer pressure to black holes.

title: A WORK PROGRAM FOR 18-YEAR-OLDS PROPOSED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch plans to create a voluntary service program designed to give 18-year-old New Yorkers experience in helping others.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE General Accounting Office in Washington has found that local sewage authorities and private industrial plants in New Jersey and elsewhere have not been complying with a permit system that was supposed to have been protecting water quality since 1972.

title: HOW LEHMAN IS USING THE NATIONAL PROGRAM
description: GRAMMAR. Diction. Punctuation. Structure. For decades those were the operative words when teaching students to write.

title: Community Care Of Mentally Ill
description: Recently the New York Times carried two articles and concerning an impending lawsuit by the Connecticut Hospital Association (''Hospitals Ask State to Take Mentally Ill,'' Oct. 23, and ''Ruling on Hospitals Facing Challenge,'' Nov. 20). I would like to provide you with the Connecticut Department of Mental Health's rationale for its position. Hopefully, this will present a more balanced picture of the mental health system in Connecticut.

title: RICHARD DANA, EX-PUBLISHER AND ROCKEFELLER U. EXECUTIVE
description: Richard H. Dana, a former publisher, arts administrator, Rockefeller University executive and president of the Diller-Quaile School of Music, died of a heart attack Friday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan and Washington, Conn.

title: SCHOOL CHANCELLOR OFFERS SPORT AS AN ANSWER TO DROPOUT RATE
description: WHEN the United States Department of Education released a report last Thursday showing an increased dropout rate among the nation's high school students, Schools Chancellor Dr. Anthony Alvarado said that he was alarmed but not surprised that New York City's dropout rate had leaped to 45 percent.

title: CHADIAN MINISTER DIES ON EVE OF PEACE TALKS
description: The Government announced today that Chad's Foreign Minister died of malaria today, on the eve of the opening Monday of a peace conference in Ethiopia with rebels who control much of this divided nation.

title: STATE TRIES TO FIX WATER SYSTEM
description: ''CHAOS'' is one legislator's word for it: Six hundred small water companies - some even lacking both full-time management and the money to install filtration equipment - serve many of Connecticut's 2.5 million residents who rely on public sources for their needs.

title: REDSKINS' BUTZ MAKES USE OF MORE THAN HIS BRAWN
description: FOR the better part of his 11 years as a defensive tackle in the National Football League,

title: Sports of The Times; Raiders Want the Redskins
description: LOS ANGELES WHEN the question was asked, Jim Plunkett's listeners expected the 35- year-old quarterback to talk about how he wasn't looking ahead to Super Bowl XVIII in Tampa in two weeks, that the Los Angeles Raiders were only thinking about the Seattle Seahawks in today's American Conference championship game. But like the good quarterback he is, Jim Plunkett fooled the defense.

title: COMPUTER SOFTWEAR TEACHES WITH FUN
description: Ris for rocket, the screen says, and after the machine beeps out a countdown, the rocket blasts off, flying up and off the screen. V is for violin, the monitor informs the young viewer and as a bow swings back and forth on the instrument's strings, Liszt's Hungarian Waltz is heard.

title: EDUCATION IN TEXAS
Jean M. Idleman Becomes a Bride
description: Jean Martha Idleman, a corporate bond analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company, and Brent Bonbright Erensel, a securities analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., were married yesterday. The Rev. John Wade Payne performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) in New York, where the bride's great-grandfather, the late Rev. Finis Idleman, was minister from 1916 to 1941.

title: AFTER THE 'BOOM,' CHAMBER MUSIC IS HERE TO STAY
description: Five years ago, when purveyors of chamber music realized that their concert subscriptions and record sales were looking healthier than ever, they put it about that the world was experiencing a ''chamber music boom.'' To some extent, they were overdramatizing. After all, legendary ensembles like the Budapest, Galimir and Busch Quartets - not to mention all-star ensembles on the Rubinstein-Heifetz-Piatigorsky ''Million Dollar Trio'' model - were thriving decades ago, long before the ''boom'' and its attendant media hype. Even comparative upstarts like the Juilliard Quartet and the Beaux Arts Trio already had a quarter of a century behind them when the ''boom'' hit; and younger ensembles, like the Cleveland and Tokyo Quartets, had been working together for about a decade.

title: BALLET AND COMEDY ON NEW CASSETTES
description: Channels/Inserts, Locale and Fractions I Three Media Dances by Merce Cunningham Cunningham Dance Foundation 30 minutes each. $64 each or $185 for the three

title: VIABLE OPPOSITION PARTIES ARE EMERGING IN EGYPT
description: After more than 30 years of single-party dominance, officials here say a genuine political opposition is beginning to emerge.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: VICTORIAN ART

title: NOVELIST ALICE WALKER TELLING THE BLACK WOMAN'S STORY
description: FIRST MET ALICE WALKER THE WAY PEOPLE used to: Someone I liked and respected pressed a dogeared copy of one of her books into my hands and said, ''You've got to read this.'' The book was ''In Love & Trouble,'' a collection of stories written between 1967 and 1973. Some of them had been published previously in periodicals directed at a primarily black readership, in the feminist standard, Ms., and in mainstream magazines like Harper's, a spectrum that hinted at the range of Alice Walker's appeal, just as the book's eventual winning of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters' Rosenthal Award was a harbinger of honors to come, including the Pulitzer Prize for fiction.

title: SALVAGING HOUSING
description: Residents of the Norwood section of the Bronx watched in frustration for years as the 20-unit apartment building at 3347 Decatur Avenue slid toward decay and abandonment after its landlord stopped making repairs.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: both the university and the town - is the well-known ''A Princeton Companion,'' by Alexander Leitch (Princeton University Press, Princeton, N.J. 08540, $22.50), a collection of about 400 articles about ''diverse elements of Princeton's heritage and its ongoing life.''

title: OPERA: 'MAHAGONNY' IS REVIVED AT THE MET
description: John Dexter's production of Kurt Weill's ''Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny,'' revived by the Metropolitan Opera Thursday night, was one of the representative hits of the ''new Met'' when first seen in late 1979.

title: NEW CREDIT CARDS FOR PHONES
description: IN a move designed to combat

title: Steinkuhler's Choice
description: Dean Steinkuhler, the Nebraska offensive lineman who won the Outland and Lombardi awards, says he wouldn't mind playing in the United States Football League - if the price is right. ''You're playing for money and that will probably be the ultimate factor that I will base my decision on,'' he told The Omaha World-Herald.

title: DAVID M. HEYMAN, FINANCIER AND A HEALTH SERVICES LEADER
description: David M. Heyman, financier, philanthropist and advocate of better municipal health services, died yesterday at his home on East 76th Street. Mr. Heyman, who was 92 years old, also had a home in Armonk, N.Y.

title: Reagan Renews Praise For Europe's Socialists
description: President Reagan, in an interview with a French newspaper, has restated his praise for Western Socialist governments that he says share such basic values as democracy, liberty and human dignity.

title: COMING TO LIFE Hard-Bitten
description: Some young archeologists in California think that, through chemical analysis of fossil bones, they can figure out what early man ate. It's an appealing prospect.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Busch Gardens Celebrates

title: MAD-HATTER TESTS OF GOOD TEACHING
description: ONCE upon a time in Wonderland, a prestigious national commission declared that the state of health care in that country was abominable. There were so many unhealthy people walking around that the commission declared the nation at risk and called for sweeping reforms. In response, a major hospital decided to institute performance measures of patient outcomes and to tie decisions on patient dismissals as well as doctor's salaries to those measures. The most widely used instrument for assessing health in Wonderland was a simple tool that produced a single score with proven reliability. That instrument, called a thermometer, had the added advantage of being easy to administer and record. No one had to spend a great deal of time trying to decipher doctors' illegible handwriting or soliciting their subjective opinions about patient health.

title: REGRETS OF A REVOLUTIONARY
description: Alan Cheuse is the author of ''The Bohemians,'' a novel, and ''Candace & Other Stories.'' . . . KILL MEMORY . . . By William Herrick. 134 pp. New York: New Directions. Cloth, $13.50. Paper, $6.95.

title: CONCEDING THE SUBCOMPACT TO JAPAN
description: ''FOR years I thought what was good for our country was good for General Motors and vice versa,'' said a former G.M. president, Charles E. Wilson, some 30 years ago. But the evidence surrounding the General Motors-Toyota joint venture in California to produce a subcompact car with American labor and Japanese technology and production-line know-how suggests that this old equation simply does not compute.

title: BILL MOYERS LOOKS AT A CHANGING AMERICA
description: ''AWalk Through the 20th Century With Bill Moyers'' looks, at first, as discursive as the century itself. The 19-part public-television series begins on Wednesday night with a visit to Marshall, Tex., Mr. Moyers's old hometown, and continues in the months to come by examining, among other things, the growth of public relations, American automobiles, world's fairs and the differences between Franklin Delano Roosevelt and Adolf Hitler. It seems to be not so much a walk though the times as a serendipitous meander, with Mr. Moyers led only by whim. Watch the series for a while, however, and a purpose appears: Mr. Moyers wants to show what joins rather than divides us. We are meant to look at the connective tissue of our time.

title: Harrisburg Bishop Installed
description: The Rev. William Keeler, 52 years old, was installed Wednesday at St. Patrick's Cathedral as bishop of the Harrisburg diocese, becoming the spiritual leader of 200,000 Roman Catholics in central and eastern Pennsylvania. Appointed by Pope John Paul II, he succeeds Bishop Joseph Daley, who died in September at the age of 67.

title: STAMP DESIGNER IS AN UNSUNG HERO OF ART WORLD
description: ''IAM constantly amazed by the amount of publicity these stamps generate,'' said Dennis Lyall of Norwalk about the five commemoratives he designed last year for the United States Postal Service. No other work the illustrator has done has brought him so much attention, he said, adding, ''You could do a nice annual report, but nobody would think twice.''

title: A NEW YORK QUINTET SLIDES INTO SECOND
description: Every time a national championship is contested North America's best players are there, fighting for a title. That is the theory, but there are three minor exceptions and one major one because the national organization permits some overlapping. The final stages of the three national knockout championships coincide with other, shorter, events, - relatively unimportant since the knockout involves only a handful of players.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Cliffhangers: A Place To Look Over Fifteen years ago Cliffhangers opened in Bronxville with gifts and American craft items and it expanded to a second shop across Pondfield Road with Portuguese pottery, Mexican glass, Indian dhurrie and rag rugs and rag pillows plus all manner of Christmas ornaments and decorations seasonally. Prices have been dropped by 40 to 50 per cent on holiday items and other selected merchandise and storewide markdowns of varying amounts will precede the shop's closing by Jan. 21, with the goal of moving as little as possible from the shelves to a new location on the same block. The reopening is set for Feb. 1.

title: Danger on the Film Set
description: Stuart Black's article ''Danger on the Film Set'' (Dec. 4) accurately depicts conditions and attitudes surrounding stunt filming today.

title: MUSIC: SONG CYCLE BY LEON KIRCHNER
description: Composers seem to envy Emily Dickinson her tensile rhythm and compact imagery, and perhaps this is why so many contemporary songwriters turn to her poetry, hoping with their music to equal these texts in power and beauty and form compatible partnerships with them.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In some copies of the Arts and Leisure section today, an article on page 25 about the forthcoming public-television series ''Smithsonsian World'' misstates its production budget and the nature of the underwriting. The budget, $3.5 million, was underwritten principally by the James S. McDonnell Foundation, a private family foundation.

title: A NEW YORK KEY TO JOB DOORS
description: OFFIR KILION wishes he had more time to go bicycling and Colin Baker misses playing football with buddies. But both of these New York City teen- agers are convinced that forgoing play will lead to better pay. They are among 2,000 high school students taking part in the city's two-year-old Training Opportunities Program, which was honored recently by the United States Department of Education as one of the country's 10 outstanding vocational-education programs.

title: STATE PLANS TO DELEGATE CONTROL OF WETLANDS
description: New York State is preparing to delegate to local governments most of the regulatory control of its freshwater wetlands, which cover 800,000 acres, or just under 3 percent of the total area of the state.

title: CHANGES AFOOT IN ROLES OF STATE AND LOCALITIES
description: TRENTON THE 200th New Jersey Legislature will give way to the 201st on Tuesday amid indications that the coming two- year session could bring important changes in the relationship between the state and its subdivisions.

title: THE MEANING OF CELEBRITY
ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: IF there is one saying that Phil

title: Jackson Trip Is a Gamble That Pays Off
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson was the only gambler in the drama that last week resulted in Syria's freeing a captured American Navy flier, but he was not the only winner and perhaps not even the biggest. Accompanied by Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr., the Democratic Presidential contender came home to White House congratulations and with hope, albeit uncertain, that his mission to Damascus might set off negotiations leading perhaps not to Middle East peace, but to more of it than Lebanon has known in a decade.

title: SEX AND THE MARRIED VICTORIANS
description: THE BOURGEOIS EXPERIENCE Victoria to Freud. Volume One: Education of the Senses. By Peter Gay. Illustrated. 534 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: Miranda K. Booke Is Married to George C. de Kay
description: Miranda Knickerbocker Booke, an editor at the Literary Guild, was married yesterday to George C. de Kay, founder and president of the New York book publishing company of M. Evans & Company. Justice James J. Leff of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Manhattan.

title: THE GERMAN PROBLEM
description: Only yesterday, West Germany was the embodiment of industriousness and resolve; today, it is a nation with a raging case of intellectual anomie, entrepreneurial timidity and diplomatic desperation. A Western bulwark is turning into a Western headache.

title: ARAFAT MAY MEET WITH KING HUSSEIN
description: A close associate of Yasir Arafat said today that the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization would soon meet with King Hussein of Jordan to discuss ways of realizing what he called their ''agreed target.'' The official said the objective was a confederation of Jordan and a sovereign Palestinian state.

title: YONKERS DANCE SERIES BEGINS SATURDAY
description: WINTERDANCE II, a series of four dance concerts ranging from modern to classic, opens in Yonkers at 8 P.M. Saturday, kicking off that city's 1984 Untermyer Performing Arts Festival.

title: CRIME
description: The traditional British mystery lives on. And on. And on. In the breast of every British lady writer lies a slumbering Christie or Sayers. So it is with Alison Cairns and her first novel, STRAINED RELATIONS (St. Martin's, $10.95). Here it is more Christie than Sayers. The action takes place in a quiet part of the English countryside. Characters are introduced as though there is world enough and time. They do a lot of talking, and the book is filled with the polite mur-murings of well-bred Britons. There is a murder, introduced almost apologetically. The unusual suspects abound, with the usual family tensions (hence the title of the book).

title: LOOKING BACK AT 'NICE GIRLS'
description: Even before the question is asked, Alice- Leone Moats lets loose a couple of mild swear words. Yes, Moatsie, as she is known to her friends, does swear. And always did, she says. The question of profanity is inevitable. Miss Moats is the author of ''No Nice Girl Swears,'' a sassy book of etiquette that was a best-seller back in 1933, an achievement few people have allowed her to forget.

title: SOVIET AFFIRMS ITS OPPOSITION TO RESUMING OF ARMS PARLEY
description: The Communist Party daily newspaper Pravda today dismissed Western expectations that Soviet negotiators would return any time soon to the Geneva talks on medium-range nuclear weapons.

title: TO HEAL A MENTAL ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: ZONING FOR WATER PROTECTION
description: estate developers and town and village officials are observing with interest the progress of a proposal by the Oyster Bay Town Council to upzone more than 350 acres under its jurisdiction in Jericho in order to protect ground water from contaminants.

title: IN SHORT
description: FICTION

title: Hallmark's Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Helen C. Banks to Marry Naval Lieutenant in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Banks of Bedford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Curran Banks, to Lieut.

title: Susan Miller and Michael B. Reuben, Lawyers, Marry at the Pinnacle Club
description: Susan Barbara Miller and Michael Barrett Reuben, both lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at the Pinnacle Club in Manhattan. Associate Justice Theodore R. Kupferman of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: LEGACY OF THE CONQUISTADORS
description: The Spanish conquistadors who vanquished the Aztec Empire are better remembered for the riches they took out of Mexico than for what they left behind. But the colonists did give the country a legacy in the stately haciendas they built to re-create the glories of Spain.

title: DIRECTOR'S BASE IS AT LONG WHARF
description: AFTER his successful staging of Simon Gray's ''Quartermaine's Terms,'' which moved from Long Wharf's Stage Two to Off Broadway's Playhouse 91, where it closes tonight, Kenneth Frankel's directorial stock soared.

title: MONUMENT OF MOTHER LOVE
description: Francine du Plessix Gray is the author of ''Lovers and Tyrants'' and ''World Without End.'' MADAME DE SEVIGNE A Life and Letters. By Frances Mossiker. Illustrated. 538 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: THE REGION
description: New JerseyMoves to HelpFire DepartmentsWhile the Neros of Trenton fiddle,'' Federal Judge H. Lee Sarokin said last week, ''Newark burns.'' The judge was himself fuming over a squabble that started in November, when Governor Kean proposed a $5 million bailout to help Newark and five other distressed cities avoid layoffs of police officers and firefighters. When the Legislature responded with $14 million in aid and included 329 other towns, many of them wealthy suburbs, the Governor threatened a veto. A compromise was last week and the Assembly approved a $7.4 million plan that would send $5.25 million to the Newark, Paterson, Jersey City, Elizabeth, Trenton and Camden and the remainder to other localities.

title: BALLET AND COMEDY ON NEW CASSETTES
description: Blotto; A Flock of Seagulls Sony Video 45's 13 minutes each. $19.95

title: OUR DOLLAR IN NEED OF LOSING WEIGHT
description: To the Editor:
