title: TAKING A VOCATIONAL PLUNGE ON WALL STREET
description: THE blackboard posed the question: ''How can a brokerage house be sure that what it thinks has been traded has actually been traded?'' And the teacher, Ada Dolch, fired additional questions at the 16- and 17-year-old students to elicit the answer. ''What's the difference between a compared and an uncompared trade?'' ''Why do you have a D.K. here?''

title: Miss Garrison Gains Final
description: Zina Garrison fought from a 2-0 deficit in the third set to defeat Pam Casale today and join Hana Mandlikova in the final of the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Washington tennis tournament.

title: VASSALLO FACING MAJOR TEST
description: From 1978 to 1982, Jesse Vassallo was the best individual medley swimmer in the world.

title: Matsunaga Said to Improve
description: Senator Spark M. Matsunaga, Democrat of Hawaii, who suffered a heart attack last week, was moved out of the intensive care unit at Bethesda Naval Hospital today and watched the Washington-San Francisco football game, his press spokesman said. The 67-year- old Mr.Matsunaga was reported in ''satisfactory'' condition. He was moved to the coronary care unit where he watched the game.

title: 2 MAJOR POSTS SEEN IN A RESHAPED G.M.
description: Robert C. Stempel, general manager of the Chevrolet division, and Lloyd E. Reuss, general manager of the Buick division, seem likely to head two new groups that would result from a proposed reorganization of the General Motors Corporation, according to people in the auto industry.

title: Fans in Melee After Title Game
description: At least four people were injured and a dozen arrested today following the American Conference championship game in a melee that occurred as fans charged the field and tried to tear down the goalposts.

title: NEW CHIEF OF POLICE OPERATIONS A 'TOUGH COP'
description: Robert J. Johnston Jr. has a reputation for being a ''tough cop,'' but on Friday, when he was appointed to be the New York City Police Department's new chief of operations, he had to fight hard to control his emotions.

title: ROCK MUSIC: COOL IT REBA
description: COOL It Reba, one of New York's best local rock bands, played a terse, invigorating set Saturday at the Peppermint Lounge. The quartet's songs are intricate paradoxes; while David Hansen sings about characters who are disoriented and dispossessed, he is adding guitar parts to tightly focused tunes that know exactly where they're going.

title: Dr. Hilton Read, 84, Founder Of Foreign Interns Program
description: Dr. Hilton S. Read, a New Jersey physician who started an internship program for foreign medical school graduates at community hospitals in the United States, died Thursday at his home in Thomasville, Ga. He was 84 years old.

title: EXPLORING THE CITY AROUND ITS EDGES
description: In the concrete jungle, stalking Mother Nature can be an arduous task.

title: 'RED CAPS' FIGHTING ARSON IN THE NORTHWEST BRONX
description: The Red Caps have come to the northwest Bronx. And with the arrival of the Fire Department's special arson- fighting squad, the city has moved north of Fordham Road in its efforts to keep arsonists from further devastating the borough.

title: GUIDES LIMN MANY FACES OF NEW YORK
description: For some foreign visitors to New York, a first impression of the city comes from the pages of travel guides, which provide warnings, advice and sometimes an inspired glimpse of the cityscape. Here is what some of the guides have to say.

title: EX-GRENADIAN INFORMER STILL BACKS THE CAUSE
description: The small, solidly built man of 20 said he had been an informer for the People's Revolutionary Government of Grenada and was proud of his contribution to the revolution.

title: COMPANY NEWS In Electronics, Optimism and Worry
description: In a year, laser disks may begin replacing tape decks in automobile dashboards. Beginning next summer, amateur photographers who want to see their home movies on the television screen may be able to choose from an array of smaller, lighter and less expensive video cameras. And consumers hunting for their own telephones may find many models that are indistinguishable from small computers, sporting display screens for messages that, among other things, can tell which room in a house is on fire.

title: NICARAGUA'S LABOR MINISTER: MAN IN MIDDLE, PRAISED BY BOTH SIDES
description: In a Marxist-dominated Government led by combat-hardened visionaries, Virgilio Godoy Reyes seems an unlikely Cabinet minister.

title: Watson Wins $100,000 in PGA Opener
description: Tom Watson won the $100,000 top prize today at the $1 million Seiko-Tucson Match Play Championship, the PGA Tour season opener, for his first American victory since the 1982 United States Open.

title: COPING WITH TAIWAN
description: Five years after normalization of relations between the United States and China, Taiwan remains the knottiest, most contentious issue between the two countries. Peking describes it as the principal obstacle to the further development of relations, and Premier Zhao Ziyang has said that his primary purpose in visiting America this week is to convey the ''strong sentiments of the Chinese people'' on the Taiwan question. Both capitals need to find ways of managing the issue so that it does not damage their broader relationship. This requires their both facing some basic facts.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report Dec. 22 in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page, about President Reagan's exercises, misidentified a professional wrestler. He is Andre the Giant.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Manhattan Express

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Columbia Pictures, a division of Columbia Pictures Industries, has named Robert Bookman executive vice president, worldwide production.

title: Eva Samano Is Dead at 71; Former First Lady of Mexico
description: Eva Samano de Lopez Mateos, the former First Lady of Mexico, died at Mexico City's military hospital Saturday after a series of heart attacks. She was 71 years old.

title: ARBITRAGER BENEFITS IN EAGLE STAR DEAL
description: The fine hand of Ivan F. Boesky appears in many a deal where there is money to be made on stock transactions in mergers and takeovers. Now that fine hand can be seen operating overseas as well.

title: Capitals 7, Flyers 1
description: Bengt Gustafsson scored five goals for Washington, which sent Philadelphia to only its second loss in 11 games.

title: Sanjay Gandhi's Widow Running for Parliament
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's daughter-in-law and political opponent, Maneka Gandhi, announced today that she would run for Parliament in a constituency represented by her brother- in-law, Rajiv Gandhi, who is regarded as the Prime Minister's political heir.

title: OUTDOORS: THE SKI TOW IS 50 YEARS OLD
description: SKIERS from all over the country should pause for a toast and a silent thank you on Jan. 18, for that is the 50th anniversary of the first ski tow in the United States. That rope tow, powered by a Model T Ford truck, was put up on a 640-foot high hill on Clinton Gilbert's Farm in Woodstock, Vt., and with it came the era of modern skiing.

title: Erosion Made by Man
description: American farms lose more than five billion tons of soil to the wind and rain each year. But the damage in last summer's record heat and drought was far greater, probably as bad as in the dust bowl years of the 1930's. Mother Nature is not to blame for much of that extra loss. Government policy is.

title: PRETORIA SUGGESTS TALKS WITH REBELS
description: South Africa has made a public offer of direct negotiations between its representatives ruling South-West Africa and the insurgents who have been contesting Pretoria's rule of the territory for the last 17 years.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Judge Upsets Damages In Contraceptive Suit
description: A Federal jury ruled that the Dalkon Shield contraceptive device was ''dangerously defective,'' but its $295,000 award has been overruled by a judge.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Ghosts of the Seaport Past

title: The Death Penalty's Ugly Question
description: Unable to prevail with the view that execution is always unconstitutional, the opponents of capital punishment offer a lesser but still impressive argument. They ask the courts to recognize that death sentences are much more frequent in cases where the murder victim is white rather than black.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Dubious Distinction

title: Tax-Exempt List Light This Week Activity in the tax-exempt market this week will include financings by two municipally owned utilities - the Jacksonville Electric Authority in Florida, and the Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Electric Company. Over all, the supply of new tax-exempt issues is light, with analysts at Salomon Brothers estimating that only $906 million are scheduled for sale this week.
description: The Jacksonville and Massachusetts financings are a study in contrasts, since the Florida utility relies on coal and oil-fired generation plants, while the Massachusetts utility is financing part of the Seabrook nuclear power plants, the most expensive nuclear power plants under construction. The strong financial performance of the Florida utility, plus its rating of A-1/AA, led analysts to expect that its long-term bonds will yield about 10 percent or slightly more. The problems associated with the Seabrook power plants and the recent downgrading of the Massachuseets utility to Baa/BBBx led analysts to expect its long-term bonds to yield more than 12 percent.

title: KISSINGER PANEL REPORTED TO BACK AID FOR THE NICARAGUAN GUERRILLAS
description: A Presidential commission on Central America will recommend continued American aid to insurgents seeking the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government, three commission members reported today.

title: ZUT ALORS! THE FRENCH ARE BURIED IN FRENCHNESS
description: This is a city of verbal picadors, each trying to lance the flesh of Parisian conversation. The right thrust one week draws blood and admiration; repeated a month later, the barb pierces nothing and clatters to the ground, under hoof.

title: Flier Gets a Hearty Welcome On Return to New Hampshire
description: Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr., the Navy flier recently released by the Syrians, returned to New Hampshire today and received a noisy welcome at the Manchester airport.

title: FEDERAL RIGHTS TRIAL OPENING IN DEATHS AT GREENSBORO, N.C., RALLY
description: -SALEM, N.C., Jan. 8 - Six Ku Klux Klansmen and three American Nazi Party members are to go on trial here Monday on Federal civil rights charges, more than three years after some members of the groups were acquitted in state court on charges of murdering five Communist Worker Party members at a 1979 rally in Greensboro, N.C.

title: WHAT NEW YORK CITY WELFARE FAMILIES GET
description: To the Editor:

title: Cosmos Trounce Roughnecks, 11-4
description: Alan Green scored three goals and Gerry Gray added two as the Cosmos routed the Tulsa Roughnecks, 11-4, today at Byrne Meadowlands Arena to take sole possession of first place in the North American Soccer League.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Please explain the rule governing the added line going toward first base.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''September was as if someone had turned on a spigot. Business poured in.''

title: IRONS IDENTIFIES WITH 'REAL THING' ROLE
description: THE handsome, brooding face of Jeremy Irons is familiar to millions of Americans as that of Charles Ryder, the protagonist of ''Brideshead Revisited,'' the dramatization of Evelyn Waugh's novel that ran on public television. In film, starring roles in ''The French Lieutenant's Woman'' and ''Betrayal'' helped to confirm his growing reputation as a leading man of the movies.

title: Andrea Tabot Is Wed To a Brooklyn Senator
description: Andrea Jill Tabot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Tabot of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to State Senator Martin M. Solomon, son of Susan Rose Kaplan of Valley Stream, L.I., and the late Harry Solomon. Rabbi Abraham Avrech performed the ceremony at the Park Ten restaurant in Manhattan.

title: MONDAY, JANUARY 9, 1984 International
description: An attack on United States marines in Beirut killed one of them. At least a dozen marines were fired on by unidentified assailants as they were leaving a helicopter. Two Lebanese Army soldiers were wounded when they joined the marines in returning the fire. The dead marine was identified as Cpl. Edward J. Gargano, of Quincy, Mass. (Page A1, Column 1.) Israel denied published reports that it was willing to withdraw its troops from Lebanon without a reciprocal pullout by Syria. An emphatic denial came from Dan Meridor, the Cabinet Secretary. The Israeli press published reports last week that were then circulated by United States officials in Washington that Israel had revised its policy and was willing to consider a pullout despite the presence of Syrian troops in eastern and northern Lebanon. (A1:2.)

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.66

title: SEAHAWKS FALL, 30-14
description: Inspired by the opportunity to reach the Super Bowl for the second time in four years, humbled by two regular-season losses to the Seattle Seahawks, and aroused by what they perceived as a lack of respect, the Los Angeles Raiders controlled the American Conference championship game this afternoon.

title: REAGAN'S SHAKING FIST
description: Patriotism may not be ''the last refuge of a scoundrel,'' as Dr. Johnson said it was in the 18th century. But militarism, often disguised as patriotism, is the first refuge of a bankrupt foreign policy, as Ronald Reagan is proving in the 20th.

title: POLITICS SEEMS PREDICTABLE, UNTIL...
description: Politics always seems the most predictable of enterprises until something happens. That is when this city rediscovers, yet again, how quickly its conventional wisdom gets outdated.

title: AT ROCKEFELLER U., SCIENCEIS AN ONGOING EXPERIMENT
description: On a wooded plot of land behind an elaborate wrought-iron gate at 66th Street and York Avenue, some of the world's most brilliant scientists are trying to solve such puzzles as: How does a canary learn to sing? How does a person get cancer? How does a person get fat? How do we see? What do animals think? How was life on earth created?

title: U.S. ATTORNEY STEERING OFFICE IN NEW DIRECTIONS
description: Last summer, soon after he was sworn in as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, Rudolph W. Giuliani made four unpublicized visits to the Lower East Side.

title: A HIKER'S GOOD WISHES FOR A NEW STATE PARK
description: To the Editor:

title: HOT TOPIC IN TEXAS: THE COLD
description: When people talk about the weather in Houston, it's usually about the heat, the sultry days before Houston became the most air-conditioned city in the country, when British diplomats got hardship benefits for being posted here, and how there are hotter places and more humid places, but nowhere that's quite as hot and quite as humid all at once.

title: IN FRANCE, SCHOOLS ARE EITHER 'FREE' OR 'PUBLIC'
description: To the Editor:

title: MARSHALL PLAN AGAIN?
description: The traditional, post-World War II U.S. response to crisis abroad is a massive aid program. True to form, and whatever its other contents, the Kissinger Commission report apparently will recommend perhaps as much as $8 billion in economic aid and plenty more in military aid for Central America.

title: Washington WatchPeter T. Kilborn Women Listed For Fed Post WASHINGTON
description: T HE White House is moving with deliberate

title: ; PRODS THAT DON'T ADD UP TO AN INDUSTRIAL POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Washington Bullets vs. Nets , at East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. The Nets have split their two games with the Bullets this season.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: An Honest Pitcher

title: JACKSON DRAWS LARGEST AUDIENCE YET IN WAKE OF DAMASCUS SUCCESS
description: More than 6,000 people cheered the Rev. Jesse Jackson in what was billed as a celebration of his success in winning the freedom of a Navy flier, Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr., from Syria.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 9, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SHARP GAIN FOUND FOR BLACK ELECTED OFFICIALS
description: The number of black elected officials in the country rose to 5,606 last year from 5,160 in 1982, according to a report released today by the Joint Center for Political Studies. The 1983 gain of 8.6 percent ended an eight-year decline in the rate of increase.

title: Fali Time Wins
description: Fali Time won a stretch duel with Fortune's Kingdom today to capture the $110,900 California Breeders Stakes for 3-year-olds at Santa Anita.

title: SCHOOL CHILDREN LEARN TO TREAT ANIMALS KINDLY
description: ''We're trying to make students think about the relationship between animals and humans, their responsibilities to animals,'' said Dr. Ann Squire, the new director of the education department at the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. ''Sometimes we show them the full kennels so that they can understand what abandonment is. That is very powerful.''

title: SOFTWARE OLD-TIMER, 37, AT HELM OF ARKTRONICS
description: Arktronics Inc., a computer software company started by two young men at the University of Michigan, has lured James Spillars, a seasoned manager, to be its president.

title: JAZZ: AT VILLAGE GATE, ALUMNI JOIN ART BLAKEY'S MESSENGERS
description: TO celebrate Art Blakey's 45th year in jazz and the 31st year of his leadership of the Jazz Messengers (a big band before it took its present small group dimensions in 1955), the Village Gate is presenting Mr. Blakey's current Jazz Messengers supplemented by visits from whatever alumni of the Messengers happen to be in town for two weekends, last weekend and next.

title: BAR TO CUBA DEBT PACT REPORTED
description: An agreement between 150 Western banks stretching out repayment of $130 million in medium-term debt owed them by Cuba has collapsed because of opposition by the American Express Company, according to banking sources.

title: ISLAMIC GROUP CLAIMS ROLE IN TUNIS RIOT
description: Two representatives of an outlawed Islamic fundamentalist organization here say their group helped organize last week's anti-Government demonstrations over the doubling of bread prices.

title: Denmark Electing Parliament Tomorrow
description: Danish voters elect a new Parliament Tuesday, with 13 parties running 1,139 candidates for the 179-seat Parliament.

title: SUCCESS ON THE COURT BRINGS ANGUISH FOR YANNICK NOAH
description: ''There are two tragedies in life.

title: THE RULE OF LAW (II)
description: Look underneath the headlines from Washington and you can see a movement in American constitutionalism. It is there in President Reagan's insistence that Congress cannot limit his commitment of marines to Lebanon. It is there in other expansive claims of Presidential power, and in court decisions upholding them.

title: NEW CASE OF NAZI CRIMINAL USED AS SPY BY U.S. IS UNDER STUDY
description: For the second time in a year, the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations has begun an inquiry into the use of a Nazi war criminal by American intelligence authorities after World War II.

title: CABARET: JULIE WILSON
description: JULIE Wilson has had a close relationship with Cole Porter's songs for more than 30 years, since she first played Bianca in ''Kiss Me, Kate.'' But when her own experience is supplemented by the research in Robert Kimball's recently published book, ''The Complete Lyrics of Cole Porter,'' which is the basis for her current engagement at Michael's Pub, where she will be singing for the next three weeks, it is an evening of revelations.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 75 Years of the N.A.A.C.P.

title: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be reported this week
description: Monday

title: Juilliard Will Honor Career of Louis Horst
description: The career of the late Louis Horst, the influential American dance theorist, teacher, author and composer, will be honored at the Juilliard Theater, 144 West 66th Street, at noon Thursday.

title: FRENCH OFFICIALS STILL PUZZLED BY BOMBINGS TIED TO 'CARLOS'
description: Despite their receipt last week of a letter that handwriting experts said appeared to have been written by a well-known international terrorist, officials have made little headway in their efforts to solve the New Year's Eve bombings in France that killed 5 people and wounded 50.

title: Suriname's Premier And Cabinet Resign
description: Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse, Suriname's left-wing ruler, announced tonight that Prime Minister Errol Alibux and his Cabinet had resigned and a new Government would be formed immediately.

title: 2 Gunmen and Officer Slain in Elmira Battle
description: Two gunmen who killed a police officer and wounded two others today were found dead after a shootout with the police at an apartment here, authorities said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: NEW FARE AT FOLK CITY For a quarter of a century, an eon in the lifespan of intimate entertainment forums, Folk City, 130 West Third Street (AL 4-8449), has been making music for Greenwich Village folks and others who throb to beats that may or may not be found in more general circles, fare that has ranged from pop to Appalachian. Sundays, Folk City has been trying out unmusical comedy and it has attracted such audiences that, starting tonight, the club is lacing its musical menu with helpings of other arts.

title: THE DANCE: A TALE SET IN NIGERIA
description: IT isn't every program that includes dances inspired by the

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Another Debut for Milnes

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch Dec. 28 on state laws regarding tape-recorded telephone conversations incorrectly stated the law of Georgia. The Georgia Supreme Court has ruled that the law does not prohibit one party to a conversation from secretly recording or transmitting it without the consent of the other.

title: Bridge: Variety of Disputes Covered In Booklet by Edgar Kaplan
description: Serious tournament play generates a wide variety of complex arguments that have to be resolved by directors and committees: arguments about hesitations, other unauthorized information and partnership understandings.

title: COMPUTER MAKERS' NEW MOOD
description: It is a more sober and wiser home computer industry that greets a visitor to this winter's consumer electronics show. Gone are the emphasis on cut-rate prices and the flurry of dazzling product introductions. Instead, at least the manufacturers hope, there will be profits.

title: Debussy's Preludes For Piano Performed
description: Debussy's two books of Preludes for Piano are more known about than actually played; still their fineness of rhythm, their coloration, and, above all, their unusual way of nourishing and developing tiny melodic germs create some of the most satisfying keyboard music in the literature.

title: William F. Long, 103; A Flier in World War I
description: William Frew Long, a World War I flier who went on to successful business and political careers, died Saturday at the age of 103. He was the nation's oldest retired Air Force officer.

title: Required Reading Kumquat What?
description: Item, as it appeared in the Farm Paper Letter, published by the Department of Agriculture, Dec. 16, 1983:

title: THE U.S. IS SAID TO TAKE BRIGHTER VIEW OF SYRIA
description: A senior State Department official said today that the United States no longer believed that Syria was trying to thwart an agreement on Lebanon.

title: MISS CAULKINS OUT TO REGAIN STATURE
description: Tom Caulkins was an educator and part-time swimming coach, and he thought his three children would enjoy the sport. So he had 11-year-old Tim, 10-year- old Amy and 8-year-old Tracy join a swim club.

title: STAFF AVERTS MOST SURPRISES ON MONDALE'S 5 DAYS IN SOUTH
description: As his motorcade drove into Savannah, Ga., from the airport Friday night, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale agreed to Chip Carter's proposal to pay a quick visit to Pinkie Masters' Lounge, a normally crowded hangout for local politicians and reporters.

title: PURCHASING AGENTS CITE NEW GAINS
description: The economy expanded in December for the 12th consecutive month, corporate purchasing agents said yesterday, with the group's composite index rising to its highest level in more than 10 years.

title: U.S. MARINE KILLED BY BEIRUT GUNMEN IN BEACH AMBUSH
description: A United States marine was killed today when he and at least a dozen of his comrades were fired on by unidentified assailants as they got out of a helicopter on the edge of downtown Beirut.

title: CUOMO TO PROPOSE LEGALIZED BETTING ON SPORTS EVENTS
description: Governor Cuomo will propose creating a form of legalized sports betting in New York to raise extra money for education, administration officials said yesterday.

title: Tennessee Wins Its 1,000th Game
description: Rob Jones scored 20 points and Dan Federmann 18 as Tennessee overpowered Southeastern Conference rival Mississippi, 83-59, today for its 1,000th victory in 76 years of college basketball.

title: 13 SKIERS MAKE U.S. TEAM
description: The United States Ski Association named eight men, including an alternate, and five women to its cross- country squad for the 1984 Winter Olympics today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, JANUARY 9, 1984
description: International United States-China trade ties are strengthening on the eve of Premier Zhao Ziyang's first visit to this country. The trip will dramatize Peking's growing investments in American industry. Trade between the two countries could reach between $5.5 billion and $6 billion this year, compared with $4.4 billion last year. (A1.)

title: Marilyn Baumel Wed In Jersey to a Lawyer
description: Marilyn Baumel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Baumel of Andover, Mass., was married yesterday to Robert Becker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Becker of Linden, N.J. Rabbi Herbert Weiner performed the ceremony at Temple Sharey Tefilo-Israel in South Orange, N.J.

title: MusicNoted in Brief; Rossini's 'Stabat Mater' At Alice Tully Hall
description: The American Symphony Orchestra, the Louisiana Chorale of Acadiana, the Camerata Singers of Baton Rouge and the Collegiate Chorale of New York, all under the direction of Peter Tiboris, teamed up Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall for a benefit concert to commemorate Archbishop Iakovos's 25th anniversary as Primate of the Greek Orthodox Church in the Americas.

title: GENE PASZKIET
description: Gene Paszkiet, an athletic trainer at the University of Notre Dame for 31 years, died Saturday after a brief illness.

title: MRS. MARCOS SETS CHINA ACCORDS
description: The Government announced today that Imelda Marcos had concluded cooperative agreements with top Chinese officials during a four-day visit to Peking.

title: Basques Rally in Three Cities In Protest Over Two Killings
description: Thousands of people demonstrated in three provincial capitals of Spain's Basque region today over the deaths of two reputed members of the Basque separatist group known as E.T.A. last week in southern France.

title: Jack Hunt Dies at 65; Flew Atlantic in Blimp
description: Jack R. Hunt, who was awarded a trophy in 1958 by President Eisenhower for piloting the longest nonstop, nonrefueled trans-Atlantic flight in a blimp, died at his home Saturday after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Briefing-Book Figure Called on Casey in '80
description: Three days before Ronald Reagan met President Carter in a crucial debate in 1980, a political consultant who has been questioned about how Mr. Carter's debate briefing book was passed to the Republican team visited the office of the Reagan campaign chief, William J. Casey, it was learned today.

title: HANDLING A DIFFICULT YOUNGSTER
description: THEY can be seen on playgrounds, in a neighbor's house,

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Bonanza for Track

title: Argentine Papers In Timerman Dispute
description: Jacobo Timerman's return to Argentina provoked a dispute in the Argentine press today over the assets of his newspaper, confiscated by a previous military Government.

title: GETTY DEAL COMPLETED BY TEXACO
description: Texaco Inc. announced last night that it had reached agreement with Gordon P. Getty, trustee of the Sarah C. Getty Trust, to buy the 31.8 million Getty Oil Company shares held by the trust for $125 a share, or $3.98 billion. This represents 40.2 percent of Getty's shares outstanding and gives Texaco control of the company, subject only to antitrust clearance.

title: White Sox Sign Cruz for 6 Years
description: Julio Cruz, the free-agent second baseman who last year helped the Chicago White Sox win the American League West Division, has signed a six-year contract with the White Sox, the team's owners said today.

title: ALZADO'S ADDRESS
description: LOS ANGELES WHEN the Los Angeles Raiders were about to go out for the kickoff yesterday to try to qualify for Super Bowl XVIII, Tom Flores talked to his team, as he always does. But then the Raider coach turned and nodded at Lyle Alzado, who got up from the chair at his locker, strode to the middle of the gray-carpeted locker room and addressed his teammates.

title: Article 163802 -- No Title
description: More than $100,000 in jewelry and other property was stolen over the weekend from an Upper East Side town house, the police said yesterday.

title: 49ERS BEATEN BY 24-21
description: For all their imaginative plays, their superior record and the advantage of playing on their home turf, the Washington Redskins still needed a field goal in the final minute to defeat the San Francisco 49ers today, 24-21, in the National Conference championship game.

title: '84 OLYMPIC EFFORT A GREAT LEAP FORWARD FOR CHINA
description: PEKING WHEN China went to its first Olympic Games, in Los Angeles in 1932, its squad consisted of a 100- meter sprinter, who was eliminated in the trials, and his coach.

title: PROJECT BRINGS CHILDREN HURT IN LEBANON TO U.S. FOR TREATMENT
description: When 10-year-old Fayzeh Amin was struck by shrapnel in the fall of 1982, doctors feared she would become yet another child crippled for life by the violence in Lebanon.

title: Kahane Released on Bail
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, the former leader of the militant Jewish Defense League, who escaped police custody last week, turned himself in today and was released on bail. Mr. Kahane was detained last Thursday on a charge of inciting violence against Arabs, but he walked unnoticed out of an interrogation room.

title: NO-GEAR AUTO TRANSMISSION
description: The Ford Motor Company's European unit and Fiat, the Italian auto maker, will bring out a new line of cars this year powered by a type of automatic transmission that has no gears, company officials have disclosed.

title: ISLANDERS BEATEN BY RANGERS, 5-4
description: The excitement that is usually continuous in games between the Rangers and Islanders didn't really start until 10 minutes 23 seconds had gone by in the third period last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: JAZZ: BURRAGE WITH QUINTET
description: ANYONE who has heard the drummer Ronnie Burrage as a sideman would expect him to push his own quintet hard. He did just that in his first set Saturday at Seventh Avenue South.

title: Motivation Called a Key To Violence in Schools By The Associated Press
description: A more ''attractive school environment,'' rather than ''brute force and enforcement,'' could solve the problem of violence in schools, Education Secretary T. H. Bell said yesterday.

title: Independent Sector Is Helped by O. & M.
description: The Advertising Council last week displayed a new multimedia advertising campaign created by Ogilvy & Mather in behalf of Independent Sector, a three-year-old organization that encourages volunteer help for the needy from private sources.

title: N.C.A.A. RULE PLAN GETS MODIFICATIONS
description: The American Council on Education, which has proposed the creation of a board of presidents with broad powers within the National Collegiate Athletic Association, has made some changes in its proposal in hopes of gaining votes at the association's convention.

title: U.S. LEGISLATORS AGAINST CIVILIAN AND OFFICIAL ULSTER VIOLENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: 'AMELIA' ON ABC A MOVIE ABOUT INCEST
description: AT first glance, Amelia seems to be a fairly ordinary 13 year old. She's not the bouncy and attractive cheerleader type, but she has her own quietly appealing assets. She's a bit shy but, except for a sudden moment of panic, she handles her first date rather well, enough for the boy to want to take her to the movies the following week. Yet, as the title of tonight's ABC Theater presentation at 9 warns, there is ''Something About Amelia.'' That something, it turns out, is the fact that her father has been forcing her, for about two years, to have sexual intercourse with him.

title: BRIEFING
description: Commerce vs. Defense

title: CHINA CAUTIOUSLY INCREASING ITS WORLDWIDE INVESTMENTS
description: China, on the eve of Premier Zhao Ziyang's first visit to the United States, is testing the waters of international capitalism.

title: DANCE: DEBUTS AT CITY BALLET
description: DIFFERENT ballets, along with debuts of differing quality, made their first appearance of the season with the New York City Ballet this weekend.

title: DPCC to Get Pepper's Data
description: The DPCC Acquisition Corporation announced yesterday that the Dr Pepper Company, which it seeks to buy, had agreed to grant access to financial data sought by DPCC.

title: HELPING TO HEAL THE SCARS LEFT BY INCEST
description: Patricia is 27 years old, and she is only beginning to talk about the ties of incest that bind and lacerate her family.

title: EGYPT'S ROLE AMONG ARABS
description: News Analysis

title: CONTRIBUTORS TO NEEDIEST AID THE POOR
description: With the onset and continuation of cold weather, many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund find that the most compelling reason for giving is the plight of the poor and elderly whom they encounter wandering the streets.

title: Richter Defeats Carey
description: Rick Carey of Mount Kisco, N.Y., the world- record holder at both backstroke distances, was defeated in a backstroke race tonight for the first time since 1982.

title: POP: SONGS OF BEATLES
description: WITH the 20th anniversary of Beatlemania upon us, a deluge of Lennon-McCartney retrospectives is under way. And since the original Beatlemaniacs are now in their 30's and 40's, we can expect many recyclings of Beatles music in fancy ''grown-up'' settings.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Muscles Reagan

title: SSC&B Resigns Homelite Business
description: There were a number of interesting account moves as the first week of the year came to a close.

title: WITHDRAWAL PLAN DENIED BY ISRAELI
description: The Israeli Cabinet Secretary denied today that Israel was willing to withdraw its troops from Lebanon without a reciprocal pullout by Syrian forces.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A review Friday of the book ''Dismantling America: The Rush to Deregulate'' misquoted a sentence in the book. It should have read: ''It was a classic case of industry turning to the government to restore public confidence in their products - a much overlooked function of government regulation.''

title: Chinese Lost for a Day From New Illinois Home
description: David Tom, a Chinese immigrant who never learned English and was mistakenly kept in mental institutions for 31 years, wandered away from his new home and was missing for more than a day before he turned up 10 miles away.

title: TRADE SPECIALIST HEADS A SEARS JOINT VENTURE
description: Eugene A. Sekulow, former head of RCA International, has been named president and chief executive officer of Sears Schenkers Services Inc., a new company formed by Sears World Trade and Schenkers International Forwarders. Sears World Trade is a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company; Schenkers is the American unit of Schenkers & Company G.m.b.H., a big West German freight forwarder.

title: MISS MANDLIKOVA TAKES FINAL EASILY
description: Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia won her first tournament in more than two years tonight, defeating Zina Garrison, 6-1, 6-1, in the final of the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Washington.

title: SIX JUSTICE BILLS SENT BY CUOMO TO LEGISLATURE
description: Governor Cuomo announced today that he had sent the State Legislature six bills that would caary out criminal-justice proposals he made last week in his State of the State Message.

title: CHAD'S LEADER TO SHUN TALKS
description: President Hissen Habre of Chad, apparently piqued over a welcoming ceremony given a rebel leader here, said today that he would not personally take part in peace talks that are to open Monday with Libyan- backed insurgents.

title: TO HELP HOMEOWNERS KEEP THEIR HOMES
description: To the Editor:

title: JOBLESS TURNING RESTLESS ON GRENADA WATERFRONT
description: Along the rows of bars and small restaurants that line the port here, unemployed young men pass the slow, hot hours watching women and United States patrols pass by, and talking about politics, jobs and revolution.

title: The Slow Response to AIDS
description: To the end of 1983, more than 3,000 cases of AIDS, acquired immune deficiency syndrome, had been reported across America since the strange disease first appeared in the spring of 1981. As with other new maladies, like Legionnaires' disease and toxic shock, the cause and means of prevention will doubtless be discovered in time. But while it still baffles, there is reason for a twinge of disquiet at the state of our defense against novel diseases.

title: Bel Canto Opero Offers Weber's 'Oberon'
description: No doubt, there are comic possibilities in Carl Maria von Weber's ''Oberon,'' with its tale of fairy magic, pirate abductions, Tunisian slavery and true love. Its style, combining the German ''singspiel'' with the English ''pantomine,'' lends itself to large gestures, to silent movie-type antics, to exaggerations of characters as well as theatrical conventions. In fact, this fantastical work, which Weber wrote for an English text by James Robinson Planche, cries out for a sophisticated sense of style.

title: LATIN PEACE PLAN IS APPROVED
description: Nine Latin American Foreign Ministers agreed tonight on a peace plan for Central America after deleting or amending several key proposals found in the original plan.

title: EDNA BROWN SETS 500-METER RECORD
description: Edna Brown of New York City's Atoms Track Club set a women's American indoor record today for the 500-meter run at 1 minutes 11.1 seconds in the 15th annual Dartmouth Relays at the Leverone Field House.

title: Topics In Exchange
description: Beware the Inanimates

title: OWNER OF RANGERS AND KNICKS REPEATS PLEDGE TO KEEP THEM IN CITY
description: The corporate owner of Madison Square Garden and its professional basketball and hockey teams said yesterday that it was not wavering from its 1982 commitment to keep the New York Knickerbockers and the New York Rangers in the city for at least a decade.

title: GREATER LIBERTIES TAKEN BY THE THREE NETWORKS
description: Tonight at 9, ABC-TV will topple one of network television's most formidable taboos by presenting the first film confronting incest between a father and daughter.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Electric Utility Vs. Bell Issues
description: W ALL STREET rang in 1984 with a rousing rally last week as pension funds, mutual funds and other big institutional investors poured money into the market. The broad advance was attributed to various factors, from short-covering by speculators to hopes that interest rates would decline and thereby provide further fuel for a rising market.

title: PARIS'S ELECTRONIC PHONE BOOK
description: The electronic telephone book has arrived in France, and with it the French join Britain, the United States and other countries looking for ways to bring sophisticated telecommunications into every home and office.

title: GLOUCESTER'S ALARM AT MOON'S CHURCH ABATES
description: Three years ago this fishing town was rife with rumors about ''the Moonies,'' as followers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon are known to outsiders. Members of Mr. Moon's Unification Church had bought prime waterfront property here, and the worried talk was that they were going to take over Gloucester and its fishing industry.

title: KICKING IN SAND
description: WASHINGTON WHILE the San Francisco 49ers were erasing a 21-point lead and a home crowd was having trouble singing ''Hail to the Redskins'' through throat constrictions, a solitary man in a burgundy cape kicked imaginary field goals into a portable practice net.

title: Japanese Modern Dance
description: The dance of the late Kenji Hinoki, a pioneer of modern dance in Japan, will be featured in a performance by Chizuko Kuramochi on Jan. 28 and 29 at 8 P.M. at Larry Richardson's Dance Gallery, 242 East 14th Street. Mr. Hinoki's students include Mr. Kuramochi, who will make his New York debut with the program, and the New York-based Kei Takei and Yuriko Kimura.

title: PARITY ONE FACTOR IN 76ERS' VINCIBILITY
description: Between puffs of his victory cigar after the final game last season, Billy Cunningham explained the ease with which the Philadelphia 76ers had won the National Basketball Association championship.

title: MUSIC: COMPLETING BRUCKNER'S NINTH
description: COMPLETING the Finale to Bruckner's Ninth Symphony is a bit more daring than the usual filling out of incomplete sketches by musicologists. For Bruckner's Ninth is a work that is suffused with mythic import. Its first three movements, which have defined the scope of the work, are heard as nothing less than a ''spiritual autobiography,'' a summation of a troubled composer's life, invoking his earlier music, suggesting musical trials and religious doubts made still more significant by Bruckner's impending death.

title: U.S. PANEL SAYS HUNGER CANNOT BE DOCUMENTED
description: A 13-member Presidential commission has concluded that ''hunger does persist'' in America but that ''allegations of rampant hunger simply cannot be documented.''

title: NEBRASKA BAPTISTS DEFY STATE OVER SCHOOL CONTROL
description: R. SHIPP

title: CREDIT MARKETS Rate Outlook Splits Analysts Retail, Output Data Awaited
description: Contrasting economic forecasts underlie the credit market's split outlook for interest rates. There seem to be two evenly divided camps - those expecting rates to rise this year and those expecting lower rates by mid- year.

title: MacLeish Traded To Red Wings
description: Rick MacLeish, a veteran center, was traded by the Philadelphia Flyers to the Detroit Red Wings today for future considerations.

title: BASKETBALL TOURNEY GOES TO 64 IN 1985
description: The Executive Committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association voted today to increase the field of the championship basketball tournament to 64 teams, starting in 1985.

title: Hard-Line P.L.O. Leaders Quit Executive Meeting in Tunis
description: Three hard-line Palestinian leaders flew back to Damascus today, leaving only moderate factions represented at a meeting here of the Palestine Liberation Organization executive committee, P.L.O. sources said.

title: INSIDER TRADING HARD TO MEASURE
description: Many small investors, tallying their losses over the years, must have wondered whether the deck was stacked against them. Are they simply enriching the advantaged few who have an inside line at companies?

title: Debt Issues
description: * General Cinema Corp. filed an estimated $80 million of subordinated debentures, exchangeable for a portion of the R.J. Reynolds Industries common stock that it owns, through Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc.

title: CHECKS FIND FLAW IN GRUMMAN BUSES
description: A fault in the steering mechanisms of nearly half the city's 850 Grumman Flxible buses was found this weekend, but transit officials said they expected no ''major impact'' on today's rush hour.

title: U.S. Women Take Volleyball Title
description: The United States women's volleyball team stormed back from a first-set loss to defeat world champion China, 3-1, today in the title match at the Bremen international volleyball tournament.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Skin-Care Ads Taken to Court Procter & Gamble went to

title: Advertising; Miles Labs, H.B.O. Try New Twist
description: TWO major advertisers last week previewed their new agencies' work - advertising that will take them in new directions.

title: 2 OFFICIALS SELL TIES, AND CITY REAPS PROFITS
description: At precisely 11:59 A.M. the other day, a dark blue Ford sedan pulled up to the corner of West Fourth Street and the Avenue of the Americas, where ceremonies celebrating the opening of a recycling center were about to begin.

title: Early Goals Lift Arrows to Victory
description: First- period goals by Michael Collins, Njego Pesa, Mark Liveric and Nicky Megaloudis carried the New York Arrows to a 5-3 victory over the Phoenix Pride in a Major Indoor Soccer League game tonight at Nassau Coliseum. The victory, achieved before a crowd of 6,944, was the Arrows' third straight and evened the team's record at 9-9.

title: MONDALE ASSAILS GLENN AND REAGAN ON ACID RAIN
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale today sharply criticized the environmental record of Senator John Glenn and heaped scorn on President Reagan's.

title: CommoditiesH. J. Maidenberg Exchanges Shift Tie to Eurodollar
description: T HE Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Singapore International Monetary Exchange, which plan to link operations this summer, have decided to start with Eurodollar rather than the gold futures that had been planned.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Us Publisher Leaves

title: PISTONS BEAT BUCKS, SHARE FIRST PLACE
description: Kelly Tripucka's 9 points triggered a 19-4 spurt in the third quarter to lead Detroit to a 111-100 victory over Milwaukee today, pulling the Pistons into a tie with the Bucks for first place in the Central Division of the Western Conference.

title: COPY/Dividend Meetings for Monday's paper/ J.McCue/Fin News
description: Dividend Meetings

title: CHARLES CARRYING WOLFPACK BURDEN
description: This has been a season of personal reward and critical acclaim, but Lorenzo Charles is also beginning to feel a burden of responsibility that has exceeded his expectations.

title: Jane Ellen Lederer Is the Bride of Harry Ansorge
description: Jane Ellen Lederer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lederer of Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Harry O. Ansorge, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry O. Ansorge. Rabbi Eric Gurvis performed the ceremony at the Center for Inter- American Relations in New York.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Stretching the Holiday Out

title: Briton Arrives in Egypt To Start Mideast Tour
description: Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary, arrived here today to begin a five- day tour of Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Syria, his first visit to the region since he took office in June.

title: A Former Nixon Aide Was Security Writer
description: The draft chapter on Central American Security Issues, considered one of the most sensitive topics of the report, was written by an experienced hand, Raymond K. Price Jr., a longtime associate of former President Nixon.

title: MUSIC: SMETANA PERFORMED
description: BEDRICH SMETANA'S ''Two Widows'' is a charming work, and the Bronx Opera Company's current production is well worth attention. A romantic comedy in two acts, featuring a libretto by Emanuel Z"ungel, ''The Two Widows'' was begun in 1873, some seven years after the premiere of the more famous ''Bartered Bride.'' Smetana revised the score in 1877, adding two minor characters, and transforming spoken dialogue into recitative. The present revival is a felicitous combination of both versions.

title: U.S. LEGISLATORS AGAINST CIVILIAN AND OFFICIAL ULSTER VIOLENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK CITY REPORTS '83 TOURISM WINDFALL
description: Fewer French and English accents were heard on Fifth Avenue, but a healthier United States economy brought an unexpected number of American visitors and business travelers to New York, making 1983 a surprisingly profitable year for tourism, city travel officials say.

title: TV: MOZART'S 'MAGIC FLUTE' ON PBS
description: IT is difficult to imagine an opera

title: Rozier Talks Said To Be Stalemated
description: Negotiations with Mike Rozier, the Heisman Trophy winner, are stalemated, the Pittsburgh Maulers said today. But the United States Football League team remains hopeful an agreement will be reached soon with the Nebraska running back.

title: Prices Down For Gasoline LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (AP) - The big freeze over most of the nation has driven gasoline prices down while pushing up the cost of home heating oil, an industry analyst, Dan Lundberg, said today.
description: The cost of heating oil has jumped in a range of 1.5 cents to 3 cents a gallon since early December, depending on the region of the country, Mr. Lundberg said. Meanwhile, the average price of a gallon of gas dropped 2.03 cents nationwide.

title: Fonda Center Closing
description: Jane Fonda will close her fitness center in downtown San Francisco at the end of the monthbecause vibrations caused by exercising have drawn complaints from neighbors, a spokesman for the center said.

title: Four Artists to Discuss 'From Score to Stage'
description: Beginning Feb. 2, the 92d Street Y, in cooperation with the Metropolitan Opera Guild, will present its fourth annual ''From Score to Stage'' lecture series, which this year will explore ''The Interpreter as Creator.''

title: Blues 5, Maple Leafs 2
description: Jorgen Pettersson scored two goals and the St. Louis goaltender, Mike Liut, celebrated his 28th birthday by stopping 37 shots.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ROMAN. By Roman Polanski. 461 pages. William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: MUSIC: RONEE BLAKELEY
description: -known for her luminous portrayal of a Loretta Lynn-like country star in the movie ''Nashville,'' Miss Blakeley's talents are much too idiosyncratic for her to be packaged in the Nashville cookie-cutter manner. Her original songs about growing up wild and restless in Western cowboy territory have a free-flowing narrative verve that's closer to folk music than to country.

title: Fairfield Defeats Holy Cross, 69-68
description: Pat Yerina hit a 15-foot jumper with two seconds left tonight to give Fairfield a 69-68 victory over Holy Cross in a Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference game.

title: Marini to Maine
description: star last season, has been dispatched to the Maine Mariners, the Devils' farm club in Portland, pending his clearing of waivers. The right wing and former Islander has been limited to 4 points with 2 goals and 2 assists in 32 games this season, with 47 penalty minutes.

title: EXCERPTS FROM KEAN'S STATE OF THE STATE MESSAGE
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Kean's State of the State Message to the Legislature, as issued by the Governor's office today:

title: HARRIS & PAULSON INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Braniff Filing
description: A rejuvenated Braniff International Corporation said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 2.2 million shares of common stock at between $12 and $15 a share. The stock offering, which would generate at least $26.4 million for the carrier, is the latest move in Braniff's attempt to return to service on March 1. Braniff shut down and filed for bankruptcy protection in 1982 and was reorganized through a $70 million buyout by the Hyatt Corporation, the Chicago- based hotel chain.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS CONTRADICT ISRAELIS OVER PULLOUT
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that, despite denials from the Israeli Government, it remained a ''live option'' for Israel to withdraw most of its troops from Lebanon without a simultaneous pullback of Syrian forces.

title: CYBERMEDIC INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
ALL RUNS NORMAL
description: The Transit Authority said that it had delivered normal bus service yesterday after mechanics worked through the night to fix as many Grumman Flxible buses as possible for the morning rush hour.

title: ALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
U.N. OFFICIAL ASSERTS CHINA WASTES HALF OF ITS FOOD OUTPUT
description: China could export large quantities of food to needy nations if it did not waste almost half of its food supplies because of antiquated storage methods, the head of the World Food Council said today.

title: SCHULMAN, A, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes $177,000, or 3 cents a share, of tax benefits for an investment incentive in the company's Belgian operations. All share earnings are adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split paid in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend on Nov. 30, 1983.

title: MURDOCH DISCUSSES PLANS FOR WARNER
description: The Australian publisher Rupert Murdoch told bankers here today that if he decides to wage a proxy battle for control of Warner Communications Inc., its aim would be to preserve the value of Warner's movie operations.

title: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Quaker Group Reports Rights Curbs in Grenada
description: A five-member private study group reported today that it had found restrictions on civil rights in Grenada and friction among Caribbean nations after the United States invasion of Grenada.

title: British Study Urges System To Gauge Acid Rain Increase
description: A Government study made public today urged that a nationwide system be set up to monitor increasing acid rain in Britain.

title: Florida Offering
description: A $125 million issue of the Florida Power and Light Company's 12 7/8 percent bonds, rated A-1 and due in 2014, is being offered at a price of 99 1/4, to yield 12.97 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. At the time of pricing, the bonds yielded 114 basis points (hundredths of a percentage point) more than 30- year Treasury bonds.

title: PLAYERSMalcolm Moran; Kid From Queens In the Super Bowl
description: LOS ANGELES The telephone call that Bill Pickel

title: NAVY SECRETARY SAID TO FAVOR REPRIMANDS IN BEIRUT BLAST
description: The Secretary of the Navy has recommended that military officers be reprimanded for command failures associated with the Oct. 23 truck-bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: UNICOA CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After gain on sale of investments of $1.9 million. c-After loss on sale of investments of $25.9 million.

title: SPLIT IN ADMINISTRATION ON TAX MOVES DEEPEN
description: Administration officials said today that, while President Reagan remained opposed to increasing taxes to shrink budget deficits, his top aides were deeply divided on what course should be taken.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Express Co. said its Shearson/American Express Inc. unit had agreed in principle to acquire Columbia Group, a privately held mortgage finance firm, for an undisclosed cash price.

title: Rutgers Candidate
description: The appearance of Dr. Edward Bloustein , the president of Rutgers, with Dick Anderson , the offensive coordinator at Penn State, at the New Jersey State House yesterday stirred speculation that a new football coach was in the offing for the Scarlet Knights. Not yet, university sources reported. Mr. Bloustein, who was in Trenton to seek more money for the football program, introduced Anderson to legislators as ''a candidate'' for the job. A decision is expected soon.

title: SCIENTIST SUSPECTS SHUTTLE'S GLOW RUINED HIS EXPERIMENT
description: ATELESCOPE aboard the most recent space shuttle flight looked into the heavens and drew a disappointing blank. The telescope's photographic film, when processed after the mission, was black from overexposure and totally useless, and scientists are at a loss to explain the failure.

title: Doubts on Sale Of Conrail Brokerage analysts specializing in railroads said yesterday that the possibility that the Norfolk Southern Corporation would acquire the Consolidated Rail Corporation was remote because of antitrust problems, opposition from other railroads and other choices open to the Government in disposing of the carrier.
description: Norfolk Southern said Friday that it was beginning studies ''looking toward the possible inclusion of Conrail in the Norfolk Southern system.''

title: PIANO: ROBERT SILVERMAN
description: Robert Silverman, the Canadian pianist, evidently likes to do things in a big way. Mr. Silverman's program at the 92d Street Y Sunday afternoon offered continuous opportunities for pianism on a grand scale, and he was careful to take advantage of them all.

title: TV: IS ALOCHOLISM A DISEASE OR AN ABERRATION?
description: Coincidentally, alcoholism is an issue on two television programs tonight, neither of them with much else in common. The first is ''Nova,'' the public television series, on PBS. The second is ''License to Kill,'' a two- hour movie on CBS.

title: TUESDAY, JANUARY 10, 1984 International
description: Efforts to separate factions in Lebanon appeared to have bogged down, and Government officials expressed pessimism over the chances of reaching an agreement soon. Syria, which had indicated it favored the proposed accord, appeared to have reversed itself. Also in Beirut, a French paratrooper was killed and two others were wounded in an attack by gunmen. (Page A1, Column 1.) Officers should be reprimanded for command failures associated with the Oct. 23 truck-bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut, according to a recommendation of Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr., Reagan Administration officials said. They said the recommendation, which was submitted to Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, called for the issuance of disciplinary letters. (A1:1-2.)

title: Chile-Argentina Accord On Beagle Isles Reported
description: Pope John Paul II will announce this week that Argentina and Chile have agreed to accept his 1980 proposals to resolve their century-old dispute over several small islands at the tip of South America, Foreign Ministry sources and diplomats said today.

description: Nine Red Cross volunteers have been freed by the Ugandan guerrillas who abducted them but two others are still being held, Red Cross sources said today. Freed in Uganda were three Swiss nationals and six Ugandans, who were kidnapped Saturday in the Mpigi district in southern Uganda, the sources said. A French doctor and a Ugandan Red Cross worker were reportedly still being held.

Gretzky, who increased his scoring streak to all 43 games this season and his goal total to 52, tied the league record of 10 short-handed goals in a season, set by Marcel Dionne of Detroit in 1974-75.

description: Fifteen Bedouin sheiks presented Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir with a series of complaints today about drought, postponed construction and shortages of grazing land.

description: The new chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division, J. Paul McGrath, said today that he planned to expand the use of criminal enforcement techniques, such as granting immunity from prosecution, in investigating antitrust violations.

title: MOSCOW'S MILITARY 'COSTS'
description: The Administration reportedly plans to ask $305 billion for defense in fiscal 1985 - an impressive 19 percent more than this year's appropriation. As usual, the rationale for the hike will be supposed runaway Soviet defense spending America must match. Yet the Central Intelligence Agency, in a report last fall that got too little attention, undermined the ''Russians are coming'' rationale the Administration has harped upon for three years to justify its military buildup. A more realistic Gordon Adams directs the defense budget project at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a public-policy organization. assessment of Soviet strength, and a more reasonable defense budget, are possible and urgently needed. Our defense spending has nearly doubled since 1980, rising more than 40 percent in uninflated dollars. The White House argues: ''From 1970 to 1981 the Soviets outinvested the U. S. in defense by about half a trillion dollars in constant 1984 dollars.'' This estimate of Soviet military spending and, implicitly, capabilities will not wash, as the C.I.A.'s dollar-ruble comparison has made clear. Since the Kremlin does not publicize full data on military outlays, we cannot know precisely how much its military output costs. So we invent a method to try to assess it, but, as the C.I.A. has demonstrated, that method causes us to chase a phantom spending gap. The result: illusory security.

Milwaukee Road Loan Arranged CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) - The Milwaukee Road will have a $75 million standby loan available when the railroad emerges from reorganization in United States Bankruptcy Court in 1985, its parent company said. The Chicago Milwaukee Corporation, which owns 96 percent of the railroad's stock, said it had arranged to borrow the money, if needed, through the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago and the First National Bank of St. Paul.
description: Chicago Milwaukee said in a statement that it does not expect to have to use the money, but wanted to provide ''the standby support if necessary to assure appropriate financial strength for the Milwaukee Road.'' Although the railroad has been in reorganization since December 1977, it expects to report a profit for 1983, its first from rail operations since 1966.

description: Britain began issuing plastic National Insurance cards today, despite suggestions by critics that they could be turned into identification cards storing secret information.

title: TAYLOR'S LAWYER, MEETS TRUMP
description: Donald Trump, the owner of the Generals, will meet with a lawyer for Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' star linebacker, tomorrow to try to work out a deal that could free Taylor of a personal services contract to Trump while extending Taylor's playing career with the Giants.

title: SUPER STORYLINE SHAPING UP
description: LOS ANGELES For a change, the Super Bowl has

title: Bridge: Chinese Women Get Chance In Far East Championships
description: The world's most populous country has an increasing bridge population. China, thanks to the encouragement of Deng Xiaoping, himself an enthusiast, has been actively involved in the game for the past five years.

title: A STUDY OF POLAR STORMS
description: Government researchers are launching a study of devastating Arctic winter storms, similar to hurricanes.

title: TAGO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ABE OLMAN, 95, A SONGWRITER
description: Abe Olman, a songwriter and music publisher, died Wednesday in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 95 years old.

title: THE DESPISED WOLF HAS ITS ENDEARING SIDE
description: STILL despised by farmers and feared by readers of ''Little Red Riding Hood,'' the wolf has found an ally in persistent scientists. Because of them the evidence keeps expanding to persuasively show that this snarling animal is actually among the shyest and most socially complicated of all.

title: Lawford in Alcohol and Drug Center
description: Peter Lawford has joined Elizabeth Taylor and Johnny Cash at a desert treatment center for alcohol and drug abuse, it was reported by the trade paper Daily Variety.

title: A Threat in Honduras To Kill G.I.'s Reported
description: A little-known leftist guerrilla group has threatened to ''exterminate'' 150 American military advisers and 1,200 Salvadoran soldiers training in northern Honduras, a top police official said today.

title: U.S. FOLK HERO FOR SOVIET BLOC
description: EAST BERLIN ON one wall, an American flag hangs upside down. On a shelf stands a gold record from the Bulgarian record company Balkanton for more than a million records sold in Bulgaria. On another wall, there is a signed photograph of Yasir Arafat; a separate memento shows the artist strumming his guitar with the fedayeen in southern Lebanon, a Soviet assault rifle cradled between his knees.

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: b-Including a tax credit of $653,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Arafat Arrives in Algiers
description: Yasir Arafat arrived here today from Tunis to visit Palestinian guerrillas recently evacuated to Algeria. Mr. Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, was also expected to meet President Chadli Benjedid during his stay, officials said. After the Dec. 20 evacuation of his forces from the Lebanese port of Tripoli, Mr. Arafat said one of his first objectives was to visit guerrillas loyal to his leadership.

title: REDSKINS DISPLAYED DEFENSIVE LAPSES
description: On the second of the three touchdowns the San Francisco 49ers scored in the fourth quarter of the National Conference championship game Sunday, Freddie Solomon caught a pass deep over the middle from Joe Montana and outraced the cornerback Darrell Green to the end zone.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: COSIMA VON B"ULOW never showed up at the dinner given in her honor by Nicholas VerPlank Beavers.

title: KEAN TO SEEK MORE INFLUENCE OVER PORT AUTHORITY POLICIES
description: Excerpts from message, page B6

title: INTEGRTAED SOFTWARE MAKES ITS MARK
description: PERSONAL computing seems, sometimes, to promise simplicity and deliver complexity. Hardware is not compatible with other hardware or, when it is, requires a mechanical genius to connect the pieces. Manuals are apt to be incomprehensible. Software, elaborate in its operation at best, is an almost endless source of frustration for most people.

title: U.S. SEEKS TREATY WITH THE CHINESE ON NUCLEAR TIES
description: Mr. Zhao has shown a willingness to bend Marxist ideology in an effort to put Deng Xiaoping's economic policies into effect. Page A7.

title: CITY CUTS EMERGENCY RESPONSE TIME FOR AMBULANCES TO UNDER 10 MINUTES
description: New York City's municipal ambulance service has reduced its reponse time - once the slowest of any major American city - to under 10 minutes for high-priority 911 emergency calls, officials said yesterday.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS College Basketball
description: Connecticut at St. John's , 8 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M., Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; WRTN-FM, 93.5; WGBB, 1240; 8 P.M.); Marist at St. Francis, 8 P.M.; Louisiana State at Tennessee (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M.); Stanford at U.C.L.A. (Television - ESPN, 11 P.M.). Hockey Devils vs.

title: Death of Kelp Is Laid to El Nino
description: Giant kelp beds in the Pacific Ocean between San Diego and Santa Barbara have been devastated by warm water from last winter's El Nino ocean current, threatening fishing and other industries, scientists say.

title: THE FORMER JET STAR TIED TO INSIDER CASE
description: From New York to Dallas, from southern California to South Carolina to south Georgia, William H. Mathis has a solid reputation for honesty, friendliness and business acumen.

title: Prosecutor Fights Margiotta Parole
description: The United States Attorney in Brooklyn yesterday asked the Federal Parole Commission to ''reconsider'' its decision granting early parole to Joseph M. Margiotta, the former Nassau County Republican leader. He is serving a two-year Federal prison sentence for arranging insurance kickbacks and is scheduled to be paroled April 14 after 10 months in prison.

title: GORDON GETTY'S GOAL REALIZED
description: A failure in the eyes of his billionaire father during three separate assignments in family businesses, Gordon P. Getty might be congratulating himself, at last, for the outcome of his latest whirlwind encounter with the Getty Oil Company.

title: JORDANIAN PARLIAMENT, INACTIVE SINCE 1976, MEETS
description: Jordan's Parliament, which was last convened in 1976, met today and amended the nation's Constitution to permit Palestinians from the Israeli-occupied West Bank to be appointed as members.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Sedgwick Chairman The Sedgwick Group P.L.C., Britain's largest insurance broker, has named Carel Mosselmans, 54, to succeed Neil Mills, 60, as chairman on April 1. Sedgwick also said that an executive committee had been formed to act as general manager of the group.
description: When asked the purpose of the new executive committee, Mr. Mosselmans said: ''We will try to divide responsibility as a plan for expansion. The basic principle is to move responsibility downward as far as we can to the autonomous units and give the various individual profit centers as much scope as possible.''

title: ROZIER GOES TO U.S.F.L.
description: The Pittsburgh maulers, a new team in the two-year-old United States Football League, have reportedly given Mike Rozier $1 million in advance salary and have signed the Heisman Trophy winner from Nebraska to a three-year contract reportedly worth almost $1 million a year.

title: State of the City - and the Mayor
description: The substance of Mayor Koch's State of the City address, his first in five years, is perhaps less important than his inclination to give it. The speech, a catalogue of accomplishments and a commitment to continued prosperity, revealed a vigorously optimistic Mayor, well recovered from the gloom that descended after his loss to Mario Cuomo in the 1982 race for governor.

title: Big Bad Oil: Not So Bad
description: The Texaco-Getty merger, the largest in American history, has all the elements of good boardroom melodrama: a clash of wills among the heirs of a great fortune . . . secret eleventh-hour negotiations in hotel rooms . . . angry threats of lawsuits from a losing bidder. But there is more than drama here, more at stake than which billionaire catches the brass ring. Happily, the public probably stands to benefit as well.

title: I.B.M. Settles Secrets Suit
description: The International Business Machines Corporation reached a settlement yesterday in its suit charging the National Semiconductor Corporation with stealing trade secrets worth as much as $2.5 billion. I.B.M. agreed to drop all charges and claims in return for an agreement by National Semiconductor to return proprietary I.B.M. information.

title: U.N. Says 5 Million Children Die of Hunger in Africa Yearly
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today that nearly five million African children die each year and another five million are crippled for life because of malnutrition and hunger.

title: Phone Lobby Group Set Up
description: Several major American corporations and 19 trade associations representing smaller businesses today announced the formation of a lobbying group to protest legislation that it said would add to business telephone costs.

title: BURDENSOME ASBESTOS CASES
description: S INCE the Manville Corporation filed for bankruptcy 16 months ago, smaller asbestos companies that did not choose that route have had to bear the burden of the thousands of asbestos-related lawsuits that sent Manville into Chapter 11 proceedings.

title: INTERSTATE UNIFORM SERVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
Judge Backs Congress In Ban on Coal Leases
description: A Federal district judge upheld the House Interior Committee today in its battle with former Interior Secretary James G. Watt over the leasing of Federal coal lands in Montana and North Dakota.

title: Effect on Baseball
description: Many baseball players who do not take drugs are suffering from the publicity generated by those who do, according to Tim Raines , the Montreal Expos' outfielder who was placed in a rehabilitation program when he admitted after the 1982 season that he had used cocaine. ''It puts new pressure on the ballplayers because you never know if someone is following you,'' said Raines, who led the National League in stolen bases and runs scored last year. ''Nowadays, if a player doesn't have a good season, people think he has a problem.

title: NICARAGUAN SAYS CONTADORA ACCORD IS INADEQUATE
description: Nicaragua's Foreign Minister said today that an agreement Sunday night by Central American governments on peace measures for the region was a step forward but failed to touch the roots of the problem.

title: Smoking Is Found No Longer 'Cool'
description: People pictured with cigarettes were ranked by college students as being less sexy, less honest and less mature than the same people when pictured without cigarettes, according to a study.

title: Top Executive Quits Legal Defense Fund
description: Jack John Olivero announced yesterday that he had resigned as president and general counsel of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund.

title: ADVERTISING ; Radio's 'New Waves' Gets Ocean Spray Ads
description: ''New Waves,'' a syndicated Sunday morning radio show for the 9-to- 14 age group, has got its first advertiser, Ocean Spray cranberries, through Kenyon & Eckhardt/Boston.

title: Coghlan in Millrose
description: Eamonn Coghlan , who holds the world-best indoor time for the one- mile run (3 minutes 49.78), will try to win his sixth Wanamaker Mile at the Millrose Games Jan. 27 at Madison Square Garden. Coghlan, the Millrose winner in 1977, 1979, 1980, 1981 and 1983, will be trying to match the record of six Millrose victories set by Glenn Cunningham in 1933, 1934, 1935, 1937, 1938 and 1939. Other announced entrants in this year's race are Steve Scott , the 1982 winner and American record-holder, Tom Byers , Ross Donoghue and Frank O'Mara.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Reaching Out for Repairs

title: MAN WITH 'GUILTY CONSCIENCE' GIVES UP IN KILLING
description: A 24-year-old man walked into a police station yesterday and confessed to being the gunman who had gone on a 15-minute two-block rampage in midtown Manhattan in 1981, killing a teen- ager on the street, the police said.

title: PENTAGON IS SAID TO FOCUS ON ESP FOR WARTIME USE
description: THE Pentagon has spent millions of dollars, according to three new reports, on secret projects to investigate extrasensory phenomena and to see if the sheer power of the human mind can be harnessed to perform various acts of espionage and war - penetrating secret files, for example, locating submarines or blowing up guided missiles in midflight.

title: MEMORIAL SERVICE AT HARVARD SET FOR CHARLES BRENTON FISK
description: A memorial service for the organ builder Charles Brenton Fisk will be held in Memorial Church of Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., on Jan. 21 at 2 P.M. Mr. Fisk died on Dec. 16 in Boston. He was 58 years old.

title: URBANE GUEST FROM PEKING
description: With his smart business suits and scholarly horn- rimmed glasses, Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang, who arrived in Washington today for the start of talks Tuesday with President Reagan, hardly looks like the tough administrator of the world's most populous nation. His talent, first in the provinces and now at the center of power, has been to dare to try something different.

title: 3 Killed in Fire Near Casino Strip
description: Three people were killed and five were injured today after an arsonist set a fire that damaged a four-story brick apartment building two blocks from the casino area on the Boardwalk, the authorities said.

title: CONCERT: JOEL KROSNICK
description: THE cello, with its throbbing baritonal voice, might seem by nature and temperament the quintessential Romantic instrument. For many listeners, merely hearing the bow drawn slowly across a cello string is enough to set off evocations of lonely hearts and lost loves. However, Joel Krosnick and Gilbert Kalish, who last night at the Juilliard Theater embarked on a six-concert series entitled ''The Cello: A 20th Century American Retrospective,'' proposed to show that the instrument also feels quite at home speaking the multifarious languages and dialects of our eclectic time. Mr. Krosnick, the Juilliard String Quartet's cellist, and Mr. Kalish, his pianist in this ambitious series, have developed programs that include works in a wide variety of styles, from early in this century right up to the present moment.

title: BARRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: 7TH AVENUE LOOKS TO SUMMER
description: Summer is the immediate concern of Seventh Avenue designers and manufacturers as the new year gets under way, but the situation is not that clear-cut. The summer collections also include fashion segments called ''transition'' and even some called ''early fall.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Message From the Met

title: MUSIC: VIOLINIST AND PIANIST
description: The violinist Michael Barta and the pianist Jeffrey Uhlig offered a collaborative program of chamber music Sunday evening in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: FIDELITY MEDICAL SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $25,762 from discontinued operations and a gain of $223,037 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $137,454. Year-ago results have been reclassified for comparative purposes.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Ties and More Ties

title: MCENROE IS STAKING HIS CLAIM TO NO. 1
description: John McEnroe is still perceived by many as the punk kid of tennis, but he has been around long enough to be one of the senior citizens at the $400,000 Volvo Masters. Yesterday, on the eve of the Madison Square Garden event, he offered some cogent comments on the tournament and the debate it has inspired about who deserves the top ranking for 1983.

title: Pact With Fujitsu
description: Fujitsu Ltd. and Texas Instruments Inc. said they had agreed to cooperate in the production of semiconductors. The companies said Fujitsu would supply Texas Instruments with its gate-array integrated circuits design and fabrication technology. Fujitsu will have an option to use computer-aided design tools made by Texas Instruments for gate-array products.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: BOOM TIMES The boom of the period during which Chinese ceramics entered one of its most creative times was the boom of arms during a war that diverted traditional subsidy money for this elegant art and freed potters to pursue their own designs different from those usually ordered by the Imperial Court.

title: PROFILES OF MISSING CHILDREN SHOWN ON TV By The Associated Press
description: In a project inspired by ''Adam,'' the television movie about the abduction and murder of a 6-year-old Florida boy, five NBC television stations last night began showing weekly profiles of missing children.

title: KEY PRESIDENTIAL BUFFER LOOKS BACK
description: After three years as President Reagan's director of communications, David R. Gergen is leaving to do some teaching, thinking and writing about his sometimes turbulent experiences at the White House.

title: GLENN ASKS ACTION ON PROLIFERATION
description: Senator John Glenn, declaring in a campaign speech that the world faced the prospect of ''being held hostage by state- supported nuclear terrorism,'' today presented a nine-point program aimed at curbing the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Tunis Protests to Libya Over Oil Pipeline Attack
