description: A four-man commando team drove from Libya into southern Tunisia, blew up a section of oil pipeline, and returned to Libya, the Tunisian Government said today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES Hospital Bonds In Ada, Okla. A $33.5 million bond issue for the Valley View Hospital Authority in Ada, Okla., was tentatively priced by an E. F. Hutton group with a maximum yield of 10 percent for bonds due in 2014. Among shorter- term maturities, yields ranged from 7 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 9 percent in 1995 and 9 7/8 percent in 2004.
description: The bonds were rated AAA by Standard & Poor's because of an insurance policy issued by the Industrial Indemnity Company, a unit of Crum & Forster, the nation's 14th-largest property and casualty insurance group. Industrial Indemnity insures bond issues that have been analyzed and organized by American Health Capital Management Inc.

title: LINEAR INSTRUMENTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STATES CONCERNED ON STUDENT LOANS
description: Officials at state agencies that channel funds into student loans assert that efforts by the Department of Education to reduce the Government's costs on guaranteed student loans will reduce the availability of such loans for the next school year.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: ORION PICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $46,000. c-After loss from discontinued operations of $304,000.

title: WILLIAM FRANKLIN BALL
description: The Rev. William Franklin Ball, bishop of the African Methodist Church for Tennessee and the church's oldest active bishop, died of a stroke Saturday. He was 82 years old. Bishop Ball, who , lived in Nashville, was on a vacation here with relatives, church officials said.

title: Fotomat Debt
description: The Fotomat Corporation, which had been asked to repay $12.5 million in bank loans by Dec. 31, said it is working on a plan to restructure the debt arrangements. The film-processing company said it hoped the plan could be concluded within 60 days. Fotomat said that it has sold its losing peripheral businesses, established a central headquarters, reduced its retail network to a core of markets covering 55 percent of the nation's households, and adjusted its marketing strategy to improve products and speed services.

title: ; WHERE ARABS AND JEWS LIVE IN FREEDOM AND PEACE
description: T o the Editor:

title: Mr. Wick's Public Disservice
description: After two weeks of evasion and denials, Charles Wick finally admits he secretly taped and transcribed phone calls during most of his two years as director of the United States Information Agency. He's sorry - and should be. Mr. Wick has shown the arrogance of someone who thinks he is immune from the rules that govern the rest of us. He has badly served both the authority and the friendship of his patron, the President. He has set a terrible example for public servants.

title: KNICKS TROUNCE 76ERS BY 111-73
description: The Knicks shut down the Philadelphia 76ers' offense and kept Moses Malone off the boards last night as they overwhelmed the 76ers, 111-73, before a capacity crowd of 19,591 at Madison Square Garden.

title: KEY LEGISLATORS URGING PRISON SYSTEM CHANGES
description: Two key lawmakers urged today that a certain percentage of experienced prison guards be required at all maximum security prisons in the state.

title: HEALTH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $189,000 for the quarter and $308,000 for the 9 months and net income of $132,000 for the quarter and 9 months from discontinued operations. c-Net loss.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH MERIT PAY?
description: THE outcry by teachers' organizations against merit pay may puzzle, and even offend, Americans brought up on the idea that merit should be rewarded. People may wonder why merit pay has become such a fighting word, just when the public has at last recognized how urgent it is to spend more money for teachers of higher quality.

title: U.S. News Bid
description: U.S. News & World Report Inc. announced it had hired the New York investment banking firm of Morgan Stanley & Company to evaluate its worth and advise it on its alternatives in light of a bid to buy the publishing house. The company, which is employee-owned and publishes the newsweekly magazine U.S. News & World Report, disclosed last month that it had received a purchase offer from an unidentified third party.

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The loss in the latest quarter and year resulted from providing a $6,188,000 after-tax valuation reserve on the company's drilling rigs.

title: GRANDMA LEE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: TACO VIVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Alaska Air Issue
description: A $10 million issue of Alaska Airlines 9 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2003, is being offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The debentures may be converted at any time into common stock at a price of 18 1/8 a share. Alaska Airlines stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 14 1/4, unchanged from Friday.

title: ORANGE'S OIL SHOWS PROMISE AS INSECTICIDE
description: IN a cage full of houseflies, scientists placed an orange. Nothing

title: HLH PETROLEUM CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: TV for the Blind

title: RITA LAVELLE GETS 6-MONTH TERM AND IS FINED $10,000 FOR PERJURY
description: Rita M. Lavelle, former chief of the Environmental Protection Agency's toxic waste programs, was sentenced today to six months in prison and fined $10,000 for lying to Congress.

title: Molesting Case Dropped As Child Remains Silent
description: A judge dismissed child molestation charges against a man today because the 12-year-old involved, his stepdaughter, refused to testify for the prosecution even though she had been held in solitary confinement eight days.

title: Castle & Cooke
description: The United Financial Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it intends to increase its stake in Castle & Cooke Inc. to more than 15 percent of the company's outstanding shares. United Financial already owns 5.4 percent of the food-products company's shares. Castle & Cooke, which is trying to buy the Dr Pepper soft-drink company, said in a separate statement that it had retained Kidder, Peabody & Company to assist it in restructuring its real estate holdings and development activities ''with a view to realizing their value to Castle & Cooke and its shareholders.''

title: A WICK PARLEY WITH NO HINT OF PARTY POLITICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlotte Curtis
description: Spectacular Olympics Party

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;  Dean Witter Executive Joins Oppenheimer Francis H. M. Kelly, chairman of the investment policy committee at Dean Witter Reynolds, has joined Oppenheimer & Company as director of research, Oppenheimer announced yesterday.
description: Mr. Kelly, 46, succeeds Burton Fingerhut, 40, an outdoors enthusiast who after 19 years has left the firm to go hiking the world over. Mr. Fingerhut was among Oppenheimer executives who profited in the sale of the firm to Britain's Mercantile House.

title: LACK OF COPYRIGHT IN CHINA DISTURBS U.S. AUTHORS
description: When his hosts in China presented E. L. Doctorow with the Chinese version of his novel ''Ragtime,'' he had mixed emotions. ''I said I was delighted that they found merit in it for a Chinese audience,'' Mr. Doctorow said recently, ''then I said I was disturbed that I had not been given the courtesy of knowing they were going to publish it.''

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Pollution and Plant Pests

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allied Stores Corporation has appointed Ralph Nofi president of its Allied Stores Marketing Corporation.

title: IS ANYBODY HUNGRY?
description: Is anybody out there hungry? If so, write immediately to the White House. The occupants are ''perplexed'' by reports of underfed citizens and have said that ''if there is one person in this country hungry, that is one too many.'' Once they get the information, these puzzled occupants say, they want to do something about it.

title: CONCERT: BAROQUE WORKS AT ST. JOSEPH'S
description: THE last movement of the Sonata No. 5 by Georg Muffat (1653-1704) is a passacaglia; it is skittish and exuberant. The figuration playfully weaves about and is varying while underneath a repeated bass line gives it foundation.

title: IRMA WOLPE
description: Irma Wolpe, a pianist and teacher, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 81 years old.

title: SCOUTING
description: Divided Loyalties

title: ALUMINUM ISSUES FAVORED
description: A LUMINUM stocks have shone brightly among the metals since the bull market began in August 1982, and some Wall Street firms envisage further gains this year.

title: ISSUE AS DANES VOTE: A MAJORITY AT LAST?
description: It is widely believed here that Denmark's Prime Minister, Poul Schluter, will be returned to office as a result of the national election on Tuesday. Officials here say the real question is whether he can turn his personal popularity into a working majority in Parliament.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You have indeed violated the public trust. The perjury offense strikes at the very core of the trust that had been conferred to you.''

title: Honda Ohio Expansion
description: The Honda Motor Company plans a $240 million expansion of its Marysville, Ohio,

title: CLAYTON SILVER MINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Comparable year-ago third quarter results were not reported because of low silver prices. c-Net loss.

title: MSGR. JOHN M. BALL
description: Msgr. John M. Ball, a leader in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rochester for more than 50 years, died Sunday.

title: Biegenwald Trial Is Ordered Moved
description: A Superior Court judge ordered that the second murder trial of Richard F. Biegenwald, to be held next month, be moved from Monmouth to Burlington County.

title: STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BROKEN PROMISE TO A CITY'S ABUSED CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL ELECTRONICS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $735,000. c-Net income.

title: INTERDYNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ARGENTINE EX-CHIEF SNUBS COURT
description: Gen. Reynaldo Bignone, who was President of Argentina for 17 months, failed again today to appear in court to testify about the 1978 disappearance of a scientist.

title: KEVLIN MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
JACKSON FAILS IN BID TO WOO CHICAGO MAYOR
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, returned to his home city today amid cheers for his role in the release of a captured Navy flier from Syria. But he also tackled a muddled political situation centering on whether he will have the support of the city's black Mayor or even an identifiable slate of delegate candidates pledged to him in the Illinois primary March 20.

title: THEATER: 'FRIENDS' BY LEE KALCHEIM
description: THOUGH they were great pals as Yale undergraduates, the two aging buddies who reunite in Lee Kalcheim's ''Friends'' seem to be an utterly mismatched odd couple. Okie (Craig T. Nelson), who grew up on an Oklahoma farm, is now a fast-rising diplomat at the United Nations. Mel (Ron Silver) is a frazzled New Yorker who has bounced through ''umpteen'' careers, finally to end up in Vermont as a freelance cartoonist. While Okie has a wife, two kids and a Mercedes, Mel has only one-night-stands, a runaway pet mutt and a beat-up jalopy.

title: The Mayor and Miss Ida
description: The stage, in a Bronx home for the elderly, was makeshift and the audience was confused, glassy- eyed. Yet within minutes the spirit turned electric. A volunteer troupe of schoolchildren, trained by a program called ''Magic Me,'' danced in and out among the wheelchairs. Slowly, the stares turned to grins. Wrinkled hands started clapping to the rock beat. The nurses turned, incredulous, toward a stroke victim. ''Look at Miss Ida!'' one said. ''Call the doctor to come and see!'' Miss Ida, though nearly paralyzed, was smiling - and, with two fragile fingers, was tapping out the beat.

title: Soviet Player Pursued
description: He was the 138th player selected in the N.H.L. draft, and his seventh- round selection by the Montreal Canadiens was considered something of a long shot, but Montreal officials say they are confident that Vladislav Tretiak , the star Soviet goaltender, will switch to a Canadien uniform after the Winter Olympics. Serge Savard , the Canadiens' general manager, said he and other Montreal officials would attend the Winter Games in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, and might go to Moscow afterward in an effort to sign the 31-year-old star.

title: FORMER PRESIDENT HELD IN ARGENTINA
description: Former President Reynaldo Bignone was arrested tonight in an investigation into the disappearance of two army conscripts, both Communists, in 1976.

title: PANEL SEES SAVING OF $58.9 BILLION IF I.R.S. IS NOTIFIED OF AID TO NEEDY
description: A Presidential panel recommended today that a W-2-type form be issued by each Federal agency that provides benefits to individuals so that Government programs can be reduced and redirected to the ''truly needy.''

title: City Takes Steps To Fight Storm
description: As a fast-moving snowstorm swirled across the metropolitan area, the city's Sanitation Department sent 333 salt spreaders and more than 100 snow plows out to roads and bridges last night. Another 467 plows were ready to be dispatched if it snowed through the night as expected, a department spokesman said.

title: Reactor Pact in Europe
description: Five Governments of Western Europe have signed an agreement to coordinate research on fast breeder nuclear reactor programs, Industry Minister Laurent Fabius said today. The accord by France, West Germany, Britain, Italy and Belgium does not provide for common development of a new generation of reactors.

title: PLAYSAlex Yannis
description: The Nets have rarely been able to

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Purveying Pizza And Staying Thin

title: OSTEOPOROSIS: DEBILITATING BONE CONDITION CAN BE PREVENTED
description: A QUESTION often asked, especially by women, is, ''How much milk should I drink every day to get enough calcium?'' The answer, which often elicits a gasp, is you should consume as much calcium as there is in five glasses of milk. Few Americans, at least few adult Americans, come anywhere near that level of calcium intake. And the statistics on osteoporosis and broken bones show that we are paying a high price for our neglect of this vital nutrient.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net for the 1982 year reflects a gain of $2.5 million from the sale of Popular Bank of Florida's stock during the second quarter.

title: APARICIO AND KILLEBREW PICKD FOR HALL OF FAME
description: Luis Aparicio, Harmon Killebrew and Don Drysdale were elected to baseball's Hall of Fame last night, the largest group of players picked in 12 years.

title: Hospital
description: The board of governors of the Greater New York Hospital Association yesterday named Kenneth E. Raske as president. Mr. Raske, formerly senior vice president of the Michigan Hospital Association, succeeds Dr. S. David Pomrinse, who retired. The association represents private, nonprofit hospitals and public hospitals.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TIME AFTER TIME. By Molly Keane. 249

title: MONCHIK-WEBER CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Whittaker Fee
description: Saudi Arabia has paid the Whittaker Corporation $72 million as ''partial payment'' for health services and supplies after ending a three-year contract. Whittaker, which can bid for the new contract, gets 81 percent of its operating profits from the Middle East, mostly from Saudi Arabia.

title: KRIEK OVERCOMES ARIAS IN MASTERS OPENER, 7-6, 6-4
description: Jimmy Arias knew enough not to expect much. He had earned one of the 12 spots in the Volvo Masters tennis tournament for the first time, but the timing could not have been worse. At age 19, he was making his first appearance at Madison Square Garden, and his preparation had been weeks spent in bed in Buffalo while he recovered from mononucleosis.

title: COASTAL INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,283,000, or 72 cents a share.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the most amusing cooking techniques I have encountered was suggested eight or nine years ago in an advertisement promoting travel to Italy. Mentioning a restaurant in Amalfi, it said: ''Unless you've been to the Trattoria di Ciccio, you don't know how spaghetti should taste. First, Ciccio makes a sauce with clams. Next he boils some spaghetti. Then he puts both things in a paper bag, folds it shut and heats it in an oven. What comes out of that paper bag isn't just spaghetti with sauce on it. But spaghetti with sauce in it.''

title: COMMUNICATIONS & CABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
KEAN'S ADDRESS INDICATES TRANSIT FINANCING WILL BE KEY ISSUE
description: Behind the ceremony of the start of the new legislative session and the renewed pledges of bipartisan cooperation that Governor Kean and legislative leaders exchanged today, the stage was set for a new confrontation over how to finance transportation improvements.

title: IN MEXICO, SPECIALTIES OF THE HOUSE
description: ZITACUARO, Mexico IF Diana Kennedy feels blessed in her new home

title: JAZZ: OLIVER LAKE QUINTET
description: THE saxophonist Oliver Lake used his first local quintet engagement in recent years to try a conventional jazz format. His first set Sunday at Sweet Basil featured a fast tune, a ballad, a vamp and a bluesy tune, each with a round of solos.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOK PRIZE GIVEN
description: (AP) - Beverly Cleary's ''Dear Mr. Henshaw,'' a book about a boy dealing with problems ranging from lunchbag thieves to a lost dog to his parents' divorce, has been chosen by a librarians' group as the children's book of the year.

title: EVA LE GALLIENNE STILL STAGE-STRUCK AT 85
description: As dusk begins to fall, Eva Le Gallienne leaves her fireside chair, her lap dog and her tea and goes briskly to the little greenhouse beside her kitchen. Taking a small wooden trough, she cuts up a thick slab of tongue with gardening shears, rips a loaf of bread into small pieces and arranges chicken bones around the growing mound, poking and fussing until the food is artfully distributed.

title: RIGHTS GROUPS CALL U.S. POLICY 'LITANY OF FAILURE'
description: Three human rights groups criticized the Reagan Administration's human rights policy this week as a ''litany of failure.'' They accused Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, of acting as an ''apologist'' for many nations that commit rights abuses.

title: HOVNANIAN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $262,000 for the quarter and $517,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $261,000 from discontinued operations.

title: BRIEFING
description: All Aboard for Grenada

title: Security Pacific's Duff & Phelps Bid LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (AP) - The Security Pacific Corporation said it plans to buy the investment company Duff & Phelps Inc. for more than $35 million.
description: Duff & Phelps offers investment research, credit ratings and investment management. It is based in Chicago and also has offices in Cleveland.

title: A $125 Million Jersey Issue
description: A $125 million issue of New

title: Coleco Production
description: Employees at Coleco Industries here are returning to work after a six- day annual inventory, but a spokesman, when asked if all the workers would be rehired, said, ''It depends on how the production schedules crank out.'' On Dec. 30, Coleco said it planned to lay off hundreds of workers from its plant here, which makes the Adam home computer and packages the Cabbage Patch Kids dolls. The plant had 4,000 workers.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 23
description: b-Net loss.

title: LIVE IN 'SIN' AND SAVE
description: To the Editor:

title: DEFENSE EXPECTED TO DEPICT U.S. JUDGE AS A VICTIM
description: Pretrial motions filed in the last two days indicate the defense in the trial of Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne will be built on the contention that he is the victim of a ruthless persecution of Federal officials who lost rulings in his court.

title: Martin Says He's Eager To Serve the Yankees
description: looking even after having lost 23 pounds, said yesterday that he had not touched a drop of whisky in almost six months and could, if he wished, spend the rest of his life counting his money in a rocking chair on his front porch. But that isn't what he has in mind.

title: New Chief Picked By A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: Edward J. Cleary was elected president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. yesterday, succeeding Raymond R. Corbett, who resigned last month after 22 years in the federation's top post.

title: ACCORD ASKED ON REPORTING OF U.S. MILITARY OPERATIONS
description: In a display of unity prompted by restraints on coverage of the invasion of Grenada, 10 major news organizations asked the Reagan Administration yesterday to affirm as a matter of principle that reporters will be allowed to cover United States military operations.

title: Blue Jays Sign Lamp
description: Dennis Lamp , the right-handed reliever whose 7 victories and 15 saves helped the Chicago White Sox win the American League West championship last year, signed a five-year contract with the Toronto Blue Jays that, he said, could earn him $1 million in salary and performance bonuses next season. Lamp, a free agent, said the Blue Jays had offered ''far more'' than the Texas Rangers and the Baltimore Orioles, who had also been trying to sign him.

title: Dallas Is Getting Team in M.I.S.L.
description: DALLAS, Jan. 10

title: TV: JANE GOODALL 'AMONG THE WILD CHIMPANZEES'
description: FOR the most part, ''Among the Wild Chimpanzees,'' a National Geographic special, is about exactly what you think it is about: chimpanzees at home, messing around, carrying on, getting through life. The other parts are about Jane Goodall, or Jane Goodall and her relationship with chimpanzees. Miss Goodall, a remarkable British naturalist, has observed, befriended and pondered them for years. The program will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 tonight.

title: Market PlaceSteve Lohr More Gains Seen in Japan TOKYO
description: B Y tradition, stock trading begins here each year only after a hand-clapping ceremony on the floor of the exchange. Thousands of people take part, from scruffy floor traders to kimono-clad women, all trying to invite prosperity. This year, they must have done something right.

title: GOVERNMENT FEEDS HUNDREDS LEFT JOBLESS BY TEXAS FREEZE
description: Scores of hungry farm laborers and their families, thrown out of work by a freeze that devastated the winter's citrus and vegetable crops, left long unemployment and charity lines tonight for a free dinner on the government.

title: HOME CENTERS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company was formed in March 1983.

title: EMULEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
Guides Are Endorsed For Artificial Heart
description: A University of Utah panel today authorized revised guidelines for implanting an artificial heart in a second human.

title: Lost Papers No Bar to Suit
description: A Federal judge has refused to dismiss a Government suit against First Jersey Securities Inc., despite the disappearance of 220,000 pages of company records from a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing room.

title: TOWER SAYS WITHDRAWING TROOPS IN LEBANON WOULD BE DISASTROUS
description: Senator John Tower, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, who returned Monday night from a weeklong trip to the Middle East, said today that a withdrawal of American troops from Lebanon now would be ''disastrous.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Koch Offers Critics Tour of Shelters

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT was the custom years ago for funeral processions to make a brief stop on the way to

title: NORTH KOREA PROPOSES TALKS
description: North Korea has proposed a conference with the United States and South Korea aimed at unifying Korea, the Pyongyang radio said today.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Courses Related to Food

title: TEST SHOWS EARLY STAGES OF CONDITION
description: Although osteoporosis is usually not detected and treated until the disease is well advanced and serious fractures have occurred, there are relatively simple tests that determine who may be suffering from the early stages of the disease. These tests, performed by a radiologist, measure the density of the bones in the spine.

title: Combination of 0000 WinsaJerseyLottery
description: The winning number in New Jersey's Pick 4 lottery last night was 0000.

title: Special Concert Series For Schoolchildren
description: More than 1,800 elementary-school students from the New York metropolitan area will participate in a special concert series at the 92d Street Y beginning Feb. 3.

title: Lawyer Indicted In $275,000 Theft
description: A Manhattan lawyer was indicted yesterday on charges that he stole $275,000 from an 83-year-old widow and her estate because he needed money to support his drug habit.

title: BRIEFS
description: Alhambra Mines Inc., a mining and exploration company based in Reno, said its Gold Run Mining subsidiary had received a notice of default from creditors for failing to make a $97.6 million payment due Dec. 15.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in February 1983 and a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August 1983.

title: DOW DECLINES BY 7.74, TO 1,278.48
description: Stock prices finished moderately lower yesterday in accelerated trading as profit taking weakened the list for the second consecutive session.

title: 'EL NORTE,' PROMISED LAND FOR GUATEMALANS
description: A SMALL, personal, independently made film with the sweep of ''El Norte,'' with solid, sympathetic performances by unknown actors and a visual style of astonishing vibrancy, must be regarded as a remarkable accomplishment.

title: Ex-Senator Church of Idaho Is Hospitalized in New York
description: The Associated Press

title: New World Pictures Names Chief Executive Robert Rehme, who recently left the presidency of MCA-Universal's theatrical motion picture division, has been named to the newly created post of chief executive of New World Pictures.
description: Mr. Rehme, 48, said yesterday that he had acquired an interest in New World and would be one of three principal owners, along with Harry Evans Sloan and Lawrence L. Kuppin. The three will be co-chairmen. Mr. Sloan and Mr. Kuppin bought the business last year from Roger Corman, the producer-director.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WARSAW PACT PROPOSES CHEMICAL ARMS TALKS
description: The Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies proposed to the Atlantic alliance today to negotiate a ban on chemical weapons in Europe.

title: 'TECHNICAL' POINTS DELAYING DISENGAEMENT IN LEBANON
description: King Hussein has increased the number of Palestinians in his Cabinet and in other key posts, the Government announced today.

title: 3 Groups Realigned At Simon & Schuster
description: Simon & Schuster announced yesterday a restructuring of three publishing groups - trade, juvenile and reference books.

title: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 11, 1984 International
description: Washington and the Vatican established full diplomatic relations for the first time in 117 years. The action was described by spokesmen for the Reagan Administration as aimed at improving communications at a time when Pope John Paul II has become increasingly involved in international affairs. (Page A1, Column 6.) Many Protestant groups, some Jewish groups and some civil liberties organizations criticized the re-establishment of full diplomatic ties between the United States and the Vatican. (A4:4-6.)

title: FOR ALL NON - WALKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 South Koreans Arrested
description: The police have arrested a Christian pastor and two former college professors accused of spreading Communist propaganda. The police said today that the three were Cho Seung Hyok, 49 years old, director of the Christian Research Institute of Korea for Social Affairs; Lee Yong Hi, 54, a former professor at Hanyang University in Seoul, and Kang Man Kil, 51, former professor at Korea University.

title: Corsican Separatists Threatening Teachers
description: A schoolteacher from Marseilles fled from Corsica with his family today after receiving death threats from the National Front for the Liberation of Corsica.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: U.S. May Face Tax Reprisals
description: The United States could face reprisals if American states persist in taxing the worldwide income of foreign-based companies operating within their borders, a spokesman for a European industry group said today. The spokesman for the Union of European Community Industries said countries whose companies were hit by the unitary tax system could be prompted to renegotiate double taxation agreements with the United States, with adverse effects on American corporate subsidiaries in Europe.

title: Braves' Pitcher Held for Drugs
description: Pascual Perez, the Atlanta Braves pitcher, was arrested today in Santiago on charges of possessing a half-gram of cocaine with intent to distribute it, the police here said.

title: Some Electricity Cut Off To Suriname's Capital
description: Bauxite miners demanding the resignation of Suriname's military ruler cut electricity to parts of the capital today, and soldiers seized an electric plant to prevent a total blackout.

title: FORD GIVES GO-AHEAD IN MEXICO
description: Citing new Mexican requirements for its auto industry, the Ford Motor Company today made official its plans to build a $500 million stamping and assembly plant in Hermosillo, Mexico.

title: HOUSTON WINS 13TH
description: Reid Gettys scored 12 points to lead Houston to a 69-58 Southwest Conference victory tonight over Texas.

title: DANISH PREMIER WINS VOTE BUT FAILS TO GAIN A MAJORITY
description: Prime Minister Poul Schluter's Conservative People's Party scored significant gains in today's national election, but his four-party coalition was denied a working majority in Denmark's Parliament.

title: BALDWIN SECURITIES CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New Unit for Ill Children

title: Frank X. Tolbert, 72, Is Dead Columnist and Chili Fancier
description: Frank X. Tolbert, a longtime newspaper columnist and lover of chili who originated the Terlingua world championship chili cookoffs, died at home Monday night, a business associate said today. Mr. Tolbert was 72 years old.

title: Decision Reversed
description: Edwin Curet's victory Friday night over Ken Bogner in a lightweight boxing match was reversed today by the New Jersey State Athletic Commission.

title: THE BASIC OBJECTION TO UNITARY TAXATION
description: To the Editor:

title: MGM-UA HOME ENTERTAINENT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
STAGE: 'STRANGE AWAY' BY BECKETT, AT LA MAMA
description: ''NO way in, none out.'' In Samuel Beckett's ''All Strange Away,'' a man is caged in a hollow glass rotunda, like a ship model inside a bottle, surrounded by mirrored walls and by the sound of his own voice. He is talking to himself to death. In this Dantean vision of ''a place to die in,'' when words ebb, the world ends. Fade to black.

title: Advertising; A Heroic Computer Campaign
description: WHEN it came time for Robert J. Amman, president of the MDS Systems division of Mohawk Data Sciences, to introduce a new product into the overcrowded computer field, he knew he was going to have to make a lot of noise to be heard.

title: IBH Affiliate Warns of Layoffs HANOVER, West Germany, Jan. 10 (AP) - Hanomag, a construction machinery maker, warned of mass layoffs in the next few months in an apparent prelude to bankruptcy proceedings. Hanomag was an affiliate of IBH, the world's third-largest construction equipment producer, which filed for bankruptcy on Dec. 13.
description: ''We would be ill advised and would lie to our employees if we were to say we still have that many parties interested in continuing the company or in taking it over,'' a spokesman said. Most of the dismissals would take effect in February and March.

title: FOUR DEMOCRATIC CANDIDTES SEEK MINORITY HELP IN IOWA
description: Four candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination appealed for votes from Iowa's tiny black and Hispanic communities at a forum here by attacking the Reagan Administration and pledging to do more to end discrimination.

title: CHURCH GROUPS DENOUNCE REAGAN MOVE
description: President Reagan's establishment of full diplomatic relations with the Vatican drew swift criticism today from a broad range of Protestant groups and from some Jewish groups and civil liberties organizations. Roman Catholic reaction was restrained and cautious.

title: LILCO PUTS TAX FOR SHOREHAM IN ESCROW FUND
description: The Long Island Lighting Company did not make a property tax payment due yesterday on its Shoreham nuclear plant, and instead put the money in escrow.

title: HeroinSellerUsed His Own Label
description: A 29-year-old man from Brooklyn admitted manufacturing and selling heroin under his own ''label'' on the Lower East Side, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: JACKSON'S SHORTCUT TO U.S.-P.L.O. TALKS
description: To the Editor:

title: French-Built PBX By Reuters
description: Jeumont-Schneider of France plans to market telephone switching systems, or PBX's, to United States telephone companies, Henri G. Sulzer, a company official, said.

title: E.E.C. NEARS RETALIATION OVER STEEL
description: The European Common Market is preparing to curb imports from the United States of basic chemicals and sporting equipment in retaliation against Reagan Administration restraints, announced last July, on imports of specialty steel from Europe, a top American trade official said today.

title: King Buys Bronxville House
description: King Hassan II of Morocco has bought a 23-room house in Bronxville with an estimated value of $950,000, according to property records in the Westchester County Clerk's office. The house is on a 2.65-acre site on Pondfield Road.

title: A STAR IN BIATHLON AFTE ONLY 2 YEARS
description: The 21-year-old Thompson, whose blond hair, blue eyes and baby face make him appear even younger, already has recorded two first places and a third place to lead all competitors after the first three races at the United States trials in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: SOUTHERN STATES MOVING TO IMPROVE SCHOOLS
description: For years public school systems in the South have been rated among the poorest in the country in terms of state financial support and pupil performance.

title: LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MELLON'S 4TH-PERIOD NET ROSE TO $53.6 MILLION
description: The Mellon National Corporation, which yesterday became the first major banking company to report its fourth-quarter earnings, said its net income amounted to $53.6 million, or $2.01 a share, in the period.

title: Sims Sues Agent
description: Billy Sims , the Detroit Lion running back who has signed contracts in two leagues, has brought a damage suit against his former agent, Jerry Argovitz , an owner of the United States Football League's Houston Gamblers. The suit accused Argovitz of a conflict of interest when he negotiated a secret five-year, $3.5 million contract between Sims and the Gamblers last year.

title: Lloyd's Sets Stricter Rules
description: Lloyd's of London today announced new rules to carry out a 1982 law requiring insurance brokers to divest themselves of interests in Lloyd's underwriters by July 22, 1987.

title: WINE TALK
description: Did you know that France has less than half as much land in wine grape cultivation now as it had in 1962? There are, from Alsace to the Pyrenees, just under 2.5 million acres of wine grapes. This is 10 percent less than in 1979, 20 percent less than in 1970 and 57 percent less, to be precise, than in 1962.

title: GRANDEUR OF THE PAST AT A.T.&T.'S OLD HEADQUARTERS
description: When the American Telephone and Telegraph Company decided to build a new home on Madison Avenue several years ago, it withheld a decision on whether to keep its old corporate headquarters at 195 Broadway in lower Manhattan.

title: Menuhin Concert Off
description: Yehudi Menuhin is ill and will be unable to perform at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday at 3 P.M. His concert has been rescheduled for March 11 at 8 P.M. Original tickets will be honored and the program will remain the same.

title: Suspect in Slaying At Cornell Jailed
description: The suspected slayer of two freshmen at Cornell University was arraigned today and sent to the Tompkins County jail without bail.

title: INVALID DIES IN BLAZE AT ROW HOUSES IN THE BRONX
description: An elderly invalid died in her apartment and at least 15 other people were injured yesterday when a four-alarm fire swept through a row of eight two- story brick houses in the Bronx.

title: U.S. ACCUSES BEATTY OF $200,000 THEFT FROM URBAN FUNDS
description: Former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn, who was convicted last month of state charges involving election fraud, was accused by Federal authorities yesterday of stealing more than $200,000 from a neighborhood rehabilitation program.

title: Citicorp, Shearson Rates Off at Sales Interest rates fell at this week's sales of commercial paper by Citicorp and Shearson/American Express Inc.
description: Citicorp sold $100 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 9.322 percent, down from 9.569 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 9.341 percent, down from 9.522 percent.

title: Rebuke Is Upheld In Football Death
description: A State Supreme Court justice today upheld a reprimand of the former athletic director of the Yonkers school system, even though he said the official was not directly responsible for the death of a high school football player.

title: CINTAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SCOUTING
description: A New Wizard

title: U.S. PANEL URGES 4-POINT PROGRAM TO REDUCE HUNGER
description: A Federal advisory committee today gave President Reagan four broad recommendations to alleviate hunger in America at only slight additional cost to the Government.

title: THE MARKET'S BIGGEST '83 HIT
description: In 1970 Harvey Tauman took over a successful family-owned dental laboratory from his father and sold most of its equipment to concentrate on selling what he thought would be a revolutionary new material to make dentures.

title: Debt Issues
description: * European Investment Bank's $130 million issue of 11 5/8 percent Eurobonds was priced at 99.5, through Nikko Securities Co. Buyers have a choice of maturities: Seven-year bonds will be redeemed at par, to yield 11.73 percent; fifteen-year bonds will be redeemed at 113, to yield 12.05 percent.

title: Gretzky Loses a Record
description: Wayne Gretzky , the Edmonton Oiler star who tied a National Hockey League record when he was credited with his 10th short-handed goal of the season in a game against the Detroit Red Wings Monday night, is going to get a chance to do it all over again. Because of a timekeeping error, the league announced yesterday, Gretzky had been incorrectly credited with his ninth short-handed goal in a game against the Hartford Whalers Saturday night. The Oilers and the Whalers were at equal strength when Gretzky scored, the league said.

title: MGM-UA ENTERTAINMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Beneficial Corporation, Wilmington, Del., a diversified financial services holding company, has appointed Frederick M. Dawson chairman of its Beneficial Commercial Corporation subsidiary.

title: Reagan 'Open Minded' On Salvador Proposal
description: After having asserted that President Reagan would oppose a key Kissinger commission proposal on El Salvador, the President's spokesman says Mr. Reagan will withhold judgment until he receives the panel's report.

title: 10 HOSPITALS NOW IN TRAUMA SYSTEM
description: A new network of trauma centers manned around the clock and equipped to treat critically injured victims has become fully operational at 10 hospitals in four boroughs, the New York City Emergency Medical Service said yesterday.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.*A Touch of the Past

title: Women in Story and Myth
description: Laura Simms, a storyteller, will present a program of traditional stories and myths from many cultures in ''Women and Wild Animals,'' on Friday at 8 P.M. at the Alternative Museum, 17 White Street. The program will focus on the importance of the female in creation myths and transformation legends, which will be performed with original music, songs and animal sounds. The composer Steven Gorn will provide musical accompaniment.

title: Confessed Killer To Undergo Test
description: A Philippine immigrant who had admitted that he went on a 1981 midtown shooting spree in which a 17- year-old boy died was ordered yesterday to undergo a psychiatric examination.

title: ST. JOHN'S BEATS UCONN, 68-65
description: St. John's overcame a 10-point halftime deficit last night to defeat Connecticut, 68-65, before 5,016 fans at Alumni Hall.

title: Key Rates
description: Kenny index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Economic SceneSteven Greenhouse Unions Pressed On 'Givebacks'
description: W HEN the Greyhound Corporation demanded huge rollbacks from workers at its bus lines, the strike that ensued seemed tailor-made for a union victory.

title: FOOD AND FAITH ON THE LOWER EAST SIDE
description: AN intrepid group of two dozen New Yorkers braved the snow flurries and walked for three and a half hours last Sunday on an ethnic food tour of the Lower East Side of Manhattan, where restaurants and stores that feature bialys, kosher wines, cannoli and sauerbraten exist side by side, much like the immigrant traditions - among them German, Puerto Rican, Polish, Russian, Italian and Chinese - from which they sprang.

title: ISRAELI DOCUMENT ASKS LEBANON EXIT
description: A secret military document recommending an early Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon was disclosed today in Parliament by an opposition legislator.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ADVERTISING
description: People

title: Polish Bank In Warning WARSAW, Jan. 10 (Reuters) - The president of Poland's National Bank today warned industrial companies with financial difficulties that they could be declared bankrupt if they failed to improve their performance.
description: In the latest sign of determination by the Communist authorities to press ahead with economic reform, the bank president, Stanislaw Majewski, said ''several scores'' of the companies that had received loans from the state-run institution were facing bankruptcy.

title: General Foods
description: The General Foods Corporation said it had agreed to buy the Ronzoni Corporation.

title: Dimitrios Bitsios Dies at 68; Was Greek Foreign Minister
description: Former Foreign Minister Dimitrios Bitsios died of cancer today, his family said.

title: UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $257,000 for the quarter and $1,190,000 for the 6 months.

title: REAGAN DRIVE FOR DISCIPLINE IN SCHOOLS: POPULAR STAND BUT ELUSIVE GOAL
description: In attacking ''unruly behavior'' in the public schools, President Reagan has opened a campaign that surveys indicate is likely to have popular appeal. Respondents to all 15 of the Gallup Poll's annual surveys of attitudes toward education have said that ''lack of discipline'' is their No. 1 concern in elementary and secondary education. Each month 282,000 students and 5,200 teachers are assaulted in the schools around the country, according to a study in 1978 by the National Institute of Education, which also found that 25 percent of schools suffer some sort of vandalism every month.

title: Strawberry Pleased
description: The Mets and Darryl Strawberry made it official yesterday: a one-year contract at $200,000 for the 21-year-old outfielder who hit 26 home runs and was voted the National League's rookie of the year.

title: Sale of Cuban Debt
description: A subsidiary of the American Express Company, the Trade Development Bank, sold about $1.75 million of Cuban debt to the National Bank of Canada, a small bank in Montreal, to allow a rescheduling of Cuba's debts to proceed, a Credit Lyonnais spokesman said today. American Express said Monday that requests for United States Treasury approval to take part in the rescheduling had been refused. Credit Lyonnais, which led the commercial bank debt talks, announced agreement on rescheduling terms on Dec. 23, but said signature would be delayed for a few days because of a problem not related to the restructuring.

title: Driving and Drinking
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: JB'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 18
SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 11, 1984

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday, about telecommunciations, misidentified Ellis Woodward, a former press advance official in the Carter White House. He is an aide to Representative Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado.

title: 50 Said to Die in Crash Of Bulgarian Airliner
description: A Bulgarian airliner crashed while trying to land at Sofia's airport Tuesday, killing all 50 people on board, the East German news agency ADN reported today.

title: DR. JACOB J. BEAVER
description: Dr. Jacob J. Beaver, who taught chemistry at Columbia University from 1921 to 1961, died Sunday at the Hallmark Nursing Center in Queensbury, N.Y. He was 90 years old and lived in Lake Luzerne, N.Y.

title: HEAD OF STUDY SAYS U.S. COAL LEASING PROGRAM IS IN 'CHAOTIC' STATE
description: The chairman of a commission investigating Federal coal leasing policies says the panel's findings show the management of the Interior Department's leasing program to be in a ''chaotic'' state.

title: BANCO DE PONCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
B.P. Abandons Well Off China LONDON, Jan. 10 (AP) - The British Petroleum Company said it had abandoned its first exploration well off China after encountering only limited signs of crude oil.
description: B.P. is operator for a group of companies that signed the first exploration contracts with the Chinese Government under competitive bidding that began in 1982.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: G.M. SETS CHANGE TO 2 GROUPS
description: The General Motors Corporation, in a sweeping reorganization, announced today that it would combine all of its automobile design, engineering and manufacturing operations in the United States and Canada into two groups - one for large cars, one for small cars.

title: IN CATALONIA, SCORN FOR MADRID, RESPECT FOR MONEY
description: The quarrel between Madrid and Barcelona runs deeper than New York-Washington. It predates Fort Worth-Dallas, is more heartfelt than Los Angeles-San Francisco. It goes something like this: ''Barcelona has an opera house.'' ''Madrid has the Prado.''

title: Europeans in Nuclear Pact
description: France, Britain, West Germany, Italy and Belgium signed an agreement today to share technology and industrial expertise in the commercial development of fast breeder nuclear reactors. The Netherlands is expected to sign the agreement later this year. France's breeder, the Superphenix, which is the West's only commercial nuclear plant of this type, is scheduled to go on line later this year or in early 1985.

title: SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TEXAS BASKETBALL IN TURMOIL
description: Just a few weeks ago, each day seemed to bring a new defection, a new name on the list of players who had had enough of University of Texas basketball and the Longhorn coach, Bob Weltlich.

title: JUDGE RULES ON NICARAGUA REBELS
description: A Federal judge here has refused to reverse a ruling directing Attorney General William French Smith to study charges that the Reagan Administration's support of Nicaraguan insurgents violates the Neutrality Act.

title: ; ATLANTIC CITY SUCCESS STORY
description: To the Editor:

title: RESCH EXCELS IN LOSING CAUSE
description: Glenn (Chico) Resch played an outstanding game in goal for the Devils tonight, but it wasn't enough as the Islanders scored a 4-2 victory at Nassau Coliseum.

title: HICKOK ELECTRICAL INSTRUENT CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $10,800.

title: Learning in Brattleboro
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: FOOD ACCENT FOR THE 80'S IS DECIDEDLY AMERICAN
description: WHILE Americans continue to buy imported automobiles, televisions, shoes and steel, food from abroad is slowly losing its cachet. If the 1970's was the decade of mustards from France, olive oils from Italy, soy sauces from China and seaweeds from Japan, the 80's promise to show that American-grown foodstuffs and wines are as good as, and sometimes even better than, the imports they seek to emulate.

title: Vaclav Vytlacil, Artist; Began Abstract Group
description: Vaclav Vytlacil, an early American modernist painter and one of the founders of the American Abstract Artists group, died last Thursday in New York City. He was 91 years old.

title: PARKLANDS PLEDGE OFFERED BY CLARK
description: Interior Secretary William P. Clark pledged today that no national parklands, wilderness areas, game refuges or wetlands would be offered for lease or sale while he was is office.

title: HOPEFUL ON PEACE PLAN
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau will visit New York Wednesday for talks at the United Nations on his two-month-old effort to stimulate renewed discussions on disarmament encouraged by responses from nations such as China and individuals such as Senator John Glenn, according to aides.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: France Staying Calm on Dollar
description: Finance Minister Jacques Delors says there is no need at the moment for France to tighten its policy to offset the inflationary impact of the strengthening dollar.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CONGRESS'S ECONOMIC CHALLENGE
description: Hardly anyone has a good word for Congress nowadays. But, truth to tell, it is Congress that in 1982 acted to bring the nation out of the recession. And it is Congress that must act with equal courage in 1984 to avoid bequeathing a crisis-prone economy to whoever occupies the White House in 1985.

title: Careers; Computers: Midlife Blues Cited
description: EVEN the newest professions may eventually suffer from the midlife blues. That difficulty has apparently come to M.I.S. professionals - specialists in management information systems or, in plain language, computer experts in business. Many have begun to seek promotion to top management jobs, but few have made it.

title: ARIZONA BANCWEST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JUSTICES TIGHTEN RULES FOR ALIENS
description: The Supreme Court today tightened one of the standards that deportable aliens must meet to avoid deportation.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in September.

title: Inquiry Continues on Sitzberger
description: Police investigating the death of Ken Sitzberger, the former Olympic diving champion, have so far found no evidence of foul play, according to Comdr.

title: Nynex Names Agency For New Retail Chain
description: Nynex, the phone company serving New York and New England, has plans to establish at least one retail chain, set up to serve the information and communications needs of small businesses and professional people.

title: Crime Figure Is Killed In Kansas City Blast
description: An explosion in the office of a used-car lot here Monday killed Carl Spero, the fourth brother in his family to die violently.

title: Penn State Aide To Coach Rutgers
description: Dick Anderson became the new football coach at Rutgers University yesterday and said he hoped to ''bring the team to a point where it will be nationally recognized.'' He will leave his post as offensive coordinator at Penn State to take over a Rutgers team that posted losing records for the last three years and in 1983 suffered its worst season in 30 years with a 3-8 mark.

title: VILLELLA OUT AS EGLEVSKY'S DIRECTOR
description: Edward Villella is no longer artistic director of the Eglevsky Ballet of Long Island.

title: NEW CHIEF OF PATROL APPOINTED
description: Hamilton Robinson, the chief of the Housing Authority police, was named the New York City Police Department's new chief of patrol yesterday.

title: RECITAL: FISCHER'S BACK CELLO MARATHON
description: THE Symphony Space's Bach Mondays series offered an ambitious marathon this week in the form of a complete, two-intermission, nearly-four- hour traversal of all six of the composer's unaccompanied Cello Suites. The traverser was Norman Fischer, best known as cellist of the Concord String Quartet, and those who remained of the initially large audience gave him a deserved ovation when he finished, shortly before midnight.

title: ACCOUNTING FOR PENSIONS: FOOTNOTES OR LIABILITIES?
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board opens debate today on the controversial issue of how companies account for pensions.

title: Envoys Say Afghans Downed 3 Soviet MIG's
description: Afghan guerrillas shot down three Soviet MIG's and at least one helicopter in the last two weeks, and Soviet air strikes killed more than 100 civilians, Western diplomats said today.

title: Salvador Spinach
description: Presented with a dish of broccoli, the child in the famous New Yorker cartoon pushes it away, saying ''I say it's spinach, and I say the hell with it.'' That seems to be President Reagan's view of any required certification of human rights progress in El Salvador. His own Kissinger commission will not formally present its report until today, yet a White House spokesman has already said Mr. Reagan is ''inclined'' to reject its recommendation on certification.

title: SERVED AS PREMIER FOR MANY YEARS
description: Souvanna Phouma, the neutralist Prime Minister of Laos who was ousted when the Communist Pathet Lao took power in 1975, died yesterday at his villa in Vientiane, the Laotian capital, the Vientiane radio announced. He was 82 years old.

title: TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. AND VATICAN RESTORE FULL TIES AFTER 117 YEARS
description: The United States and the Vatican established full diplomatic relations today for the first time in 117 years.

title: RELATIVES AND FRIENDS SEARCH FOR MISSING DIVINITY STUDENT
description: Sam, the middle child, is missing. That he is 24 years old rather than a small boy is of little comfort to his mother, father and two brothers, who have searched the streets of Manhattan for him night and day since he left a New Year's Eve party on Mulberry Street for some fresh air and vanished.

title: MELLON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 figures do not include the earnings of the Girard Company, CCB Bancorp Inc., and Mortgage & Trust Inc., which were merged into Mellon during 1983.

title: Sports of The Times; Who's Watching the Store?
description: The last week has given a few more examples for skeptics who believe that big-time

title: WilliamC.Campbell,60,Dies; Rubber Trade Group Official
description: William C. Campbell, a vice president of the Rubber Manufacturers Association here who was a former Mayor of two New Jersey towns, died of a heart attack last Thursday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 60 years old.

title: WASHINGTON FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (DC) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EASTGROUP PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including gains from the sale of real estate of $3,920,000 for the quarter and $5,586,000 for the year. c-Including gains from the sale of real estate of $159,000 for the quarter and $1,663,000 for the year.

title: REPORT SAYS CITY AND STATE PAY TOO MUCH FOR BUILDINGS
description: A state agency asserted yesterday that policies by the State Labor Department and the New York City Comptroller's office had inflated the costs of public construction and had hampered efforts at racial integration in the building trade unions.

title: HUSSEIN PUTS MORE PALESTINIANS INTO KEY POSITIONS
description: King Hussein has increased the number of Palestinians in his Cabinet and in other key posts, the Government announced today.

title: Governor Kean's Bootstraps
description: New Jersey's Governor Kean failed to pull in enough Republicans in last November's election to wrest either house of the New Jersey Legislature from Democratic control. Since the new Legislature is unlikely to vote him the funds for any spectacular initiatives, his State of the State Message should have made thin reading. But he plans to overcome his lack of coattails with bootstraps, extracting funds from less hostile sources.

title: U S West, Fluor In Cellular Radio DENVER, Jan. 10 (Reuters) - U S West, one of the seven regional companies created by the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said it and Fluor Engineers Inc., a unit of the Fluor Corporation, had signed a letter of intent to develop a cellular radio telecommunications system. The system would serve the offshore communications needs in the Gulf from south of New Orleans to south of Corpus Christi, Tex., extending about 150 miles out to sea.
description: Separately, U S West said it had organized a subsidiary to provide financial services to its affiliates. U S West owns Mountain Bell, Northwestern Bell, Pacific Northwest Bell and several unregulated subsidiaries. To start, the unit will offer equipment leasing and sales financing.

title: DONORS REMEMBER FAMILY AND FRIENDS IN GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: The memory of generous friends and beloved family members, and sometimes of innocent victims of neglect or violence, often inspires contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We find hunger to be a real and significant problem throughout our nation.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN PARLEY WITH MOZAMBIQUE SET
description: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa announced Monday night that high-level talks would begin next week with Mozambique.

title: CALIFORINA GETS BUDGET PROPOSAL WITH A SURPLUS
description: Gov. George Deukmejian said today that government in California, which was on the brink of bankruptcy a year ago, will have enough money in its next fiscal year to set aside an emergency fund of almost $1 billion while sharply increasing spending for schools, universities, state employee salaries and a wide range of other needs.

title: Giants Doubtful Of Signing Moon
description: George Young, the Giants' general manager, was pessimistic yesterday on the possibility of obtaining the star quarterback Warren Moon, who is a free agent after playing for the Edmonton Eskimos of the Canadian Football League for five years.

title: DOUBT ON START OF SOVIET GAS LINE GROWS AFTER REPORT OF PUMP
description: FIRE By JOHN F. BURNS

title: DMI FURNITURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ICE AGE There was a time when savages roamed North America, hunting prehistoric game with crude tools, and fighting for survival against the ice and snow. Tonight at 7:30, five specialists in the fields of archeology and anthropology will present a symposium on the Ice Age, examining recently excavated bones, campfire sites and artifacts and relating them to the migration patterns, hunting technologies and subsistence strategies of the peoples of the time. The symposium will be held at the American Museum of Natural History, at Central Park West at 79th Street. Tickets are $15; for information: 873- 7507.

title: SCOUTING
description: Officials' League

title: U.S. SAID TO BE LIMITED IN WAYS IT CAN AID IRAQ
description: The Reagan Administration has concluded that the defeat of Iraq by Iran would be a major setback to American interests but that there is little the United States can do to help Iraq directly, Administration officials said today.

title: REAGAN'S GENTLER MELODY
description: Something new is going on here. President Reagan is beginning to talk about foreign policy in a gentler way. He slips into the old hellfire religion once in awhile, but he is no longer a prisoner of his past anti-Communist pronouncements.

title: COMPANY NEWS Retailers Seek Growth Ideas
description: With the year's sales outlook already robust, retailers at a national convention in New York yesterday pushed for new ideas that could provide still more strength.

title: DEPLETION CASES LOST BY I.R.S.
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, by 5 to 4, that independent producers of oil and natural gas may claim a depletion allowance on their Federal tax returns for years during which no production takes place.

title: TRUST COMPANY OF GEORGIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for both years have been restated for acquisitions.

title: HOLD FOR MR. MARCONI
description: Dear Alexander Graham Nynex,

title: ZHAO SAYS TIES TO U.S. HAVE 'UPS AND DOWNS'
description: President Reagan told Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China today that his visit symbolized ''the growing trust and cooperation'' between the two countries. Mr. Reagan said the United States and China shared ''common ground'' in opposing foreign expansionism.

title: Accused Opens Fire In Florida Courtroom
description: A man who came to court to answer charges of resisting arrest whipped?out a pistol, a shotgun and an assault rifle today and opened fire in the courtroom, killing one bailiff and critically wounding two others.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Chicago Bulls vs. Nets, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. Both clubs are struggling to reach the .500 mark.

title: Sears Units File Ginnie Mae Issue Subsidiaries of Sears, Roebuck & Company announced this week that they had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of up to $1 billion of Government National Mortgage Association-backed mortgage pass-through certificates. The first offering is expected in February, with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. acting as sole underwriter.
description: The financing is an initial effort to integrate the business of the Sears securities affiliate - Dean Witter - and its mortgage banking affiliate - Allstate Enterprises, formerly Coldwell Banker.

title: Ailing Track Stars
description: Steve Cram , the British runner who won the world championship in the 1,500-meter event last year, said that he had developed tendinitis in his knees and might have to alter his training schedule for the Olympics. Despite the ailment, Cram left on schedule yesterday for six weeks of training and racing in Australia and New Zealand, but he said he might have to return to London early if his knees didn't improve. . . . Mary Decker , the star middle-distance runner, is suffering from a minor calf injury and has canceled her two scheduled indoor appearances to assure her full recovery for the Olympics.

title: U.S. EMBASSY NOT ENVISAGED
description: The decision today to establish full diplomatic relations with the Holy See will give the United States a greater presence in the Vatican but will prompt no adjustments in American diplomatic quarters.

title: SCOUTING
description: Reaching a Goal In Division I

title: AMBASSADOR DESIGNATE
description: Manin theNews

title: LYNN PAYS $50,000, REJOINS JETS
description: In one of the more unusual developments in the history of professional sports contracts, Johnny Lynn returned to the Jets yesterday by buying out his contract for $50,000 from the United States Football League's Los Angeles Express, for whom he never played a down.

title: ROYKO MAVING COLUMN TO CHICAGO TRIBUNE
description: Mike Royko, the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist for The Chicago Sun-Times, announced today that he had resigned to join the rival Chicago Tribune because he believed the new owner of The Sun-Times ''will substantially alter the paper.''

title: ROYAL CROWN AIDES WEIGHING A BUYOUT
description: The Royal Crown Companies said yesterday that ''a management-led group'' is considering making a leveraged buyout at about $35 a share.

title: Veiled-Camera Evidence Ruled Out by U.S. Judge
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that evidence obtained by hidden cameras could not be used in the trial of four men, suspected to be members of the Puerto Rican terrorist group F.A.L.N., who are charged with plotting to bomb Government facilities.

title: ARRESTS OF NIGERIANS REPORTED
description: The new military Government was reported today to have arrested relatives of three leading figures in the deposed civilian administration.

title: LEARNING IN BRATTLEBORO
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: PARKER PEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss after restructuring costs of $5,383,000 for the writing instrument group.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: PROFITING FROM CONTADORA
description: In principle, everyone involved supports the efforts of the Contadora countries - Colombia, Panama, Mexico and Venezuela - to advance peace in Central America: Presidents Reagan and Castro, the Democratic Party, all the Central American governments. Yet, as the Contadora meeting last weekend in Panama shows, the group's specific proposals are unlikely to be adopted. The search for peace requires a more modest and workable policy.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Conveying a Message In Words and Sculpture

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Dec 11
GUIDES TO THE CURRENT AMERICAN CUISINE
description: THE American section of the cookbook shelf has been expanding in recent months, and some of the new additions are most worthwhile.

description: Lehrman on Cuomo's Year

title: 2 High-Level Changes Are Reported by Savin The Savin Corporation has announced that Richard T. Gralton, president and chief operating officer, has been moved up to vice chairman and Serge Gouin has been brought in as president and chief operating officer.
description: Mr. Gouin, 38, comes from the Canada Development Corporation, where he was executive vice president. The corporation, partly owned by the Canadian Government, holds a 57 percent interest in Savin and has recently agreed to increase its ownership to 72 percent through the purchase of $30 million in units consisting of common stocks and warrants.

title: WHAT'S AHEAD FOR CITY IN '84
description: NewsAnalysis

title: ESPN FATE TIED TO GETTY SALE
description: Whether it is Texaco Inc., as seems likely, or the Pennzoil Corporation that buys the Getty Oil Company, one thing appears certain: Neither owner is likely to want to be in the cable television business. And that means the nation's largest cable television service, ESPN, the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network - of which Getty is the major shareholder - will probably go on the auction block.

title: No Headline
description: Sir Frederick Gibberd Dead; Designed Liverpool Cathedral

title: ACCORD REACHED ON CLEANING UP NIAGARA WASTES
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, in a proposed out-of-court settlement, has agreed to spend more than $36 million to clean up and contain toxic chemicals buried in a dump in Niagara Falls, N.Y.

title: Hart in China Deal
description: Hart Industries said China's Ministry of Aerospace and Astronautics Industry had approved a 15-year, $490 million manufacturing agreement between the company and the China Great Wall Industry Corporation.

title: Earnings Rise At MGM/UA CULVER CITY, Calif., Jan. 10 (AP) - The MGM/UA Entertainment Company reported today that its latest three-month profit rose nearly 4.7 percent, reflecting its box- office successes with the James Bond movie ''Octopussy'' and the computer adventure ''War Games.''
description: MGM/UA's chairman, Frank Rothman, said net income in the fiscal first quarter, ended Nov. 30, was $10.96 million, or 22 cents a share, up from $10.47 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier. Operating revenues declined to $192.18 million from $204.1 million.

title: EXCERPTS FROM FINAL REPORT OF THE PRESIDENTIAL PANEL OF FOOD ASSISTANCE
description: Following are excerpts from the summary of the final report of President Reagan's Task Force on Food Assistance:

description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Balks On Loan Deal RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 10 (Reuters) - The Brazilian Government will not sign the agreement covering its jumbo commercial bank loan until commitments reach the full $6.5 billion, according to a statement issued today by the central bank's governor, Affonso Pastore.
description: The statement said that $6.35 billion had been committed and that the Government would not accept any form of window dressing involving greater participation by the big banks to make up the total.

title: Y.& R. Consolidates Its Marketing Units
description: Young & Rubicam has formed its three direct marketing subsidiaries into the Y.& R. Direct Marketing Group and has named Lester Wunderman chairman and chief executive of the group and Joseph W. Ostrow president and chief operating officer.

title: TEXT OF JOURNALISTS' JOINT STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of a statement made public yesterday by a special committee of representatives of news organizations on access to information about military operations:

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ''RIGHT now, the jazz scene is really devoid of bands,'' the bassist Buster Williams was saying the other day. ''All-star bands are put together every summer to play the jazz festivals, but the music they play is more of a jam session. I'm talking about real bands that work together and develop a sound together over a period of time. There are very few bands of that sort.''

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
Western Air Shifts Top Management
description: Western Airlines announced yesterday that its chairman, Gerald Grinstein, had been named president and chief operating officer. Lawrence E. Lee, chief executive, takes on the additional duties of chairman.

title: Bridge: Regional Tournament Starts For Players in Tristate Area
description: For enthusiasts in the New York metropolitan area the first tournament of Orwell's year - the Tristate Regional - begins today at the Rye Town Hilton Hotel in Port Chester, N.Y. Big Brother, however, will not be watching through closed-circuit television cameras, although that intrusive possibility has been proposed at the national level, in the interest of monitoring possible improprieties.

title: STENMARK POSTS 75TH VICTORY
description: Ingemar Stenmark, Sweden's 27-year-old star, scored his 75th World Cup ski victory today.

title: Actress's Ex-Mate Cleared of Charge
description: A weapons possession charge against the former husband of the actress Jennifer O'Neill, involving the gun with which she accidentally shot herself, was dismissed today.

title: RATES EASE IN STABLE OUTLOOK
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined modestly yesterday, though some analysts said there was no fundamental change in the outlook.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Jacksonville Financing Has Zero Coupon Bonds

title: THE LEAKY BUSINESS OF PRESIDENTIAL COMMISSIONS
description: On Wednesday morning, former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger is to go through the formality of delivering to President Reagan the report of the Presidential commission on Central America, which he headed. But the report's contents are already well known to political Washington, and they are caught in a crossfire between the White House and some Democrats.

title: COLLEGE HEADS' BID FOR POWER BEATEN
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association soundly defeated today the American Council on Education's attempt to establish a strong board of college presidents with veto power over N.C.A.A. rules involving the academic standards and financial integrity of schools.

title: PENNZOIL SUES OVER GETTY DEAL
description: The Pennzoil Company, defeated by Texaco Inc. in its bid to buy the Getty Oil Company, yesterday sued Getty, Texaco and others to force them to make good on an agreement that would give Pennzoil an automatic profit of $120 million.

title: Robust Recovery, but Not for All
description: The year-end employment statistics are better than almost anyone predicted - and a source of legitimate satisfaction for Republicans with an eye on Election Day. But it remains important to understand that the explanation for the drop in the unemployment rate is not political.

title: Pension Aide Leaving
description: Edwin Jones is expected to announce tomorrow that he is resigning for personal reasons as executive director of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. No effective date has been set. Mr. Jones has held the position since May 1982.

title: STEEL WORKERS LOSE, THE MANAGERS WIN
description: To the Editor:

title: SANTA MONICA BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rozier Says He Signed
description: Mike Rozier confirmed today, after a day of confusion, that he had signed a three-year contract to play for the Pittsburgh Maulers of the United States Football League. The Heisman Trophy winner from Nebraska told the newspapers USA Today and Stars and Stripes that he had indeed with the expansion team, which had made him the first pick in the year-old league's college player draft last week.

title: 112 NATIONS MEET TO DISCUSS RADIO
description: A 112-nation conference on radio broadcasting opened here today, with developing countries expected to press for greater access to the world's high-frequency airwaves.

title: NEW SAUSAGE STUFFER
description: MOST commercial sausages sold in supermarkets today have no distinctive flavor and contain up to 50 percent fat, which is the Government limit. That much fat is not necessary to make moist sausage; in fact, it detracts from the flavor besides adding a lot of cholesterol. About 35 percent fat in a meat sausage suits my taste but the only way to get it is to make the sausage myself.

title: Air Florida In Debt
description: Pact Air Florida System Inc. said it had agreed with its largest creditor, the Interfirst Bank of Dallas, on a plan to eliminate more than $33 million in debt. Under the arrangement, Interfirst was paid $6.5 million and was given 15 percent of the common stock of Air Florida on a fully diluted basis.

title: RUSSIANS ARE REPORTED CONCERNED ABOUT EDB IN U.S. GRAIN
description: The Soviet Union is concerned that grain imported from the United States may be contaminated with the pesticide ethylene dibromide and has asked Federal agriculture officials how to detect its presence in food, Federal officials said today.

title: LOOKING BACK FROM THE IVORY TOWER
description: Even on a clear day, says former Representative John Brademas, the view of Capitol Hill from the ivory tower can get pretty cloudy.

title: DESIGNHOUSE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Ticket Shortage In Washington
description: Super Bowl tickets have become the hottest in town and nearly impossible to obtain, even by faithful Redskin fans. Most will be left out in the cold on Jan. 22, when the defending champions meet the Los Angeles Raiders in Tampa, Fla.

title: Gulf Rejects Pickens's Plan
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said its directors had unanimously rejected a royalty trust proposal received from T.

title: ART DECO AWARDS MADE
description: The Art Deco Society of New York has announced the recipients of its first awards for achievement in Art Deco design, preservation and restoration.

title: N.L.R.B. SAYS SAFETY PROTEST BY LONE WORKER WAS ILLEGAL
description: The National Labor Relations Board has upheld the dismissal of an employee who refused to drive a truck he considered unsafe and filed individual protests.

title: CHARTING A LATIN COURSE
description: News Analysis

STAGE: SASHA DALTON IN 'DINAH! QUEEN OF THE BLUES'
description: IN ''Dinah! Queen of the Blues,'' Sasha Dalton attempts to celebrate Dinah Washington with a one-woman show about her music and her brief, meteoric career. However, the result is essentially a cabaret recapitulation on stage. The musical, which opened last night at the Westside Arts Center, was presented in a shorter version last year at the Ballroom, and a club would seem to be a more natural milieu.

description: ''Dear parents and children. This is from a boy who loves you all. We are sorry that you are poor. Please let me know wen you need more money.''
