TRAIN KILLS 2 GIRLS ON TRACKS
description: Two 13-year-old girls were struck and killed by an N.J. Transit express passenger train as they walked along a curving stretch of railroad tracks in Maplewood, N.J., shortly after dark yesterday, the authorities said.

title: PENALTY FOR BLACK MEN
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Is Dedicated To Senator Jackson
description: The 132- page report released today by the President's commission on Central America is dedicated to Senator Henry M. Jackson.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Dec. 10 about opposition to the building of a movie theater in Southampton, L.I., misidentified a lawyer for the developer. He is William Esseks.

title: 29 Saved From Ship in Gulf
description: Twenty-eight crewmen and a pregnant woman were rescued Tuesday from a crippled Liberian tanker in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: PARKER DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: PLAYS-WITHIN-PLAYS ARE DOUBLING THE THEATERGOER'S PLEASURE
description: YOU may think that the Broadway season has thus far given us two hit English plays, Michael Frayn's ''Noises Off'' and Tom Stoppard's ''Real Thing,'' but count again: The truth is that we now have at least four. Within ''Noises Off'' is a second farce called ''Nothing On,'' a play that Mr. Frayn's characters, the members of a tatty acting troupe, are performing up and down the English countryside. ''The Real Thing'' folds several plays into its Chinese box structure, most notably a high comedy titled ''House of Cards.'' The author of ''House of Cards'' is Henry (Jeremy Irons), the playwright at the center of ''The Real Thing.''

title: Honor for Bradley
description: Senator Bill Bradley, the Democrat of New Jersey who is better known to basketball fans as the Dollar Bill who helped the Knicks win their only two National Basketball Association championships, in 1970 and 1973, will be back on the court for the Knick game against the Nets at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 18, but not to play. He and several of his former teammates will be on hand for a halftime ceremony in which Bradley's uniform, No. 24, will be formally retired and raised to the rafters, where it will join those of Walt Frazier (No. 10), Willis Reed (No. 19) and Dave DeBusschere (No. 22). The ceremony was originally scheduled for the Knicks' home opener against the Washington Bullets Oct. 19, but because of the labor dispute involving the referees the Senator thought it would be impolitic to cross a picket line.

title: ZHAO SAYS CHINA WILL NEVER CLOSE ITS DOOR AGAIN
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China, in meetings with United States Government officials and business leaders, continued today to promote cooperation over contention, and lobbied strongly for a heavier flow of trade and aid from the United States to his country.

title: RAI RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend payable Jan. 11.

title: KILEY APPOINTS A PHILADELPHIAN TO TRANSIT POST
description: David L. Gunn, the head of Philadelphia's mass-transit system, was named yesterday as president of the New York City Transit Authority, the largest subway and bus system in the country.

title: Continental Group
description: The Continental Group said it had reorganized its packaging subsidiary, creating three new subdivisions within the unit: food and beverage packaging, international packaging and specialty packaging.

title: FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $275,000.

title: SALVADOR LEADER ENDORSES REPORT
description: The Provisional President of El Salvador praised the Kissinger commission's report on Central America as ''responsible,'' while Nicaragua brushed it off and Guatemala said it would gladly accept United States aid if no conditions were attached.

title: Mahaffey Shares Lead in Hope Golf
description: John Mahaffey birdied four of the first six holes, had no bogeys and carded a 6-under-par 66 for a share of the first-round lead in the $400,000 Bob Hope Desert Golf Classic today.

title: 20 YEARS AFTER U.S. REPORT, MANY STILL SMOKE
description: The physician who released the first Surgeon General's report on smoking 20 years ago today says the evidence that one-third of the adult population still smokes shows the anti-cigarette campaign has not been as successful as he had hoped.

title: Freighter Refloated in West
description: Tugboats aided by high tide freed a 587- foot Greek freighter today from the north bank of the Columbia River, where she ran aground more than 26 hours earlier. Up to eight tugs took part in the third effort to refloat the freighter Star Centaurus, according to Lieut. Kristin Quann of the Coast Guard in Portland.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ACLI International Commodity Services, White Plains, the futures trading arm of ACLI International, a commodity brokerage firm, named Thomas A. Zimmerman vice president and director of research.

title: A MASTER'S DEGREE IN U.S. FOLK ART
description: COURSES include ''The Woman as Folk Artist'' and ''Living Traditions in Art.'' The final project may be mounting an exhibition of whirligigs or publishing a paper on decoys. They are part of the master's degree program in American folk art co-sponsored by the Museum of American Folk Art and New York University.

title: JAMES WISE, RUG EXECUTIVE AND RESERVE BANK DIRECTOR
description: James DeCamp Wise, a leader in the rug industry and a former director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died Saturday at Jamaica Hospital in Queens after suffering a heart attack at Kennedy International Airport. He was 85 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Greenpeace Plans Action
description: The environmental organization Greenpeace, citing an order by an unidentified Far Eastern nation for the sex organs of 10,000 male harp seals, said it will try to intervene in a seal hunt scheduled off Canada and Norway this year. Greenpeace officials said the Norwegian press carried the announcement, advertising that a nation of the Far East was offering to buy seal testicles for use as aphrodisiacs.

title: But Will They Believe?
description: At the heart of the problem in El Salvador there is a fact of life that has existed, unchanged, for generations. A small minority exercises power by brute force. When election results challenge that fact, the results are overturned. When individuals are suspected of wanting to challenge it, they are killed. Death squads are only the latest expression of the social reality.

title: SCOUTING
description: Mileage Adds Up For Mrs. Lloyd

title: CSX PLANS CLOSE LOOK AT CONRAIL
description: The CSX Corporation said yesterday that its board of directors had authorized management to begin a review of Conrail to determine if the company should acquire the carrier.

title: CRITIC OF ISRAEL ON THE VOICE GOT AN ARAB INSTITUTE GRANT
description: A columnist for The Village Voice who has often been harshly critical of Israeli policies in the Middle East has acknowledged accepting a $10,000 grant from an organization called pro-Arab by its critics.

title: Rent Overcharges To Be Refunded
description: Two landlords and three Manhattan management companies have agreed to refund $450,000 to hundreds of city tenants who had been victims of rent overcharges, Attorney General Robert Abrams said yesterday.

title: NATO SAYS MOSCOW DEPLOYS 9 NEW SS-20'S
description: Moscow has deployed a battery of nine SS-20 missiles in the eastern Soviet Union since suspending negotiations on limiting intermediate-range weapons in Europe, a NATO spokesman said today.

title: Yugoslav Inflation Peak
description: Inflation in Yugoslavia reached a record of 58.4 percent last year, the official Tanyug press agency said today.

title: AT AUCTION IN 1983: 20TH CENTURY SOARS
description: -CENTURY designs - a 1908 Viennese vitrine, a 1909 California hall bench and a stained-glass door from a house in Buffalo - commanded the same fierce bidding at auction last year that more venerable 18th-century antiques did. These prices constituted the single most important trend for collectors in last year's auctions of decorative arts, more than a decade after the revivals began of Art Deco, Arts and Crafts and architect-designed turn-of-the-century furnishings.

title: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 net figures include $2,371,000, or 9 cents a share, from sale of certain mortgage loan servicing in the first quarter. The year-earlier fourth quarter and full year net also includes $925,000 as a result of income tax rate benefits from capital transactions.

title: AMERITRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Ayer Wins J.C. Penney Account
description: THE J.C. Penney Company, the giant New York-based retail chain, announced yesterday that it had selected N.W. Ayer to handle its estimated $60 million national advertising account.

title: SHARON IS REJECTED FOR JOB OF INDUCING ISRAELI IMMIGRATION
description: Former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon lost tonight in his bid to become chairman of the Jewish Agency's immigration department. The vote against him, by Israeli and foreign members of the General Zionist Council, was 58 to 49.

title: 'SOME HITTERS HIT THEMSELVES'
description: They never change. Don Drysdale

title: MOTHER SAYS SHCHARANSKY LOOKS EMACIATED
description: The mother of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned dissident, said today that on a recent visit she had found him emaciated and in pain from an ailing heart.

title: Taylor Offered Life Pay
description: Lawrence Taylor's agreement with the New Jersey Generals, which led to a meeting with the club yesterday to resolve his status, contained more provisions than were previously learned. The latest disclosure was that, even if Taylor were to play only three of the four years covered in his agreement with the Generals, he would receive $100,000 a year, starting at age 39, for the rest of his life.

title: DAISY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $21,000.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a net gain of $913,900 on the sale of land. Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split in January.

title: COMMODITIES U.S. Reduces Estimate Of Florida Orange Crop
description: The Department of Agriculture said yesterday that freezing temperatures in Florida last month had reduced the state's orange crop by 23 percent, to 129 million boxes, from the 169 million estimated in October.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $243,900,000 from discontinued operations.

title: INTEREST RATES SLIGHTLY LOWER
description: Interest rates declined slightly in quiet trading yesterday. Market participants stayed on the sidelines waiting for new economic data that might provide some direction.

title: Transactions
description: AUTO RACING

title: American Express In A.T.& T. Tie By The Associated Press
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced an agreement that will allow holders of American Express Company cards to charge calls placed on A.T.& T.'s new ''card caller'' public telephones.

title: Harvester Backed
description: International Harvester shareholders approved a restructuring of the company's $3.5 billion debt that its creditors agreed to last month. As part of the restructuring, the amount of authorized common stock of Harvester, a major maker of commercial trucks and farm machinery, will be increased to 200 million, from 100 million shares.

title: On Thin Ice
description: Steve Weeks will be in goal tonight for the Rangers in Philadelphia, looking for his first victory in almost two months. Weeks, 0-5-1 in his 6 starts since a Nov. 13 victory over Detroit, has been a backup to Glen Hanlon ever since a Dec. 26 loss in Pittsburgh.

title: BRIEFING
description: Wintry Coping

title: STRATEGIC GOALS OFTEN APPEAR TO LOOM BEHIND ASSISTANCE FOR LATIN REGION
description: The report today urging a sharp increase in American aid to Central America comes at a time when the United States is already spending hundreds of millions of dollars in economic assistance to El Salvador, Honduras and Costa Rica.

title: U.S. HUNGER: A NEW FOCUS
description: If President Reagan thought he could end the debate over hunger in America through appointment of a blue-ribbon commission to study the problem, he must be disappointed. The summary of the panel's final report, issued Tuesday, has focused new attention on the issue and intensified the debate. Early drafts of the commission's report, prepared by the staff under supervision of the chairman, J. Clayburn LaForce Jr., tended to minimize the problem and recommended further cutbacks in Federal spending on food assistance, several panel members said. The body of the final report, which includes the panel's findings on the extent of hunger in America, remains virtually the same.

title: MPG INVESTMENT CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Max Meth, Musical Director Of Over 25 Broadway Shows
description: Max Meth, the musical director of more than 25 Broadway shows including ''Pal Joey'' and ''Finian's Rainbow,'' died on Jan. 3 in Wyckoff, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Credithrift Note Sale

title: Musical 'Jean Seberg' Cuts Run in London
description: Citing a ''disappointing reception by the critics'' and low attendance, the National Theater announced today that the new Marvin Hamlisch musical, ''Jean Seberg,'' will close on April 4.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pudding and Politics (I)

title: Nigeria Curb On Currency LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 11 (Reuters) - Nigeria's military Government has imposed stringent new foreign exchange controls, banking officials said today.
description: They said central bank officials told commercial and merchant banks about the new regulations on Tuesday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DUTCH MASTERS

title: No Headline
description: Stanley Steemer Moves

title: PROVIDENCE STUNS BOSTON COLLEGE BY 1
description: Brian Waller hit a jump shot with 22 seconds to play tonight, putting Providence ahead for the first time, and the Friars held on to upset Boston College, 63-62.

title: Memorial for Anton Dolin
description: A memorial for the late Sir Anton Dolin, the English choreographer and dancer, will be held on Jan. 21 at 11 A.M. in the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. Among those expected to speak at the memorial, which is under the direction of Donald Saddler, are Dame Alicia Markova, Lillian Gish, Alexandra Danilova, Maria Karnilova and Tamara Geva.

title: WOR-TV RESHAPING ITSELF AS VOICE OF JERSEY
description: After three hours on the road and six hours reporting on a possible news story, Bob Miller reluctantly gave his TV producer the bad word about the assignment.

title: FIRST BANKERS CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. LOOKS TO TALKS WITH SYRIANS TO HELP SETTLE THE LEBANON CRISIS
description: Administration officials said today that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria had agreed to receive President Reagan's special Middle East envoy, Donald Rumsfeld. The meeting would come at a time when the United States attaches importance to better relations with Syria as a way of resolving the Lebanese crisis.

title: SOVIET VIEW OF GENEVA
description: The United States has expressed ''regrets'' about the discontinuation of the Geneva talks on the reduction of nuclear arms in Europe. We on the Soviet side feel that this is insincere. In fact, throughout the talks, we suggested and were prepared to effect large-scale, meaningful arms cuts, while the United States was never at any stage prepared to reduce its arms. It stubbornly proceeded with its nuclear buildup in Europe and at best agreed to consider deploying fewer missiles in exchange for unilateral disarmament by the Soviet Union.

title: NATO LEADER'S LANGUID AIR MASKS IRON RESOLVE
description: Lord Carrington, the former British Foreign Secretary, who will take over as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization this year, uses understatement, humor and languor to mask an underlying seriousness, commitment and determination.

title: NOW AN EX-SMOKER
description: ''I smoke for my health,'' I proclaimed on this page in 1979. Since I am a physician, this medical advice attracted amused attention. I reasoned that smoking made me cough and thus prevented pneumonia. Smoking made my heart go faster and eliminated need for additional exercise. Smoking curbed my appetite and kept me from getting fat. I no longer smoke for my health.

title: DeLorean's Judge Bids Agencies Present Data
description: The judge who will preside at the trial of John Z. DeLorean on drug charges ordered Federal agencies on Tuesday to turn over all related documents showing contacts between the United States and British Governments.

title: A PALESTINIAN PROFESSOR UNQUALIFIED TO BE CALLED A 'MODERATE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Frank X. Tolbert, 72, Is Dead; Columnist and Chili Fancier
description: Frank X. Tolbert, a longtime newspaper columnist and lover of chili who originated the Terlingua world championship chili cookoffs, died at home Monday night, a business associate said Tuesday. Mr. Tolbert was 72 years old.

title: DR. JACOB J. BEAVER
description: Dr. Jacob J. Beaver, who taught chemistry at Columbia University from 1921 to 1961, died Sunday at the Hallmark Nursing Center in Queensbury, N.Y. He was 90 years old.

title: GERIATRIC & MEDICAL CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
RIEGEL TEXTILE CORP reports earnings for 13 wks to Dec 31
BANK OF NEW YORK, THE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our task now, as a nation, is to transform the crisis in Central America into an opportunity: to seize the impetus it provides and to use this to help our neighbors not only to secure their freedom from aggression snd violence but also to set in place the policies, processes and institutions that will make them both prosperous and free.'' - The report of the President's commission on Central America. (A16:6.)

title: MORGENTHAU URGES END TO NIGHTTIME 'SUPERSTAR' CONCERTS IN CENTRAL PARK
description: The Manhattan District Attorney called yesterday for an end to nighttime ''superstar'' concerts in Central Park to help prevent the kind of violence that followed last summer's appearance by Diana Ross.

title: FLAWED ANALOGIES
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME ALTERNATIVES TO USING ROCK SALT
description: Icy sidewalks, steps, driveways and roads are among the most serious hazards of winter. What are the safest solutions?

title: No Headline
description: Furr's Cafeteria

title: Douglas to Build Jetliners in China LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP) - The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent with the Shanghai Aircraft Industrial Corporation of China to build 25 jetliners in China in a deal worth ''several hundred million dollars.''
description: The MD-80 airliners, twin-engine jets that carry about 150 passengers, would be assembled by the Chinese corporation, a McDonnell Douglas spokesman, Michael Eastman, said. McDonnell Douglas will provide parts and subassemblies.

title: MARSHALL & ILSLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Peter Herrick, president of the Bank of New York, has been named to the additional post of president of the parent, the Bank of New York Company.

title: Data General Net Nearly Triples The Data General Corporation said yesterday that its earnings nearly tripled in the first fiscal quarter of 1984 because the rise in demand for its computer products that began last summer was continuing.
description: The company, based in Westboro, Mass., said earnings soared to $9 million, or 36 cents a share, from $3.1 million, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues increased 21.1 percent, to $219.6 million, from $181.4 million.

title: REAGAN SETS SPEECH ON SOVIET
description: President Reagan, hoping to resume talks with the Soviet Union, will deliver a major address next Monday on the state of relations with Moscow, the White House announced today.

title: Stocks Fall for 3d Day in Row
description: Stock prices declined yesterday for the third consecutive session. Trading slowed as some of the recent hectic participation by institutional accounts slackened.

title: CIVIL DEFENSE CAN'T WARD OFF THE NUCLEAR WINTER
description: To the Editor:

title: A PALESTINIAN PROFESSOR UNQUALIFIED TO BE CALLED A 'MODERATE'
description: To the Editor:

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
ELECTRIC SNOW SHOVEL
description: SHOVELING snow can be a tiresome job, and it can be next to impossible for those with a delicate back. There are several new products to ease the strain.

title: LIMITED HANGOUT ROUTE
description: The story in The Washington Post today that the U.S.I.A. Director, Charles Wick, had secretly taped a conversation with former President Jimmy Carter contained this line: ''The U.S.I.A. no longer has a transcript of Wick's call to Carter, but the sources said the agency has given a document reconstructing the conversation to two Congressional panels. . . .''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pudding and Politics (II)

title: THURSDAY, JANUARY 12, 1984 International
description: A Soviet-Cuban challenge in Central America has ''importantly engaged'' United States security interests, according to a bipartisan Presidential commission. In a 132-page report, the commission proposed quick new infusions of military aid to El Salvador and a broad five-year, $8 billion economic aid program for the region. (Page A1, Column 6.) No bipartisan consensus on policy toward Central America was generated immediately by the recommendations of the Presidential commission, according to members of Congress. Republicans backed most recommendations, while Democrats generally deplored what they consider overreliance on military aid. (A20:1-2.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Celebrating Hamilton

title: SOCIAL SECURITY AID FOR THE MENTALLY ILL REINSTATED BY JUDGE
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered the Federal Government to reconsider its denial or termination of disability benefits to ''thousands'' of mentally ill New York State residents.

title: NEW PRESIDENT OF THE CITY TRANSIT AUTHORITY: DAVID LAWRENCE GUNN
description: He does not own a car and he would rather climb a mountain than crawl down a subway tunnel, but David L. Gunn still knows how to make wheels turn in the mass-transit business.

title: Bank Fund Rates Rise After three weeks without change, average interest rates on money market accounts nationwide increased slightly in the week ended yesterday, to 8.50 percent, from 8.49 percent, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.
description: ''It's a significant jump considering the flatness of the market,'' said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor. He attributed the rise partly to the decision by the Bowery Savings Bank to raise its money market account rate to 9.19 percent from 8.96 percent.

title: A Plan to Aid Ambrosiano's Creditors LONDON, Jan. 11 (Reuters) - An agreement in which the 93 creditor banks of Italy's failed Banco Ambrosiano may recover up to 80 percent of bad debts could be in place soon, banking officials said today.
description: They said the plan calls for the Vatican to contribute funds toward a total $450 million owed on two syndicated loans made to Banco Ambrosiano's Luxembourg subsidiary.

title: A FOUNDING FIGURE OF THE IRISH REPUBLIC DUBLIN, Jan. 11 (AP) - Sean MacEntee, a leading figure in the founding of the independent Irish Republic and the last surviving member of the first Fianna Fail Government, died Monday night at his home in Dublin, the party announced Tuesday. He was 94 years old.
description: In a tribute, Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald said Mr. MacEntee was the last link with the founding in 1921 of the Irish Free State, which later became the Irish Republic.

title: GENERAL IN ARMY RESERVE IS FOUND BOUND AND HANGED ON TEXAS BASE
description: A commanding general in the Army Reserve was found bound and hanged early today in a headquarters building on Fort Sam Houston, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: Required Reading Back to School
description: The Reagan Administration entered office with an ambitious domestic policy agenda. Federal aid to education was targeted for substantial reductions. Among its specific ideas, the Administration proposed to reduce Federal regulation, cut spending, enact a program of tuition tax credits, restore school prayer and abolish the Department of Education.

title: WHEN THEY WERE VERY YOUNG
description: In their youth, they probably wondered whether one day ''Mrs.'' would become part of their names.

title: TEXACO'S AGGRESSIVE LEADER
description: As president of Texaco Inc. during the 1970's, John K. McKinley was part of a senior management team that had gained a reputation as one of the stodgiest and slowest moving in the oil industry.

title: SUMMIT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DRUGS DULLING GOLDEN YOUTH IN YUGOSLAVIA
description: ''They don't want to work. They'd rather sleep until noon and get money from their parents. At night they make the rounds of five or six night spots - the new disco on Usicka Street. Our acquaintances, they don't believe in anything. Not in politics, the party or the state. Just clothes and music.''

title: BOOK OF THE TIMES
description: FEMININITY. By Susan Brownmiller. 270 pages. Linden/Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: GOVERNMENT ACTION TO REVIVIFY INDUSTRY IS PROPOSED IN STUDY
description: A group headed by prominent business and labor leaders has prepared a report proposing ambitious new Government institutions to restore industrial growth and competition.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Litton Executive to Run A Unit Going Private Justin S. Oppenheim has worked for Litton Industries for 24 years. Now, at age 60, he will soon head a private company made up of Litton's furniture, fixtures and office products group.

title: WOMEN AND COMPUTERS
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Tunisian Sees U.S. Envoy
description: President Habib Bourguiba conferred here today with Gen. Vernon Walters, special envoy of President Reagan, the Tunisian news agency reported. General Walters, who arrived here a week after rioting over food prices, said he had assured Mr. Bourguiba that the United States attached great importance to Tunisia's security.

title: SCOUTING
description: Going First Class

title: PROS AND CONS OF DEFEASANCE
description: Thanks to some creative accounting blessed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, Wall Street has a new product that it is eagerly peddling to corporate clients.

title: Mr. Kissinger's Unbalanced Bargain
description: It would be churlish for President Reagan to complain about the Kissinger commission's much- awaited verdict on his Central American policies. This distinguished panel has for the most part conferred bipartisan blessings on the Administration's basic contentions - that the United States indeed has a vital stake in Central America and that massive aid is needed to counter leftist revolutions encouraged by Moscow and Havana.

title: Sanyo 8 Millimeter
description: The Sanyo Electric Company plans to market eight-millimeter videotape systems under its own brand name in the United States by the end of 1984, a Sanyo official said.

title: Refinery Union Reaches Accord With Gulf Oil
description: The threat of a nationwide walkout by 50,000 refinery workers was averted today when the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union reached agreement with the Gulf Oil Corporation on a two-year contract that is expected to set a pattern for agreement.

title: TIMES ELECTRICIANS AGREE ON CONTRACT
description: The New York Times and its electricians have agreed on a three-year contract extension, Howard Bishow, vice president of employee relations, announced yesterday.

title: DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to Dec 17
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split, effective Nov. 18.

title: COURT DENIES ROLE TO COASTAL STATES IN U.S. OIL LEASES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal Government need not consider the environmental concerns of the coastal states when offering oil and gas leases for sale on the outer continental shelf.

title: 8 DEMOCRATS ARE ENTICED INTO A NO-RULES DEBATE
description: For three hours this Sunday, in an auditorium at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., all eight major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination will participate in an event whose plain purpose is to single out the best performer the Democratic Party can field against President Reagan, a former actor.

title: Key Rates
description: Kenny index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Israelis Allow Free Passage On Bridges to South Lebanon
description: Israel opened bridges crossing the Awali River to free passage today to ease the movement into and out of Israeli-occupied southern Lebanon.

title: Nissan Recall on 2 Models
description: Nissan U.S.A. announced Tuesday that it was recalling 238,055 Sentra autos for a wiper blade defect and 9,858 300-ZX sports cars with possibly faulty hood latches. The automobile maker said the Sentra malfunction involved subcompacts built from January 1982 to March 1983.

title: SMID TOPPLES NOAH IN MASTERS, 6-4, 6-4
description: Yannick Noah, who recently quit Paris for New York, played his first match in his adopted city last night and turned in a lackluster performance in losing to Tomas Smid, 6-4, 6-4.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Beneficial Corp. said its Beneficial Overseas Finance Corp. N.V. subsidiary would offer $100 million of 12 percent Eurobonds due in 1991, through Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. The issue price is to be fixed next Tuesday.

title: LAKE ONTARIO CEMENT LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A SAMPLER FROM 'LADIES'
description: ''. . . And Ladies of the Club,'' which spans the years between 1868 and 1932, chronicles the lives of two families in a small town in southwestern Ohio. The following excerpt recounts the shooting of President James A. Garfield.

title: JURY SELECTION BIAS NEEDS FULLER RESTRAINT
description: To the Editor:

title: PAYTON WEIGHS $6 MILLION OFFER
description: Walter Payton, the running back for the Chicago Bears, said yesterday he was considering an offer from the Chicago Blitz that would make him the highest-paid player in football.

title: Armada on Far East Cruise
description: An 11- ship battle group led by the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk will begin a seven- month cruise Friday in the Western Pacific, the Navy announced today. The San Diego-based armada, code- named Battlegroup Bravo, will patrol the waters off Asia and is scheduled to stop in Japan, Singapore, the Philippines, Thailand and Korea.

title: Palestinian Acquitted Of Killing P.L.O. Aide
description: An avowed Palestinian revolutionary was acquitted today of murdering a leading official of the Palestine Liberation Organization here last year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 12, 1984

title: Kaiser Posts Gain In Quarter
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, citing soaring demand for aluminum and gains from the sale of real estate, reported yesterday that it had posted a substantial profit in the fourth quarter of 1984.

title: LEBANESE ARMY BATTLES MOSLEMS IN SOUTH BEIRUT
description: Fighting flared through much of today between Government troops and Moslem militiamen in the southern Beirut suburbs and neighboring hills, forcing another delay incompleting an agreement on separating the Lebanese civil war antagonists.

title: German Shipyard Link
description: A merger plan for two major West German shipyards, Bremer Vulkan A.G. in Bremen and Hapag-Lloyd A.G. in Bremerhaven, has been approved, the state of Bremen's Economics Minister, Werner Lenz, said today.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: -controlled garage-door openers have been around for a long time, models designed for the do- it-yourself installer have been marketed for only a few years.

description: A Discoth eque Offers Its Glimpse of the Future

title: HIBERNIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $134,000. c-Including a tax credit of $1,801,000.

title: NATIONAL BANCORP OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRESERVING A SURVIVOR OF THE CLAPBOARD ERA
description: NEW YORK may be a city of survivors, but small clapboard houses are rare among them. Very few wooden buildings from the 18th and early 19th century have survived the city's fires and urban development. According to John Sanguiliano, the New York restoration architect and preservation consultant, there are now only about 20 privately owned and occupied wood-frame houses remaining of the once-numerous two- and three-story buildings that made up the vigorous first growth of structures in Manhattan.

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chrysler Seeks G.M. Deal Data
description: The Chrysler Corporation has asked the Federal Trade Commission to release key documents used in making its decision to approve tentatively a joint venture between the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation, a Chrysler spokesman said today.

title: Policy Proves Hard to Define
description: The term ''industrial policy'' was born in the Carter Administration's efforts to deal with the decline of the country's basic industries and the success of foreigners in penetrating American markets.

title: E.P.A. UNDER INTENSE PRESSURE TO ACT ON PESTICIDE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is coming under intense pressure from state governments and industry to set safety guidelines immediately for a pesticide being found in a growing number of food products, agency officials said today.

title: DETROIT MUSEUM DIRECTOR RESIGNING
description: Frederick J. Cummings, who during the last decade led the Detroit Institute of Arts to its greatest growth and success, announced his resignation as director yesterday after months of criticism over his spending practices and what his critics called favoritism toward friends.

title: Delay Sought On Citicorp WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) - Top Illinois officials urged the Federal Reserve Board today to delay a decision on a proposal by Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, to acquire the financially troubled First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Chicago.
description: Attorney General Neil Hartigan of Illinois said at an informal hearing by the Federal Reserve staff that the Citicorp acquisition would amount to ''a bank with 61 branches superimposed on the unit-banking system of Illinois.'' Citicorp is based in New York.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: A SYMPOSIUM ON METALWORK
description: Virtuoso: A Symposium, Cooper-

title: State Utility Bond To Yield 12.483% A $100 million issue of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation 12 3/8 percent bonds due in 1994 is offered today at a price of 99 3/8 to yield 12.483 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.
description: The bonds are rated Baa-2/BBBx by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's, respectively.

title: Extended Nutritional Deprivation
description: Meanwhile, another Presidential commission has been looking into hunger. Well, not exactly. It's been looking into the ''general claims of widespread hunger'' in America and it quickly became engrossed in disputations about the meaning of ''widespread'' and ''hunger.''

title: DEVELOPER PAYS EXPENSES FOR VOTING ON ZONING ON LITTLE HAWAIIAN ISLAND
description: Most of the $50,000 cost of a special election on the island of Kauai has been paid by a Japanese-owned development company that hopes voters will reverse themselves and remove a stumbling block to the completion of a multimillion-dollar project at Nukolii Beach.

title: NEW SOFTWARE DELIVERY IDEAS
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Carl Lewis , the track and field star, was named male athlete of the year for 1983 by an Associated Press panel of sportswriters and broadcasters. Wayne Gretzky , the hockey star, came in second, followed by Moses Malone , the basketball center, and Dale Murphy , the Atlanta outfielder. . . . Joe Theismann, the Washington Redskin quarterback, has been named the National Football League's most valuable player by the Pro Football Writers of America.

description: Under Pressure

description: Recalling Grim Days of 1783

description: Why Just Teachers?

title: AFTER 10 YEARS IN OFFICE, DETROIT MAYOR HAS FIRM HOLD ON CITY
description: Ten years after taking office, Coleman A. Young, Detroit's first black Mayor, is firmly entrenched as the dominant political figure in the city and is widely regarded as capable of winning re-election for as long as he cares to hold the office.

title: PAST AND PRESENT ROBOTS GATHER FOR EXHIBITION
description: WORDS failed Tot. It was only days before he was to usher visitors into the new exhibition at American Craft Museum 2, and all he could do was flail his arms or blurt out the wrong time. ''He's not outputting speech properly,'' said his creator, Jerome Hamlin. ''His battery must be low.''

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: WINDS OF HOPE IN ALBANY
description: The snow has fallen nearly a foot deep around the Capitol and now blows in great swirls about the statue of Philip Henry Sheridan, an Albanian, as people here call themselves, who went on to become one of the great cavalry commanders of the Civil War.

title: EX-CRIME LEADER IN DETROIT
description: Peter Joseph Licavoli Sr., the racketeer who headed the Purple Gang in Detroit in the Prohibition era, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 81 years old.

title: TOWN HELD BY REBELS SHIFTS GEARS
description: Guerrillas appear to have established firm control over this town and an area of about 60 square miles around it, giving them free access to the Pacific coast and authority over rich coffee and cotton plantations.

title: ESPRIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company commenced business in February 1983.

title: TRYING TO ESTABLISH A CAMPAIGN ISSUE
description: Many Democrats, from those running for President to those running for Congress, are trying to turn industrial policy into a 1984 campaign issue. But the effort, carried forward in the draft of the proposal presented today by the Industrial Policy Study Group, is proving difficult.

title: British Columbia Hydro Issue Sold A $200 million issue of British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority 12 1/2 percent bonds due in 2014 was offered at a price of 98.84 to yield 12.65 percent through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. The bonds, rated Aa-1, are not callable for 15 years and carried a yield that is 85 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, higher than 30- year Treusury bonds.
description: Underwriters said the issue was completely sold yesterday, and the bonds were offered in the secondary market at 98 7/8.

title: SUFFOLK WANTS ASSETS OF LILCO SEIZED FOR TAXES
description: Suffolk County officials yesterday asked the State Attorney General to take action against the Long Island Lighting Company to force it to pay $26.2 million in taxes that it is withholding.

title: LATE GOAL EXTENDS GRETZKY MARK TO 44
description: Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers scored an empty-net goal with two seconds remaining to extend his National Hockey League scoring-streak record to 44 games in a 5-3 victory tonight over the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: RATLIFF DRILLING & EXPLORATION COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

description: Thousands of blue-collar workers at the giant Weirton steel plant became their own bosses today as documents were signed creating the nation's largest experiment in employee ownership.

description: largest bank holding company, yesterday reported a 9.7 percent increase in fourth-quarter net income, to $126.1 million, from $114.9 million in the comparable quarter of 1982.

title: A STAR FINDS RECRUITING NO 'HASSLE'
description: The wooing of Craig Heyward is in its final stage.

title: LATIN PANEL ASKS STEPPED-UP HELP, CITING PERIL TO U.S.
description: Key sections of the report are on pages 6 to 8.

title: A 'Forgotten' Ticket Wins $3.35 Million
description: A New Jersey postal worker who had forgotten about a Lotto ticket is the winner of $3.35 million in the game's Dec. 31 drawing, State Lottery Division officials said today.

title: U.S. ROLE IN LEBANON FAULTED IN SENATE
description: Several Democratic Senators, with some support from Republicans, today attacked President Reagan's policy toward Lebanon, and called for the withdrawal of the Marines.

title: SOVIET CONFIRMS FIRE AT GAS PIPELINE
description: The official chiefly responsible for the new natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe confirmed today that there had been a fire at the first and biggest of the 41 pumping stations on the 2,800-mile line, but he denied that it would delay the commissioning.

description: Year-ago share earnings adjusted for 10 percent stock dividends in September 1982 and 1983 and a 3-for-2 stock split in January 1983.

description: For the fourth time in the last 16 years, the Ivy League institutions were on the losing side of a major legislative battle at a National Collegiate Athletic Association convention Tuesday. It is no coincidence, according to some college officials who admitted that the Ivy League is to the N.C.A.A. what a red cape is to a bull.

Psychiatrist, 33, Is Found Dead
description: A 33-year-old psychiatrist was found dead in his Bronx apartment on Tuesday, apparently of a self-inflicted stab wound, the police said.

title: 1,400 ATTEND RITES FOR OFFICER SLAIN DURING ELMIRA SHOOTOUT;
description: Three blank rifle shots and a pair of bugles sounded as an estimated 1,400 police officers gathered today for the funeral of the first Elmira police officer slain on duty since 1915, Sgt. John C. Hawley.

title: MARCOS ASKS NEW VOTER LIST, AS DETERMINED BY OPPOSITION
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos agreed today to the first of several demands made by opposition groups as conditions for taking part in National Assembly elections in May.

title: TARGETS IN U.S. ASSAIL TRADE CURBS BY E.E.C.
description: Representatives of the American chemical and sporting goods industries complained yesterday that they had been unfairly caught up in a trans-Atlantic dispute over steel trade.

description: Members of Congress indicated today that the Kissinger commission's recommendations had failed to generate an immediate, bipartisan consensus on United States policy toward Central America.

description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

description: A new ruling on natural gas pricing approved by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission today could result in more than $1 billion in refunds to consumers.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Baskin-Robbins in Shift Of Its Top Management The Baskin-Robbins Ice Cream Company announced yesterday that Robert J. Hudecek, president and chief executive, had been named chairman and will continue as chief executive.

title: 8 INCHES OF SNOW HITS METROPOLITAN AREA
description: The winter's first major snowstorm in the New York metropolitan area dropped between four and eight inches of snow before ending at 3:45 A.M. yesterday. There were three weatherrelated deaths, a number of traffic accidents and tie-ups, delays on commuter rail lines and some school closings.

title: IN A SHOW OF STUDIO GLASS, MULTITUDE OF FORMS AND IDEAS
description: GLASS has recently become an important collectors' item among the crafts. An indirect testament to this is the current show at the Heller Gallery - one of the first galleries in the country to specialize in serious glass work - ''Glass America 1984.''

title: TRUDEAU IN AN ARMS PLEA AT U.N.
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada proposed today that the five nuclear powers use the United Nations as a forum for talks on reducing nuclear weapons.

title: Dow-Allied Deal
description: Thd Dow Chemical Company has purchased new electrolytic cell technology from the Allied Corporation for producing chlorine and caustic soda, a Dow spokesman said. Dow purchased 12 patents and patent applications for an undisclosed price. The spokesman, Thomas Sinclair, said both materials are ''workhorse'' processing chemicals used in a variety of applications.

title: Pitcher Denied Bail
description: Pascual Perez , the Atlanta Brave pitcher who was arrested in the Dominican Republic Monday and charged with the possession of half?a gram of cocaine, has admitted that he had the drug in his wallet, according to a Dominican prosecutor. The official, Luis Coss , said that Perez, a Dominican native who had returned to his country after signing a new contract with the Braves Sunday, was being held without bail because of his criminal record, which includes arrests on a drug violation in 1982 and on a weapons charge last year.

title: Czech Playwright Defects
description: Czechoslovak emigres said today that a Czech playwright, Iva Prochaska; her husband, Ivo Pokorny, and their two small children arrived here about five days ago and asked for political asylum in Austria.

title: ADVERTISING ; Rapp & Collins Gets CARE Direct Account
description: CARE, the relief agency, has awarded its direct marketing account to Rapp & Collins, a subsidiary of Doyle Dane Bernbach.

title: Nakasone Acts on Curbs
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, in an effort to ease trade friction with the United States, instructed the Government and the ruling Liberal-Democratic Party today to complete a plan by March giving foreigners greater access to Japan's capital and financial markets, party officials said.

title: LITTLE-KNOWN AGENCY DRAWS WORLDWIDE INTEREST
description: A tiny Federal agency with an extraordinarily mandate has become a powerful magnet for government officials from all over the world.

title: Newsprint Shift At International PINE BLUFF, Ark., Jan. 11 (AP) - The International Paper Company said it plans to add to its capacity to produce white papers, used for envelopes and business forms, but that it is ending production of newsprint.
description: The shift was announced as the company disclosed plans to spend more than $300 million to modernize a paper mill at Mobile, Ala., which was built more than 50 years ago. It also said it would shut down two newsprint machines in Arkansas next month, idling 400 of the 1,400 workers at its Pine Bluff mill.

title: HIGH COURT CLEARS AWARD IN KAREN SILKWOOD CASE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal law did not bar the $10 million punitive damage award won by the estate of Karen Silkwood in a negligence suit against the Kerr-McGee Corporation.

title: 23 FOR BIRDSONGD
description: After having so many potential victories slip away in the fourth quarter this season, the Nets tonight built a second-half margin large enough to afford another collapse. But this time it did not occur.

title: RETAILERS HOPEFUL ON FIRST HALF
description: America's retailers concluded their annual convention in New York yesterday, expressing strong confidence about the year's first six months but some trepidation about the second.

description: b-Including a net gain of $8.9 million, or 33 cents a share, on the sale of a small portion of the company's phosphate reserves.

title: OUSTED GRENADA ELITE ARE NOW THE OUTCASTS
description: It seemed an unremarkable enough meeting in the Nutmeg Restaurant, where louvered windows open onto the quiet harbor: a young woman approaching a seated couple, exchanging a kiss and a few words, then moving off.

title: A $6 MILLION ARTS CENTER OPENS IN MIAMI
description: If the weather in this bustling tourist capital has always been celebrated, its cultural climate has not. But since Dade County voters approved a $553 million public bond issue in 1972 that provided substantial sums for recreation and the arts, things have been looking up.

title: HISTORIAN WAS 69
description: Ronald Lewin, the British military historian and former chief of the British Broadcasting Corporation's domestic radio service, died Friday at his home in Surrey, England. He was 69 years old and had been in ill health for some time.

description: A United States Army helicopter pilot was killed Wednesday in Honduras by hostile fire ''from the direction of the Nicaraguan border from a person or persons unknown'' after he made an emergency landing, the Defense Department said.

Gulf Italiana S.p.A. owns 75 percent of the 80,000-barrel- a-day Sarni refinery near Milan, along with 1,500 gasoline stations, terminals and aviation fuel outlets, a Gulf spokesman said. Gulf claims a 3.5 percent share of the gasoline market in Italy and a similar share of the petroleum products market.

Soviet Skier's Plight
description: Aleksandr Zavyalov , the Soviet cross-country skier who has twice won the sport's World Cup, may not be able to participate in the Olympics next month, according to a Soviet newspaper, which said he has been recuperating from a severe cold that had caused him to miss preliminary competition. As a result, according to the account in Soviet Sport, Zavyalov must do well in the national championships later this month to qualify for the six-man Olympic team.

title: A CLOSET IN A TENT
description: WHEN the Adamses, Janet and Howard, moved into a floor-through East Side apartment, they loved the high ceilings and the cozy atmosphere, but they desperately needed more closet space.

title: Suriname's Army Fails To End Bauxite Strike
description: Suriname's Army today failed to end a strike in the country's vital bauxite industry apparently aimed at toppling the military ruler, Desi Bouterse, the Dutch news agency A.N.P. reported.

description: A mother broke down in tears today as she testified how she watched her 6-year-old daughter perish on the ''Twilight Zone'' movie set after being assured the child was in no danger.

title: Circus Circus Inc. May Seek Dunes LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 11 (UPI) - Officials of Circus Circus Inc. may decide this week whether to pursue purchase of a controlling interest in the Dunes Hotel in Las Vegas.
description: ''We are going to seriously take a look at the Dunes,'' said William Bennett, chairman of Circus Circus Inc. ''I think it is a viable property for any good gaming operator.

title: STUDY INDICATES FEW CABLE-TV CHANNELS VIEWED

The study adds to a growing body of research suggesting that if cable systems offer 40 or more channels of programming to their subscribers, many of the channels may go practically unused.

title: GOLDEN AGE OF DUTCH AT THE MET
description: -century Dutch paintings that have just reached the Metropolitan Museum of Art have been touring the United States and Canada since the spring of 1982. The original purpose of their visit was to celebrate 200 years of friendly relations between the United States and the Netherlands. Comforting as that is, it doesn't rate more than a few moments' attention when compared with the other ''alliances'' implied by the paintings themselves.

title: CITY APPROVES A PLAN TO SAVE ON HEAT COSTS
description: New York City has agreed to let a private company improve the efficiency of heating systems in 50 to 60 city-owned buildings at no cost to the city, housing officials announced yesterday. In exchange, they said, the company will share with the city for seven years the money saved on fuel.

title: FOE OF FEDERAL WASTE
description: A few years ago, when J. Peter Grace was about to be interviewed by a newspaper reporter, he turned the tables by first interviewing the reporter. When, after a few minutes he was politely reminded of the purpose of the meeting, he smiled, observing: ''Of course, but I learn things by talking to as many people as I can.'' Yesterday Mr. Grace, the chairman of W. R. Grace & Company and of the President's Private Sector Survey on Cost Control, released the details of an 18-monthstudy of waste in Federal Government. The study will be formally presented to President Reagan on Monday.

title: DANCE: WON KYUNG CHO
description: WON KYUNG CHO'S feet often skimmed the ground. Yet he seldom seemed rushed at his solo concert of Korean dances on Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church. The program included both traditional dances and works choreographed by Myung Kyun Pae. All were unhurried, and the choreography featured gentle glides, smooth runs and dignified swayings of the arms. These were dances to calm, rather than to excite, the viewer.
