title: A LOOSE CHACON LEARNS TO FACE FACTS
description: The closer to fight time, the more revived Bobby Chacon seems to be. He was even joking today about broken noses, cut eyes and the ''black lights'' of unconsciousness.

title: MONEY BROKERS FACING F.D.I.C. INSURANCE CURB
description: The staff of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is recommending that the agency sharply restrict the federally backed insurance available on deposits placed by money brokers, a spokesman for the agency said yesterday.

title: WILANDER AND MCENROE GAIN MASTERS SEMIFINALS
description: A gesture of sportsmanship and a gesture of petulance marked yesterday's play at the Volvo Masters tennis tournament as Mats Wilander beat Jose Higueras and John McEnroe beat Johan Kriek to move into tomorrow's semifinals.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday KING JOHN' ON BOWERY

title: Osborne Is Certain
description: For almost two weeks, Tom Osborne , the Nebraska football coach, has been asked why he ordered the 2-point conversion attempt with 48 seconds left instead of trying to get the almost-sure extra point that would have given the Cornhuskers a tie with Miami in the Orange Bowl. That point would have given Nebraska a 12-0-1 record and a chance at the national championship.

title: STOUDT SIGNED BY THE STALLIONS
description: The Birmingham Stallions of the United States Football League today signed the Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback Cliff Stoudt after sending Reggie Collier, the Stallions' starting quarterback for much of last season, to the Washington Federals of the U.S.F.L.

title: High-Wire Performer Killed in 150-Foot Fall
description: A high-wire performer from Florida who once worked with Karl Wallenda plunged 150 feet to his death from a trapeze on a helicopter today as carnival spectators watched.

title: A BAND THAT'S MAKING RABELAISIAN GIANTS LIVE
description: ''Gargantua and Pantagruel'' are Renaissance giants, outrageous inventions of Francois Rabelais, who wrote about them in a sprawling work printed in the 16th century. This weekend, the New York Renaissance Band will bring them to life in a staged production with period music, instruments and costumes.

title: MUSIC: MANN AND SON
description: THE only flaw in Wednesday's superlatively played, superlatively interpreted program at the 92d Street Y by Robert Mann and his son, Nicholas, was that it ended anticlimactically. The two men began unexceptionably with 18th-century music for two violas by Jean-Marie Leclair, and followed with 20th-century music by Prokofiev, Ralph Shapey and Stefan Wolpe. They then concluded with Franz Krommer's Duo for Two Violins in E (Op. 110, No. 2) from 1829, which for all its energetic brilliance at the very end sounded pallid after all that modernist spice.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST MAKE PLEA TO OTHERS TO CONTINUE GIVING
description: Some contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund voice concern that many people will not share in the benefits of an improving economy.

title: DEATH SENTENCE CAN BE IMPOSED FOR ESPIONAGE, U.S. JUDGE RULES
description: The Federal district judge who will preside at the trial of James Durward Harper Jr., an engineer charged with espionage, has ruled that Mr. Harper is subject to the death penalty if convicted.

title: MERCANTILE TEXAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 results have been restated for an acquisition accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: FRIDAY, JANUARY 13, 1984 International
description: More military aid for El Salvador will be sought by the Reagan Administration, according to a White House official. He said officials were preparing to ask Congress for $250 million more in military aid in the present fiscal year, nearly four times the current level. He also said the Administration planned to seek about $350 million in military aid for El Salvador in the next fiscal year. (Page A1, Col. 6.) A report on Central America issued Wednesday by a Presidential advisory commission was challenged by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. The New York Senator said he found no evidence in the report to support the panel's position that a Soviet- Cuban challenge in the region represented a serious threat to United States security. (A8:5-6.)

title: SHELLING RENEWED IN BEIRUT REGION
description: Lebanese soldiers and Druse militiamen fought heavy artillery battles today as Donald Rumsfeld, the special American envoy, began talks with Syrian officials in Damascus on ways to separate Lebanon's warring factions.

title: MARCOS NAMES CENTRAL BANKER
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today named Jose B. Fernandez, a highly respected private banker, to be the new head of the Philippine central bank, the Government's television station announced.

title: THE METHOD BEHIND THE SUPER BOWL MADNESS
description: Thirty- one days has January, but in Washington the month can seem like an Arctic night when there is nothing to look forward to except the familiar political rituals and the first snow of winter.

title: La. Tech Romps
description: Janice Lawrence's 19 points led top- ranked and unbeaten Louisiana Tech to an 83-56 victory over Notre Dame tonight. Also in double figures for Louisiana Tech (12-0), which ran up a 41-25 halftime lead, were Pam Gant and Tori Harrison with 13 points apiece, and Kim Mulkey with 10. The game's high scorer was Laura Dougherty, who led Notre Dame (6-7) with 23 points.

title: FILM: 'ANGEL,' IN SCHOOL AND OUTSIDE THE LAW
description: -YEAR-OLD Molly, a pert student in pigtails at the exclusive North Oaks Prep School in Los Angeles, is called in for a little talk by her faculty adviser, a kindly woman who's worried about Molly's obsession with books. ''You know,'' she says with concern, ''there's more to life than straight A's.''

title: VERBATIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in August 1983.

title: Sharon Asks Portfolio In Israeli Government
description: Ariel Sharon, smarting from being rejected for a high immigration job on Wednesday, today lashed out at his colleagues in the governing Herut Party for denying him a portfolio in the Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

title: PETER KY LEE
description: Peter Ky Lee, professor emeritus of anesthesiology at the University of Florida's College of Medicine in Gainesville, died of a brain tumor Saturday at the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

title: SIX WOMEN FIND HARD HATS ARE A GOOD FIT
description: ''When I first began the job there were all kinds of remarks, all kinds of flak,'' Arvera Robinson said. ''Like what? Oh, go back into the kitchen. Go make babies. Stuff like that.''

title: RPM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 25 percent stock dividend paid Nov. 7, 1983.

title: SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOUSE FIRE KILLS QUEENS WOMAN AND 4 CHILDREN
description: A 22-year-old Queens mother and her four children died early yesterday when a fire destroyed the attic rooms in which they were sleeping.

title: THE U.S. SHOULD FUND NEITHER LEFT NOR RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Pancreatic Tumor Is Found In Surgery on Frank Church By The Associated Press
description: Former Senator Frank Church of Idaho has a tumor of the pancreas, surgery disclosed yesterday, but it was not known whether the tumor was cancerous, said officials at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital Center here.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Sierra Leone Students On Rampage in Capital

title: GOLDOME'S EXPANSION HITS SNAG
description: Regulatory problems have blocked the Goldome Bank for Savings from acquiring a commercial bank in Albany from the Bankers Trust Company of New York.

title: SPEARHEAD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a charge of $169,000 from a ruling by the U.S. Customs Court against the company.

title: SHULTZ VOWS 'CONSTRUCTIVE SPIRIT' IN STOCKHOLM TALK WITH GROMYKO
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he was prepared to discuss all the issues between the United States and the Soviet Union ''in a constructive spirit'' when he meets with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko next week in Stockholm.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Young Cardozo

title: HOW APARTHEID UPROOTS AND TRANSPLANTS MILLIONS
description: In parts of South Africa's brushlands, there stand, incongruously, row upon row of modest tin buildings, glimmering in the heat, morose sentinels of hard policies.

title: Texas Oil Net Up
description: The Texas Oil and Gas Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the first fiscal quarter of 1984 ended Nov. 30 rose 15.9 percent, while sales advanced 13.4 percent. The company, based in Dallas, said that net income in the latest three months rose to $79.5 million, or 38 cents a share, from $68.6 million, or 33 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues increased to $487.6 million, from $430.1 million.

title: 3 ARE SENTENCED TO PRISON TERMS IN SENTRY THEFT
description: Three men, including a father and son, were sentenced to prison terms yesterday on Federal charges involving the theft of $11 million in 1982 from the Sentry Armored Courier Corporation in the Bronx.

title: 6 Brokerage Firms Sued on Baldwin The Massachusetts Attorney General's office has sued six major brokerage firms in an attempt to hold them responsible for losses on $187 million worth of Baldwin-United annuities that they sold to about 8,500 state residents. The losses could total about $35 million, according to a statement from Francis X. Bellotti, the Attorney General.
description: The six firms against which he filed a civil suit in Suffolk Superior Court were Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.; E.F. Hutton & Company; Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc.; Shearson/American Express Inc.; Kidder, Peabody & Company, and Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Inc. Spokesmen for most of the firms either said they would not comment on pending litigation or denied wrongdoing.

title: CORESTATES FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in October.

title: Business Council Post
description: William L. Lurie, vice president and general counsel of the International Paper Company, has been named president of the Business Roundtable, it was announced yesterday. The Roundtable, comprising the chief executive officers of 200 major corporations, takes positions on public issues. Its president serves as executive director. Mr. Lurie, 52 years old, succeeds G. Wallace Bates, who is retiring after a decade in the post.

title: Chess Final Opens March 10
description: The final world championship chess match will begin March 10 in Vilnius, the capital of Soviet Lithuania, the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia has reported.

title: Sinclair's New Personal Computer
description: Sinclair Research Ltd., the pioneer in Britain's thriving home computer industry, introduced a new computer designed to retail here for just over $550 and to outperform leading personal computers such as the I.B.M. PC and the Apple IIe.

title: Paul Winter Consort
description: The Paul Winter Consort, whose music incorporates influences from around the world as well as the sounds of wolves and whales, will perform tonight at 8 P.M. at the Great Hall of Cooper Union (254-6300, ext. 205), Third Avenue and Seventh Street. Tickets are $10, and benefit the New York Open Center, 929-3166.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Good Deed

title: LIFE IN HIGH-STRESS SILICON VALLRY TAKES A TOLL
description: The Silicon Valley of California has been portrayed as a vision of the American post-industrial future, the epitome of free enterprise, a place where anybody with brains, a good idea and the courage to exploit it can make an overnight fortune in electronics.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WARSAW RETREATS OVER FOOD PRICES
description: In the face of widespread criticism of proposed increases in food prices, the Polish authorities announced today that there would be no change in the cost of such staples as cooking oil, cottage cheese and low-quality beef.

title: SCOUTING
description: One Who Knows Praises Sampson

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 15-year veteran of the New York City Police Department, Officer Roy Lucien Jr., surrendered yesterday after his indictment by a Queens grand jury on charges that he stole more than $250 in jewelry during two 1981 burglary investigations. . . . Raymond Melendez Torres, 19 years old, was arrested at 4 A.M. at Kennedy International Airport after a flight from Puerto Rico and charged with fatally stabbing a grocer during a robbery attempt Jan. 5. The grocer, Azanally Abrahim, was stabbed in his store on East 143d Street in the Bronx. Mr. Torres is also charged with stabbing Mr. Abrahim's 14-year-old helper. . . . Calvin Jones, 24, and Eugene Bryant, 26, were arrested and charged with holding up a retired police officer, John Jaklitsch, and demanding his wallet at 1 P.M. on Gates Avenue in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. Mr. Jones was wounded by Mr. Jaklitsch and was taken to Woodhull Hospital in critical condition. Mr. Bryant was not injured.

title: ConflictCited by Raiders
description: The Los Angeles Raiders today accused Justice Marc Poche of the State Court of Appeals of having an ''unconscionable'' conflict of interest when he wrote a court opinion against the football team Dec. 29.

title: Banker Pleads Guilty
description: An official of the failed Penn Square Bank pleaded guilty today to Federal charges of conspiracy to commit bank fraud and income tax evasion in a scheme involving loans worth millions of dollars, United States Attorney Bill Price said. Mr. Price said Thomas Orr, former executive vice president of the bank, had been involved in a scheme through which he made loans for the purchase of thoroughbred horses in return for a 10 percent commission from the buyers.

title: 4 CONVENTION CENTER HALL OFFICIALS REPLACED
description: The new head of New York City's Convention Center has replaced four of the center's officers, including the official in charge of its construction on a day-to-day basis.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Associates Corp. of North America, a unit of Gulf and Western Industries, said its $100 million issue of 11 3/4 percent notes due in 1988 was priced at par, through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The issue is rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service and Ax by Standard & Poor's Corp.

title: Tampa to Build Domed Stadium
description: The Tampa Bay Baseball Group signed a contract today to build a 46,000-seat domed baseball stadium adjacent to Tampa Stadium.

title: Chlordane Found In 5 L.I. Schools
description: Traces of the pesticide chlordane, which is suspected of causing cancer, have been found in five schools in the Northport-East Northport School District, officials said today.

title: SERVED ON COUNCIL OF TWELVE
description: Mark E. Petersen, who was second in line to succeed Spencer W. Kimball as president of the Mormon Church, died Wednesday night of complications related to cancer.

title: FORNATALE'S RADIO SHOW OF THE NOT SO LONG AGO
description: When the songs were young, so was the audience. The listeners may have been joining an anti-Vietnam War rally the first time they heard James Taylor sing ''Fire and Rain,'' or perhaps they were lying on the beach at midnight the first time they heard Judy Collins sing ''First Boy I Loved.''

title: BEYOND THE BORDERS OF IMMUNITY
description: The embassy business is booming.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 13, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: In Albany, a Big Stick and a Bad Bet; A Sports Lottery: More Lottery Than Sport
description: Governor Cuomo's suggested sports lottery for New York would hoodwink citizens into believing they are betting on their sports savvy when they would simply be betting on their lottery luck. And it would yield only modest revenue.

title: Boy, 11, Is Killed In a Harlem Fire
description: An 11-year-old boy was killed when a fire swept through his family's apartment in Harlem last night, the police said.

title: 9 JERSEY CASINOS HAD 1983 GROSS OF $1.77 BILLION
description: Atlantic City's nine casinos grossed $1.77 billion last year, the Casino Control Commission reported today, an 18.6 percent increase over the 1982 total.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm not saying there is no evidence. But if you go to all this effort, facts please.''

title: HELP TO STOP THE INCIPIENT CHILD ABUSER
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Company News report in Business Day on Wednesday misstated the amount of a debt repayment for which a subsidiary of Alhambra Mines Inc. received a notice of default. The amount is $97,580.65.

title: Refinery Pact Averts Strike
description: Negotiators for the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union reached a tentative contract agreement with the Atlantic Richfield Company tonight, averting a strike set for noon Friday by nearly 2,000 union workers in in Texas and California. Terms of the two-year contract proposal, which faces a ratification vote by workers, were not immediately available.

title: Article 173938 -- No Title
description: Governor Kean announced today a $3 million plan to upgrade the football facilities at Rutgers University to try to attract talented players, build a winning team and increase attendance.

title: F.C.C. SEEKS EASING OF STATION BUYING RULES
description: The Federal Communications Commission today proposed to scrap a rule intended to keep a broadcaster from building a monopoly in any region of the country.

title: U.S. CALLS KILLING OF PILOT RECKLESS
description: The Government said today that a United States Army helicopter pilot killed Wednesday near the Nicaragua-Honduras border had come under fire from Nicaraguan troops after his forced landing in Honduras. The White House called the killing ''reckless and unprovoked.''

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Parachute Is the Wrong Target
description: It is easier for the officers of a company to devote their full attention to a takeover attempt if they know they will be financially secure no matter who wins. - Martin Lipton, a lawyer specializing in corporate takeovers.

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
ARABS AND JEWS IN HARMONY: 'SOME SEEDS HAVE BEEN PLANTED'
description: To the Editor: In its emphasis on emotional extremes (young children, victims of military brutality and disappointed lovers), David Shipler's series presented a powerful portrayal of conflict, but not a comprehensive picture of the reality of Jewish-Arab relations. Mr. Shipler has thereby aided those who espouse the politics of despair. In actuality, the situation is far more complex than the portfolio of negative snapshots offered. Early in 1982, the Institute for Middle East Peace and Development at the City University of New York Graduate Center, carried out over 5,000 interviews in Israel, Egypt and the Gaza Strip to learn about Jewish and Arab attitudes toward their political future. Results of this largest-ever survey on the conflict show a wide spectrum of opinion among both Jews and Arabs about the chances for peace, with a solid majority on both sides favoring negotiation over confrontation.

title: Bridge: Sometimes a Hand Manages To Survive New Year's Day
description: Many players bring in the New Year while indulging in their favorite game, and a few of them find that an individual duplicate event provides the appropriate atmosphere.

title: BATON BROADCASTING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 31
CABLE TV CUTS ASKED IN MILWAUKEE
description: Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc., one of the country's largest cable companies, yesterday asked the City of Milwaukee for major revisions in the ambitious cable system it is building for that city.

title: 76 GROUPS TO PERFORM IN OLYMPICS ARTS FESTIVAL
description: by ALJEAN HARMETZ

title: BIPARTISAN DEFICIT UNIT ADVANCES
description: President Reagan and his advisers, unable to agree on drastic remedies to reduce the Federal deficit, were reported today to be leaning toward recommending the creation of a bipartisan Presidential commission to come up with new budget solutions.

title: Africa Foundation President
description: Constance Hilliard, a foreign policy specialist on Capitol Hill, has been named to be first president of the United States-sponsored African Development Foundation, officials said today. Dr. Hilliard, a Harvard graduate in African and Middle East studies, is an adviser to the Republican members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The foundation was created in 1980 to promote development of private aid for economic and social development in Africa.

title: WAR POWERS: BACK IN COURT
description: For the first time since the Vietnam War, the Federal courts are being forced to grapple with allegations that the President has illegally usurped the power of Congress by waging an undeclared war. The issue this time centers on Central America. The latest development on the legal front was a ruling Tuesday by Federal District Judge Stanley A. Weigel in San Francisco that President Reagan and top defense aides may have committed criminal violations of the Neutrality Act of 1794 by supporting guerrilla attacks on Nicaragua.

title: ISLAMIC CONFERENCE LEADER GLUM ON PARLEY'S PROSPECTS
description: Foreign ministers of about 40 Moslem countries who are here to draft an agenda for an Islamic Conference meeting heard a gloomy description of disunity today from the conference's Secretary General. The Islamic meeting is to open Monday in Casablanca.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: STAGE: GRAVESIDE 'HAMLET' BY CHRISTOPHER MARTIN
description: ''HAMLET'' has often been subjected to directorial interpretation, including last season, when he was played by a young actress, but Christopher Martin's version must be considered a pioneering act of iconoclasm. Admitting that this is an adaptation rather than the Real Thing, he and his collaborator, Karen Sunde, subtitle the play, ''After Shakespeare.'' Were Shakespeare alive, he undoubtedly would be after Martin.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Chicgo Board Planning Municipals Contract

title: NORDIQUES OUTCLASS DEVILS AND WIN, 4-1
description: The Quebec Nordiques were so much better than the Devils here tonight that the local team had difficulty even when the visitors were playing a man short.

title: Judge Dismisses Counts In House of Judah Trial
description: A judge today dismissed charges against two members of a religious cult who were accused of beating a 12-year-old boy to death, but ruled that there was sufficient evidence to continue the trial for William A. Lewis, who is called the prophet of the cult.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Little Changed
description: Interest rates were little changed in quiet trading yesterday, as dealers waited for new economic data to be released today. The economic data, which includes retail sales and industrial production for December, are expected to show that the economy is continuing to expand at rapid rate.

title: CYRIL B. EGAN
description: Cyril B. Egan, a mathematics instructor at Regis High School in Manhattan for 44 years who also taught at Fordham University and Pace College, died last Friday at Westchester Square Hospital in the Bronx.

title: Blakey and Messengers
description: The drummer Art Blakey will lead his Jazz Messengers tonight and tomorrow at the Village Gate (475- 5120), Bleecker and Thompson Streets. Sets begin at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M.; there is an $8 cover and a two- drink minimum.

title: WILLIAMS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Proxy Fight Seen
description: Howard M. Benedek and Michael J. Kaplan, directors of a stockholders group that controls the largest block of common shares within Electronic Associates Inc., announced that they intended to wage a proxy fight for control of the New Jersey-based manufacturer of computer simulators. They said that they intended to solicit proxy votes for the election of candidates they will propose to fill seven upcoming vacancies on the company's 10-member board. The company's stock closed down 12 1/2 cents, to $7.75, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Financial Corp. and its chairman, Carl Lindner, said they had increased their stake in Circle K Corp., an operator of convenience food stores, to the equivalent of 5.83 million common shares, or 37.8 percent of the total outstanding.

title: CUOMO VOWS AID FOR STATE EQUAL RIGHTS MEASURE
description: Governor Cuomo told leaders of women's groups yesterday that he would commit whatever resources were needed to win passage from the voters next year of a New York State constitutional amendment guaranteeing equal rights for women.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise Assets of the nation's money market funds rose $1.1 billion, to $164.6 billion, in the period ended Wednesday, the largest weekly increase in 14 months, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.
description: Despite the rise in assets, seven- day yields on the funds declined to 8.81 percent from 8.94 percent, Donoghue's Money Fund Report said.

title: Trump Says Taylor Can't Buy Out of Pact
description: Donald Trump refused initial offers yesterday by Lawrence Taylor's agent to buy back the option that obligates the star linebacker to start playing for Trump's New Jersey Generals in 1988.

title: CSX Aide to Step Down
description: The CSX Corporation said today that Dennis R. Hendrix, its vice chairman, plans to resign next month to pursue other business interests.

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Amtrak Facing Asbestos Charges
description: The New Jersey Public Advocate charged in a complaint filed today that Amtrak consistently violates Federal safety standards for worker exposure to harmful asbestos fibers.

title: A Chiropractor Is Fined in Jersey
description: A Passaic County chiropractor who admitted bilking insurance companies for services he did not perform was fined $5,000 today and ordered to perform 200 hours of community service a year for five years.

title: TAR HEELS TOP MARYLAND, 74-62
description: Coach Lefty Driesell of Maryland had been saying that he finally had a team this season that could play North Carolina on even terms. For almost 38 minutes tonight, that was true.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN GEORGIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Anheuser-Busch Companies, St. Louis, has named Jerry E. Ritter vice president and group executive.

title: Eastern Airlines
description: Eastern Airlines' unionized flight attendants have voted to approve a $367 million financial bailout plan, leaving only the pilots to cast ballots on the proposal negotiated in December.

title: ARGENTINA OUTLINES DEBT PLAN
description: Bernardo Grinspun, the Minister of Finance in the new civilian Government of Argentina, said in private conversations today that his nation needs $20 billion this year to pay the interest and principal on its foreign debt.

title: JOURNAL PUBLISHES DISPUTED STUDY ON CANCER INCREASES IN MORMANS
description: A study finding that radioactive fallout from nuclear bomb tests in Nevada has caused an excess of cancer among Mormons living in southern Utah has been published in this week's issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: uf912
description: To the Editor:

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Golden State Warriors vs. Nets, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. Buck Williams had a big game with 23 points and 16 rebounds when the Nets beat the Warriors in Oakland last month.

title: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: Year-ago sales figures include gains from discontinued operations of $1,109,367 for the quarter and $2,038,029 for the 6 months.

title: BROADWAY
description: WHEN ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' the new Stephen Sondheim- James Lapine musical, was being developed last summer in a top-secret workshop at Playwrights Horizons, there was little doubt that the show would turn up on Broadway this season. It was just a question of when and where. All that has now been answered. ''Sunday in the Park With George'' will open April 22 at the Booth Theater. It will star Mandy Patinkin and Bernadette Peters, and will be directed by Mr. Lapine. The producers are the Shubert Organization, Emanuel Azenberg and Playwrights Horizons.

title: OFF THE BEATEN PATHS AT CITY TREASURE HOUSES
description: NEW YORK CITY museums are an extraordinary resource. For one thing, there are more than 70 museums listed for Manhattan alone in the 1984 Official Museum Directory, devoted to a range of subjects that includes textiles, seafaring and holography. Another measure of that resource is the quality not just of big exhibitions, which may hammer the public into submission with their crowds and publicity, but also of small ones, where the work is just there, with space to listen and think. While crowds line up for Manet, people rummaging through the small galleries and empty halls of the Metropolitan discover the real character and strength of the museum.

title: ACAPULCO Y LOS ARCOS RESTAURANTES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Net income. Results for 1983 include a charge of $4,800,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Stocks Regain Ground; Dow Up 1.99
description: The stock market rose slightly yesterday in active trading, after declining in the preceding three sessions. Issues responding to specific news posted the largest price moves.

title: INNOPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
STUDY BACKS CUTTING CHOLESTEROL TO CURB HEART DISEASE RISK
description: Medical researchers today announced ''the first study to demonstrate conclusively'' that lowering cholesterol levels in the bloodstream reduced the rate of heart attacks in a high-risk group of middle- aged men.

title: ROYAL BUSINESS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-Net income.

title: CRAFT MUSEUM 2 PRESENTS ROBOTS
description: Looking vaguely like a mechanical mushroom, the 29-inch Bubblebot goes on public view today - together with 160 other robots and robot images - at the American Craft Museum 2 in the International Paper Plaza, 77 West 45th Street. ''The Robot Exhibit: History, Fantasy and Reality'' will be open through May 11, Monday to Saturday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $1.50; 75 cents for children, students and the elderly. More information: 397- 0605.

title: MILITARY-SCHOOL FICTION, HOTEL-CRIME REALITY
description: -fire ingredients, ''Hard Knox'' has them all, or pretty nearly all: an honorable, aging warrior, a military school, cadets who look like the Bad News Bears, a hint of romance, a spoonful of sentiment (a couple of spoonfuls, actually), the Marine Corps hymn and a foot race. Occasionally, ''Hard Knox'' even gets the ingredients to work. Mostly, however, it doesn't, and ''Hard Knox'' is just another two-hour television movie, painless but not necessarily interesting. This ''NBC Movie of the Week'' will be seen on Channel 4 tonight at 8.

title: A New Managing Look At D'Arcy MacManus
description: The new look at D'Arcy MacManus Masius Worldwide, as you can tell at a glance, means the disappearance of a hyphen, a comma and an ampersand. But that change, and the simple DMM logotype accompanying it, was not the most exciting announcement yesterday from Hal Bay, chairman and chief executive.

title: In Albany, a Big Stick and a Bad Bet; Rescuing Probation, a Stepchild of Justice
description: ''There's a difference between being tough and being loud,'' candidate Mario Cuomo said about his crime policy. But as Governor, he's disappointed those who hoped a quiet administrative approach would make criminal justice work better.

title: CALLON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: FORMER CONGRESSMAN GIVEN 18-MONTH ABSCAM SENTENCE
description: A judge today sentenced former Representative Richard Kelly, Republican of Florida, to six to 18 months in prison for his Abscam bribery conviction. It was the lightest jail sentence given any of the seven members of Congress convicted in the investigation.

title: COMPUSHOP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss. Results reflect the pooling-of-interest acquisition of Time-Tronics Inc. in the fourth quarter of 1983.

description: The 74th National Boat Show

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures were adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split in January 1984.

CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The earnings per share for 1983 reflected common stock issued during the year, and preferred stock issued in the second and third quarters of 1982.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Coghlan Out of Action
description: Eamonn Coghlan , the world's fastest indoor miler, suffered a stress fracture last month that has forced him to abandon the indoor season, including scheduled appearances at the Wannamaker-Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden on Jan. 27 and the Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational at the Meadowlands Feb. 11. According to Howard Schmertz , the Millrose director, Coghlan suffered the stress fracture of his right tibia in early December but had hoped that he would recover from the shin injury in time for the Millrose Games.

title: Library Shuttle Bus
description: Starting tomorrow, the New York Public Library will run a free shuttle bus Saturdays from the Epiphany Branch, 228 East 23d Street, which is closed for renovation, to the Muhlenberg Branch, 209 West 23d Street, not open Saturdays, to the Jefferson Market Library at Avenue of the Americas and 10th Street. A valid library card is all that is needed to board the bus, which will leave the Epiphany branch at 11 A.M., noon and 1 P.M. Return trips from Jefferson Market are at 11:40 A.M. and 12:40 and 1:40 P.M.

title: LATIN PANEL'S SOVIET FINDING IS CHALLENGED BY MOYNIHAN
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today that he found no evidence in the report of the commission on Central America to support its position that a Soviet- Cuban challenge in the region represented a serious threat to United States security interests.

title: REAGAN PLANNING ARMS AID INCREASE FOR EL SALVADOR
description: The Reagan Administration is preparing to ask Congress for $250 million in military aid for El Salvador, nearly four times the current figure for this year, a White House official said today.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: PRUNELLE'S decor is stunning. Its service is impeccable. Its contemporary food is neither. For every well-prepared dish, there is one that shows a distinct lack of imagination.

title: MALONE & HYDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 10
COURT SUPPORTS MRS. ONASSIS ON AD
description: The rights of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis were ''trampled upon'' when the fashion house of Christian Dior used a look-alike model in a recent advertising campaign, a State Supreme Court justice said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Battling Ethnic Insults

title: Appeals Judge Stays Execution in N. Carolina
description: Judge J. Dickson Phillips Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit issued a stay of execution at midnight today for James W. Hutchins, a convicted murderer who had been scheduled to die by injection at 6 A.M. Friday, said Joe Cheshire, one of the defense attorneys.

title: Study Group Checks Treatment of Disabled
description: A California study commission reported today that many people were sexually abused and otherwise mistreated in some community care facilities that house the elderly or handicapped.

title: VLSI TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: b-Net loss.

title: Financial Services At K Mart DETROIT, Jan. 12 (AP) - The K Mart Corporation, the nation's second-largest retailer, said today that it would expand its financial services operations, a move it has contemplated for some five years.
description: The retailer, based in Troy, Mich., said it would add 50 insurance centers to stores in Texas and Florida and offer savings accounts, on a test basis, at three of the centers in Florida.

title: MEMBERS OF REVIEW PANEL
description: The commission subcommittee that reviewed all 47 reports on cutting Government costs was headed by J. Peter Grace, chairman and chief executive officer of W. R. Grace & Company. The other members were: Joseph Alibrandi, president and chief executive officer, Whittaker Corporation. Bennett Archambault, chairman, president and chief executive Officer, Stewart Warner Corporation. O. T. Berkman, president and chairman,

description: Changing Signals

title: NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 per share figures have been adjusted to reflect the 10 percent stock dividend declared on Jan. 10, 1983.

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SCREEN: 'KAMILLA'
description: ''Kamilla'' was shown in last year's ''New Directors/New Films'' series. Following is Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times last March 20. The film opens today at Lincoln Plaza 3, Broadway, between 62d and 63d Streets.

title: KAUFMAN'S 'JUNE MOON' A REVIVAL AND TESTAMENT
description: One day late in George S. Kaufman's life, when he had stopped writing plays and started appearing on television shows, he told his daughter, ''I suppose I'll be remembered as a TV star and not as a playwright.''

title: CHRYSLER BRINGS G.M.-TOYOTA SUIT
description: The Chrysler Corporation filed suit today in Federal court to block a proposed joint venture between the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation to build subcompact cars in California.

title: CLARK SAYS HE WILL OFFER A ROLE TO CRITICS IN OFFSHORE OIL LEASING
description: Interior Secretary William P. Clark announced today that he was overhauling the offshore oil leasing program to increase public participation and take greater account of environmental concerns.

title: 9.4% RISE IN OUTLAYS IS PLANNED
description: American business, spurred by the continuing economic expansion and reductions in business taxes, plans a sharp 9.4 percent increase in spending on new plants and equipment this year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Terms of Inspiration

title: New Tiffany Chairman
description: William R. Chaney, executive vice president of Avon Products Inc., has been named to the additional post of chairman of its Tiffany & Company unit, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Chaney, 51 years old, will fill the post vacated at the end of last year when David W. Mitchell retired as chairman of both Tiffany and Avon. Anthony D. Ostrom continues as president of Tiffany.

title: JOSEPH A. BONDANZA Jr.
description: Joseph A. Bondanza Jr., a lawyer and a former president of Flushing Hospital in Queens, died of a heart attack on Jan. 3 at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 64 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: ; A CAR INDUSTRY THAT DESERVES TO GO UNDER
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: MEL LEWIS AND BAND GAZE INTO JAZZ FUTURE

title: Drug Charge Disputed
description: The Atlanta Brave pitcher Pascual Perez , arrested Monday in the Dominican Republic on charges of possessing half a gram of cocaine, said he was not a drug user and would clear his name in court. ''I swear that I have never consumed cocaine, neither am I a drug addict,'' Perez said in a telephone interview from the prison where he has been held in Santiago, 90 miles northwest of Santo Domingo.

title: TAIWAN SEEMS UNEASY ABOUT ZHAO'S VISIT TO U.S.
description: The visit of Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China to the United States has aroused unease in Taiwan that it may portend new setbacks when President Reagan visits Peking in April.

title: FOR GOODE, CO-OP TREAT
description: The pianist Richard Goode, who will perform Mozart's Concerto in B flat (K. 456) tonight at Lehman College in the Bronx and tomorrow at Carnegie Hall, has been rehearsing with particular pleasure. He's playing it with Orpheus, the orchestra that has no conductor, and Mr. Goode has been working with its 26 members in a way in which he almost never can with other orchestras.

title: SECURITY FOR EUROPE
description: The full acronym of the Conference on Confidence- and Security-Building Measures and Disarmament in Europe, known as C.D.E., never tumbled trippingly from the tongue of even the staunchest bureaucrat. Yet the conference, which opens in Stockholm next week, marks a new and important phase in East-West negotiations. Its purpose is not arms control or arms reduction in the usual sense; rather, it will seek to make it more difficult for either side to use the arms that do exist in Europe for surprise attack or intimidation. The conference also represents the first East-West arms negotiation inaugurated during the Reagan Administration.

title: NORTHERN TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFING
description: Taking No Chances

title: ADVERTISING
description: '14 Wonderful Years'

title: Hazeltine Wins F.A.A. Contract The Hazeltine Corporation of Greenlawn, L.I., was awarded a $90.6 million contract yesterday to begin producing a radically advanced type of landing aid that will enable planes to fly a wide variety of approach paths to airport runways.
description: Under the Federal Aviation Administration contract, the agency said, the company will deliver 172 of the new landing aids over a five-year period beginning in the summer of 1985.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Jack LaRue, Actor, Is Dead; In 200 Films, Often as Villain
description: The actor Jack LaRue, who appeared in 200 films, often as a villain, suffered a heart attack and died Wednesday at St. John's Hospital.

title: S.E.C. INVESTIGATING POWER BOND SALE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday announced a formal investigation into the sale of bonds issued by the Washington Public Power Supply System.

title: Farm Credit Bond Yields Are Set The Federal Farm Credit System announced interest rates for two bond issues totaling $1.26 billion, which are being offered through various securities dealers.
description: A $633 million issue of bonds due April 21, 1986, is offered with a 10.85 percent yield, or five basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, higher than for outstanding Treasury issues of comparable maturity. A $625 million issue due Jan. 23, 1989, is offered with an 11.65 percent yield, or 15 basis points higher than comparable Treasury issues. Both issues are offered at a price of 100.

title: KISSINGER'S OFFICE SITE OF PROTEST
description: A group of about 50 demonstrators gathered yesterday outside the building where former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has his New York office to protest the recommendations made Wednesday by the commission he headed on Central America.

title: Alcoa Subsidiary
description: Soldiers armed with carbines guarded the Suriname Aluminum Company plant in Paranam today after the owners shut it down and laid off 2,300 workers in response to spreading labor unrest. The plant is run by Suralco, a subsidiary of the Aluminum Company of America, which is based in Pittsburgh. The troubles at the plant were part of a growing workers' protest in this former Dutch possession against the military Government's tax policies.

title: SWEDES REACH ACCORD ON RETURN OF COMPUTER PARTS THEY SEIZED
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation agreed today to buy computer parts recently seized in Sweden, officials said. The United States had charged that the equipment was being smuggled to the Soviet Union.

title: FOR A QUAINT TOWN IN FLORIDA, A QUEST FOR A BUMPY ROAD TO PROSPERITY
description: Winter Park is to central Floridians what the Hamptons are to New Yorkers: old, quaint and elegant.

title: HANGING DEATH OF TEXAS GENERAL A MYSTERY TO FEDERAL INVESTIGATORS
description: Federal investigators sought today to unravel the bizarre hanging death of an Army reserve general, puzzling over contradictory physical evidence and trying to find out about the state of his mind.

title: Recognizing Rome - and Politics
description: President Reagan's decision to restore diplomatic relations with the Vatican sounds purely political. The diplomatic arguments for doing it are thin. The arguments against it are hardly stronger, but they are deeply felt by millions of Americans. So why revive such a contentious issue? We suspect Richard Wirthlin's polling for the White House indicated that on balance, it's a winner.

title: MUSIC: ORMANDY'S BARTOK
description: RICCARDO MUTI is supposedly attempting to alter and vary the ''Philadelphia sound'' as the Philadelphia Orchestra's new music director. But when his predecessor, Eugene Ormandy, is on the podium, as he was Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, it is as if nothing has changed. Mr. Ormandy looks frailer than he used to.

title: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LSI LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Simons Leads by 3 on 63-132
description: Jim Simons, under near-ideal playing conditions, shot a 9-under-par 63 at the La Quinta course and took a three-stroke lead today after two rounds of the $400,000 Bob Hope Desert Classic.

title: FALSE NOTIONS ABOUT COMPUTERS
description: Many computer companies have spent considerable sums on advertisements that build parental computer guilt: the idea that children will fail in school and life if they don't have a home computer. This is a clever and deceptive play to public fears and is nothing more than a high-tech version of encyclopedia sales.

title: PUBLISHING: FROM TV TO BEST SELLERS
description: THE debate over whether television contributes to illiteracy may never be settled, but one thing is beyond debate: television exposure can do wonders for the sale of books.

title: BREEDERS CUP IS PLAGUED BY PROBLEMS
description: This is the year of the Breeders Cup, the ambitious new program that is supposed to revolutionize thoroughbred racing by distributing $20 million in bonuses to the top finishers in major races, including $10 million in seven new rich races Nov. 10 at Hollywood Park. But less than two weeks into the new year, it is obvious that the program is in trouble.

title: Signal Companies Offers Debentures A $103.4 million issue of Signal Companies 8 percent subordinated debentures due in 2009 is being offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Lazard Fr eres & Company.
description: Each $1,000 of the debentures may be exchanged at any time for 25 common shares of the Unitrode Corporation owned by Signal. Proceeds of the financing will be used by Signal for general purposes.

title: Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. announced an agreement with Safeway Stores and National Transaction Systems, which handles the processing of cash machines in Safeway stores, to permit the Cash Management Account Visa cards of the securities firm to be used in some of those stores. The cards will be usa ble in machines in 54 Safeway stores in southern California beginning in March and in another 50 stores in northern California later in the year. Plans call for a maximum of $500 to be withdrawn in each transaction, and a fee of $1 per transaction.

title: WHEN A STOCK FALLS ABRUPTLY
description: R ARELY a week passes without some stocks displaying such large price declines in a single day that unsuspecting investors might well wonder if they had somehow missed, say, a 5-for-4 stock split.

title: Canadian Confidence
description: Consumer confidence in Canada dipped sharply in the fourth quarter of 1983 after reaching an 18-year high in the second and third quarters, according to the latest survey by the Conference Board of Canada, a business-sponsored research group. The board's seasonally adjusted index of consumer attitudes dropped to 103.3, base 1961, in the fourth quarter, from 123.3 in the two previous quarters. It is the first decline in the index since it began its rapid upward climb in the third quarter of 1982, the board said.

title: Villanova Upsets Georgetown, 65-63; Villanova Upsets Georgetown, 65-63
description: Dwight Wilbur's 18-foot jumper with two seconds remaining in the second overtime gave Villanova a 65-63 upset over Georgetown in a Big East Conference game tonight.

title: DORCHESTER GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: MONDALE ON ICY MAIN STREET
description: It was 9 A.M., the temperature stood firmly at 2 degrees, and Walter F. Mondale stepped carefully over the ice along Main Street. In Martha's Fudge Shop the candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination beamed at a 2-year-old boy, shook hands and engaged in some small talk about the frosty weather.

title: SOVIET ANNOUNCES AN ACCORD TO BOLSTERA ANGOLAN DEFENSE
description: The Soviet Union said today that, after consultations with Angolan and Cuban representatives, agreement had been reached to strengthen Angola's ''defenses, independence and territorial integrity.''

title: ADVERTISING
description: Control Data Unit

title: NUTRITION STUDIES WON AWARD
description: Dr. Icie Macy Hoobler, an authority on nutrition and child growth who was the first woman to head a division of the American Chemical Society, died last Friday in Gallatin, Mo. She was 91 years old.

title: Wildlife Officials Get Donations to Feed Deer By United Press International
description: More than $100,000 in donations have been received at the Utah Wildlife Division in a national campaign to save tens of thousands of deer and other animals starving in Western grazing areas covered with snow. Some people were giving tons of livestock feed.

title: EXCERPTS FROM LETTER ON U.S. COSTS
description: Following are excerpts from the letter to President Reagan transmitting the final report of the President's Private Sector Survey on Cost Control.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Martina Navratilova , the tennis star, has been named The Associated Press female athlete of the year in a poll of sportswriters and broadcasters. Miss Navratilova got 82 votes.

title: PNC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DEKALB AGRESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,400,000 from the extinguishment of debt. Year-ago results are restated.

title: Tampering Charges
description: A high school basketball coach in Georgia has accused athletic officials at the University of Georgia of engaging in illegal recruiting practices to sign one of his top players and then talking the player into transferring to another high school. The charges were made by Charley Hood , the Marietta High School coach, after he learned that his star center, Cedric Henderson , had applied for permission to transfer to a high school in Atlanta after signing a grant-in-aid letter of intent to attend Georgia next fall.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE tall, slender Vibeke Lokkeberg strides into the room, a cloud of brown hair falling below her shoulders. Once, she was a fashion model; now she is one of the three female movie directors in Norway.

title: Murray S. Hanes, Architect in Lincoln's Town, Is Dead
description: Murray S. Hanes, an architect who pressed the drive to restore the old State Capitol building here, died Sunday at his home near Chatham after a brief illness.

title: National Can
description: The National Can Company, which produces and markets aluminum and steel cans and other containers, said it was exploring a leveraged buyout of the company. National Can reported third-quarter earnings of $19 million on sales of $489.2 million, compared with earnings of $15.5 million on sales of $439.6 million a year earlier. The company scored the second-biggest percentage gain yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $36, up $5.75.

title: PANEL SAYS U.S. CAN TRIM COSTS BY $24 BILLION
description: The Government could save $424.4 billion over three years if it adopted nearly 2,500 recommendations to eliminate ''waste,'' reduce Federal retirement benefits and generally put Federal operations on a more businesslike footing, a Presidential panel said today.

title: TO ALLEVIATE HUNGER
description: The report issued earlier this week by the President's Task Force on Food Assistance represents a triumph of ideology over evidence. Applying an ''Alice in Wonderland'' kind of logic, a majority of the commission members view the increasingly long lines for food at charity soup kitchens and emergency shelters around the country not as proof of a serious hunger problem but as confirmation that the social ''safety net'' is intact.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Style page article on Dec. 2 about the opening of a new Herm es shop in New York City misidentified a party guest, Elia Tasca. He is the leading shareholder of The Daily American, a newspaper in Rome. Christopher Winner is the editor.

title: AN ABOUT-FACE FOR KERKORIAN
description: MGM's lion is not chasing its own tail anymore.

title: BABBLING OF BABIES IS STUDIED
description: The babble of babies, often dismissed as mere noisemaking, can provide clues to possible learning or hearing disorders, according to Michael Lewis, a professor of pediatrics at the Rutgers Medical School of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. He is studying such sounds to help teach parents and doctors how to detect potential problems.

description: A New Woe for Buses

title: Olajuwon Rules Boards
description: Akeem Olajuwon grabbed a career-high 25 rebounds, blocked 10 shots and scored 18 points to lead Houston to an 88-66 victory over Texas Tech tonight. Michael Young added 21 points for the Cougars (14-2 and 4-0), who have won 28 straight Southwest Conference games.

title: U.S. AND CHINA SIGN TECHNOLOGY PACTS
description: The United States and China signed two agreements today on science and technology.

title: SmithKline's Emerson Deal The SmithKline Beckman
description: Corporation, a diversified drug and health-care products company, said that it had agreed to sell its industrial products group to the Emerson Electric Company. SmithKline said Emerson would pay cash, but declined to say how much.

title: Beverly Hills Thrift Dispute
description: The Swiss investor Werner Rey confirmed today that he was dropping plans to take control of the Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association.

title: AUCTIONS
description: TWO major J. M. W. Turner paintings from the heirs of Lady Eunice Oakes and Sir Harry Oakes of the Bahamas and 10 old-master still lifes from the collection of Paul Mellon will be auctioned in Christie's first sale of the year next Wednesday at 2 P.M. at the galleries at Park Avenue at 59th Street.

description: ''IT'S about time we had a place on

title: Distress Call Reported From Vessel off Cuba
description: A sailing boat off the coast of Cuba sent out a distress signal Wednesday night saying it was ''being attacked and shot on,'' according to the captain of a nearby passenger ship, who said he relayed the distress call to the Miami Coast Guard.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL;
description: IN an era when many restaurateurs value

title: Member of Panel Quits In Wick Tapes Protest
description: Olin Robison, president of Middlebury College, has resigned from the United States Advisory Commission on Public Diplomacy to protest the surreptitious taping of telephone conversations by Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency.

title: TWENTIETH CENTURY-FOX FILM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-After an amortization write-off of $12,800,000. c-Net loss after an amortization write-off of $16,300,000.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Jerusalem dispatch yesterday on the rejection of former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon as chairman of the Jewish Agency's immigration department misstated the vote against?him. It was 59 to 48.

title: St. Louis Paper's Staff Accepts Severance Bid
description: News employees of The St. Louis Globe- Democrat voted overwhelmingly today to accept a new severance waiver, clearing the way for Jeffrey M. Gluck, a magazine publisher, to take over the morning paper Feb. 25.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Dean Witter Recruits A Top Morgan Analyst

title: U.S. HOCKEY SQUAD DROPS TWO PLAYERS
description: Rich Costello and Kurt Kleinendorst have been cut from the United States Olympic hockey team, General Manager Larry Johnson said today.

title: San Diego State Confirms Penalty
description: Mary Alice Hill, the athletic director at San Diego State, confirmed today that the school's basketball program would be penalized by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: ART THAT WAS TOAST OF PARIS
description: NOTHING quite like the current exhibition at the National Academy of Design has ever been seen before, in Europe or in this country. Both in content and in presentation, it treads unfamiliar ground. Titled ''The Grand Prix de Rome: Paintings From the Ecole des Beaux-Arts, 1797-1863,'' it consists of 133 paintings and drawings, and a cogent, sometimes hilarious documentation of life in the school.

title: PROJECT EVOKES CITY'S BROWNSTONE ERA
description: Amid the scars of housing abandonment in the Manhattan Valley section of the Upper West Side, a new development that evokes the brownstone town houses of the past is taking shape a block west of Central Park West, along Manhattan Avenue.

description: The 20th Century-Fox

description: Big-Time Thrills

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Parade in Miami Hails No. 1 Team
description: Confetti, shredded newspaper and computer printouts cascaded from downtown Miami office buildings today as the city saluted Coach Howard Schnellenberger and his University of Miami football team.

title: MUSIC: BLACK AND SLAVIC MIX
description: TOWARD the end of his concert in Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, the tenor Curtis Rayam sang a moving spiritual, its musical lines seeking resolution with the same vigor as the words. It seemed as authentic as any of the other spirituals on the program, but it was actually a theme from Dvorak's ''New World'' Symphony, which William Arms Fisher put to words and called ''Goin' Home.''

title: Giscard Makes Charges In Sniffer-Plane Case
description: Former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing? under attack for his role in the so-called sniffer-plane case, has denounced President Francois Mitterrand.

title: GussieAnnLevineandPeterL.GreerAreMarried
description: Gussie Ann Levine, daughter of Gloria Schulman Levine of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Samuel Levine, was married yesterday to Peter Lee Greer, son of Estelle Greer of New York and Ernest Greer of Dallas. Rabbi Murray Grauer of the Hebrew Institute in White Plains performed the ceremony at the Ritz Carlton Hotel in New York.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
USE OF BOWERY HOTEL FOR HOMELESS OPPOSED
description: They are not against sheltering the homeless, Lower East Siders told the Board of Estimate yesterday, but they are against the city's taking over a private hotel for use as a permanent shelter.

title: Still Puffing Away
description: Labor Day 1966 lives in my memory. That morning I woke up coughing, hacking and spewing as usual, reaching with palsied hand for a cigarette. As my yellow-tipped fingers closed around the pack, somewhere in my shriveled interior a contemptuous voice whispered hoarsely:

title: Des Moines Art Official Gets Post at Hirshhorn
description: James T. Demetrion, director of the Des Moines Art Center, was named today as director of the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, which is the Smithsonian Institution's museum of modern and contemporary art.

title: AMBIVALENCE ON THE DOLLAR
description: The recent sharp rise in the value of the dollar is bolstering American imports of goods from Western Europe. This gives a modest boost to depressed European economies and lessens earlier fears that the higher cost of some of Europe's imports would prevent an economic upturn.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 13, 1984

title: 'Napoleon' of 1927
description: ''Napoleon,'' the 1927 silent feature by Abel Gance, will be shown this weekend at the New Community Cinema at 423 Park Avenue in Huntington, L.I. A recorded score by Carmine Coppola will be played at the screenings.

title: CRANSTON, MCGOVERN AND HART: SURVIVAL AT ISSUE
description: Senators Alan Cranston and Gary Hart and former Senator George McGovern have much in common - too much, their political advisers say.

title: NATIONAL CONVENIENCE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Oct. 21, 1983.

description: Consumer installment credit outstanding increased by a seasonally adjusted $4.67 billion in November, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

description: American Express Aide

title: Whitfield a Dodger
description: Terry Whitfield , the former San Francisco Giants oufielder who has played the last three years in Japan, has signed a three-year contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers as a free agent, the team announced yesterday. Whitfield sought his free agency by the Japanese club to be near family in Blythe, Calif., and because of his interest in playing in Los Angeles. The 31-year old Whitfield played with the Seibu Lions of Japan's Pacific League, Whitfield played all three outfield positions during his seven-year major league career, hitting .288 with 26 home runs and 145 runs-batted-in. . . . Dwight Evans , the Boston Red Sox outfielder, signed a three year extension of his contract, which would have expired at the end of the 1984 season.

title: DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $114,000 for the quarter and $321,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $277,000 for the quarter and $1,051,000 for the year.

title: CHEMICAL UP 69.1% IN QUARTER
description: The Chemical New York Corporation reported yesterday that fourth- quarter earnings rose 69.1 percent, largely because of a sharp swing in securities transactions.

title: BUREAUCRACY SLOWS STONY BROOK EFFORT TO KEEP TOP PROFESSOR
description: There are few things the president of the State University branch here would like more than to keep Prof. Paul C. Lauterbur on his faculty.

STATE ADVISES DENTISTS ON PATIENTS WITH AIDS
description: The New York State Health Department yesterday released a draft of guidelines to dentists for the care of patients who have AIDS.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split on Nov. 15.

title: RANGERS DOWN FLYERS
description: The Rangers were 2-1 winners over the Flyers at the Spectrum tonight, despite opening with perhaps their worst 20 minutes of hockey this season.

title: I.B.M. LIFTS COMPUTER CAPABILITY
description: In an apparent move to counter the expected entry by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company into the desktop computer market, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would make a popular computer operating system, originally developed by Bell Laboratories, available to users of the I.B.M. Personal Computer.

title: EX-ST. JOE PRESIDENT NAMED TO GTE POST
description: The GTE Corporation, whose management ranks were shaken last month with the resignation of its president, said yesterday that it had hired James L. Broadhead, a former president of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, to fill a top executive post.

title: ARREST IN STUDENT'S SHOOTING
description: A 26-year-old Bronx man has been arrested and charged with firing a shot last month that went through a dormitory window at Fordham University and struck a student in her right eye as she was combing her hair, the police said yesterday.

title: BARNES HELPED IN THE PROSECUTION
description: Four men who took over a Harlem heroin ring once headed by Leroy (Nicky) Barnes were sentenced yesterday to life in prison without parole following their convictions based in large part on testimony by Mr. Barnes, who became a Government informant.

title: NEW JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $727,000 for the quarter and $2,171,000 for the year.
