description: Share earnings are adjusted to give effect to a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock distribution made Jan. 13 and for the 10 percent stock dividend distributed July 15.

title: FIRST OF AMERICA BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEN PAGE IS TAKING A CAT'S NIGHT OUT
description: WHEN Ken Page, the Broadway originator of the sphinxlike feline, Old Deuteronomy, in ''Cats'' takes the stage at the Bottom Line tonight, the 29-year-old singer won't be playing a solemn sage with nine lives to contemplate. The music he'll sing is what he likes to call ''rocking rhythm and rolling blues.'' With the backing of a band led by Ray Chew, the keyboardist, who has worked closely with Diana Ross and Ashford and Simpson, Mr. Page will sing a mostly pop repertory that runs from Jackie Wilson and Rod Stewart to the current Paul McCartney-Michael Jackson hit, ''Say Say Say.''

title: ALLIED BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 5-for- 4 stock split in December.

title: ANDROPOV REPEATS ARMS VIEWS IN MESSAGE TO FRENCH GROUP
description: Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, sent a message to a French leftist pro-disarmament group today saying ''not a single opportunity'' should be missed in seeking to revive disarmament talks. But he repeated his insistence that this could happen only if the United States reversed its deployment of new medium-range missiles.

title: SCANFORMS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Case Is Closed, But Questions Linger

title: CONTRIBUTIONS FOR NEEDIEST REPLACE GIFTS
description: Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are individuals and business or professional groups that find their donations more satisfying than traditional gift-giving.

title: Dr. Lorraine Brancato, Ophthalmologist, Wed
description: Dr. Lorraine Jocelyn Brancato, chief resident in ophthalmology at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, was married in Manhattan yesterday to E. Gayle McGuigan Jr., a first vice president of Shearson/American Express. The Rev. Bernard Dolan performed the ceremony in the chapel at St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Hawks 117, Pacers 108
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 32 points and led the Hawks.

title: SATELLITE BUSINESS REPLACES PRESIDENT
description: Satellite Business Systems, which has been plagued by deficits, announced a management shake-up today and said it was embarking on a major cost-reduction program that would include reducing the workforce through attrition.

title: ELLIS ISLAND: A SYMBOL 'BEST FORGOTTEN'
description: To the Editor:

title: MILLER OVERTAKES SIMONS, LEADS BY 1
description: Johnny Miller believes that he should win or come close to winning at the PGA Tour's winter stops in the Far West. The 35-year-old native of California has gained 10 of his 22 tour victories during the winter months, including 4 of the 8 victories he posted in his spectacular year of 1974.

title: RETAIL SALES UP 0.1% IN DECEMBER
description: Sales at the retail level edged up a slight one-tenth of 1 percent in December compared with November, pushing 1983's total sales 9.1 percent above 1982's, the Commerce Department said today.

title: SECRET SERVICE IS PREPARING TO PROTECT CANDIDATES
description: The Secret Service begins election-year protection of Presidential candidates this weekend.

title: DR. KING CENTER COUNTS A GAIN AND A RUNNING LOSS
description: The annual gathering here of friends and followers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., to celebrate his birthday has been especially sweet.

title: Gretzky Streak Now at 45 Games
description: Wayne Gretzky extended his National Hockey League scoring streak to 45 consecutive games tonight, but the Edmonton Oilers' 13-game undefeated streak was ended by the Buffalo Sabres, 3-1.

title: County Defers Charge Against Erring Mechanic
description: County prosecutors said today that no charges would be filed against an 18-year-old worker who put the wrong type of fuel in a cargo plane, which crashed Monday, killing the co-pilot.

title: IN MALAYSIAN BATTLE ROYAL, THE SULTANS GET A DRAW
description: Malaysians relish telling foreign visitors that their country, though a relatively small power with 14 million people, has nine hereditary sultans who constitute nearly one-third of the world total of reigning royalty.

title: BANK OF VIRGINIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ZHAO GOT TOMATOES, OTHERS SPLIT PEA
description: It was 5:30 P.M., Tuesday. The Premier of China, Zhao Ziyang, had a few hours earlier been guest of honor at an official luncheon at the State Department. I was picking my way through State's corridors trying not to bump into an ambiguity. In the distance was a set of pin stripes that, as I approached, turned out to be an old diplomat friend. He waved me over - in public. Something of a surprise, this simple act, since the department is so newly smitten with secrecy. ''Do you have a minute?'' he asked.

title: U.S. SAYS COPTER DID NOT AID REBELS
description: United States diplomats and leaders of United States-backed guerrillas fighting to overthrow Nicaragua's Sandinista Government said today that the American military helicopter that went down near the Nicaragua-Honduras border Wednesday was not in any way connected to the anti-Sandinista insurgency.

title: INTEL'S EARNINGS GREW SHARPLY IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: The Intel Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter earnings soared more than fivefold, a jump that analysts attributed in part to continuing strong demand for Intel's small-computer microprocessors.

title: HELMS RESIGNATION: POOR TIMING FOR U.S. AVIATION
description: News Analysis

title: STATES OF THE STATES
description: News Analysis

title: Winter Sports; Hanni Wenzel Wins Downhill
description: Hanni Wenzel of Liechtenstein edged the World Cup leader, Irene Epple of West Germany, by four one-hundredths of a second today to win the second downhill race of her 12-year career.

title: ZHAO MEETS ROBOT AND SIDESTEPS BOA
description: First a small flashing robot stepped on the Chinese Prime Minister's toes. Then a 7-foot Colombian boa constrictor stuck out its forked tongue at him. Then Zhao Ziyang was treated to a slide show of bugs eating fruit and given a chance to examine some dead mosquitoes in a bottle.

title: TIMES DRAMA CRITIC 31 YEARS
description: Brooks Atkinson, the drama critic of The New York Times for 31 years, and the winner of the Pulitzer Prize for foreign correspondence in 1947, died of pneumonia yesterday at Crestwood Hospital in Huntsville, Ala. He was 89 years old.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Rises
description: Japan had a trade surplus of $20.46 billion in 1983, its largest and nearly three times the 1982 surplus, the Government reported today.

title: DATAVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it took a writedown in the latest quarter of $1,844,000 for the reduction of certain assets.

title: Home Mortgage Plan
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said yesterday that it will begin buying adjustable-rate mortgages on Feb. 1 in a program allowing home buyers to limit the increase in their mortgage payments if interest rates rise sharply. The mortgages will be linked to an index of one- , three- or five-year Treasury securities, and the amount of interest and of the monthly payment will be limited if rates jump, Kenneth J. Thygerson, president of the corporation, said.

title: PATENTS
description: Simplified Engine Runs On Most Liquid Fuels

title: FILM: 'HOT DOG,' SKIERS COMPETING AND PLAYING
description: If a ski movie like ''Hot Dog'' appeared during warmer weather, it might qualify as escapism. At this time of year, it's more like a cheap vacation. Set in Squaw Valley and revolving around the World Cup Freestyle competition, it features a cast of cute, young hopefuls who battle on the slopes by day and mingle in the hot tubs after sundown. It's a beach party movie, marginally better than the average, with snow taking the place of surf.

title: Four Stabbed and Strangled In South Side Chicago Home
description: Four people were tied up, strangled and stabbed to death Thursday by an assailant who then set fire to the victims' South Side apartment to conceal what the authorities described as ''torture murders.''

title: Ottawa Official to Australia
description: Edward Schreyer, the Governor General of Canada for the past five years, was named High Commissioner to Australia today by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau.

title: O.A.U. ENDS EFFORTS TO START PEACE TALKS BY FACTIONS IN CHAD
description: The Organization of African Unity today abandoned attempts to open a conference of the warring factions in Chad.

title: TRAFFIC UP, PORT AGENCY PLANS STUDY
description: A dramatic rise in rush-hour traffic congestion in the last three years on Hudson River crossings into Manhattan prompted the Port Authority to announce yesterday that it will ask a task force to come up with long-term solutions to the problem.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Jan. 5 about Conde Nast Publications, and a St. Louis dispatch by The Associated Press on the Herald Company that appeared in some editions Jan. 7, incorrectly described the ownership of those two companies. Both are owned either directly or through intermediaries by Advance Publications Inc., which in turn is the property of several trust funds and of Newhouse family members, some of whom are not lineally related to S. I. Newhouse.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Manhole Metaphors

title: Article 177190 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: WEST PREPARING EARLY FOR SNOW RUNOFF FLOODING
description: With the Rockies mantled in record snows, operators of Federal dams are letting water out of their reservoirs to prevent a repetition of last year's disastrous spring flooding.

title: A SURVEY OF CITY'S SHOPPERS
description: THE New York City Department

title: OPERA: THREE CAST CHANGES IN 'TRISTAN'
description: The Metropolitan Opera performance of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' on Wednesday night offered three artists who have joined the cast since earlier this season.

title: Rose Still Available
description: More than two months after he left the Philadelphia Phillies to become a free agent, Pete Rose says he still hasn't narrowed his list of potential teams but is as eager as ever to extend his career.

title: Fugitive Killed In Jersey Shootout
description: A man sought in the shooting of a police officer was shot and killed after the police cornered him in a vacant building and efforts to have him surrender were answered by gunfire, the police said today.

title: PLAYERSRoy S. Johnson; A Master of the 3-Point Shot
description: When Darrell Griffith decided it was time for him to make a name while attending the University of Louisville, he didn't pine away the hours pondering how. ''Back then,'' he says, ''the one way to get everyone's attention was to dunk.''

title: PRINCIPAL'S POLICY ON WRITING FOUGHT
description: This week, as the first semester of the school year neared an end, the teachers at Louis D. Brandeis High School on the West Side gave their department chairmen thousands of folders filled with students' writing assignments to pass along to the principal.

title: PRODUCER PRICES IN SMALL RISES
description: Producer prices inched up by two- tenths of 1 percent in December, bringing the rise for the year to a scant six-tenths of 1 percent, the best showing in two decades, the Government reported today.

title: Algerian President Wins In Uncontested Election
description: President Chadli Benjedid was elected to a second five-year term with 95 percent of the vote, final results showed today. Mr. Benjedid was the only candidate.

title: Thousands of Youths Riot in Hong Kong
description: Thousands of teen-agers rampaged through the streets of Kowloon, the mainland city of Hong Kong, on Friday night, attacking policemen, burning and overturning cars and looting shops, the police reported.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A WOLF IN SHEEPSKIN CLOTHING
description: The following ''Letter to a Sexual Harassee'' was found in a campus wastebasket and forwarded to me.

title: Article 176011 -- No Title
description: The combatants in the battle are giants; the stakes are high; the taxpayers are watching, and Congress has sought to avoid the fray.

title: SCOUTING
description: Volume Traces History of N.H.L.

title: Cleveland Schools Reopen
description: Pupils returned to the public schools today as custodians ended a two-day work stoppage that had closed the schools. The custodial workers, members of the International Brotherhood of Firemen and Oilers, had been calling in sick to express their frustration with a lack of progress in contract bargaining talks.

title: Mancini Can Answer Critics
description: As if his recent embarrassments had helped to restore the icy look to his eyes, Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini faces his toughest challenge as World Boxing Association lightweight champion Saturday night with renewed intensity when he meets Bobby Chacon.

title: Data on Funds
description: Despite an increase in total

title: Quiet U.S.-Soviet Talks Proposed by Kissinger
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that President Reagan and Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, should appoint special envoys to quietly pursue a reduction of East-West tensions. He said he was not a candidate for the job.

title: Fire in Korean Hotel Kills 34 and Injures 70
description: At least 34 people died and about 70 were injured today when a fire gutted a 10-story tourist hotel in the southern Korean port of Pusan, the police said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a production error, the Money Market Mutual Funds table that appeared in Business Day yesterday omitted the Donoghue's Money Fund Average. It appears today on page 31.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: It's All in the Water

title: Soviet Ends Chess Boycott Oo
description: The Soviet Union today ended its boycott of chess tournaments involving the grandmaster Viktor Korchnoi, closing a dispute that has split the chess world since his defection from Moscow in 1976.

title: SLOPPY NETS FALL, 114-111
description: For the final three minutes of the third period tonight and for almost the entire fourth quarter of the game against Golden State, Kelvin Ransey, the Nets' starting point guard, was on the bench.

title: BUCKS END SLIDE, TOP KNICKS
description: Coach Don Nelson of the Milwaukee Bucks tonight used his 10th different starting lineup in the last 12 games, and returned Junior Bridgeman to his role as the sixth man.

title: Reward Offered for Aid In Finding Paroled Killer
description: A group offered a $10,000 reward today for information on the whereabouts of Dan White, the paroled slayer of two San Francisco politicians, and filed a suit to force the state to disclose his address.

title: FLARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: 1982 figures were restated to reflect an accounting change. b-Net loss is after a loss from discontinued operations of $2.2 million.

title: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $550,000 of deferred U.S. taxes previously provided on undistributed earnings of its Swiss unit which are now considered to be permanently reinvested.

title: PRETORIA ENDING RAID INTO ANGOLA
description: A South African invasion force was reported tonight to be pulling out of southern Angola in a long column of trucks laden with captured equipment supplied by the Soviet Union to its allies in the territory.

title: SPA CUISINE IS A HIT WITH DINERS
description: Not everyone is used to the idea yet, but Paul Kovi and Tom Margittai, co- proprietors of the Four Seasons, believe that the nutritional value of foods ought to be a concern of their elegant and contemporary restaurant. Less than a month ago they introduced five items to their seasonally changing menu that reflect this concern.

title: Digital Sees Profit Gain
description: The Digital Equipment

title: GENERAL BURIED AS U.S. AGENTS SEARCH FOR CLUES
description: Maj. Gen. Robert G. Ownby Jr. was buried with military honors today, and Federal investigators said it would be next week at the earliest before there was any answer to whether he or someone else took his life and why.

title: A Soviet General Is Reported To Have Died in Line of Duty
description: The Soviet armed forces newspaper reported today that a Soviet general ''died suddenly in the performance of his duties.'' Some Western analysts said the report suggested the general might have been killed in Afghanistan.

title: Coroner Report on Wilson
description: Dennis Wilson, the Beach Boys' drummer, was drunk when he drowned last month while swimming near a friend's yacht in Marina del Rey, the coroner's office reported today. Tests found that Mr. Wilson, who was 39 years old, had a blood alcohol level of 0.26 - more than twice the limit for driving in California. No evidence of other drugs was found.

title: COLONIAL BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Two juries, 18 people I've convinced. How many more do we have to go? How much more justice can I afford?'' - Christine Craft, awarded $325,000 in a retrial of her suit against a television station. (43:1.)

title: SATURDAYSPORTS
description: College Football Senior Bowl, at Mobile, Ala. Walter Lewis of Alabama, Wayne Peace of Florida and Kelly Powell of Mississippi will be the quarterbacks for the South. Leading the North offensively will be Ernest Anderson, the Oklahoma State running back. (Televison - ESPN, 1 P.M., live, and 8:30 P.M., tape, and WPIX- TV, 3 P.M., tape.) Hockey

title: CUOMO WILL SEEK $302 MILLION RISE IN EDUCATION AID
description: Governor Cuomo will propose a $302 million increase in education aid in his budget next week, including funds for a score of programs to improve the quality of education, state officials said today.

title: OPERA: REVISED 'MACBETH'
description: When Peter Hall's production of Verdi's ''Macbeth'' had its premiere at the Metropolitan Opera in November 1982, the reaction was mostly derisive. The witches' scenes looked campy and cluttered, Renata Scotto's acting as Lady Macbeth seemed melodramatic and the whole event was dismissed as ludicrous.

title: HERITAGE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 figures have been adjusted to reflect only net income, excluding certain nonrecurring items, principally the gain on the sale of the Heritage Mortgage Finance Co.

title: THE INNOVATIVE ROYAL CROWN
description: The Royal Crown Companies, the soft-drink industry's perpetual also- ran, has either been the most innovative company in the business, or simply its test-marketing guinea pig, depending on one's perspective.

title: China's Open Door to Nuclear Trade
description: The visit to Washington of China's Prime Minister, Zhao Ziyang, marks the welcome continuation of a still-difficult relationship. Mr. Zhao, forsaking Mao jacket for Western suit and tie, said that ''China has opened its door and will never close it again.'' But the doorway is still cluttered with stumbling blocks, among them Taiwan and nuclear trade.

title: Taylor's Offer Rejected
description: Lawrence Taylor may have offered as much as $750,000 to buy back the option that Donald Trump has on his playing for the New Jersey Generals. In addition, according to a source familiar with the negotiations, Taylor would return a $1 million loan.

title: BURLINGTON COAT FACTORY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
THE STEWART CASE
description: -dawn hours, Michael Stewart was arrested by the Transit Authority Police for writing graffiti with felt markers on a subway station wall in lower Manhattan.

title: Karl Baarslag, Author And Ex-Congress Aide
description: Karl Herman William Baarslag, an author and former research director of a Senate subcommittee headed by Joseph R. McCarthy, died of a heart attack Tuesday at the Palm Beach Martin County Hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: AUBURN STUNS KENTUCKY BY 19
description: Chuck Person scored 25 points and Charles Barkley added 21 and controlled the backboards tonight to spark Auburn to an 82-63 upset of previously unbeaten Kentucky. It was the Wildcats' worst defeat in nearly 10 years.

title: JORDANIANS SAID TO BACK KING'S PLANS
description: King Hussein appears to have won broad support in Jordan for his decision to expand Palestinian participation in both Parliament and the Cabinet.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about a city proposal to condemn a Bowery hotel incorrectly reported what the city would pay the owners. No price has been set.

title: SOVIET JEWS' ANXIETY
description: East-West relations, with their inevitable impact upon human rights in the Soviet Union, will be at center stage in Stockholm on Jan. 17 at the Conference on Confidence- and Security-Building Measures and Disarmament in Europe. Whatever else is on the agenda, the forum must not preclude the airing of urgent human rights issues, including the treatment of Soviet Jews.

title: BANK OF NEW ENGLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOUNDER OF COMMODORE RESIGNS UNEXPECTEDLY
description: Jack Tramiel, the hard-driving executive who brought Commodore International to the top of the home computer market, resigned suddenly today as president and chief executive and as a director.

title: CONNORS AND LENDL GAIN
description: Jimmy Connors secured his position as New York's favorite street fighter yesterday by grunting and clawing his way to a 6-4, 2-6, 6-2 victory over Tomas Smid in the first singles match of the Volvo Masters tennis tournament to go three sets.

title: Jewish Museum's Hours
description: The Jewish Museum has announced that it will no longer have evening hours on Tuesdays. The museum, at Fifth Avenue and 92d Street, will now be open from noon to 5 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays and from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Sundays. It is closed Fridays and Saturdays.

title: Paper Handlers Accept Times Pact
description: Paper Handlers Union No. 1 reached agreement with The New York Times yesterday on a three- year contract extension that provides for $110 a week in pay increases over the three years and a bonus increase of $25.93 a week retroactive to last March 31.

title: MURDERER GRANTED ANOTHER STAY
description: The North Carolina Supreme Court blocked the execution scheduled for today of James W. Hutchins, a 54-year-old tree- trimmer and mechanic convicted of killing three law-enforcement officers in 1979.

title: LEADER DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WOMEN EXAMINE FAITH AND FEMINISM
description: Within their churches and synagogues, women have been raising the banner of feminism, overturning bedrock assumptions and nudging aside barriers that have limited their religious roles. Now, in increasing numbers, they are reaching beyond their separate traditions to touch base with a wider circle of religious women to share their joys and struggles.

title: YONKERS NAMES 7TH CITY MANAGER IN 10 YEARS
description: The City Council today named a new City Manager, the seventh in the last 10 years for this financially troubled city of 195,000 people.

title: KMW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CASTLE ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes reserves, writedowns and writeoffs of $4,020,000. c-Net income

title: Hrudey Sought
description: The Canadian Olympic team has asked the Islanders about the possibility that Kelly Hrudey , an Islander goalie, might join the Canadian team for the Winter Olympics in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. The Islanders said yesterday, however, that technicalities regarding Hrudey's eligibility still remained to be worked out.

title: KOCH PROPOSES PROGRAM TO CUT JAIL POPULATION
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed giving $1.5 million to the five District Attorneys and the Special Narcotics Prosecutor to help reduce the jail population and move cases more quickly to trial.

title: ; CITY NEIGHBORHOOD ECONOMIES IMPERILED BY SHOPPING CENTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: MARINES IN BEIRUT UNDER FIRE AGAIN
description: A section of the United States Marine base here came under heavy rifle fire today, fighting broke out in downtown West Beirut and artillery shells exploded in the streets of East Beirut and in the nearby hills. It was one of the sharpest upsurges of violence in the Lebanese capital in months.

title: SECT LEADER IS FOUND NOT GUILTY OF CHARGES IN BOY'S BEATING DEATH
description: A leader of the House of Judah religious sect was found not guilty today of a charge of cruelty to a child in the death of a 12-year-old boy who attended the group's camp last summer.

title: Your MoneyLeonard Sloane Insurer Funds Protect Policies
description: -United Corporation have called attention

title: AIC PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Panel to Analyze Special Education
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that he would appoint a commission to study the benefits and rising costs of special-education programs.

title: ANTHEM ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: -city youth, as well as some musical artists they like, have created a variety of dances - the mashed potato, the monkey, the chicken, the karate, the boogaloo and so on, ad infinitum. Often, such dances are choreographed on the streets in summer and are demonstrated during the indoor partying season.

title: MICHAEL JACKSON AT 25: A MUSICAL PHENOMENON
description: In the world of pop music, there is Michael Jackson and there is everybody else.

title: A.T.&T. to End TV Commercial WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) - The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has notified the Justice Department it will stop running a television commercial that was the subject of a complaint filed last Monday by the Tandy Corporation, one of its equipment competitors.
description: Under the reorganization plan that governed the breakup of A.T.& T., the right to use the Bell name and logotype was reserved for the 22 local Bell companies, now reorganized into seven independent regional companies, instead of A.T.& T.

title: SCOUTING
description: New Favorite

title: Monsanto to Add Belgian Concern ST. LOUIS, Jan. 13 (AP) - The Monsanto Company announced it had reached an agreement in principle to buy Continental Pharma, S.A., a Belgian pharmaceutical company. The purchase price was not disclosed.
description: Continental Pharma manufactures ethical pharmaceuticals, which it markets mostly in Belgium and through licensees in other parts of the world. The company had 1983 revenues of about $40 million.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Maine Chance?

title: Letter: On Taxis ; The Case Against 'Green-Stripe' Cabs
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Alfred Gilman Dies at 75; Authority on Pharmacology
description: Dr. Alfred Gilman, a leading pharmacologist, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in New Haven. He was 75 years old.

title: CLASH OVER PALISADES LEGACY
description: Until the squabbling started recently, it had been 42 years of neighborliness between two of the largest property owners on the Palisades - the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America and the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
COURT IN ROME ORDERS BULGARIAN IN POPE'S SHOOTING BACK TO PRISON
description: A court today ordered a Bulgarian suspect in the shooting of Pope John Paul II returned to prison within three days, the Italian news agency ANSA reported.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 36.

title: MOZAMBIQUE AND SOUTH AFRICANS BEGIN TALKS ON EASING TENSIONS
description: Senior officials from Mozambique and South Africa started talks today as part of an effort, supported by the United States, to ease the hostility that has built up between Pretoria's white rulers and their black-ruled, avowedly Marxist, neighbors.

title: INSIDE SOVIET EMBASSY WITH DEAN OF DIPLOMATS
description: About this time last year, rumors were rampant that Anatoly F. Dobrynin would be returning to Moscow after 21 years as the Soviet Ambassador to the United States. Well, a year has passed and the rumors have stopped.

title: CITY BALLET' 'HARLEQUINADE'
description: It is hard to believe that until Thursday night ''Harlequinade,'' George Balanchine's delightful, fond look back at a special French-Russian ballet, had not been performed since 1980.

title: 34 WORLD BANK NATIONS SET $9 BILLION AID LIMIT
description: Thirty- four nations attending a World Bank meeting here agreed today to contribute $9 billion over the next three years to the poorest countries, but remained deadlocked over the amount to be given by each, officials said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, JANUARY 14, 1984

title: SPILL CAUSES SPECIAL CONCERN AT BOBSLED TRIALS
description: The United States Olympic trials in four-man bobsledding began today, and the first crew down the course had a frightening accident.

title:
PATENTS;
CONTROLLING SATELLITES IN SPACE
description: WASHINGTON A N improved method of controlling communications satellites has been invented for the RCA Corporation. Patent 4,424,948, assigned to the company, was granted this week to three technical staff members.

title: POLICY THAT WILL CURTAIL NO STUDENT LOANS
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN SAYS ARMS BUILDUP IMPROVES CHANCES FOR PEACE
description: President Reagan said today that while candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination were ''yelling that we are threatened by imminent war,'' his military buildup program had eased the threat of war by increasing the nation's deterrent power.

title: Reagan's Staff Chief Hints He'd Step Down
description: The White House chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, has said President Reagan ''would be better served by someone else'' if he is elected to a second term.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Trade Center Translation

title: MODEL FOR A CITY PLAN TO GIVE YOUTHS WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Cancer Study To Begin on L.I.
description: A three-year study will begin next month in an attempt to determine why there is an abnormally high incidence of breast cancer among women who live in Nassau County, it was announced today.

title: Bridge: A Bit of Confusion Leads to Success
description: The vagaries of the game are such that players who suffer a bidding confusion occasionally wind up with a profit. North-South had such a confusion on the diagramed deal, from the Tristate Women's Teams in Port Chester, N.Y., Thursday and almost deprived their opponents of the title.

title: MONDALE DEVISES ROLE AS LEADER OF OPPOSITION
description: In recent weeks Walter F. Mondale and his aides have quietly devised a dual political strategy aimed not only at winning the Democratic Presidential nomination but also at placing the Republicans on the defensive in the 1984 elections.

title: 2 HIGH SOVIET OFFICIALS ARE EXECUTED FOR GRAFT
description: Two senior Soviet foreign trade officials have been executed for ''systematically taking big bribes,'' Tass reported today.

title: REAGAN IS SAID TO FIND BREACHES BY SOVIET OF AGREEMENTS ON ARMS
description: President Reagan has determined that the Soviet Union has committed ''violations or probable violations'' of some terms of several arms control agreements or obligations, a senior State Department official said today.

title: PARKER HANNIFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CREIDT MARKET POST RALLY
description: The financial markets rallied yesterday in response to Government reports early in the day that indicated that economic growth was slowing and that inflation remained under control. Confidence was further bolstered in the late afternoon by the release by the Federal Reserve of three measures of the money supply, all of which were well within the ranges set by the central bank.

title: CREATURE OF FORTUNE
description: First I wanted to be a garbage man. Then I wanted to be a cowboy. Next I wanted to be a G-man. When that passed I wanted to be an airplane pilot with a belted leather jacket like Tailspin Tommy's and a mustache like Smilin' Jack's.

title: Looking Ahead
description: Bart Starr , the former head coach of the Green Bay Packers, was named coach and director of football operations for the phantom Phoenix Firebirds, which he and the club's owners hope someday will become an expansion franchise of the National Football League. The operation is headed by Joe Foss , the former commissioner of the now defunct American Football League, and Bob Whitlow , the former general manager of the defunct Phoenix Roadrunner hockey team. Although the N.F.L. is merely studying the feasibility of expansion and has not designated any cities to get new teams, the Foss group plans to be in line when new franchises are handed out.

title: 12-Year Sentence For $20 Drug Sale
description: A man was sentenced to 12 years in prison yesterday for selling $20 worth of cocaine to an undercover agent.

title: VOLCKER FOCUS: ECONOMY'S RESILIENCY
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, brought his yearlong campaign against the Federal budget deficits today to a sympathetic audience of 150 summer-suited Florida businessmen.

title: Italian Assures Reagan On the Lebanon Force
description: Foreign Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy assured President Reagan today that his country would not withdraw from the multinational peacekeeping force in Lebanon on its own, the White House said.

title: PATENTS
description: A Method of Regulating Solar Energy Storage

title: SOVIET YOUTHS EMBRACE AN 'INVASION' OF ENGLISH
description: ''I'm a khailaifist,'' wrote the 20-year-old, bragging of his American jeans, Japanese stereo, rock music collection and library of science fiction.

title: MCI Profits Flat in Quarter
description: The MCI Communications

title: Connors Is Named To Davis Team The United States Tennis Association announced yesterday that Jimmy Connors would be a member of the American Davis Cup team when it faces Rumania next month and that he had made a commitment to play in the entire 1984 campaign.
description: Connors's teammates for the opening round of Davis Cup play in Bucharest will be John McEnroe and Peter Fleming, with a fourth player to be selected.

title: ASK COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAMAUR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Carteret Savings
description: Carteret Savings and Loan Association, a large New Jersey financial services company with headquarters in Morristown, N.J., announced it had agreed in principle to acquire 10 branches owned by the Amerifirst Federal Savings and Loan Association, in Broward, Dade and Palm Beach counties, in Florida. Carteret, which said the branches have total deposits of $250 million, would not disclose the price to be paid beyond saying that Amerifirst will have a profit of about $10 million from the cash sale planned for late February.

title: JURY AWARDS CHRISTINE CRAFT $325,000
description: Christine Craft, the television news anchor who sued her former employers at a Kansas City television station, yesterday won a victory in the retrial of her case. The jury in Federal Court in Joplin, Mo., awarded Miss Craft $325,000 in damages.

title: 'PIONEER' SETTLERS BRING GLOW TO SOUTH BRONX
description: ''People kept saying, 'Look at that, Christmas lights on Charlotte Street,' '' said Irma Rivera, smiling at the thought of passers-by staring at the lighted tree in her yard. ''No one believed it. They'd come back for a second look. For the South Bronx, this was a miracle.''

title: Frazier Arrested On Gun Charge
description: Joe Frazier, the former world heavyweight boxing champion, has been released on his own recognizance after he was arrested here on charges of possessing an unregistered handgun, officials said today.

title: G.M. Korea Import Plan
description: The General Motors Corporation is considering importing a small car in the next two years from its 50 percent owned Daewoo Motor Company affiliate in South Korea. G.M. declined to comment yesterday on the plan, but company sources said it was near the end of a long study and would make a final decision by the end of January. A small import would join a lineup of small cars G.M. plans to sell as part of a bigger strategy to sell Japanese cars, including a minicar from the Suzuki Motor Company, a subcompact from Isuzu Motors Ltd.

title: Dow Drops by 9.21; Trading Is Heavy
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in heavy trading, in part because of a delayed reaction to some weaker- than-expected economic reports and in part because of a selloff in International Business Machines, a market trend-setter.

title: A 'Vampire' in Indonesia
description: Vampire-like attacks have been reported by 21 young women in Sumatra who said a man had bitten their necks to suck blood, the Jakarta daily Sinar Harapan said today. A local Member of Parliament told the paper that he had not believed the accounts at first but that after seeing the victims he was convinced a vampire was on the loose.

title: NICARAGUANS SAY THEY FIRED AT U.S. HELICOPTER ON GROUND
description: Nicaraguan soldiers said today that they opened fire on a United States helicopter on Wednesday over Nicaraguan territory and then sprayed it with gunfire after it landed on the Honduran side of the border.

title: WARD ASKS A DEPUTY TO LEAVE JOB
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that he had asked the department's deputy commissioner for community affairs, William E. Perry Jr., to step down.

title: INDUSTRY OUTPUT CAPS '83 SURGE WITH 0.5% RISE
description: The United States closed out its first full year of economic recovery from the longest downturn since World War II with industrial production expanding at a moderate rate and inflation in check, figures for December showed today.

title: WHY ASTHMA HITS SOME MINORITIES HARDEST
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times Linking Sports and Life
description: CURVES OF PURSUIT. By Thomas Farber. 186 pages. Putnam. $14.95. Some men express in sport feelings they wouldn't dare bring out in life, or even in love - feelings about grace, trust and dependence, for example. The spirit of teamwork is their flirtation with the fact of love. In football, the pat on the butt after a beautiful play is a macho translation of tenderness and gratitude.

title: MCI COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Open Valve Found AtNineMilePoint
description: Workers at the Nine Mile Point 1 nuclear power plant in Scriba, N.Y., accidently left open a valve that could have allowed radiation to escape during a mishap, a spokesman for the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday.

title: JAN. 1-10 CAR SALES ROSE 31.8%
description: The nation's six major automobile manufacturers today reported a 31.8 percent gain in car sales in the first 10 days of the year, from the corresponding period a year earlier. There were seven selling days in each period.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 17
Sonics Sign Thompson
description: After holding out for almost half a season, David Thompson , the Seattle Super Sonics' free-agent guard, has signed a contract that will keep him with the team through next season. No details were disclosed. Thompson, who underwent drug-rehabilitation treatment last summer, had rejected the original offer of a base salary of $200,000, far below the $700,000 he made last season.

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 14, 1984 International
description: Moscow is not living up to its word in arms control pacts, President Reagan believes. He has, according to a senior State Department official, determined that the Soviet Union has committed ''violations or probable violations'' of the terms of seven arms control agreements or obligations, ''but the President has not concluded that we should give up our search for serious arms control agreements,'' the official said. (Page 1, Column 2.) An attack on the U.S. marine base in Beirut was part of one of the sharpest outbreaks of violence in the Lebanese capital in months. (1:1.)

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTGAGE INESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST OF AMERICA BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Job With Possibilities
description: Drinking and drugs cost Bob Newton his job with the Seattle Seahawks in 1982 and his job with the Boston Breakers in 1983.

description: Kenny index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

WINE-DARK TABLECLOTHS

description: b-After income from minority stake in Damon Biotech Inc. of $129,743 and gain from debt repurchase of $70,974. c-Net loss

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: CELTICS BEAT 76ERS, 105-104
description: Larry Bird scored 29 points, and had 19 rebounds and 8 assists to help the Boston Celtics edge the Philadelphia 76ers, 105-104, tonight.

title: THE BIG SURPRISE
description: It was the summer of 1955 and the

title: Wishful, but Worthwhile, on Waste
description: One of Ronald Reagan's passionate promises in 1980 was to stamp out wasteful Federal spending. He appointed a commission of businessmen to look into it 18 months ago, and now has their finding that $424 billion of fat could be cut out in just three years. There's fat in the commission's estimate, too, and a dose of political naivete. But the enterprise was worthwhile.

title: CORVUS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: 2 Groups Say U.S. Violates South Africa Arms Embargo
description: Two groups charged today that the United States had systematically violated the mandatory United Nations embargo on the sale of military equipment to South Africa by approving licenses worth $28 million for export of parts that could be used for military purposes.

title: ISRAEL'S AUSTERITY IS CASTING POLITICAL SHADOW ON SHAMIR
description: Israel is heading into a period of forced austerity that may translate into political problems for the fragile governing coalition of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

title: Suit Filed on Gulf Reincorporation PITTSBURGH, Jan. 13 (AP) - T. Boone Pickens Jr., the leader of a dissident group of Gulf Oil Corporation shareholders, sued today to challenge the outcome of a Gulf shareholder election that gave the company the authority to reincorporate in Delaware. Gulf announced earlier today that it had won the election with 52.5 percent of the vote.
description: The reincorporation move is intended to head off the Pickens group, which is trying to put pressure on Gulf to spin off some of its domestic oil and natural gas reserves into a royalty trust.

title: Raymond Swords Dies at 64; Jesuit Led Holy Cross College
description: The Rev. Raymond J. Swords, S.J., president of Cheverus High School and a former president of Holy Cross College, died of a heart attack at the Jesuit residence here last night. He was 64 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: On-the-Spot Lesson

title: PATENTS
description: Procedure to Fabricate Diamond Heat Sink

title: CBS PLANS TO USE PLAYWRIGHTS FOR 'COMEDY ZONE'
description: Names and faces from Broadway and Off Broadway have been cropping up increasingly on the home screen in recent years, through public television's ''American Playhouse'' series as well as occasional productions on pay-television services such as Showtime and Home Box Office.

title: Transactions; FOOTBALL
description: OKLAHOMA (USFL) - Jim Johnson, who resigned as defensive coach at Notre Dame University, was named defensive coordinator.

title: MONFORT OF COLORADO (CO) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
JACKSON'S CAMP APPLIES FOR MATCHING FUNDS
description: The Presidential campaign of the Rev. Jesse Jackson submitted documentation yesterday in an attempt to become eligible for Federal matching funds.

title: BROOKS ATKINSON ON THEATER: A SAMPLER
description: From a review of Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur's ''Front Page,'' on Aug. 18, 1928.

title: SCOUTING
description: Philosophical

title: Loiselle of Wings Is Suspended
description: Claude Loiselle, a left wing for the Detroit Red Wings, has been suspended for six games for a stick- swinging incident in a game against the Philadelphia Flyers Jan. 7.

title: Trottier Has Sprain
description: Bryan Trottier 's knee sprain, suffered in the Islanders' 7-3 victory over the Canadiens Thursday night, did not keep the veteran center from working out yesterday at the club's practice in Hicksville, L.I.. Trottier, his left knee fitted for a derotation brace, skated in the morning drill and might be able to play in the game tonight against the Rangers at Nassau Coliseum. ''It doesn't look like it's going to be anything long-term,'' said the Islander trainer, Ron Waske . . . . The Rangers said that Kent-Erik Andersson , driven into the boards by Ron Sutter during New York's 2-1 victory in Philadelphia Thursday night, suffered a fractured 10th rib of the left side and would be sidelined for two to three weeks.

title: Communists in Spain Confer To Form a Pro-Soviet Party
description: Five Spanish Communist groups began a three-day meeting here today to form an orthodox pro-Soviet party opposed to the Eurocommunist line of Spain's existing Communist Party.

title: Some Babies Named Doe
description: In the spring of 1982 an Indiana baby with Down's syndrome and an incomplete esophagus died six days after his birth. His death was, in one sense, natural: he died of starvation. In another, it was not: his parents had chosen not to feed him, and the courts went along.

title: Warner Sells Unit
description: Warner Communications Inc. said that it had agreed to sell its fragrance and cosmetics business for approximately $146 million to Cosmair Inc., the exclusive licensee in the United States for L'Oreal and Lancome. The sale will result in a gain to Warner of more than $100 million, the company said.

title: Egyptair-Boeing
description: Egyptair has ordered three Boeing 767's to be delivered in July for about $150 million, Boeing Commercial Airplane Company officials said Thursday.

title: Counterfeiting Materials Found in Prison Shop
description: State officials said today that they had found in a prison shop negatives and printing plates used by inmates to make bogus money orders and birth certificates.

title: F.D.A. Finding On Aspartame WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) - The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had found no evidence that the sweetener aspartame may break down into toxic levels of methyl alcohol.
description: In fact, an F.D.A. spokesman said, the agency found that many natural fruit juices contain higher levels of the natural compound than aspartame-sweetened products.

title: NEW GUISES FOR OLD FURS
description: Brooke Hayward had a dark mink coat she was so bored with that it languished in storage for a couple of years. The tawny mink Joan Hall had inherited from her mother was out of date and she never wore it unless the weather was bitterly cold. The silver fox shawl Ullanda McCullough bought in a fit of extravagance was a bit much, even for a rock singer, and she tired of it quickly.

title: Howard H. Tomlinson To Wed Kathrin Poole
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Poole of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathrin Winne Poole, to Howard Holmes Tomlinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Tomlinson of New Vernon, N.J. The wedding to be in June.

title: PHONE NUMBER GONE, BUT NOT FORGOTTEN
description: IN the spirit of the A.T.&T.; breakup, the town

title: A 'FORGOTTEN' FIGURE IN U.S. BALLET HISTORY
description: Considering that Edward M. M. Warburg is a man of the present, luring him into a talk about the past is not that simple. But luckily, he did agree to reminisce the other day about his role as a founding father of the American Ballet - George Balanchine's first American company and the precursor of the New York City Ballet.

title: 'DAY IN HOLLYWOOD' WORTH AN EVENING
description: ELMSFORD THE musical theater's tribute to the movies, the double feature ''A Day in Hollywood/A Night in the Ukraine,'' was a Broadway success. It lasted a little less than a year and a half after opening in 1980.

title: SHOREHAM'S COST HEADS L.I. LIST OF ALBANY ISSUES
description: ALBANY AS Long Island legislators return to the snows of Albany, preparing to do battle over the Shoreham nuclear power plant, everyone agrees that something has to be done this year, but no one seems to know what to do, or even what can be done.

title: Greece
description: To the Editor: Marvine Howe's arti

title: VIEQUES: ISLAND OF SLOWER RHYTHMS
description: There is something about a middlingsize island that concentrates the mind as much as it stirs fantasy, whether it be Manhattan or Diego Garcia. It is the scale of such a place that performs both functions: small enough so that you can survey its entirety from some lofty vantage point, large and strange enough to invite exploration.

title:
DINING OUT;
COMING UP A BIT SHORT IN TRENTON
description: CONSIDERING that Trenton is the capital of one of the most densely populated states in the country, it is surprising how few good restaurants there are in that city. What is not surprising, however, is that the most popular and well-known restaurants in the area are Italian.

title: THE NEW PHILIPS STRATEGY IN ELECTRONICS
description: EINDHOVEN, THE NETHERLANDS TWELVE years ago, when Philips introduced the world's first video casette recorder, it confidently expected to dominate this very promising new market.

title: THE VOID FILLED BY CITIZEN JACKSON
description: To the Editor:

title: ASIAN BIRD IS FOUND ON COAST
description: A sparrow-like bird from Asia has been found along the California coast, the latest in a series of birds found on the wrong side of the globe this winter.

title: COUNTY'S ECONOMY IS JUDGED 'STABLE'
description: THE county's economy could experience some slow, steady growth this year, but the same forces that have given it strength during the recession could eventually lead to its deterioration.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Disposable Funds

title: HUSSEIN GIVES PALESTINIANS A LARGER ROLE IN PUBLIC LIFE
description: King Hussein reconvened Parliament last week to amend the Constitution so that Palestinians from the Israeli-occupied West Bank could be appointed as members. He also shuffled his 20-member Cabinet to increase the number of Jordanians of Palestinian origin from four to nine.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: A Freer Hand in Offshore Leasing

title: THAI, SPICY AND DELICIOUS
description: IN the melting pot that is Elmhurst, Queens,
