description: Drawing the Line in Europe

title: CHAMPIONS OF THE ICE APPEAR
description: With the arrival of the first deep freeze comes the appearance of a kind of ice people - winter sports enthusiasts, easily identified by their balaclavas, snowmobile suits, goose-down garments and felt-lined boots. They flock to the county's frozen ponds, lakes and reservoirs to ice fish, skate, play hockey, race ice boats, skate sail or just to slip and slide.

title: THE NEW BOARD BEGINS ITS WORK
description: IT was in a festive mood and before a packed gallery last week

title:
ANTIQUES;
REPRODUCTIONS AFFECT PRICES
description: or sometimes what they unfortunately have been persuaded are antiques - today than ever before, say Connecticut dealers. Some items euphemistically referred to as collectibles abound in many shops. Collectibles, however, are not antiques.

title: THE AGE OF MATURITY --
description: What a foolish obsession with youth and good looks!

title:
NUMISMATICS;
ANS PRESENTS TWO TOP AWARDS
description: The American Numismatic Society yesterday bestowed its two top awards on a pair of Europeans who have rendered impressive service to numismatics. The awards were announced and presented at the 126th annual meeting of the society, which took place at the ANS museum in Manhattan.

title: A SPY STORY EVEN JAMES BOND MIGHT ENVY
description: Michael Billington writes frequently about the British cultural scene.

title: DRAWING THE LINE IN EUROPE --
description: If I were dying of cancer and Mark Helprin brought me the news that it was of viral rather than chemical origin, I would be just as reassured as I am by his message that the crisis between the superpowers is political not military. As a matter of fact, the latter distinction is even more meaningless than the former if you accept the Clausewitz doctrine that war and politics are variations of the same process.

title: THE WAY THAT WORKS AT LINCOLN
description: EUCLID, OHIO TWO years ago, when the Lincoln

title: Postal Board Names Leader
description: John R. McKean, president of a firm of certified public accountants in San Francisco, has been elected chairman of the Postal Service's Board of Governors. Mr. McKean succeeded Robert L. Hardesty, the president of Southwest Texas State University, whose term of office as chairman ended Dec. 8.

title: MAKING A VIRTUE OF DIVERSITY
description: Edith Milton is a short story writer and critic.

title: DONALD ARMSTRONG
description: Gen. Donald Armstrong, a retired business executive and career Army officer who served during both world wars, died Wednesday at a nursing home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 94 years old and had lived in Palm Beach for several years.

title: KOCH TELLS THE CITY HOW HE'S DOING, IN NO UNCERTAIN TERMS
description: After he was elected in 1977, Edward I. Koch often said he intended to be the greatest Mayor the city ever had. He doesn't say that much any more, but from the tone and content of his State of the City speech last week, he seems to believe he has largely achieved his goal.

title: HONDURAN SAYS U.S. COPTER FLEW OVER NICARAGUA
description: The commander of the Honduran Armed Forces has acknowledged that the American helicopter whose pilot was killed Wednesday near the border with Nicaragua was over Nicaraguan territory when first attacked.

title: CUOMO FIGURES ODDS ON SPORTS BETTING
description: The Cuomo Administration unveiled a plan last week for legal sports betting in New York. The Governor's aides said they were confident that the proposal for a state sports lottery would win approval from the State Legislature and the Attorney General. By the end of the week, however, some were beginnning to lay longer odds on the plan's success.

title: CHABROL PUTS DE BEAUVOIR ON FILM
description: PARIS

title: WHEN BUTTRESSES TOOK FLIGHT
description: Robert Mark, a professor of civil engineering and architecture at Princeton University, is the author of ''Experiments in Gothic Structure.'' FRENCH GOTHIC ARCHITECTURE OF THE 12TH AND 13TH CENTURIES By Jean Bony. Illustrated. 623 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $115.

title: PANEL STUDIES MALLS FOR EFFECTS ON CITIES
description: AMID charges of ulterior political motives, the General Assembly has begun to study whether suburban shopping malls would hasten a deterioration of Connecticut's cities.

title: THE OWNER WHO BROUGHT A BIG BONUS TO TAMPA
description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: SYRIA DEMANDS MARINES LEAVE LEBANON FIRST
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria said today that he would not withdraw Syrian troops from Lebanon until United States marines and other foreign troops had left, the Syrian press agency said.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: FOR two excellent reasons, the National Board of the National Trust for Historic Preservation spent last Wednesday in the county.

title: PETE ROZELLE
description: David Harris is a frequent contributor to The New York Times Magazine. By David Harris ETE ROZELLE, COMMISSIONER OF the National Football League, first encountered the essential premise of his career when he was 10 years old and attending a summer day camp in the hills near his home in southern California. The campers had gathered for ''a little talk'' by one of the counselors. ''Character,'' the counselor pointed out, ''is what you are . Reputation is what people think you are. But,'' he went on as young Rozelle listened intently, ''if your reputation is bad, you might as well have bad character - the one is useless without the other.''

title: Boston College Defeats St. John's
description: Less than a week after playing its best half of the season in a victory over Connecticut, St. John's played its most inconsistent 20 minutes today and lost, 69-67, to Boston College before a crowd of 4,000 at Roberts Center.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE Norwalk Common Council has voted to charge a $1 fee for those who attend the city's Oyster Festival this summer, despite the concern of some who fear it will keep some children from attending. Doris A. Ross , a member of the 11- person council, cast one of three opposing votes against charging the festival's first admission fee.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
CREATING A SLOW DEATH
description: IT is often said that regulation has

title: MCENROE FACES LENDL IN FINAL
description: John McEnroe avenged three humiliating 1983 losses to Mats Wilander by dominating the teen-ager, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday to move into the final of the Volvo Masters tennis tournament. There he will meet the man who beat him here last year in straight sets, Ivan Lendl, who powered his way into the final by beating Jimmy Connors yesterday, 6-3, 6-4.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dieter Ficken, the coach of Columbia's unbeaten 1983 soccer team, has been named Division I coach of the year by the National Soccer Coaches Association of America. . . . Johnny Ray, the Pittsburgh Pirate second baseman, has broken off contract negotiations and will file for arbitrattion, his agent said. . . . Terry Bradshaw , the Pittsburgh Steelers' quarterback, says the elbow injury that put him out of action this season won't force him out of football. ''I am going to play,'' Bradshaw said at Louisiana Tech's annual football banquet Friday night. . . .

title: LEGISLATURE INHERITS MIXED BAG
description: TRENTON THE final session of the 200th Legislature ended in disarray last Monday, when both the Senate and Assembly adjourned with dozens of bills in position for votes. The session was dominated by an argument over whether the Governor's office delivered 23 vetoes on time. Some of the veto messages were accepted, others were not.

title: ON SILENT BIDDING
description: The average American duplicate bridge club is considerably noisier than clubs in many other parts of the world. This is not simply because American players shout more, although that is probably true. It is because American organizers are relatively backward in adopting methods of silent bidding.

title: SELECTMAN SPEAKES AS A POET
description: ROBERT A. WARD leaned back in his chair, folded his arms across his chest, stretched his long legs and gazed thoughtfully out his office window. As First Selectman of Kent, he was concerned about the bad weather. The town's salt pile needed to be put in order and its snow-removal equipment had to be ready to roll.

title: AN INTIMACY WITH DEATH
description: Fitzhugh Mullan is a pediatrician and the author of ''Vital Signs: A Young Doctor's Struggle With Cancer.'' A MORTAL CONDITION By Martha Fay. 284 pp. New York: Coward-McCann. $16.95.

title: IN THE SHADOW OF THE CLOVERLEAF
description: Ron Loewinsohn teaches English at the University of California, Berkeley. His most recent book is ''Magnetic Field(s),'' a novel. WHITE JAZZ By Charles Newman. 213 pp. New York: The Dial Press/Doubleday & Co. Paper, $7.95.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: With faith in charity and advertising, small Beloit College in Wisconsin ran a paid appeal in The Wall Street Journal and The New York Times last fall for a benefactor ''of vision'' who was ''willing to commit $1 million or more to our kind of school.''

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in this section last Sunday, a caption incorrectly identified the interior of a hotel as part of the Hacienda la Mansion. The hotel shown was the Hacienda Galindo.

title: BUILT MCDONALD'S CHAIN
description: Ray A. Kroc, the builder of the McDonald's hamburger empire, who helped change American business and eating habits by deftly orchestrating the purveying of billions of small beef patties, died yesterday in San Diego. He was 81 years old and lived in La Jolla, Calif.

title: No Headline
description: Claire Sterling wrote ''The Time of the Assassins'' during 10 months in 1983 in a room of her farmhouse in Tuscany. Mrs. Sterling and her husband, Tom, a writer, have lived in Italy since 1951 when Max Ascoli, the Italian- born editor and publisher of The Reporter, sent her there as a wedding present. Mrs. Sterling, a graduate of Brooklyn College and the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, was with The Reporter throughout its 19-year life and spent 17 of those years overseas. After the magazine folded in 1968, Mrs. Sterling wrote for the International Herald Tribune, The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal.

title: Nancy A. Brown To Wed Lawyer
description: The engagement of Nancy Andrews Brown, a second-year law student at the University of Pennsylvania, to Scott Floyd Smith, an associate with the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Barrett Bolton Brown of Wilton, Conn., parents of the bride-to- be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Sammons Smith Jr. of Hot Springs, Ark.

title: CONSUMER RATES
R.P.I. Case Shows Recruiting Problem
description: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute has built one of the better hockey programs in the East, but Coach Mike Addesa is going to have a much harder time maintaining his team's quality than he ordinarily would. The recruiting of next year's freshmen is intensifying, and Addesa and a few other Eastern coaches are at a disadvantage because their schools have chosen to align with the Ivy League next season.

title: Boston
description: To the Editor: In reference to Fox Butterfield's ''What's Doing in Bos

title: Before the Apostrophe
description: Writing as a near ''apostrophiliac,'' I'd like to point out the very close connection between the uses William Safire ascribes to apostrophes - to indicate a letter or letters left out (''Apostrophe Catastrophe,'' On Language, Dec. 11). Over the years, I have noticed many times, working in 17th- and 18th-century books, that an owner would inscribe his book thus: ''William Safire: His Book.''

title: THEATER GROUP GOES TO THE SCHOOLS
description: FIVE years ago, four young actors were selected by M. Edgar Rosenbloom, the executive director of the Long Wharf Theater, to form a community theater company in New Haven. When the program's financing ran out a year later, it expanded, rather than disbanded.

title: The Dream Lives
description: Next year, this day, January 15, will officially become a national holiday. Official or not, it's a fit day to reflect on the death, and life, of Martin Luther King Jr., who would have been 55 years old today.

title: MET OPERA SEEKS 'CIVIL WARS' WORK
description: The Metropolitan Opera is attempting to work out last-minute details to present significant portions of Robert Wilson's latest work of musical theater, ''The Civil Wars: A Tree Is Best Measured When It Is Down,'' at the Metropolitan Opera House next July 5-7.

title: Ellen Kirschner Wed to Joseph Popper
description: Ellen Ruth Kirschner, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul A. Kirschner of New York and Wellfleet, Mass., was married yesterday to Joseph Alan Popper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Popper of Lake Success, L.I. Rabbi Stephen Franklin of the Riverdale Temple performed the ceremony at the Georgian Suite in Manhattan.

title: Miss Bradley Plans to Wed Bruce Wood
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Kevin J. Bradley of West Hartford, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Kendall Jean Bradley, to Bruce Bennett Wood, son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Wood of Port Washington, L.I.

title: Quake Panics Yugoslavs
description: A strong earth tremor caused panic but no casualties or damage Friday night in the southern republic of Montenegro, officials said today.

title: Yukiko Okuma and Andrew Leon Wed
description: Yukiko Okuma, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Masaji Okuma of Honolulu, and Andrew Casell Leon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Leon Jr. of Shaker Heights, Ohio, were married in Manhattan yesterday at the home of Dr. Louis Z. Cooper and Madeline Appell Cooper. The bride's father, a Congregational minister, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg officiated.

title: ABOUT MEN
description: BREAKING DOWN BY RICHARD REEVES Richard Reeves is an author and syndicated columnist. ELIZABETH BRADY

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: AIR ILLINOIS GETS U.S. CERTIFICATION
description: The first Air Illinois flight since the airline halted operations after a Federal investigation raised safety questions arrived at O'Hare International Airport this morning carrying a dozen passengers, including the company's president.

title: LILCO'S TAX MOVE STIRS LEGAL DEBATE
description: AS the debate proceeds in Albany and on the Island about what would happen if the Shoreham nuclear power plant were never opened, the Long Island Lighting Company took a major step that illustrates one likely effect of abandonment: property tax losses.

title: DRAWING THE LINE IN EUROPE --
description: Mark Helprin's calm, analytical reasoning factually verified everything this reader has been coming to believe since late 1979.

title:
ART;
'GRASS ROOTS':WORKS BY COUNTY ARTISTS
description: -known artists can be disheartening, but they can also be rare chances for artistic discovery. Much depends on selection, of course, but the element of sheer luck often enters into the situation. This winter's ''Grass Roots'' exhibition in the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson, through Feb. 19, is the fortunate beneficiary of talented curators, as well as the happy chance of coming upon a young, very promising and little-known artist named Gregg Williams.

title: CRIME
description: It's all British this week, and we'll start with THE BLACK SERAPHIM by Michael Gilbert (Harper & Row, 3.95). Mr. Gilbert is one of the grand veterans of the traditional British mystery - his first book was published in 1930. Today, a half century later, his vision has not faltered. Perhaps that is because he never has been content to specialize in one kind of book. He has written procedurals, spy novels, short stories, courtroom dramas (in real life he is a lawyer) and just about anything in the mystery field. Perhaps it is the variety that has kept him on his toes.

title: Texas Fish Remain Plentiful
description: Commercial and sports fishermen say the recent record cold spell that killed thousands of fish along the southern Texas coast was not the disaster that experts feared. Government officials originally estimated the freeze could cost the state's fishing industry as much as $300 million. George Hull, a commercial fisherman, said he had hauled in about 800 pounds of black drum one day last week, about the same amount he had been landing before the freeze.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: January 15, 1984Fiction 1211 PET SEMATARY, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The new family in town discovers the horrors that lie in a neighboring cemetery. 2120 POLAND, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Seven centuries of history in fictional form. 3330 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 4104

title: CHURCH PROVIDING BOTH SOUP AND JOBS IN GREENBURGH
description: OUTSIDE the unadorned red brick church on Manhattan Avenue, in the Fairview section of Greenburgh, is a small white sign that proclaims: ''Neighborhood Food Kitchen Sponsored by Union Baptist Church - Monday-Friday 11-2.''

title: HIGH DECIBELS UNDER CONTROL
description: With lots of letters left over from last year, I'm trying to make a dent in the pile, selecting as usual only queries of general interest. Q. Last summer you reported on a pocket-size tape player with a light that blinks when the music gets loud enough to do damage. You said that you expected many manufacturers to offer similar safety checks for listening with earphones. Please tell me who they are because I am afraid my 9-year-old son is ruining his ears with his pocket stereo.

title: MYSTERIES JOIN THE MAINSTREAM
description: In his famous 1945 essay ''Who Cares Who Killed Roger Ackroyd?,'' Edmund Wilson dismissed detective stories as ''wasteful of time and degrading to the intellect.'' ''With so many fine books to be read, so much to be studied and known,'' he argued, ''there is no need to bore ourselves with this rubbish. And with the (wartime) paper shortage pressing on all publications and many writers forced out of print, we shall do well to discourage the squandering of this paper that might be put to better use.''

title: BALLET: BALANCHINE'S 'HARLEQUINADE'
description: It is hard to believe that until Thursday night ''Harlequinade,'' George Balanchine's delightful, fond look back at a special French-Russian ballet, had not been performed since 1980.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WARM CASH AND HOT FUDGE IN THE CASINO
description: Inside the Golden Nugget casino, I expect to see Frank Sinatra pinching the hotel owner's cheek, just like in the television commercial. Instead, I see hundreds of old people, mostly women, playing the slot machines. The nickel slots are especially crowded, and it occurs to me that the gambling industry is subsidized by the Social Security Administration.

title: Matsunaga Out of Hospital
description: Senator Spark M. Matsunaga, Democrat of Hawaii, was released today from the United States Naval Hospital at Bethesda, Hawaii, 10 days after he was admitted for treament of a mild heart attack. Mr. Matsunaga, who is 67 years old, spent four days under intensive care.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
MEXICO'S MIRACLE OF MIRRORS
description: MEXICO'S economic performance in 1983 has been depicted with great optimism. Eager for any favorable omen, Western analysts and bankers have seized on a number of financial and trade developments during the past year as happy evidence of improvement in the Mexican economy.

title: Japan
description: To the Editor: The week before we left Maplewood, N.J., for our trip to the Far East, I read the article by Amanda Stinchecum entitled ''In Kyoto, Ceremonial and Subtle Sweets'' about Japan's traditional tea service (Travel, Oct. 30).

title: Stating the Case For Nebraska
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PIANISTS SPAN THE REPERTORY FROM BACH TO JOPLIN
description: Amere music critic is not given to using such adjectives as ''fabulous,'' but that is the word one performing musician uses about another's recording in the liner notes for a recent release. The recording is by the pianist Andras Schiff of Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations, Four Duets (BWV 802-5) and Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue (London 72013, two disks, digital). The extravagant praise comes from George Malcolm, the fine British harpsichordist, in his discussion of the music itself.

title: TICKET POLICY ANGERS ATHLETES
description: Some United States Olympic athletes may consider skipping the opening and closing ceremonies in Los Angeles this summer if their families cannot purchase tickets, the athletes' representatives warned the United States Olympic Committee today.

title: LESS FORTUNATE, TOO, ADD THEIR DONATIONS TO FUND FOR NEEDIEST
description: Contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are from the wealthy, from people of modest resources and even from those who have suffered tragedy or financial hardship. Whatever their origins, all the gifts are intended to give solace or material aid to the severely distressed.

title: EGYPT ISSUE FAILS TO MAKE CONFERENCE AGENDA
description: The hopes of moderate Moslem countries that the Islamic conference opening Monday would lead to the return of Egypt to Arab councils appeared dashed today. The conference organization's Secretary General, Habib Chatti, said the meeting of about 40 foreign ministers to draft a conference agenda had not raised the issue.

title: CORPORATE PRESS: A NEW IMAGE IN PRINT
description: MANY of the most widely read magazines published in New Jersey are never on newsstands or in a dentist's waiting room. But they can be found in corporate suites, manufacturing plants and field offices of the state's major corporations, which publish them as the centerpieces of broad, and sometimes lavish, corporate communications programs.

title: Soviet Pipeline Official Made Deputy Premier
description: Boris Y. Shcherbina, Minister for Oil and Gas Construction, who directed the new Siberian gas pipeline project, has been made a Deputy Prime Minister.

title: Lisa D. Warren To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert O. Y. Warren of Suffield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Douglas Warren, to Bruce Alan Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Johnson of Winter Garden, Fla. The wedding is planned for June.

title: THE VOID FILLED BY CITIZEN JACKSON
description: * To the Editor: Your Jan. 4 editorial did a disservice to an ambassador of peace, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, and his testament of peace, the freeing of Lieut. Robert Goodman by Syria.

title: A RACE THAT TESTS TECHNOLOGY AND TENACITY
description: Imagine an auto race with 100 vehicles on the starting grid, everything from modified family sedans to super-charged sports specials. Only one driver to a car, please. Now send them off on a non-stop, round-the-clock, 1,800-mile rally and give a modest silver cup to the winner. Remind the late finishers to record their own times because the race committee won't stick around four or five weeks waiting for them to arrive.

title: 'VERTIGO' STILL GIVES RISE TO POWERFUL EMOTIONS
description: An astonishing burst of applause greeted the penultimate moments of Alfred Hitchcock's 1958 ''Vertigo'' at the performance I attended last week - astonishing because, only seconds later, the film's real ending left the audience gasping in disbelief. Those who had cheered the happy- looking near-finale must not have seen ''Vertigo'' before. They must have been caught off-guard by this film's stubborn, single-minded intensity, and by its uncharacteristic (for Hitchcock) reluctance to please.

title: MUSIC: MONOLOGUE BY STARER
description: Just about the time one begins to feel that the writing of effective vocal music is an art gone completely down the drain, a composer comes along with a piece to refute the notion. Robert Starer did it on Tuesday night with ''Anna Margarita's Will,'' a dramatic monologue sung by Irene Gobrud in the Musica Camerit concert at Goodman House.

title: Miss DeGraff Has Nuptials
description: Pamela Joyce DeGraff, an account representative at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York, and A. Hobart Porter, an assistant treasurer at Morgan Guaranty, were married yesterday. Bishop John T. Walker performed the ceremony at the National Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Headliners

title: CALL IT TV, BUT DON'T CALL IT REALITY
description: Where does reality programming go now, and, along with that, a corollary question: What is reality, anyway? Television took a giant step in an uncertain direction last week with ''Something About Amelia,'' a drama about incest. The drama was, as ABC and its publicists had said it would be, tasteful and discreet, with nothing explicit, nothing offensive, and thoughtfulness all around. Moreover, at the close of ''Something About Amelia'' a solemn message appeared on screen. ''This story dramatized a therapeutic approach to the problem,'' it said, and reminded viewers of the high- mindedness of what they had seen. After all, there is nothing exploitative about a ''therapeutic approach.'' Indeed, it suggests that ABC was performing a public service.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Indiana Pacers, at Indianapolis. The Nets ended a four- game losing streak when they defeated the Pacers, 118-106, on Dec. 30. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M., live. Radio - WNBC, 660, 8 P.M.)

title: U.S.-ISRAELI MILITARY PACT TO START SOON
description: American and Israeli military officials are scheduled to meet here soon to start planning joint military exercises and other elements of the military cooperation that President Reagan and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir agreed to in November.

title: HE HAD IT BAD FOR MOLLY ALLGOOD
description: Richard Ellmann is the author of books on Joyce, Yeats and other modern writers. THE COLLECTED LETTERS OF JOHN MILLINGTON SYNGE Volume One: 1871-1907. Edited by Ann Saddlemyer. 385 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $63.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A COOL GREENHOUSE
description: THE goal of most home greenhouse owners would seem to be to create a microcosm of the tropics by filling their greenhouses with exotic plants from such far-off places as the Amazon jungle.

title: WITH WINTER VEGETABLES, THE LUXURY OF PHEASANT AND PIGEON
description: SMALL birds such as Cornish game hens, pigeons or young pheasants, make convenient meals for one or two. They are also luxurious and attractive dinner-party dishes, especially appropriate for this time of year, because they go with winter vegetables such as chestnuts, celery, brussels sprouts, turnips or red cabbage.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Reagan Faces The East and Smiles Politely

title: Town to Get Assistance In Radium Plant Cleanup
description: Gov. James R. Thompson today signed a measure providing $2 million to clean up an abandoned factory blamed for the deaths of dozens of women who used radium to make the numbers on watches and clocks glow in the dark.

title: No Headline
description: ANY parent with two or more children is well acquainted with what experts label ''sibling rivalry.'' These parents are familiar with the constant bickering, pushing and tattling that occurs between their children. And, unfortunately, they have also experienced the nerve-racking anxiety that accompanies sibling rivalry.

title: Texas Rules Texts May Drop Darwin
description: The State Board of Education today ruled that biology textbooks used in the public schools of Texas do not have to mention Charles Darwin, who formulated the theory of evolution.

title: INFLATABLE GAINING WIDER RESPECT
description: Though salesmen at the boat shows may still leap up and down on pontoons and floors of inflatable boats in an effort to convince hard-bitten skeptics of the value of a soft-sided vessel, there are lately fewer skeptics and far more sales as the inflatable gains acceptance as a viable alternative to small wood, fiberglass or metal boats.

title:
MUSIC;
MODERN MUSIC IN MONTCLAIR SERIES
description: MONTCLAIR THE Montclair Art Museum will be the setting for an impressive three-part contemporary music series featuring the works of major composers from New Jersey and elsewhere, most of whom will be there to give views of their work.

title: 'KEAN': A CASE STUDY OF THE HIGH COST OF THEATER ON BROADWAY
description: When the play ''Edmund Kean'' with Ben Kingsley ran in London last year, the production cost $30,000 and the top ticket price was $13. When the identical play and actor came to Broadway earlier this season, the production cost $150,000 and the best seat was $32.50.

title: SHULTZ AND GROMYKO
description: In preparation for his meeting in Stockholm with Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko, the experts on U.S.-Soviet relations here provided Secretary of State George Shultz with a stack of briefing books on all recent policy and medical reports out of Moscow.

title: WIDER REGULATION OF DOCTORS PROPOSED
description: TO FOSTER ''greater competitive equity'' in New Jersey's health-care system, the Statewide Health Coordinating Council has called for government regulation to be extended to more health-care providers.

title: ; FATHERS, BE NOT AFRAID OF MOTHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: FUNERAL PLANS
description: RECENTLY my mother, who is 80 years old and in excellent health, handed me a sheaf of closely written pages.

title: U.C.L.A. IS UPSET BY OREGON
description: Blair Rasmussen, the 7-foot center, scored 18 of his 20 points in the second half to help Oregon to a 62-51 upset victory over U.C.L.A. in a Pacific-10 Conference game today.

title: NEW JOB PROGRAM TO MARK BIG SHIFT
description: A major reduction in Federal funds for the states for job training and employment will take effect in July under a Reagan Administration program that replaces the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.

title: AN AFRICAN NATION OF 380 LANGUAGES
description: To the Editor:

title: MODEST PROPOSAL
description: For some time I have been pondering Americans' reactions to public displays of nudity here in Europe. The depth of winter may seem an inappropriate time to address this matter - which is typically a dilemma for beaches in summer - but a skiing vacation, of all things, has brought it into focus.

title: POND FIGHT: A NEW ROUND
description: ALMOST 10 years after preservationists defeated a developer's attempt to build houses near the shoreline of Poxabogue Pond in Bridgehampton, a new plan for subdividing close to its shores has been back in the trenches.

title:
CRAFTS;
CONSTRUCTIONS AT THE MONTCLAIR
description: MONTCLAIR UNDER its director, Robert J. Koenig, the Montclair Art Museum devotes some 25 percent of its exhibition time and space to contemporary artists and craftspeople, with emphasis on New Jersey work.

title: ART: COMPLEX DISPLAY OF 'THREE PHASES'
description: NOW that technology is usurping many human endeavors, its role in art has become a question with growing significance. Will science produce images that can be regarded as art experiences? Will our responses be different? If so, how?

title: GRENADIANS HOPING FOR A REVIVAL OF TOURISM
description: These days the gently curving white beaches of Grenada's tourist hotels are populated by United States Embassy officers, their walky-talkies crackling beside them, and by off-duty American soldiers guarded by their on-duty comrades.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: -year silence on the issue, the New Jersey Audubon Society has endorsed a ban on the steel leghold trap, a device used to catch some 450,000 raccoons, muskrats, foxes and other animals in the state each year.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Monty Alexander's appearance at Village West (Hudson Street near Bank Street, starting Tuesday for two weeks) will be unusual although Mr. Alexander's performances in recent years have never been ''usual'' in the sense that his playing was stylistically or programatically in a common mold.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: FEROCIOUS ALPHABETS, by Denis Donoghue. (Columbia University Press, $7.95.) The most formidable figures in Denis Donoghue's study of ideological strife among contemporary literary critics are those who ''reject the significance of authors altogether (and) judge the imagination a ghost from the start, with not even a corpse behind it,'' Theodore Weiss said in his 1981 review. ''Ferocious Alphabets'' focuses on Kenneth Burke, Paul Ricoeur, Harold Bloom, Jacques Derrida, Paul de Man and a number of other participants in what Mr. Donoghue calls ''a war of words about words.'' SOMEONE ELSE'S MONEY, by Michael M. Thomas. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) The intricate plot of this ''compulsively readable'' novel ''revolves around a pair of scams, one apiece in the linked worlds of big money and big-league art collection,'' our reviewer, Robert Le kachman, observed. Having been both a financial consultant and an assistant curator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Michael Thomas ''knows both these environments intimately enough to detest most of the characters he has drawn'' but he peoples his story with some sympathetic men and women too.

title: ADVENTURES ON THE WATER AND IN THE SNOW
description: Creatures Of the Deep

title: POLICE TRY TO CURB SMUGGLING
description: -enforcement agencies are asking local police departments along the Connecticut shoreline for help in their effort to curb the smuggling of marijuana by air and sea.

title: A TUMULTUOUS CORNER OF LONDON
description: The tightly clustered little neighborhood around Smithfield Meat Market is a corner of central London that even longtime Londoners rarely explore. It lies at the northern edge of the City, the old London of Roman and medieval times, a 10-minute walk from St. Paul's Cathedral, and possesses all those enticements that City-lovers seem to admire - pubs with traditions and antique charm, inexpensive restaurants serving the freshest of meats and vegetables, old churches, priories and bits of ancient walls, tranquil squares and odd little nooks and crannies where history is embalmed in worn bricks and cobblestones.

title: REBUILDING PLANS AWAIT ASSEMBLY
description: HARTFORD AS its most publicized transportation problem was finally alleviated last weekend, Connecticut was confronting an even bigger task: finding billions of dollars over the next 10 years to rebuild its bridges, dams and roads.

title: KEY VOICE IN DRAMA 31 YEARS
description: Brooks Atkinson, the nation's most influential critic at a time when American drama first emerged as a serious art form, died of pneumonia yesterday at Crestwood Hospital in Huntsville, Ala. He was 89 years old.

title: A VANISHED VISTA
description: THERE is a brief stretch of Route 91 with a view that is a picture postcard of Connecticut.

title: THIRD PARTY IN A DIVORCE: THE I.R.S.
description: If a settlement ignores tax angles, a couple could end up paying 'alimony' to Uncle Sam.

title: Myra Jo Kaplan to Marry Douglas Marc Gildenberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kaplan of Waldwick, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Myra Jo Kaplan, to Douglas Marc Gildenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Gildenberg of Kendall Park, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: THE WORLD
description: Argentina Jails Former President

title: ROOM FOR THOUGHT
description: -in caretakers of a vacant old Vanderbilt mansion in Lloyd Harbor. The place had 25 bedrooms and a view of the North Shore I thought was available only by airplane. A greenhouse of stone, fountains and lazy vegetation encircled part of the outer wall of the house.

title: BRAZIL'S PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS MOVING INTO POSITION
description: Unofficial but intense campaigning is under way for the selection of Brazil's next President, who is likely to be a civilian after 20 years of military chiefs.

title: TENANTS CRITICIZE BOARD ON RENT-COMPLAINT FILING
description: MATTHEW L. WALD

title: Mauritius Expels Libyan Diplomats
description: Prime Minister Aneerood Jugnauth of Mauritius said today that his country expelled Libyan diplomats Friday, adding that the action was taken because the Libyans were interfering in the island's affairs.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ALDRICH EXHIBITION

title: BARGAIN-HUNTING BRITONS FLOCKING TO FRANCE
description: The only things that separate the English and the French, some say, are the English Channel and mutual antipathy. Yet any cross-Channel differences are put aside under the banner of bargain-hunting.

title: Reaching for the Top
description: While the United States Ski Team deserves great credit for its increasing dominance of World Cup skiing, I dispute the implication that the erosion of the European hold on the sport was a function solely of the rise of the United States team (''Reaching for the Top,'' by Herbert Burkholz, Dec. 18). Over the past eight years, the Russians, the British, the Australians and especially the Canadians have been instrumental in making World Cup skiing truly a world event. Indeed, it was probably the kamikaze style of Canadian skiers like Dave Murray, Ken Read and Steve Podborski (a former World Cup downhill champion) that kindled the interest of the majority of North American sports enthusiasts - i.e., those who participate from the armchair - and, in turn, draw the attention (and the funding) required in order to build the strength of the United States team. PETER G. SMITH New York City

title: A NEW COMPACT CAMERA RECORDER IS A TRIUMPH OF THINKING SMALL
description: ''The quick flick is the in-thing.'' This pert phrase was overheard recently in Central Park from a young man pointing a video camera at a presumptive girl friend. Translated, it means that there is a current vogue for making your own video movies.

title: Beautiful Buster
description: Joseph Frank Keaton was known to his foreign audiences as Malec, Frigo, Zephonio, Zybsko, Kazunk, Glo Glo and Wong Wong. To America, he was Buster.

title: Nuptials Planned By Lisa Harrison
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Harrison of Chatham, N.J., and Piseco Lake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Ann Gould Harrison, to James Worden Toffey, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. James Toffey of New Vernon, N.J., and Kennebunk Beach, Me. A June wedding is planned.

title: Utility Under Fire For Water Pollution
description: -BARRE, Pa., Jan. 14 - About 150,000 people in 18 northeastern Pennsylvania communities face up to eight more months of boiling their drinking water because of water pollution.

title: Business Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: THE AGE OF MATURITY --
description: I have a couple of suggestions for Charles Simmons. First, he must change his walking habits.

title: 2 Brothers Found Slain I
description: Two brothers were found stabbed to death Friday in their home in Elmont, L.I., apparently the victims of a robber, the Nassau County police said yesterday.

title: Dr. Jamie Lyn Hoffman to Marry Paul Rosenfeld
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Hoffman of Oreland, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Jamie Lyn Hoffman, to Paul Charles Rosenfeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Rosenfeld of East Williston, L.I. A March wedding is planned.

title: RURAL AREAS FIND CABLE TV ELUSIVE
description: GEORGE LINDNER lives in North Salem, a land of spacious old homes on four-acre lots, a land where Mercedes- Benzes share the road with mounted fox hunters - but a land with no cable television.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: January 15, 1984Fiction 1 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) A car that kills is at large among a Pennyslvania town's high school set.

title: THE MET GETS HANDEL OPERA-AT LAST
description: Thursday night's opening of Handel's ''Rinaldo'' will be a first step toward resolving some long and unexplained absences at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: PLAYING ON GLASS
description: Musical instruments have often been associated with mythological or cosmic powers - Orpheus and his lute, the Devil and his violin, Angels and their voices. But one little-known instrument, now being built in a glassblower's laboratory in Waltham, Mass., for the first time in 150 years, has rivaled many others in its powers.

title: WESTWARD HO!
description: No one at the City Planning Commission can say for sure when an office building last rose on Eighth Avenue. But the recent start of a $3 million commercial project between 50th and 51st Streets is one of the first signs that the panel's 1982 bonus space incentives, to shift development from the congested East Side to the West Side, has taken root.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT RANGERS BY 4-2
description: The final goal was so precise, so quick, that the Ranger goalie Glen Hanlon had to get out of his seat after the game to describe it.

title:
CAMERA;
GETTING THE MOST OUT OF LONG LENSES
description: Lou Jacobs Jr. is the author of several books on photography.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
BALLET FEVER
description: EASTCHESTER SOME years ago, Leslie Otto gave her three sons their first ballet lessons by the side of the youngest boy's crib. ''They asked me what mommy did as a little girl,'' she recalled. ''I got out some snapshots of myself dancing, then I asked them to hold onto the crib rail, and I taught them some positions.''

title: CHARACTER OF A ROAD IS AT ISSUE
description: DEER PARK AVENUE in Dix Hills is a main artery, but one that is surrounded by residences, farmland, churches and schools. A plan to convert one of those schools to a medical complex has pitted developers against area residents who say they want to retain the character of Deer Park Avenue.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: YEAR OF THE RAT

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: WILD TURKEYS, it seems, love New Jersey beyond anyone's belief. Six years ago, state wildlife biologists began a program to restore the birds to state woodlands for the first time in decades. Few were certain then of success.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Operating on a yearly budget of $75,000, the village of Alanson, Mich., was having a hard time in June 1982 trying to persuade the Federal Highway Administration that it did not need a new $500,000 bridge. All it wanted, the one-square-mile village said, was help in rebuilding a one- lane, 66-foot swing bridge over the Crooked River.

title: Workers for Mrs. Gandhi Slain by Kashmir Police
description: The police shot and killed at least three workers of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party today during violent protests in Kashmir State against the local ruling party, authorities said.

title: 'MAGNET' SCHOOLS MAY FACE CHANGE
description: The division of the Board of Education in charge of high schools, supporting a contention by many principals that ''magnet'' schools are skimming off the best students, wants to change how the schools select their students.

title: JOURNEY INTO MALI'S LAND OF THE DOGON'S
description: It is a journey back through time, back

title: U.S. OLYMPIC SAILORS STRONG
description: Through the years, with such skippers as Owen Churchill, Britton Chance, Lowell North and Dennis Conner, the United States has won more than its share of medals in Olympic yachting. This year, on the home waters off Long Beach, Calif., the United States has an opportunity to make its strongest Olympic showing ever.

title: FOR HACKENSACK A SYMBOL OF A REVIVAL
description: TWO exterior walls of Court Plaza North,

title: GEORGE VECSEYSports of the Times; The Devils' Mickey Mouse Question
description: T O mouse or not to mouse? That was the

title: APRIL, MAY, JUNE AND JASPER
description: Jean Strouse, the author of ''Alice James: A Biography,'' is working on a biography of J. Pierpont Morgan. TIME AFTER TIME By Molly Keane. 249 pp. New York: Alfred A, Knopf. $13.95.

title: The Joy Of Letter Writing
description: Roseann Pontello LaManna's lovely essay on letter writing (''Sincerely Yours, Opinion Page, Dec. 11), triggered a resonant response in me, as letters have long been my favorite genre of writing. As an editor and writer by profession, strangely I welcome my personal correspondence as a joy rather than a chore.

title: COMEBACK FOR A SEATTLE LANDMARK
description: After the expenditure of $60 million and a great deal of hard work, the old Olympic Hotel, a beloved but fading landmark in Seattle, has been truned into the new Four Seasons Olympic Hotel. And for once today looks better than the good old days.

title: JUDGE SAYS NIXON IS IMMUNE IN WIRETAP LAWSUIT
description: Morton I. Halperin, a staff member of the National Security Council in the Nixon Administration, cannot recover token damages from former President Richard M. Nixon and other officials who tapped his telephone for 21 months, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: METAMORPHOSES AND OTHER SHENANIGANS
description: Charles R. Larson's books include ''The Emergence of African Fiction'' and, most recently, ''Arthur Dimmesdale,'' a novel. FOREST OF A THOUSAND DAEMONS By D. O. Fagunwa. Translated by Wole Soyinka. Illustrated by Bruce Onabrakpeya. 144 pp. New York: Random House. $12.95. KWAKU Or, The Man Who Could Not Keep His Mouth Shut. By Roy A. K. Heath. 254 pp. New York: Allison & Busby/Schocken Books. $13.95.

title: FINANCING VARIED AND QUICK
description: When it comes to financing a new boat these days, the available choices have become almost as plentiful as home mortgages and the entire process has become almost as fast as it is for car loans.

title: Margaret Pickman to Wed D. S. Lobel
description: A June wedding is planned for Margaret Ann Pickman, a jewelry designer for Avon Products in New York, and David Stanton Lobel, a vice president of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, the financial concern.

title: THE AGE OF MATURITY --
description: Regarding ''The Age of Maturity'': Speak for yourself, Charles Simmons. HENRY STONE New York City

title: Linda Kathleen Kast Becomes a Bride
description: Linda Kathleen Kast, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Kast of Boonton and Beach Haven, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas Kinney Read Frelinghuysen, son of Roselyne de Viry Frelinghuysen of Princeton, N.J., and Siesta, Fla., and the late Thomas T. K. Frelinghuysen. The Rev. Dennis Hogan performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Mountain Lakes, N.J. He was assisted by the Rev. Richard Bower, an Episcopal priest.

title: NEW HELP IN BUYING A HOME
description: MANY blacks, Hispanics and members of other minority groups often give up hope of owning a home because they think lenders will not grant them mortgages even when their earnings are more than sufficient to carry a loan.

title: SATELLITES EXPAND HORIZONSOF CLASSROOMS ON CAMPUSES

description: The current recovery is preparing the way for the coming crisis of the American economy.

description: ''ONE of the most significant factors in the past 10 or 15 years,'' said Robert C. Baranaskas of Northport as he discussed the liquor industry, ''has been the younger entry drinkers - the baby boomers and their drinking patterns.

title: THE TOBACCO LOBBY'S UPHILL CAMPAIGN
description: THE decor is tobacco-colored brown leather. Framed on the reception room wall are 175 or so different packages of American cigarettes representing a staggering array of brands. It is the Washington headquarters of The Tobacco Institute, a lobbyist for and defender of America's leading cigarette manufacturers, an organization as condemnatory today of the Surgeon General's report on smoking as it was 20 years ago when the report was issued. ''It's an anniversary of dubious distinction,'' the institute declared last week. ''The report politicized - regrettably and evidently permanently - a medical controversy that should have been resolved by objective scientists.''

description: THE CELESTIAL STEAM LOCOMOTIVE By Michael Coney. 264 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $13.95. WORLDS APART By Joe Haldeman. 227 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.95.

description: The Consumer Electronics Show began only seven days after the official breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and there was no shortage of electronics companies ready to edge into the wider market for telephone equipment.

title: Judith Williams To Wed in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. George C. Williams of Setauket, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith A. Williams, to Peter Pitsiokos, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Pitsiokos, also of Setauket. A June wedding is planned.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS

title: REDUCING TENSIONS
description: The outset of the year 1984 finds Soviet-American relations in deep trouble. All arms control talks, nuclear and conventional, have broken down. The weapons race is now in many respects effectively out of control. Soviet-American trade has declined to almost insignificant levels. A number of cultural and scientific exchanges have had to be abandoned, and those that have survived are hampered by uncertainties. Official communication between the two governments has sunk to the most rudimentary level imaginable for nations not officially at war.

title: TOTAL FOR UNITED WAY IN 1983 WAS $15.5 MILLION, A 12% RISE
description: The United Way of New York City collected $2 million more in contributions in its 1983 fund-raising drive than in 1982, according to the chairman of the campaign.

title: TWO FACE CHARGES ON EXPORT OF GEAR
description: Two Americans, including one living in Switzerland, were accused today of illegally exporting high-technology equipment that officials believe has reached Eastern Bloc countries or their allies.

title: Israeli Group Seeking Pact With Palestinians
description: A former civilian administrator of the Israeli-occupied West Bank says that he has formed a new political action group in Israel and that it has won the support of an important coalition for his proposals for negotiated peace with the Palestinians.

title: International
description: The U.S. and its NATO allies agreed on a six-point proposal to present next week to the Soviet bloc and other European countries on ways to reduce the risk of war in Europe, State Department officials said. The proposal is to be presented to a new East- West conference opening Monday in Stockholm. It will be attended by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union. (Page 1, Col. 6.)

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The Bauhaus artist Oskar Schlemmer approached dance through painting and sculpture, and the results were a revelation. But until recently all that was available of his work for most New Yorkers was a vivid film of his signature ''Triadic Dance,'' housed at the Dance Collection.

description: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find particularly appealing. Our examples this week are taken from the five nominations for the 1983 National Book Critics Circle Award.

title: GLOBECONOMICS
description: By now, there is no question that the United States is participating in a new world economy. Some 70 percent of our products face foreign competition. The collapse of our exports over the past several years made the recession three times worse than it might have been and continues to cost us almost two million jobs.

title: WHAT'S THE NAME OF THE NEW GAME? TRIVIAL PURSUIT
description: It's called Trivial Pursuit. It was created in 1979 by two newsmen in Canada, has rapidly gained popularity in this country since it was introduced in late 1982 and - trivially speaking, perhaps - is affecting the winter social life of a lot of New Yorkers.

title: U.S. MONEY POLICY ASSAILED IN PARIS
description: Finance Minister Jacques Delors of France said today that Western Europe ought to think about imposing penalties on the export of capital to the United States if the Americans did not restrain the rise of the dollar on international markets.

title: POST-HOLIDAY LOOK AT THE ORCHESTRAS
description: TODAY let us consider the orchestras that are returning after their holiday recess. Tonight at 8, the New Haven Symphony plays at the Teletrack Theater for the second in its new series of Sunday pop concerts, with the help of the Fairfield County Chorale: it is an evening of Rodgers and Hammerstein.

title: Trends
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST GERMANY LOOSENS UP THROUGH CONTACTS WITH WEST
description: An odd thing has happened in the southeastern corner of East Germany, a quirk that goes against the image of a country widely perceived in the West as a gray unflinching bastion of neo-Stalinism. In the southeast, around Dresden, reception of West German television, which is watched by more than 70 percent of East Germany's 17 million people, is bad or nonexistent. This makes bureaucrats and even Communist Party functionaries reluctant to move to the area. So, quietly, the authorities have started laying cables to bring capitalist programs into socialist homes.

title: HEADLINERS
description: The $4 Billion Smile If Gordon P. Getty never got too worked up about peddling oil, it might have been because he never had an opportunity to sell it in multimillion barrel lots. He saw the chance last week and cut a pretty fair country deal for the family trust, unloading its 42 percent interest in Getty Oil for about $4 billion, nearly $2.4 billion more than it was worth a year ago.

title: AFRICA STRUGGLES AGAINST MALIGNANT DROUGHT
description: Rainfall has been insufficient in 36 African countries, with effects ranging from the inconvenient to the catastrophic.

title: More Arizona Police Guard Picket Lines
description: More state police officers were sent here today to quiet renewed violence between strikers at the Phelps Dodge copper mines and workers who have been crossing picket lines.

title: Jamie Ellen Fisher and Dr. Hilton Adler Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marc J. Fisher of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jamie Ellen Fisher, to Dr. Hilton Clifford Adler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Adler of Massapequa, L.I., and Margate, Fla. The wedding is planned for May 20.

title: Amy's Story
description: How did a 12-year-old victim of sex abuse become the only one locked up after the start of legal proceedings designed to protect children? That's the story of Amy, who spent eight days in solitary confinement at the order of a California court. It bears study.

title: WHEN ARTISTS PORTRAY UTIPIA AND ARMAGEDDON
description: There is utopia, a never-never world of moral, social and political perfection. And there is dystopia, its diametric opposite, the kind of glum universe described by Orwell's ''1984.'' Once upon a rosy time, in the early 20th century, there were visionary artists - Severini, Kandinsky, Mondrian, Malevich, Moholy-Nagy - who not only believed that a utopia, of one sort or another, was possible, but that art could help bring it about. Their dreams died with the advent of the Depression, Stalin and Hitler, World War II and the atomic age. And nowadays, it's dystopian fantasies, along with those of nuclear apocalypse, that prevail among artists; such is the state of civilization.

title:
ART;
PAVING THE WAY FOR BREAKTHROUGHS
description: THE surge of figurative expressionism among younger painters has spurred renewed interest in the work of their spiritual forebears. The very fact that the current movement has been dubbed ''neo- expressionism'' acknowledges that it derives from a precedent - if not by direct lineage, at least in recognition of an established tradition that is now being re-examined.

title: N.Y.U. DORMS
description: Among the handsome 19th century buildings lining Washington Square Park that are part of New York University are two seven-story structures on the southeastern corner that have long served as administrative offices for the university. Next summer, as part of a project to beautify the square and improve living conditions for N.Y.U. students, the facades of 80 Washington Square East and the adjoining structure at 41 East FourthStreet will be restored and their interiors combined and transformed into a 70,000-square-foot student residence with dining and study facilities.

title: Patricia Schuler Plans To Wed Iver Anderson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond T. Schuler of Niskayuna, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Schuler, to Iver M. Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Anderson of Glens Falls, N.Y.

title: Up From Anonymity
description: A half-century ago, when she first began writing novels and plays, Molly Keane hid behind a pseudonym, M. J. Farrell. As a young woman living among the Irish gentry in her native horse- and-hounds country, she did not think it would sit too well with the young gentlemen she was trying to impress to be known as a literary instead of a riding person. Success came fairly early to Mrs. Keane. As a playwright, she wrote what one observer called tea-cozy comedies. At the end of 1938, M. J. Farrell had a modest Broadway hit at the Morosco Theater called ''Spring Meeting,'' starring Gladys Cooper and directed by John Gielgud. The New York Times drama critic, Brooks Atkinson, sort of praised it - ''It is written with impish abandon and acted with gayety and relish. Nothing cerebral, you understand.'' Her early writing, however, was followed by a long silence, which was broken by the novel ''Good Behaviour,'' published here in 1981 under the author's real name. From her small aerie above the fishing village of Ardmore on the southern coast of Ireland, Mrs. Keane, now 80, cheerfully explained the stops and starts of her career. ''I wrote a lot when I was very young and it's never been easy - that awful discipline. I'm quite slow, write in longhand, never learned the typewriter. After many years of inactivity, four years ago I decided to try my hand again on a novel. I was a widow, my daughters were married, I had time on my hands and a lack of money.''

title: DANCE: INNER CITY GROUP
description: The Inner City Ensemble Theater and Dance Company of Paterson, N.J., is essentially a training company for urban youngsters with varying degrees of theatrical experience. But it does put on a good show, and a program Thursday in the Theater of the Riverside Church yielded some striking young performers.

description: -esteem and psychosomatic problems that started early in life. Some say they were not encouraged to achieve academically or allowed to express emotion in the home. Growing up in a culture that played down work for women, they married in an era when marriage was forever and became tied to the role of homemaker. As the years passed, they still couldn't express themselves. Worse, they couldn't get through the day.

title: An Ear for an Ear in Iran
description: A man who cut off another man's ear in a brawl in Iran has had one of his own ears severed as a penalty under Islamic law, a Teheran newspaper reported today. The newspaper Ettelaat said the ear was severed in the holy city of Qum. The report said Iranian authorities, a doctor and the victim of the assault were present when the ear was cut off.

description: Two city police officers indicted on Federal drug trafficking and racketeering charges surrendered Friday to the United States marshal here. They were said to have eluded the authorities for nearly three days.

title: GFindRobberySuspects
description: A German-trained police dog once criticized because it did not understand commands in English helped to find two robbery suspects today.

title: NOW IS THE TIME FOR VISIONS OF FOLIAGE-PLANT DESIGNS ;
description: Frederick McGourty is a writer and nurseryman who specializes in unusual perennials.

title: A NEW GENERATION FINDS IT HARD TO LEAVE THE NEST
description: When Jeanie Holley graduated from college four years ago, she packed her things, left home and moved into an apartment. But last year, at the depth of the recession, she lost her job and moved back into the suburban home near here where she had grown up.

title: CASINOS AND NEVADA BACK JERSEY ON UNION RULES
description: Atlantic City's casino companies and the State of Nevada have filed briefs with the United States Supreme Court supporting New Jersey's appeal for approval of limited regulatory control of casino unions.

title: THE KISSENGER REPORT COULD SHARPEN LATIN POLICY DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON T HREE times in the last 12 months, President Reagan has used bipartisan commissions to try to get out of political trouble. A Presidential commission neutralized the prickly issue of Social Security financing. Another helped persuade Congress to reverse itself and go along with the MX missile. But at least initially, it seemed unlikely that the National Bipartisan Commission on Central America would rescue Mr. Reagan from the deadlock that has dogged his Central American policy for nearly three years. The commission report could even fan the flames of Election Year partisanship. Unquestionably, it has lit a fuse. After months of preoccupation with Lebanon, the White House was busy this weekend translating the panel's recommendations into legislative proposals. Mr. Reagan said yesterday he would ask Congress for a program that would help Central Americans to vote ''with ballots instead of bullets.'' At present aid levels, he argued, ''what we have been doing is let them slowly bleed to death.'' Officials said he would ask for about $400 million in military aid for El Salvador for the rest of 1984 and 1985, roughly six times the $65 million previously provided for 1984. Henry A. Kissinger, the commission chairman, was booked to testify before Congressional committees early next month to try to generate political momentum. But the report touched off partisan reaction reflecting troubles the President hoped to overcome when he appointed the panel last summer. Congress was then in an uproar over large-scale American military exercises in Central America and fear of deeper American military involvement.

title: TOPICS
description: THE sight of that face staring at me with those dark, piercing eyes sent a chill up my spine. I stood there frozen, unable even to speak. His hair was a stringy, disheveled mess, and beads of sweat made their way through his stubbled beard in intricate patterned trails down his face.

title: DANCE MUSIC- FROM LILTING WALTZES TO SENSUAL TANGOS
description: Edward Schneider writes frequently about recordings.

title: ALARM OVER U.S. PILOT'S DEATH
description: U NTIL last week, the several thousand American troops on extended maneuvers in Honduras had managed to stay out of the line of fire along the border where American-supported rebels are fighting the Nicaraguan Sandinistas. Now the first American has been shot and killed: Army Chief Warrant Officer Jeffery C. Schwab, the pilot of an unarmed helicopter that American and Honduran officials said had strayed off course.

title: FINNISH CURB ON POLICY BRIEFINGS IS EXTENDED
description: President Mauno Koivisto of Finland, who recently vowed that the Finnish press would never again get any official explanation of his ''way of thinking,'' has extended this restriction to reporters around the world.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: THE COST OF USING CREDIT CARDS OVERSEAS
description: ''The past summer I toured Great Britain,'' Benjamin Rothfeld said, ''and found it convenient to use credit cards. When statements came for payment, I was surprised to find that MasterCard charges were all converted at a rate that was 6 cents per British pound higher than Visa, American Express or Avis.''

title: Stephanie T. Saylor Becomes Bride in Bryn Mawr
description: Stephanie Templin Saylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Benjamin Saylor of Doylestown, Pa., was married yesterday to John Black McGowan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McGowan of Malvern, Pa. The Rev. George Hollingshead performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church.

title: HISTORY IN MINIATURE
description: In the cavernous main room of the seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 66th Street, 72 invited antique dealers will soon be unpacking crates containing the prized furniture, art and decorative objects that they have been saving all year to display at the 30th annual Winter Antiques Show, which opens Saturday and runs through Jan. 30.

title: SKIING IN NEW ENGLAND'S NORTH COUNTRY
description: Weekend after weekend, all season long, the winter ritual would repeat itself: In the old days, when skiing was young, New Yorkers would gather in Grand Central Station, baggage in hand. All Friday night they would travel, east and then north, and by morning, often sleepless, they would spill into a small New Hampshire town. For two days, on wooden skis with leather bindings, they would ride the hills, sleeping in farmhouses and small inns, and then, as dusk gathered on Sunday afternoon, they would meet again, return to the trains and pull into New York by 6:30 Monday morning.

title: EMBEZZLEMENT TRIAL OPENS
description: CAMDEN FRANK GERACE, president of the largest hotel-casino union in Atlantic City, went on trial in Federal District Court here last week on charges of embezzling union funds.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CONSUMER ELECTRONICS
description: LAS VEGAS The festivities at this year's International Winter Consumer Electronics Show here generally took the form of staid luncheons, not the flashy, all-night fetes of years past. Parties, when they were held, usually ended by 10 P.M., sometimes to save money. In fact, the four-day show held here last week was dominated by an atmosphere of caution and unease. The great fear was that the spiral of overproduction and price cutting that cost hundreds of millions of dollars for video game and home computer makers like Atari, Mattel and Texas Instruments last year could spread to other areas of the industry before the new year is out.

title: GOOD AND HOMEY IN DARIEN
description: THE name of Gourmet Caboose, a small storefront restaurant in Darien, derives from the mobile van that used to sell frozen dinners to commuters at the Westport and New Canaan railroad stations.

title: WHY IT'S BEST TO BE LAST ON THE BLOCK TO GET THE LATEST GADGET
description: WE had always conquered the urge to be the first on the block to buy a new toy. We were in the company of those who did not buy a calculator until it could be purchased for $9.99. Staunchly resisting the toughest advertising telling us we needed some new device in order to be fulfilled, we waited for the product to be refined. The closest we had come to being impulsive was when we almost bought a computer last year. But a delay in the model being shipped to the store, and cold feet, stopped us.

title: CITY REFINES SANITATION-TICKET PROCEDURES
description: MANY New York City property owners believe they are being unjustly penalized under the ''nail-and-mail'' enforcement procedures adopted by the Department of Sanitation, and they are watching with eager interest a court challenge to those procedures.

title: Sarah Raup Is Betrothed
description: Sarah Keen Raup, an assistant vice president of the Marine Midland Bank in New York, and Richard Andrew Carlson, an associate with the New York law firm of Lord, Day & Lord, plan to be married in May. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Bryant Raup of Springfield, Ohio, parents of the future bride.

title: TESTAMENTS TO EARLY ENTERPRISE
description: Late 19th-century America produced great inventors, the pioneers of industry, a special breed that flourished in ways not seen before or since. The list of the most famous includes Thomas A. Edison, Alexander Graham Bell, Samuel F. B. Morse and Elias Howe, names every school child can identify. And there are many more, as can be seen in ''American Enterprise: 19th-Century Patent Models,'' an exhibition opening Tuesday at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, 2 East 91st Street, and remaining through April 1.

title: SPAIN'S LIVELY LITERARY REVIVAL
description: DESPITE sever unemployment, cultural life in Spain is booming. Spaniards now have a firm sense of national pride; a recent flurry of articles in the European and home press characterized Madrid as the new cultural mecca, and tastes now are more eclectic. Unexpectedly, Anagrama, a small, prize-winning independent literary house, found it had a year-long super best seller with John Kennedy Toole's ''Confederacy of Dunces.'' Good writers are making their prose more accessible. Both Eduardo Mendoza and Manolo Vazquez Montalban have experimented with the detective novel, now a very modish genre.

title: WHY VIRGINIA LOST ITS CLOUT
description: Edmund S. Morgan, who teaches history at Yale University, is the author of ''American Slavery - American Freedom: The Ordeal of Colonial Virginia.'' description: Maj. Saad Haddad, a former Lebanese Army officer who for years ran his own militia force in southern Lebanon with Israeli support, died at his home yesterday at the age of 47, Israeli officials in Tel Aviv reported. His family had said he was ill with cancer.

description: The United States and its NATO allies have agreed on a six-point proposal to present next week to the Soviet bloc and other European countries on ways to reduce the risk of war in Europe, State Department officials said today.

description: President Reagan has told some of his top advisers that he has decided not to propose any major tax increases in his 1985 budget, Administration sources said today.

description: TUNIS A LTHOUGH Tunisia's President Habib Bourguiba had the political agility to turn a week of anti-Government tumult into personal victory, the affair has reminded Tunisians that their leader, now in his 80's, is only mortal. Some were wondering last week if he was still fit to lead and who could carry on after him.

description: -timer in Whitehouse Station knows that the correct name for Cushetunk is Pickel Mountain, named for an early Dutch settler.

description: The Library of Congress is the biggest library in the whole world. It has also become one of the nation's largest attics, so filled with thousands of other things besides books that there is never enough space in its three enormous buildings to exhibit, at any given time, even a fraction of what the library owns.

description: For two days this week it was impossible to tell the two daily newspapers apart by which carried the column of that quintessential Chicagoan, Mike Royko.

description: Television sets of all shapes and sizes have had one thing in common - when the set is off, the screen has a dull, greenish-gray color.

description: FOR every Katharine Hepburn, Robert Motherwell and Skitch Henderson in Connecticut, there are scores of other artists, ranging from authors to xylophone players, who are searching for ways to make money.

title: 250,000 A YEAR VISIT REFUGE
description: -frozen trails of the Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge on an early January morning, a visitor is hard put to see how anything could disrupt the vast salt marshes, meadows and heavily wooded uplands that overlook Great Bay and Reeds Bay.

description: Two free throws by Ray Williams with no time remaining gave the Knicks a 113-111 victory tonight over the Bulls at Chicago Stadium.

description: Whatever became of our guardians of virtue, our so-called religious leaders, lashing out against the tidal wave of hunger and corruption? Whatever became of the disciples of God who led their congregations by extolling the words of God?

title: AID TO HANDICAPPED IS OFFERED
description: TWO loan programs that offer more than $2.2 million for the development of group homes for the mentally retarded or for renovations to homes of the physically handicapped are being offered through the West Hartford-based Corporation for Independent Living.

title: ENGLISH POP-PLENTY OF HITS WITH LITTLE IN COMMON
description: One sign of the overall artistic health of pop music these days is the fact that what has been called the Second British Invasion hasn't excluded other English rock from the American charts. Recent hit albums by the Rolling Stones, Yes, and Culture Club represent three generations of English musicians, and the multiplicity of styles embraced by the most popular British rock acts includes heavy metal (Def Leppard), winsome kiddie pop (Paul McCartney) and anthemic folk- rock (Big Country). Among newer English pop albums, Culture Club's ''Colour by Numbers,'' a record that has made its androgynous lead singer Boy George into an international superstar, and ''90125,'' by the reconvened art-rock group, Yes, are the two most commercially successful, though in some ways they couldn't be more dissimilar.

title: NICARAGUAN ANNOUNCES ELECTIONS
description: A Nicaraguan official announced today that elections will be held next year for president, vice president and a constituent assembly.

title: REFLECTIONS ON DR. KING'S LEGACY
description: WHEN President Reagan signed the bill creating a national holiday to honor Martin Luther King Jr., he stated that Dr. King's words and deeds had ''stirred our nation to the very depths of its soul'' and that he had ''changed America forever.'' In a previous news conference, the President had affirmed his belief in the importance of ''the symbolism of that day.''

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE 30 January days, omitting that first, euphoric one, are a dismal interim in the calendar. It is all letdown, waiting for the other shoe, usually in the form of snow or sleet, to drop.

title: Zhao Arrives in New York

D'Amato. Mr. Koch presented Mr. Zhao with a key to the city and said he would serve him ''authentic American beef stew - the best ever.''

title: R. T. Fisher, Miss Bourne Are to Marry
description: The engagement of Kimberly Graham Bourne to Richmond T. Fisher has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James Edelin Bourne of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram B. Fisher, also of Greenwich.

title: Sara Fraser to Marry Jon E. Budish in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. James E. Fraser of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Ann Fraser, to Jon Elliott Budish, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard E. Budish of Livingston, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: The Age of Maturity
description: As a writer who has been working on a book about the invasion of privacy to which women are subjected daily in the form of leers, lewd comments and vulgar suggestions, I was infuriated by Charles Simmons's article ''The Age of Maturity'' (About Men, Dec.11).

title: RETIREMENT: IT MUST BE OPTIONAL
description: RETIREMENT, the ''golden years,'' a time to enjoy in independence and dignity the fruits of a lifetime of labor. This is a fundamental aspiration of most New Jerseyans.

title: EXPERT ON THE SIDELINES
description: In the halcyon early days of the Nixon Administration, I used to cadge free tickets to the Washington Redskins games (an ethical lapse) and take along Henry Kissinger, then a little- known football fan who worked in the basement of the White House.

title: YANKS WERE NO. 1 IN SALARIES
description: Although the Yankees didn't produce any championships on the field in 1983, they regained a No. 1 ranking off the field. After a lapse of one season, the Yankees registered the highest average player salary last year.

title: NORTH CAROLINA WINS BY 70-62
description: North Carolina extended its winning streak to 12 games and improved its Atlantic Coast Conference record to 3-0 with a 70-62 victory over Wake Forest (11-2, 0-2) today.

title: Antelope 'Daemon'
description: My father took up his gun and returned home. And it so happened that the path he took led him past a field of okro on the way to the town. . . . Coming up to the field he looked over to the other side and observed someone approaching from that direction. Quickly he climbed up a tree, waiting to see what this person was about. The figure came on unswerving until it vanished into a large anthill. Shortly afterwards, an antelope emerged from this anthill, entered the field and began to feed on the okro. My father brought his gun to bear on the creature and drove furnaces into its skull. The gun had no sooner roared than there came from the antelope a human cry and the words, ''Ah, woe is me!'' That night my father slept in a little hut by the field. When daylight broke he went to the spot where the antelope was shot, but he found nothing there, only blood. He began to follow the trail of blood, and it was with increasing astonishment that he found the trail led homewards. He followed it until he arrived right home. But in midtown the trail vanished completely and he did not come upon it again until he was nearly at his own doorstep: then it led him straight into my mother's room. I had not myself slept at home that night. Whenever my father was away I hated to spend the night at home because the spirits gave one no peace all through the night.

title: POLITICS GOES TO THE MOVIES
description: Roger Ebert is film critic of The Chicago Sun-Times and co-host of the television program ''At the Movies.'' SEEING IS BELIEVING How Hollywood Taught Us to Stop Worrying and Love the Fifties. By Peter Biskind. Illustrated. 371 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $22.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: GIVE THEM A CHOICE
description: Since there are so many fascinating possibilities in a single game, why not arrange to try all - or at least several - of them? This was the basis of David Bronstein's madcap suggestion that each game have available four or five boards and pieces.

title: A Military Solution
description: In a rueful backward glance at Vietnam, Gen. Maxwell Taylor once remarked, ''Until we know the enemy and know our allies and know ourselves, we'd better keep out of this dirty kind of business.'' It's an apt text for weighing the wisdom of the proposals now offered by the Kissinger commission on Central America.

title: OUTDOORSNelson Bryant

title: SHOPPING CENTER SITE OPPOSED
description: APROPOSED shopping center site in Northport has turned into a battleground, and the conflict between the developer and the village's Planning Board has gone to court.

ANTIQUES;
PHONES: NOT JUST FOR TALKING INTO
description: WHAT technology renders obsolete in everyday life, time often endows with a patina of value. So it has been with antique automobiles, vintage aircraft, oak iceboxes and old telephones. These enduringly popular items are increasingly sought after.

title: DEBATE WILL PUT DEMOCRATS TO TEST
description: The eight major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination will come together today before a national audience. Not quite a debate, not quite a free-for-all, it is the campaign's first nationally telecast forum designed to pit the whole Democratic field of primary candidates against one another at once.
