title: BKillinginParaguay
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn has ruled that the family of a Paraguayan youth tortured and murdered in that country in 1976 is entitled to $10.4 million in damages from a former Paraguayan police official who later lived in Brooklyn.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions yesterday on the denial of an operating license for the Byron Nuclear Power Station in Illinois incorrectly described a statement by a Government licensing panel. The panel did not accuse the Hatfield Electric Company of ''fraudulent'' performance.

description: A man once questioned in the 1982 deaths of seven people who took Extra-Strength Tylenol that was laced with cyanide could be sentenced up to 40 years in prison in a separate case for killing a man he believed to be an informer.

description: THE goal of most home greenhouse owners would seem to be to create a microcosm of the tropics by filling their greenhouses with exotic plants from such far-off places as the Amazon jungle.

description: Four coal miners have died in separate accidents in Kentucky in a nine-day period, including one Friday, indicating ''a careless trend'' in the industry, a state official says.

title: COMPANIES WIDEN WORKER ROLE IN DECISIONS

Practices that have historically represented distinctions between blue- collar and white-collar workers have in part been eliminated, including time clocks, reserved parking and private dining rooms.

description: YONKERS EARLY efforts to save Yonkers from a threatening budget crisis gathered momentum last week at City Hall here and in Albany. Half way through their fiscal year, officials in this city have been seeking ways to close a predicted gap of about $40 million between expenses and revenues over the next 18 months.

title: AN ARTS PROGRAM SURVIVES THE CRITICS

title: LOST HEADS AND FINANCE FOR TOTS
description: Move over, Jane Fonda . . . Spinnaker Software, which makes educational programs for the home, plans to introduce a program named ''Aerobics'' for Commodore and Atari computers. A colorful female cartoon character appears on the screen, twisting, bending and running in sync with a funky tune that plays over the computer's speaker. ''We had some great bugs to work out,'' said William H. Bowman, Spinnaker's chairman. During the character's first try at neck exercises, ''her head separated from her body and flew across the screen,'' he said.

THE LIVELY ARTS;

description: AS an actress, even one trained in the instinctive style that eventually was christened the Method, Barbara Bolton has always done a great deal of research, she said, to ''load my unconscious with a lot of images to draw upon.''

title: EX-WILDLIFE AIDES TELL OF REBUFFS IN SMITHVILLE CASE
description: TWO former officials of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service said last week that they were either ignored or reprimanded by superiors when they warned that a development near the Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge was likely to destroy parts of the refuge, pollute a river and endanger wildlife.

title: REAGAN AS MILITARY COMMANDER
description: Richard Halloran, a member of The Times's Washington bureau, covers military affairs. By Richard Halloran VER THE LAST 18 months, President Reagan has clearly stepped into the front ranks of those American Presidents who, since World War II, have been willing to employ military force as an instrument of national policy. In his constitutional post as Commander in Chief of the armed forces, Mr. Reagan has dispatched marines and warships to Lebanon, mounted an aerial and naval show of force against Libya, sent warships and combat soldiers to Central America and ordered the invasion of Grenada.

title: THE LIVING THEATER RETURNS TO ITS BIRTHPLACE
description: Thirty-seven years after it was created, the Living Theater is still Living, an emblem of the cause of political theater. The company is also a tribute to the survivability of Julian Beck and Judith Malina, the couple that founded it and have continued as its leaders and primary artistic resources. During those intervening years, the Living Theater has been situated in several European countries and has gone through a number of metamorphoses while preserving its ideological and artistic identity. It is a theater of revolution that by its very nature is still embroiled in controversy, provoking audience riots and sustaining collisions with civil authorities on three continents.

description: HARTFORD BASED upon an architectural consultant's report saying in part that ''the Harvey & Lewis Building is not especially significant on a national level,'' a developer has decided to go ahead with plans to demolish the structure, one of Hartford's first Art Deco-style buildings.

description: Claire Bloom has played an abandoned waif with Charles Chaplin in ''Limelight,'' a daintily crushed ingenue with Laurence Olivier in ''Richard III,'' an asp of a mother who ''kills with a touch'' in ''Brideshead Revisited'' - and a hundred other women. But never, in her 38 years as a professional in theater and film, has the line between life and fiction seemed harder to discern than in her latest role.

title: HIGH PERFORMANCE: TODAY, SPEED SELLS
description: For anyone interested in going fast on the water, there is a lot to look at inside the New York Coliseum during the boat show. In fact, there are bigger boats (and more of them), bigger engines, and a greater variety of drive systems than ever before.

title: ENGLAND NOW HAS A MOST-BORROWED LIST, TOO
description: After a long educational and parliamentary effort, Government checks will begin going out next month to about 6,000 authors whose books were borrowed from public libraries under a concept known as Public Lending Right. In the mother country of the English language, where so many British writers continue an old struggle for survival, the plan is the culmination of a campaign that began a quarter of a century ago. It is based on the premise that a writer should be compensated every time his book is loaned from a public library, not just when a copy is sold.

title: In Short
description: MYSELF MY ENEMY. By Jean Plaidy. (Putman $13.95.) Jean Plaidy has voluminous list of historic novels to her credit. Her intest is the first volume of ''Queens of England'' series. Its protagonist is Henrietta Maria, the girl who left the court of her father Henri IV of France, when she wed King Charles I. From that start, Henrietta is a provacative Queen who inspires the mistrust of her subjects in 17th-century England. Her frequent rages and her unwillingness to replace her retinue of French servants with English ones quickly earn her an unsavory reputation for being obstinate and peevish. Her insistence on leading men staunchly. Protestant people to Catholicism, her own ''true Faith,'' proves her undoing. Her blunders create a political crisis that neither she nor her virtuous but weak husband can halt. The tale of this royal couple is ideal material for Miss Plaidy. She excels at blending history with romance and drama, components that are nicely balanced in ''Myself my Enemy,'' and the book's rapid pace, plus an abundance of colorful characters, makes it engrossing reading.

title: MORE THAN AN ALSO-RAN
description: DARK HORSE A Biography of Wendell Willkie. By Steve Neal. Illustrated. 371 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: BRITONS WIN DANCE WITH 11 PERFECT 6'S
description: Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean, the reigning British world champions, won the ice dance title in the European figure skating championships today with a stunning performance in the free dance that drew 11 maximum 6.0 scores.

Mr. and Mrs. Carl Viggo of Rochester have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Wexler of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: REVIVING THE RITUALS OF THE DEBUTANTE
description: D. Susan Barron is an assistant professor in the Department of Communications at Simmons College in Boston. By D. Susan Barron OR EVERYTHING THERE IS A SEA son, including one for ''coming out,'' the custom whereby young women are presented to that privileged circle called ''society.'' Within the past few weeks throughout America, properly credentialed debutantes have been celebrating the zenith of their season with unabashed enthusiasm. From Dallas, where an elite handful of debutantes are culminating three months of social pyrotechnics, to the more restrained provinces of Boston, where the season is significant though fleeting, it seems fashionable once again to display the perquisites of wealth and class.

title: MINI-SERIES AND COMEDIES KICK OFF THE NEW SEASON
description: The beginning of 1984 is a time for premieres on cable television, as cable networks introduce new series, produced-for-cable plays, and films that have rarely, if ever, been shown on the home screen.

description: -SALEM, N.C. - On Nov. 3, 1979, five members or supporters of the Communist Workers Party were killed in a gun battle with Ku Klux Klan and American Nazi Party members on the streets of Greensboro.

description: Stephen Schlesinger, an assistant to Governor Cuomo for communications, and Judith Elster, a copy editor for The Dispatch in Union City, N.J., plan to be married March 18.

description: 2,500 Ideas For Cutting Federal Fat

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Inflation at the producer level during 1983 rose by the smallest increment in 20 years, thanks to a 10 percent drop in gasoline prices and a 15.8 percent decline in heating oil. December's increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index left the indicator up only six-tenths of 1 percent for the year, compared with a 3.7 percent rise in 1982 and a 7.1 percent jump in 1981. It was the lowest since a five-tenths of 1 percent rise in 1964. But the bad news was that beef prices are surging - rising 6.3 percent in December alone, the largest jump in three-and-a-half years, and economists fear that the effects of last summer's drought will continue pushing meat prices up. In other economic news, the Government said that American businesses plan to increase their spending on new plants and equipment by 9.4 percent this year, the largest increase since 1977; industrial production rose a modest five-tenths of 1 percent in December, and retail sales edged up a mere one- tenth of 1 percent.

title: Search Ends for 5 in Crash
description: The Coast Guard said Friday that it was abandoning its search for five members of a Federal team assigned to the national drug enforcement cmmpaign whose helicopter crash-landed in the ocean near Nassau, Bahamas. Four other men in the helicopter were rescued shortly after the craft was ditched Monday. Officials theorized that the five missing men were trapped inside the helicopter when it sank in 6,000 feet of water.

title: BARNES RECOGNIZED FOR HELP IN 48 INDICTMENTS
description: Leroy (Nicky) Barnes, who is serving a life sentence for narcotics trafficking, has provided information resulting in the indictment of 48 defendants, according to Federal prosecutors.

description: SENATORIAL courtesy, which has been practiced in New Jersey for 140 years and has never successfully been challenged in the courts, is expected to face legislative scrutiny this year as a growing number of lawyers join Governor Kean in protest of the practice.

title: Luger Gets Another Chance After Fall in Olympic Trials
description: At age 23, Frank Masley of Newark, Del., is the best male luger the United States has ever produced. People in the sport think he can place in the top 10 in next month's Winter Olympics in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia.

description: Rafael Addison, Dwayne Washington and Andre Hawkins each converted 1-and-1 free-throw chances in the last minute to give Syracuse a 70- 62 victory over Providence tonight in a Big East Conference game.

title: MEDIOCRE CONDUCTORS HAVE TOO MUCH POWER
description: Afew weeks ago, to buttress an argument about conductors past and present, I mentioned a few of the many respected masters whom a concertgoer might have heard in the decades immediately following World War II. I ran on until I had dropped 31 names, then stopped, making plain that no exhaustive survey was intended. Nonetheless, distressed readers came rushing forward to champion favorite conductors whom they felt had been slighted. I hereby append some of the more familiar names that were thrown at me, even though certain of these maestros enjoyed major careers that fell outside my own listening experience:

title: No Prank to Rose Bowl
description: It was an inspired prank designed to earn college credit, but now it appears that Dan Kegel and Ted Williams , the Cal Tech seniors who took electronic control of the Rose Bowl scoreboard on New Year's Day, are going to get the full course. Prosecutors in Pasadena said they planned to charge Kegel and Williams with trespassing and malicious mischief in connection with the stunt.

title: Pornography Code May Return for a Vote
description: Although Mayor Donald Fraser's veto of an ordinance defining pornography as discrimination against women was upheld by the City Council, the Council has also decided to allow reintroduction of the measure.

description: HOBOKEN AFORMIDABLE hurdle in this city's struggle to build a $500 million waterfront complex was formally cleared last week when the Federal Government signed over to it, for $1.5 million, the property rights to three abandoned piers.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Bob Hope has been making December pilgrimages to entertain United States servicemen since World War II. Now 80 years old, Mr. Hope recently returned from his 30th U.S.O. tour, which took him to battle-torn Lebanon. Sunday night at 9, a two-hour special program, entitled ''Bob Hope's U.S.O. Christmas in Beirut,'' will be broadcast on NBC. The program, which will include footage from the tour, will also feature Brooke Shields, Ann Jillian, Cathy Lee Crosby, Vic Damone, George Kirby and the current Miss U.S.A., Julie Hayek.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: For Want of an Amp PATRICK MCDONNELL

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
EUROPEANS AND AMERICANS, AND HOW THEY SAW THE 30'S
description: For an interestingly slanted look at one of the great decades of photography, the place to go is the Sander Gallery, 51 Greene Street, through Jan. 28. The current exhibition, entitled ''Photography in the Thirties,'' includes very few photographs by Americans - only one by a Life photographer, and not even one of the photographs of rural poverty in America that were taken during the 30's for the Farm Security Administration. What it has, instead, is a strong concentration of Central European, particularly German, photographs placed in a context that suggests links with contemporary trends across the Atlantic.

title: MSGR. MERRITT YEAGER
description: Msgr. Merritt E. Yeager, Roman Catholic chaplain emeritus of the New York City Fire Department, died Jan. 4 in Brooklyn Hospital.

title: STATE REPORT URGES MORE NEW HOUSING
description: FOR the next three years, the amount of housing construction that was authorized in the state in 1982 - 10,562 units - will have to be nearly doubled if demand is likely to be met, according to a report of the Department of Housing.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: All Roads Lead To Damascus

title: STAGE: COLE PORTER'S 'RED, HOT AND BLUE!' REVIVED
description: There are good reasons why some musicals, no matter how distinguished their scores, remain better left to history. Cole Porter's 1936 show, ''Red, Hot and Blue!'' which the Equity Library Theater has bravely undertaken to resurrect, should probably have been left in the drawer. With a book by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse that is little more than strung-together wisecracks, many of which were daringly smutty for their day, the story doesn't even make sense by the madcap standards of Depression-era Broadway.

title: FOR SOME GIFTED MUSICIANS, FREELANCING OFFERS CAREER
description: Every year thousands of gifted young musicians graduate from universities and conservatories throughout the country and come to New York, instrument in hand, to pursue their dreams.

title: ADVERTISING DOES NOT BELONG IN THE CLASSROOM
description: SEVERAL weeks ago a salesman stopped by one of my elementary school libraries to discuss a program for teaching library skills with filmstrips. The program would be taught by ''teachers'' sent in by his company and could be completed at our three elementary schools in a couple of days.

title: Retiring No. 53
description: He's just been elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame, and now Don Drysdale, the former Dodger pitcher, is going to get another honor. His uniform No. 53 will be retired in a pre- game ceremony at Dodger Stadium on July 1. At the same time the Dodgers will also retire No. 1, which was worn by Drysdale's teammate, Pee Wee Reese, the former shortstop. Nos. 1 and 53 will join six other famous Dodger uniforms that have been retired, Nos. 4, 19, 24, 32, 39 and 42, which, as any true Dodger fan doesn't need to be reminded, were worn by Duke Snider, Jim Gilliam, Walter Alston, Sandy Koufax, Roy Campanella and Jackie Robinson.

title: Suffolk: The Lure Of the Forbidden
description: After chuckling over Richard F. Shepard's recent ''About Long Island'' piece concerning a State Department ruling banning travel by Russians to Suffolk County, I began to wonder if this seemingly arbitrary measure might not have wider effects. Americans are noted for their fascination with anything that's forbidden - will those who dwell at some distance now become more curious, developing an interest in a New York area formerly avoided as somewhat inaccessible?

title: FOR DEVIL'S BAG, THE LIMITS ARE UNKNOWN
description: DAWN had pierced the cool darkness, suddenly turning the sky to pink and purple above the stables at Hialeah Race Track. The sun must have felt good as it warmed the coat of the brown colt who had just been led out from the center stall in Barn M, his home for 23 hours a day. He arched his neck toward the sun as Philip Gleaves, his exercise rider, swung into the saddle and steered him onto the path that cuts through the palm trees and on to the race track.

title: WESTCHESTER ACTING TO MONITOR AIRPORT NOISE
description: Westchester County has named its first airport ''noise abatement officer,'' giving him responsibility for a new electronic system the county intends to use to monitor noise around Westchester County Airport.

title: FOR THE U.N., A TINY BREAK IN DOLDRUMS
description: The halls of United Nations headquarters are dark, empty, even a bit lugubrious in these days of no major ongoing meetings. But diplomacy goes on, fashioned of discussions, compromises and a certain degree of diplomatic passion.

title: FRENCH MUSIC PROVES ITS POPULARITY AT HOME
description: There is little room for doubt that orchestral programs in our concert halls are heavily weighted in favor of Germanic music. The symphonies of Beethoven, Brahms and the like are the meat-and-potatoes staples that - according to orchestra management theory - no subscriber can ever get enough of. Other musics are admitted, of course, but pretty much on a sweets-and-sours, condiment or garnish basis.

description: THE Eglevsky Ballet, which has been trying for several years to stabilize itself artistically and financially, has lost its artistic director, Edward Villella.

description: The New York City subway system's JFK Express was scheduled to lose its exclusive character under a plan put forth by the New York City Transit Authority in June 1983. The ''Train to the Plane'' was to run much like any other city subway train, with added stops and a total fare to Kennedy International Airport of $1.50 instead of $5.

title: MILLER UP BY 1 ON 105-YARD WEDGE SHOT FOR EAGLE
description: If Johnny Miller has a pitching wedge in his hand and a shot of 100 to 110 yards, he thinks he has gone to golf heaven. Because he does it so well, there is nothing he likes to do more than hit that shot.

title: IOWA CONTEST REFLECTS PARTIES' HOPES
description: Senator Roger Jepsen was driving to a speech at the Rotary Club on Thursday when he flipped on the car radio. The first voice he heard was that of Representative Tom Harkin announcing he was running against Mr. Jepsen in November. Mr. Harkin, who is unopposed for the Democratic nomination, accused the Republican incumbent of ''appealing to the base instincts of people'' with ''simplistic slogans and inflammatory statements.'' When he called for a debate, Mr. Jepsen spun around and told an aide riding in the back seat to accept.

title: WHY DROPOUT RATE IS HIGH IN 12TH YEAR
description: ''APRIL may still be the cruelest month for struggling poets,'' said Edna Durand, a former high school counselor, ''but for high school seniors, January is the real wasteland.''

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: All over Africa and Latin America, religious ceremonies are tied to music and dance, with specific rhythms dedicated to specific rituals and spirits. Non-believers rarely get a chance to observe these rituals, but recently New Yorkers have had a chance to see and hear La Troupe Makandal, a voodoo troupe led by the master drummer Frisner Augustin.

description: To the Editor:

title: EARNINGS OF ARTISTS
description: THE National Endowment for the Arts, using Census Bureau figures, has found that the number of artists living in the United States rose 81 percent from 1970 to 1980.

title: THE PROGNOSIS IS GUARDED FOR NEW JERSEY'S AILING CITIES
description: ''The state of the state is very good,'' Governor Kean told the New Jersey Legislature last week in his annual message. Amid all the upbeat economic news - progress in employment, construction and business - Mr. Kean sounded a single alarm. ''Despite the healthy job growth in our state's suburbs, parts of our inner cities remain a sore to the eyes and bring an ache to the heart,'' he said. ''We cannot abandon them.''

title: REAGAN ENDORSES PROPOSAL FOR AID TO LATIN AMERICA
description: A Nicaraguan official announced tonight that elections for a president, vice president and an assembly would be held in 1985. Page 12.

title: THE GROWING MILITANCY OF THE NATION'S NONSMOKERS
description: T WENTY years ago last week, the Surgeon General of the United States shocked smokers with news of just how deadly the cigarette habit is. The 1964 report, prepared by experts who had been approved by cigarette manufacturers, described mounting evidence that smoking contributed heavily to hundreds of thousands of deaths each year from heart disease, lung disease and cancer, particularly among men.

title: Jane B. Creamer Will Be Married To Jeffrey Plank
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Creamer of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Beach Creamer, to Jeffrey Otto Plank, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Plank of Lexington and Duxbury, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

description: James J. Storrow Jr., publisher of The Nation magazine from 1965 to 1977, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 66 years old and also had a home in Stormville, N.Y.

description: Kings Court Shoppes and College Corners are retail development projects that are being planned along Brooklyn's Flatbush Avenue, and both of them are responses to an upsurge in the demand for retail space in the borough and the revitalization of many of its shopping thoroughfares.

description: The Chadian Government has put the blame for the collapse of peace talks with Chadian rebels in Addis Ababa on the Ethiopian leader, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, and the acting Secretary General of the Organization of African Unity, Peter Onu.

title: IN SOUTH AFRICA, THE ARMY STILL WRITES ITS OWN TICKET
description: South Africa's latest incursion into southern Angola in pursuit of South-West African guerrillas appears to have met unusual resistance. The development has prompted doubts at home and encouraged peace talks over an area that Pretoria continues to control despite international condemnation.

description: WE can take pride in the high quality and increasing number of musical events in Westchester County, while also realizing that many intriguing concerts in the Bronx, Rockland County and Connecticut communities are an easy drive away.

description: An immigration policy dispute has developed over whether children who worked for Pol Pot's forces in Cambodia in the 1970's should be allowed to enter the United States, according to United States officials and leaders of human rights and refugee resettlement organizations.

description: Despite a sharp drop in the cabbage crop in 1983, New York retained its place as the leading state in the production of cabbage for sauerkraut, according to a year-end report made this week by the State Crop Reporting Service.

description: NEW HAVEN LAST year, a worker at St. Raphael's Hospital here choked to death in a restaurant. That tragedy prompted hospital officials to establish a program to teach waiters and waitresses in the New Haven area how to aid choking victims.

title: Griffin and Bulls Talk
description: Archie Griffin , the 29-year-old two- time Heisman Trophy winner from Ohio State who was dropped by the Cincinnati Bengals last month, has opened negotiations with the Jacksonville Bulls of the United States Football League. ''If it works out, it would be super for us and I think it would be super for Archie,'' said Lindy Infante , the Bulls' head coach, after the Bulls acquired rights to Griffin from the New Jersey Generals.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: WOOD ENGRAVINGS IN OLD LYME
description: THOMAS WILLOUGHBY NASON died in 1971 at the age of 81, leaving a large body of prints, most of which are wood engravings. These had been commissioned as illustrations to books, reproduced in magazines and newspapers or had been seen in the numerous exhibitions in which the artist had participated.

title: SOME BASKETBALL COURTS ARE DEEMED HAZARDOUS
description: LAST March, when the Connecticut Interscholastic Athletic Association discovered that the gymnasium at Madison's Daniel Hand High School did not have at least 500 seats and four feet of space separating the walls and the ends of the basketball court, it ruled that the facility could not be used for a boys' basketball tournament.

title: DISCUSSION SERIES FOR TEENS TO OPEN
description: LAST spring, two North Salem High School committed suicide. The first to die was 17- year-old Cathy Ann Petruso, described by her classmates as popular and outgoing. She was found hanged in a restroom at a drive-in movie in Danbury, Conn. Her death left the school ''devastated,'' a school guidance counselor said.

title: A PIANIST, VIOLINIST AND CELLIST PERFORM RECITAL PROGRAMS
description: The most finished - and musically the most interesting - of last week's debut performers was Anne-Marie McDermott, a young New York pianist who played Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y under the auspices of Young Concert Artists.

title: Mariners Drop Out Of Bidding for Rose
description: The Seattle Mariners have taken themselves out of the bidding for Pete Rose.

title: LIVE FROM DARTMOUTH: EIGHT DEMOCRATS
description: This has been a time of settling in for the Presidential contenders. Last week, the Democrats' eight announced candidates slogged through the rimed streets and the hedgerows of Iowa and New Hampshire. The unannounced Republican candidate was closeted in the White House, quietly studying the political dangers of the Administration's record budget deficits.

title: NEW HANDS ON OLD SALEM REINS
description: North Salem, in the northeastern corner of Westchester County, is a community of horse lovers, but even there horse farms are being sold off and divided into building lots. That will not be the fate, however, of Old Salem Farm, a 54-acre riding school and horse farm that had been owned by Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward.

title: 13 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 13 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN TAMPA
description: REGINALD STUART is chief of the Miami bureau of The Times.

title: FOOD
description: NCE IN A WHILE, we encounter a food book that has never, to our knowledge, received the fanfare it deserves. I would put in this category a book in my library, one which I cherish and refer to often because it is so thoroughgoing and authoritative in its subject matter, and the recipes are uncommonly well written and authentic. It is ''The Complete Asian Cookbook'' by Charmaine Solomon. The dust jacket says (I have never met the author) that she ''comes from a family of exceptionally good cooks'' and that she started out as a reporter for an English-language newspaper in Sri Lanka. She wrote a cookery column and ''did not realize her own potential in the kitchen until she came to Australia,'' where she also wrote a food column and gave cooking lessons on the art of Chinese and international cooking. I bought my first copy of this book in Hong Kong, where it was recommended to me by an acquaintance who knows his way around the kitchen. When I returned home, I found that it was, and is, available in hard cover in major bookstores in Manhattan.

title: ANTI-MISSIONARY DRIVE PRESSED IN ISRAEL
description: Orthodox Jews are pressing a campaign against what they see as a growing effort to convert Israeli Jews to Christianity.

title: 74TH SHOW BRINGS SIGNS OF SUCCESSFUL '84
description: Cold winds may blast across Central Park and snow may crunch under foot. But warm memories of golden seas, and fresh summer breezes and fast boats spring to mind on visiting the 74th National Boat Show, which opened at the New York Coliseum yesterday for a nine-day run.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday (it is today) will become a national holiday in 1986. But New Jersey, the first state to do so, made the day a holiday in April 1977.

title: KUHN IS NAMED IN GRIEVANCES
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association, as expected, has filed grievances over Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's suspension of four players for their involvement with illegal drugs. The grievances, initiated Friday, will attempt to overturn the one-year suspensions of Steve Howe, Willie Wilson, Willie Aikens and Jerry Martin.

title: Instant Celebrities
description: American basketball is held in awe in India, so when a United States team toured the country for a series of games against members of India's national team, it was hardly surprising that the American players were greeted as heroes, even with a parade worthy of Olympic champions. It was a bit surprising, however, for the Americans, who were not Olympic champions, but members of the Division III team at M.I.T., a school better known for its academic tradition than its athletic accomplishments.

title: 76ERS DOWN WARRIORS, 129-103
description: Julius Erving scored 27 points as the Philadelphia 76ers defeated Golden State, 129-103, tonight for their fifth straight victory over the Warriors at the Spectrum.

title: THIS WATCH NEEDS A WARM-UP
description: It looks just like a watch. And it is a watch, except that Casio Inc.'s new ''read sensor'' timepiece is also a calculator without buttons.

title: Lisa J. Gelfman and Gary S. Matthews Are Engaged to Be Married in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Gelfman of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Jane Gelfman, to Gary Steven Matthews, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman S. Matthews of Cincinnati, formerly of Scarsdale.

description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: SCANDINAVIAN COMPOSERS
description: The music of Scandinavians has a peculiar place in the classical tradition. Many of the works of Grieg, Sibelius and Nielsen - the most significant Scandinavian composers - seem to hover at the periphery of things, as if written in isolation, displaying an entrancing eccentricity and quirky self-involvement.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I agree completely with the objectives of improving prospects for democracy and human rights in El Salvador. I am also committed to preventing Cuban-and Nicaraguan-supported guerrillas from violently overthrowing El Salvador's elected government and others in the region.'' - President Reagan. (12:4.)

title:
STAMPS;
U.S. SPEEDS FLOW OF NEW COMMEMORATIVES
description: The United States has just issued a commemorative for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and right behind it are commemoratives for Soil and Water Conservation, Credit Unions and Carter G. Woodson.

title: Two Who Aided Miss Hearst Win $30,000 in a Libel Award
description: The couple who helped Patricia Hearst elude capture after her abduction by the Symbionese Liberation Army, a radical group, have won $30,000 out of court in a libel suit against her.

title: Six Accused by Police In Korean Hotel Fire
description: The police sought arrest warrants today for six people accused of negligence in a hotel fire in South Korea's second largest city that killed at least 38 people and injured 74.

title: Advertising; Agencies Optimistic About 1984
description: EVEN the admitted pessimists in the agency business are optimistic about 1984. It may be guarded optimism, as it is in the case of John J. Kinsella, president and chief executive of the Leo Burnett Company of Chicago, but it is optimism all the same. And it is optimism not only for their own agencies but also for the advertising industry as a whole.

title: More Pregnant Women Abstain From Liquor
description: A national survey indicates that 30 percent of married mothers are heeding warnings about their babies' health and are giving up drinking during pregnancy, health officials say.

title: Loss of 1,700 Pounds Of Uranium Is Reported
description: More than 1,700 pounds of enriched uranium, enough to make 85 atomic bombs, has been reported missing since 1947 from a Government nuclear weapons plant at Oak Ridge, according to a published report.

title: 12-YEAR-OLD CHARGED IN THE BEATING DEATH OF ATLANTIC CITY BOY, 7
description: A 12-year-old boy was arrested in Atlantic City yesterday and charged with murder in the beating death of a 7-year- old, the son of a police detective in the resort community.

title: DELEWARE'S PAPERLESS BOND SALE
description: The State of Delaware, in a break with normal practice in the municipal bond market, announced Friday that it wants to sell $50 million of tax-exempt bonds using a system in which records of bond ownership are kept electronically, with no paper certificates available to investors.

title: Peak Volume In New Issues
description: Initial public offerings totaled a record $12.95 billion in 1983, up from $1.45 billion in 1982 and nearly quadruple the previous record of $3.32 billion set in 1981, according to New Issues, a newsletter.

description: The Economy

title: Learn English, Austria Told
description: Interior Minister Karl Blecha is ordering Austria's entire police force to learn English, Kronen Zeitung, a popular daily, reported today. ''I plan to put out an official memorandum saying that all policemen and gendarmes must learn English,'' Mr. Blecha was quoted as saying. He said he wanted to insure that tourists would get proper advice and assistance from his officers.

title: HAWKS BLANK PENGUINS
description: Chicago's goalie, Tony Esposito, recorded his 76th career shutout and Behn Wilson scored two goals tonight, leading the Black Hawks to a 2-0 decision over the Pittsburgh Penguins. The loss was the Penguins' seventh in a row.

title: 6 MILLION WOMEN ARE PAID MORE THAN THEIR HUSBANDS, U.S. SAYS
description: Nearly six million American wives earned more than their husbands in 1981, a sharp contrast with the conventional role of the wife as keeping house or supplementing her husband's earnings, according to a Census Bureau study released today.

title: BABY DEATH TRIAL WILL BEGIN TODAY
description: Jury selection begins Monday in the murder trial of Genene Ann Jones, a licensed vocational nurse charged with injecting a 15-month-old girl in Kerrville with a lethal dose of a muscle relaxant.

title: People
description: * Norman Sherman has been named executive vice president for marketing at Avrett, Free & Ginsburg Inc.

description: An attorney for Gov. Bill Allain said today that he had obtained sworn statements from three male prostitutes recanting allegations they made in the gubernatorial campaign last fall that they had engaged in sexual acts with Mr. Allain on several occasions over the past three years.

description: Officials of Rockwell International Collins, concerned over possible terrorist attacks, said today that, starting Monday, they will search the lunch boxes, briefcases and purses of everyone entering and leaving the military contractor's plants.

This was the work of the new school of supply-side economists, who promised long-term growth from tax cuts because lower taxes, they said, encourage hard work, savings and investment.

title: PROTOCOLS OF PALESTINE

For years before the birth of Israel, and then afterward, Palestinian leaders fought the very idea of a Jewish state, rejecting negotiation, using hateful language and violence. Now, as more Palestinians are ready for compromise, some on the other side answer them with suspicion and hate.

Its blue and gold kiosks multiplied in shopping malls and parking lots across America at the rate of 500 a year. Its revenues and earnings tripled in the space of five years. Some people called it the McDonald's of photography.
