title: Brewers in Kaiser Fight
description: The Pearl and Falstaff brewing companies, which together own 5 percent of the stock of the Kaiser Steel Corporation, went to court Saturday to prevent Kaiser from holding a shareholders' meeting scheduled for this Wednesday, Kaiser Steel said yesterday. The move by the brewers was aimed at preventing the completion of a merger between Kaiser and an investor group led by J. A. Frates. A court hearing on the brewers' plea is scheduled for tomorrow in Los Angeles, Kaiser Steel added.

title: U.S. Six Tops Salt Lake City, 6-2
description: Paul Guay scored one goal and assisted on two others today to lead the United States hockey team to a 6-2 victory over the Salt Lake City Golden Eagles of the Central Hockey League.

title: 2 Held in Killings in Chicago; Victims' Apartment Set Afire
description: Two men have been charged with murder in the slayings of four people whose apartment was set afire in an attempt to hide the crime, according to the police.

title: CABARET: 'CINDERELLA'
description: the New Year,'' the popular

title: DANCE: WASHINGTON BALLET COMPANY
description: MARY DAY, who founded and directs the Washington Ballet and its school, has a reputation for producing new talent. That she has done it again was suggested by the performing of young Bonnie Moore at the Brooklyn Center at Brooklyn College on Saturday night, when the Washington-based company presented a program of new and recent ballets.

title: FOCUS ON PEOPLE CAUGHT IN THE MIDEAST CONFLICT
description: To the Editor:

title: CURRENCY OPTIONS GROWING
description: The days are gone when London was the unchallenged capital of world finance. But with more than half of the world's currency trading taking place in the City, London's financial district, it is still to the foreign exchange business what Broadway is to musicals.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TRANSCRIPT OF DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES' DEBATE
description: Following are key sections of a transcript of a debate yesterday at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., among eight major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of the Public Broadcasting System. Ted Koppel of ABC News moderated the first 90 minutes of the three-hour debate. Phil Donahue, the television host, moderated the second 90-minute segment. Woman on Ticket

title: JAZZ: JOHNNY O'NEAL, PIANIST
description: DURING the last 28 years, Art Blakey has seen a seemingly endless stream of jazz pianists leave his Jazz Messengers to build successful careers of their own, starting with Horace Silver and including Bobby Timmons, Cedar Walton, Albert Dailey and Keith Jarrett. The latest to take off from the Blakey keyboard is Johnny O'Neal, who played solo piano at Village West, Hudson Street near Bank Street.

title: 'PLEASE CLAP FOR ME'
description: N EAR the end of the second set, a baby could be heard crying in the darkened seats above the illuminated green tennis court at Madison Square Garden.

title: FOR JAPAN, 'DAY AFTER' IS NO MATCH FOR HIROSHIMA
description: Nuclear disaster, Hollywood-style, came to Japan this weekend. The real day after had been a lot worse, said some of the people who were there.

title: DEMS, THERE IS A VA.
description: Rappahannock County, in western Virginia, backs up against the Blue Ridge Mountains. The point of view of most of the 5,000 inhabitants is that of people who live in hollows. The view from a hollow begins at a point, as at the angle of a triangle. Precise and narrow, it widens into the distance - a view with perspective.

title: U.S. SKIER WINS CUP DOWNHILL RACE
description: Bill Johnson, a little-known skier from Van Nuys, Calif., scored the United States' first World Cup downhill skiing victory ever in the men's division today.

title: THEISMANN LOOKS TO MONK AND BROWN FOR BIG PLAYS
description: WASHINGTON I N the Washington Redskins'

title: OUTDOORS: A SEASON FOR FLY-TYING
description: I T is not happenstance that nearly all of the fly-

title: Miss Warner Wins
description: Bonny Warner, the defending national women's luge champion, won her second trial race in two weeks today, qualifying for the United States Olympic luge team with ease, and Tim Nardiello, a local entrant, edged Frank Masley of Newark, Del., in the men's race.

title: ; A GOVERNMENT RELUCTANT TO INFORM
description: To the Editor:

title: LEBANESE CHRISTIANS AND ISRAELIS MOURN HADDAD
description: Maj. Saad Haddad, the southern Lebanese militia leader allied with Israel who died on Saturday of cancer, lay in state today in his home town as hundreds of Lebanese and Israelis paid him tribute.

title: POP: THE CULT AT RADIO CITY
description: COMMERCIAL acceptance hasn't done a thing for the Blue Oyster Cult. When the group emerged in the early 1970's, its songs were smarter, wittier and more virtuosic than most hard rock, while the band members looked surprisingly mild-mannered.

title: Dr. Kunio Sakan Dies; Leader in Drug Studies PITTSBURGH, Jan. 15 (UPI) - Kunio Sakan, a chemistry professor at Carnegie-Mellon University who helped synthesize a bacteria-fighting antibiotic, was found dead Thursday, apparently by suicide, the authorities said. He was 39 years old.
description: Professor Sakan's body was found by his wife in the bathroom of their home.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Hockey Islanders vs. Bruins , at Boston, 7:35 P.M. (Television - WOR-TV, Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WOR, 710; 7:30 P.M.) The Islanders are 0-5-1 against the Bruins in regular-season play since November 1981.

title: JEANNETTE O. BAYLIES
description: Jeannette O. Baylies, the president general, from 1977 to 1980, of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution, died Thursday at her home in Scarsdale, N.Y. She was 71 years old.

title: PACERS OVERTAKEN BY NETS, 140-134
description: Through most of this season, Darwin Cook has been lost in the crowd that has been the Nets' backcourt. Since being replaced in the starting lineup last month by Kelvin Ransey, he has been squeezed out of significant playing time, especially since the recent unexpected return of Micheal Ray Richardson.

title: G.I. IS FOUND SAFE IN BAVARIA AFTER REPORTED KIDNAPPING
description: The American soldier stationed at a missile base in south Germany who was reported by the police to have been kidnapped was discovered today by a farmer's wife in a barn some 145 miles from his base.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA HAS STREAK BROKEN
description: Hana Mandlikova ended Martina Navratilova's streak of victories at 54 today in the final of the Virginia Slims of California at the Oakland Coliseum Arena. The scores were 7-6, 3-6, 6-4 in a match that was rated among the best on the tour in a long time.

title: APPLE EXPANDS PRODUCT LINE
description: One year ago Apple Computer Inc. hoped to dazzle the computer world with a revolutionary new machine called Lisa that was said to be the key to the company's future. But Lisa turned out to be a poor seller, and Apple's earnings and its leadership in the personal computer market crumpled under an attack from the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: When Labor Owns the Mill
description: Weirton, W. Va., was in a mood to celebrate last week. Weirton Steel, which at full capacity employs 10,000 and dominates the economy of this mill town west of Pittsburgh, has been spared from closure. Its workers bought the aging plant from the National Intergroup conglomerate, creating the largest employee-owned business in America.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Dome Chief to Reassure Japan's Utilities on Gas J. Howard MacDonald is off this week to Japan in an attempt to reassure prospective customers about Dome Petroleum Ltd.'s agreements to deliver $2 billion of liquefied natural gas to Japanese utilities.

title: Pieta Cohen and P. A. Bellizia Marry in Short Hills
description: Pieta Cohen, daughter of Annette Cohen of Forest Hills, Queens, and Martin D. Cohen of Santa Monica, Calif., was married yesterday to Prosper Andrew Bellizia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent R. Bellizia of North Brunswick, N.J. Superior Court Judge Murray G. Simon performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's late grandfather, Louis J. Cohen, in Short Hills, N.J.

title: I.D.S. Tie Completed
description: The American Express Company and the Alleghany Corporation have announced a formal conclusion to the merger of Investors Diversified Services into American Express. I.D.S., a major financial services company, formerly Alleghany's principal subsidiary, was acquired by American Express for 11.5 million of its shares plus $333 million in cash and a $40 million 10-year note carrying interest at 8 percent a year.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture that appeared Wednesday with articles about diplomatic relations between the United States and the Vatican was incorrect. It showed Rufus King, a member of the Continental Congress and later a United States Senator, not the Rufus King who was Minister to the Papal States under Pope Pius IX.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Upstaging Olympics

title: TV: A BALLET ON INDIANS
description: MICHAEL SMUIN'S ''Song for Dead Warriors,'' to be shown at 8 tonight on WNET/Channel 13 as part of the ''Dance in America'' series, is that rarity: a ballet with a social conscience.

title: STUDY FINDS SIGNIFICANT DROP IN FINANCIAL AID FOR STUDENTS
description: After two decades of rapid growth, the amount of financial aid available for college students has dropped by $2 billion in the last two years, the College Board said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Jan. 6 on acquired immune deficiency, or AIDS, referred ambiguously to a group at risk of contracting the disease. It should have stated that people born in Haiti but living in the United States now account for 5 percent of the total number of disease victims in the United States.

title: 'FARMERS' MARKET' SELLS USED CARS IN PITTSBURGH
description: The idea of a sort of farmers' market for used cars seems so natural that a lot of people are wondering why they never thought of it. But it took a game of tennis, a trip to England and an unlikely pair of entrepreneurs to allow the idea to take root here.

title: PATRIOTIC PRICE WAR
description: WHEN I was in grade school a long time ago, some civic group sponsored an essay contest on the glories of the free- enterprise system. We all dipped our pens in the ink-holders on our desks - that will give a clue how long ago it was - and scribbled our thoughts on the open market, free competition and laissez-faire democracy.

title: RAIL FAN FINDS RUSTING DREAM OF WEST SIDE
description: Within one of New York City's more obscure but passionate subcultures, that of the railroad aficionado, the name Peter Obletz ranks with that of, say, Ferdinand Magellan.

title: CABBAGE PATCH KIDS: BORN FOR 'ADOPTION' AT A PRICE
description: The Cabbage Patch Kids - those pudgy, homely, soft little dolls with no chins that seemed to be just about everywhere during the holidays - were so extraordinarily popular because they were designed to be substitute children, according to researchers and pyschologists who helped with the development of the dolls.

title: 7,000 Workers Strike At 336 Supermarkets
description: About 7,000 butchers and delicatessen clerks at 336 supermarkets in New Jersey and New York voted to strike today, hours after negotiations with four supermarket chains collapsed.

title: CUSTOMS SERVICE GIVES TEXTILES A TWICE-OVER
description: In the world of smuggling these days, fashion is the fashion.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Time Takes Toll

title: TELERATE GIRDS FOR CHALLENGE
description: Telerate Inc., the dominant provider of electronic financial information in the United States, has 350 sources in the banking and securities community feeding it information on trades as they occur, which may involve as many as 500,000 price updates a day. It has 8,000 viewing terminals on the desktops of financial institutions in the United States, including all 100 of the country's largest banks and 46 of the 50 biggest securities companies.

title: MUSIC: ORPHEUS PLAYS MOZART AND DVORAK
description: ORPHEUS, New York's conductorless chamber orchestra, warmed a large crowd at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night with a comfortable evening of music. There was one tentative foray into the 20th century - Stravinsky's ''Eight Instrumental Miniatures'' - but the rest of the program moved through the familiar worlds of the 18th and 19th centuries.

title: URUGUAYAN PUBLIC DISCONTENT SPURS CRACKDOWN ON DISSENT
description: The Government of Gen. Gregorio Alvarez, faced with growing public discontent after more than 10 years of military rule, has reimposed a crackdown on political dissent.

title: Cameroon Leader Re-elected By 99.98% of Nation's Voters
description: President Paul Biya was returned to office for five years by winning 99.98 percent of the vote in Saturday's election, the Interior Ministry announced today.

title: SONGWRITERS EXPRESS COPYRIGHT LAW CONCERNS
description: Many of America's leading songwriters joined forces with Tony Bennett, Peggy Lee, Cab Calloway and other well-known performers in the program ''We Write the Songs! A Celebration of the American Songwriter'' at the Palace Theater last night.

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS PREDICT SUCCESS WITH U.S. AID
description: Leaders of guerrillas fighting the Nicaraguan Government said in interviews over the weekend that with the help of continued aid from the United States, they can bring down the Government in 1984.

title: Bridge: Tristate Men's Team Title Is Retained by Jim Becker
description: Successful defense of a regional team title is rather rare. The feat was achieved last Thursday in the Tristate Regionals in Port Chester, N.Y., and in a manner that may be unique.

title: Morgan Guaranty Will End Survey
description: After almost 63 years, The Morgan Guaranty Survey, one of the nation's most erudite economic monthlies, will halt publication with the January issue, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has announced.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Mercantile Stores Co. is offering $50 million of its 12.50 percent sinking fund debentures due 2014 at 99.68 percent, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: OPERA: CAST CHANGES IN MET'S 'MAHAGONNY'
description: THE current run of Kurt Weill's ''Mahagonny'' continued Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera but this time with two major changes in the cast. Patricia Craig appeared as Jenny and William Lewis as Jimmy Mahoney.

title: MCENROE OVERCOMES LENDL IN FINAL BY 6-3, 6-4, 6-4
description: John McEnroe put on a tennis clinic at Ivan Lendl's expense yesterday, reversing the outcome of last year's Volvo Masters final with a commanding 6-3, 6-4, 6-4 victory.

title: ON ALIENS, PHYSICIANS AND 'DUKE'
description: Nearly 450,000 aliens were arrested last year in a single county, San Diego, as they tried illegally to enter the United States, the Border Patrol reported.

title: Afghans Said to Break Rebel Siege of a Town
description: The Soviet-backed Afghan Army has broken through a guerrilla blockade of the strategic eastern town of Urgun, sending in its first convoy by land since last summer, guerrilla sources said today.

title: Couple Are MissingIn Boston Explosion
description: An explosion rocked a four-story brick apartment building in this Boston suburb tonight, causing the rear walls to collapse and triggering a roaring fire that forced some residents to jump from their windows, the authorities said. Two people were missing, and two women were taken to the hospital.

title: FIRING ON MARINES SETS OFF SHELLING BY U.S. BATTLESHIP
description: The battleship New Jersey shelled rocket and mortar positions in the hills east of Beirut today after United States Marines came under heavy fire and a Marine Corps fuel depot was set ablaze.

title: N.C. State Loses To Georgia Tech
description: John Salley scored 6 points during a 14-2 run early in the second half as Georgia Tech downed North Carolina State, 56-47, today.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A player in a National Basketball Association game has control of the ball near the end line. Trapped, he passes the ball behind the backboard to a teammate. The ball does not touch the support, but is the pass legal?

title: PETER A. BATOR
description: Peter A. Bator, a senior partner in the New York City law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, died of heart failure Friday at his apartment in Manhattan.

title: ZHAO'S WIT PROVES TO BE A MATCH FOR MAYOR
description: Zhao Ziyang held his Tiffany's crystal seal of New York aloft, showing the assembled crowd his latest American gift.

title: COMMODORE EXECUTIVE RIFT DENIED
description: The chairman of Commodore International Ltd. denied yesterday that a dispute with directors had led to the unexpected resignation late Friday of Jack Tramiel, Commodore's hard- driving and mercurial founder.

title: WAGE LAG IS FOUND FOR WHITE WOMEN
description: A new study of census data shows that the wages of white women entering the job market were further behind the wages of comparable white men in 1980 than they were in 1970, despite the growth of affirmative action and education gains by women.

title: REDSDKINS TO USE A VARIED ATTACK
description: To win Super Bowl XVIII the Washington Redskins will have to be innovative in their offensive game plan and work hard in their defensive schemes to protect a vulnerable secondary. Against the Los Angeles Raiders they will need more than their considerable reputation and their excellent record.

title: Bucks 106, Celtics 87
description: Marques Johnson scored 24 points and Milwaukee held Larry Bird to 8 in ending Boston's six-game winning streak.

title: SHEARSON PICKS MANHATTAN SITE FOR NEW CENTER
description: The Shearson/American Express Inc. has decided to build a $500 million computer complex and office tower in Manhattan instead of in Jersey City, according to city and company officials.

title: CHINESE REPORTERS THWARTED IN TRYING TO COVER THEIR MAN
description: For the Chinese journalists following Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang, this has been a trying trip. They often look bewildered, both by their more aggressive American counterparts and by the maze of security precautions. Worst of all, they can't get near Mr. Zhao.

title: Required Reading On Presidents
description: If CBS were to run a computer composite of the last five Presidents of the United States - Ronald Reagan, Jimmy Carter, Gerald Ford, Richard Nixon, Lyndon Johnson - the resulting image would appear no more frightening than your average neighborhood used car salesman.

title: A Real Estate Broker Is Slain In His Apartment in 'Village'
description: A 46-year-old real-estate broker was found stabbed to death last night in his Greenwich Village apartment, the police said.

title: PRO-SOVIET COMMUNISTS IN SPAIN BREAK FORMALLY WITH MAIN PARTY
description: A faction of Spanish Communists opposed to Eurocommunism and determined to return to a more rigorous pro-Soviet policy formally established a new party today.

title: STATE'S BUDGET DIVISION: POWER AND CONTROVERSY
description: The State Division of the Budget occupies much of the marbled ground floor of the Capitol, beneath the Governor's office and the Legislature's chambers, and in many ways it occupies the ground floor of state government as well.

title: CITY RADIATION EXPERT QUITS IN DISPUTE OVER ROCKEFELLER U. WASTES
description: New York City's private adviser on radiation has quit over a refusal by the city's Department of Health to allow the Rockefeller University to burn low- level radioactive waste on campus.

title: A HIGH U.S. OFFICIAL SUGGESTS COMPROMISE ON SALVADOR AID
description: A senior Government official said today that the Administration did not want Congress to produce an ''all or nothing'' situation on military aid to El Salvador in which American aid would have to be cut off completely if the Salvadoran Government did not make sufficient progress on human rights.

title: REAGAN TO ASK MOSCOW TO HELP END ARMS RACE
description: President Reagan, shifting away from previous sharp attacks on the Soviet Union, will ask Moscow on Monday to ''direct attention to our common interests'' in curbing the arms race, a senior White House official disclosed today.

title: Kashmir Police Break Up Second Day of Protests
description: Policemen swung nightsticks to break up crowds of stone-throwing workers today, the second day of protests in northern Kashmir State by members of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party.

title: Illinois Utility Is Optimistic Officials of the Commonwealth Edison Company expect the Government's denial of a license to operate its nearly completed $3.95 billion nuclear power plant to be short-lived, according to a spokesman for the Chicago utility. As a result, he said, Commonwealth Edison expects the long- term cost to the company to be negligible.
description: The denial of the permit, the first unconditional refusal made by the Government, was announced last Friday by the Licensing Board of the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The board said it has ''no confidence'' in the twin reactors being installed at the Byron Nuclear Power Station near Rockford, Ill.

title: FISHERMEN IN U.S. ANGERED BY CANADA
description: Canada, in effect, nationalized its East Coast fisheries in December. And the threat of an enormous, Government-subsidized company dumping cheap fish on United States markets is raising the hackles of American East Coast fishermen, Congress and Federal regulators.

title: ISLES' GORING BACK IN SPOTLIGHT AGAIN
description: His job wasn't always this clear, this specialized. When Butch Goring joined the Islanders in 1980, he was called upon to do a variety of things.

title: MAHAFFEY TRIUMPHS IN PLAYOFF
description: John Mahaffey blasted out of a bunker and dropped a 10-foot par putt on the second hole of a playoff against Jim Simons today to win the 25th annual Bob Hope Classic, his first PGA Tour victory in two and a half years.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: 2 Executives Promoted At Flowers Industries Flowers Industries, a specialty food company that has grown large since its beginnings in Thomasville, Ga., has promoted two executives: Amos R. McMullian and Frederick E. Cooper.

title: NICKEL RISE IN GAS TAX SWELLS ROAD PROJECTS
description: Congress gave state highway officials a Christmas bonanza a year ago, increasing the Federal gasoline tax a nickel and producing almost $5 billion in new road funds. But where did all the nickels go?

title: MAURICE BELLONTE, FAMOUS FLIER, DIES
description: Maurice Bellonte, who was the navigator and radio operator on the first nonstop trans-Atlantic airplane flight from Paris to New York, died Saturday at his home in Paris. He was 87 years old.

title: ON PAYING FOR A PSYCHOTHERAPIST'S SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Shelley M. Greenwald Weds Fellow Lawyer
description: Shelley M. Greenwald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Greenwald of Glen Rock, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Lawrence B. Saftler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Saftler of Lido Beach, L.I. Rabbi Hyman Krantz performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: F.D.I.C. LIMIT WEIGHED ON BROKERAGE DEPOSITS
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation plans to decide today whether to limit its insurance of accounts that brokerage firms set up for investors at banks and savings institutions, a spokesman said today. The F.D.I.C. staff has recommended the change.

title: CANADA, AWAITING ZHAO, RECALLS WARM FRIENDSHIP
description: On a quiet street in this tidy, conservative village of 8,000 is a yellow gingerbread parsonage that stands as a symbol of how differently Canada and the United States have dealt with China.

title: Dividend Meetings for Monday's paper/McCue/Fin News
description: Dividend Meetings

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Revolt in Carolina

title: GRETZKY'S 3 ASSISTS AID OILERS' VICTORY
description: Wayne Gretzky's presence was overshadowed here tonight by some third-period heroics of the Devils, who treated a sellout crowd of 19,023 to excitement before losing, 5-4.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Carter, Ford TV Vote Spots Two former Presidents,

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MAKING BELIEVE A couple living in squalor in the Bronx dress up, pretending they are rich vacationers in Paris, in Pedro Pietri's ''Masses Are Asses,'' now in previews at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater's 47th Street Playhouse, 304 West 47th Street.

title: 'Don Carlo' From the Met
description: Verdi's ''Don Carlo'' will be broadcast on Channel 13 on Feb. 1 at 8 P.M. as part of the ''Live from the Met'' series. Videotaped in a live performance last March 26, the cast includes Mirella Freni as Elizabeth, Grace Bumbry as Eboli, Placido Domingo as Don Carlo, Louis Quilico as Rodrigro, Nicolai Ghiaurov as Philip II and Ferruccio Furlanetto as the Grand Inquisitor. James Levine conducts.

title: JAPAN PBX MARKET CRACKED BY ROLM
description: The Rolm Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., hascracked the high-technology end of the Japanese telecommunications market, breaking into an arena traditionally reserved for a handful of Japan's biggest and most influential companies.

title: Networks Will Carry Address by President
description: President Reagan's address will be broadcast live at 10 A.M. New York time on the CBS, NBC and ABC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network. In addition, some local affiliates of PBS may carry the half-hour talk, either live or as a taped delayed broadcast.

title: FORMAT SHOWED POLITICS CAN BE GOOD TELEVISION
description: In three hours of debate that turned from serious to spontaneous, biting, funny and at times impassioned, the eight major Democratic candidates for President proved today that politics need not be dull and can, in fact, be good television.

title: BRIGHT SPOT FOR U.S. IN NORDIC SKIING
description: Olympic champions in Nordic skiing do not have names like Smith or Jones or Brown or Black. The names, as they were here in 1980, are more like Wassberg and Zimyatov and Wehling and Innauer and Tormanen. Nordic skiing was invented by Scandinavians and refined by Finns and Russians and East Germans. But at next month's Winter Olympics in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, the tide may turn, at least for the two days it takes to run the Nordic combined.

title: Archless McDonald's Is Set for Maine Town
description: A McDonald's restaurant is scheduled to be operating in the historic Gore House here by the end of the year, but it will not be graced by one of the company's golden arches.

title: MANY E.E.C. ROLES IN STEEL DISPUTE
description: Economic Analysis

title: 4 Fatal Coal Mine Accidents Occur in 9 Days in Kentucky
description: Four coal miners died in separate accidents in Kentucky in a nine-day period, including one Friday, indicating ''a careless trend'' in the industry, a state official says.

title: PAUL NEWMAN GIVES $20,000 TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: The actor Paul Newman has given $20,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund from profits realized from his food company, Newman's Own Inc., of Westport, Conn., a maker of spaghetti sauce.

title: Craig Virgin Wins Central Park Run
description: Craig Virgin, two-time international cross-country champion, captured the New York Roadrunner's Club winter series 6-mile run in 29 minutes 16 seconds yesterday morning over a slippery course in Central Park.

title: TINY ROOM: GRANDEUR FOR A CAUSE
description: Eugene Kupjack's exquisite miniature rooms can be found in many museums, including the Chicago Art Institute.

title: THE VOTERS AND THE ARMS RACE
description: Senato r Alan Cranston has been developing what may prove to be the most galvanizing idea of the Presidential campaign - that the Democratic Party should get behind a self-enforcing U.S. initiative to stop the testing and deployment of nuclear weapons.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SHADOWS OF THE RISING SUN. By Jared Taylor. 336 pages. William Morrow & Company. $14.95.

title: Things Booming for Mancini
description: The boom times are back for Ray Mancini. For Bobby Chacon, it may be time to retire.

title: WOMEN DIRECTING MORE PLAYS BUT BROADWAY IS STILL ELUSIVE
description: THERE was an American play about aging children of the counterculture, and there was a Chekhov. There was a cycle of one-woman plays about male domination of women, and there was Shakespeare. There was a play about the dehumanizing effects of totalitarianism by a dissident Czechoslovak playwright, and there was an acid domestic comedy about a Lancashire family leading desolate lives.

title: MERLE ROBBINS
description: Merle Robbins, who invented the popular card game Uno with several family members, died at the Good Samaritan Hospital Saturday.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Truffles, Oil and Experts
description: Truffles, those rare subterranean delicacies, are sniffed out by pigs specially trained to recognize their subtle aroma. Equally delicious is the political scandal now entertaining France. The affair of the

title: MONDAY, JANUARY 16, 1984 International
description: A U.S. battleship off Beirut shelled rocket and mortar positions in the hills east of Beirut after United States Marines were fired on and a Marine fuel depot was set afire. The U.S.S. New Jersey was joined in the countertattack by the destroyer U.S.S. Tattnall, a Marine spokesman said. Civilians at Beirut International Airport, where the marines are based, said that rockets, mortars and fire from antiaircraft guns came from hills occupied by Druse militiamen. (Page A1, Column 6.) Uruguay has reimposed a crackdown on political dissent. After more than 10 years of military rule, the Government of Gen. Gregorio Alvarez is facing growing public discontent. The crackdown and other developments could cause postponement of elections scheduled this year. (A1:3.)

title: CUOMO SAYS FUNDS WILL BE RESTORED AT FOUR AGENCIES
description: Governor Cuomo said today that his new budget will include increases in spending at four major agencies that were hit hard by cuts last year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We don't want to crow or make anyone else eat crow, but we're glad we won. I've always said New Jersey is a nice place to visit, but. . . .'' - Mayor Koch. (A1:5.)

title: ALLEN IS RUNNING TO FORM AGAIN
description: LOS ANGELES C ENTER STREET had not seen this much activity since El Segundo Junior High School locked its doors and shut down in 1979. The inhabitants of the building became larger when the Los Angeles Raiders made the school their training facility this season. Late last week, the crowds had also grown.

title: OUR LEARNED JUDGES WITHOUT LAW DEGREE
description: To the Editor:

title: Tsongas Says He Has Mild Case of Lymphoma
description: Senator Paul Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts, said in an interview today that the illness prompting his decision to leave office is a mild form of cancer of the lymph nodes.

title: Barbara M. Edelson Is Wed To Dr. James Andrew Roth
description: At B'nai Israel Congregation in Pittsburgh yesterday, Barbara Mae Edeson, a speech and language pathologist, was married to Dr. James Andrew Roth, an internist in practice in Valhalla, N.Y. Rabbi Richard Marcovitz, assisted by Rabbi Morris Landes, performed the ceremony.

title: France Will Honor U.S. Choreographer
description: Alwin Nikolais, the American choreographer, composer and designer, will be made a Chevalier of the Legion of Honor by the French Government Thursday.

title: RAIDERS SCOUTING REPORT ; RAIDERS KEEP THINGS SIMPLE
description: In an era of specialized players, the Los Angeles Raiders are a throwback to the past. They change their lineup the least of any team, and their message is that they expect to win with the same people regardless of down- and-yardage situations.

title: DUMP AGREEMENT PART OF MAJOR EFFORT
description: A settlement announced last week on the cleanup of a toxic dump site in Niagara Falls, N.Y., is one part of a major environmental effort that will continue for years, according to state and local officials.

title: U.S. AND BRITAIN BAR CONCESSIONS TO MOSCOW ON ARMS
description: The United States and Britain agreed today not to offer any concessions to persuade the Russians to resume negotiations on arms control, American and British officials said.

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: President Reagan begins a busy week with a major foreign policy address this morning on the state of American-Soviet relations. His speech, to a White House gathering of present and former Government officials, is expected to be of a conciliatory nature in an effort to open the way for arms control negotiations between the two countries. Later in the morning, Mr. Reagan meets with members of his Private Sector Survey on Cost Control to discuss the panel's findings, made public last week, on ways to trim Federal Government costs by $424 billion over three years.

title: SAN DIEGO'S MAYOR SEEN LIKELY TO BE RE-ELECTED
description: After seven months as Mayor of San Diego, Roger Hedgecock has built his popularity here to the point that some observers of both parties call him a sure bet for election this year to a full four-year term.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: On Call

title: WHEN IN DOUBT, NAME A COMMISSION
description: After assessing the work of President Reagan's commission on Central America last week, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale couldn't resist a jab at Mr. Reagan for creating the commission in the first place.

title: Futures/OptionsH. J. Maidenberg Bid on Settling Of Gold in Cash
description: P EOPLE who invest or trade gold have claimed they prefer the metal to paper stores of value such as securities, money market and other financial instruments or cash. Nor has the fact that the value of gold has dropped $30 an ounce, to $371, since the latest decline began late last September changed their attitude toward the metal.

title: WHY U.S. AID TO ZIMBABWE WAS REDUCED
description: To the Editor:

title: CLARENCE V. BECK
description: Clarence V. Beck, who served two terms as the Kansas Attorney General in the 1930's, died Saturday. He was 87 years old. Mr. Beck practiced law in Emporia, Kan., 40 years before moving to Raleigh in 1970.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Cleary Law Partner Joining A.G. Becker

title: DISCIPLINE AN ERRANT PROSECUTOR
description: The American Bar Association acknowledges that a prosecutor is a ''minister of justice'' whose obligation is ''to seek justice, not merely to convict.'' It is time for the A.B.A. to turn such shibboleths into specific rules of conduct, and for the bar to enforce them against prosecutors who violate their public trust and professional responsibilities with impunity.

title: FED'S ROLE IN BANKING NEGOTIATED
description: The Federal Reserve appears ready to give up some of its supervisory powers over commercial banks as part of a plan to consolidate bank regulation in a new entity called the Federal Banking Agency.

title: GOING UNRECOGNIZED IS FINE WITH HEIDEN
description: H E was on Madison Avenue at 53d Street trying to track down a cab one day last week. A young man, 25 years old, about 6 feet 1 inch tall, broad shoulders, long brown hair, red flannel shirt, faded blue jeans hugging thick thighs, sneakers, winter jacket under his arm and a back pack slung over his shoulder. He looked like a college student, and he is. He is also one of the most famous athletes in the world; the only person to win five individual gold medals in one Olympic Games.

title: Cosmos Defeat Whitecaps, 6-5
description: Chico Vorja scored on a rebound at 2:10 of overtime today to lift the Cosmos to a 6-5 victory over the Vancouver Whitecaps.

title: CITY WILL OPEN OFFICE ON COAST FOR TAX AUDITS
description: The long arm of the New York City Finance Department will soon reach California, with the opening of a Los Angeles office to audit the tax returns of West Coast concerns that do business here.

title: Polish Primate to See Pope
description: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, will visit Rome Monday for talks with Pope John Paul II, an aide said today. He is expected to discuss efforts by Polish church authorities to persuade the Communist Government to release political prisoners held since the dissolution of the Solidarity trade union. Cardinal Glemp met with Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski earlier this month to discuss this issue along with difficulties in church-state relations.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Engine Company 47 As Learning Laboratory

title: SHORT-TERM U.S. BILLS SET THIS WEEK
description: New Treasury financings this week are confined to sales of short-term bills today and Thursday. Government securities dealers expect the Treasury to announce during the week an $8.25 billion issue of two-year notes to be auctioned next week.

title: South African Troops Pull Out of Angola
description: South African troops completed a pullout from Angola today after a five-week foray, a military spokesman said.

title: How to End Freeloading on the Phone
description: ''I don't think anyone wants to vote for higher telephone rates,'' says one Senate staffer. That explains why so few members of Congress oppose a bill that would block ''access charges'' for residential telephones.

title: Suit on Police Spying May Be Near Settlement
description: The City Council has agreed in principle to the American Civil Liberties Union's offer to settle a suit charging illegal police spying, a case that was scheduled to go to trial this week, a councilman has confirmed.

title: Israeli Inflation 190.7%
description: Israel's inflation rate in 1983 was a record 190.7 percent, the Government announced in Jerusalem tonight. David Neuman, a spokesman for the Central Bureau of Statistics, said the consumer price index rose 11.6 percent last month from the November level. The state treasury said inflation would be gradually tamed after the $5.1 billion deficit in Israel's international balance of payments is reduced by restricting public spending, domestic credits and disposable incomes.

title: TV: 'A MATTER OF SEX,' STORY OF A BANK STRIKE
description: ''AMATTER OF SEX,'' the prologue says, is ''based on a true event'' - a strike by eight women employees of a small bank in Willmar, Minn. The strike lasted from Dec. 16, 1977, until March 23, 1979, and ended in something like a Pyrrhic victory for the strikers: Honor was saved; jobs and back pay were lost. ''A Matter of Sex,'' a terrible title for this, will be seen on NBC at 9 P.M. tonight.

title: PERSONAL HOMILY ON LOVE AND LOSS
description: At the All Souls Unitarian Church on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, worshipers have often heard the minister speak about the fragile nature of human life. But in yesterday's sermon, words like life and death took on special meaning.

title: PANEL DETAILS 'ABUSIVE CONDITIONS' IN CALIFORNIA CARE FACILITIES
description: A state commission, reporting on a nine- month inquiry, has found ''abusive, unhealthful, unsafe and uncaring conditions'' in California community care facilities that house the elderly, the mentally ill and the physically disabled.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about video games misstated the wholesale price of Coleco's Adam home computer system. It is $650.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Barringer Resources Inc., Denver, a high technology company, has appointed Anthony R. Barringer chairman and chief executive officer and Gary M. Cook president and chief operating officer.

title: 3 Thai Children Killed By Erring Policeman
description: A Thai policeman performing a shooting exhibition at a school to celebrate National Children's Day accidentally fired his rifle into a crowded grandstand, killing 3 children and wounding 17, the police said today.

title: Lawsuit Settled Over Legal Books
description: A lawsuit in which a retired professor at Brooklyn Law School charged the dean of the St. John's University School of Law with stealing credit from him for legal writings has ended with an ''amicable resolution,'' both men said yesterday.

title: Henderson Is 'Broke'
description: Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson , the former Dallas Cowboy linebacker, who is facing felony charges of assaulting two teen-age girls, is offering to sell his three Super Bowl rings to raise money for his legal defense. He says he is broke.

title: NEW HAVEN DIVIDED ON OFFICIAL'S DRUG ADDICTION
description: Maurice Sykes has been a source of pride for many of his neighbors in the lowincome Newhallville section of New Haven. He was a star athlete at the local high school, Hillhouse, and then at Dodge City College in Kansas.

title: Charlotte Curtis The Man From Macy's chairman and chief executive officer of R.H. Macy's 126-year-old retailing empire, has been upgrading stores, divisions and profits so successfully over the years that competitors and analysts alike regard it as the industry's outstanding performer. The restored New York Macy's, despite its age, its unfashionable location and its decades-old bargain-basement image, has become the city's newest ''exciting'' department store, a place to shop for caviar and furs as well as kitchenware. And in the process, Mr. Finkelstein has been granted celebrity status, and that troubles him.
description: ''I worry about the cult of personality,'' he said. ''Mostly it's a bunch of baloney. I'm not speaking with false modesty. I made a contribution to the turnaround of the business. But I had a lot of things going for me and lots of talented people.''

title: Chess: Issues Are Still Being Settled On Poisoned Pawn Variation
description: Three decades of the poisoned pawn variation of the Najdorf Sicilian have not dampened the ardor either of those who believe that the misplaced black queen and White's lead in development should produce a winning attack or of those who believe that Black's solid pawn structure should prove an impenetrable barrier.

title: SECURITY NEW YORK STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GENERAL HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BLACK WOMEN'S GAINS PRESENT POLITICAL PUZZLE
description: Maxine Waters still remembers the meeting six years ago at which the small cluster of black and white female activists broached what many in politics regard as a puzzle: why black women seem more involved and more successful than white women in politics.

title: BANKERS TRUST OF SOUTH CAROLINA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year nets include gain of $45.8 million from the sale of a mortgage subsidiary on Dec. 31.

title: Dr. King's Birthday Is Hailed ; Dr. King Holiday Held 'Holy Day' by Jackson
description: More than 3,000 people jammed a church today to hear the Rev. Jesse Jackson proclaim the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King's birthday a ''holy day,'' while Coretta Scott King remembered her husband as a fighter for peace and love.

title: ROZIER'S AGENT IS DISMISSED
description: Mike Trope has been dismissed as Mike Rozier's agent, less than two weeks after negotiating a $3 million, three-year deal for the Heisman Trophy running back from Nebraska. But Trope, who was dismissed by Rozier's family, will keep the $300,000 fee he received for making the deal with the Pittsburgh Maulers, a new team in the United States Football League.

title: Eritreans Claim Victory
description: The Eritrean People's Liberation Front, an insurgent group, said here today that guerrillas fighting the Ethiopian Government had captured Teseney, near the Sudanese border, 150 mileswest of Asmara.

title: MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected March 14, 1983.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Allied Corp., an oil and chemical company, said its 125-million-mark (nearly $45 million) issue of 7 1/2 percent Eurobonds due in 1994 was priced at par, through Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb.

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF ; Katsurako Mikami In Piano Recital
description: Katsurako Mikami is a winning pianist, one who combines polished technical skill and a bejeweled tone with forceful, but gracefully executed, ideas about the music she plays.

title: A SPLIT OVER BROKER INSURANCE CURB
description: Federal regulators, in a move to reduce the losses of the two Federal deposit insurance funds, voted tentatively today to limit the availability of insurance on deposits placed by brokers, but ran into unexpected - and potentially fatal - opposition from the Treasury Department.

title: Farm Workers in Ohio Win $180,000 Settlement
description: Putnam County officials and a union of migrant farm workers reached an out-of- court settlement today of a $2 million civil rights suit that asserted the workers and their union had been harassed.

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income of $26,700,000, or $1.00 a share, from the sale of properties. c-Includes income from the sale of properties of $1,000,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,000,000, or 8 cents a share, for the year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Talks on Lincoln West

title: CHILDREN OF CHINATOWN GET A DAY-CARE CENTER
description: It took a Chinese-language petition signed by 3,000 immigrant seamstresses to get it started, and today it will be opened formally: the Garment Industry Day Care Center of Chinatown.

title: ABC TESTING PAY-TV
description: A new kind of pay-television service offering recent movies such as ''WarGames,'' ''Octopussy'' and ''Risky Business'' - four to seven months before they appear on Home Box Office or other subscription channels - will begin experimentally early tomorrow morning in Chicago.

title: 9.7% Top Yield Set By Arizona Utility A $150 million issue of electric revenue bonds of Arizona's Salt River Project Agricultural Improvement and Power District, rated double-A, was tentatively offered with a maximum yield of 9.7 percent for 9 5/8 percent bonds due in 2023 offered at a price of 99 1/4 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The financing includes serial bonds with yields ranging from 8.7 percent for bonds due in 1995 to 9.5 percent in 2005.
description: Proceeds of the sale will be used to pay for Salt River's share of the Palo Verde nuclear power project. The three plants are scheduled to begin loading fuel on May 1, 1984; Feb. 1, 1985, and May 1, 1986. After completion of the plants, nuclear power is to account for only about 17 percent of the utility's power.

title: FINGERMATRIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-No comparable year-ago revenue figures were given.

title: JOSTENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition, in December 1983, of Metridata Education Systems Inc. which was accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: LAND OF PLENTY'S SCARCITY
description: To the Editor:

title: SIMPLE SEA URCHIN YIELDS CLUES TO LIFE
description: The simple little sea urchin

title: Colt Is Destroyed
description: Billy Ball, a 4-year-old gray colt who earned $159,084 and a faithful fan club in nine career starts, has been destroyed after efforts to save his left leg were unsuccessful.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FLUKE, JOHN, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
DOES EVERYONE NEED TO LEARN PROGRAMMING?
description: ''SHOULD I learn to program?'' and ''Do I have to learn to program?'' are two variants of the question probably most asked by people testing the waters of computer ownership. The answer usually boils down to an emphatic ''that depends . . ., but probably not.''

title: Chase and Hanover Post Gains
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation yesterday reported small increases in net income for the fourth quarter of 1983 from a year earlier, but both said earnings were substantially helped by gains from securities transactions or other special factors.

title: Marines Reclassify 241 Killed In Lebanon as Battle Deaths
description: The Marine Corps, responding to Congressional pressure, has agreed to reclassify servicemen killed in the Oct. 23 bombing in Lebanon as battle casualties instead of accidental deaths.

title: Fed Governor Delay Is Seen
description: The Reagan Administration apparently will not have a replacement ready for Nancy Hays Teeters, a Federal Reserve governor, when her term expires on Jan. 31, a White House spokesman said today. That means Mrs. Teeters, who is known as the board's most liberal member and is the only woman governor in Federal Reserve history, will keep her post at least a while longer.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter net includes a gain of $13.5 million on the sale of the Indiana National Bank's leasehold interest in its headquarters building. Also during the quarter the company sold about $60 million in U.S. Treasury securities which resulted in a loss of $2.4 million.

title: MUSIC: WORKS BY SIEGMEISTER
description: Elie Siegmeister, along with a generation of American composers, went to Paris to study with Nadia Boulanger in the late 1920's. When he returned to these shores four years later, he also had the ambition - like many of his compatriots - of capturing his nationality in his music.

title: TRACKING MONEY SPENT 'IN A LOT OF SMALL PIECES'
description: Tacked to the inside of the door to Joseph H. Sherick's office in the Pentagon is a poster of W. C. Fields looking slyly over cards he holds close to his vest. ''It reminds me,'' Mr. Sherick said, ''of the kind of people I have to deal with.''

title: Bridge:A Close Knockout Match Can Depend on One Deal
description: When a knockout match is close going into the last session of play, a single big swing deal is often decisive. In the Tristate Regional final in Port Chester, N.Y., on Saturday, with one team leading by six international match points, the diagramed deal filled the crucial role.

title: REAGAN SAID TO OPPOSE PANEL ON PARING DEFICITS
description: President Reagan is leaning against setting up a special commission to develop proposals to reduce future budget deficits, Administration officials said today.

title: Mix-Up Disqualifies a Mahre
description: Mark Girardelli of Luxembourg was declared the winner of a World Cup slalom race today after Steve Mahre of Yakima, Wash., who had the fastest total time in the two runs, was disqualified for mistakenly wearing his twin brother's starting number.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAZARE KAPLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: DEEPENING OF NUCLEAR WOES
description: In the last four days the nation's nuclear energy industry has been rocked by what many analysts say are two stunning and potentially destructive precedents.

title: British Storms Kill 22
description: Snow storms in northern Britain have killed at least 22 people in the last five days.

title: REAGAN'S ADDRESS: TRYING A NEW TACTIC
description: News Analysis

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOVIET PRESS AGENCY FINDS NO NEW IDEAS OR PROPOSALS IN PRESIDENT'S SPEECH
description: In the first Soviet reaction to President Reagan's speech, the press agency Tass today dismissed the address as propaganda devoid of new ideas or proposals.

title: No Headline
description: TRAVELING LIGHT. By Bill Barich. 226 pages. Viking. $15.95.

title: Onstage Surprise
description: While on vacation in Los Angeles

title: TEACHERS UP IN ARMS OVER ARKANSAS'S SKILLS TEST
description: Like many state lawmakers, Representative Joseph K. Mahony has always thought of himself as a friend of Arkansas's teachers.

title: CBS, TOO, IS WORKING ON A 'GAME PLAN'
description: Finding compatible producer-director teams

title: JAPANESE VOTERS' RESPONSE TO U.S. PRODDING
description: To the Editor:

title: West Germany Hunts 6 In Reported Kidnapping
description: Military policemen searched today for six antinuclear activists an American soldier said had held him hostage for 43 hours and threatened to kill him before releasing him unharmed.

title: ST. JOHN'S BEATEN BY PITT, 63-61
description: Andre Williams tipped in a missed shot with just over a minute remaining in overtime tonight as Pittsburgh upset St. John's, 63-61, in a Big East Conference game.

title: MusicNoted in Brief
description: Skrowaczewski Leads Y Chamber Symphony

title: France Sells Air Defense Missiles To Saudi Arabia for $4.5 Billion
description: France announced today that it had reached an arms sales agreement of about $4.5 billion to provide Saudi Arabia a mobile system of antiaircraft missiles for the protection of its oilfields and other important ground installations.

title: Caterpillar Closings
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, in a continuing drive to consolidate operations and cut excess plant space, said today that it is considering closing three of its factories in the Middle West.

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF ; Musica Aeterna At Met Museum
description: The concert played by the Musica Aeterna Orchestra, conducted by Frederic Waldman, at the Metropolitan Museum on Saturday night was almost too standard in form - beginning with a novelty, proceeding to the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto and ending with Beethoven's Eighth Symphony. But the playing, while never strikingly original and offering few insights into this overly familiar music, was nonetheless proficient and sensitive.

title: GUIDE IS DESIGNED TO HELP SCIENCE STUDENTS
description: ALL proposals for school reform agree on one point: Science must be given far greater priority. But will students be able to cope with that admittedly tough subject?

title: UNITEL VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
EXCERPTS FROM GOVERNOR CUOMO'S BUDGET MESSAGE TO THE STATE LEGISLATURE
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Cuomo's budget message to the Legislature:

title: NEW YORK ; VITAL SIGNS IN THE BRONX
description: A couple of news stories over the weekend reminded me of the frustrated and sometimes angry letters received here when I wrote a column two years ago about human and housing blight in the South Bronx. The letters, from Bronx residents, said my pessimistic vision was myopic in failing to see the pockets of renewal and could only serve to perpetuate the national image of the South Bronx as a lunar wasteland.

title: SCOUTING
description: Increase in Sales

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF ; Gregg Smith Singers At St. Peter's Church
description: The Gregg Smith Singers offered an agreeable combination of early sacred music and its contemporary counterpart Saturday night at St. Peter's Church in the Citicorp Center.

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
RIGHTS STILL 'CENTRAL PROBLEM' IN SALVADOR, U.S. REPORT SAYS
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the war in El Salvador was at an impasse and that human rights abuses remained ''a central problem'' despite some improvements in recent months.

title: Bonds May Return
description: Bobby Bonds , out of major league baseball since 1981, said that he hopes to make another comeback this spring.

title: SAINT LAURENT FOR MEN: CAR COATS AND LEATHER
description: The showing of Yves Saint Laurent's fall collection for men was everything a fashion show should be. It was beautifully staged in the Astor Hall of the New York Public Library, the runway covered with marblized canvas. The music was buoyant, a sort of French-Moroccan electric punk. Not least, the clothes were memorable, no small achievement considering that most men's fashion shows look like little more than one long gray line of suits.

title: CRAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-ago 6 months loss doesn't reflect approximately $3,700,000 of tax benefits available for carryforward to future periods.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Because their teams had the best records, as of yesterday, in their respective conferences, K. C. Jones of the Boston Celtics will coach the East team and Frank Layden of the surprising Utah Jazz will head the West squad in the 34th National Basketball Association All-Star game Jan. 29 in Denver. . . A three-man review board heard closing arguments yesterday in Guillermo Vilas 's appeal of his one- year suspension. Vilas was charged with accepting an illegal guarantee of $60,000 to play in a Grand Prix tennis tournament in the Netherlands last March.

title: TAMPA SEES GAINS FOR ITS HARD WORK
description: The other day a man telephoned the National Football League's temporary offices here, identified himself as the oldest parachutist in the country at the age of 86, and asked for permission to jump into Tampa Stadium Sunday during Super Bowl XVIII. He also said that as a precaution, he had arranged for Ted Hendricks, the linebacker of the Los Angeles Raiders, to catch him.

title: DESIGNCRAFT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results for the latest quarter include a gain of 13 cents a share compared with a gain of 10 cents a share in the year-ago quarter. Results for the latest 9 months include a gain of 39 cents a share compared with 29 cents a share for the year-ago 9 months.

title: THE DEMOCRATIC DEBATE: REAGAN MAY BE THE CHIEF BENEFICIARY
description: News Analysis

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The income for all of 1982 included a $2.7 million pre-tax, or $1.6 million after-tax, gain on the sale in the third quarter of certain Lockheed Corp. securities.

title: B.P. Starts China Well
description: The British Petroleum Company, the first foreign oil company to drill for oil in China, said today that it had started a second well exploring the Pearl River Basin of the South China Sea. British Petroleum announced a week ago that its first offshore well had struck oil, but that not enough ahd been found to be worth exploiting and the well was abandoned.

title: DISPUTE IN CONGRESS HOLDING UP $5.5 BILLION IN HIGHWAY AID
description: While the higher Federal gasoline tax spurred road construction last year, a dispute in Congress is now blocking the flow of more than $5 billion in new money and stalling Interstate System highway projects approved only last summer.

title: INDEX CAN RATE SCHOOL PERFORMANCE NUMERICALLY
description: WITH a national debate now raging over the quality of American education, high schools in New York City have developed an ''Academic Index'' to measure educational excellence through an objective formula.

title: TECH-OPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $103,000, or 12 cents a share, from the transfer of part of a real estate development.

title: USP REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from the sale of property of $1,725,429 for the quarter and $1,791,476 for the year. c-After a loss of $85,556 from the sale of property. d-Net loss after a loss of $419,759 from the sale of property.

title: FRENCH OFFICAL IS GLOOMY AFTER TALK WITH GROMYKO
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France met today with his Soviet counterpart, Andrei A. Gromyko, to prepare for the East-West conference on European security, which opens here Tuesday. He said he had detected no signs that the Russians would return to nuclear arms talks soon.

title: Grand Union Sets Property Auction ELMWOOD PARK, N.J., Jan. 16 (AP) - The Grand Union Company, a retail grocery chain owned by Generale Occidentale in Paris, said it plans to sell its supermarkets, discount grocery stores and distribution facilities in Florida and suburban Washington so it can ''concentrate resources in stronger market areas.''
description: The properties are to be offered for sale through an auction to be conducted by mail, the company said.

title: Accused Nazi Is Fighting Deportation From U.S.
description: A suburban Cleveland man accused of being the Nazi death camp guard ''Ivan the Terrible'' testified today that he would be executed if he was ordered out of the country.

title: BLUE RIDGE-BIG BOULDER reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago results are restated.

title: GLENN SAYS REAGAN, IF RE-ELECTED, WILL RESHAPE HIGH COURT
description: Senator John Glenn warned today that if President Reagan was re-elected, he would reshape the Supreme Court in his ''far-right political ideology'' and endanger the advances of the civil rights movement.

title: ABRAMS AIDE CASTS DOUBT ON LEGALITY OF BETTING PLAN
description: Governor Cuomo's plan for a form of sports betting will ''very likely'' require an amendment to the State Constitution, a spokesman for the State Attorney General said today.

title: 2 UNIT TRUSTS OFFERED FOR EXXON AND G.M.
description: A new investment vehicle, tried previously with only limited success, is now being offered to the holders of Exxon and General Motors stock. The Americus Shareowner Service Corporation said yesterday that it has filed, with the Securities and Exchange Commission, proposals to establish two unit trusts, one for Exxon Corporation shares and one for shares of the General Motors Corporation.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Fall in Waste Concern Stock
description: I N the first week of January, shares of Waste

title: AD ANGENCY STOCK: NEW IMAGE
description: They are the consummate image- makers. From soap flakes to Presidential candidates, advertising agencies have sold it all, with ever-increasing sophistication. Yet until lately, Madison Avenue had an image problem on Wall Street.

title: Adopted Youth Is Facing Charges
description: A teen-ager was charged with felony theft today for having reportedly taken a car and a gun from a former New York City policeman who adopted the youth after talking him out of jumping from a roof.

title: Expos Ponder Signing Rose
description: Pete Rose's chances of prolonging his 21-year career apparently rested yesterday with

title: FACING SECOND TRIAL
description: Attorneys for Lenell Geter, a young black engineer given a life sentence in a 1982 armed robbery, said today that he would not take a prosecution lie detector test and would face a second trial in April.

title: Exiled Ex-Premier of Grenada To Return Home, Aide Says
description: The exiled former Prime Minister, Sir Eric Gairy, plans to return to Grenada on Saturday for the first time since he was deposed nearly five years ago, an aide said today.

title: Radioactive Well Is Found and Shut
description: This Bergen County borough has closed a well because of radioactive contamination, and state environmental officials are testing ground water.

title: UNR Sues U.S. on Asbestos UNR Industries, which in July 1982 became the first company pushed into bankruptcy proceedings by the rapidly rising cost of asbestos-related lawsuits, filed a $100 million suit yesterday against the Federal Government, charging that it should bear the cost of thousands of asbestos claims by people who worked in shipyards during World War II.
description: UNR's suit, filed in the United States Claims Court, argues that the Government asked UNR to develop Government asked UNR to develop and produce asbestos insulation products, actively participated in the development of the products - in some cases even supplying the raw asbestos - and had full responsibility for the shipyards' working conditions.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Meaning's the Same

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The earnings per share were affected by dividends on preferred stock issued by the company since last year's fourth quarter.

title: MORTON THIOKOL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Companies
description: The Marble Hill nuclear plant is being abandoned because of a huge rise in costs, Public Service of Indiana announced. The half- completed project, on which $2.5 billion has already been spent, is the costliest ever dropped. (Page A1.) The abandonment of Marble Hill, together with Friday's denial of an operating license to the Byron plant near Rockford, Ill., has stunned the nuclear energy industry. (D1.) Many other nuclear power plant projects around the country are in trouble as well. (D17.)

title: THEATER: 'TARPITS,' WITH PETER RIEGERT
description: By all rights, Peter Riegert should be an irritating actor. With his diffident, vaguely pugnacious manner and jittery, whiny diction, he seems to be the soul of brashness: He comes on like a used-car salesman who makes a sport of unloading lemons. But even as we are busy being put off by Mr. Riegert, he is surreptitiously winning us over.

title: Talking Businesswith Brian Freeman, financial adviser The Workers' Bid for Conrail The prospects for the Dep will have to wait and see what these railroads propose. However, I would not envision purchase by either of them because that would be counter to the interest of the public, rail service in the Northeast and the employees. The whole purpose of the Government investing $7 billion since 1976 was to maximize service. Acquisition by either of the railroads would result in a substantial reduction in service, competition and employment because of substantial overlap between Conrail and the other railroads.
description: Q. Some Transportation Department officials have said the unions' offer was not good

title: THE HOMELESS PROMPT GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: ''The neediest of the needy, it seems to me on these bitter cold nights, are people who lack warm, safe shelter,'' Ruth H. Zinn of Plainview, L.I., said in a note accompanying a $25 donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: ON THE SIDEWALKS OF ATHENS, BATTLE OF THE BOOTHS

It is also seriously deficient in its sense of political reality.

Proceeds of the bonds, rated A-1/Ax, will be used to construct power lines between coal-fired power plants in central Utah and southern Californa municipalities that have agreed to buy the power.

title: Dr. Earl L. Muetterties, Chemist, Is Dead at 56

Although the region is now a part of the Soviet Union, its music is related to Persian and Turkish music, and the songs had lyrics in Uzbek, a Turkish dialect, and Tadzhik, an Iranian dialect.

title: TREATING MENTALLY ILL: TRIESTE'S LESSON

title: Guerrillas in Salvador Attack Vital Bridge
description: Guerrillas attacked a strategic railroad bridge for the second time in three days today as part of a possible attempt to split the country into two, military sources said. They said a seven-hour firefight between rebels and United States-trained troops of the Atonal Battalion and local ''hunter'' battalions ended before dawn.

title: G.E. UP 10.5% IN 4TH QUARTER
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter rose to a record $579 million, or $1.27 a share, up 10.5 percent from earnings of $524 million, or $1.15 a share, a year earlier.

title: THE DANCE: 'PROJECTS'
description: RUBY Shang's new ''Vernacular Projects,'' performed on Friday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Sch"onberg Theater, calls to mind the imaginary monuments of Claes Oldenburg, wittily celebratory and obstructive of their sites. Miss Shang envisions dances that spring out of the peculiar characteristics of such landscapes as the discrete little islands of the Swedish Archipelago, the hilly roads of Emmental, Switzerland, and the sprawl of Duke University's East Campus, as well as the architecture of Cooper Union and the bustling whole of New York City.

title: JUSTICESS BAR A.T. &. T. APPEAL

title: Murdoch Raises New F.C.C. Issue WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) - Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher, has told the Federal Communications Commission that Warner Communications Inc. and Chris-Craft Industries cannot complete their deal without the approval of local officials in California and Oregon, or the companies would violate F.C.C. rules barring ownership of cable systems and TV stations serving the same area.
description: Warner and Chris-Craft announced Dec. 29 that they had reached agreement on a deal that would give Warner a 42.5 percent stake in Chris- Craft's television subsidiary, BHC Inc., while Chris-Craft would acquire 19 percent of Warner. Mr. Murdoch has said he wants to buy up to 49.9 percent of Warner's stock.

The opaque style matched a bare-shouldered halter-neck dress with a low back that could be worn for cocktails or dinner during the hot summer months and into September.

title: Kaiser Meeting Is Subject of Suit FONTANA, Calif., Jan. 16 (Reuters) - The Kaiser Steel Corporation said two of its stockholders had applied for a temporary restraining order to prevent it from holding a shareholder meeting on Wednesday and from voting on or consummating a merger agreement with a group led by J. A. Frates, an Oklahoma investor. The application was filed by the Pearl Brewing Company and the Falstaff Brewing Company, which together own about 5 percent of Kaiser. It said the court for the Central District of California would hear the application on Tuesday in Los Angeles.
description: Kaiser also said a Nevada district court had denied an application by a Brazilian mining company, Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, seeking $67 million in damages against Kaiser for breach of a contract to buy iron ore pellets.

description: Ten months ago President Reagan delivered to the National Association of Evangelicals what Henry Steele Commager, the historian, described as ''The worst Presidential speech in American history.'' Better dead than Red, the President implied, as he denounced ''the aggressive impulses of an evil empire.''

title: TUESDAY, JANUARY 17, 1984 International
description: The United States so far has failed to work out a political settlement in Lebanon with Syria, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said. At a news conference in London, Mr. Shultz said, ''As of now, it is not possible to report any real progress,'' despite the talks that Donald Rumsfeld, the United States special envoy, held last week with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria. (Page A1, Column 6.) The economic and military growth of the United States in the last three years has been so strong that it ''can now offer something in return'' for any concessions the Soviet Union might offer in nuclear arms talks, President Reagan said. He called on the Russians to return to the negotiating table and join him in a ''constructive working relationship.'' (A1:5.)

A LEAGUE WONDERS IF IT IS AT ITS PEAK
description: The answers to the questions raised this season about whether there has been a decline in the popularity of the National Football League probably will not be known for at least another year and perhaps two or three, according to advertising and television executives. But when Commissioner Pete Rozelle gives his annual state of the N.F.L. address Friday in Tampa, his assessment, in part, will be based on his ability to predict the future and provide those answers now.

description: Governor Cuomo today proposed a $35.3 billion state budget that calls for nearly 10 percent more spending, with much of the increase to be made possible by revenue from an improving economy.

title: Equal Rights for Infants
description: America's infant mortality rate has declined since 1977 from 14.1 to 11.2 per 1,000 live births. For the nine months of 1983 so far reported, it was 10.7. But there are parts of this country in which a baby has less chance of living to his first birthday than one born in Trinidad, the Soviet Union or Guyana. There are neighborhoods in New York City where the infant mortality rate is 24. What these places have in common is poverty, and the inadequate prenatal care and poor nutrition that go with it.

description: Mr. Day spent 26 years with Chrysler, most recently as executive vice- president, corporate staff and international. But Ken Page, the pop-soul belter whose Broadway roles have varied from Fats Waller to the staid operatic Old Deuteronomy in the Broadway production of ''Cats,'' has the versatility it takes to make the leap.
