title: Youth, 18, Is Shot At L.I. Roller Rink
description: A group of young people were robbed - and one of them was shot - as they were leaving an Elmont roller-skating rink early today.

title: COMPO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest quarter include a gain of $3,400,000 from the sale of a plant.

title: Peugeot Output Gains
description: Production at Peugeot's Talbot plant at Poissy has reached 90 percent of capacity after a monthlong strike over layoffs, a company spokesman said today. The plant is expected to reach full capacity on Tuesday, he added.

title: Beverly Hills
description: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association said it had authorized its management and financial adviser, Shearson/American Express, to explore alternatives, including a sale or merger, to its possible acquisition by a shareholder, Paul Amir. Mr. Amir has asked a California state court to compel the thrift unit to call a special shareholders meeting for next month. Separately, Beverly Hills said it had bought two pension fund actuarial concerns, National Associates Inc. of Seattle and the Woolley Corporation of Alamo, Calif., for $5.7 million.

title: Possible S.E.C.  Candidates
description: A Los Angeles lawyer is under consideration for one of the two Democratic openings on the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to Administration officials. She is Aulana L. Peters, a partner in the law firm of Gibson Dunn & Crutcher, which is the former firm of Attorney General William French Smith. Mrs. Peters, 42 years old, refused to comment.

title: MOBIL ASKS U.S. RULING ON A TRUST
description: The Mobil Corporation has asked the Internal Revenue Service to rule on whether Mobil can set up a special company, or royalty trust, and give shares in the trust to stockholders, oil industry sources disclosed yesterday.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S SPEECH ON SOVIET-AMERICAN RELATIONS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's foreign policy address at the White House yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Robinson Still Out
description: Len (Truck) Robinson , the Knicks' power forward who is sidelined with a sprained left wrist, will miss his sixth straight game tonight when New York plays host to the Nets at Madison Square Garden.

title: NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest figures include Cabarrus Bank & Trust Co. which was merged into Northwestern Financial April 1, 1983.

title: 3 Hungarians Arrested In Theft of 7 Paintings
description: Three Hungarians have been arrested in connection with the theft of seven Italian paintings valued at $28 million from a Budapest museum, officials announced today.

title: ROLM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCOUTING
description: A Swift Record

title: AMSOUTH BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 3-for- 2 stock split to be paid Jan. 18.

title: Plant Use At Highest Since '81 WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) - The nation's industries operated last month at 79.4 percent of capacity, the highest level since late 1981, with auto makers enjoying their best month in more than four years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
description: The operating rate rose three- tenths of one percentage point in December from November, the 13th consecutive increase, and put the production level almost 10 points above the rate when the recession ended in November 1982.

title: 5 Morgan Executives Headed for Shearson Five members of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company's international investment unit here, including a senior vice president, Karl Van Horn, 48, and Herschel Post, 44, a member of the senior management group for institutional investment, have left to form the core of a new seven-man Shearson/American Express investment subsidiary.
description: ''Morgan has been a victim of its own success,'' said Mr. Post, who will be chief operating officer of American Express Asset Management Holdings. Mr. Post described Morgan's problem as one of too many talented young executives with too little room to advance.

title: BONN ASTIR OVER REPORT A GENERAL IS HOMOSEXUAL
description: Already unsettled by corruption charges against its Economics Minister, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government finds itself embroiled in accusations of homosexuality against a four-star general.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Calcium for Learning

title: U.S. Criticized On the Deficit
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned today that the United States economic recovery might begin to evaporate next year if the Reagan Administration did not cut the huge Federal deficit.

title: RANGERS TOP RED WINGS, 8-5
description: In a game marked by 187 minutes in penalties and five ejections, the Rangers defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 8-5, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: STAGE: 'LIFE AND DEATH OF KING JOHN'
description: Written after ''Richard II'' and before ''Henry IV,'' ''The Life and Death of King John'' is marginal Shakespeare, raising political issues that were treated with greater depth in other histories and tragedies. For obvious reasons, the play is seldom performed in this country. However, it is authoritative in individual moments and it has a grasp of the internecine conflicts that can destroy a monarch's will. In the character of Philip Faulconbridge, the illegitimate son of Richard the Lion-Hearted, the play also has Shakespeare's most engaging Bastard.

title: NEW FOCUS ON WORLD HEALTH
description: FOR many Americans, international health is a subject far removed from their lives, something that only arouses their interest if they get sick while traveling abroad and have to find ''the best doctor,'' or if they develop an exotic malady after returning home.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: INVENTIONS A coffin for someone who may not be dead and a pigeon-startler are among the more than 500 miniature inventions that can be seen today through April 1 at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street.

title: TV: ADAPTATION OF PHILIP ROTH'S 'GHOST WRITER'
description: Public television's eminently worthy ''American Playhouse'' returns for a third season tonight with ''The Ghost Writer,'' an adaptation of what is arguably Philip Roth's best novel, the first in a trilogy that includes ''Zuckerman Unbound'' and ''The Anatomy Lesson.'' In ''The Ghost Writer,'' published in 1979, Mr. Roth found the virtually perfect balance for the themes that have long obsessed him, most notably the tension between being a loyal Jewish son, in terms of both family and community, and being an unfettered creative writer.

title: TOP ISLAM LEADERS SKIP CONFERENCE
description: In the splendor of the royal palace, 42 members of the Islamic Conference Organization today opened their fourth meeting since the group was founded in 1969.

title: Home, Sour Home
description: On the Lower East Side of Manhattan, near the overcrowded municipal shelter, the Koch administration puts up homeless men in six privately owned buildings. Five are also privately run.

title: LAID-OFF EMPLOYEES JOIN WORKERS IN BID TO BUY AN IRON PLANT
description: Workers at an 80-year-old Bronx iron works that is scheduled to close this week are joining with laid-off employees in an attempt to buy the plant from its owners.

title: Pressure From Fans
description: When George Raveling left his coaching job at Washington State to become the coach at Iowa this season, great things were expected of the Hawkeyes. Raveling's new team was picked in the Top 10 in preseason ratings and favored to win the Big Ten Conference championship.

title: Kostmayer Runs Again
description: Representative Peter H. Kostmayer, Democrat of Pennsylvania, announced his candidacy today for a fourth term in Pennsylvania's Eighth Congressional District, where Republicans hold a substantial voter registration edge. Mr. Kostmayer, 37 years old, made the announcement at a ceramics plant that reopened after he helped it to get a $750,000 Federal Urban Development Action grant, the first in the county's history.

title: KOCH ASKS BUDGET OF $17.8 BILLION
description: Text of message, page B6.

title: A'SIMPLE' SLAYING SPAWNS A MYSTERY ABOUT PROSECUTION
description: The death of Walter Kilson on a Brooklyn street on Nov. 16, 1982, seemed little different from many other homicides that begin with a fight between friends who have been drinking. As far as the authorities were concerned, it was an open and shut case.

title: SOUGHT SUMMIT TALKS, EX-THATCHER AIDE SAYS
description: Francis Pym, a former Foreign Secretary, said tonight that he had tried unsuccessfully to persuade President Reagan to seek a meeting with Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, shortly after Mr. Andropov succeeded Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: ADVERTISING
description: People

title: CITICORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OCCIDENTAL IN OFFER FOR WILSON
description: In a move to expand its big meatpacking operations, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it was seeking to acquire the Wilson Foods Corporation for $95 million in cash.

title: MAYFAIR SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
IN NEW BOOK, KOCH SAYS HE WAS 'GUILTY OF HUBRIS' IN RUNNING FOR GOVERNOR
description: Mayor Koch says in a new book that he was ''guilty of hubris'' in running for Governor in 1982 only months after being overwhelmingly re-elected to a second term at City Hall and recalls that ''in my heart, I knew that I really belonged in New York City.''

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE gossip columns might lead you to believe that every writer in New York lives at Elaine's. Nonsense. A lot of them live in bookstores. It is a verifiable fact that one out of every three people in the bookstores of this city has just had a book published.

title: JAPAN TRADE BARS WORRY U.S.
description: The Japanese Government is considering legislation in two high-technology fields - computer software and sophisticated telecommunications services - that United States trade officials and industry executives say will restrict foreign imports and reduce legal protection for American technology.

title: HERDS' FATE IS DEBATED IN ROCKIES
description: The threat of winter starvation for thousands of Rocky Mountain game animals has inspired emergency feeding programs, but some game experts argue that the feeding may do more harm than good in the long run.

title: NAFCO FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in April 1983.

title: SAUDIS' CONSUL GENERAL IN LEBANON IS KIDNAPPED
description: A group of unidentified gunmen kidnapped the Saudi Arabian consul general in Beirut today while he was driving to work.

title: LOWERING CHOLESTEROL IN BLOOD
description: MOST people have long been aware of the potential dangers of high cholesterol. For more than a decade, the American Heart Association, later joined by more than a dozen health organizations, has been urging Americans to lower their blood cholesterol levels by eating less of the foods that are rich in cholesterol and cholesterol-raising saturated fats.

title: CHILTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DYNAMICS COST DATA PROFFERED
description: P. Takis Veliotis, a former executive of the General Dynamics Corporation, has offered to provide information to Justice Department officials that he contends can prove that the company defrauded the Navy of hundreds of millions of dollars, persons familiar with the matter said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bringing Joy to the Elderly

title: COWBOY TAKES HIS LAST RIDE
description: The friends of John A. Mancini laid the Colorado cowboy to rest today as he had wished, dressed in his stove-pipe boots and blue jeans, pipe in hand, and buried on Deer Mountain.

title: CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ROSE RAYMOND
description: The pianist Rose Raymond, a student of Leopold Godowsky and former president of the Associated Music Teachers League, died Jan. 9 in her Manhattan home after a long illness. She was 94 years old.

title: MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FUNDING GAPS THAT PERIL AMERICAN TREASURES
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION TAPING AT HOME IS UPHELD BY SUPREME COURT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that consumers do not violate Federal copyright law when they use video recorders to tape television programs for their own use.

title: NCNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are living longer, we are living healthier, and we are providing the benefits of our unparallelled health care system more widely and more equitably.'' - Margaret Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human Services. (A17:1.)

title: SCOUTING
description: Honor Deserved

title: Nakasone Trade View
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone told American officials today that he was hopeful Japan and the United States could compromise on trade issues, associates of the Japanese leader said. Mr. Nakasone specifically mentioned American demands that Japan buy more American telecommunications equipment and agricultural products such as beef and citrus fruits, the aides said.

title: WAS RIGHTIST
description: Yoshio Kodama, a shadowy ultrarightist and one of Japan's backstage power-brokers until his trial as a central figure in the multimillion-dollar Lockheed bribery scandal of 1976, died yesterday of a stroke in a Tokyo hospital, the Kyodo news service reported. He was 72 years old.

title: ELECTION PLAN IN NICARAGUA IS CRITICIZED BY OPPOSITION
description: Opponents of the Nicaraguan Government say they remain skeptical that national elections next year will be truly free despite new details on the voting made public by the Government.

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including gains from property sales of $9.8 million for the quarter and $10.8 million for the year and income of $10,487,000 for the quarter and $13,751,000 for the year from the company's share of the income of unconsolidated subsidiary and affiliates. c-After charges of $2 million for the quarter and $6.9 million for the year from devaluation of the Mexican peso, a gain of $2.2 million for the quarter and year from property sales and income of $1,890,000 for the quarter and $79,000 for the year from the company's share of the income of unconsolidated subsidiary and affiliates.

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Opening paragraphs of W. T. Tyler's new novel, ''The Shadow Cabinet''
description: It had been a gray Monday in Washington, a day too chilly to be autumn and too wet to be winter, a day when the trees seemed as bare as January, naked against a sodden sky, but a day when some leaves still fell out across the Virginia and Maryland hills. Darkness had fallen as Haven Wilson reached Farragut Square in his old Chevrolet station wagon. The commuter exodus had been snarled by a brief deluge that drowned visibility and crippled a few stoplights. Some intersections were blocked. By the time he found a parking garage, he was fifteen minutes late.

title: N.J. Transit to Get Casino Revenue
description: Governor Kean signed legislation today that allows the N.J. Transit Corporation to use $13 million from the casino revenue fund during the next two years to expand transportation services for the elderly and disabled.

title: CROCKER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: JUDGE DISMISSES SPYING CHARGES AGAINST BULGARIAN TRADE OFFICIAL

Sears Accused of Fraud in Imports WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) - A Federal grand jury indicted Sears, Roebuck & Company today, accusing the retailer of conspiring to defraud the Government in the importation of Japanese and Korean television sets from 1968 to 1975.
description: Attorney General William French Smith said the 13-count indictment, which superseded an indictment returned against the company on Feb. 26, 1980, was returned in United States District Court in Los Angeles. The new indictment charges the company with one count of conspiracy to defraud the United States and 12 counts of false statements to the Government.

title: GOING OUTY GUIDE
description: ROBOTS Robots have captured the imagination of children and adults alike in this automated age, and an exhibition that examines them in a variety of manifestations is currently on display at the American Craft Museum II in a show called ''The Robot Exhibit: History, Fantasy and Reality.'' The 160 items on display give an overview of the development of robots from articulated puppets and articulated masks to automatons and electrical objects moving on their own, to computerized robots - a development that went from fantasy to reality.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COURT'S MAJORITY AND DISSENTING OPINIONS ; Justice Stevens, for the Court
description: Following are excerpts from the opinion and the dissent in the Supreme Court's decision today on home videotape recorders. The opinion, by Associate Justice John Paul Stevens, was joined by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Associate Justices William J. Brennan Jr., Byron R. White and Sandra Day O'Connor. Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun's dissenting opinion was joined by Associate Justices Thurgood Marshall, Lewis F. Powell Jr. and William H. Rehnquist. Petitioners manufacture and sell home videotape recorders. Respondents own the copyrights on some of the television programs that are broadcast on the public airwaves. Some members of the general public use videotape recorders sold by petitioners to record some of these broadcasts, as well as a large number of other broadcasts.

title: THE REGION ; 1,000 DUCKS SWEPT OVER NIAGARA FALLS
description: More than 1,000 merganser ducks apparently became disoriented in dense fog and were swept over the American and Horseshoe Falls and into the gorge more than 150 feet below, the police said today.

title: U.N. CHIEF ASK MAJOR PARLEY ON THE ARAB-ISRAELI CONFLICT
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations proposed here today that the Security Council authorize him to sound out all interested parties on the possibility of convening an international conference on the conflict between Israel and Arab nations.

title: STAGE: 'CRIMINAL MINDS'
description: It's rare that one finds a play in which every single line falls flat as soon as it leaves an actor's mouth. If you have an academic urge to encounter such a rarity, then you have a reason to visit Robin Swicord's ''Criminal Minds,'' a hollow absurdist farce that has been given a gratuitously expert staging at the Production Company.

title: DiMaggio Knows
description: Joe DiMaggio knows the pressures facing Wayne Gretzky as the hockey star attempts to keep his record scoring streak - now at 46 games - alive. DiMaggio, who in 1941 set a major league record by hitting safely in 56 straight games, told The Edmonton Sun yesterday: ''I'm sure the pressure on him is getting greater and greater.

title: CUOMO BUDGET FLABBERGASTS' G.O.P. LEADER
description: The majority leader of the State Senate said today that he was ''flabbergasted'' at the increase in spending in Governor Cuomo's proposed budget and he called for up to $300 million in tax cuts instead.

title: THE DOUBLE LIFE OF A LOOK-ALIKE
description: PEOPLE who look like others seem to have affection for the people they resemble, and in some ways their lives seem to mirror the lives of their look- alikes.

title: Chief of AM Plans to Resign
description: AM International Inc. said

title: Compucorp
description: Compucorp said it had ended its plans to buy a majority interest in Litton Industries' Monroe Systems division.

title: RADIO COMMERCIAL AGAINST ATOM ARMS CARRIES POPE'S VOICE
description: A message from Pope John Paul II warning against an arms race is the centerpiece of an unusual new radio commercial sponsored by the Roman Catholic bishops in the United States.

title: The Deficit Dodges
description: It is daily more obvious that President Reagan will do nothing this year to reduce the huge deficits he's built into the Federal budgets of the 1980's. They have bought a lively recovery from recession and a booming armaments industry, so why burden the electorate with the costs and consequences? What Mr. Reagan wants in 1984 are not new taxes or serious defense cutbacks, just some cover for his shameless unconcern.

title: LEVI STRAUSS DESIGNER DEAL
description: Levi Strauss & Company, the nation's largest apparel company, until now has resisted putting a designer label on its clothing. But the jeans giant has obviously changed its mind.

title: PLAN IS SET TO INCREASE BLACK-MEDICAL STUDENTS
description: A new effort to increase lagging enrollment of minority group members in medical schools, by recruiting black college students in the sophomore year and then helping them as medical students, was announced yesterday by Boston University and the four black colleges that make up the Atlanta University Center in Georgia.

title: LEBANON AIRLINE, AFTER BRAVING THE WARS, IS PENNILESS
description: Lebanon's national flag airline, whose pilots have gained a reputation for getting passengers to Beirut in all but the most perilous of times, is on the verge of bankruptcy after a year of devastating losses.

title: LEONARD GREBLA
description: Leonard Grebla, senior director of marketing in the Western Hemisphere for the Hilton International Company, died of a heart attack Sunday.

title: SHULTZ, ECHOING REAGAN, INVITES RUSSIANSTO NEW TALKS WITH U.S.
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States firmly believed that ''pragmatic progress'' could be achieved on arms control and other East-West issues. He called upon the Soviet Union to join the United States in a new, more comprehensive dialogue.

description: What happens to the ''Children of Theater Street'' after they are graduated from the Vaganova Choreographic Institute in Leningrad and move on, if gifted and lucky, to the Kirov Ballet? The subject of a 1977 documentary of the same name, those children begin the even harder and more uncompromising life glimpsed in ''Backstage at the Kirov,'' which opens today at the Guild Theater.

description: France narrowed its foreign trade deficit in 1983, well ahead of expectations, and reduced its overall balance of payments shortfall, the Ministry of Foreign Trade said today.

The bank itself is co-lead manager and is running the books, with Credit Suisse and First Boston Ltd. joint lead managers.

title: SPACE FACTORY MAKES BEADS FOR SCIENCE
description: Plastic beads so tiny that millions fit in a bottle smaller than a little finger will earn the National Aeronautics and Space Administration $210,000 next year as the first commercial product made in space.

description: Elizabeth Bouvia, the quadriplegic who has asked to be allowed to starve to death, can remain at Riverside General Hospital indefinitely because it ''cannot logically or humanely discharge her,'' the hospital told the California Supreme Court today.

title: BLACK & DECKER IN THE KITCHEN
description: At first glance, the planned acquisition of General Electric's housewares operations by Black & Decker looks like a deal neither party could refuse.

title: AN UNHAPPY HOLLYWOOD WEIGHS THE NEXT MOVE
description: The movie industry responded to today's Supreme Court decision legalizing home taping with disappointment but not despair.

title: KRUEGER, W A, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW JOHN LENNON MUSIC
description: During the weeks after the murder of John Lennon, ''Double Fantasy,'' the album he had made with his wife, Yoko Ono, after a five-year sabbatical from music-making, was a best seller. Amid the outpourings of grief and the hours of radio time devoted to Mr. Lennon's music as a Beatle and a solo artist, no one seemed to remember that Mr. Lennon and Miss Ono had recorded enough material for two albums during the summer and fall of 1980, of which ''Double Fantasy'' was the first. The second album was to be called ''Milk and Honey.''

description: Dr. Hans Beller, a research chemist who held 25 United States patents and 50 foreign patents for his work in electronics and organic chemistry, died Jan. 5 at his home in Watchung, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: Anti-Semitic Incidents Down Sharply in 1983
description: Anti-Semitic incidents in the nation ''declined substantially'' last year for the second consecutive year, the Anti- Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reported yesterday in its annual audit.

title: OPERA: PHILADELPHIANS OFFER 'FAUST'
description: Gounod's ''Faust'' was once so popular that between its 1859 premiere and the close of the 19th century it received more than 1,000 performances in Paris alone. It opened New York's Metropolitan Opera House in 1883. George Bernard Shaw complained about its prevalence in London. And its arias served as grist for church sermons everywhere.

Shultz called on Moscow to join the United States in a new, more comprehensive dialogue on arms control and other East-West issues. His address in Stockholm was consistent with President Reagan's call on Monday for a more constructive Soviet-American relationship. (Page A1, Column 2.) A British-Chinese agreement on the future of Hong Kong after Britain's lease on the crown colony expires in 1997 should be reached now, a senior Chinese official said. Ji Pengfei, who directs the Government's Office of Hong Kong and Macao Affairs, said the ''time is ripe'' for such an agreement. He detailed what appeared to be Peking's plan for running Hong Kong. title: CONCERT: TWO PIANISTS IN A GERSHWIN PROGRAM
description: WHEN George Gershwin died at the age of 38 he was still not a complete composer in the traditional European sense. He began to study orchestration and other niceties too late in life ever to master all the facets of his craft. It does his reputation no harm to admit that these educational gaps were never quite closed. However, the man was a prodigious pianist for whom the instrument seemed a natural appendage to his body. The recordings he left tell us unmistakably that his peculiar brand of insouciant virtuosity was an integral and undetachable part of his remarkable though partly formed composing talent.

title: SOVIET IS MANNING NEW MISSILE UNITS
description: A Soviet news dispatch said today that Soviet troops are already manning new nuclear missile batteries in East Germany in response to the deployment in Western Europe of American Pershing 2 and cruise missiles.

title: CLARIFYING LEBANON'S HISTORY
description: Journalists, diplomats and others have fallen victim to a fiction that purports to be a fact. Over and over again, we hear the refrain that Lebanon is not a nation, that Lebanon is a new and artificial creation, that Lebanon has always been in turmoil, that Lebanon is not viable. Yet this is not history.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan The High-Tech Stock Outlook
description: -TECHNOLOGY stocks, those heart- pounders that often produce either big gains or big losses for their owners, recently have staged some improvement in the market. During the last six weeks this strength has focused mainly in areas related to capital spending.

title: LOEWS PURSUING MULTISCREEN CONCEPT
description: A construction crew is burrowing deep into the ground at the northeast corner of Broadway and 84th Street as part of the initial stages of construction for a six-auditorium cinema complex being built by the Loews theater chain.

title: ENTERTAINMENT INDUSTRY VOWS FIGHT IN CONGRESS
description: Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, said today that his organization and others would continue to fight in Congress this year for legislation that would levy a user fee on the sale of video cassette recorders and blank tapes.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Greenmarket in Winter

title: Rooney Pace Buys Stake in Norlin Rooney Pace Inc., a New York securities firm, has purchased 18.5 percent of the Norlin Corporation, a maker of musical instruments, Rooney Pace said in a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Rooney, Pace also said it might seek ''significant influence over the company.''
description: Norlin has filed a complaint in United States District Court in New York protesting the stock purchase.

title: Queens Woman Killed by Robber
description: The 58-year-old wife of a printing company executive, was killed on Monday, apparently by a robber who entered her home on 33d Avenue in Bayside, Queens, the police said.

title: Private Control Of OTB Sought
description: A plan to transform New York State's financially troubled Offtrack Betting Corporations into a private business that would generate greater revenues was outlined yesterday by Bernard Rome, a former chairman and president of New York City's OTB corporation.

title: TODD SHIPYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
COMPANY NEWS
description: Getty-Texaco Suit Filed by Pennzoil

title: NETS DOWN KNICKS TO GAIN .500 MARK
description: Bernard King of the Knicks and Otis Birdsong of the Nets were named to the National Basketball Association all-star team yesterday, and hours later played like all-stars. But Kelvin Ransey made the difference as the Nets defeated the Knicks, 121-115, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: LED WORLD COUNCIL OF CHURCHES
description: The Rev. Dr. John Coventry Smith, a former president of the World Council of Churches and a leader of the United Presbyterian Church, died Sunday after suffering a heart attack while participating in a panel discussion at the Abington Presbyterian Church in Abington, Pa. He was 80 years old.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 18, 1984
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: STATE STREET BOSTON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $14,291,000 for the quarter and year on the sale of real estate purchase options. c-After a loss of $2,510,000 on the sale of subsidiaries.

title: RULING IS A BASIS FOR FURTHER ACTION
description: News Analysis

title: M.A.C. PASSES $1 BILLION PLAN TO AID THE CITY
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday approved a plan to provide more than $1 billion over the next five years to New York City for its capital and operating budgets and for economic-development programs.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Israel's Rules On Investing
description: A spokesman for the Bank of Israel said today that under currency restrictions imposed

title: ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tip Tax Rule Brings Suit
description: A group representing restaurant and hotel chains today sued to block new Internal Revenue Service regulations that employers allocate 8 percent of gross receipts from food and beverage sales as tip income for waiters and waitresses.

title: German Prices Up 0.4%
description: Wholesale prices in West Germany rose four-tenths of 1 percent in December from November and were up 1.7 percent from December 1982, the Federal Statistics Office reported today. The agency said prices rose for aluminum, unground coffee, skins and furs, copper and nonferrous scrap metal but declined for sea fish and tropical fruit.

title: Article 184739 -- No Title
description: Somewhere, probably in Ontario, there is a person who apparently has better things to do than pick up a check for $11 million, tax free.

title: THE REGION
description: uf1 2 Drug Raiders Shot in Jersey

title: Yankees Choose Ohio Pitcher in Draft
description: Tim Belcher, a 6-foot-3-inch right- handed pitcher with a 93-mile-an- hour fastball and an attorney who had a .285 career batting average in the minor leagues, refused to sign with the Minnesota Twins after being selected first in last June's amateur draft. But after Belcher was taken by the Yankees as the first pick in the secondary stage yesterday, his attorney said the two teams were ''like butter vs. margarine.''

title: No Headline
description: DREAM WEST. By David Nevin. 639 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95. HOW can anyone take seriously a novel with a title like ''Dream West''? Yet this is a good book of its kind, a rousing, old-fashioned yarn, a saga, the sort of novel, with a cast of thousands, that we generally call ''sprawling.'' And David Nevin is just the man to write the story of the exploration and development of the American West. While this is only his first novel, he is an award-winning journalist who has written several popular histories of the West. He says he spent more than eight years researching ''Dream West,'' and it's full of authentic, colorful stuff.

title: FILM: 'DDEP IN THE HEART'
description: The viewer's sympathies are certainly with Kathleen, the heroine of Tony Garnett's ''Deep in the Heart,'' when she is raped by her date. Kathleen (Karen Young), after all, is an innocent Irish Catholic schoolteacher. Her date, Larry Keeler (Clayton Day), is a swinger, a gun enthusiast and a corporate lawyer. Furthermore, Larry says things like ''the build-up in government-supported welfare programs is contradictory to the frontier spirit.'' And on the night of the attack, he serves Kathleen some venison from a deer that, he is proud to say, he has bagged himself.

title: Hail the Boring City Budget
description: Instead of a yawning fiscal gap, Mayor Koch's preliminary four-year financial plan offers New Yorkers only a yawn: a blessed boredom. The deficit of more than $1 billion predicted last January for the current year has disappeared. The predicted shortfall of $484 million in the year beginning next July is down to a mere trickle of red. The foreseeable accounts will be easily balanced if the economies of nation and city continue on course. The only thing to fear is boredom itself.

title: Regents Will Revise 5-Year Schools Plan
description: The State Board of Regents said today that, in response to criticism from around the state, it would revise its five-year plan to improve the state's elementary and secondary schools.

title: Zaire Bars Aeroflot's Planes After an Explosion at Airport
description: Zaire has suspended landing rights for the Soviet airline Aeroflot after a bomb explosion at Kinshasa airport, the official press agency reported Monday.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Ratings Cut on Utilities Building Nuclear Plants

title: REALTY VALUES IN CITY UP $3.2 BILLION
description: The taxable value of New York City property has been tentatively set at $48.933 billion, an increase of $3.222 billion over last year, the city's Finance Department announced yesterday.

title: AS BULK FOOD SALES GROW, SO DO HEALTH QUESTIONS
description: -BARREL philosophers of a few decades ago who convened at the general store to swap stories and comment on the state of mankind are close to extinction in this age of sprawling supermarkets. Badinage in front of the frozen-yogurt cooler somehow lacks the same quaintness. But while aseptic, Muzak-inflicted supermarkets may never revive the social functions of the old general store, the retail food industry is trying to humanize shopping by bringing back the cracker barrel - and coffee barrels, dried-nuts barrels, candy barrels, spice barrels, cereal barrels and dozens more.

title: TV: 'SMITHSONIAN WORLD' STARTING
description: Say this about ''Smithsonian World'': It is as ambitious, eclectic and chockablock as the great institution itself. ''Time and Light,'' the opening program in this seven-part series on public television shows us timepieces as diverse as the sea urchin (for measuring evolutionary time) and the atomic clock (accurate to within a single second every 30,000 years). Indeed, it seems to be showing us everything it can. The program will be seen on PBS tonight.

title: KNAPE & VOGT MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Settlement Ends a Suit Against Dalkon Shield
description: The third case among 13 involving women who sued the manufacturer of the Dalkon Shield contraceptive has been resolved in an out-of-court settlement.

title: BANC ONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Economic SceneMichael Blumstein Banking Lines Begin to Blur
description: L IKE a tidal wave pressing against a seawall, the

title: N.F.L. SEES PROBLEMS, ARGUES SOLUTIONS
description: From the time he became the commissioner in 1960, Pete Rozelle has been accorded a major share of the credit for the rise of the National Football League to pre-eminence among the professional sports leagues in this country.

title: AMERICAN FLETCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A KOCH SAMPLER: ON 'WACKOS,' RADICALS AND GOD
description: There was something in the atmosphere of strikebound New York that made people, and not just me, ebullient. Women in their Madison Avenue business suits strode along wearing their Uptown stockings and their jogging sneakers. People pulled rusty bicycles out of basements. Everyone had an excuse for being a little late. On rainy days, New Yorkers looked as if they'd just stood under a downspout. Somehow, all those things made people feel better about themselves and their city.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUTHTRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'CIVIL DEFENSE IS A MATTER OF HUMAN RIGHTS'
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS ON TIES WITH SOVIET IS PRAISED BY ALLIES
description: Major European allies today welcomed the foreign policy speech President Reagan delivered on Monday, but commentators were divided on whether the speech's conciliatory tone was directed toward the Soviet Union or the American voter.

title: Iraqi Planes Attack Iranian Positions
description: Iraqi warplanes today mounted their first attack on Iranian positions in a month, striking at troop concentrations in the central sector of the Persian Gulf war front, the High Command said.

title: THE REGION ;  Top State Court Acts on Judges
description: The state's top court today removed two local justices from the bench, censured a third and said a fourth judge had to turn over his business records to a watchdog commission.

title: Hrudey Is Unsure On Olympic Bid
description: Responding to a report he was no longer under consideration to join the Canadian hockey team for the Winter Olympics, the Islander goalie Kelly Hrudey said last night he had not yet received word on whether he would be selected for the club.

title: A Circulating Library On Video Established
description: The Museum of Modern Art has established a Circulating Video Library to make the work of independent video makers accessible to a wider audience of students, scholars and critics.

title: LOAN PROVISIONS RISE
description: Six major bank holding companies, including Citicorp, the largest, announced their fourth quarter results yesterday, with most reporting only modest gains.

title: Stocks Rise; Dow Gains 3.87
description: Stock prices finished with small gains yesterday in active trading, with Digital Equipment the stellar performer for the second consecutive session.

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ford Irish Closing
description: The Ford Motor Company Ltd. announced it is closing its car assembly plant in Cork later this year, with the loss of 800 jobs. The company, which has been operating in Cork for 67 years, said the size and location of the plant made it uncompetitive, despite the injection of $11 million since 1979.

title: REDESIGN KISSINGER ECONOMIC PROPOSAL
description: The report of the Kissinger commission includes a superb analysis of Central America's social and economic problems and offers many constructive, innovative ideas for addressing them. Unfortunately, the $8 billion economic plan it proposes is unworkable in a climate of violence and uncertainty. Its proposals could, however, be redesigned to promote both peace and prosperity.

title: MIAMI BATTLES RISE IN SEXUAL DISEASE
description: An accelerated campaign by public health workers here to halt a surge in certain types of sexually transmitted diseases appears to be making some progress, according to officials leading the drive.

title: 3M in Japan
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said its 3M Health Care Ltd. and Sumitomo 3M subsidiaries had signed agreements with the Eisai Pharmaceutical Company of Japan to introduce pharmaceutical products in Japan. It said the agreements involve development and marketing in Japan of flecainide acetate, a drug designed to control heart rhythm disturbances.

title: MYLAN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WORSENING GREEK-U.S. RELATIONS: A PROBLEM WITH DEEP ROOTS
description: The visiting American Congressman was shocked.

title: Pay TV of A.C.C. Is Discontinued
description: A controversial pay-television package that was to give Atlantic Coast Conference basketball viewers extra games has been discontinued for the rest of this season, league and television officials said today.

title: Lilco Plans to Sell Preferred Stock The Long Island Lighting Company filed a shelf registration statement yesterday for the sale of up to $100 million of preferred stock. The company said the stock might be sold through underwriters or agents, or directly to investors.
description: Delays in the construction and operation of the company's Shoreham nuclear power plant have hurt Lilco's financial condition and made it more difficult to sell its securities, analysts said. Lilco's long-term bonds were recently downgraded to a speculative Ba/BB category by Moody's and S.& P.

title: Bridge: 2 Seasoned Young Players Share Laurels in Regionals
description: The conclusion of the Tristate Regionals in Port Chester, N.Y., Sunday night proved to be a triumph for youth. Heading the standings going into the final round of the Swiss team event was a team that included two ''elderly'' teen-agers: Steve Weinstein of Accord, N.Y., and Peter Lieberman of Providence, R.I., both 19.

title: MINI MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
Norman Raben to Buy Ultrasport Magazine
description: Norman Raben has resigned from Bernard Goldhirsh's Inc. organization and has fallen in with the crowd that is starting Ultrasport, the magazine for people who like to overdo it athletically.

title: NICOTINE GUM APPROVED BY U.S.
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the sale by prescription of chewing gum containing nicotine that might help cigarette smokers give up the habit.

title: Net Up 27.1% At Donaldson
description: Donaldson, Lukfin & Jenrette, the investment firm, reported record earnings in the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31 of $7.5 million, or 50 cents a share, up 27.1 percent from $5.9 million, or 44 cents a share on fewer shares in the period a year ago.

title: RIGHTS COMMISSION ABANDONS BACKING OF RACIAL QUOTAS
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights, with a new majority firmly in control, today denounced the use of numerical quotas for the promotion of blacks and prodded the Supreme Court to adopt a similar position.

title: New U.S. Envoy to Nigeria
description: President Reagan has selected Thomas W. M. Smith, a career diplomat, to be the new United States Ambassador to Nigeria, the White House said today. Mr. Smith replaces Thomas R. Pickering, who is now the Ambassador to El Salvador. Mr. Smith, a former Ambassador to Ghana, takes over the post at a sensitive time in relations between Washington and Nigeria, where a democratically elected Government was recently overthrown in a military coup.

title: BAD NEWS FOR SALVADOR'S TEEN-AGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: West German Bank Dismisses Two Officers In a major shake-up, Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale, the third- largest bank in West Germany, has dismissed two senior officers amid strains in the bank's domestic and overseas business.
description: In a one-line statement, the D"usseldorf-based bank said Vinzenz K. E. Grothgar, 48 years old, deputy chairman of the management board responsible for international business, and Heinrich Viefers, 56, the board member for domestic lending, had left the board Monday. The bank is owned by North Rhine-Westphalia state agencies.

MARCHI VS. WATERFRONT REDEVELOPMENT

description: Asher B. Edelman, the owner of 7.4 percent of the common stock of Management Assistance Inc., told Management Assistance directors that two companies are interested in acquiring all or part of Management Assistance's businesses, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Doctors Rebuild Flippers For Mangled Sea Turtle
description: Lucky, a loggerhead sea turtle that lost her flippers to a shark while frolicking with her mate, paddled triumphantly across a tank of water today with a pair of rubber flippers that had been attached in a $200,000 operation.

title: Meeting Held On Sugar Pact
description: Representatives of the world's leading sugar exporters are meeting in London to discuss drafting a new international sugar agreement to stabilize prices. The delegates began the two-week meeting Monday hoping to narrow differences that twice last year prevented agreement on a new pact.

title: ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue figures were unavailable.

title: ZHAO ADDRESSES CANADA ASSEMBLY
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China addressed a joint session of Canada's Parliament today and praised Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau for his efforts to quell a nuclear arms race that ''is becoming white hot.''

title: XIDEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a net gain of $945,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of common stock.

COMMERCIAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

$200 Million Issue For G.E. Credit A $200 million issue of 11 percent Eurobonds of a General Electric Credit Corporation subsidiary is being offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley International. The company also sold 200,000 warrants, which may be used before Dec. 15 to buy an additional $200 million of 11 percent bonds due in 10 years.
description: The company sold the bonds to Morgan Stanley after soliciting bids for the securities from six securities firms.

Cold Water of South Carolina Threatens Shrimp Harvests
description: Unusually cold temperatures killed more than 15 percent of the shrimp in South Carolina's coastal waters in the past month, state officials estimate.

description: b-Comparable year-ago results were unavailable because the company went public in September.

title: ROLLY BESTER
description: Rolly Bester, an actress and later an advertising executive, died of cancer in New York City last Thursday.

title: MONDALE, BUOYANT AFTER DEBATE, CALLS CAMPAIGN 'ONE OF SWEETEST'
description: Walter F. Mondale said today that the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination was ''one of the sweetest primary fights in the party's history'' and that there was a strong unified commitment among all the candidates to defeat the Republican Party.

title: CONTINENTAL AIR UNIONS LOSE ATTACK ON PAY CUT
description: A Federal bankruptcy court judge yesterday denied a petition by three unions to dismiss the filing of Continental Air Lines for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy law.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the abondonment of a nuclear power plant in Indiana incorrectly described payments that the Public Service Company of Indiana plans to make to holders of its bonds and preferred stock. It plans to maintain the current levels of payments, not reduce them.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Former Gimbels Head Chosen as Higbee Chief Robert R. Broadbent, a former head of Gimbels New York, was named yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the Higbee Company, the Cleveland department store.

title: Vilas's Suspension Is Off, Fine Stands
description: A review panel of three tennis officials affirmed yesterday that Guillermo Vilas was guilty of having accepted $60,000 to appear at a tournament last year, and upheld his fine of $20,000. But it canceled the one-year suspension that had been imposed on the 31-year-old Argentine.

title: MANUFACTURERS SEE LITTLE IMPACT ON THEIR SALES
description: Manufacturers of home videotaping equipment said that yesterday's Supreme Court decision on home video, though a great victory, would have little impact on sales, which have been booming unhindered by uncertainty over the case.

title: AS MEXICO PUMPS ITS OIL, THE GRAFT FLOWS FREELY
description: President Miguel de la Madrid's campaign against Mexico's flourishing corruption has run head on into his campaign to salvage the country's faltering economy.

title: Arrows Threaten Move
description: The Arrows of the Major Indoor Soccer League said today that they would move unless home attendance doubled for the rest of the season. ''Several major sports towns in the country are waiting to grab a

title: BRIEFING
description: Ivan, Anya, Jim and Sally

title: General From Georgia
description: The New Jersey Generals signed Freddie Gilbert , a Georgia defensive end who had played with the Generals' star running back, Herschel Walker . . . . The Los Angeles Express signed Gordon Hudson , Brigham Young's star tight end, to a multiyear contract, and Hudson said he hoped the Express would be able to sign his teammate, Steve Young , the quarterback. Hudson, who was injured in the seventh game of the 1983 season, set a collegiate single-game record for a tight end by gaining 259 yards on 13 receptions.

title: TEXAS COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 figures were restated for pooled acquisition of Bank of Pasadena, Texas.

title: S.I.A. Opposes Insurance Rule
description: The Securities Industry Association, a group that represents brokers and investment

title: BARS OFFERING 'MOCKTAILS' FOR THE ROAD
description: They traded recipes for ''mocktails'' - drinks with no alcohol. They exchanged tips on happy hours. They swapped stories of drunken customers and how to stop them from drinking more.

title: St. Regis Sale
description: The St. Regis Corporation has reached a tentative agreement to sell two plants in a move the company says will keep them open. St. Regis will sell its folding carton plant and one of two paperboard mills to the Field Container Corporation of Elk Grove Village, Ill., a St. Regis spokesman, John T. Gould, said. Sale of the plants is ''mainly contingent'' on Field Container obtaining a new labor agreement with the four unions representing hourly employees, Mr. Gould said.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Backers Riot in Calcutta
description: Supporters of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's party rampaged through Calcutta today, setting fire to five buses and damaging others to protest the arrest of some party leaders.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Named Terry Crowley batting instructor in minor league organization. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Rick Sutcliffe, pitcher, and Tony Bernazard, second baseman, to one-year contracts; signed Jamie Easterly, free-agent pitcher to two-year contract. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Dave Roberts was named manager of Eugene, Ore., club in Northwest League, which has working agreement with Royals. MONTREAL (NL) - Signed Miguel Dilone, free-agent outfielder, to one-year contract. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Announced that contract of Frank Robinson, manager, would be extended for at least another year. BASKETBALL PORTLAND (NBA) - Signed Eddie Jordan, guard, to second 10-day contract. COLLEGES NORTHERN ILLINOIS - Named Lee Corso football coach. NORTHWESTERN - Named Dave Ottmar quarterback-receivers coach, Earle Mosley defensive secondary coach, Scott Schuhmann offensive coordinator and Francis Peay defensive coordinator. FOOTBALL ARIZONA (USFL) - Signed Darryl Nichols, linebacker; John Sherlock, offensive guard, and Bob Jenkins and Andy Molls, defensive backs. Named Pete Ketella wide receiver coach.; CINCINNATI (AFC) - Named Bill Urbanik defensive line coach. GENERALS (USFL) - Signed Freddie Gilbert, defensive end. JACKSONVILLE (USFL) - Signed Tommy Thurson, linebacker, and James Brown and Warren Gray, offensive guards. Tom Dinkel, linebacker, agreed to terms. LOS ANGELES (USFL) - Signed Gordon Hudson and Chuck Walker, tight ends; Mark Gardner, guard; Dee Monson, defensive tackle; Dennis Williams and Lance Dodson, offensive tackles; Don Brown, linebacker, and Rodney Webster, running back. NEW ORLEANS (USFL) - Named John North quarterback coach. OAKLAND (USFL) - Named Mike Dolby defensive line coach; signed Kevin Baird, safety; Gavin Carr, cornerback; James Carter, guard, and Chris Riehm, nose tackle.j PHILADELPHIA (USFL) - Signed Tom Kilkenny, linebacker, to one-year contract.

title: MORTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income including extraordinary credits of $221,000 for the quarter and $586,000 for the 9 months.

title: Digital to Offer UNIX System WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (Reuters) - The Digital Equipment Corporation said it would offer an operating system based on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's UNIX software system for its mid- range and high-range Vax computers. The company said it would distribute Ultrex-32 under an A.T.& T. license.
description: Last week, the International Business Machines Corporation said it would make the UNIX system available to users of its Personal Computer. That move was seen as upstaging A.T.& T. UNIX is widely used on much larger computers, primarily by engineers and on campuses. It can permit several computer users to work on a single machine simultaneously.

title: FIRST-TIME DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST SEE START OF A TRADITION
description: Tradition plays a large role in the support of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, and joining the ranks of long-time donors this year are new contributors who vow that their gift to the fund is a start of their own tradition of giving.

title: ARCHDIOCESE CALMLY BUT EAGERLY AWAITS A NEW HEAD
description: In St. Patrick's Cathedral, the archbishop's throne of carved wood and red cushions remains empty, three months after the death of Terence Cardinal Cooke. All the while, Bishop Joseph T. O'Keefe has calmly assumed temporary command of the sprawling archdiocese from his 19th-floor office at the chancery, at First Avenue and 55th Street.

title: New Polish Food Prices Take Effect Jan. 30
description: Food price increases, delayed and cut back after a public outcry, will go into effect Jan. 30 and average 10 percent, the Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, said today.

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN REPORTED MOVING TO PLAN THAT WOULD REDUCE ACID RAIN
description: President Reagan is ''moving toward'' proposing additional steps to curb acid rain in a program that would cost substantially less than one previously advocated by the Environmental Protection Agency, an Administration official said today.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Key Rates
description: Kenny index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Connecticut Fire Kills 2
description: A 31-year-old woman and her 5-year- old daughter were killed when fire swept through their home on Hope Street in the Springdale section of Stamford, Conn., shortly after noon yesterday. The mother, Theresa Evans, was dead on arrival at Stamford Hospital and her daughter, Jennifer, died later of injuries sustained in the fire. Five firefighters were treated for smoke inhalation and burns, and one reportedly suffered a heart attack.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Detroit Pistons, at Pontiac, Mich., 7:30 P.M. This is the first of six meetings between the teams. Detroit won three of the five games they played last season. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.)

title: 4 Challenged Ad Claims Are Dropped or Altered
description: The National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus ended 1983 without any particular fireworks.

title: Nuclear Plant Cost Overruns
description: The nuclear industry, shaken by the cancellation of one power plant and the Government's refusal to license another, got more bad news today with a Government report showing that three-fourths of the nation's reactors cost consumers at least double what was promised. The Energy Department's Energy Information Administration said the final costs for 77 percent of the plants now operating were at least double the pre-construction estimates.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dave Langevin , the Islander defenseman who twisted his knee during Monday's 2-0 loss to the Bruins in Boston, apparently damaged some cartilage. The full extent of his injury will not be determined until he is examined today. . . . Marvelous Marvin Hagler has won the Edward J. Neil Award as fighter of the year, it was announced by the Boxing Writers Association. . . . John McEnroe was named the International Tennis Federation's world champion for 1983 and the No. 1 player in the world by Tennis Magazine. . . . Bob Lurie , the owner of the San Francisco Giants, said Frank Robinson would continue as manager next season.

title: ARMS EXPERT OPPOSES MOVE TO BYPASS TALKS IN GENEVA
description: Paul H. Nitze , the chief United States negotiator on medium-range missiles in Europe , said today that he opposed bypassing the regular negotiations in Geneva in an effort to break the stalemate in the talks with the Soviet Union.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a new type of investment trust misstated the number of shares in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that were exchanged for units of a similar trust.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: THE problem with most electric hot trays on the market is that they are not particularly graceful additions to the dining room - bulky, inelegant boxes with grid marks, red lights and little knobs or dials.

title: COMMONWEALTH FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Not available as the bank converted to a public stock company on April 14, 1983. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1.1 million and a nonrecurring gain of $643,000. d-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $3.4 million. The per share figures reflect a 2-for- 1 stock split distributed in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend to stockholders of record September 1983.

title: TO SAVE OUR FUTURE
description: To the Editor: Averell Harriman is our wisest liv

title: N.H.L. to Review Fighting Reports
description: Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League's executive vice president, is expected to begin a review today of officials' reports of a fight that led to the assessment of seven game-misconduct penalties against two Rangers and three Detroit Red Wings in a game marked by 187 minutes of penalties Monday night.

title: BURR-BROWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: THE RETURN OF THE POLO COAT
description: POLO coats of all kinds are being seen on the streets of New York this winter but none seems more popular than one designed by Perry Ellis. His version has a new, long shape and low patch pockets and comes in a low-button double-breasted style. Mr. Ellis has designed the coat for both men and women, and they are taking it up with what appears to be equal enthusiasm. The polo coat was traditionally navy, but the most popular colors this winter are camel and black.

description: Siultanen's goal at 18:37 ruined a New Jersey comeback from a 2-0 first-period deficit.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: FROM time to time, I have written about what I call neutral foods, bland items such as pasta, potatoes or chicken that need a flavor boost to give them character. My favorite neutral meat is veal, probably because it so easily melds with foods that complement it. Veal harmonizes happily with almost any assertive herb or spice, including tarragon and rosemary. This meat is simply a pleasure to cook.

title: Racing Case Dropped
description: Louisiana authorities have refused to prosecute a prominent racing veterinarian who had been arrested and charged with illegal possession of drugs and hypodermic needles at his apartment at the Fair Grounds in New Orleans. The man, Dr. Alex Harthill , is not licensed to practice in Louisiana but serves as a consultant to the president of the track. In announcing that he would not press the case against Dr. Harthill, Eric Dubelier , an assistant to the Orleans Parish District Attorney, Harry Connick , said it was his opinion that it was ''not a violation of state law for a licensed veterinarian to possess a controlled substance in Louisiana even if he is not licensed in this state.''

title: London Police Arrest Former Beatle's Wife
description: Paul McCartney's wife, Linda, was arrested at Heathrow Airport today and charged with possessing marijuana, Scotland Yard said. The arrest came after the couple cut short a vacation in Barbados because of marijuana convictions there.

title: Mutual Fund Trading Rule WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (Reuters) - The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed the relaxation of a rule prohibiting mutual funds from investing in the shares of publicly traded brokerage firms.
description: Kathryn McGrath, director of the agency's investment management division, said the proposed change would permit the funds to purchase both the debt and equity securities of brokerages ''in fairly large amounts.''

title: The Ministry of Truth (had) three slogans: WAR IS PEACE, FREEDOM IS SLAVERY and IGNORANCE IS STRENGTH.
description: As we have already seen in the case of the word free , words which had once borne a heretical meaning were sometimes retained for the sake of convenience, but only with the undesirable meanings purged out of them. Countless other words such as honor, justice, morality, internationalism, democracy, science and religion had simply ceased to exist.

title: PENNZOIL MAY RAISE GETTY BID
description: The Pennzoil Company, gambling that Texaco Inc. will face Government opposition or long legal delays in its $10 billion deal to buy the Getty Oil Company, said yesterday that it was prepared to increase its own offer for Getty stock to $125 a share - the same price offered by Texaco.

title: 5 STATES WARNING E.P.A. OF A SUIT OVER ACID RAIN
description: New York and four other states told the Environmental Protection Agency today that they intended to sue it because the agency had failed to order reductions in sulfur emissions that cause acid rain.

title: Miss Walters to Lead Debate
description: The League of Women Voters said today that Barbara Walters, the ABC News commentator, would moderate its Feb. 23 debate among the eight major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination. The debate is to be held at St. Anselm's College in Manchester, N.H.

title: Demand Is Strong For Florida Issue A $231 million financing for the Lakeland, Fla., municipally owned electric utility was tentatively priced by Salomon Brothers to yield a maximum of 9 7/8 percent for bonds due in 2012. An insured part of the financing, 9 5/8 percent bonds due in 2012, was priced at 99 1/2 to yield 9.68 percent.
description: Strong demand for the issue enabled underwriters to reduce yields on the long-term bonds from the 10 percent level set early yesterday.

title: RESTORING A CHAIR WITH HAND CANING
description: For the amount of work involved and the still high standards maintained, the hand weaving of cane is the best buy of all restoration skills today. The cost is usually about three times that of the fitting of the machine-woven cane.

title: Taylor Explains Dealing
description: Lawrence Taylor, ending his silence on a tangled web of negotiations, said today the reason he had made a deal giving the New Jersey Generals an option on his future services was for the security of a million-dollar loan from Donald Trump, the Generals' owner.

title: Accord Set On Futures WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) - Federal regulators said today that they reached agreement on minimum guidelines that must be met for approval of new futures contracts based on certain stock market indexes.
description: The agreement came in partial response to efforts by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to offer futures contracts based on four Standard & Poor's indexes.

title: Professor From M.I.T. Moving to Wall Street One of the financial world's best- known academics is leaving the ivory tower for the dollars-and-cents world of Wall Street. On Feb. 6, Fischer Black, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will become a vice president-trading and arbitrage at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
description: Mr. Black, in a telephone interview yesterday from Cambridge, Mass., said some of his colleagues were surprised by his decision. ''But the better they know me, I think the less surprised they are,'' he said.

title: European Oil Stock Plan
description: The European Commission is to invite major oil traders and oil companies to participate in a proposed plan to report on European stocks of crude oil and oil products on a monthly basis, officials here said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Express Co. said American Telephone and Telegraph Co.'s Information Systems subsidiary had signed a contract to design, install and maintain a voice and data information system at American Express's new headquarters building in Manhattan.

title: CONCERT: EIGHTH RICHARD TUCKER GALA
description: The eighth annual Richard Tucker Music Foundation Gala at Carnegie Hall Sunday night was more a celebration of good works in the name of music than a celebration of music itself. There were some excellent voices on hand, a full orchestra to accompany them and Sherrill Milnes, the American baritone, as master of ceremonies. Musically, however, the evening represented a collection of good ingredients half cooked and sometimes not cooked at all.

title: David T. Tuma Is Dead at 44; Taught at Carnegie-Mellon U.
description: David T. Tuma, a professor of electrical engineering at Carnegie-Mellon University since 1971, was killed today when his car skidded off the icy Penn-Lincoln Parkway and into the Monongahela River. Dr. Tuma, 44 years old, was pronounced dead at Presbyterian-University Hospital.

title: No Headline
description: Trial of the American Civil Liberties Union's lawsuit charging police spying, scheduled to start today, was postponed until Feb. 1 at the request of lawyers seeking an out-of-court settlement. Judge Lester Olson of Superior Court granted a last-minute request for a delay in the trial Tuesday. The civil action, filed by the A.C.L.U. on behalf of 131 individuals and groups, accuses the Los Angeles Police Department's now-defunct Public Disorder Intelligence Division of illegal spying.

title: THEATER: 'THE ARCHAELOGY OF SLEEP'
description: AS is their wont, the nomadic members of the Living Theater scamper through the aisles of their new temporary New York home, the Joyce Theater. And, as is also their wont, they're not content to leave well enough alone. Suddenly, I found a performer poised above me, asking the question, ''Are you afraid if I touch you like this?'' And, even as the performer's final sibilant lingered in the air, I felt a sweaty kiss on my right ear. Before I could respond, another performer - Julian Beck, the Living Theater's co-founder, no less - was by my side, asking the same question. The next thing I knew, Mr. Beck had reached his hand under my notebook and placed it between my legs.

title: HOGS IN THREE-PIECE SUITS
description: TAMPA, Fla. mpian By the nature of their role, offensive lines toil without attention, usually without a nickname, always until now without a corporation. Block and be quiet. One of the few lines ever to emerge as even slightly famous was the Electric Company, which turned on the juice for O. J. Simpson in Buffalo a decade ago. Around that time the Miami Dolphins also had their Mushrooms. "They called us that," Bob Kuechenberg said, "because we were kept in the dark." But as Super Bowl XVIII approaches, the Hogs have joined Miss Piggy and the Three Little Pigs as the most storied swine in history. These are prize Hogs on the cleat instead of the hoof - the five offensive linemen, two tight ends and the fullback John Riggins - who will be helping the Washington Redskins defend their National Football League championship Sunday against the Los Angeles Raiders. At stake is the Hogs' corporate future in three-piece suits, not shoulder pads. If the Redskins were to lose, would it be possible, or proper, for them to maintain Super Hogs Inc. as the title of the firm that grossed $150,000 last year? At their office in Washington, the Hogs license 40 products, from pig snouts and T-shirts to posters and the ultimate contradiction in terms, Hog quiche. Their office also handles Hog appearances and speaking engagements, with 15 percent of the corporate income going to Martha's Table, a soup kitchen in Washington for homeless children. "It's something we did not to make a profit off of," the left guard Russ Grimm was saying now. "We just did it to bring the team together and bring the Washington fans together. But now it's a term we have to live up to." It's also a term that Russ Grimm is considering abandoning in order to join the Pittsburgh Maulers of the United States Football League if he doesn't sign a new Redskin contract before Feb. 1, when he would become a free agent. "I don't want to talk about that contract situation now," Russ Grimm said. "When the Super Bowl is over, I'll get all the facts on the table from both teams and make my decision. By myself. I don't have an agent, I don't need one. I know what I'm worth." But at least one Hog would not resent Russ Grimm's leaving the pigpen. "If Russ were to go to the U.S.F.L.," said the right tackle George Starke, "it would affect the group to a degree, but as a Hog and as a friend, I'd be supportive. The bottom line of this business is to make money. If he can make more money, good for him." George Starke's title is the Head Hog, not to be confused with the Boss Hog, alias Joe Bugel, the Redskins' assistant head coach-offense, who baptized them. "In training camp before the 1982 season," George Starke recalled, "Coach Bugel looked at Russ Grimm and said, 'You are a prototype hog.' After that, it just caught on among us and the tight ends, then we made John a member, too." George Starke, once the center on Columbia basketball teams with Jim McMillian and Heyward Dotson and now a film-maker, is also the senior Hog at age 35, but all the other linemen are young. In height and weight, these Hogs are huge: Left tackle: Joe Jacoby, 6-7, 311, age 24, a free agent from Louisville signed as a defensive lineman, third season. Left guard: Russ Grimm, 6-3, 292, age 24, a third-round choice from Pittsburgh, where he had been a center, third season. Center: Jeff Bostic, 6-2, 258, age 25, a free agent from Clemson, fourth season. Right guard: Mark May, 6-6, 295, age 24, first-round choice from Pittsburgh, third season. Right tackle: George Starke, 6-5, 270, age 35, free agent from Columbia, 11th season. If those five Hogs were prodded into a stockyard, their weights would add up to 1,426 pounds, give or take their latest meal. Including the two tight ends, 245-pound Don Warren and 243-pound Rick Walker, and 235- pound John Riggins, the 8 Hogs weigh a total of 2,149 pounds, more than a ton. And yesterday, wearing a camouflage outfit, John Riggins was asked to provide a capsule description of the Hogs he loves to run behind. "Joe Jacoby," he said, "Interstate 66, go West, young man, go West. He's gonna be around a few years. "Russ Grimm, he'll be a tremendous player for the Maulers once they land him. Jeff Bostic, the best center in the league. Mark May, none to compare with him, U.S. 373. "George Starke, like myself, us dinosaurs have managed to escape evolution." Those five Hogs enabled John Riggins to set a Super Bowl record with 166 rushing yards against the Miami Dolphins last year as the Redskins accumulated a record 276 rushing yards in their 27-17 victory. But if the Redskins are to win their second Super Bowl ring, the Hogs must block effectively not only for John Riggins but also for the quarterback, Joe Theismann. "Theismann hasn't been hurt," Lyle Alzado was saying yesterday, "but I don't think anybody has put a good shot on him." To accomplish that, Lyle Alzado must get by Joe Jacoby, an all-pro as big as a building. In the Redskins' 37- 35 triumph over the Raiders early this season, the bearded defensive end had only one tackle and shared one sack. "Jacoby's one of the better tackles. He's good," Lyle Alzado acknowledged reluctantly. "I'm not going to say he's great. He's not as great as Jim Brown, as Deacon Jones, as Forrest Gregg." After the Raiders won the American Football Conference title, Lyle Alzado talked about "tearing off" John Riggins's head if the opportunity develops. When the Redskin fullback was reminded of that threat yesterday as he stood at the lectern in his only public appearance this week, he smiled. "Over at the stadium yesterday at photo day I was looking for a nice soft spot on the grass, so that when he knocks my block off, it won't bounce too far," John Riggins said. "I hope he's enough of a gentleman so that when my head falls off, he'll hand it back to me." Told later of John Riggins's response, Lyle Alzado laughed. "I'll put his head back," the bearded Raider said, smiling, "as long as he takes the cleat marks out of my chest." Make that Hog hooves out of his chest, not cleat marks. - SPORTS OF THE TIMES

The stock dividend follows Alleghany's sale this month of its Investors Diversified Services subsidiary to American Express for 11.5 million American Express shares, plus $333 million in cash and a $40 million note.
description: Alleghany had been paying a cash dividend of 27 cents a share, or $1.08 a year. It said it would now pay one American Express share twice a year for every 50 shares of Alleghany. At American Express's closing price yesterday, $32.625 a share, the dividend would be worth 65 1/4 cents for each Alleghany share every six months, or $1.305 a year.

title: U.S. INTEREST RATES RISE A BIT
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday for short- and long-term Treasury issues. Government securities dealers said there was little reason for the increase in long-term yields, except that demand from institutional investors was weak and financing costs of securities dealers rose slightly.

title: THURSDAY, JANUARY 19, 1984 International
description: High Soviet and American officials talked for five hours about virtually every issue that has divided the two countries. Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union met in Stockholm where they are attending the 35-nation East-West conference on security in Europe. Aides described the talks as ''serious'' despite a speech Mr. Gromyko made earlier in the day denouncing the United States as the main threat to peace. (Page A1,Column 6.) An American educator was killed in Beirut by unidentified gunmen. Malcolm H. Kerr, the president of the American University there, died after being shot twice in the head. A caller who said he was from a group called Islamic Holy War, took responsibility for the killing and vowed that ''not a single American or Frenchman will remain on this soil.'' (A1:5.)

title: Tentative Yields Set On New M.A.C. Bonds
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation is selling $200 million of bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The bonds were tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 9 3/4 percent for the 2008 maturity, falling to 9 1/2 percent in 1999 and 8 3/4 percent in 1994.

title: THE LIMITS OF A NOVEL'S POINT OF VIEW ;
description: WHY does it bother me so much when novelists wantonly violate the logic of their narrative points of view, by which, of course, I mean the central intelligences that are telling the novels' stories? E. M. Forster would have said it bothers me because I am a critic. In his ''Aspects of the Novel,'' the English writer observed about ''point of view'': ''Critics are more apt to object than readers. Zealous for the novel's eminence, they are a little too apt to look out for problems that shall be peculiar to it, and differentiate it from the drama; they feel it can be accepted as an independent art; and since the problem of point of view certainly is peculiar to the novel they have rather overstressed it.''

title: EX-BARNARD BURSAR SEIZED AND CHARGED IN $240,000 THEFT
description: A former bursar at Barnard College was arrested yesterday and charged with having embezzled more than $240,000 from the college.

title: CONCERT: SONATAS FOR TUBA
description: WEST 57th Street was closed to traffic on Sunday afternoon - the Prime Minister of China, Zhao Ziyang, was visiting nearby and security was tight - but those who found their way to Carnegie Recital Hall were rewarded by an excellent and unusual concert. There, with the gifted Steven Harlos at the keyboard, Harvey Phillips presented a program of four recent sonatas for tuba and piano: works by Thomas Beversdorf, Walter Hartley, Alec Wilder and Paul Hindemith.

title: New President For Cosmair
description: Jean Levy, who began his career with L'Oreal Group of France, has been named president of Cosmair Inc., L'Oreal's exclusive cosmetic and fragrance licensee. The 51-year- old executive succeeds Lindsay Owen-Jones, who was named president of L'Oreal Worldwide.

title: Federal Judge Is Jailed For Drunken Driving
description: A Federal judge was found guilty of drunken driving today and sentenced to three days in jail starting next week.

title: STOCKMAN WARNS IMMIGRATION BILL MAY BE TOO COSTLY
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, has expressed new concern about a comprehensive immigration bill, saying the cost would probably be ''unacceptable.'' President Reagan has publicly supported such legislation.

title: MUSIC: LARRY KENT SINGS

title: Carter Leaves Hospital
description: Former President Jimmy Carter was released today from Emory University Hospital, where he underwent minor surgery for hemorrhoids, a spokesman said. Jane Simpson, of Mr. Carter's Atlanta office, said he had left for his home in Plains. Mr. Carter, 59 years old, was admitted at the hospital Sunday and had surgery Monday morning, she said, adding that there were no complications.

Far from qualifying as a fanatic's "nationalist" gesture, it is a grave assault on civilization everywhere.
