title: Comings and Goings
description: Reggie White , the all-America defensive tackle from Tennessee, has accepted a $4 million offer from the Memphis Showboats and plans to sign with the United States Football League club as soon as minor details are worked out, his agent, Bob Fargarson, said. . . . Gary McAdam, a former Devil right wing who was claimed on waivers by the Washington Capitals in November, has been reacquired by the Devils. . . . Archie Manning , the Minnsota Viking quarterback, who has been suffering from a thyroid problem, said he felt fine and was planning to be back for his 14th season next fall. . . . Another quarterback, Bill Kenney of the Kansas City Chiefs, has replaced Dan Marino of Miami on the American Conference roster for the Pro Bowl Jan. 29. Marino underwent knee surgery two weeks ago and has not received full clearance to play. Joe Theismann , the Washington Redskin quarterback, was named the most valuable player in the National Conference, and Curt Warner , the Seattle Seahawk running back, won the honor in the American Conference in balloting by league players.

title: College Basketball; North Carolina Holds Off Virginia, 69-66 CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan. 18 (AP) - Michael Jordan scored 23 points, including 3 in the closing moments, as unbeaten North Carolina held off Virginia, 69-66, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: THE U.S. NEGOTIATOR'S VIE OF GENEVA TALKS
description: -Ed page carried an article by Yuli Kvitsinsky, the Soviet Union's chief negotiator in the intermediate-range nuclear missile talks in Geneva, that was an abridged version of his first detailed personal account of the negotiations. Paul H. Nitze, the United States negotiator, offers the following account. WASHINGTON - In order to assess the significance of the Soviet Union's refusal to resume negotiations on intermediate-range nuclear forces, it is worth examining the evolution of those talks and the development, over time, of the United States' and Soviet Union's negotiating positions. Such an examination makes clear the lengths to which America is prepared to go in seeking an equitable, meaningful solution. Equally clear is Moscow's pursuit of a one-sided outcome that would preserve its military advantage and monopoly in this category of weapons. President Reagan and General Secretary Leonid I. Brezhnev publicly outlined their respective initial positions shortly before the I.N.F. negotiations began. During the initial round, the American delegation took the initiative and presented a draft treaty text that spelled out in detail how it thought the various issues could and should be dealt with. In the second round, the Soviet side clarified its position and submitted a draft treaty text spelling out its approach. By that time, both sides pretty thoroughly understood each other's positions and the issues dividing them. Ambassador Yuli Kvitsinsky had proved himself during these first two rounds to be sharp and intelligent, an accomplished diplomat able to rise above the deadening hand of the Soviet bureaucratic process.

title: U.S. Sues to Halt Beverly Takeover WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) - The Justice Department brought suit in an effort to prevent Beverly Enterprises, which operates more than 800 nursing homes, from acquiring another nursing home operator. The civil antitrust suit was filed in United States District Court in Macon, Ga., against Beverly, which has headquarters in Pasadena, Calif., and the target of its bid, Southern Medical Services Inc. of Birmingham, Ala.
description: The suit charges that the acquisition will violate the Clayton Act because it might substantially reduce competition among nursing homes in four cities in Georgia and Alabama.

title: THE RIGHT TO 'NO'
description: In 1969 I was a White House speechwriter and had just finished banging out the first draft of a Vietnam speech for the President. To keep every staff aide and his brother from fiddling with my prose, I typed across the top the impressive-looking words and acronyms that so frequently are used in the national security world: ''TOP SECRET SENSITIVE.'' To give that a little authentic zip, I added ''NOFORN, NOCONTRACT,'' which has to do with restricting the distribution from foreign allies and defense contractors.

STAGE: McKELLEN AND SHAKESPEARE
description: ''THE more I see his plays and the more I act in them,'' says Ian McKellen, ''the more I love this man.'' The man to whom Mr. McKellen refers is William Shakespeare, and the declaration of love is not loose talk. In his one-man show at the Ritz, this brilliant English actor makes us feel his affection (and our own) for Shakespeare, without ever lapsing into pomposity or sanctimoniousness. Even if ''Ian McKellen Acting Shakespeare'' were not an invigorating display of the actor's craft, it would still be enjoyable as a warm account of a man's lifelong love affair with the theater's greatest poet.

title: SCHOOL OF AMERICAN BALLET, AT 50, AS RIGOROUS AS EVER
description: At the School of American Ballet in Lincoln Center, the brown corridors are jeweled with antique prints and engravings depicting imperial St. Petersburg, 19th-century costume and stage design, French theater and opera. The rehearsal studios are more reminiscent of the old corral - lined on four sides with three-tiered wooden barres to fit dancers aged 8 to 20.

title: TV WEEKEND ; THE PRESS AND GRENADA
description: However one interprets the Grenada invasion, the press was one of its casualties. The press complained when the Reagan Administration kept reporters away from the invasion. Most Americans, meanwhile, apparently applauded. ''Inside Story,'' the public-television series that looks at the press, examines the phenomenon on PBS tonight. It finds something unprecedented, or, as former President Jimmy Carter says in an interview, ''steps more Draconian in nature, much more repressive in nature, than anything I remember in the history of our country.''

title: RULING IS UPHELD IN SUICIDE APPEAL
description: The California Supreme Court today let stand a ruling that Elizabeth Bouvia, a paralyzed 26-year-old victim of cerebral palsy, does not have the right to make society help her commit suicide.

title: IN JUDGING '85 BUDGET, REVIEW MILITARY AIMS
description: The Reagan Administration is discussing a hefty 17 percent defense budget increase for fiscal year 1985, to be followed by further increases in 1986, 1987 and 1988. This expensive program reflects an ambitious military strategy - a new combination of strategic goals and contingency plans that together significantly expand America's military requirements. Yet most of the new missions included in this strategy are unrealistically demanding, or dangerous, or peripheral to basic American aims. Accordingly, before Congress considers the Administration's specific requests for defense appropriations, it should take a second look at the underlying strategy and ask whether its goals are sound.

title: HARLAND, JOHN H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: The Ministry of International Trade and Industry has set the quotas for eight Japanese auto makers' exports to the United States, a leading Japanese economic daily reported today. The quotas cover the fiscal year beginning April 1.

title: ART: ANATOMY LESSONS BY LEONARDO
description: 1519) was undoubtedly the first person to describe in anatomical terms a smile on its way to happening. ''The muscles called lips of the mouth in narrowing themselves toward their center pull behind them the lateral muscles,'' he wrote on a sheet of drawings of mouth movements around 1506-8, ''and when the lateral muscles pull, so shortening themselves, then they pull behind them the lips of the mouth and so the mouth is extended, etc.'' Part of a large group of anatomical studies by Leonardo, this small sheet bears - along with far more clinical renderings - a slightly smiling pair of lips. They may or may not have to do with the subtle, mysterious smile of the ''Mona Lisa,'' on which he was probably working at the time.

title: Ronco's Parent May Reorganize CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (UPI) - An involuntary bankruptcy petition filed against Ronco Inc., the widely known distributor of household gadgets, may force its parent, Ronco Teleproducts Inc., and its other divisions into reorganization, a Ronco attorney said. Three creditors filed the petition Tuesday, contending that Ronco owes them more than $2 million.

Ellie Greenwich said the other day during a break in rehearsals for her show this weekend at the Bottom Line. The two-act theatrical production, titled ''Leader of the Pack'' and based on Miss Greenwich's life and times, features 33 of her songs and a cast of six - the others are Rory Dodd, Ula Hedwig, Bobby Jay, Hank Martin and Darlene Love. The first act is a musical biography with sets and costumes. In the second act, Miss Greenwich appears, performing for the first time in front of a live audience.

title: SCREEN: 'SCANDALOUS'
description: ''SCANDALOUS'' is a charmless caper movie that seems chiefly a pretext for the characters to keep changing their clothes. John Gielgud, as an aristocratic con man, appears in a punk outfit. Pamela Stephenson, as his fashionable niece, turns up as a redhead, a brunette and a blonde. Robert Hays, playing a television reporter, keeps a relatively low profile, but then he is supposed to be relatively naive. ''We wanted this movie, which is a murder mystery and a romantic comedy, to be both a souffle and a glass of white wine,'' Rob Cohen, the film's director and co- screenwriter, has said. Well, not every souffle rises.

title: CURTICE-BURNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 23
EX-AIDE IN MOSCOW
description: Panteleimon K. Ponomarenko, a Soviet guerrilla leader in World War II who rose to national prominence in the last five years of Stalin's rule, died Wednesday, the official press agency Tass reported in Moscow yesterday. He was 81 years old.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: MAYBE it's an outgrowth of equality for women, but every second lovely creature you see in a movie these days is toting a howitzer. Not only is Sondra Locke out there emasculating her enemies (and filling theaters, in Clint Eastwood's ''Sudden Impact''), but also in ''Deep in the Heart,'' at the Manhattan Twin, Karen Young practices with a .357 magnum Python, hoping it will help her retaliate against a white-collar rapist. And in ''Angel,'' Donna Wilkes picks up a cannon that weighs as much as she does, before tearing off to find a murderer who's been dismembering prostitutes.

title: STATE ADOPTS PLAN TO CUT BUILDING BY HOSPITALS IN CITY BY 50 PERCENT
description: About $2 billion in capital rebuilding proposed by major teaching hospitals in Manhattan would be cut by more than half in a plan approved yesterday by a key state health agency.

title: AN E.E.C. WARNING ON STEEL
description: Etienne Davignon, vice president of the European Economic Community's Executive Commission, warned today that European nations might end their curbs on steel exports if the Bethlehem Steel Corporation asked the Federal Government for protection against imports from all parts of the world.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press from Lansing, Mich., yesterday, about a settlement under which three Michigan prisons will be improved, incorrectly described a result of the settlement. It will avert the trial of a Federal lawsuit.

title: Rookie Starts Off Like Tour Veteran
description: Corey Pavin says he does not feel quite like a rookie on the PGA Tour, even though the 24-year-old former U.C.L.A. student played only his fifth round of tour golf today in the start of the $400,000 Phoenix Open.

title: Boxer Out of Coma
description: Stewart Darden , the boxer who lapsed into a coma after being injured during a fight Tuesday night, has regained consciousness after undergoing surgery at a San Diego hospital. But he is still in critical condition, the hospital said. The 24-year-old Darden, a junior welterweight, slumped to the canvass after being hit with an uppercut by Steve Acosta in the 10th round of their bout.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 20, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SCOUTING
description: Help Wanted

title: New Pact for MacLeod
description: Coach John MacLeod, coach of the Phoenix Suns, has signed a new multiyear contract, ending more than eight months of negotiations, the team said tonight. The announcement was made at a news conference just 90 minutes before the Suns defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 138-123.

title: Biegenwald Given New 10-Year Term
description: Richard Biegenwald, who has been sentenced to death for killing a Camden woman, today was given an additional 10 years in prison for weapons and drug charges related to the slaying, in 1982.

title: Mitterrands Visit Monaco
description: President Francois Mitterrand arrived here today on the first visit by a French leader in 23 years.

title: THRIFTIMART INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
MONDALE ATTACKS REAGAN AS WOMEN'S RIGHTS FOE
description: Walter F. Mondale, in one of his sharpest attacks on the Reagan Administration, said today that President Reagan and his appointees were ''radicals'' on the issue of women's rights and ''the Khomeinis of current American society.''

title: GLENN CAMP FIGHTS TO KEEP SMILING
description: For days the sidewalks have been full and the courthouses crowded, but something besides voters has been waiting for Senator John Glenn in a campaign tour in the South. He has also been greeted by bad news.

title: FINANCIAL SERVICE POSTS FILLED BY AMERICAN CAN
description: The American Can Company yesterday announced several top management appointments in its expanding financial services sector, including the promotions of Joseph Fafian Jr., 44, and John T. Sharpe, 47.

title: BANK OF BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN'S MAN ON BLUE COLLAR VOTERS
description: Roger J. Stone wears $600 Savile Row suits and red suspenders from Bergdorf Goodman. He drives a Mercedes Benz sports coupe fitted with a telephone, and likes to lunch at the ''21'' Club in Manhattan with the lawyer Roy M. Cohn and the publisher Rupert Murdoch.

title: AUCTIONS
description: NOBODY knows for sure who made or first owned the rare Federal card table that has become the most talked-about lot in the Americana sales set for next week at three New York auction houses. But the specialists at Sotheby's confidently attribute the carving of a basket of fruit and flowers on the front of the late-1790's table and the rosettes and channeling in the frieze edging the top to Samuel McIntire, the Salem, Mass., architect. The oversize table will be auctioned in the last session of three days of sales next Thursday, Friday and Saturday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. in Sotheby's galleries at York Avenue and 72d Street.

title: MISS SUMMERS IN SKATE LEAD
description: Rival buttons, some disputed scoring and a swarm of spectators and reporters greeted Rosalynn Sumners and Elaine Zayak today for the women's compulsory figures at the national figure skating championships.

title: Mayer Cuts Prima Stake
description: Oscar Mayer & Company has cut its stake in Prima Meat Packers Ltd. of Japan to 10.04 percent, from 24.85 percent, Prima said today. Oscar Mayer, a unit of the General Foods Corporation, sold 14.8 percent of Prima's stock Wednesday to 13 Japanese concerns, including C. Itoh & Company.

title: Britain in Protest to Greece Over Its Antimissile Appeal
description: The Greek Government said today that it had received a protest from Britain over the appeal with Rumania that the deployment of nuclear missiles in Europe be ended.

title: N.C.A.A. Adopts New Kickoff Rule
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association Football Rules Committee has adopted several rules changes for the 1984 season, including one on touchbacks on kickoffs.

title: KENTUCKY UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains reflecting the effect of an accounting change of $480,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $13,637,000, or 76 cents a share, for the year.

title: PHONE ACCESS FEE DELAYED UNTIL '85
description: The Federal Communications Commission, citing public pressure, voted today to delay until 1985 the imposition of monthly charges to connect homes and small businesses to the telephone system.

title: Montana Power
description: A $117 million bond offering by Forsyth, Mont., to finance pollution control facilities for the Montana Power Company is offered through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Reaching into its permanent collection, the Whitney Museum of American Art, Fairfield County - the branch of the institution in Stamford, Conn. - will display more than 50 works by Alexander Calder today through March 21. Calder (1898-1976), who came from a family of artists and who was trained in mechanical engineering, introduced the notion of motion in sculpture by creating mobiles, one of which, ''Dots and Dashes'' (1959), is in the show. Other works include some of his large, free- standing metal sculptures, wood sculptures, drawings, tapestries, prints, a painting and jewelry. The museum, at Atlantic Street and Tresser Boulevard, is open free Tuesday through Saturday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Information: (203) 358-7630. HENRY STREET MEMORIES

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Money Fund Assets Rise Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $133 million, to $164.73 billion, in the period ended Wednesday, the second consecutive increase, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.
description: In the previous week, the assets rose $1.1 billion, the largest weekly increase in 14 months. The past week's increase, while smaller, was also the first time in 10 weeks that assets rose in all categories of money market funds.

title: Bass Family's Texaco Stake The Bass family of Texas told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in Texaco Inc. to 18.5 million shares, or 7.2 percent, Texaco said. Texaco said that Sid R. Bass and others in the family have been big shareholders in the company ''for some time.'' It said Mr. Bass had informed Texaco that he supports the company's proposed acquisition of the Getty Oil Company.
description: Stock holdings must be made public once they reach 5 percent, and since no disclosure had been made until now, analysts noted, the family must have increased its purchases in the last few weeks, or since the deal with Getty was first proposed. At Texaco's $38.37 1/2 close yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, the family's stake was worth $710 million.

Utility Panel's Plan Rejected SEATTLE, Jan. 19 (AP) - A national bondholders committee has rejected a special panel's recommendations for resolving a dispute over the Washington Public Power Supply System's default on a $2.25 billion debt for two terminated nuclear plants.
description: The committee, which reviewed a report by the specially appointed Luce Commission, said the courts might offer the only solutions. The Luce Commission was appointed by Gov. John Spellman of Washington and Gov. Vic Atiyeh of Oregon last fall.

title: Psst! About That Immigration Bill . . .
description: In Washington, city of lawyers, there's one respect in which lawyers are not needed. Opportunities for legislative evasion are endless, but when political practitioners give their word they require no contracts. When they strike a bargain, it can be counted on. Usually.

title: Penalty Ruling
description: Brian O'Neill , the National Hockey League executive vice president, ruled that a two-game suspension served by the Boston Bruins' Mike Milbury was adequate for a match penalty incurred during a game against the Pittsburgh Penguins last Saturday. In accordance with N.H.L. bylaws, Milbury was automatically suspended after being assessed the match penalty.

description: Results for 1983 include the operations of J. C. Carter Co. and two other units acquired by Armatron last year.

title: TIMES SQUARE SUBWAY FIRE FORCES THOUSANDS TO STREET
description: A smoky fire just north of the Times Square station yesterday afternoon halted subway service on a large part of the West Side and forced thousands of rush-hour travelers from the station.

title: Argentine Prelate Says Pope Plans Visit in Island Dispute
description: Pope John Paul II will visit Argentina to bring to a close his mediation effort in the Beagle Channel dispute with Chile, Juan Carlos Cardinal Aramburu of Buenos Aires said today.

title: WOMEN, ANGRY, MAY GAIN
description: This year, the 11th anniversary of the Supreme Court's decision legalizing abortion, brings the possibility of a breakthrough in abortion rights. It should, in fact, be a breakthrough political year for women. For, no matter who becomes the Democratic candidate, his prospects may depend on successfully making women's issues crucial in the Presidential and Congressional campaigns.

title: A GALA SALUTE TO MAINBOCHER
description: Thirteen years after he closed his couture salon on Fifth Avenue and eight years after his death in Munich, Main Rousseau Bocher was honored at the Plaza Hotel Wednesday night. Several hundred admirers, including clients and fashion people, gathered to celebrate the designer whose work spanned almost 50 years in the middle of this century. It was a benefit for the Girl Scouts.

title: THREE CIVILIANS DIE AS MILITIA GROUPS BATTLE IN LEBANON
description: Three civilians were killed and eight wounded in clashes today between two pro-Syrian Lebanese militia forces in northern Lebanon.

title: KOCH'S UNABASHED MEMOIR: FANS AND FOES WONDER WHY HE WROTE IN NOW
description: Why did he do it?

Two Steelmakers Set Venture
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the Inland Steel Company announced yesterday that they had agreed in principle to jointly develop an electrogalvanizing capacity to meet the automobile industry's demands for rust-resistant steel.

title: CERMETEK MICROELECTRONCS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE EVENING HOURS
description: WHAT do you think of a man who gives with one hand and takes it back with the other, to wit, John Coleman, who owns the Ritz-Carlton Hotel? Mr. Coleman gave the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association a rather grand donation for its 10th anniversary auction celebration Tuesday night. The gift was a private dinner for up to 120 guests at the Jockey Club restaurant in the hotel. So who do you think ended up with it? None other than Mr. Coleman, who wrote out a check for more than $10,000 for the privilege of being the host of a party in his own restaurant. Who's going to be entertained? It will be a surprise, he said.

title: Yonkers Says It Needs a Loan
description: Mayor Angelo Martinelli said today that a $12 million loan from the state was the only way the City of Yonkers would be able to cover its budget deficit for this year.

title: BANCAL TRI-STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $553,000.

title: PANEL CALLS FOR CHANGES TO LIMIT GROUPS' INFLUENCE ON CAMPAIGNS
description: A special study group headed by Edmund S. Muskie, a former Secretary of State, recommended today that Congress limit the amount of money political action committees may give a candidate. It also urged an increase in the ceiling on individual contributions to political parties.

title: PIONEER STANDARD ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN AND CONGRESS ASSAILED ON PLIGHT OF BLACKS
description: The National Urban League charged today that the Reagan Administration and Congress were displaying a complaceny toward the plight of blacks and the economically deprived that bordered on ''the callous.''

title: BUDGET INCLUDES CUT IN TAX RATE IN ESSEX COUNTY
description: The Essex County Executive proposed a $301 million budget today that provides for a 5.5-point reduction in the tax rate.

title: APPEALS COURT UPHOLDS S.E.C.'S NEWSLETTER BAN
description: An appeals court has ruled that the Securities and Exchange Commission may prohibit the publication of an investment newsletter because the publisher was convicted of crimes.

title: Zairian Leader Greets Israeli With Advice on Mideast Issue
description: President Mobutu Sese Seko told the visiting Israeli President, Chaim Herzog, that Israel would have to tackle the Palestinian issue more seriously to win peace in the Middle East, a Government spokesman said today.

title: EX-BATUS OFFICIAL JOINING CALVIN KLEIN
description: Robert J. Suslow, former chairman of the Batus Retail Division of Batus Inc., was named yesterday to be president of a new corporate entity for the Calvin Klein fashion business. The 50-year-old Mr. Suslow will also be an equity partner in the privately held company, which has annual sales of $500 million.

description: b-Year-ago share earnings are not available since the company only went public on Jan. 20, 1983.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a developer's offer to build a pedestrian tunnel between two Manhattan subway lines incorrectly quoted a member of the community board that backed the plan. The member, Brenda Levin, said, ''It is a functional improvement to the subway system, the type of amenity for which bonusable space will benefit people living in and traveling to and from Queens, as well as people living and working in Manhattan.''

title: A TRIUMPH FOR HANDEL
description: ''Rinaldo,'' the sixth of Handel's 46 operas, was the first he composed for London. The first of his ''magic operas,'' it was a triumph at its premiere on Feb. 24, 1711, partly owing to lavish stage effects.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS College Basketball
description: Kentucky vs. Vanderbilt, at Lexington, Ky. Kentucky will be trying to get back on the winning track after losing two straight Southeastern Conference games, to Auburn and Florida. (Television - WTBS, 8 P.M.)

AT THE ARMORY, THE GREATEST CURIO SHOP IN AMERICA
description: PEDIGREE antiques from farmhouses and palaces reign side by side at the 30th annual Winter Antiques Show, which opens tomorrow for a nine-day run at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street. The bazaar, which is considered the country's most important event for secondhand wares, has once again transformed the arsenal's vaulted, sprawling interiors into a flower-filled setting of curiosity shops, in which 72 dealers offer wares they have saved for this show - antiques that they consider among the most exotic, exciting or exquisite to be found anywhere.

Last month, the former welterweight champion's lawyer, Mike Trainer , called John Condon , the president of the Garden's boxing department, asking about the availability of that date.

title: Europe as Little Old Lady
description: In his recent book, ''The Europeans,'' Luigi Barzini wisely writes of the United States: ''No matter who the President is, whether he is well up on foreign affairs or not, whether he leads or forgets to lead the West, no matter how well or badly armed the American defense establishment is, and no matter what the American foreign policy is at the moment, hard or soft, a large number of Europeans will not be pleased.''

title: CHINA SAID TO JAIL EX-U.S. ATTORNEY
description: Two years ago, Hanson Huang, a Hong Kong-born, Harvard-trained lawyer and a former partner in a major New York law firm, disappeared from his hotel room while on an extended visit to Peking.

description: Walls were still being plastered yesterday morning. The slate floors were still being scrubbed. The final touches were being applied to the electronic information booths in the lobbies.

SATURDAY, JANUARY 21, 1984 International
description: Egypt, Jordan and the P.L.O. will meet in March or April to work out a new approach toward resuming negotiations for the return of Israeli-occupied territories, Egypt's senior foreign policy adviser to President Hosni Mubarak said. The adviser, Osama el-Baz, said, ''Since the time is not right for Israel to join us, the United States should act as a go-between.'' (Page 1, Column 2.) A meeting in London between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Donald Rumsfeld, President Reagan's special Middle East envoy, encouraged speculation that the United States and three of its major European allies were actively seeking some alternative to keeping their military forces in Lebanon. (5:2.)

description: President Reagan said Friday that the meeting this week between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union ''did not resolve our differences,'' but that it had helped in reducing world tensions.

description: New York City's Board of Ethics announced new guidelines yesterday that require municipal employees to report to their superiors whenever they accept more than $5 in food or refreshments from anyone doing business with the city.

title: AMFAC TO SELL 12% OF ASSETS
description: Amfac Inc., Hawaii's largest company, said yesterday that it would divest itself of $177 million in assets, or 12 percent of the company, and take a $25 million one-time charge against earnings in 1983. Preliminary results indicate that Amfac will post a loss of $68 million in 1983; earnings are to be reported Thursday.

PISTOL MANUFACTURER FOUND NOT LIABLE FOR INJURY ITS PRODUCT CAUSED
description: A jury of four men and eight women decided today that the manufacturer and seller of a pistol that crippled a Texas teen-ager six years ago were not liable for his injury.

title: Peabody Buys Armco Mines
description: Armco Inc. said it had signed an agreement to sell its West Virginia coal mines to Peabody Holding Company Inc. of St. Louis for $257 million. Peabody will pay at least $142 million when it takes over the coal properties Feb. 27, Armco said.

description: Six Democratic Presidential aspirants will face an audience of about 2,500 people here Saturday in a forum on farm policy that could have a heavy impact on how they fare in Iowa's precinct caucuses, now only a month away, and in other agricultural areas.

HOW BROADWAY COPES WITH THE JANUARY BLAHS
description: Some compare it to locusts, others to taxes. In the realm of the inevitable, Broadway has the January doldrums. It happens every year - the valley in ticket sales between the peaks of Christmas week and the February school vacations. Only the degree differs.

title: LONDON ROBBERS GET MILLION IN GEMS AT CHRISTIE'S
description: Robbers armed with sawed-off shotguns invaded the showrooms at Christie's today and made off with jewelry valued at more than $1 million.

description: To the Editor:

title: FED LETS CITICORP BUY 2 THRIFT UNITS
description: In a further erosion of Federal laws barring interstate banking, a divided Federal Reserve Board today gave Citicorp of New York permission to acquire savings and loan associations in Florida and Illinois.

title: Downhill Put Off
description: Bad weather forced postponement until Saturday of the women's World Cup downhill race that was scheduled for today.

title: SPAN-AMERICA MEDICAL SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dow Jones Link
description: Dow Jones & Company, a business news service company and publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said it had bought stock in the CDEX Corporation of Los Altos, Calif., for an undisclosed price. The company develops and markets software used by businesses and consumers. Late in 1983 Dow Jones purchased stock interests in two other software companies - Software Ventures Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., and Planning Economics Software of Boston.

title: Rose Finds a Spot
description: At the age of 42, Pete Rose is not as strong at the plate as he once was and his defensive skills are not as sharp, but when he was introduced by his new team, the Montreal Expos, yesterday, Rose took pains to make clear that he had more than his reputation for leadership to offer. ''All they are going to do is see me play hard,'' Rose said.

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday on the earnings of the BankAmerica Corporation misattributed a special $31 million gain. It occurred in the fourth quarter of 1982.

title: GOVERNORS AND REAGAN TALK ABOUT ACID RAIN
description: A group of Northeastern and Middle Western governors said after a White House meeting today that they had received no commitment from President Reagan that he would take immediate action to curb acid rain.

title: Le Monde, Bastion of Words, Now Publishes More Photos
description: Le Monde took a cautious step toward changing its image today by starting to publish photographs on a regular basis.

title: HEAD OF AQUINO PANEL DOUBTS MANILA'S ACCOUNT
description: The chairman of an inquiry into the murder of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. said today that the panel had cause to doubt that the man blamed by the Government was the real killer.

title: Former Boston Mayor To Teach at University
description: Kevin H. White, who stepped down as Mayor of Boston this month after 16 years in office, has been appointed a professor of communication and public management at Boston University, the school's president has announced.

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: WHICH came first, the increase in chicken prices or the increase in egg prices?

title: Equal Rights in Boulder
description: The Boulder Office of Human Rights has banned ''Ladies' Nights'' in bars, and any other specials with discounts limited to women, on the ground that such events discriminate against men. Businesses that ignore the ruling made Thursday can face fines of up to $300 a day.

title: FOURTH FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Military Contracts
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, a major military contractor, said that it had received a $210.2 million order from the Air Force for spare parts for airframes and flight systems for the B-1B bomber. The Air Force also awarded TRW Inc. a $27.1 million contract for the satellite communications program; the Eaton Corporation a $17.5 million contract for maintenance of data processing systems, and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation a $13 million contract for F-15 fighter plane fuel tanks.

title: U.S. AND BRITAIN DISCUSS ALTERNATIVES FOR LEBANON
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher met tonight with Donald Rumsfeld, President Reagan's special envoy to the Middle East, amid signs the United States and three of its European allies were seeking some alternative to keeping military forces in Lebanon.

title: THE REGION ;  Williams Spends FirstDayinPrison
description: A spokesman for the Allenwood Federal Prison Camp said today that former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey spent his first day at Allenwood ''just orienting himself to the institution.''

title: Poland Calls U.S. Move On Sanctions 'Illusory'
description: The state- controlled Polish press today reported the easing of two American economic sanctions against Poland and urged the United States to end all the restrictions imposed after martial law was declared two years ago.

title: Judge Anthony Julian Of U.S. Court in Boston
description: Federal District Judge Anthony Julian died Wednesday of a heart condition. Judge Julian, 81 years old, was stricken at his home here and died on the way to the hospital.

title: Yugoslav Road Crash Kills 6
description: Six people were killed and 25 injured when a bus and a truck collided near the central Yugoslav town of Banya Luka today, the official Tanyug press agency said.

description: Officials today expelled four people arrested in an investigation of the railway bombings Dec. 31 that killed five people, judicial officials said.

title: Grundig Gets Bid
description: Grundig A.G. and N.V. Philips' Gloeilampenfabrieken have held preliminary talks with the Federal Cartel Office on the planned takeover of Grundig by a Philips-led consortium, but have not yet formally presented the merger plan for approval, a cartel office spokesman said. He said the concerns had agreed to submit the plan by the beginning of February at the latest. He declined details on the takeover, but said it could involve a major restructuring of Grundig.

title: A No to the Garden
description: When Sugar Ray Leonard tried to book Madison Square Garden for his comeback bout against Kevin Howard on Feb. 25, the Garden said ''no,'' because it had already said ''yes'' to Yes, a rock group that had scheduled a concert for the same night. Then illness forced Yes to say ''no'' to the Garden date and the Garden offered it to Leonard. Yesterday, Leonard's lawyer, Mike Trainer , who had already made plans to hold the fight in Atlantic City, gave the Garden his answer - ''no, thank you.''

title: PATENTS
description: Colgate-Palmolive

title: SUIT BY LAWYER OVER BABY JANE DOE IS THROWN OUT
description: A Federal judge today refused to appoint a legal guardian for Baby Jane Doe, a severely handicapped infant whose parents decided against life-prolonging surgery, and fined the lawyer who had filed the motion.

title: Talvela in Recital
description: The bass Martti Talvela will present a recital at the Metropolitan Opera House tomorrow at 5 P.M. The program will include two arias from Haydn's ''The Seasons,'' Loewe's ''Odin's Meeresritt,'' Brahms's ''Vier Ernste Ges"ange,'' Mussorgsky's ''Songs and Dances of Death'' and selections by Rimsky-Korsakov and Yrjo Kilpinen. James Levine will be the piano accompanist. Tickets are $7.50 to $17.50 at the Metropolitan Opera box office: 362-6000.

title: PRINTERS' UNION ORDERS NEW VOTE FOR ITS TOP OFFICE AFTER MARCH 31
description: The International Typographical Union ordered a new election for president today after concluding that ''at least nine'' local unions had improperly used members' dues money to finance the campaign of the successful candidate, Bob McMichen.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET TO DISCUSS A-ARMS PACTS
description: Soviet and United States delegates to a body that discusses compliance with nuclear arms control agreements will meet again in Geneva, probably in late March, American officials said today.

title: SEASON IS TOO LONG FOR GIBBS
description: For most teams the football season is too short. For Joe Gibbs, whose Washington Redskins have played in more games than any other National Football League team the last two seasons, the season is too long.

title: MARCHI STUDIES HUNTERS POINT FOR A STADIUM
description: State Senator John J. Marchi who had been a key opponent of legislation to permit large-scale waterfront development in Hunters Point, Queens, and Hoboken, N.J., said yesterday that he believed his objections were close to being resolved and that a bill could be passed in the next few months.

title: Wisconsin Shake-Up
description: Elroy Hirsch , the University of Wisconsin's athletic director for the last 15 years, was stripped of many of his duties yesterday but was allowed to continue in the position. In a shake- up prompted by football recruiting violations, the school's athletic board promoted Ralph Neale , an associate athletic director, to deputy director and gave him direct responsibility for all personnel and fiscal administration, leaving Hirsch little more than his title. At the same time, the school's chancellor, Irving Shain , said that Coach Dave McClain and his recruiting coordinator, Jerry Fishbain , would be given letters of reprimand for the recruiting violations uncovered in an N.C.A.A. investigation last year.

title: 2 MORE FOUND GUILTY FOR REFUSING TO TALK IN F.A.L.N. INQUIRY
description: Two advocates of Puerto Rican independence, the eighth and ninth in the last year, were found guilty yesterday of criminal contempt of court for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating nearly 40 unsolved New York City bombings.

title: Tribune Co. to Sell 5 Florida Units WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) - The Justice Department filed a proposed consent decree requiring the Tribune Company of Chicago and its Florida subsidiary to sell two shopping guides and three weekly newspapers in Osceola County, Fla.
description: Attorney General William French Smith said the consent judgment was filed in United States District Court in Orlando, Fla., and will become final on approval by the court. The Government and the companies agreed to the order to settle a civil antitrust suit filed by the Justice Department on May 16, 1982, against the Tribune Company and the Sentinel Star Company, predecessor to the current Florida subsidiary, Sentinel Communications Company of Orlando. The two shopping guides and three weeklies were acquired in 1980 by the Sentinel Star Company.

title: County Center May Be Expanded
description: A proposal to renovate and expand the Westchester County Center for $10.4 million was announced here today by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: Justice in the Open
description: Public trials have been a valued legal tradition at least since early England, when justice was dispensed at town meetings. Four years ago the Supreme Court spelled out in bold letters that ''a presumption of openness inheres in the very nature of a criminal trial in our system of justice.''

title: 2 CLOSING BIRDIES HELP STRANGE TO 66
description: A little bit of luck on a green shaped like a four-leaf clover and a strange bounce on the next hole helped Curtis Strange close with two birdies today. That finish gave Strange a five-under-par 66 for a total of 134 midway through the $400,000 Phoenix Open.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: . . . And Enlightenment

title: UNFORTUNATE CHILDREN INSPIRE CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: The personal interests or experiences of many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund lead them to ask that their gifts be used to ease the plight of abused youngsters or hard-pressed single-parent families.

title: SOHIO WRITE OFF 2 BEAUFORT TRACTS
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said yesterday that it would take a fourth-quarter after-tax write-off of $163 million after having failed to find oil in what was considered a promising tract off Alaska's North Slope.

description: The Reagan Administration celebrated itself today with all the verve needed for a full-fledged re-election campaign: boastful oratory about its record, self- confident denunciations of the opposition and flag waving on a grand and brassy scale.

title: Max Bentley, 63, a Member Of the Hockey Hall of Fame
description: Max Bentley, a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame, died late Thursday. He was 63 years old.

title: DEMOCRATS REJECT COMPROMISE PLAN ON DELEGATE RULES

title: LOUISIANA GOVERNOR TAKES A PARIS TRIP WITH BACKERS
description: On an eight- day European trip accompanied by more than 600 political followers, Edwin Edwards, the Governor-elect of Louisiana, saluted his state's ''French cousins'' today by laying a wreath at the Arc de Triomphe.

title: M
description: One person was killed this evening when a Metro-North commuter train slammed into an automobile at the Camp Avenue grade crossing on the New Canaan branch line, the police reported.

Her cards and those of the dealer appeared on the screen and Mrs. Maher could either push a button asking for an additional card or one indicating she would stand.

title: AVOIDABLE NEW YORK POLLUTION
description: As a mass-transit activist, I was bemused by Governor Cuomo's recent attack on Midwestern states for producing wind-carried air pollution that eventually produces acid rain in New York. By virtue of its heavy bias toward trucks and cars over buses and trains, New York itself produces huge amounts of air pollution that not only befoul its own atmosphere but also that of Connecticut and other New England states.

Last night, over 2,500 people had purchased $150 tickets for the patrons' party and $90 tickets for the preview party - both events which marked the opening of the Annual Winter Antiques Show.

description: The senior member of the House Veterans Affairs Committee today called for an international study of whether Agent Orange, a herbicide used to defoliate trees and kill crops in the Vietnam War, had caused harm to the Vietnamese who were exposed to it.

description: Dr. Lewis L. Robbins, medical director of the Hillside Division of Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center for 20 years, died Tuesday at Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I..

title: OFFICIALS CITE A RISE IN KILLERS WHO ROAM U.S. FOR VICTIMS
description: Law-enforcement officials report growing evidence of a substantial increase in the number of killers who strike again and again, sometimes traveling from city to city, choosing strangers as victims, then moving on to kill again. They say the killers are extremely difficult to catch because they are often highly intelligent, kill without apparent motive and leave few clues. Most people commonly call such killers mass murderers, but Justice Department officials draw a distinction between ''mass murderers,'' whose multiple killings usually occur in one spot at one time, and ''serial murderers,'' who kill repeatedly over a period of time, often over a wide area. According to a Justice Department study, there have been more than 30 cases in the past decade in which a single killer has murdered at least six people over a period of time, in most cases choosing strangers as the victims. In the past five years alone, the study said, there have been at least 17 men who over time killed a minimum of 10 people each and at least nine who killed 20 people or more. Investigators here said they believe that one man has killed at least 13 girls and young women, and possibly as many as 21, in the past 18 months. The killer is called the ''Green River Killer'' because he dumped the bodies of some of his victims beside a scenic river southeast of here. Law-enforcement officials say there have been isolated examples of such criminals in the past, including ''Jack the Ripper,'' who terrorized prostitutes in 19th century London.

title: G.I. ADMITS KIDNAPPING HOAX
description: A 21-year-old United States soldier who a week ago asserted that he had been kidnapped by West German antimissile activists has admitted that the story was a hoax, a local prosecutor said today.

title: Letter: On Nuclear Power The Non-Economics of Nine Mile 2 To the Editor:
description: Your Jan. 7 editorial ''New York's Other Nuclear Elephant,'' referring to the Nine Mile 2 nuclear power plant being constructed near Oswego, N.Y., focuses correctly on the huge escalation in the estimated cost of building the plant, from $400 million in 1971 to $5 billion today, with no guarantee that the latest estimate won't again be raised and the target date pushed further into the future.

title: Sarasota Editors Appointed

Waldo Proffitt Jr., editorial director of The Herald-Tribune, will become editor of the Sarasota newspaper, which is owned by The New York Times Company. In announcing the appointments, Elven Grubbs, the publisher, said C. Edward Pierce would remain as managing editor.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, JANUARY 21, 1984
description: The Economy The economy grew at a 4.5 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter and inflation remained subdued, the Commerce Department reported. The rate, although less than half the 9.7 percent surge of last spring, was seen as encouraging by officials. However, they said high interest rates and the high- valued dollar, linked by many economists to Federal budget deficits, had caused a sharp deterioration in the trade balance and had stunted what otherwise would have been much stronger growth in the economy. (Page 1.)

title: EGYPT PLANNING MOVE ON TALKS OVER WEST BANK
description: President Hosni Mubarak's senior foreign policy adviser said Friday that Egypt, Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization would meet in March or April to work out a new approach on negotiations for the return of Israeli-occupied territories. ''Since the time is not right for Israel to join us,'' the adviser, Osama el-Baz, said in an interview, ''the United States should act as a go-between.'' He also called on President Reagan to appoint a high-level panel to review and reassess the Middle Eastern policies of the United States in the same way that a commission headed by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger recently completed a study on Central America. Mr. Baz made his remarks in a rare interview granted one day after the Islamic Conference decided to invite Egypt to resume its membership in the organization, from which it was suspended after it signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1979. The presidential adviser said the invitation, extended Thursday at a meeting of Islamic leaders in Casablanca, Morocco, was ''a corrective step in recognition of the role Egypt has played in the past, that it now plays and will play in the future struggle for the Arab and Palestinian cause.'' But he said the Egyptian government had reserved its decision on the invitation until it could be assured by a delegation from the meeting that no conditions had been attached. In Casablanca, it was announced that a delegation consisting of the foreign ministers of Pakistan, Guinea and Iraq and the secretary general of the Islamic Conference Organization, would visit Mubarak in Cairo soon.

title: HONDURANS SAID TO CHANGE COPTER STORY

title: Netherlands Bank

title: WET, HAPPY TAMPA BRACES FOR THE GAME
description: Ah, sweet bird of opportunity. Since last Saturday, the airplanes flying south from Washington have been filling with Redskin fans, wagging beer cans across the aisles at one another in high glee, rocking the cabins with bursts of the fight song of their beloved Hogs, bringing their portion of an estimated $60 million in Super Bowl spending here to Tampa, a city in thrall. In the coach section Tuesday night John Kiefer, who has warmed a seat in the Redskins' home stadiums 31 years, was content with his lot. He had his old friend and best man, their wives, four tickets to the Super Bowl and a week in a condominium on the Gulf of Mexico for $40 a night. He was impressed with the price. Last year, he had to pay $100 a night to root for the Redskins. But he thought about all the fans left behind in Washington with no tickets and predicted solemnly that Congress would mount an investigation. From the distant West Coast, in lesser numbers, have come the followers of the Los Angeles Raiders, the two air trains converging on a city giddy with a sense of coming of age and dripping with gray rain. In the wake of the hard Christmas freeze, Tampa's tropical foliage lies black and rubbery on the ground; its icy skyline of glassy new buildings reflects dense mist. But expectations here burn hot and bright. J. Leonard Levy, known as ''Super Fan'' here, remains unfazed.

title: OPERA: PREMIERE OF 'RINALDO' AT MET

The production, borrowed almost intact from Canada's National Arts Center, might have astonished or perplexed him in some ways, but he probably would have found it as entertaining, ultimately, as most of the audience at this premiere obviously did.

title: Beer by Anheuser ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20 (AP) - Anheuser-Busch Companies Inc. announced plans to introduce a new light alcohol beer in test markets across the country beginning April 1. ''This product, which will be priced at premium beer levels and will provide real beer taste, continues our longstanding approach of offering consumers the widest possible choice,'' said August A. Busch 3d, chairman and president of the company. Mr. Busch said the new product, which will be called ''L.A. from Anheuser-Busch,'' will have an alcohol content of about half that of regular beer. Anheuser-Busch, the world's largest brewer, sold more than 60 million barrels of beer last year, accounting for about one-third of all beer sold in the United States.;  Military Contracts The Rockwell International Corporation, a major military contractor, said that it had received a $210.2 million order from the Air Force for spare parts for airframes and flight systems for the B-1B bomber. title: DANCE: MULTIMEDIA 'BOYS' BREATH'
description: Gina Wendkos has created a mad world of inherent logic in her intriguingly named ''Boys' Breath,'' a wonderfully tacky new multimedia extravaganza seen on Wednesday at La Mama ETC Annex, where it will play through today. Miss Wendkos, a painter, conceived and directs the play in collaboration with Lynne Taylor-Corbett, a ballet choreographer who has worked with American Ballet Theater and the Pennsylvania Ballet. ''Boys' Breath'' depicts sexual and emotional abuse as seen through the eyes of a precocious little girl in an inventive evening that calls to mind a remarkable mix of the work of Robert Wilson, ''A Chorus Line'' and ''L'Enfant et les Sortil eges.''

title: SONY PREVAILS IN THE BETAMAX CASE
description: After months of indecision, the Supreme Court ruled on the bitterly contested Sony Betamax case - in Sony's favor. The decision, a close 5-to-4 vote, found that consumers who make video recordings of television programs at home do not violate copyright law, nor do companies that make and sell the machines and blank tapes. The decision spelled relief for the entire video recorder industry and was a blow to the motion picture business - Universal City and Walt Disney Productions in particular - which had gotten a favorable ruling in a California appeals court in 1981. The motion picture industry said it would fight on, seeking passage in Congress of a bill that would levy a user fee on video recorder sales and tapes. Thus, there's more lobbying ahead for Sony's American chief executive, Kenji Tamiya.

title: MIA FARROW AND HER DIRECTOR ON THEIR FILM COLLABORATION
description: No doubt you've seen a woman who looks like Woody Allen's latest heroine somewhere, someplace before - certainly not in one of Mr. Allen's earlier films, but maybe sipping daiquiris at the bar in Caesar's Palace or chain-smoking in some chintzy nightclub in New York. She wears ruffled shirts, tight slacks and a gold name chain around her neck; keeps her blonde hair teased in a 1950's ''do''; and she never goes anywhere - even at night - without a pair of sunglasses clamped firmly on her nose. When we first meet Tina Vitale in ''Broadway Danny Rose,'' she is screaming - in a nasal Brooklyn accent - at her fickle boyfriend on the phone. ''I don't buy it,'' she says, chomping fiercely on a stick of gum. ''You're lucky I don't stick an ice pick in your goddamned chest.''

title: HEADLINERS
description: Free and Clear Seldom is justice miscarried as far as it was in the case of Nathaniel Carter when he was convicted of murdering his former mother-in-law in 1982. Mr. Carter got 25 years to life in prison mainly because of the testimony of his former wife, Delissa Carter, who was granted immunity in the case. She swore he had broken into the Queens home she shared with her foster mother and attacked them both. Investigators who didn't believe her pursued the case, and last week the former Mrs. Carter admitted she had done the killing. Mr. Carter went free immediately, and, because of her immunity, it appeared his ex-wife would do likewise.

title: TAPETALK
description: Secretly recording telephone conversations may be ethically wrong, but the tapes are linguistically revealing. Here, on the relentlessly faithful magnetic tape, is the language unadorned, denuded of literary pretension and stripped of the requirements of public presentation. Tapetalk is the way people actually speak, and the willingness every decade or so of some officials - who have little concern for their callers' privacy - to push a button that preserves that speech gives the world a chance to eavesdrop on the lingo as she is spoke.

title: MISTAKE IN THE MASTER PLAN

title: Peter Prime, Miss Purcell Plan to Wed

By Mary Kelley. 409 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: A COMMUNITY COLLEGE MEASURES ITS ROLE

Hankin, the president of Westchester Community College, has a panoramic view of the 218-acre campus and a striking picture of what this 38-year-old institution once was, what it has become and what it strives to be.

title: EDUCATION COMMISSION OVERLOOKS NEED FOR CLERKS, TRUCKERS
description: IT is nice that the National Commission on Excellence in Education wants more academic courses, more homework, stricter grading, better people teaching. It is salutary for educators periodically to engage in self-criticism and for government commissions to issue calls for reform, zeal and rigor. It is fair that education gets some media attention and that politicians make speeches about it; but before every high school graduate reads Plato, takes calculus and becomes a sober grind; before our best and brightest college students forego money to become school masters; before we take ''A Nation at Risk: The Imperative for Educational Reform'' too seriously - a cautionary note and some stubborn facts.

title: DEVISING A TEST FOR HEART ATTACKS
description: ''BECAUSE the heart is a very primitive organ,'' said John Y. Kiyasu of Garden City, ''it can withstand the lack of oxygen for a fairly long time - anywhere from an hour and a half or two hours of a complete occlusion. Most heart attacks are not complete occlusions. Blockage is partial.

title: Adoption Information Available at Library
description: Adoption is very much in the news these days - in both a meaningful sense as reported in the article ''Adoption: What Is the Age to Tell?'' (Nov. 13, 1983) and in the debatable values attached to the adoption feature of the highly publicized Cabbage Patch dolls. The latter prompted Joseph A. title: MORE THAN POLITICS CLOGS UP THE CONGRESS

As they finished, a reporter collared Speaker O'Neill to ask about the second session of the 98th Congress, which begins tomorrow. The Speaker tossed back the judgment that in the early weeks, ''it'll mostly be Lebanon and Central America.'' More sweepingly, he added, ''Don't expect very much new legislation.''

title: New & Noteworthy; MINDS, MARKETS, AND MONEY
description: Psychological Foundations of Economic Behavior, by Shlomo Maital. (Basic Books, $7.95.) The Israeli economist Shlomo Maital aims ''to show how the concepts and methods of psychology beautifully complement and strengthen those of economics.'' ''If our intellect is to solve our economic problems,'' he argues with wit and conviction, ''it must first look into the ways of the heart.'' Our reviewer, Peter Passell, found this ''a delight, the rare important book about economics that charms as it informs.'' THE MAN WHO LIVED AT THE RITZ, by A. E. Hotchner. (Berkley, $3.50.) Set in Nazi-occupied France, ''The Man Who Lived at the Ritz'' is ''an oddly satisfying novel of intrigue and adventure'' that is haunted by the specter of Ernest Hemingway, Alan Cheuse observed in his review. Its central character, Philip Weber, is an American who appears to be a weak-willed dilettante until a murder ''sends him into the arms of the underground . . . and inspires him to become the kind of hero Papa Hemingway would be proud of.''

title: Writers Need Wide Vocabulary

Even though he gets more solo time than anyone else in the big band, the small-group setting provides a more fully rounded display of his playing.

title: TV VIEW
description: O nly 52 percent of the people who were eligible to vote in the last Presidential election did vote, a fact that may be regarded angrily, mournfully or simply shrugged off. Undeniably, however, in any measure of voter participation, the United States is near or at the bottom of the list of Western democracies. Moreover, in the past 20 years the percentage of people eligible to vote who did not vote has risen steadily. ''Who or what is responsible?'' an admirable ABC program, ''Voting for Democracy,'' asks right off the bat at 12:30 P.M. today, and then goes on to identify, if not the who's, then at least some what's. One what scarcely mentioned, however, is television itself.

title: COAL'S FUTURE COULD RIVAL ITS PAST
description: For nuclear power plants in the ''construction pipeline,'' recent days have been bad ones. The Public Service Company of Indiana terminated its Marble Hill project, nearly half-complete, after having invested $2.5 billion. Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company said yesterday that, because of the high cost of completing its Zimmer nuclear plant, it would try to convert the facility to burn coal. And Commonwealth Edison Company in Illinois, which managed to finish its Byron facility, was denied a license to operate.

title: THE STAGES TO SUCCESS
description: Progress in a chess-underdeveloped country can be observed by identifying several stages. In the first, a major international tournament is held and the prominent foreign players wipe out the local contingent. In the second stage, the prominent foreigners win heavily against the natives, but they drop a sensational game or two. In the third stage, the host country has produced several international masters and a grandmaster or two capable of taking frequent points from their more renowned visitors.

title: WHEN THE CAMERA DOES OUR SEEING FOR US
description: D ance on film is seen in so many different ways today that the term, ''dance film'' hardly remains meaningful. Is such a film a documentary about dance, dancers, a dance school or a dance company? Is it a filmed performance of a ballet or choreography created for film? Perhaps it is a feature film in which dance is used to advance the narrative. And perhaps it is even a blatantly commercial film in which dance is exploited (''Flashdance'') for its physical appeal and kinesthetic excitement - disguised as a plot element but actually of little help to the story. Is dance, in fact, becoming a pretext for filmmakers who aren't clear about their goals but who sense that dance on film is no longer restricted to specialist viewers?

title: THE BULL MARKET IN THE FAR EAST
description: OPTIMISM abounds on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. While the American securities markets have been backing and filling over the last seven months, and the Dow Jones industrial average has shown little ability to sustain its interim gains on the New York Stock Exchange, the Nikkei-Dow Jones stock index in Tokyo has continued an upward surge that began early in 1983. Just 13 days ago, the index broke 10,000 yen for the first time, and to hear brokers and analysts tell it, it could break 13,000 by the end of the year.

title: ON THE HUNT FOR ANTIQUES IN LONDON
description: London is full of antiques, in private homes (admire, but please don't touch) and scores and scores of shops (buy, but bear in mind that stocks are specialized and limited). To make the most of your time and see the widest array of antiques, you should acquaint yourself with three particular kinds of commercial enterprises: antiques centers, markets and fairs. The three terms are sometimes used interchangeably but the big difference usually lies in their degree of permanence. Antiques centers occupy fixed premises and operate from as many as four to six days a week in the same place; inside of each you will find as many as a hundred or more independent proprietors displaying merchandise in booths or small shops. Markets usually operate only one day (usually the same day) each week in a fixed place.

title: UNESCO IS NO GUIDE
description: The United States was right in announcing its intention to leave Unesco. To expect us to acquiesce in, not to mention actively support, the regulations proposed at the Paris conference on communications for control of the distribution of news is to expect us to spit in our soup, if you will excuse the vulgarity, and I am glad and proud that we did not do it.

title: FROM HOLOCAUST TO HOLLYWOOD
description: Thomas Keneally is an Australian writer whose most recent book is ''Schindler's List,'' which deals with the rescue of a number of Polish Jews in Krakow during World War II. ROMAN By Roman Polanski. Illustrated. 461 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $17.95.

title: WAR IN EL SALVADOR: A CRITICAL PHASE
description: MilitaryAnalysis

title: THE SPIRIT OF CONCILITATION IS AMONG BUDGET DELETIONS
description: When he was Lieutenant Governor, Mario Cuomo would sit back and watch Gov. Hugh L. Carey war with the Legislature. He didn't like what he saw. You have to talk to the legislators, he would explain, listen to their problems. You have to show them respect.

title: ALFONSIN'S MOVES MAKE FOR NERVOUS NEIGHBORS
description: On a clear day, a person looking across the broad River Plate from Buenos Aires can see the faint outlines of this small, troubled country, which has long been in Argentina's shadow. When eight years of military rule came to an end last month in Argentina and Raul Alfonsin became the elected President, there was a noticeable stirring here. Last week, labor unions closed down Montevideo during a 24-hour general strike, the first in a decade of military government.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: LINCOLN SQUARE
description: DANCERS step gracefully along the sidewalks, their slippered toes pointed outward, their hair tightly pulled into chignons and pinned into place. The sounds of street music complement their movements. The Chagall murals of the Metropolitan Opera House loom and the crowds lean forward with anticipation.

title: LET THE BETTORS BET, AND MAKE IT LEGAL
description: T HE gambler bets money voluntarily, is not coerced and has no

title: HEADLINERS
description: The Time Arrives Former Senator Harrison Williams Jr. has run out of appeals, motions, petitions and time.

title: Do Not Discount New Technology
description: In his article ''New Technology Does Not Teach'' (Jan. 1), Paul Q. Beeching claims that nonprint media are useless in the classroom. This claim is inaccurate and dangerous. If attended, it will aid those who would sustain mediocrity in the nation's schools.

title: Boxer's Benefit
description: A benefit for Sugar Ray Seales, the 31-year-old middleweight who lost nearly all of his sight to injuries in the ring, flopped financially in Tacoma, Wash., Friday night. The event was a failure despite the presence of big names in boxing and the entertainment industry.

title: ROOKIE LEADS BY 1 IN PHOENIX OPEN
description: Corey Pavin, a PGA Tour rookie, played today like an experienced golfer who does not get rattled by the big fellows and held onto a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the $400,000 Phoenix Open.

title: Jostling and Jamming at Geneva
description: The delegates to that international linguistic conference that resolved millennia ago to construct the tower of Babel at least reached agreement. A more daunting challenge faces the World Administrative Radio Conference now under way in Geneva.

title: 1,000 Hurt in Tokyo Snow
description: More than 1,000 people have been injured in falls on frozen streets since Thursday when Tokyo had its heaviest snowfall in 15 years, officials said today. They said 547 people had been admitted to hospitals and 471 sent home after treatment.

title: GALBRAITH ELECTED CHIEF OF ARTS GROUP
description: John Kenneth Galbraith, economist, author and former Ambassador, has been elected president of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, succeeding Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., historian, author and professor, who served for the last three years.

title: THE AMERICAN FAULT IN A GERMAN 'PROBLEM OF THE SPIRIT'
description: To the Editor:

BUSINESS FORUM;
A FREE RIDE FOR MANAGEMENT INSIDERS
description: IT is in Wall Street's nature to be up

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: A World Cruise By Private Jet Take one 707 jet reconfigured to hold 86 passengers in first class. Add an itinerary that begins in Los Angeles, ends in Miami and spans the world, with stops in Chile, New Zealand, Indonesia, Hong Kong, China, Thailand, Kenya, South Africa and Brazil. Spice it with such special attractions as a visit to the Rano Raruku Quarry on Easter Island, a ride aboard the Blue Train from Johannesburg to Cape Town and a cruise on the Yangtze River.

title: INTERPRETING THERESULTSOF THE YEARLY U.S. PHYSICAL
description: In the time-honored way Washington copes with an explosive issue, Mrs. Heckler appointed a task force to study the problem, the ''disparity in the burden of death, illness and disability'' for blacks and whites. Earlier this month several antipoverty groups asserted that cutbacks in Federal health and nutrition programs, made at the request of the Reagan Administration, were disproportionately harming poor people and members of minority groups. ''The Government already has a wealth of data that would justify immediate action to provide more health services,'' said Sara Rosenbaum of the Children's Defense Fund. But Charles Kline, a spokesman for Mrs. Heckler, said, ''The work of the task force will prove that it's not just a cosmetic effort.''

title: LABOR'S GAMBLE ON MONDALE
description: A. H. Raskin, for many years The Times's chief labor correspondent, is writing a history of the union movement since the New Deal. By A. H. Raskin ANE KIRKLAND IS NO plunger. When the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. makes one of his rare visits to a race track, he lines up at the $2 window with the truck drivers, the ditchdiggers and the ribbon clerks. Attending a union convention in Las Vegas or Atlantic City, he stops in at the casino just long enough to put a single quarter in a slot machine. The big-money gaming tables are not for him.

title: Armen Ordjanian Wed to Charles W. Elliott
description: Armen Susan Ordjanian, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nikit Ordjanian of Fresh Meadows, Queens, was married yesterday to Charles William Elliott, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Elliott of Easton, Pa. Archbishop Torkom Manoogian performed the ceremony at St. Vartan's Armenian Cathedral in Manhattan, assisted by Archbishop Tiran Nersoyan and the Rev. Arten Ashjian.

title: A 20-FOOTER AT :0001 BEAT KNICKS, 97-95
description: A 20-foot jumper is not a shot one would expect from a 7-foot-1-inch center. Yet that was the shot that beat the Knicks last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: DIPLOMAS SOUGHT FOR SPECIAL EDUCATION
description: ''I T made me feel horrible - I was mad,'' said Patricia Carbone Flynn. ''They never told me I wasn't getting a diploma until graduation.''

title: TAIWAN FENDS FOR ITSELF, AND THEN SOME
description: When the United States decided in 1979 to break relations with the Republic of China on Taiwan and to establish diplomatic ties with the People's Republic of China on the mainland, the stunned Nationalist Government got barely eight hours' warning.

title: KY AND WIFE 'ENJOYING LIFE' DESPITE FINANCIAL TROUBLES
description: ''We are enjoying life,'' said Nguyen Cao Ky, the former Prime Minister of South Vietnam, who was sitting with his wife in the Saigon Deli.

description: New York State mental health officials say there will be no funds to open or operate a new maximum-security hospital for the criminally insane on Wards Island.

ANTIQUES;
LIKE GOLD, SILVER CAN GLITTER, TOO
description: NEWARK U NTIL the late 1800's, very little was known about the work of Colonial silversmiths. It was assumed that affluent colonists had either brought their plate, as early silver pieces were called, with them or imported it from England.

STAMPS;
THE U.S. ISSUES ITS FIRST DEFINITVES FOR 1984
description: The first United States definitive of the year is a 20-cent stamp for the 100th anniversary of the birth of Harry S. Truman, more and more esteemed by Americans as one of the nation's outstanding Presidents. The stamp is in the Great Americans Series being issued this Thursday in Washington, D.C.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ALGARVE
description: Most visitors come to the the Algarve in summer, expanding the population of Portugal's southernmost coastal province from 300,000 to 800,000 - a throng that at times sorely strains electricity and water supplies. But for many, winter and spring in this subtropical region hold more delights.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Linda Martinson, Lawyer, to Marry
description: Linda Martinson, general counsel to Baron Capital Management, an investment concern in New York, and Christopher Mayer, a partner in the New York law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell, plan to be married in March.

description: Elizabeth Taylor checked out Friday from the drug and alcohol rehabilitation center she voluntary entered last month for treatment of dependency on prescription drugs.

description: The Reagan Administration is preparing a legal challenge to a decision by a Federal judge who ordered millions of dollars in back pay and raises for women found to have been paid less than men holding jobs of comparable worth.

title: SMALL BUT DELICIOUS SWISS TREAT
description: THE Swiss Cafe in Stamford reminds us of edelweiss - flowering in an unexpected place. Not high in the Alps like the flower, to be sure, this small Swiss restaurant is flourishing in a shopping mall.

title: WIDER ROLE FOR COMPUTERS IN STUDENT LIFE
description: Tuck's computer center has a new look: A mezzanine level above the existing mainframe terminals now houses 45 I.B.M. personal computers. Students have dubbed their new facility the ''PC Lounge.''

title: COMPENSATION RULE MAY BE CHANGED
description: When the Mets lost Tom Seaver to the Chicago White Sox on Friday, it underlined a situation that Marvin Miller and the players union tried diligently to prevent nearly three and a half years ago.

title: K. W. Spencer to Wed Lisa Shane Mendelson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Mendelson of Bedford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Shane Mendelson, to Kean William Spencer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Spencer of Bloomfield Village, Mich. An October wedding is planned.

description: Tom Seaver neared a decision yesterday on his baseball future, with strong indications that he would join the Chicago White Sox and continue his 17-year career.

description: CRITICISMS of leveraged buyouts seem to be proliferating almost as rapidly as the transactions themselves. Yet many of these criticisms are both misplaced in light of standard economic logic and simply unsupported by the available evidence.

description: Transit Troubles Back at the Shop

title:
ANTIQUES;
WEBSTER'S FAMOUS BOOKS
description: WEST HARTFORD S INCE the end of the Revolution in 1783, perhaps only two books, the Bible and McGuffey's Reader, sold more copies in this country than Noah Webster's familiar blue-backed spelling book. Some estimates declare the total sales to have reached 100 million copies a year by 1850. Remarkably, the book is still in print.

title: REGAN PROPOSES MEASURE TO CUT YEARLY BORROWING
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has proposed a constitutional amendment that is intended to reduce sharply the state's $4 billion annual spring borrowing, a practice long criticized by the financial community.

title: DANCE: DANIEL LEWIS AND ANNA SOKOLOW
description: Daniel Lewis is a noted graduate of the Juilliard School, where he now teaches, and he danced with Jose Limon, whose works he has staged. Given that background, it wasn't surprising that a program by Daniel Lewis Dance on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church was an evening of solid choreography performed by capable dancers.

title: CROWNING TOUCH
description: After decades of a trend in architectural design that produced high-rise structures with featureless rooflines, many developers now are demanding designed tops for their buildings that will make distinctive statements on the city's skyline.

title: MUSIC: JUILLIARD FESTIVAL OPENS WITH NOD AT PAST
description: Although the Juilliard School's Festival of Contemporary Music hardly pretends to present the cutting edge, most of its programs at least offer some music of today. But the festival's opening night on Friday in Alice Tully Hall was strictly a retrospective. Before the intermission, the looking backward was to the mid- 1950's; after that the view stretched all the way back to 1930.

title: THE REGION
description: Mall Gets Right To Bar Activists

title: Ice Cream Maker Wins Suit on Oral Contract
description: A jury has awarded $52 million in damages to an ice cream company that sued the McDonald's Corporation, asserting that McDonald's broke a 20-year-old handshake agreement made by its founder, Ray A. Kroc.

title: GOVERNORS SEEK DRINKING-AGE UNITY
description: Governor Cuomo and Gov. J. Joseph Garrahy of Rhode Island have opened a campaign for a uniform minimum drinking age in seven Northeastern states by asking legislators to raise the age in their states to 21.
