title: ONE TIRESOME EXTREME MAY HAVE BRED ANOTHER
description: Along time ago when I was starting out as a music reviewer, shortly after the Bronze Age, a young conductor collared me in a lobby and proceeded to upbraid me because I had shown so little enthusiasm for a celebrated atonal work that he had recently presented. ''I suppose,'' he said in winding up his indictment, ''you are one of those people who think music should go back to

title: GALLERIES ARE THE SEEDBEDSOF TOMORROW'S ART
description: P eople in the 1980's play art the way they play horses. They also play art the way they play the stock market, at no matter what level. Art in recent years has been judged by whether or not it ''performs.'' As a hedge against inflation, the paintings of J. M. W. Turner have ''performed'' in spectacular style, whereas the pound sterling has not. As a repository for hot money, moreover, art beats real estate, beats the stock market and beats the gold bar.

title:
DINING OUT;
FISH SPECIALTIES IN NORTH COUNTY
description: N EW restaurants usually take a couple of months to settle into their routine. Ordinarily we would give Elliotts', open almost two months, a little more time to smooth rough edges. However, because the north- central part of the county lacks a place such as this - informal yet elegant, the food promising - it is worth knowing about even now.

title: THE CODFISH FAMILY OFFERS SOME COLD-WEATHER VARIETY
description: ONCE, about the only fish you could be sure of finding in the market in winter was cod. And if fresh cod was not available there was always the salted kind, to soak for a day or more in several changes of water, then cook.

title: FINDING SHELF SPACEFOR NEW JERSEY HARVESTS
description: When New Jersey's farmers and agricultural officials gather this week in Cherry Hill for their annual convention, the theme could well be: ''Now that we grew it, what do we do with it?''

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: U.C.L.A. at Louisville. The Bruins are the defending Pacific-10 hampions, and the Cardinals are the defending Metro Conference champions. (Television - Channel 4, noon.)

title: ATLANTIC CITY SEEKS IMPROVED AIRPORTS
description: ATLANTIC CITY P ASSENGER use of Atlantic City's two airports rose by 65 percent last year, creating major congestion problems. The boom in air traffic is a result of charter flights to the resort's hotel-casinos and expansion of commercial service between here and Florida.

title: RELOCATION SERVICES ARE GROWING
description: A NDREA LINDSAY wanted a busy community in which to reestablish her successful advertising business. Kathy Masters hoped to find a job as an information specialist. Frankie Davies needed a large house with a garden and a good school for her two teen- agers.

title: UNIVERSITY AND SYRACUSE BATTLING IN COURT OVER STADIUM TAX STATUS
description: The 50,000- seat covered stadium here known as the Carrier Dome has brought big- name musicians, professional sports events and increased civic pride to this upstate city. It has also brought lawsuits and the possibility that Syracuse University may be forced to relinquish its tax-exempt status on the stadium.

title: NEW STIRRINGS OF PATRIOTISM
Gretzky Streak Alive at 49
description: Wayne Gretzky made two assists in the third period tonight to extend his consecutive scoring streak to 49 games and lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 6-3 triumph over the Los Angeles Kings. Gretzky, held pointless going into the final period, passed ahead to Glenn Anderson, who drilled in a 20-footer on the breakaway to snap a 3-3 tie with 18:32 to play. Gretzky later assisted on Pat Hughes's second goal with Edmonton a man short.

description: 1 1984, by George Orwell. (NAL/Signet, $2.95.) The classic 1949 novel about life in a society when Big Brother watches. 2 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) A car that kills is at large among a Pennyslvania town's high school set.

title: ILLEGAL SPORTS BETTING CALLED GROWING AND INTRACTABLE PROBLEM IN NEW YORK
description: Illegal sports betting is a thriving underground economy that law-enforcement officials say cuts across all segments of the New York region's population and remains an intractable problem.

description: STEVE KOVACK of Bridgeport, using two separate approaches, has accomplished the single goal of uncovering beauty in a city thought to be on the edge of decay.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: O N A tidal stream at the northern end of Barnegat Bay, a great blue heron alighted on a snow-covered bank. It waded for a while, looking for small fish or other prey; then, with a few strokes of its broad wings, it caught the winter wind and soared out toward the open water.

title: 'BEDROCK,' MARRIAGE THAT SURVIVES IT ALL
description: W HAT the playwright David Epstein has done successfully in ''Bedrock'' at the Hartman Theater is set up a grown-up premarital and marital relationship, kinks and everything.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT'S FEISTY CHAIRMAN-HE'S RELISHING THE INTENSE BATTLE OVER WARNER
description: HERBERT JAY SIEGEL, the wheeling and dealing chairman of Chris-Craft Industries who is now exchanging blows with Australian mogul Rupert Murdoch in the battle over control of Warner Communications, tells a favorite story about his late father, Jacob Siegel.

description: Edward Hoagland is the author of ''African Calliope: A Journey to the Sudan.'' AMAZON By Brian Kelly and Mark London. 382 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95.

title: CARVING OUT A NICHE FOR RELIGION
description: T he strategy at CBN, the Christian network that arrived this month on Manhattan Cable TV's channel S, goes something like this: Religious programming doesn't have to be preachy; but television entertainment doesn't have to be Godless.

description: Charles Michener is a New York editor and writer. O, HOW THE WHEEL BECOMES IT!

description: N ANCY SEAVER calls it a sports superstition: Never buy a house in the city where your husband plays because he will be traded to another team in another city.

title: Frank Emblen;  ARTISTRY ON ICE
description: When Charlie Tickner won a bronze medal at Lake Placid, N.Y. in 1980, he became the first American man in 12 years to annex an Olympic figure- skating prize. Now a professional, Mr. Tickner will be among the headliners when the Ice Capades takes over the Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford Tuesday through Sunday.

title: New Arena Is Riddle for Paris
description: In truth, this isn't much of a sports town. London roars for Arsenal or Tottenham; Paris usually yawns about Paris-St. Germain. A little racing at Longchamps or Auteuil, tennis for a couple of weeks at Roland Garros Stadium in the spring, maybe a boxing match now and then - the city's sporting passions are discreet, circumscribed.

title: TOWNS POISED TO REMOVE SIGNS
description: F OR sign companies on the East End, the rural countryside and farmland communities offered a fair return in the 1950's and early 60's. For $15 or so, a company could rent a spot in the middle of an open field, or on a vacant lot next to the local grocery store, and put up a large double billboard advertising the latest national product. So it was not surprising when Congress passed the Federal Highway Beautification Act in 1965 to stop the proliferation of roadside billboards.

title: Concerns Acquitted Of Conspiring to Rig Bids at Atom Plants
description: Four of the nation's largest electrical contracting companies and six of their executives were acquitted today of charges of conspiring to rig bids on nuclear power plants in Washington and Indiana.

title: Kenya
description: To the Editor: As an added note to Hugh Muir's article, ''Crossing Kenya on the 'Iron Snake' '' (Travel, Nov. 13), I would like to point out that an outstanding one-day outing can be made by rail to the town of Naivasha. The train goes north in the opposite direction from Mombasa.

title: WILL A BITTER,BLUSTERY WINTER GIVE WAY TO SPRING FLOODS?
description: Friday was officially proclaimed Weather Modification Day by Colorado's Gov. Richard D. Lamm, who ordered ''whatever forces are in charge of this polar onslaught cease and desist,'' and to return ''our pleasant winter weather.''

title: CONCERT: SHARON ISBIN
description: Sharon Isbin is a gifted young guitarist, one who combines digital proficiency with innate musicality. Miss Isbin opened her Tuesday evening concert at the Abraham Goodman House with a rendition of J. S. Bach's Suite (BWV 997), in an edition prepared by Rosalyn Tureck.

title: LETTING GO WHEN ADOLESCENCE CLAIMS A DAUGHTER
description: T HE morning sounds are birds, the starting of cars, and the drone of her hair dryer. I take the phone off the hook at dinner time. It would be for her again.

title: PRIVATE LAWYERS OFFER TO DEFEND THE POOR
description: A N argument over who can represent indigent criminal defendants in Suffolk County best and least expensively has the attention of county officials and lawyers who handle criminal cases in Suffolk courts.

title: Coaches Honored
description: Jack Bicknell of Boston College and Bob Ricca of St. John's have been named the top Eastern coaches for 1983 by the Football Writers Association of New York.

title: TIME FOR THE BAROQUE PERIOD

title: Hebert Holds Out
description: A contract dispute will keep the Michigan Panthers quarterback Bobby Hebert away when the training camp of the defending champions of the United States Football League opens next week.Hebert's agent, Greg Campbell , said his client is seeking to re-negotiate his contract before reporting to camp in Phoenix, Ariz.

title: IN YONKERS, A NEW CITY MANAGER AND A GROWING DEFICIT
description: Even before Rodney H. Irwin has finished one municipal budget in New Jersey, he is busy now thinking about fashioning a much larger one for Yonkers, where an impending budget gap assumed greater proportions last week.

title: A BRASS QUINTET AND TWO PIANISTS APPEAR IN RECITALS
description: Two pianists making their New York debut recitals last week opened with major late works by Beethoven, included Debussy in their programs, offered some eccentricities, and ended with music by notably original composers from their native lands.

title: REVUE: 'LEADER OF THE PACK'
description: ''Leader of the Pack,'' the revue of Ellie Greenwich songs that played at the Bottom Line Thursday through yesterday, has the makings of what could become the ''Dreamgirls'' of 1960's pop. The show, which strings together 33 songs with narration and comic sketches, celebrates one of the unsung talents of that era.

title: AT LAST, A DIPLOMA. AND NOW?
description: -SIX years, 100 term papers, 1,000 bottles of gray hair cover-up, two husbands and three children later than my supposed-to-be ''Pomp and Circumstance'' march down the aisle with the class of '57, I graduated from college. I walked after my son, who preceded me only because his name comes first alphabetically.

title: BONN-SAUDI TALKS DISTURB ISRAELIS
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl plans to visit Israel next week at a moment when relations are clouded by possible West German arms sales to Saudi Arabia.

title: CONTEMPORARY MUSIC TO SUIT EVERY TASTE
description: N ormally, contemporary works account for a minuscule portion of newly released recordings. But during the last couple of months, there has been - by normal standards - a bumper crop of new music disks covering an array of compositional styles: There is lush, ultra-conservative orchestral music; robust percussion ensemble scores; electronic works; jazz-tinged chamber pieces; walls of harsh atonality; and an adventurous recent incarnation of what is still sometimes called minimalism. There is, in fact, something to suit (and something else to offend) virtually every taste:

title: JAPAN RESPONDS TO U.S. DEFENSE CRITICS
description: Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe says that American critics of Japan's defense policies focus too hard on how much money is spent and not enough on ''overall'' Japanese efforts.

title: CAIRO: THE DIN AND THE GLORY
description: In Arabic, Cairo is known as El-Quhera,

title: A CAMEL RIDE TO THE PYRIMADS OF ABU SIR
description: Everyone who goes to Egypt visits the pyramids of Giza; everyone spends a day exploring the Step Pyramid and necropolis of Sakkara, 10 miles to the south. In between Giza and Sakkara stand the Fifth Dynasty (2465-2323 B.C.) pyramids of Abu Sir.

title: MELANIE MARRIED AVTAR
description: Barbara Thompson is a short-story writer and critic. TO A NATIVE SHORE By Valerie Anand. 287 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $15.95.

title: BEHIND TE BALFOUR DECLARATION
description: Paul Johnson's most recent book is ''Modern Times: The World From the Twenties to the Eighties.'' THE HIGH WALLS OF JERUSALEM A History of the Balfour Declaration and the Birth of the British Mandate for Palestine. By Ronald Sanders. 746 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $24.95.

title: COLD WAR ISN'T ABOUT ANYTHING
description: What is the cold war about? If you replay it with the sound turned off - no speeches, no polemics, no self-justifying history from either side - what do you see? One long progression in the art of weaponry.

title: A LIFE OF DUBIOUS BATTLE
description: Kevin Starr is the author of ''Americans and the California Dream 1850-1915'' and the forthcoming ''Southern California - the Founding Era.'' THE TRUE ADVENTURES OF JOHN STEINBECK, WRITER By Jackson J. Benson. Illustrated. 1,116 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $35.

title: Elizabeth Wurts to Wed C. K. Norton
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Wurts Jr. of Gladwyne, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Carter Wurts to Christopher Kilbourne Norton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Norton of North Westchester, Conn. A spring wedding is planned.

title: WHY MONEY MANAGERS BOMBED
description: GERALD R. Jordan, one of the nation's top money managers, should have enjoyed 1983. The stock and bond portfolios under his control had risen a spectacular 49 percent in value in 1982. Impressed by such investing skill, executives from Conoco, Nabisco Brands and Philip Morris signed up Mr. Jordan to manage millions of dollars in their pension funds. He seemed to have the world by the tail.

title: AUTO INSURANCE: THE LEGISLATURE WILL TRY AGAIN
description: TRENTON A UTOMOBILE-insurance revision, the issue that dominated the 200th Legislature, shows signs of doing the same in the 201st, which will hold its first working session tomorrow.

title: A Train of Disasters for Nuclear Power
description: A weeklong train of disasters has put the nuclear power industry through its darkest days since the accident at Three Mile Island:

title: VIOLENCE IN COPPER MINE STRIKE MARS A NEW BID FOR ATTENTION
description: Angry copper mine workers, in the seventh month of a strike against the Phelps Dodge Corporation, are engaged in what they acknowledge is a desperate effort to win national attention for their confrontation with the country's second largest copper producer.

title: Amy Schimmel To Wed Sept. 15
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Schimmel of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Leigh Schimmel, to Andrew Michael Kramer, son of Gerald Kramer of Bay Shore, L.I., and Fire Island and Joan Kramer of Pittstown, N.J. A Sept. 15 wedding is planned.

title: Helen Hummer Is Married
description: The marriage of Helen Hurley Hummer of New York to Stephen Berthold Feid, an institutional stock trader with Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc. in New York, took place yesterday at St. Clement's Roman Catholic Church in Chicago. The Rev. John Fahey performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Philip Wayner Hummer of Chicago and Mr. and Mrs. Jack Feid Jr. of Granville, Ohio.

title: CAPTAIN COOK'S ARCADIA

title: ECONOMISTS SEE '84 ON THE ISLAND AS BRIGHT YEAR
description: T HE economic outlook for Long Island in 1984 is one of continued optimism, according to most economists and government officials. They warn, though, that the financial impact of the Shoreham nuclear plant will have both short- and long-term effects on utility rates and property taxes.

title: CHIANTI: SEEKING AN IDENTITY
description: Much Chianti is still made with ''governo'' - a thick juice made from grapes that have been dried to reduce their water content. Many producers, however, are experimenting with leaving it out.

title: DEVELOPMENT PLAN ENVISIONS HOMES FOR $40,000 INCOMES
description: W ESTCHESTER and an association representing private businesses are working out the details of a proposed program to encourage construction of housing for families in the $40,000 to $50,000 income bracket.

title: HUMAN RIGHTSIS ALSO AN ISSUE IN HONDURAS
description: Raul Omar Vasquez Amaya, who died in police custody two weeks ago, might easily have passed unnoticed, becoming just another entry on the long list of young Latin Americans from Guatemala to Argentina who have been killed by Government officials. But the Vasquez case exploded into public scandal. A few days after the facts became known, the chief of the National Intelligence Directorate, Maj. Juan Blas Salazar Meza, was transferred. The Armed Forces Commander, Gen. Gustavo Alvarez Martinez, promised the crime would be investigated and that those responsible would be ''punished with the full force of the law.''

title: THAT WINNING ATTITUDE
description: WINTER is no time to hibernate from golf, tennis or any other sport that you normally enjoy outdoors in warm weather. Instead of bemoaning the fact that old man winter will not let you participate, you can improve your techniques, brush up on your fundamentals and increase your concentration.

title: JamesCunningham,68,Dies; Buffalo Police Commissioner
description: Police Commissioner James B. Cunningham died of a heart attack early this morning at Sisters of Charity Hospital here. He was 68 years old.

title: MARGIOTTA AIDE JOINS GULOTTA
description: R OBERT McDONALD, a former newspaper reporter who held the difficult job of spokesman for Joseph M. Margiotta, the former Nassau Republican leader, for 14 years, left his Nassau Republican organization post last week to become a top aide to another Long Island politician, Thomas S. Gulotta, the Hempstead Town Presiding Supervisor.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Phoenix Suns have signed Johnny High to another 10-day contract because Paul Westphal is not expected to return from injuries in his right leg until Feb. 1. . . . Louis Wright , the Denver Bronco cornerback selected to play in the Pro Bowl next Sunday, will not make it because of an injured hand and has been replaced on the American Conference roster by Raymond Clayborn of the New England Patriots. . . . Murray Murdoch , who played 508 consecutive games for the New York Rangers from 1926 to 1937, will be the recipient of the team's Alumni Association Award at Madison Square Garden Thursday night before the game against the Montreal Canadiens.

So the decision by the White Plains Beautification Foundation to build a band pavilion in honor of the four-term County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian, who died last September, seemed particularly proper.

GARDENING;
FLOWERS FOR THE COOLER HOMES OF TODAY
description: THE flowers and flowering plants used in homes a half- century or more ago had a certain charm and grace about them that has been lacking in those used in more recent years. Subtle colors, daintiness and fragrance were deemed more desirable than bold colors, superdoubleness and massive size.

title: Elizabeth Kellogg Marries R. J. Ruble
description: Elizabeth Hyler Kellogg, daughter of the late John Stewart Kellogg of Bedford Village, N.Y., and New York City, and the late Mrs. Nelson Loud of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to Raymond John Ruble, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Ruble of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Irving A. Marsland Jr. of the Metropolitan Community United Methodist Church in New York performed the ceremony at the Creek Club in Locust Valley.

title: POSTINGS;
description: The market for cooperative apartments in Manhattan's top-of-the- line buildings still is on the rise, according to the latest survey by Douglas-Elliman Gibbons & Ives. The survey is based on the recorded sales prices of all the apartments that changed hands in 200 buildings the company manages between 96th Street and Washington Square, with most of the buildings in the prime East Side residential district between Fifth Avenue and Sutton Place.

title: AN ALMOST-PLAY AND A 'COLLAGE'
description: MONTCLAIR E RICA, a designer of stage costumes, is a resilient, ferociously independent woman who has struggled to keep her family - an elderly mother and a teen-age daughter - together in her Greenwich Village apartment. She also has thrown out her husband.

title: A May Wedding For Miss Woods
description: The engagement of Regina Marie Woods to David Maisano has been announced by Anne F. Woods of Ossining, N.Y., mother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Maisano of Sands Point, L.I., and Manhattan.

title: AN AMERICAN SOPRANO COMES HOME
description: Heidi Waleson writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: NEW OPERATIC FARE GETS A BOOST
description: O pera America, which consists of American and Canadian opera companies and their administrators, has developed a new program designed to stimulate its members' interest in contemporary opera and new forms of avant-garde theatrical collaboration.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW BOOKS PROVIDE A WEALTH OF INFORMATION
description: The coin hobby's growth has been greatly stimulated by the steady stream of numismatic books and periodicals published in recent years - a flow of information that has continued unabated despite the protracted slump in the buying and selling of coins. If anything, in fact, the number of publication seems to have increased because lately there has been a veritable bonanza of important new books and updated editions released.

title: WISE ACTION ON DEER ISSUE IS NONE AT ALL
description: COULD anyone who has gazed with awe upon the grace of their gait, or the elegant delicacy of their shape, ever entertain for an instant the idea that there are too many deer?

description: W HAT David Epstein has done successfully in ''Bedrock'' at the Hartman Theater is set up a grown-up premarital and marital relationship, kinks and everything.

description: The Housing Problem Sometimes it seems Richard M. Nixon hasn't been able to get the residence of his choice since he left the White House.

title: MT. KOSCO JUDGE IS REMOVED
description: A JUDGE accused of uttering ''threatening remarks'' and ''racial epithets'' during a dispute in a Mount Kisco tavern has become the first judge in recorded county history to be removed from office. Vincent T. Cerbone, 52 years old, a Village Court justice in Mount Kisco for the last 20 years, was found to have ''engaged in such misconduct that he should be removed from office'' and ''should no longer be allowed to serve in a judicial position.''

title: Victoria Horn Is the Bride Of K. F. Bochat, a Lawyer
description: Victoria H. Horn, director of public relations and special projects for the New York Health and Racquet Clubs in New York, was married yesterday to Kenneth F. Bochat, a lawyer with E. F. Hutton & Company.

title: WHEN WIDOWERS NEED HELP
description: -year-old, self- employed salesman, developed migraine headaches and high blood pressure four months after his wife died of cancer. In the course of treatment, his doctor learned that Mr. Z. had been working 12 hours a day, seven days a week, to avoid staying home alone since his wife's death.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE TALKING EARTH By Jean Craighead George. 151 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $9.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: U.S. OBTAINS CURB ON JUDGE'S ATTACK ON JUSTICE DEPT.
description: The Justice Department has obtained a highly unusual temporary order from a Federal appeals court barring a law book company from publishing an opinion by a Federal district judge in Colorado that was critical of the department.

title: HIS IMAGINATION RESHAPES REALITY
description: Our experience of the world, it would seem, is becoming increasingly secondhand. Our views are as much shaped by what happens in our living rooms as by any immediate contact with the world at large. If, in the 1960's, one left an anti-war demonstration early, it was to race home and watch oneself demonstrating on the TV news - the experience of television somehow giving credence to the experience of the event. Given this growing dependence on mediated reality, it is not surprising that many photographers have forsaken the street for the studio, there to make fabricated realities suited to their privatized perceptions.

title: LIQUOR RAID STIRS ENTRAPMENT CHARGE
description: F OR two years the Willimantic police have been receiving complaints that minors are buying liquor in local stores and restaurants and, the police say, attempts to control the problem have been unsuccessful.

title: Boston Wedding For Faith Wilcox And Clive J. Russ
description: Faith Fuller Wilcox, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Sanborn Wilcox of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Clive Jeppe Russ, son of Norman Durham Russ of Johannesburg and Princess Michel Cantacuz ene of Paris. The Rev. Richard Holloway performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Boston, assisted by the Rev. Geoffrey Hahneman.

description: PRINCETON F OUR Princeton University students have formed an alternative student and alumni contribution fund to protest Princeton's investment in financial institutions that lend money to South Africa's Government.

title: OUTDOORSNelson Bryant; Snow and Ice Hold Off-Season Joys
description: E MERGING from late fall's and early winter's delightful offerings - whether casting for bluefish in the surf or for trout in the morning mist on a remote lake, pursuing deer in the mountains or waterfowl in the salt marshes - the hunter and fisherman in the Northeast must show some ingenuity if he does not wish to spend much of the dreadful months ahead slumped before a flickering screen.

title: THE U.N. VERSUS THE U.S.

By Richard Bernstein EVERAL MONTHS AGO, IN AN EFFORT TO find out just what went on in the multiplicity of meetings, commissions, committees and working groups that together make up the United Nations, the United States Mission to the world body made a quantitative study of the organization's activities. description: It was about this time last year that a special excitement began to collect around the basketball team at Springfield Gardens High School. Led by the acrobatic shooting of Richie Anderson and the flamboyant coaching of Ken Fiedler, the Eagles went on to win the Queens Division title, then raced to the Public Schools Athletic League Division A playoffs where they defeated Stevenson in the semifinals and upset Alexander Hamilton for the school's first P.S.A.L. title.

description: Governor Cuomo finished his first year in office with a positive rating among the state's voters, although he is not as well received upstate as downstate, according to the results of a poll released last week.

title: THOSE WHO LOOK OVER ALVARADO'S SHOULDER
description: Last Wednesday, as on most Wednesdays, Anthony J. Alvarado, New York's School Chancellor, and his senior staff spent the entire day with the seven members of the Board of Education. It is a time-consuming process, especially since much of the previous day is taken up with preparation for the meeting.

title: Miss Rice, Nurse, Engaged to Wed Jorge Barroso 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Hugh Rice Jr. of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miriam Coward Rice, to Jorge Luis Barroso 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barroso of Miami. The wedding is planned for July 14.

title: 'SKYROOM' CONDOMINIUMS
description: Among the views in these parts, the vista of Manhattan's skyline from the New Jersey side of the Hudson ranks near the top. But in most of the residential towers that dot the Palisades, for every unit that faces Manhattan, there is another on the other side of the building that faces less dramatic vistas to the west.

title: HOW A MINOR CLASSIC GREW INTO MAJOR BROADWAY ENTRY
description: W hen ''Open Admissions'' opened at the Ensemble Studio Theater in 1981, it made a noise utterly disproportionate to its size. A 22- minute play in a 99-seat theater, ''Open Admissions'' was named to several lists of the 10 best plays of the year, alongside as grandiose a production as ''Nicholas Nickelby.'' The author, Shirley Mezvinsky Lauro, won major awards from Samuel French publishers and the Dramatists Guild.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
WHY BONUSES MAKE SENSE FOR UNIONS
description: CORPORATE profits rose sharply last year, and are expected to grow further during 1984, according to many forecasters. Meanwhile, wage increases have slowed perceptibly, from a rate of 8.5 percent in 1981 to about half that in 1983. Can union leaders be expected to sit by without trying to get a share in the bonanza for their members? Are members likely to allow the leadership to be moderate in its demands even if it were so inclined?

title: U.S. WEIGHING ROLE IN U.N. FARM UNIT
description: The Reagan Administration is considering ending United States participation in a small, specialized United Nations organization based in Rome that assists small farmers and landless laborers in the poorest countries.

description: ANEW Federal law to combat a nationwide milk surplus by paying dairy farmers for a reduction in production of up to 30 percent will have a profound effect on Connecticut's largest farm industry, according to farmers and agricultural experts.

Greek poet.

description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul S. Russell of Chestnut Hill, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Rice Russell, to Scott David Malkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter L. Malkin of Greenwich, Conn. The wedding is to take place May 27.

title: WEEDING OUT THE BAD CAREER CHOICES

She returned to school, she said, certain that her previous job in operations ''had not been a good match, in terms of personality or value systems,'' but unsure of the career path she should take.

As 1982 was the year of the Mexican debt crisis and 1983 was the year of the Brazilian debt crisis, so 1984 is the first year of a more serious Latin American debt and political crisis with implications for the United States' own economic recovery.

title: U.S. Aide Dies in Guatemala
description: An assistant military attache at the United States Embassy in Guatemala City was among 11 people reported killed when an army transport plane crashed today, an embassy spokesman said. Mike Hahn, a press attache, said the crash occurred 11 miles north of Guatemala City. The nationalities of the other 10 people who died were not immediately known, and no further details were immediately available.

We weren't being deported - just transported up the Hudson, without heat, although the mercury was dropping rapidly into the single digits.

title: The Worm and the Apple Season's Greenings
description: Concert Compensation

title: CITY AT THE MIDDLE OF THE WORLD
description: On a brilliantly clear night along the rocky crest of a hill high up on Quito's east side shone a moon with a fullness that was frightening. Below, the city stretched out over the base of Pichincha, the 15,423-foot mountain that dominates the city from the west. Although many miles away, some of the snow-covered peaks along the ''Avenue of Volcanoes,'' as the German naturalist Alexander von Humboldt called it, appeared gin- clear.

title: FOR PATERSON, A NOVEL CATALYST, OLD MILLS BEING MADE INTO LIVING SAPCE FOR ARTISTS
description: PATERSON has always been a pragmatic city. Despite the presence of the roaring, 77-foot-high Great Falls, it was founded not as a resort but as an industrial center that would harness the cascading water power and become the nation's first planned manufacturing community.

title: TRYING TO BUILD A BANDWAGONFOR THE NONPROFIT MUSICAL
description: There is an old saying in the theater that goes, ''If Hitler is alive, may he be out of town with a musical.'' The curse attests to the punishing odds against new musicals succeeding if they follow the traditional route from rehearsal studio to road tour to Broadway.

title: Perfect Scores May Have Begun the Hamilton Era
description: Scott Hamilton's four perfect scores in the national figure skating championships Friday night may have ushered in a new era in the sport.

title: Sholom Aleichem at Y
description: An English version of Sholom Aleichem's play ''It's Hard to Be a Jew'' will be presented Feb. 11 to April 1 at the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue.

title: Q&A A Question of Decontrol Question:
description: I have lived in a rent-controlled apartment since 1950. The Mount Vernon City Council has passed a law cancelling rent controls. Is this legal? Also, how can I get my apartment painted? . . . B.B.W., Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: THEATER: 'AND BABY MAKES SEVEN'
description: In Vi Bremen's ''And Baby Makes Seven,'' a male homosexual and two lesbians, one of them pregnant, share a menage that is centered on a hyperactive fantasy life. The two women pretend to be a trio of imaginary children who outdo their creators in matters of bizarre behavior. Drenched with whimsy and hemlock, ''And Baby Makes Seven,'' at the 18th Street Playhouse, has a premise that is self-defeating. But, as a study of regressive adolescence, the evening is not without interest.

title: 140-YEAR-OLD ORGAN TO SOUND AGAIN
description: F OR the last 60 years, a piece of state history has sat unused and gathering dust in the balcony of an old church in Hampton Center, but thanks to the efforts of dozens of townspeople and nearly $20,000 in contributions from people in 16 states, this particular piece of history will soon be heard from again.

title: GO-GO LICENSING SOUGHT IN LINDEN
description: LINDEN O FFICIALS OF THIS blue-collar city of 40,000 people are trying to require the licensing of go-go dancers in taverns, and tavern owners say they are being singled out for harassment.

title: Nancy Ann Foster and Dr. Eric Munoz Are Wed
description: Nancy Ann Foster and Dr. Eric Munoz were married yesterday evening at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Munoz of Freehold, N.J., by Mayor John G. McGackin.

title: EXPERT'S DAY IN COURT --
description: John Jenkins might have mentioned the role of mental- health professionals as experts in child-custody litigation. When parents disagree as to the best custodial arrangement for their children, it is essential that a neutral mental-health professional, experienced in both child development and the emotional impact of divorce on children, perform an impartial evaluation of the entire family.

title: MUSIC: NEW YORK POPS
description: Skitch Henderson, the founder and music director of the New York Pops, with his white goatee and cultivated twinkle, bears an amusing resemblance to Sir Thomas Beecham, and it was with a Beecham-like elan that he lectured latecomers at the ensemble's Friday evening concert at Carnegie Hall.

description: William K. Stevens is The Times's bureau chief in New Delhi. By William K. Stevens

title: Headliners; A Promise Fulfilled
description: Mayor Koch feared for a while that the city was getting a song and dance from Diana Ross and her production company when it appeared they wouldn't come up with a promised donation for a new children's playground in Central Park. The money was supposed to come from the proceeds of a film of Miss Ross's free Central Park concert last summer, but her company said that beaause the concert had to be restaged after being rained out, there were no profits. The singer decided to leave all that to the accountants and last week handed a beaming Mayor Koch her personal check for $250,000.

title: Gnoncheh Sirossi Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. A. Houshang Sirossi of Seattle, formerly of Teheran, Iran, of the engagement of their daughter, Ghoncheh Sirossi, to Allen Dulles Jebsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jens H. Jebsen of Lloyd Neck, L.I.

title: U.S. Olympians Trounce Canadians, 8-2
description: Pat LaFontaine scored two goals and assisted on a goal in leading the United States Olympic hockey team to an 8-2 victory over Canada's team today.

title: NEW STIRRINGS OF PATRIOTISM --
description: Mr. Apple relates how the British public is puzzled at the idea of a movie star becoming President. European politicians, he informs us, are seasoned professionals. Of all the professions, there is none less benefited by ''seasoning'' than that of the politician. EBENEZER WRIGHT Syracuse

title: ANNE REYNOLDS IS ENGAGED TO MARRY J.T. RIE IN JULY
description: Dr. and Mrs. Benedict M. Reynolds of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Marie Reynolds, to Jonathan Thomas Rie, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Rie Jr. of White Plains.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
description: ARBORETUM CONCERTS

title: IN SEARCH OF AN AMERICAN MUSE
description: BEING a poet in the United States has meant for me years of confusion, blundering and self-doubt. The confusion lies in not knowing whether I am writing in the American language or the English or, more exactly, how much of the musical power of Chaucer, Marvell and Keats can can be kept in free verse. Not knowing how to live, or even how to make a living, results in blunders. And the self-doubt comes from living in small towns. Yet I think it is a lucky thing to be a poet in the United States. I say that aloud to ward off pity. Some people keep away from poetry and compensate by feeling sorry for poets: ''You poets must have a really hard time.'' William Stafford mentioned to me that if someone asks him, ''Why do you write poetry?'' he may reply, ''Why did you stop?''

title: GEORGETOWN DEFEATS ST. JOHN'S
description: Georgetown, combining impressive offense with defensive pressure, defeated St. John's, 83-61, before 15,901 in the second game of a Big East Conference doubleheader yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find particularly appealing.

title: The Tendency To See Ghosts
description: Will there ever be a time when a writer, in describing an old home, does not try to increase interest by referring to a ghost in the house? Even the raison d'^etre for this ghost story is incorrect. The Peace and Plenty Inn (''300 Years of History, and Maybe a Ghost,'' Jan. 1) was used as an inn (boardinghouse) until the early years of this century, long after Asa Chichester had gone to his reward.

title: FORMER NEW YORKERS ANSWER APPEAL TO AID CITY'S NEEDIEST
description: Whether they now live across the continent or only a state or two away, many former New Yorkers respond to the needs of their one-time hometown with warmth and generosity.

title: A MILLROSE GAMES FAMILY ALBUM
description: O NE lonely night in January 1945, while aboard a military hospital ship en route to the United States, I was listening to music on an Armed Forces Radio broadcast. From the time of my arrival in Europe in September 1944, and during my combat duty in France, I had not had any news from home. Suddenly the announcer interrupted with the news that on the previous night Jim Rafferty had won the Wanamaker Mile in the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden. Although the world was at war, I knew that all was well at home. The Millrose Games were still going on.

title: NEARLY COMPLETED NUCLEAR PLANT WILL BE CONVERTED TO BURN COAL
description: The utility companies that own a nearly completed nuclear power plant announced today that they would try to convert the plant to a coal-burning unit.

title: NUTMEG DIPLOMACY IN GRENADA: THE AFTERMATH OF INVASION
description: GRENADA is the only nation with a nutmeg on its flag, and with good reason: The tiniest country in the Western Hemisphere, it is the world's second-largest producer of the little golden fruit with the bright red heart.

description: A Norwegian Foreign Ministry official was arrested Friday on charges of spying, the Attorney General said today.

title: THIS SEASON NEEDS A PLAY WITH TEETH
description: H onestly, there are some people you just can't cheer up. Point out to them that during Christmas week the box offices along Broadway raked in some $6 million and do they say, ''Hey, now, that's jolly good, isn't it?'' No, they don't. What they say is, ''Do you realize that there's been only one new American play on Broadway this year?'' Reeling a bit from what you know to be the truth, you mumble something about the season being at no more than the halfway mark, with hope still a viable commodity, but you don't get away with

CAMERA;
CHOOSING THE RIGHT LIGHTING TECHNIQUE

title: AROUND THE NATION;

title: ARE YOU GETTING THE BESTOUT OF YOUR NEW AUDIO SYSTEM?
description: E arly relations between a listener and his sound system often resemble a honeymoon in which bliss is occasionally shadowed by doubt. What nags is the uncertainty whether those cherished new components are really giving the best performance of which they are capable. I can offer no assurance about this; only a few hints which, if taken, might set the mind at ease.

title: COLD WAVE GRIPS CONTINENTAL U.S.
description: Below-freezing temperatures were recorded in every state of the continental United States yesterday, and records for cold were set in parts of the Middle West. Temperatures were almost 20 degrees below normal in the New York area and around the Northeast.

title: DAVE ANDERSONSports of The Times TAMPA, Fla.
description: O NE is a billionaire businessman to whom football is fun; the other is a football man to whom business is now a court-room compulsion. One basks at his own Super Bowl XVIII party, the other prefers to slink through the shadows. One is enjoying what he calls his ''third life'' as the owner of the Washington Redskins, the other is obsessed with his only life, controlling the Raider organization he moved to Los Angeles without National Football League approval after having constructed it in Oakland.

title: MANY RUNAWAYS FOUND TO HAVE TRIED SUICIDE
description: A majority of homeless and runaway children living in emergency youth shelters in New York City appear to have significant psychiatric problems, with many having attempted suicide, according to a new study.

Galvestonians Vote Against Legal Casinos
description: The people of Galveston, in their largest turnout for any city election in 15 years, today voted down an advisory referendum to legalize gambling as a way to help the economy of this island resort city.

title:
DINING OUT;
IF A BASQUE SPECIALTY IS YOUR DISH
description: T HERE are almost three dozen Spanish and Portuguese restaurants and bodegas in Newark's Ironbound district, and they owe their popularity to the copious portions of seafood they offer at relatively moderate prices. The quality of the fare is not always primary in diners' thoughts, and overcooking and off-hand preparation may be overlooked in favor of the cheerful, rather exotic nature of both the setting and the food.

title: Blast at Singapore Exhibit
description: One person was killed and eight were hurt today when a rocket grenade exploded during a demonstration at an international aerospace exhibition at the Changgi Airport here.

title: VIDEO PARLOR PLAN OPPOSED
description: APROPOSED video game parlor less than a mile from Lawrence Senior High School, in Cedarhurst, is being opposed by school officials, parents and the local public library.

title: Team Leaves In Foul Protest
description: The Ohio University team, after a technical foul on Coach Danny Nee, left the floor in protest during the last four seconds during its 51-46 loss to Bowling Green in a Mid-American Conference game today. Bowling Green (11-4 over all, 4-2 in the conference) was leading by 47-46 when, in a scramble for possession, the ball when out of bounds.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review in Weekend on Friday misstated when an exhibition of Philip Tarlow's new paintings would close. The show will run through Wednesday.

title: Super Sports
description: For both sport and violence, we much prefer the performers in today's Super Bowl to those of the Super Powers. But it occurred to us this past week that at least on television, football and diplomacy were rapidly converging, and in an instructive way.

title: TV EXPERIMENT TURNS SOME ON AND SOME OFF
description: T ODAY, Super Bowl Sunday, millions of football fans all over America are tuning in. But in Farmington, some of those who do watch are doing so with faintly guilty consciences.

title: CITY BALLET: 'PIANO PIECES' BY JEROME ROBBINS
description: Jerome Robbins's ''Piano Pieces'' frothed out onto the stage of the New York State Theater on Friday in a fine performance by the New York City Ballet. This 1981 setting of dances to Tchaikovsky piano solos, played here with brio by Jerry Zimmerman, is one of Mr. Robbins's happiest confections.

title: Miss Surette Plans to Wed

title: KOREA'S FIERY KIMCHI
description: The visitor to any residential district in Seoul cannot fail to notice all the tall earthenware pots that dot rooftops and balconies of most Korean homes. These stately urns contain Korea's most popular food - the spicy pickled vegetables known as kimchi.

title: COUNTRY FRENCH AND PLEASING
description: -than-capacity crowds, Chez No"elle in Port Washington is still seeking an appreciative audience. This small country French restaurant, tucked unobtrusively down a somewhat industrial side street, deserves one. It is honest, authentic, unpretentious and extremely good.

title: Cardinals Sign Allen
description: The pitcher Neil Allen, has agreed to a four-year contract with the St. Louis Cardinals worth an estimated $3.56 million, according to the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. The Cardinals are also believed to be close to signing the first baseman George Hendrick to a five-year contract worth about $1 million a year and the outfielder Lonnie Smith to a one-year contract in the range of $725,000.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: R ICH HILGERT says he ''doesn't worry about phones any more.'' Not an ear-catching statement, until he mentions one other fact: he is an installer for the New York Telephone Company.

title: CUOMO'S PLAN FOR SCHOOL AID
description: ALBANY U NDER Governor Cuomo's proposed budget for next year, Westchester would receive substantially less in educational aid than it did last year because the county is considerably wealthier than the rest of the state, according to budget aides.

description: N EIGHBORS are a lot like relatives. You really can't wholly choose them, in most instances. Often, the only thing that defines them as neighbors, aside from proximity, is that you and they may have, as with relatives, a lot of common enemies.

title: Miss Hester Is Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. James McNaughton Hester of New York and Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Rodes Hester, to Paul Anthony Giroux, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Giroux of New York.

title: Girl Sets 1,500 Mark
description: Shola Lynch, a 14-year-old freshman at Hunter High School, ran the fastest girls' prep school 1,500-meter race of the national indoor season Friday night at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn. In a preliminary to the Colgate Women's Games, she won in 4 minutes 29.9 seconds.

title: Desert

A sign in a real estate office describes Borrego Springs as ''the way Palm Springs was 100,000 people ago.''

title: A. M. Goodman to Wed Victoria Wilson in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Valentine L. Wilson of Rydal, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Wilson, to Andrew M. Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Goodman of New York and Woodsburgh, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

description: Announcement has been made by Dana Lee Van Buskirk of Stony Brook, L.I., and Eric J. Schmertz of Riverdale, the Bronx, of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Margaret Schmertz, to Douglas John Bowen, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Bowen of Brick Town, N.J.

title: A SURVIVOR WITH IMAGE PROBLEMS
description: NEWARK I N THE midst of the mergers,

title: A SHOPPER'S HAUNT FOR CENTURIES
description: As an Egyptian New Yorker in Khan el- Khalili, the 15th-century caravansary-bazaar in old Cairo, I follow Mamelukes, Ottoman Turks and Napoleon's soldiers who have shopped here before me. The Khan hasn't changed much, but we shoppers have. I come to the bazaar with a New Yorker's mind, innate Middle Eastern savvy, and just enough Arabic to cope. The Khan is a world unto itself within Cairo, with its own social hierarchy, families, tradition and its own style and rhythm, and it should be accepted on its own terms. As soon as I see the twin minarets of the Mosque of Al Azhar, I am enveloped by this microcosm of Mameluke Cairo.

title: MAKING THE METROPOLIS GREEN
description: Richard Bender, an architect and urban planner, is the dean of the College of Environmental Design at the University of California, Berkeley. THE GRANITE GARDEN

title: THE WORLD
description: Toward Elections In Nicaragua

title: DO LANDMARKS BELONG TO EVERYONE?
description: W ho owns New York? The question is asked often, and it is usually a lead-in to a word or two about the power of the city's real estate developers. The common wisdom is that they own the city, and that it is at their whim that buildings rise and fall; the corollary to that same piece of common wisdom suggests that the only pieces of New York City that are truly safe from the pressures of real estate wheeling and dealing are those buildings that have never been part of the real estate market in the first place - churches, synagogues, museums, libraries, and so forth.

title: DANCE: BAUHAUS DESIGN BY OSKAR SCHLEMMER
description: Oskar Schlemmer's dances were dances that only a painter could have choreographed. Schlemmer, a German painter who lived from 1888 to 1943, both taught and created dances for the Bauhaus, the innovative artistic institution of the 1920's that, in Weimar and later in Dessau, sought a unification of arts, crafts and technology.

title: N.C.A.A. TO REGISTER AGENTS
description: College administrators are taking steps which, they hope, will better inform athletes about agents who are willing to abide by National Collegiate Athletic Association regulations and what an athlete can expect when dealing with agents.

title: Nelsen Joins Lions
description: Bill Nelsen , who has 20 years of experience as a player and an assistant coach in the National Football League, was named offensive coordinator for the Detroit Lions. Nelsen replaces Ted Marchibroda , who has moved to a similar position with the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: 'Sacred Executioner'
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Clients Await DiGiacomo's Opening
description: Although he does not have office space yet, Frank DiGiacomo, who expects to fulfill a dream by opening his own agency around March 1, does have three clients waiting for him to do so.

description: To the Editor:

title: DATSUN NAME SHIFT IS COSTLY FOR NISSAN
description: The Nissan Motor Company Ltd., the world's fourth-largest maker of motor vehicles, has just spent two years and millions of dollars successfully trying to destroy one of this country's better known automobile brand names.

title: FOUR ARE KILLED AS A PLANE HITS HOUSE IN JERSEY
description: Four people in a twin-engined Cessna 310 were killed here this afternoon when the airplane hit a house and crashed onto its front yard.

title: N.I.T.'s Carlesimo Treated for Illness
description: Peter A. Carlesimo, executive director of the National Invitation Tournament, was treated at St. Vincent's Hospital Saturday after suffering a seizure at Madison Square Garden.

description: Representatives of longshoremen, ship lines and port employers on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts are to meet in Miami Beach Tuesday in an effort to resolve contract differences and avert a possible interruption in shipping operations after an interim agreement expires Jan. 31.

description: Across Eastern Europe, there are signs of a religious renewal.

description: William French Smith

title: Kentucky's 2d-Half Surge Tops Houston
description: Kenny Walker scored 20 points and grabbed 10 rebounds, and Melvin Turpin had 19 points and 11 rebounds today to help Kentucky score a 74-67 victory over Houston at Rupp Arena.

title: Gretzky Extends Streak
description: Wayne Gretzky was credited with two assists in the third period Saturday night to extend his consecutive point-scoring streak to 49 games and lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 6-3 triumph over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: ANGOLA OPENS COUNTERATTACK AFTER REBELS MAKE BIG GAINS
description: Angola, reacting to major military gains by rebel forces, has begun a major counteroffensive against the South African- backed guerrillas, according to diplomats and other authorities in Europe.

title: Deep in the Heart of Ignorance
description: The Texas Board of Education has ruled that the biology textbooks used in the state's public schools needn't mention Charles Darwin. It has doubts about the soundness of Mr. Darwin's theory of evolution.

title: SECRET 3-WAY TALKS ON NAMIBIAN ISSUE REPORTED IN PROGRESS
description: The Portuguese Government radio reported today that United States, Angolan and South African officials were meeting secretly on the future of South- West Africa. The United States denied that such talks were in progress.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Kazoos and Colonel Bogey

title: Velveeta at Burnett; JVC Shifts to SSC&B
description: The reassignment by Kraft of the Velveeta cheese brand to the Leo Burnett Company, from J. Walter Thompson, topped the recent list of campaign switches; it will probably bill more than $15 million.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Small Is Big

title: CABARET: AMY RYDER
description: ABIG woman with a big voice, Amy Ryder belongs to a school of red-hot mamas that runs from Sophie Tucker and Ethel Merman through Bette Midler. Like her forerunners, Miss Ryder blends salty, self-deprecating jokes that have decidedly nasty undertones with singing that is supposed to reveal a heart of gold underneath the brass.

title: Catharine Park Weds Mark Edward Harris
description: Catharine Shobert Park, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Park of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Edward Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell Harris of Los Angeles. The Rev. Robert Bedingfield performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church of Bronxville.

title: Parley on 'Nuclear Winter'
description: Scientists from the United States, the Soviet Union and other countries will meet in the Vatican Monday to discuss ''nuclear winter,'' the chilling climatic effect a nuclear war could have on the earth.

title: FOR APPLE, A RISKY ASSAULT ON I.B.M.
description: When Apple Computer Inc. introduces its long-awaited Macintosh computer tomorrow, it may represent the last serious assault on the dominance of the International Business Machines Corporation in the personal computer industry.

title: British Columbia Opens An Official Wolf Hunt
description: Wildlife officers, stalking by helicopter, have started killing wolves in British Columbia despite protests from a conservation group.

title: SAFETY ISSUES RAISED AT HEARING ON ACTORS' DEATHS
description: Questions about a movie director's orders and the safety of special effects used for a film are key issues in a preliminary hearing on three deaths, those of the actor Vic Morrow and two child actors.

title: STRATEGIES DEBATED BY JOURNALISM EDUCATORS
description: Journalism schools are suffering confusion about goals and methods at a time when Americans need more help to sort out an increasing flow of information, according to the heads of some of the largest and most influential of those schools.

title: U.S., PRESSURE GEMAYEL
description: President Reagan rightly feels compelled to keep the central Government of Lebanon from falling under Syrian control. His options, however, are limited by the growing unwillingness of Americans to lose more Marines' lives in an inconclusive war. At this point, there is only one way to prevent the Syrians from taking charge: by winning over those Lebanese now allied with Syria against their own Government. If these forces can be brought back in, the Government in Beirut can survive and the Syrians will eventually have to leave.

title: 145 Protesters Arrested At Nuclear Power Plant
description: Nine days of protests at the $4.3 billion Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant have led to 145 arrests, the authorities said today.

title: SENATE AIDE VISITS NICARAGUA REBELS
description: The chief administrative assistant to a Republican Senator from Idaho said today that he made a secret trip into the Nicaraguan jungle last month to meet with Eden Pastora Gomez, the leader of one of two main rebel factions seeking the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government.

title: Futures/OptionsH. J. Maidenberg Mark Trading Due in Chicago
description: I N 1972, the financial futures market was born

title: A Dire Omen Is Fulfilled
description: Pete Rozelle, the National Football League commissioner, met with reporters before the Super Bowl today and chatted on an assortment of subjects.

title: 'Miracle' Wins for Syracuse
description: Syracuse's basketball team has only one play designed for when the game is on the line. ''We call it getting the ball to Dwayne Washington,'' Coach Jim Boeheim said yesterday by telephone, ''and then we look for a miracle.''

title: Chinese-U.S. Trade Drop PEKING, Jan. 22 (AP) - American wheat sales in November helped raise monthly American-Chinese trade after a 1983 slump caused by a dispute over Chinese textiles, the United States Embassy here said.
description: Because of the rift, bilateral trade for Jan. 1 to Nov. 30 fell 19.5 percent, to $3.89 billion, from $4.83 billion in the similar period of 1982.

title: Miss Daute Sets Best in Long Jump
description: Heike Daute of East Germany achieved a world-indoor best in the women's long jump today, clearing 22 feet 11 1/4 inches.

title: IN JORDAN, CONGRATULATIONS ARE IN ORDER
description: The TalkofAmman

title: Linda Galler Is Bride Of Murray E. Singer
description: Linda Galler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Galler of New Orleans, was married yesterday to Murray Eric Singer, son of Marvin E. Singer of San Francisco and Phyllis Troup Singer of Milwaukee. Rabbis Benjamin Groner and David Goldstein performed the ceremony at the New Orleans Hilton.

title: WILL ROGERS: NOW, ABOUT CONGRESS...
description: The second session of the 98th Congress convenes Monday, and how Will Rogers would have rejoiced.

title: ROCK: VERNON REID'S TRIO
description: WITH his blistering speed, his ear for electronic sonorities and his taste for ecstatic excess, Vernon Reid has the makings of a commanding style in modern guitar. He is a member of Ronald Shannon Jackson's jazz-rock band, the Decoding Society, but last week he led a trio at 55 Grand Street, with Alex Mosely on electric bass and Greg Carter on drums.

title: TECHNOLOGY CURBS IRK EUROPEANS
description: European industrialists and government officials have reacted angrily to new American moves intended to stop militarily useful technology from being diverted to the Soviet bloc from countries outside the Western alliance.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL IS REPORTED READY TO LEAVE CABINET
description: Attorney General William French Smith has resigned, and President Reagan plans to replace him with Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, Administration officials said today.

title: Tax Guide for Arts People
description: Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts has published the 1984 edition of ''Fear of Filing: A Beginner's Guide to Tax Preparation and Record Keeping for Artists, Performers, Writers and Freelance Professionals.''

title: Rena Seplowitz, Lawyer, Weds Dr. Steven Keller
description: Rena C. Seplowitz, a lawyer with the Manhattan firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, and Dr. Steven M. Keller, a senior surgical resident at Mount Sinai Hospital, were married yesterday. Rabbi David Silber performed the ceremony at the Park East Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: MRS. THATCHER SAID TO SEE NO WAY FOR BRITAIN TO KEEP HONG KONG
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has concluded that there is no chance of Britain's retaining administrative control over Hong Kong after 1997, the year that the lease on part of the colony is due to expire, Government officials said today.

title: Egyptian Leader Is Reported Set to Visit Jordan and Iraq
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt will visit Jordan and Iraq in February, the first visit by an Egyptian President to those countries since the Arab boycott of Egypt in 1979, Jordanian sources said today.

title: The Other Superbowl: I.B.M. vs. Apple
description: Yesterday's Super Bowl telecast marked the opening of a far bigger competition than a mere football tussle: International Business Machines vs. Apple for dominance in the personal computer market.

title: EAST GERMANY LETS 6 LEAVE U.S. EMBASSY FOR THE WEST
description: The East German Government allowed six East Germans who sought freedom in the West to leave the United States Embassy in East Berlin today and cross the border into West Berlin, a West German Government spokesman said.

title: 5 More War Shells Found
description: Navy volunteers have found five more live World War II tank shells in a canyon where two boys were killed by the explosion of such a shell last month. The discovery brought to 18 the number of live shells recovered in the first week of a search that, the Navy says, may take five months. In the war the area was the site of a Marine Corps firing range.

title: THE DELEGATE-RULE DEAL THAT DIDN'T GO THROUGH
description: The Democratic National Committee and its chairman, Charles T. Manatt, may have made a fateful decision Friday, when party leaders passed up a chance to end, once and for all, the Rev. Jesse Jackson's challenge of the delegate-selection rules for the 1984 convention.

title: MCGOVERN AND HART GAIN GROUND WITH FARMERS
description: George McGovern and Gary Hart appeared today to have gained some ground among farmers who heard the views of six Democratic Presidential candidates at a forum on agricultural policy Saturday night.

title: U.S. SKATERS SHOW STRENGTH AND DEPTH
description: There were perfect scores and falls, some private and public bickering and pleasant surprises. Even Rosalynn Sumners said she wanted to have a little hotel-room chitchat with Elaine Zayak to patch up some of their personal problems.

title: REAGAN'S LAW
description: In no other country is law remotely as important a strand in the social fabric. We live in a Madisonian system, our freedoms enforced by law. A disparate and fractious people, we have been held together by law. For us law has been both a liberating and a stabilizing force: both of those because on tense issues it has offered a hope of ordered change.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If they want force, we would use force.'' - Pierre Gemayel head of Lebanon's Phalangist Party. (A1:4.)

title: RAIDERS TURN SUPER MATCH INTO A MISMATCH
description: CHARLIE SUMNER had a hunch. In the moments before Jack Squirek intercepted Joe Theismann's pass for a 5-yard touchdown that detonated the Los Angeles Raiders' 38-9 rout of the Washington Redskins in Super Bowl XVIII yesterday, the Raider linebacker coach remembered a similar situation in a 37-35 loss at Washington in the regular season.

title: HOLLINGS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE: INSISTENT STRIVING, WITH WIT
description: In the year since he began his bid for the Democratic nomination for President, Senator Ernest F. Hollings has spent more than 40 days in this small, overcanvassed state, stumping from early in the morning to late at night.

title: DOWN IN THE SUBWAY, IT'S (OOF!) A DIFFERENT JAPAN
description: The people who run Tokyo's subways have begun a campaign to tidy up the habits of their passengers. Again.

title: SMITH'S TERM: VAST CHANGE UNDER A CONSERVATIVE
description: In three years as Attorney General, William French Smith supervised profound changes in Federal policy on civil rights, antitrust enforcement and criminal justice.

title: SPIRITS CRUSHED IN THE CAPITAL
description: By the time it was over, feathered headdresses drooped, war-painted faces sagged, and Washington had grown very, very, quiet.

title: HOWARD COUGHLIN, UNION LEADER, DIES
description: Howard Coughlin, former president of the Office and Professional Employees International Union and a leader in the unionization of white-collar workers, died Thursday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Priorities on Super Sunday

title: Advertising; Guinness Broadens Ogilvy Role
description: IN a major move toward multinational marketing, Arthur Guinness Son & Company of London, the venerable brewer, has consolidated its advertising and marketing assignments in most of the non-Communist world with Ogilvy & Mather International, an American agency with a British tradition.

title: 'MEDIUM' TAX RISES DISCUSSED
description: While there is little chance of a major tax increase getting through Congress this year, $30 billion to $40 billion of so- called minor tax increases over three years could pass Congress this year and be signed into law by President Reagan.

title: A NARROW RANGE IS SEEN FOR RATES
description: The credit markets are hardly a sea of tranquility, but the outlook over at least the next few weeks is for no significant change in Federal Reserve policy or interest rates.

title: WINNING FIRM IN BIAS CASE ASKS $1.5 MILLION FROM CITY
description: A prominent law firm is seeking nearly $1.5 million from New York City for conducting a lawsuit against the city that led to the hiring of the first women as firefighters by the New York Fire Department.

title: AT WHAT AGE RETIREMENT?
description: ''Retirement should not be universal. People are different. Not all want to be put out to pasture. None want to feel ignored and useless.'' That advice was given last week by Coy G. Eklund, retired chairman of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, to a state hearing on aging.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Bid to Duplicate Growth At Storage Technology
