description: T HE International Business Machines Corporation reported last Wednesday that profits in

title: The Editorial Notebook; More on Future and Her Cats
description: In this space last month, we reported how a homeless woman who calls herself Future attracted attention in Times Square because of the loving treatment she gave four pet cats. The cats mysteriously disappeared shortly before the article ran; Future herself shortly after. What more could be learned about the woman and her cats?

title: MULTIMILLION REALTY TAX CASE FOCUSES ON ROLE OF APPRAISER
description: The former head of New York City's Law Department, citing a 1977 study, has challenged the ''independence and objectivity'' of an appraiser recently retained by the city, even though the former official had hired the appraiser many times during his own government tenure.

title: MOTHER ANGELINE MCCRORY, 91
description: Mother M. Angeline Teresa McCrory, the founder and mother general emeritus of the Carmelite Sisters for the Aged and Infirm, died here Saturday on her 91st birthday.

title: MARLO THOMAS TV FILM ON RIGHTS OF WITNESSES
description: Tomorrow night CBS will broadcast a made-for-television film that sympathetically portrays a suspected member of the Weather Underground and a woman so abused by the police and the press that she is driven to murder.

title: Ford Recalling Mark VII's
description: The Ford Motor Company said Friday that it was recalling 12,400 Mark VII luxury cars to repair a defect in the antitheft device that could cause the steering wheel to lock.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 23, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Banque de Paris Names Chief for California Unit

title: OF KHALIDI AND THE ANTI-DEFAMATION LEAGUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Predicts Ability To Buil
description: Brazil will be able to produce nuclear weapons by the 1990's, Navy Minister Maximiano da Fonseca said in an interview published today.

title: MUSIC: JANINA FIALKOWSKA
description: THE most telling moment of Janina Fialkowska's piano recital at the 92d Street Y on Thursday night came at the unlikeliest place - in one of those slightly dusty piano transcriptions of Bach organ music. The piece was the Bach-Liszt Prelude and Fugue in A minor; and it was in this piece of great length and complexity that Miss Fialkowska's playing was so beautifully paced, so careful to save climaxes until the truly climactic points in the music.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF LEROI JONES. By Amiri Baraka. 329 pages. Freundlich. $16.95.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Wanted: Dropout Solution

title: Walesa and Cardinal Confer
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity labor union, met today with Jozef Cardinal Glemp, Poland's Roman Catholic primate, for discussions on the situation in the country. Spokesmen for Mr. Walesa and the church declined to give details of the meeting, which was the first between the two men since April.

title: Tear Gas Stops a Melee
description: The police sprayed tear gas to halt a melee that broke out Saturday during the University of North Carolina at Asheville's basketball game against Mars Hill College.

title: MCENROE GIFT GOES TO ASSIST THE NEEDIEST
description: John McEnroe, the 24-year-old tennis star, has contributed $10,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The gift was made to the fund's 72d annual appeal through his father, John P. McEnroe.

title: U.S. Issues Report on Water
description: The United States is water-rich, with a renewable supply of 1.4 million million gallons a day in the contiguous 48 states, but some areas face shortages, the Government has reported in its first National Water Summary.

title: PROSECUTOR IS EXCUSED FROM CASE INVOLVING HER FATHER'S INVESTMENT
description: A special prosecutor has been named to look into charges that natural gas was repeatedly stolen at an apartment building in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman said in court papers that her office should be disqualified from prosecuting the case because her father, Sidney, has a financial interest in the building.

title: The Davis Secret: Just Win, Baby'
description: The command was repeated for the benefit of the commissioner of the National Football League, for the millions of fans watching on the other side of the television cameras and, most of all, for the football team that belongs to Al Davis.

title: ALL IN A DAY'S WORK: A BLEEDING ALCOHOLIC, CHILDREN WITH AIDS
description: Many of the cases dealt with by Dr. Ruth Macklin involve issues of life and death. Some involve limited hospital resources; others concern the baffling dilemmas of urban life. Virtually none are simple to resolve. Here are some of the cases she has had to consider:

title: RIOTING FOMENTED, MOROCCAN ASSERTS
description: King Hassan II said in an address to the nation tonight that rioting in at least six Moroccan cities had been fomented by elements he termed Communists, followers of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and Zionist intelligence agents.

title: Williams Is Upset Over Net Contract
description: The day the Nets began preparing for the season last fall, Buck Williams said that he did not want his ongoing contract negotiations to hamper his playing. ''I'll continue to play the same way I always have,'' he said. ''When I'm out on the court, I don't think about it.''

title: DANCE: MISS FOSTER PERFORMS
description: SUSAN FOSTER is a new breed of dancer and choreographer. Like Kenneth King and William Forsythe, she finds her postulates in literary theory.

title: SMITH SIXTH TO RESIGN FROM CABINET
description: In returning to private law practice, William French Smith is following a number of other Cabinet members and high officials who have resigned from the Reagan Administration, some of them under pressure.

title: RAIDERS OVERWHELM THE REDSKINS, 38-9, TO WIN SUPER BOWL
description: So often with Super Bowl games, the more that is expected, the less is delivered.

title: MUSIC: 'GUITAR PLUS' PROGRAM
description: SIMCA and Terry Heled founded Concerts Plus in 1982, to bridge what they perceived as a gap between concert performers and their audiences. They conceived programs that would feature informal introductions to the music at hand, question-and-answer sessions and a surprise guest or special demonstration.

title: DON'T DERAIL INDEXING
description: Income-tax indexing, one of the most important aspects of the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981, is scheduled to take effect in 11 months. This provision is both fair and fiscally responsible. It is imperative that Congress refrain from interfering with indexing - in a misguided attempt to lower Federal deficits - through repeal or revision.

title: ; WHAT SCHOOL LIBRARIES ARE ALL ABOUT
description: To the Editor:

title: PURTZER WINS PHOENIX OPEN
description: Tom Purtzer blasted a 60-foot bunker shot to within a foot of the cup at the 18th hole today and then putted out for a birdie 4 to win the $400,000 Phoenix Open by one shot from Corey Pavin.

title: Matke Wins Final
description: Unseeded John Matke of the United States won the men's singles final today of the third leg of the $37,500 Indian Satellite Tennis Tournament. Matke outclassed another American, Mark Wooldridge, also unseeded, 7-6, 4-6, 9-7.

title: South African Inflation
description: South Africa's consumer price inflation in 1983 was 10.97 percent, down from 13.82 percent in 1982, according to figures released Friday by the Central Statistics Office.

title: PANEL CALLS FOR REALLOCATING CHEAP UPSTATE HYDROPOWER
description: More than half the electricity generated by two hydroelectric plants on the Niagara and St. Lawrence Rivers should be shifted from upstate residential users to industry and, in smaller part, to downstate users, according to a draft report of a state commission on hydropower.

title: SAMUEL RAMEY REFLECTS ON HIS DEBUT AT THE MET
description: Samuel Ramey's current success at the Metropolitan Opera has brought him some short-term fulfillment but still hasn't resolved his longstanding dissatisfaction with the people who run the house.

title: HOUSTON FINDS THAT DRAMATIZING CRIME DOES PAY
description: On a chilly winter evening in a residential neighborhood not far from downtown, a small foreign car jerked to a stop, a door flew open and a body tumbled out on the pavement. The car, tires screeching, sped down the street.

title: December '83 Cold Set A New Record for U.S.
description: Last month was the coldest December on record in the United States, with frigid temperatures setting local records in 39 cities, the National Weather Service says.

title: 500 DINE AND DANCE AT POLICE CENTER
description: It may not have been the season's most glittering affair, despite the presence of all the brass, but it was probably the safest party in town.

title: TROUBLING ISSUES FACING CONGRESS
description: When Congress returns Monday from a two- month recess, the most pressing questions on the agenda will be whether the marines should stay in Lebanon and how a budget deficit that could approach $200 billion in the next year can be reduced.

title: Bridge: Unusual Smothering Play Occurred in Fall Nationals
description: There is considerable argument among historians about whether Richard III was responsible for having the Princes in the Tower smothered. There is no doubt at all, however, that smothering plays at the bridge table are almost as rare as they are in the history books.

title: GIRARDELLI CAPTURES HIS 2D CUP SLALOM
description: Marc Girardelli won his second consecutive men's World Cup slalom today by rallying from sixth place with a strong second run.

title: CELTICS BEAT BUCKS ON PARISH'S SHOTS
description: Robert Parish started a run of 14 consecutive points late in the third period today as the Boston Celtics broke open a close game and went on to a 109-98 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: AT LAST, CHEERS IN ADOPTED CITY
description: Thousands of people who had given the team a lukewarm reception since it moved to Los Angeles two years ago spent today cheering for the Raiders in their 38-9 victory over the Washington Redskins.

title: Rolls-Royce In Dutch Deal LONDON, Jan. 22 (Reuters) - Rolls-Royce Ltd. plans to supply the Dutch Navy with Marine-Spey gas turbines in return for the purchase by the British Navy of the Dutch Goalkeeper weapons system.
description: Rolls-Royce said in a statement Friday that the initial value of the deal for the Dutch Navy's latest frigates is expected to exceed $:20 million, or $28 million.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Who was the first running back to complete a pass in the Super Bowl?

title: President Hails Secret Weapon'
description: President Reagan congratulated the Los Angeles Raiders for their Super Bowl victory today by comparing Marcus Allen, their star running back, to a secret weapon and the team to a nuclear missile.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be reported this week.

title: CHILDREN AND RISKS THEY TAKE
description: -year-old Ben Schwartz of Brooklyn Heights goes skiing, his mother, Rita, waits nervously all day for the telephone to ring. ''By 6:30 P.M. when the ski patrol hasn't called, I know everything is all right,'' she said. ''He skis on expert slopes, but I don't know that he is an expert.''

title: EUROPEANS KEEPING TO BUILDING PLANS ON NUCLEAR POWER
description: Western Europe is busily pressing ahead with nuclear power development.

title: Industrial Policy - Industrial Politics
description: Recession and the campaign have given birth to the proposition that America cannot compete unless it adopts a national ''industrial policy.'' Vital industries are in decline, say the proponents. Productivity is down. Unemployment, though declining, is still high. And foreign producers are taking over.

title: Yoko Ono Gives Mansion To Virginia Boys' Home
description: Yoko Ono, the widow of the former Beatle John Lennon, has donated an 18th-century Virginia plantation to a home for emotionally disturbed youngsters, a real estate agent said Saturday.

title: RECORDS INCLUDED 'TEARDROPS'
description: Jackie Wilson, a successful rock-and- roll singer until a coma incapacitated him, died Saturday in Burlington County Memorial Hospital in Mount Holly, N. J. He was 49 years old.

title: POOR YEAR FOR BIGGEST BANKS
description: For the most part, 1983 was not a good year for the nation's 15 biggest bank holding companies, most of which operated under the shadow of the international debt crisis.

title: CANCER FIGHTERS AIDING WEST BANK'S ARABS
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Schoolgirls In Millrose Duel
description: The girls' one-mile invitation run at the Millrose Games Friday has been declared an open event, clearing the way for a meeting between two of the top schoolgirls in the country.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Radioactive Steel Found At Sites in Four States

title: URBAN FAD IN INDIA: BATTLING THE RICH DIET
description: Every now and again the slim, trim sons of a middle-age, middle-income Indian chef tease their father about the modest paunch he has developed.

title: FOR ALLEN, THE BEST DAY EVER
description: About a half hour after the 1984 Super Bowl game had been laid to rest, Marcus Allen was surrounded by a mass of reporters under the stands of Tampa Stadium. He wore a black Raiders' baseball cap, his black jersey with the silver numeral 32 and a smile that helped light up the interview area.

title: JEROME TOOBIN, 64, CHANNEL13'S CHIEF OF NEWS PROGRAMS
description: Jerome Toobin, the director of news and public affairs at WNET-TV, died of a heart attack yesterday at Albert Einstein Medical Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Toyo in Talks On Ford Plant
description: Toyo Kogyo of Japan is nearing an agreement to buy an idle Ford plant in Michigan to build small cars for Ford beginning in 1987, according to Ward's Auto World, an industry publication.

title: SEAVER HOLDS OFF DECISION
description: Tom Seaver said yesterday that he had not yet decided whether to report to the Chicago White Sox, and added that the decision would be based on talks with officials of the team during the next few days.

title: Capital Practitioner Of Public Relations
description: Robert K. Gray, founder of Gray & Company, the largest public relations firm in Washington, will soon take his company public through an initial offering of $5.4 million in stock.

title: Dividend Meetings for Monday's paper/ J.McCue/Fin News
description: Dividend Meetings

title: A Bad Day for the Hogs
description: THE Los Angeles Raiders' victory was so overwhelming that it even inspired Al Davis and Pete Rozelle to indulge in the briefest and most cursory of fingertip-touching that passed for a handshake.

title: MONTANA TOWN MOURNS FOR 9 DEAD AFTER TEAM BUS CRASHES IN STORM
description: People in this mountainous resort town of 4,600 people were grieving today for nine people who were killed when a school bus carrying a high school wrestling team collided with a fuel tanker in a snowstorm.

title: NATIONAL GALLERY ACQUIRES JULIUS HELD COLLECTION OF DRAWINGS
description: The National Gallery of Art in Washington has acquired 202 Old Master and modern drawings from the collection of Julius Held, one of the most distinguished scholars of 17th-century Flemish and Dutch art.

description: IN the midst of Isaac Stern's

description: * Altos Computer Systems, San Jose, Calif., has appointed David W. Hanna president and chief executive.

description: Hong Kong clothing manufacturers have come up with a new export strategy, one born of necessity: they are promoting their own fashion designers.

description: A Sister for Republicans

title: BASKETBALL ON STREETS LOSES, 6-3
description: It was not a unanimous decision when the City Council of Birmingham, Ala., voted to make it illegal to play basketball in the city's streets.

title: Scotland's Wells First in 2 Sprints
description: Scotland's Allan Wells, the 1980 Olympic 100-meter champion, scored an impressive sprint double today, and Don Paige of the United States won the 800 meters in an international track and field meet.

title: WHY THE RAIDERS WERE DOMINANT
description: For the Washington Redskins, the team with the best record in professional football, the day of horrors started early: a blocked punt for a touchdown the first time they had the ball. But after that, things grew steadily worse.

description: The Abortion-Rights Fight

title: Rozelle Denies Cowboy Sale Deal
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, said today it was ''not true'' that an agreement had been made to sell the Cowboys to a Dallas real estate developer, Vance C. Miller.

title: Austrian Ski Star Killed in Accident
description: Sepp Walcher, the 1978 world downhill champion, was killed Sunday in a skiing accident during an amateur race at his hometown of Schladming.

title: MISS MCKINNEY CARRIES U.S. SKIING HOPES
description: T AMARA McKinney stamped her feet to shake off the 14 degree cold, and powdery snow spurted from beneath her skis.

title: SHIFT OF SERVICE COST IS GOAL OF LOCAL PHONE ACCESS FEES
description: The decision by the Federal Communications Commission last week to delay the imposition of telephone access charges for consumers and businesses with one telephone line has raised questions about the charges and their purpose. Following, in question-and-answer format, is a discussion of the charges.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: IRENE WORTH I have this passion for sharing words,'' Irene Worth was saying. The actress was explaining her appearance tonight at 8 o'clock at the 92d Street Y at Lexington Avenue, when she will be sharing familiar and rarely heard words of a master: Shakespeare.

title: GLENN STRESSES RURAL VALUES AS ADVISERS STRESS THE SOUTH
description: In the last few days, as Senator John Glenn has gone from rural courthouses to agricultural experiment stations to manufacturing plants across the South, some new phrases have been creeping into the Presidential contender's standard campaign speech.

title: Common Stock
description: * Association Communications Corp., Pittsburgh, is postponing an offering of one million class B common shares.

title: Michaels Seeks Winning Mix
description: Walt Michaels has set his priorities for the training camp program of the New Jersey Generals that begins in Orlando, Fla., today at Central Florida University. ''Cohesiveness,'' the team's new coach said the other day. ''We've got to fit our new players in with the veterans that the Generals have.''

title: Worker Dies, 4 Hurt in Blast
description: An explosion in a metal finishing plant Saturday killed a worker and injured four. Five employees were in the in the Brite Metal Finishing Company plant when the blast came about 11:15 A.M., said Deputy Robert Sutka of the Allegan County Sheriff's Department.

title: Swede Captures Manila Marathon
description: Erik Kjell Stahl of Sweden narrowly beat a British runner, Gerry Helmo, today and won the third Manila International Marathon.

title: AND STILL TWO NATIONS
description: The state of ''black America'' is not just disastrous, as John Jacobs, the National Urban League's president, called it in releasing the League's annual assessment. The situation of the black community is also a reproach to the nation and a threat to its future well-being.

title: DRUSE CHIEF SAYS CABINET MUST QUIT TO HALT FIGHTING
description: The Lebanese Druse leader Walid Jumblat said today that his militia forces would not stop fighting unless the Lebanese Cabinet resigned.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: When the Winter Olympics begin Feb. 7 in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, millions of Americans will keep an eye on figure skating, Alpine skiing and hockey. A few Americans, many of them relatives of the competitors, will also pay attention to the Nordic combined.

title: Ronda J. Ormont Marries Henry Blumberg, Lawyer
description: Ronda J. Ormont, a marketing researcher, and Henry Blumberg, a lawyer, were married yesterday.

title: MONDAY, JANUARY 23, 1984 International
description: The resignation of Lebanon's Cabinet was called for by the Druse leader Walid Jumblat, who said that his militiamen would not stop fighting unless the Cabinet resigned. He said President Gemayel's policies would lead to the complete destruction of Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 4.) The United States has agreed to a Soviet proposal that talks on reducing troops and conventional arms in Central Europe resume March 16 in Vienna. The statement by Secretary of State George P. Shultz was the first formal disclosure that an agreement had been reached on any of the major East-West issues during his five-hour conversation last week with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko. (A1:5.)

title: Seoul to Cut Trade Bars
description: South Korea plans to remove import bans on about 390 commodities this year, raising the proportion of goods that may enter the country free of restrictions to 85 percent, from 80.4 percent, according to the Economic Planning Minister, Shin Byong Hyun.

title: TREASURY'S 2-YEAR NOTES AWAITED
description: This week's auction of $8.25 billion of new two-year Treasury notes is not expected to be much of a burden for the Government securities market, though some participants are looking ahead to Feb. 1, when the Treasury is expected to announce a three-part note and bond sale totaling $15 billion to $16 billion.

description: Goodrich Returns

description: To the Editor:

title: CAREY YEARS IN ALBANY: TOP AIDE LOOKS BACK
description: A year after the end of the Carey administration, its second most powerful official has provided an unusually candid assessment of the former Governor, his work habits and the inner workings of the administration.

title: Ranchers Face Ruin As Horse Deal Fails
description: A hard winter freeze and the collapse of an ambitious horse-raising deal has left more than 100 horses dead and several ranchers facing ruin.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Y.&R. Reunion, But at Kenyon It is going to be Young &

title: ARBOUR THREATENS ISLANDER CHANGES
description: When Al Arbour says ''my patience is definitely running thin'' it is usually a form of veiled threat. The Islander coach left no doubt yesterday about how the 7-1 rout by the Philadelphia Flyers Saturday had thinned his patience when he added, ''you can be sure there will be some changes made.''

title: Boston Rail Bridge To Be Out 6 Months
description: A stubborn fire that destroyed the piers under a Charles River railroad bridge smoldered today, defying firefighters' efforts to get to it, as commuters got word that it would take at least six months to rebuild the bridge.

title: Washington WatchKenneth B. Noble Isaac's Future At the F.D.I.C. WASHINGTON
description: H IS term as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has almost three months to run, but already Washington is alive with speculation about who will succeed William Isaac, or whether he will succeed himself.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: A 'First' on the Job

title: THE CHANGING IMAGE OF COLLEGE SORORITIES
description: The women who gather at alumnae meetings of their sororities this winter will be more likely to be trading business cards or listening to a lecture on personal investing then reminiscing about college days.

title: TROOP-CUT TALKS TO BE RESUMED, SHULTZ DECLARES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States had agreed to a Soviet proposal to resume negotiations on reducing troops and conventional arms in Central Europe on March 16 in Vienna.

title:
The Calendar ;
 Monday
description: This is a big day for Washington re- openings. Congress reconvenes at noon. And tonight, with President Reagan in attendance, the renovated National Theater reopens with a staging of David Merrick's ''42nd Street.'' The 7 P.M. curtain will be preceded by a reception honoring Helen Hayes.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.60

title: NUCLEAR COST STIRS INDIANA 'RATE SHOCK'
description: After canceling its Marble Hill nuclear project, a half-built plant costing nearly $2.5 billion, the Public Service Company of Indiana is desperate for cash.

title: LEINONEN SHOWS ALL-ROUND ABILITY
description: Mikko Leinonen is back in a familiar place, which means he is nowhere in particular.

title: Shell Finds Beaufort Oil HOUSTON, Jan. 22 (AP) - Oil has been found in test drilling in Alaska's Beaufort Sea, the Shell Oil Company said today.
description: The find was made at Seal Island, 12 miles northwest of Prudhoe Bay, and yielded oil at rates translating to 600 to 5,000 barrels a day, Shell said.

title: Homeless, Voiceless, Heartless
description: A homeless woman called Future, described on this page last month and again today, attracted attention because of her devotion to four pet cats. As a ''revolving-door'' mental patient, she deserves more than passing sympathy.

title: HOSPITAL PHILOSOPHER CONFRONTS LIFE'S BASIC ISSUES
description: Dr. Ruth Macklin works all day at Bronx Municipal Hospital, yet she rarely sees patients. She has never performed surgery. She does not even dispense pills.

title: E.P.A. 'FACT SHEET' ON ASBESTOS CALLED INADEQUATE BY AIDE
description: A Government ''fact sheet'' intended to guide school systems in dealing with asbestos insulation found in schools is ''grossly inadequate,'' according to one Environmental Protection Agency official, and could embroil school officials in legal problems.

title: Iraq Threatens Iran Plant Being
description: Iraq has threatened to bomb a chemical plant being built by about 80 Swedish workers in central Iran, saying the factory could be used to produce munitions and help Iran in its war with Iraq.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, JANUARY 23, 1984
description: The Economy

title: BUMPHUS FLOORED, BUT CAPTURES TITLE
description: Johnny Bumphus captured the World Boxing Association junior welterweight title vacated by Aaron Pryor with a unanimous 15-round decision over Lorenzo Garcia of Argentina today. But he could not capture Pryor's excitement.

title: DALLAS CELEBRATES ART MUSEUM BY EDWARD LARRABEE BARNES
description: DALLAS THE new building of the Dallas Museum of Art, which opened to art patrons at a gala dinner last week and which will open to the public on Sunday, looks like the sort of museum that a secure, well-established city might build. It is an immense, sprawling building of limestone, with a great vaulted space at its center, and it bespeaks a kind of self-assurance that is altogether different from the image most Easterners have of Dallas. This is not a nouveau-riche museum, or a pushy one, or a glittery one. It is a museum built by people who know about art and who know about monumentality, and who have shown respect for both.

title: AUTOS ARE RATED IN CONSUMER BOOK
description: A consumer group rates the Ford Mustang and the Volvo DL among the best new automobiles, based on safety and quality, and the Chrysler LeBaron convertible and Volkswagen Rabbit among the worst.

title: Afghan Army Reported To Recapture District
description: Afghan Government officials say their army killed more than 100 anti-Marxist guerrillas over the weekend and recaptured a strategic eastern district bordering Pakistan.

title: BATTLES OVER PRIOR RESTRAINT: VALUES OF FIRST AMENDMENT USUALLY PREVAIL
description: News Analysis

title: MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Miss Zini Takes Slalom
description: Daniela Zini won a World Cup slalom race here today, barely beating her Italian teammate, Maria Rosa Quario. The 25-year-old Miss Zini had a time of 1 minute 42.39 seconds for the two runs down the course.

title: Shoe-Import Quotas Asked
description: Management and labor in the shoe industry joined forces today to ask the Government for protection against imports, which accounted for a record two- thirds of the domestic market in 1983.

title: Hockey Medals
description: The United States may have used some players in the 1980 Olympics who were committed to compete later in the National Hockey League and could be forced to return their gold medals, according to Canada's chief negotiator in international hockey, Alan Eagleson . He was responding to the threat of a protest by United States officials over the eligibility of three Canadian Olympians - Mario Gosselin, Mark Morrison and Dan Wood - who are under professional contracts but have not played more than 10 N.H.L. games. ''We have some information that may indicate that some U. S. players had agreed to terms and to an N.H.L. contract before the 1980 Olympics,'' said Eagleson, who did not name the players.

title: Werblin Is Shifted
description: David A. (Sonny) Werblin has given up his title as chief executive officer of Madison Square Garden Corp. to assume expanded responsibilities hat include joining the board of Paramount Pictures Corp., it was announced yesterday by Gulf x Western Industries, the parent company.

title: InternationalWith a change in Spain, coup
description: Index clouds drift awayA2Diplomats estimate 60 have died

title: CHURCHES PRESS INTERFAITH UNTIY IN PRAYER WEEK
description: Protestant and Roman Catholic clergy in the New York metropolitan area, reflecting an increasing interest in interfaith relations, are exchanging pulpits this week as never before as part of an annual appeal for greater religious unity.

title: CONCERT: 'PORGY AND BESS'
description: There was a time, just over a decade ago, when George Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess'' was considered too offensive to be easily performed, too much of a caricature of blacks with its language (''Bess, you is my woman now'') and slightly sordid plot. But the politicization of the 1960's has faded, leaving ''Porgy and Bess'' in its proper place as something of a musical and cultural classic.

title: Nonprofit Groups GetCityTaxBreak
description: Mayor Koch signed a bill yesterday exempting many nonprofit organizations from paying city real- estate taxes.

title: CENTRAL & SOUTH WEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BLOCK A.T.& T.'S 'HEIST'
description: If A.T.& T. succeeds in its campaign to saddle consumers with the extra cost of local telephone service, it will have pulled off one of the largest corporate heists in the nation's history - with the blessings of the Federal Communications Commission. Under pressure from Republican Senators, the F.C.C. has delayed a final decision on the matter until 1985, when the Presidential election is safely out of the way.

title: Picasso Missing For Second Time
description: A Picasso oil painting, recovered after a 1982 armed robbery, has been reported missing again from the same Long Island home, the Nassau County police confirmed today.

title: Krickstein Wins In U.S. Pro Indoor
description: Aaron Krickstein, at age 16 the youngest in the field, advanced to the second round of the United States Pro Indoor tennis championship today.

title: THE GAME IS THE THING, UNFORTUNATELY
description: In retrospect, it was Lester Hayes,

title: MANVILLE'S CHAPTER 11 BID UPHELD
description: In a major victory for the Manville Corporation, United States Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland refused yesterday to dismiss the Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings the company filed 17 months ago to try to resolve thousands of asbestos- related lawsuits against it.

title: CCX NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Roger Blin, Theater Director; Staged Avant-Garde Works
description: Roger Blin, writer and avant-garde theater director, died of a heart attack Saturday night, his family said Sunday.

title: EAST-WEST DIALOGUES
description: To the Editor:

title: WAVETEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Packwood's Phone Measure
description: Senator Bob Packwood, backed by a coalition of consumer groups, vowed today to seek further delay in the introduction of so-called access charges on telephone users.

title: SWEDEN'S QUIET WAY
description: When the Europe that ultimately broke down in World War II was being torn between Fascism and Communism, Sweden's quiet experiment in Democratic Socialism appeared a shining model. The American journalist Marquis Childs extolled it as the ''middle way,'' the answer to the ravaging battle of ideologies.

title: SHAKLEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The U.N. Today
Norwegian Says Arrest Of K.G.B. Spy Hurt Ties
description: Prime Minister Kare Willoch said today that the arrest of a high-ranking civil servant who admitted spying for the K.G.B. had put a serious strain on relations with the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. Says an Aide Held Talks With Angolans
description: The State Department acknowledged today that one of its top experts on Africa made a weekend trip to the Cape Verde Islands where, it said, he had talks with Angolan officials.

title: Advertising; Selling Country To Cable
description: ''IT is the last mass market left in America; everything else is fractionated. It's not the top. It's not the bottom. It's the fat middle. I'm talking about incomes of $25,000 and $35,000. And they spend, not save.''

title: Fans Greet Raiders
description: Amid relatively little fanfare, the Los Angeles Raiders arrived here late this afternoon.

title: FIRST PRINCIPLES OF ARTFUL AMBIGUITY
description: It happens occasionally to almost everyone in public life. A politician's support is sought on a piece of legislation, an appointment or on potentially sticky issues. The politician seeks to avoid making an immediate commitment.

title: Reagan Names 2 Men To Legal Services Unit
description: President Reagan Saturday appointed two men loyal to his Administration to the board of the Legal Services Corporporation, a group he has sought to abolish.

title: DETROIT EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST AMERICAN BANK & TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OMAHA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CROSS & TRECKER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Key Rates
description: Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Vice Chairman Named By PPG Industries Vincent A. Sarni, named yesterday to be vice chairman and a director of PPG Industries, apparently moves into line for the top job at the glass, paint and chemical maker.
description: Although a company spokesman said, ''This isn't regarded necessarily as a plan of succession,'' L. Stanton Williams, the current chairman, is 64 and will retire Nov. 1. The company's president, J. Earl Burrell, also 64, will retire in October.

title: Strike Continues At Supermarkets
description: Contract negotiations between four supermarket chains and 7,000 striking butchers and delicatessen workers broke off after four hours today, the ninth day of the walkout.

title: Turtle Loses Rubber Flipper
description: Lucky, the giant sea turtle who swam triumphantly after artificial rubber flippers were attached to her shoulders, suffered a setback today when her left flipper fell off. But the surgeon said the 350-pound turtle would be able to swim with a single flipper, as many turtles do, even if reattachment is impossible. She lost both flippers when a hammerhead shark attacked her as she frolicked with her mate in the ocean.

title: MCKELLEN TURNS RITZ INTO GLOBE
description: The applause rippled like a wind over a wheat field, row by row from the back of the Ritz Theater, as Ian McKellen strode down the aisle and sprang onto the stage. That was the unconventional beginning of ''Acting Shakespeare.'' From then on, audience and actor were involved together in spontaneous dialogues and other kinds of stage business seldom tried on Broadway.

title: News Analysis
description: A hallmark of Attorney General William French Smith's tenure at the Justice Department has been his readiness to enforce the law according to the Reagan Administration's conservative philosophy, even when it conflicts with precedents laid down by the courts. Thus, for example, on issues ranging from civil rights to trusts, the Reagan-Smith Justice Department has refused to bring lawsuits to stop some activities that seem unlawful under the United States Supreme Court's interpretations of the Constitution and laws. It has also eschewed certain remedies that the courts have approved, in particular busing as a means of desegregating schools and racial quotas as a means of redressing job discrimination.

title: TAPING OF CALLS BY U.S.I.A. CHIEF CALLED VIOLATION OF FEDERAL RULES
description: The General Services Administration concluded in an official report today that Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, violated Federal regulations by secretly recording telephone calls.

title: Oil Resources Up in Canada OTTAWA, Jan. 23 (Reuters) - Canada's conventional oil resources are estimated at 38 billion barrels, up from 30 billion barrels in 1976, the Energy Department said today.
description: The sharpest increase is for the eastern offshore region, following the discovery of the Hibernia oil deposit. The latest estimate there is 13 billion barrels, up threefold from 4.33 billion barrels in 1976.

title: UNION CARBIDE SHOWS A LOSS
description: The RCA Corporation, bolstered by strong performances in broadcasting, financial services and transportation, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter rose 45.2 percent on a 17 percent increase in revenues.

title: TOP BONN MILITARY LEADERS TO DISCUSS GENERAL'S OUSTER
description: The Inspector General of the West German armed forces announced today that he had called a meeting for Tuesday of the nation's senior commanders to discuss the removal of one of West Germany's most senior generals on the ground that he was a homosexual.

title: 5 Jersey Escapees Back in Custody
description: Five prisoners who escaped from the Passaic County Jail last Thursday were captured or surrendered today, officials said. Three of the prisoners were found hiding in the attic of a Connecticut home.

title: FEDERAL TRIAL STARTS IN DEATHS AT CAROLINA ANTI-KLAN RALLY
description: -SALEM, N.C., Jan. 23 - In opening arguments today in the Federal trial of six Ku Klux Klansmen and three American Nazi Party members, the Federal prosecutor sketched a picture of a methodical slaughter motivated by racial hatred.

title: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are restated for the merger with R & D Associates in February 1983, accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: Watt Seal's Buffalo, A Righty, Faces Left
description: The wandering buffalo on the Interior Department seal is facing left again, ending a flirtation with the right directed by James G. Watt when he was Interior Secretary.

title: MERRILL LYNCH & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $58,228,000. c-Net income.

title: SUPREME COURT ALLOWS EXECUTIONS WITHOUT SPECIAL REVIEW BY STATES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that states may carry out the death penalty without first conducting a special review to insure that the sentence is in line with other sentences imposed in the state for similar crimes.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Share earnings are adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split declared Nov. 22, 1982 and a 3-for-2 stock split declared May 23, 1983.

title: BUSINESSLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PARK COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUPREME COURT LIMITS FEDERAL JUDGES' JURISDICTION
description: The Supreme Court, in a bitterly disputed 5-to- 4 decision, today set a significant new limit on the jurisdiction of the Federal courts to hear suits against state officials and agencies.

title: Canadian Freed Of Drug Charge
description: Mario Parente, a member of the Canadian weight-lifting team, was acquitted today of a charge of illegally importing prescription drugs.

title: FORTRESS ON THE ALERT IN A SIEGE BY THE UNKNOWN
description: The Congress that came back today to grapple with such highly charged issues as whether to keep American troops in war-torn Lebanon found itself in a veritable fortress of its own, a legacy of the Nov. 7 bombing near the Senate chamber.

title: Big Pact for Allen
description: Last spring, Neil Allen , who had been the Mets' top reliever, feared that he had lost his touch, that his baseball career was near a humiliating end. He blamed excessive drinking and wept openly over a streak of poor performances.

title: A Bethlehem Suit Expected
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, announced that it would hold a news conference today at which it is expected to announce the filing of a far-reaching ''escape-clause suit'' aimed at limiting all carbon steel imports. A Bethlehem spokesman said Donald H. Trautlein, the company's chairman, would be joined by Lynn R. Willilams, acting president of the United Steelworkers of America, at the session, which is to be held in Bethlehem, Pa.

title: 53 INDICTED IN FOUR-STATE FEDERAL INVESTIGATION OF COCAINE DEALING
description: Federal grand jury indictments were unsealed Monday charging 53 people with smuggling $3.8 billion worth of cocaine into the United States, the authorities said.

title: HARRIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,800,000 for the quarter and $5,200,000 for the 6 months. Results include the operations of Lanier Business Products, Inc., which was merged into Harris in the second quarter on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: IN SILICON VALLEY, A CITIZEN UNEASY OVER COMPUTERS
description: Engineers, businessmen and financiers come and go around here, talking of RAMS and PROMS, windows and wafers, money and more money. But in a cluttered office in the middle of it all, at least one man wonders whether semiconductor chips are all good.

title: APPLIED BIOSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $125,000 for the quarter and $520,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: OPERA: OTHER 'BOHEME'
description: ''La Boh eme,'' for those who don't already know it, is really twins. Conceived and born almost simultaneously, these two operas - one by Puccini, the other by Leoncavallo - have experienced very different destinies.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Succession in Brooklyn

title: AIRLINE CHAIRMAN
description: Edward J. Daly, the chairman and principal stockholder of World Airways, died last Saturday at his home in Orinda, Calif., after a long illness. He was 61 years old.

title: Steel Production Up By The Associated Press
description: Steel production rose to 1.802 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 2.3 percent from the previous week's 1.762 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 69.7 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 68.2 percent in the previous week. Estimated figures for the year to date showed production at 5.161 million net tons, an increase of 41.7 percent from the 3.642 million net tons in the previous year.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $3,600,000 for the quarter and $4,400,000 for the year. b-Net loss.

FIRST SAVINGS ASSN OF WISCONSIN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $39,000. c-After tax credits of $1,321,000 for the quarter and $5,650,000 for the year. d-After a tax loss of $26,000.

title: LOUISVILLE CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after a pre-tax charge of $4,550,000 from the closing of the Bessemer, Pa. plant.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: OFFICE pallor reached peak level last week. The smart went south. The rest of New York headed for every cocktail party as if their careers depended on it. Indeed, the ongoing fashion show continued, despite temperatures unkind to bare shoulders and, one would think, fashion. Nowhere was there more fashion on view than at the opening Sunday of P.S. 1's winter show, where new expressionist works vied for attention with the downtown art crowd from Manhattan. ''This isn't an art show,'' said a visitor wearing a long coat, black beret and round dark glasses. ''It's the National Hair Show.''

title: MAGIC CHEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Auto Imports Up, Bonn Says
description: Foreign manufacturers took a 27.2 percent share of the West German car market last year, up from 24.9 percent in 1982, the Federal Motor Office said today. Foreign registrations rose to 660,600 units from 537,400.

title: Chess: Spassky and Timman Play To a Tie in the Netherlands
description: Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, and Jan Timman, the Dutch champion, played to a 3-3 tie in their informal match in Hilversum, the Netherlands.

title: WHITE HOUSE OFFERS PLAN TO CLEAR WAY FOR REAGAN LIBRARY
description: Stanford University and Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, have moved a step nearer to a resolution of ground rules for establishing the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library and Museum on the campus, but differences remain over who would run a political policy study center that would be associated with the museum.

title: STATEWIDE BANCORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
UNITED ARTISTS COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 8
description: Revenue for the latest first quarter includes results of the company's 100 percent owned subsidiary, United Artists Cablesystems Corp., on a fully consolidated basis. Year-ago first quarter revenue includes the company's 49 percent share of the earnings of Rogers UA Cablesystems Inc., a predecessor company to United Artists Cablesystems Corp., on an equity accounting basis.

title: Saving Baby Jane From Her Saviors
description: A. Lawrence Washburn, an Albany lawyer, is a very persistent man. When the parents of Long Island's Baby Jane Doe chose to forgo surgery for their tragically handicapped child, he hurled himself into a sad family situation and took them to court.

title: Mets Give Lynch $100,000 Raise
description: The Mets, still brooding over the loss of Tom Seaver to the Chicago White Sox, avoided an arbitration problem with another pitcher yesterday when they signed Ed Lynch to a one-year contract.

title: DEMOCRATS CHOOSE DELEGATES
description: Walter F. Mondale captured at least seven of the first 19 delegates selected to the Democratic National Convention today as two regional caucuses of Democrats in the House of Representatives picked colleagues for the posts.

description: 2 Birds, 1 Stone

description: b-Net loss. c-Includes a gain of $26,400,000 from an accounting change.

title: Water Main Break Disrupts Inwood
description: The break of a 20-inch water main serving the northern tip of Manhattan affected thousands of Inwood residents yesterday afternoon and tied up traffic on the Harlem River Drive for part of the evening rush period, authorities reported.

title: SHOPPING MALLS' ASSAULT ON FREE SPEECH
description: To the Editor:

title: Nathan Award Won By Herbert Blau
description: Herbert Blau has been named the 1982-83 winner of the George Jean Nathan Award for Dramatic Criticism. The $5,000 award will be given to Mr. Blau for his writings on the theater, as exemplified by two recent books, ''Take Up the Bodies'' and ''Blooded Thought: Occasions of Theater.''

title: SCOUTING
description: Eyeing the Board

title: THOUSANDS RALLY AGAINST ABORTION
description: Tens of thousands of people rallied against abortion here today and their leaders backed President Reagan and said they would work to defeat six Senators at the polls.

description: The Terex Corporation said it had cut the salary and benefits of 320 hourly workers at two plants by 31 percent.

description: b-Net loss.

description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $5 million for the quarter and $14 million for the year and a gain of $1.4 million for the quarter and year on the repurchase of bonds. c-Net loss. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $10.3 million and a gain of $18.9 million on the repurchase of bonds.

title: FREUD: SECRET DOCUMENT REVEAL YEARS OF STRIFE
description: WHAT are we to make of it all? Dr. Jeffrey Masson, a Freudian scholar and provocative critic of the establishment, maintains that the light he has shed on the so-called seduction theory of Freud is, in effect, such a powerful attack on orthodox analysis that it will undo it. And the documents Dr. Masson unveiled point to a greater meanness of spirit than ever seen in Freud's official biographies as well as suggesting a previously unknown suppression of information.

title: G.M. Confirms It's Looking at Jaguar DETROIT, Jan. 23 (AP) - The General Motors Corporation confirmed that it had been examining the possibility of buying Jaguar Cars Ltd., the British maker of high-priced sports cars, but said no offer had been made. The British Government is planning to sell a number of state- owned companies, including Jaguar.
description: Jaguar, a subsidiary of BL Ltd. (formerly British Leyland), has had declining sales in recent years, but sold a recortd 29,000 cars in 1983.

title: NEW JERSEY RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOGAN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
McDonald's Suit
description: The McDonald's Corporation said a jury in Cook County, Ill., circuit court had awarded the Central Ice Cream Corporation $52 million in a suit filed against McDonald's.

title: YALE GROUP PAYS HOMAGE TO ELIZABETH I
description: The Queen swept into the Great Hall, followed by nearly 300 of her devoted subjects. For several hours, she feasted on a Sur-Loyn of Roast Beef, Buttered Colliflowers, Taffety Tarts and Raisins of the Sunne.

description: The Norlin Corporation said it is exploring the possibility of a merger of the company or a sale of one or more subsidiaries.

description: TAMPA, Fla.

HOME BANK & TRUST CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SCIENTISTS AMAZED BY THE MOLE RAT'S BIZARRE BEHAVIOR
description: AGROUP of scientists studying the naked mole rat, a rare hairless rodent that lives in East Africa, have recently found that the seldom-seen creature has one of the most bizarre social behavior patterns of any mammal in the animal kingdom.

title: REPRIEVE FROM WOUND TESTS IS ENDED FOR PIGS AND GOATS
description: The Pentagon has lifted a ban on shooting animals other than dogs and cats in a research and training program for treating soldiers' wounds, it was learned today.

title: SMITHKLINE BECKMAN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $3,444,000 for the quarter and $4,510,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $2,116,000 for the quarter and income of $538,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: DIAGNON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Since the company went public in July, there were no comparable year- ago results.

title: Jewish Scholar Quits Interfaith Conference
description: An Orthodox Jewish scholar who participated in an interfaith conference last week in Lucerne, Switzerland, left the meeting early and has denounced the proceedings.

title: Large Deficit for American Express
description: The American Express Company yesterday reported a $21.9 million loss in the fourth quarter, compared with a $156.3 million profit the year before. While the loss stemmed from previously reported problems with the company's Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, its magnitude surprised analysts.

title: Coasting Crash Kills Youth
description: A teen-ager who was coasting down a snow-covered hill on a serving tray was killed when he collided with two other people doing the same thing, the police said today. The youth, Kenneth Razzetti, 19 years old, of New Hyde Park, died at University Hospital in Stony Brook at 11:43 P.M. Sunday, about an hour after the accident.

title: Reversal Plea Set On Byron Plant CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (Reuters) - The Commonwealth Edison Company said it would ask the Nuclear Regualatory Commision's appeal board to reverse a decision by the Atomic Safety and Licensing Board on Jan. 13 denying Edison an operating license for its Byron nuclear plant. The utility said there is additional evidence to support its contention that the $3.35 billion plant is safe.
description: The utility also said it plans to reduce spending for construction projects by $200 million from 1984-88, to $5.25 billion, as a result of programs nearing completion. James O'Connor, president of Commonwealth, said the reduced outlays would occur ''in spite of the fact that estimated completion costs of the nuclear units under construction have increased.'' The utility is building five units.

title: HARDWARE REVIEW: APPLE WEIGHS IN WITH MACINTOSH
description: WHEN it comes to apples, I've always preferred tart, crisp ones like Granny Smiths or Idas to McIntoshes. It seems to me, therefore, that as a new name in Apple Computer's growing orchard of machines one of those would have done admirably. What could sound more ''user friendly'' than a Granny Smith computer around the house. Then again, maybe Apple had hamburgers on the mind in naming its new computer - in hopes of its Mac becoming as much a part of the American mythos as the golden arches are.

title: STANDARD HAVENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RESEARCH SERVICE FOR WOMEN
description: A call once came from a 55-year-old woman whose husband had informed her that he wanted a divorce after 24 years of marriage. Another call was from a woman who discovered that her husband had been having an affair with her sister. Other calls that come on a regular basis involve matter-of-fact questions about, among other things, where to get legal help or inexpensive gynecological service or where to find short-term shelter or statistics on the percentage of Middle Western households headed by women.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar , the Los Angeles Lakers' star center, suffered a strained lower back and a bruised right knee in a minor auto collision Monday in the parking lot of The Forum in Inglewood, Calif. A spokesman for the team said he was not seriously hurt and was expected to play Tuesday against the Phoenix Suns. . . . In New York, Rod Higgins , the Chicago Bulls' forward, was released from Lenox Hill Hospital Monday. He had undergone tests after suffering a seizure and concussion when he fell and hit his head in a game against the Knicks last Thursday night at Madison Square Garden. . . . The New Jersey Devils have assigned Grant Mulvey , a right wing, to the Maine Mariners of the American Hockey league for two weeks of conditioning. . . . Barry Beck , the Ranger defenseman who suffered a mild concussion Saturday night in Toronto, now has muscle spasms of the left shoulder and neck, and his status is doubtful for Wednesday night's game in Pittsburgh.

title: REPUBLICANS SEEK MORE MEMBERS TO BOLSTER CAMPAIGN
description: President Reagan's campaign organization has taken the first step of what it hopes will be the most ambitious national drive to register Republican voters in more than a decade. Leaders of the drive consider it critical to bolstering Mr. Reagan's re- election chances.

title: MSI DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
EWING HELPS HOYAS TOP BOSTON COLLEGE
description: Patrick Ewing scored 15 points, grabbed 13 rebounds and blocked 7 shots in leading Georgetown to a 92-83 victory over Boston College tonight in a Big East Conference game.

title: Talks Ended in Strike Against Phelps Dodge
description: Renewed negotiations broke down today after only 90 minutes of talks between the Phelps Dodge Corporation and 13 striking copper unions representing 2,300 workers who have been off the job six months.

title: ADVERTISING ; An Olympic Ad Debut For the Macintosh
description: Although Apple's long-awaited Macintosh computer is finally being introduced today, the first consumer advertising will not break until the Winter Olympics next month, when Apple will make a $5 million advertising commitment. Then, with the exception of a print extravaganza in March, the next advertising will not arrive until a June-September burst.

title: State Fines Charter Unit The New York State Insurance Department said yesterday that it had imposed a $100,000 fine on the Charter Company's New York life insurance unit for making investments in violation of state law. The department said the investments were illegal when they were made, although changes in state law would make some of them acceptable today. It also said they had not had a ''material impact'' on Charter's soundness.
description: Last year, the Charter Company, through insurance subsidiaries in New Jersey and New York, was the largest issuer of single-premium deferred annuities.

title: STANDARD OIL (IND) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NORTHERN TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $16.7 million for the quarter and $41.3 million for the year. c-Including tax credits of $4 million for the quarter and $7 million for the year.

description: Quarterly results are for 13 weeks for the latest period and 14 weeks for the year-ago period. All results are pro forma.

description: The Day After

title: CORNELL OFFICIAL TO TRY AGAIN IN MANHATTAN RACE FOR HOUSE
description: Betty Lall, who ran unsuccessfully for the House of Representatives from the East Side of Manhattan two years ago, said yesterday she would try again.

title: New Lionel Plan By Reuters
description: The Lionel Corporation, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, said it had agreed in principle with its creditors and shareholders committee on a revised plan of reorganization that would provide general unsecured creditors at least $72.3 million in cash, after payment of administrative expenses and priority claims, and $5.3 million shares of the company's common stock, or about 43 percent of the post-reorganization common stock. Claims of unsecured creditors, including those of banks and trade suppliers, are about $118 million. The company said it has no secured debt.

title: OMARK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hiller Chapter 11
description: Hiller Aviation Inc. said that it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws and that almost all its employees had been terminated, effective Friday.

title: PARIS: LUXURY IN SPRING COUTURE
description: The small gold chairs in the crowded salons and the mannequins with faraway looks are things of the past. The spring and summer showings of the haute couture - the high-fashion branch of the fashion business - are now presented in hotel ballrooms and other large spaces. The models look lively and make eye contact with the audience.

title: EMERSON RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,369,000, or 50 cents a share, related to a securities offering by Imatron Inc., the company's 18 percent-owned affiliate and the exercise of warrants and conversion of long-term debt for common shares of Cardiac Resuscitator Corp., its 71 percent-owned subsidiary, and represents the increased carrying value of Emerson's investment in both concerns. c-Net loss.

title: A Norwest Unit Offering Stock Norwest Mortgage Inc., a Minneapolis-based mortgage banking firm, said it had filed for an offering of $40 million of shares of Norwest Realty Investors, a newly organized self- liquidating real estate development fund. Norwest said the Realty Investors unit would operate as a separate entity, owned by its shareholders, and that a unit of Norwest Mortgage would act as an adviser to the fund.
description: Norwest said the fund is expected to invest primarily in mortgages with equity participation, mostly newer existing commercial property in the United States. The underwriting group, Norwest said, would be led by Dain Bosworth Inc. The initial public offering price is expected to be $10 a share. Norwest Mortgage is a unit of the Norwest Corporation, a diversified financial services company.

title: PBA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: An article and a picture caption yesterday about inspections of unheated New York City apartments misstated the number of inspectors in the field citywide on Sunday. There were 80.

BRIEFS
description: Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association said it had set Jan. 30 as the record date for determining what stockholders will be entitled to vote at its special shareholders meeting on Feb. 9.

title: Wells Fargo Debt
description: Wells Fargo & Company announced that it had filed for a shelf offering of up to $250 million in debt securities.

title: Israel Says Its Troops Hurt 3 Jordanians by Firing in Error
description: Israeli troops who saw a ''suspicious form'' they took to be a terrorist escaping toward Jordan on Saturday fired across the border southeast of the Sea of Galilee and accidentally wounded three Jordanian villagers, the Israeli Army spokesman said today.

title: CONVERGENT'S NEW CHALLENGE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company surprised many in the office computer industry earlier this month when it picked little-known Convergent Technologies Inc. to supply ''certain products'' exclusively for its information systems division.

description: b-Net income.

title: SPACE TELESCOPE PROJECT OVERCOME OBSTACLES
description: Astronomers get, well, starry-eyed thinking of all that the large space telescope should accomplish. From an orbital vantage point its finely polished 94-inch mirror should bring into focus heavenly vistas never before seen, objects 50 times fainter and seven times farther away than anything ever glimpsed through ground-based instruments. The view is certain to bring a galaxy of discoveries as well as some profound changes in man's understanding of the universe. A year ago, however, these visions of discovery seemed on the verge of vanishing into a black hole of technical and management troubles. The guidance sensors for pointing the telescope were suspected of being deficient. Dust contaminated the mirror. Alignment of instruments in flight suddenly seemed to be an engineering impossibility. Costs were soaring and

title: ALPHA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCIENCE WATCH
description: celled organisms, be they plants or animals, depend on plumbing and other internal systems to process and distribute food and energy. But another approach appears to have been tested in creatures that evolved 670 million years ago, when higher forms of life began to emerge.

title: BOND PRICES LITTLE CHANGED
description: Prices of fixed-income securities moved narrowly yesterday in dull trading. Dealers said institutional investors were largely absent from the market and would probably remain away until the Treasury announced the terms for the midquarter refunding on Feb. 1.

title: FARMER BROTHERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AFFIRMATIVE ACTION: 'WE CANNOT DO WITHOUT'
description: To the Editor:

title: John R. Beishline, 78, General and Teacher
description: Brig. Gen. John R. Beishline, who was special assistant to Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway in 1952 when General Ridgway was Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers in Europe and was Army liaison with the White House under President Truman, died Thursday in Clearwater, Fla.

description: At least 54 people were feared to have drowned and 42 were missing after a ferry capsized Sunday off Tawitawi Island in the southern Philippines, the police said today.

title: TUESDAY, JANUARY 24, 1984 International
description: The Marines could not be withdrawn suddenly from Lebanon without raising questions about the United States commitment to ''moderation and negotiation in the Middle East,'' according to President Reagan. In a policy statement, he said the Soviet Union, Syria and Iran were complicating efforts to bring about Lebanese national unity. (Page A1, Column 6.) Bills to bring the Marines home from Lebanon ahead of the current schedule will be acted on swiftly, Democratic leaders pledged as Congress returned to work after a two-month recess. As the second session of the 98th Congress began, leaders of both parties predicted that the election- year session would be short, unproductive and partisan. (A1:5.)

description: New York State today turned down an application by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation for assistance in financing a court-ordered cleanup of a major toxic waste dump outside Niagara Falls.

title: NEW YORK ; NO DRINKS ON THE HOUSE
description: The big oil companies are always saying that the press picks on them, so when headlines popped up a few months ago accusing the Exxon Corporation, in effect, of purloining water from the Hudson River, it was a good opportunity to check and see if much-abused big oil was being victimized again.

title: Kodak Layoffs
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it wants to cut 1,250 more employees from its payroll in the Rochester area by the end of March and said it would offer incentives to workers who volunteer for severance.

description: b-Net loss. The company noted that sales for the previous year were adversely affected by a strike at the Caterpillar Tractor Co., a major customer of Simpson Industries.

description: Jed Kesey, the 20-year-old son of the author Ken Kesey, died today of injuries suffered in an accident on an icy road.

title: TV: 'KATHTRYN BECK'
description: ''THE LOST HONOR OF KATHRYN BECK'' is a cautionary tale - earnest, gripping and intense. Mostly, its target is police detention and intimidation of witnesses. At the same time, it has it in for the press. Politically, it is trendy and up to date, with something in it for everyone, although in its heart it is a melodrama. The two-hour movie will be seen on CBS at 9 tonight.

description: TAMPA, Fla.

description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 32 percent. Digital's stock rose sharply last week when it said that its earnings would greatly exceed Wall Street predictions.

description: Less than 12 hours after his Los Angeles Raiders had scored the most points ever in a Super Bowl, Coach Tom Flores was praising the defense.

title: Energizing Justice
description: The resignation of Attorney General William French Smith gives President Reagan a chance to fill a leadership void at the Department of Justice. Edwin Meese may fill the void - but is not likely to do much to improve the quality of justice. From his perch as White House counselor, Mr. Meese has already moved into the vacuum at Justice, supporting and sometimes directing some of the Department's most offensive actions.

title: TRUANCY: ATTENDANCE TEACHERS VANSIHING
description: -grade pupil and his mother were waiting for Peter Romano when he arrived the other day at their home, a two-family house not far from Prospect Park in Brooklyn. The child had not been in class for a month, though he left for school most mornings, and Mr. Romano, an attendance teacher, was trying to find out why.

A REPOTER'S NOTEBOOK: INTRODUCING AN ASTRONAUT
description: Introducing a man who, as those who are charged with doing it almost inevitably put it, needs no introduction can produce some problems of its own.

title: Cycle Marks Set
description: The Italian cyclist Francesco Moser broke his world records for 5 and 20 kilometers today and another for distance covered in an hour. In his attempt, Moser rode continuously for one hour, aiming to break the records for 5 kilometers, 10 kilometers, 20 kilometers and the distance mark, all of which he set last Thursday on the same track here.

title: GTE Debentures
description: The GTE Corporation announced that its $200 million issue of 12 1/4 percent debentures due in 1994 had been priced at 99 1/2, to yield 12.338 percent, through underwriters led by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. The debentures, from an earlier shelf registration filing, were priced at 74 basis points (hundredths of a percentage point) above the rate on 10-year Treasury notes, GTE said. The issue is rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBBx by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Samuel Gardner, 92, Is Dead; Violinist and Juilliard Teacher
description: Samuel Gardner, a violinist and composer, died yesterday at his home in New York. He was 92 years old.

description: An earthquake that jarred a 200-mile stretch from San Francisco to San Luis Obispo Sunday was followed today by eight aftershocks along the Monterey Peninsula.

title: ALLYING WITH ISRAEL
description: The inaugural meetings in Washington this week of the United States-Israel Joint Political Military Group represents the first small but significant step toward creating a full-fledged alliance between the West's superpower and its one reliable and democratic ally in the troubled Middle East.

description: The Economy

title: Judge Proposes Dual Brink's Jury
description: The presiding judge suggested a dual jury for the trial of Kathy Boudin and Samuel Brown, accused of robbery and murder in the holdup of a Brink's truck in Nanuet on Oct. 20, 1981.

title: PITFALLS IN SHOWERING CENTRAL AMERICA WITH U.S. 'BENEFICENCE'
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: 'PUDDINHEAD WILSON'ADPATED
description: MARK TWAIN'S ''Pudd'nhead Wilson'' was published in 1894, and is considered one of his major works. The story begins in 1830, and has been described as a significant literary description of the effects of racial prejudice in America prior to the outbreak of the Civil War. That may be so, but I find the novel disturbing in ways that the author undoubtedly did not intend. And my qualms have not been alleviated by the television adaptation that can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on WNET- TV, Channel 13, as part of the prestigious ''American Playhouse'' series.

title: OVERNITE TRANSPORTATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: City Samizdat

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: SINGING AT SWEETWATERS Rhetta Hughes is the energetic woman with the big, stirring voice who starred on Broadway recently as a Harlem preacher in the musical ''Amen Corner.'' The critics were enthusiastic about her performance, but not about the show itself, which vanished not long after it opened.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Visits Paris
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain met with President Francois Mitterrand for two and a half hours today to discuss major problems facing the Common Market. A spokesman for the President said the meeting was the first of a series the President plans with Common Market leaders. Mrs. Thatcher left immediately after the meeting to return to London.

title: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FREUD: SECRET DOCUMENTS REVEAL YEARS OF STRIFE
description: -secret documents offer further indications of Sigmund Freud's anguish over his first major theory, new evidence of efforts to cover up that anguish and provide important new information about the life of the man himself.

title: Drivers Agree To Times Contract
description: The New York Times and its drivers reached a tentative agreement late last night on a three-year contract extension, according to Howard Bishow, vice president of employee relations for The Times. The agreement is contingent upon ratification by vote of the union's general membership.

title: IN SPAIN, THE COUP CLOUDS DRIFT AWAY
description: Only history will tell whether last Monday's small, ceremonial gathering in a columned room of the Prime Minister's residence was really a turning point. But for the moment, most of the Spanish press and most of the people seem content to think so.

U.S. Court Grants Stay In Florida Execution
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit early today granted a 35-hour stay of execution for convicted killer Anthony Antone, less than seven hours before he was to die in Florida's electric chair.

description: b-Net income.

description: Joseph O'Brien has no diploma, no job and no prospects, but he does have some advice for students tempted to drop out of high school: don't.

title: U.S. DEFICIT IN 1985 TO BE $180 BILLION, REAGAN AIDES SAY
description: President Reagan will send to Congress next week a budget for the fiscal year 1985 with a projected deficit of $180 billion based on spending of $925.5 billion, Administration officials said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Two interest rate charts in Business Day yesterday carried incorrect labels. Corrected charts appear today on page D15.

VAULTER BAFFLED BY NEW POLE
description: This winter, says Billy Olson, he wants to pole-vault less and enjoy it more. So far, he is meeting the first objective and is unsure about the second.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Atari Realignment Of Management Set
description: Atari Inc., the troubled unit of Warner Communications Inc., announced a realignment of management yesterday ''to position the company for future growth.''

title: ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After foreign currency translation losses of $388,000 for the quarter and $2.5 million for the year and a gain of $718,000, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter from the liquidation of LIFO inventories. c-Including a gain of $755,000, or 14 cents a share, from the liquidation of LIFO inventories. d-After a foreign currency translation loss of $351,000. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 3, 1984.

title: RENOVATED NATIONAL THEATER OPENS
description: With a long line of ticket buyers in the lobby, a hit Broadway musical on stage and President Reagan in the audience, the historic National Theater reopened here today after more than a year and a half of renovations.

description: Q.

title: French Stand On E.E.C. BRUSSELS, Jan. 23 (Reuters) - France told its skeptical Common Market partners today that it was determined to complete talks on a European Economic Community financial rescue before a conference of community leaders in eight weeks, diplomats said.
description: The French Foreign Minister, Claude Cheysson, who was chairman at a gathering of foreign ministers meeting for the first time since France took over the group's presidency Jan. 1, said preparatory work would be done mainly in private contacts.

title: STATE'S CHIEF JUDGE URGES 30 JUDGESHIPS AND HIGHER SALARIES
description: New York State's Chief Judge urged Governor Cuomo yesterday to pay for 30 new judgeships, saying, ''we have already arrived at the outer limit of judicial output'' and ''there is no more stretch in the rubber band.''

title: CANADIAN COUPLE WIN $11 MILLION IN LOTTERY
description: After a nine- day wait, a Canadian truck driver and his wife today claimed a tax-free lottery prize, a check for $13,890,588.80, or more than $11 million in United States currency. It was the largest lottery prize ever won in North America.

title: BANCOHIO GETS BID FROM NATIONAL CITY
description: The National City Corporation, a banking holding company based in Cleveland, yesterday offered to buy the BancOhio Corporation, a bank stock holding company in Columbus, Ohio, for $35 a share in cash and securities, or a total of about $280 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's just too much for one person to win.'' - Lillian Kelly, who with her husband, Stuart, won Canada's $11 million tax-free lottery prize. (A1:5.)

description: Net income figures include $800,000 for the quarter and $19.5 million for the year from the sale of tax attributes and a net gain of $29.1 million for the year from the divestment of peripheral businesses.

BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Ex-President of Yale Gets London Law Post Kingman Brewster Jr., former president of Yale University and the United States Ambassador to Britain from 1977-81, says he is ''extravagantly happy'' to be returning to London as an overseas partner of the New York City law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts. The commitment is for two years, but Mr. Brewster said he and his wife expect to remain in London indefinitely.
description: Before this appointment, Mr. Brewster was part-time counsel to Winthrop, Stimson in New York. He replaces Robert W. Gray, who is returning to the New York office.

title: Food Poisoning Postpones Game
description: An outbreak of food poisoning on the Vancouver Whitecaps has resulted in the postponement of Tuesday night's North American Soccer League game with the San Diego Sockers.

title: WHAT CAUSED FALL OF EASTER ISLANDERS?
description: THE fall of the civilization that carved more than 600 huge, elongated stone heads on Easter Island, 2,000 miles off the coast of Chile, has long been among the most tantalizing of archeological mysteries. One proposed solution, now receiving renewed support from the analysis of pollen grains embedded in the island's volcanic craters, has been an environmental collapse following the deforestation of the island by its inhabitants.

title: Car Expenses Found Lower DETROIT, Jan. 23 (UPI) - Car prices rose, but lower interest rates and gasoline prices made it cheaper to own and operate a typical new car in 1983 than in 1982, according to an annual Hertz Corporation study released today.
description: Hertz, the nation's largest auto rental-leasing agency, said it cost 43.28 cents a mile to operate a typical new car last year, compared with 44.67 cents in 1982.

title: SmithKline Earnings Rise
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation, a Philadelphia- based pharmaceutical company, reported yesterday that its net income was $119.8 million, or $1.44 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1983, up from $117.5 million, or $1.42 a share, a year earlier.

title: Timely Help for the Disabled
description: Thanks to New York City's Corporation Counsel, Frederick A.O. Schwarz Jr., a class of mentally disabled New Yorkers will again get Federal help. More than that, his energetic court action has given the nation compelling evidence of how callously the Reagan Administration mishandled the Social Security disability program.

title: JUSTICES ACCEPT SCHWAB CASE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to review the legality of the BankAmerica Corporation's 1983 acquisition of the country's biggest discount broker, Charles Schwab & Company.

title: Bridge: If You Stumble Into Trouble, Keep Your Foes in the Dark

title: PROVOST OF CHICAGO U. WILL HEAD SMITHSONIAN
description: Robert McCormick Adams, provost of the University of Chicago, was named today secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, becoming the ninth person to hold that post, perhaps the most important scientific and cultural position in the United States.
