ARGENTINA SIGNS ACCORD WITH CHILE
description: Chile and Argentina signed a friendship agreement at the Vatican today in which they pledged to resolve peacefully a longstanding territorial dispute over a strategic waterway. The friendship pact was mediated by Pope John Paul II.

title: CdF Chimie Plant
description: CdF Chimie, the chemical division of Charbonnages de France, said it is considering building a $500 million plant in Quebec to extract urea from natural gas for use in making chemical fertilizer. Jacques Neveu, an official for the province's investment corporation, Societe Generale de Financement, said he expected Quebec would take part in the project with CdF Chimie but said an agreement had not been reached. The end product would be used largely in the CdF Chimie marketing network abroad, but 30 percent would be sold in Canada.

description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), citing increased foreign oil production, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 10.6 percent. But the Atlantic Richfield Company, another major oil concern, said lower international crude prices in the quarter resulted in a 3.5 percent earnings decline.

description: b-Net loss.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Student Loan Marketing Association said it had committed to buy $40 million of student loans from First National Bank of Commerce, New Orleans, over the next four years. Sallie Mae said the the transaction constitutes the largest forward purchase commitment ever issued in its southern region.

title: A BIG LOSS FOR MERRILL IN QUARTER
description: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $42.1 million - its first quarterly loss since going public in 1971 - after setting aside $88 million for repayments to investors who bought annuities from the Baldwin-United Corporation, now in bankruptcy proceedings.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alpha Software Corp., Burlington, Mass., a supplier of business and professional software for I.B.M. personal computers and compatibles, has named Jon C. Witt to the new position of senior vice president of sales operations.

title: Reagan Issues Report On Soviet Compliance
description: President Reagan sent to Congress today a secret report of more than 50 pages on the possible noncompliance by the Soviet Union with several treaties.

description: Knicks vs. Philadelphia 76ers , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The last time the teams played, the 76ers, with Julius Erving out of the lineup, were held to the lowest Garden score of any pro team in 8 years as the Knicks romped to a 111-73 victory.

title: NBC AND ABC HALT RERUN SALE TALKS
description: Two of the three commercial television networks, NBC and ABC, have broken off efforts to negotiate a compromise in their dispute with Hollywood producers over the right to own and sell reruns of prime-time television shows.

title: CHINA IS SAID TO END A CAMPAIGN TO STOP 'SPIRITUAL POLLUTION'
description: China's formal campaign against ''spiritual pollution'' has been effectively canceled, according to Chinese and Western diplomats here.

title: MIDLANTIC BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures are fully diluted. The year-end totals reflect the acquisition of the Greater Jersey Bancorp. which joined the Midlantic system in August 1983.

title: CONGRESS READY FOR TOUGH FIGHT ON BEIRUT FORCE
description: As Congress returned to work today after a two-month recess, Democratic leaders said they would move swiftly on legislation to reduce the time limit Congress imposed on the use of Marines in Lebanon.

title: MEESE NOMINATED TO SUCCEED SMITH AT JUSTICE DEPT.
description: President Reagan today announced his selection of Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, to succeed William French Smith as United States Attorney General.

title: EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $4,646,000 from discontinued operations.

title: TEXACO BID FOR GETTY ADVANCES
description: Texaco Inc. settled litigation yesterday with all the heirs of J. Paul Getty in a major step toward completing its takeover of the Getty Oil Company.

title: Murdoch Takes Case to F.C.C. News International, headed by Rupert Murdoch, asked the Federal Communications Commission to order Warner Communications Inc. and Chris-Craft Industries to rescind an exchange of stock completed last week. It argued, as it has in other proceedings, that the exchange violated F.C.C. rules against dual ownership of television stations and cable TV in the same markets. Warner and Chris- Craft responded that they had avoided any conflict with F.C.C. rules when Warner shifted control of the cable properties to a subsidiary of the American Express Company, its partner in Warner Amex Cable.
description: Meanwhile, Chris-Craft increased its stake in Warner to approximately 20 percent by purchasing about 820,000 shares on the open market, according to Chris-Craft's chairman, Herbert J. Siegel.

title: ENVOYS ESTIMATE 60 HAVE DIED IN MOROCCAN RIOTS
description: Diplomats in Morocco estimated today that 60 people had died in two weeks of sporadic rioting in Moroccan cities, particularly in the north on the Mediterranean coast.

title: PLAYING THE ODDS ON MORTGAGES
description: When Ruddie and JoAnn Borchelt of Kansas City, Mo., bought an $84,000 home last week, they tied their future financial security to the uncertain tides of the national economy.

title: ASSEMBLY IN ALBANY PASSES BILL TO SET UP CONSUMER-ORIENTED UTILITY BOARD
description: The Assembly passed a bill today that would establish an independent board to argue the case for consumers when utilities request rate increases. The vote came as a signal that the legislators were dissatisfied with Governor Cuomo's effort to do the same thing through administrative action.

title: CABOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NBI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUMMIT HEALTH LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
T.V.A. LAYS OFF HUNDREDS OVER NUCLEAR PLANT SAFETY
description: Officials at the country's largest nuclear power plant have laid off several hundred workers and say they will keep one of the three reactors shut down until they are confident that employees can repair and maintain it properly.

title: SIPE IS IMPRESSED BY WALKER'S SPEED
description: Discovering how fast players can run 40 yards is a long-standing custom at the start of professional football training camps.

title: A.C.L.U. Would Join Publication Ban Case
description: The American Civil Liberties Union, claiming a violation of the First Amendment, was seeking today to enter a case in which an appeals court blocked publication of a ruling by a Federal judge.

title: James M. Fiore Jr., 36, Dies; Manager of Broadway Shows
description: James M. Fiore Jr., partner of Didia/Fiore, theatrical managers of Broadway and Off Broadway shows, died of complications from pneumonia Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Sunday on the William H. Zimmer nuclear plant in Ohio incorrectly characterized a November 1982 order by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The commission ordered a halt to all work on the plant's safety-related systems because of questions about whether the work was being done properly.

title: 3 Plead Guilty In Cocaine Case
description: Three men pleaded guilty today to lesser charges in a drug trafficking case that had already resulted in three-month prison terms for four players for the Kansas City Royals.

title: A 79.8% Gain in Quarter For International Paper The International Paper Company, the nation's largest paper manufacturer, yesterday reported a 79.8 percent increase in net earnings in the fourth quarter of 1983.
description: The New York-based company said fourth-quarter earnings rose to $68.7 million, or $1.25 a share, from $38.2 million, or 64 cents, a year earlier. Net income in the 1983 period was buoyed by a special $17.5 million provision for income taxes.

title: STUDENTS' SCORES ON TESTS CLIMB IN CONNECTICUT
description: Connecticut's ninth-grade public school students made ''dramatic'' improvements this year in proficiency tests for basic skills, the State Education Commissioner said today.

title: Poachers Said to Kill Starving Deer in West
description: Hungry deer gathering at troughs set up to feed them during the severe winter weather are being shot by poachers out for a thrill, state officials say.

title: Coach Censured
description: Jim Lessig , commissioner of the Mid-American Conference, publicly reprimanded Coach Danny Nee of Ohio University yesterday for pulling his team off the floor for the final four seconds of a game at Bowling Green Saturday.

title: CLOSE AND SHREWD ALLY OF THE PRESIDENT: EDWIN MEESE 3D
description: In the evolutionary tides that buffet politicians between oblivion and adaptation at the White House, Edwin Meese 3d has exhibited the tortoise's knack for survival. Relying on a thick shell and a relentless, unspectacular pace, Mr. Meese perfected the art of tucking his head back from the close-range nips of Administration rivals. More than most other denizens there, he kept the path well worn to his source of survival, President Reagan himself.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHILDREN DONATE TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: ''Do you know why we saved the money for you? Because we want you to have food and be healthy. We saved our money for you because we want you to be happy.''

description: On-the-Job Training

title: 4 Europeans Killed By Ugandan Rebels
description: Gunmen believed to be Ugandan anti-Government guerrillas killed four Europeans Sunday in what appeared to be an attempt to discredit the Government's security record, diplomatic sources said today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ALTHOUGH I had been subject to headaches since my early teens and had sought an explanation and relief from half a dozen physicians of varying specialties, it was not until age 40 that I discovered the real cause of the headaches: muscle spasms in the joints of my jaws, popularly known as TMJ (for temporomandibular joint) syndrome. TMJ syndrome, or myofacial pain dysfunction, afflicts tens of millions of Americans, most of whom are unaware of the cause of their suffering and the possibility of a simple solution.

title: More Deaths Reported In Morocco Food Riots RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 24 (AP) - Several people were killed Monday in a clash between Government forces and demonstrators in a northeastern village, local and diplomatic sources said today. title: The Civil Rights Commission as Parrot

Small and lacking enforcement power, the commission relied on its voice. It gathered and presented solid evidence of discrimination, prodding Presidents and Congress to bring equal opportunity closer to reality. Sadly, however, the commission is now becoming a parrot.

title: IMPERILED HOSPITAL UNION
description: Solidarity is the glue that holds organized labor together. Its global stretch makes American labor one with Poland's suppressed free trade union. It underpins the sense of shared purpose on which Lane Kirkland relies to keep the A.F.L.-C.I.O. united behind the Presidential candidacy of Walter F. Mondale. But it is deplorably absent in what for a quarter century has been one of the few exemplars of dynamic growth and social inventiveness in a sagging labor movement, the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees.

title: CINCINNATI UTILITY
description: Three outside directors of the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company have resigned, just days after the utility and two partners decided to convert the unfinished, $1.7 billion Zimmer generating plant from nuclear power to coal because of soaring nuclear costs. The three served on the utility board's special committee to examine litigation against the company involving charges of mismanagement relating to the construction of the Zimmer project. A utility spokesman said today that he had no sign from the three directors that they quit because of the latest developments concerning the project.

description: With fewer suburban shopping malls being built and with rents at many existing malls increasing steadily, some retail chain store operators are taking a new look at neighborhood shopping strips in older urban areas surrounding Manhattan and finding good locations for themselves.

title: Court Upholds Ruling On Bias in I.Q. Tests

title: APPLE IS EXPECTING REBOUND IN PROFITS
description: Apple Computer Inc. expects its profits to begin rising again ''by the end of the year,'' John Sculley, president and chief executive, said today.

title: Reagan Names Interior Aide
description: President Reagan today nominated Ann Dore McLaughlin to be undersecretary of the Interior Department, succeeding J. J. Simmons 3d. Since 1981, Mrs. McLaughlin, 42 years old, has been assistant secretary for public affairs at the Treasury Department. She was born in Chatham, N.J.

title: Calgary Games to ABC
description: Organizers for the 1988 Winter Olympics, which will be held in Calgary, Alberta, announced yesterday in Lausanne, Switzerland, that they have signed a $309 million contract with ABC-TV for rights to televise the Games throughout the United States. The network paid $91.5 million for American television rights to the 1984 Winter Olympics next month in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. ''The television companies expressed through their bidding a willingness to go for broke,'' said Frank King, chairman of the Calgary Olympic Organizing Committee, in explaining the large sum that the Games brought.

title: RAVIOLI: NEW FILLINGS, NEW IMAGE
description: THE lines of demarcation among various ethnic cuisines, once as impregnable as the Great Wall of China, have increasingly blurred in recent years. title: Panel to Ask Boxing Ban
description: A committee created by the British Medical Association to study the dangers of professional boxing will urge the Government to ban the sport in this country, sources within the association said today. The sources, who asked not to be identified, confirmed a front-page report in The Times of London that said the committee was prepared to launch ''the most damaging attack'' that professional boxing had ever suffered in Britain.

AN ECCUMENICAL BISHOP FOR BOSTON
description: A Roman Catholic bishop with a Harvard degree, an activist record on civil rights and ecumenical expertise was named Archbishop of Boston yesterday by Pope John Paul II. Bishop Bernard F. Law, who is 52 years old, has headed the Diocese of Springfield- Cape Girardeau in Missouri for 10 years. He succeeds Humberto Cardinal Medeiros, who died Sept. 17, in one of the most prestigious ecclesiastical posts in the nation.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;

Miss Fornes, winner of four Obie Awards, including the Sustained Achievement Award for 20 years in Off Broadway theater, also directs. Set in New York during the 1940's and 50's, ''Sarita'' is about conflicts arising out of a woman's love for two men: a devout evangelist and a Latin outcast.

description: Wishful thinking is a powerful force in shaping American perceptions of the Middle East. Every hint of Palestine Liberation Organization temperance, Syrian flexibility or Jordanian willingness to join negotiations with Israel is misread as a promise of imminent breakthrough. Talk last week about negotiations between Yasir Arafat, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan are no exception.

So he sued, and on Monday the 39-year-old Mr. Smillie was awarded the equivalent of $15,000 damages by a judge who blamed the ''powerful but misdirected drive'' of the touring pro Sam Torrance.

title: MAO'S CHEF BRINGS TRADTIONS TO AMERICA
description: MAO ZEDONG had a reputation as a Spartan eater who, in the tradition of a Hunan native, put hot peppers on everything. Perhaps that is so, says one of his former chefs, Xie De-Kun, but not when Mr. Xie was doing the cooking. The 70-year-old chef, who is in Washington for a working visit, cooked for Chairman Mao from 1959 to 1963 at the Fishing Pavilion in Peking, where he lived for part of each year and where visiting heads of state are housed. He also cooked for Prime Minister Zhou Enlai.

title: MONDALE URGES WORKERS TO VOTE DEMOCRATIC
description: Walter F. Mondale today appealed to the labor rank and file who supported President Reagan in 1980 to return to the Democratic Party, and he criticized Mr. Reagan for leading ''the most antiunion Administration in history.''

description: Chris Mullin is beginning to make St. John's look more and more like a one- man team.

description: The State Division of Gaming Enforcement has petitioned the Casino Control Commission to place Nicodemo Scarfo on the list of people barred from Atlantic City casinos, the authorities have said.

title: CONNER HEADS A BID FOR AMERICA'S CUP
description: Dennis Conner, the defending skipper in the last two America's Cup series, announced yesterday that he would forge a vast and costly national effort to recapture the cup from Australia in 1987.

title: ROSSER REEVES, 73, AD EXECUTIVE DIES
description: Rosser Reeves, who as the head of the Ted Bates & Company advertising agency won a reputation as high priest of hard sell, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 73 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY ;  WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 25, 1984 International
description: Yuri V. Andropov responded to President Reagan's call for improved relations with the Soviet Union by saying that the Kremlin valued a dialogue with Washington but that it needed ''practical deeds'' from the American side to persuade it that Washington was serious. (Page A1, Column 6.) New initiatives on South-West Africa are planned by Washington, according to State Department officials. They said the United States would soon open an intensive diplomatic effort to seek a formula for ending South African control of South-West Africa along with a parallel withdrawal of Cuban troops from neighboring Angola. (A1:5.)

title: PUBLIC'S SUPPORT OF GLENN FADES
description: President Reagan has opened the election year with strong public approval but Senator John Glenn of Ohio, once feared by the White House as potentially his most dangerous rival, has faded badly because of public doubts about his experience, a New York Times/CBS News Poll showed yesterday.

title: PAPERS' VENDING BOXES FREED FROM M.T.A. FEES
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority violated the First Amendment by charging fees for vending machines selling newspapers at commuter railroad stations.

title: SHOTAGES OF PCJR INDICATED BY I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had begun ''volume shipments'' of its first home computer, the PCjr, but warned that supplies of the machine ''will be limited and may not meet expected demand.''

title: Eagleson Upset Over Hockey Dispute
description: Alan Eagleson, a central figure in the amateur hockey dispute between the United States and Canada, says he is disappointed that the disagreement has become so intense. If it keeps up, he said yesterday, ''We may wind up in a situation where nobody will be eligible to play in the Olympics.''

title: THE POP LIFE
description: DANIEL PONCE, the Cuban percussionist who will give his first concert of the new year at Soundscape next Saturday night, makes his set of five tuned conga drums sing like an orchestra on his first solo album, ''New York Now'' (OAO/Celluloid Records). His unaccompanied conga performance, titled ''Solo Para Ti,'' uses the deeper congas for gliding bass lines, embroiders a delicate melodic counterpoint on the higher drums, and uses the drums of medium pitch for a keyboardlike chording effect. The sound of Mr. Ponce's congas is both finally nuanced and substantial; he makes the average conga drummer sound like a child whacking cardboard boxes or egg crates. And his five-drum extravaganza was recorded live, without studio trickery.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Women's Golf Bonanza
description: It will take steady hands and nerves of steel, but a female golf professional with the right touch could walk off with an extra $4 million next year. All she has to do is win the Nabisco-Dinah Shore and the J & B Scotch tournaments in April and repeat the double in 1985.

title: COURT SETS BACK BID TO PUT PHOTOS ON DRIVER LICENSES
description: After 12 years of debate over whether New York State should put photographs on driver licenses, the effort to join the 48 states using picture licenses was delayed again - no one knows for how long - by a court ruling today.

title: TV: NBC OFFERS A HISTORY OF BLACKS IN AMERICA
description: ''BLACKS: Present and Accounted For'' is a modestly effective attempt to record the history of blacks in America through the arts, artifacts and memorabilia of a single collector. It is a ''chronicle of our history'' says Ruby Dee, who, along with Ossie Davis, is the host of the program. It is also a cultural excursion through 300 years. The program, presented by WNBC-TV, will be seen on Channel 4 at 8 tonight.

title: PPG Profit Up by 63.2% PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 (AP) - PPG Industries said today that the nation's economic recovery coupled with tighter cost controls helped raise its fourth-quarter profit by 63.2 percent on a 17.4 percent sales increase.
description: The Pittsburgh-based producer of paints, glass and chemicals said it had a fourth-quarter profit of $67.9 million, or 98 cents a share, compared with a profit of $41.6 million, or 60 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1982.

THURSDAY, JANUARY 26, 1984 International
description: Vatican aid for Nazi war criminals after World War II has been alleged in statements by a French Nazi- hunter and a declassified State Department report. According to the Frenchman, Serge Klarsfeld, Walter Rauff, a former SS colonel wanted for the mass gassing of Jews in death vans, told in 1962 of having been given refuge in Vatican City convents for 18 months. Chile, which has harbored the Nazi for more than 25 years, is facing mounting demands for his expulsion. (Page A1, Column 1.) Italy's concordat with the Vatican has been tentatively revised after 15 years of negotiations. Under the plan, Roman Catholicism would cease to be the state religion. (A15:1.)

title: Chile Signs Debt Accord By Reuters
description: Chilean officials signed agreements Tuesday with international bank creditors to refinance $1.6 billion in short-term and medium-term credits to four public-sector agencies, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said yesterday.

title: HOW A BROADWAY HIT MUSICAL AND CLASSIC OPERA SHARE SOME TECHNIQUES
description: BROADWAY sophisticates seeing ''La Forza del Destino'' for the first time must come away bewildered by the ritual silliness of it all. And because it does take a while to toughen oneself to the improbabilities of operatic convention and reach down to the beauties beneath, why shouldn't the same be true on Broadway?

description: The tie enabled the Flames to extend their unbeaten streak to seven games.

title: LESSONS FROM ARGENTINA
description: In a bleak world there is one place to look these days for good news of freedom and human decency. That is to Argentina, where years of mass torture and murder under a military junta have given way to a regime of democracy and law.

title: Comings and Goings
description: William Smith , a 19-year-old shortstop from Virginia Commonwealth University who was the Yankees' first pick in the winter draft, has been signed by the club. . . . Michael Spinks will make his ninth defense of his light-heavyweight title on Feb. 25 when he faces Eddie Davis of Hempstead, L.I., in a bout in Atlantic City. . . . Fernando Valenzuela has signed a one-year contract for 1984 with the Los Angeles Dodgers. No details were given, but the left-handed pitcher said it was ''more'' than what he earned last year, when he went to arbitration and won his fight for a $1 million salary. . . . The Soviet national goalie, Vladislav Tretiak, says he is flattered by the attention given him by the Montreal Canadiens, who have the rights to him, but won't consider the possibility of playing for the N.H.L. team until after the Olympics.

title: ON AID TO SALVADOR
description: Should military aid to El Salvador be tied to human rights improvements there? To this question, raised anew by report of the National Bipartisan Commission on Central America, the Reagan Administration has a clear answer: It should. The issue is, precisely how?

title: OUSTER OF SALVADORANS DEFENDED
description: The United States immigration agency said today that up to 50 Salvadorans reported killed after their deportation from the United States could not have been granted asylum on the ground that they might die in ''random violence.''

title: MUSIC: ARLEEN AUGER
description: ALTHOUGH Arleen Auger's song recital last night at Alice Tully Hall was her first in New York, the Los Angeles-born soprano's appearance was far from fitting into any ordinary debut category. Miss Auger, who has spent much of her career to date in European opera houses and concert halls, proved to be a mature, cultivated artist with firm ideas about what she could do best and how to get it done right. Once a coloratura specialist, she has developed into a genuine lyric soprano whose voice is still remarkable for its clear, unspoiled sound.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: IRISH THEATER When Irish people gather together, and the occasion is right, songs of Thomas Davis are often sung. Two are ''A Nation Once Again'' and ''The West's Asleep.'' Davis was an Irish nationalist who was born in 1814. He founded a newspaper in Dublin, called The Nation, where most of his writings were published and he died a young man, in 1845. The impact of his work, however, made a lasting impression, such that in 1933 a group of Irish-born evening high-school students in New York founded a theater company and named it the Thomas Davis Irish Players. Their aim was to promote the culture of Ireland and to better know Irish history. Ever since, the Davis Players have presented works of Irish playwrights.

title: Ambrosiano Talks Seen ROME, Jan. 25 (Reuters) - The Vatican and liquidators of the Banco Ambrosiano will soon appoint negotiators to settle claims arising from the Milan bank's crash in 1982, according to press reports today.
description: Corriere della Sera of Milan and La Repubblica of Rome said in reports from the Vatican that it wished to reach a settlement as soon as possible to avoid a court case.

title: Just a Little Prior Restraint
description: The constitutional doctrine against prior restraint, which the Nixon Administration tested in a mighty court battle in 1971, has descended into farce in 1984. President Nixon's lawyers argued that publication of the Pentagon Papers gravely endangered national security. Disagreeing, the Supreme Court made clear that only sure, immediate risk to the nation could justify judicial orders that forbid any kind of publication.

title: ATTACKS TOUCH OFF FEAR AT NAVAJO RESERVATION
description: An unnatural chill enshrouds this rough-hewn little town on the eastern edge of the Navajo Indian Reservation, a chill unexplained by the weakened January sun or the snow on the mesas. The Navajo majority and the small Anglo population are suddenly linked by fear.

title: BALLET: 4 BY BALANCHINE
description: ON Sunday, George Balanchine would have been 80 years old. No ceremonial acknowledgment of the late choreographer's birthday was made at the New York State Theater, where the New York City Ballet, the company he guided, was dancing. Nevertheless, the afternoon and evening programs were tributes to the values he upheld.

title: Schlumberger
description: Schlumberger Ltd.'s Linear division in Mountain View, Calif., was removed from the list of qualified suppliers to the Defense Department's Electronics Supply Center because of failure to comply with testing and documentation requirements, the center said. The center said the division, part of Schlumberger's Fairchild Semiconductor operations, had been supplying microcircuits used in a number of Defense Department electronic systems. The company could be reinstated as a supplier if it corrects the deficiencies, the center said.

title: United Satellite Expands Service WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) - United Satellite Communications Inc. announced it was expanding its satellite-to-home TV service to five new markets: Washington, D.C.; Baltimore; Richmond; Cincinnati, and Harrisonburg, Va..
description: United Satellite inaugurated the nation's first satellite-to-home TV service last November in Indianapolis and has since extended service to Terre Haute, Ind.; South Bend, Ind.; Fort Wayne, Ind., and Chicago. Using relatively small satellite antennas, subscribers are able to receive TV programming directly from an orbiting satellite.

Suddenly he found himself an apprentice and confidant to the most successful trainer of classy horses in the sport.

title: Apple Pirates Sentenced TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 25 (UPI) - The owners of six local companies were sentenced to eight months in prison for illegally reproducing computer software designs developed by Apple Computer Inc. of the United States, a court source said. The source, who declined to be identified, said the defendants were the first convicted in Taiwan of pirating Apple computer software.
description: Taiwan's current copyright law safeguards the legal rights of publications, but does not specifically cover computer software programs.

title: Chrysler Loan
description: Officials of the Chrysler Corporation will meet with Michigan's Treasurer, Robert A. Bowman, next month to discuss renegotiation of the auto company's $150 million loan from Michigan, Mr. Bowman said. The 15-year loan, which Chrysler took out in 1980 when it was on the brink of bankruptcy, gives the state a first mortgage on the company's Trenton, Mich., engine plant. Mr. Bowman said Chrysler was seeking to reduce its interest payments, which have totaled $23.25 million annually.

More than one fundamentalist-survivalist religious group has settled in our particular valley of New Hampshire out of a conviction that we're situated in such a way as to escape the worst of a nuclear blast.

title: A CHOREOGRAPHER'S SPECTACULAR RISE
description: Dance, George Balanchine once said, is used at the Metropolitan Opera the way a diner uses his napkin - to wipe his mouth before resuming his meal. But then opera-dance has never had much of a reputation. Last Thursday, however, when the Met presented its new production of Handel's ''Rinaldo,'' the audience broke into cheers at a medieval battle scene in which tumblers sailed through the air while the stars engaged in equally flamboyant vocal acrobatics. And no one was more surprised at the dance's public and critical triumph than Eugene Collins, a guest choreographer who made his debut with ''Rinaldo.'' For an Irishman who'd grown up on New York's Lower East Side and was now a ballet teacher in Minneapolis, Minn., he'd done pretty well.

title: MUSIC: MODERNS FESTIVAL
description: SOMEWHERE in classic literature there is the story of the great warrior whose method of fighting was to throw his spear as deep into the enemy ranks as he could and then hack his way through the wall of bodies until he recovered it. Some such image also used to attach itself to the avant- garde artist, a creature in the Beethoven mold who, by definition, was out in front of his time, leading the charge into the brave, new future. In music, at least, that image has lost most of its force, as the Juilliard School's Festival of Contemporary Music has been demonstrating in recent days.

description: When the Supreme Court lifted a nine-year moratorium on execution in 1976, it tempered a harsh decree with reassurances. States were allowed to reinstate the death penalty, but only if their laws were carefully drawn to give extra safeguards to the condemned. ''Death is different,'' the Court said, final and irretrievable.

title: Request Renewed
description: Pat Tilley, the St. Louis Cardinals wide receiver, says he may be getting stale with the Cardinals and has renewed a request that he be traded. Tilley, who made a similar request two years ago, said that Larry Wilson, the team's director of player personnel, had told him that the Cardinals would honor the request if they could work out a trade that would benefit the team. A Cardinal spokesman said, however, that the club was not actively pursuing a trade.

title: Bello Takes The Bahamas
description: Bello, a son of Stopgap and Mop Mop, scored a three-length victory today in the $38,925 Bahamas Stakes at Hialeah Park. Bello caught the pace-setting Go Exclusive Go on the stretch turn and easily held off the late rush of D. White.

title: British Trade Surplus
description: Britain's current account, the measure of trade in goods and services, showed a surplus in December of $987 million, up from about $445 million in November, it was announced today. For 1983, Britain had a current account surplus of $2.82 billion, compared with a surplus in 1982 of $7.52 billion.

title: MALONEY EXCELS
description: Don Maloney is making a habit of scoring the winning goals for the Rangers. His last four goals have decided games, the latest coming in tonight's 6-3 victory over the Penguins.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 59-year-old postal employee on his way home from work was fatally stabbed in an apparent robbery attempt at 2:10 A.M. in the IND subway station at 155th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. The victim was Lawrence E. Papino, a father of four, who would have retired in two months. . . . A 3-year-old girl, Shakira Mitchell, was beaten to death and her sister, Tanya, 4, was severely beaten and taken to Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. Joseph Denter, 24, a friend of the mother, Diane Mitchell, was being questioned. . . . Two men wanted on a Federal warrant for a Maryland bank robbery fired shots at the police for an hour from a house at 135-08 107th Avenue, Richmond Hills, Queens, before giving up at 4 P.M. They were identified as Stanley Harris and George Miller.

title: Hong Kong Deports Animals
description: Sixteen animals confiscated over several years were taken to the Canton Zoo today.

title: DIRECTOR NOMINEES CHOSEN
description: Nominations were announced today for the 1983 Directors Guild of America award, an award which usually foreshadows the outcome of the Oscars.

title: Murray Louis Dancers Cut Four Engagements
description: The Murray Louis Dance Company has reduced its engagement at City Center, where it will now perform from Feb. 9 through 15. It attributed the move, which involved a cancellation of four planned performances, to the fact that it did not receive anticipated financing from the New York State Council on the Arts.

Trump to Appeal Reversal on Taxes
description: Donald Trump, the realty developer, plans to appeal a state appellate court's decision to reverse a property-tax exemption worth up to $50 million over 10 years for Trump Tower, the 59-story luxury building on Fifth Avenue at 56th Street.

title: P. & G.'s Net Edges Up 1.9% The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that net income in the second fiscal quarter of 1984, ended Dec. 31, edged up 1.9 percent, to $214 million, or $1.29 a share, from $210 million, or $1.27 a share, in the similar quarter a year earlier.
description: Sales rose 3.6 percent, to $3.14 billion, from $3.03 billion.

title: BOSTON MAYOR IS SAID TO AGREE TO PAY WIDOW OF MAN SHOT BY POLICE
description: Raymond L. Flynn, Boston's new Mayor, said today he would authorize payment of a court- ordered settlement of $850,000 to the widow of a black man shot by the police, according to a group of ministers who met with Mr. Flynn.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Monday showing banks' 1983 performance misstated Citicorp's return on equity. It was $16.47 on each $100 of common stockholder equity, making Citicorp No. 1 in this category. The accompanying article misstated the change in return on assets from 1982 to 1983 for several banking companies. J. P. Morgan & Company, the Chemical New York Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation reported increases; Wells Fargo & Company was unchanged.

description: Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, said yesterday that he had tried to persuade the Chicago White Sox not to claim Tom Seaver from the Mets last week because of the impact the move would have on baseball in general and on New York in particular.

title: REAGAN AND O'NEILL SQUARE OFF ON BEIRUT MISSION
description: President Reagan and Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. bluntly voiced their differences face to face today over the Marines' presence in Lebanon.

title: 10.2% Output Rise in China PEKING, Jan. 25 (AP) - Industrial production rose by 10.2 percent in China last year, to $307.4 billion, according to Government figures released today. The State Statistical Bureau said the increase reflected the consumer boom taking place under the Government's incentive- based economic policies.
description: The nation's energy shortage was not greatly alleviated, however, with production growing by only 5.1 percent, and the output in transport services gained only 4.5 percent.

title: GENERALS IMPRESSED BY A PASS RUSHER
description: Seeking to enhance the team's identity and sell season tickets, the New Jersey Generals have made much of signing prominent players from the National Football League such as Brian Sipe and Gary Barbaro.

title: Plea Rejected, Execution Set STARKE, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) - Anthony Antone's execution was scheduled for 7 A.M. Thursday after efforts to postpone it were rejected tonight by the United States Supreme Court.
description: The Court rejected, by a vote of 7 to 2, a plea to postpone the execution. It had been rescheduled for Thursday morning after one stay had expired and a Federal appeals court had refused to reconsider the case.

title: FILM: FELLINI LATEST, 'THE SHIP SAILS ON'
description: THOUGH the occasion of Federico Fellini's ''And the Ship Sails On'' initially seems somber, the film often looks like a joyful act of cinematic prestidigitation. At its best moments ''And the Ship Sails On'' floats serenely above the realities of ordinary movies - not to deny the validity of those realities but to expand the imagination.

title: Maclean Hunter
description: Maclean Hunter Ltd. of Toronto, Canada's biggest communications company, purchased a 25 percent interest in Barden Cablevision Inc. for $230,000, according to Don Barden, president of Barden Cablevision. The purchase gives the Canadian company veto power over Barden decisions, but Mr. Barden said that he would remain president of the company. Barden Cablevision has been awarded the franchise for Detroit's $150 million cable television system, but the Detroit Cable Television Commission said the city's agreement would not be affected by the ownership changes.

title: Bethlehem Loss Is Narrower
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel concern, reported yesterday that it had narrowed its loss in the final quarter of 1983 to $27.4 million from $1.15 billion a year earlier. The 1982 loss included a $930 million write-off for mill closings in Lackawanna, N.Y., and Johnstown, Pa.

description: A senior North Korean official today rejected United States suggestions that China take part in talks on a peace treaty to put a formal end to the Korean War.

description: Borough President Howard Golden was elected yesterday to succeed Meade H. Esposito as head of the Democratic Party in Brooklyn after a brief but bitter battle that involved the Mayor, the Governor and the Assembly Speaker.

title: HOST OF GOLDEN DAFFODILS SIGNALS SPRING IN BRONX
description: What better cure for the winter- weary than a stroll through spring? That can be accomplished starting tomorrow at the New York Botanical Garden, where thousands of golden daffodils, sweet-smelling hyacinths and stately blue scillas fill the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory. This Bloembollen, or Dutch flower, festival creates a wonderful illusion of the Netherlands set against facades of typical brick row houses, punctuated by a 24- foot-tall windmill with wooden blades and canvas sails. There are even cobbled streets and mock canals.

title: SWEDLOW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
O'NEILL PREDICTS HOUSE WILL BACK RESOLUTION ON LEBANON PULLOUT
description: Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. predicted today that the House of Representatives would approve a resolution urging the withdrawal of United States marines from Lebanon. His statement came as Senate Democrats reaffirmed their opposition to the 18-month deployment of the marines in Beirut.

description: The Quaker Oats Company reported yesterday that its net income in the second fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31, rose 29.4 percent, to $34.8 million, or $1.69 a share, from $26.9 million, or $1.31 a share, a year earlier. The results in the latest quarter were helped by a $5.7 million pretax gain from a debt-for-debt exchange.

Rhodes, a senior vice president at Citibank and chairman of the country's bank advisory group, announced yesterday.

The division's president, Joel Alper, said the service would provide users with digital, high-speed integrated capability for data, video teleconferencing, electronic mail, teletext, voice and other services through Intelsat, the international telecommunications satellite organization.

title: COUPLE WIN COURT BATTLE TO SEE GRANDSON, 6
description: On Sunday, George and Catherine Layton plan to pick up their 6-year-old grandson, Mark Foster, and take him to the nearby Oakdale Mall. They want to visit a toy store, watch the fountain, then cap off the afternoon at Burger King or the Friendly Ice Cream Shop.

title: ART: JANIS PRESENTS 'AMERICAN WOMEN'
description: ''SIR, a woman's preaching is like a dog walking on his hinder legs,'' observed Samuel Johnson to his friend Boswell. ''It is not done well, but you are surprised to find it done at all.'' That was in 1763. But the surprise at women's intellectual endeavors persists even today among some men, to whom the idea of women creating, rather than procreating, seems to come as a revelation. A case in point is the pointless exhibition, ''American Women Artists (Part I: 20th Century Pioneers),'' at the Sidney Janis Gallery, 110 West 57th Street (through Feb. 4). A show of works by 33 ''pioneer'' women artists (only two of them, Louise Nevelson and Marisol, succeeded in making it into the Janis stable over the years), it celebrates Mr. Janis's belated perception that women are ''seriously to be reckoned as a contemporary artistic force.''

description: In the third consecutive weekly increase, assets rose $603 million, to $165.42 billion, the institute said. Last week the assets totaled $164.73 billion.

title: CONCERT: THE NATIONAL OF NEW YORK
description: THE National Orchestra of New York's second concert of the season at Carnegie Hall Tuesday night was piquantly programmed - all-Russian, Shostakovich-Glazunov, with the only American ever to win the gold medal in the Tchaikovsky Cello Competition as soloist and a promising American conductor on the podium. But all those elements of interest, while undeniably genuine, were surpassed by the sheer skill of the orchestral execution.

description: Tom Seaver's negotiations with the Chicago White Sox were suspended for two weeks last night, with some narrowing of their differences but no agreement in sight. Edward Einhorn, president of the White Sox, said that the club had raised its offer during two meetings that lasted three hours.

title: BankAmerica's $200 Million Sale A $200 million issue of the BankAmerica Corporation's three-year extendable notes with a final maturity in 1996 is offered with an initial coupon of 11 3/8 percent and a price of 99.9 to yield 11.415 percent to 1987 through underwriters led by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. The yield on the notes, rated Aa-3/AA-, is 57 basis points greater than three-year Treasury notes. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
description: After three years, holders of the notes may redeem the issue or renew it for another three years at an interest rate to be announced at that time.

title: Bridge: Unblocking Suits Presents Big Problem for Defenders
description: Red suits and black suits, like arteries and veins, can become blocked with serious results. Unblocking them may be technically difficult, and this is especially so when the problem faces the defenders. Very few players, even of the highest class, would solve the problem posed to East on the diagramed deal.

title: MIDLAND MAY REPLACE HEAD OF CROCKER BANK
description: Midland Bank P.L.C. of London, which owns 57 percent of the outstanding stock of the Crocker National Corporation, has begun to look for a new chief executive officer for the California company's primary subsidiary, the Crocker National Bank, Ian Morison, assistant general manager of Midland, said last night.

description: Fleeting Fame

title: Hudson River Museum Offers Church's Works
description: More than 100 works by the 19th- century artist Frederic Edwin Church will be on view through March 18 at the Hudson River Museum, 511 Warburton Avenue, Yonkers. The retrospective is drawn from collections at the Cooper Hewitt Museum and other sources and includes drawings, oil paintings and sketches.

title: Iraqi Warplanes Fly Over Teheran
description: The Teheran radio told residents to take cover today, and air-raid sirens wailed across the Iranian capital as Iraqi aircraft broke the sound barrier over the city.

title: CORPORATIONS LEND A HAND TO OLYMPIC CONTENDERS
description: In 1976 Andrew Bessette nearly stopped his training for the Olympics, unable to mix the pressures of work and sport. ''I needed to make a living,'' he said, ''but after eight hours at an office, who has energy to hurl a hammer.''

title: Topics Civilized Behavior
description: Gunslinging

title: HEAD OF E.P.A. DEFENDS REAGAN PLAN FOR FURTHER ACID RAIN STUDY
description: The head of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that President Reagan's strategy for dealing with acid rain was a significant change in Administration policy because it was ''a clear admission we have a problem.''

title: BARYSHNIKOV IS QUERIED OVER PLANS TO KEEP POST
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov has been asked by the executive committee of the American Ballet Theater, which will meet tomorrow, for an indication of whether or not he plans to stay on as artistic director after the company's spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House, sources close to the company said yesterday. Mr. Baryshnikov has refused comment, and sources close to him said they did not know what his decision would be.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: Charm beneath Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Article 205181 -- No Title
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported a loss of $4.9 billion for the fourth quarter of 1983, by far the biggest ever by any company, because of extraordinary charges related largely to the breakup of the Bell System.

title: South Africa Gold Yield
description: South Africa's gold production last year rose 2.3 percent, to 747.45 tons, from 730.62 tons in 1982, the Chamber of Mines said today. South Africa, the world's largest gold producer, had output of 1.722 million ounces of gold in December, down from 1.837 million the previous month. The drop in gold prices has prompted several mines to raise the average grade of ore mined.

title: Malone on Recruiting
description: He was the first basketball player to go directly from high school to the pros, but before Moses Malone made the jump in 1974, more than 300 college coaches had offered him athletic scholarships. And some, according to Malone, offered - and in some cases gave - even more.

description: The surprising Utah Jazz, who are the talk of the National Basketball Association, showed the Nets why they are the top team in the Western Conference. They routed the lethargic Nets, 125-115, tonight before 10,116 fans at the Salt Palace to raise their record to 27-16, third best in the league.

title: Economic Scene; The President's Strategy for '84
description: ''D ID I say something funny?'' President Reagan asked during his State of the Union address to Congress as laughter swept the chamber. The laugh came when the President said he wanted to get specific recommendations for a ''historic'' tax reform - ''by December 1984.'' Great performers know that timing is all, and Mr. Reagan's timing was impeccable, since the election comes in November.

title: THE SPEECH: NOT ALL CHEERS
description: Even his critics conceded that President Reagan's State of the Union address was a stylistic success, but a sampling of opinion in the business community - though largely pro-Reagan - was divided on the speech's substance, or, to some minds, lack of it.

title: Stench Is Linked ToTankof HotOil
description: A major contributor to the stench that hung over New Jersey and parts of New York City on Tuesday night was an overheated tank of motor oil at an Exxon plant in Bayonne, state officials said today.

title: Israeli Dance Party
description: An Israeli dance party will be held Sunday at 4 P.M. at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68th Street.

title: 'HAMLET' IS CLOSING
description: The City Stage Company's production of ''Hamlet'' will close Sunday evening. The early closing of the show, which was to have run in repertory through March,is a result of cutbacks in financing and a drop in ticket sales, said Will Maitland Weiss, a spokesman for the company. There are plans to reopen the C.S.C. Theater, at 136 East 13th Street, with a different play, featuring a smaller cast.

title: SALE OF MARILYN MONROE LETTER BARRED
description: Surrogate Marie M. Lambert has issued a restraining order barring the sale of a letter Marilyn Monroe wrote a year before her death when she was in the Payne Whitney Psychiatric Clinic. In the two-page letter, written in 1961 to her friends Lee and Paula Strasberg, the actress asked for help in obtaining a release from the hospital.

title: STATION IN SPACE SEEN PROVIDING USE FOR INDUSTRY
description: President Reagan's commitment to develop a permanent manned space station will enable private industry to open the orbital frontier to a wide range of promising commercial ventures, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: Bruin Player Charged
description: Craig MacTavish , the Boston Bruin forward, was charged with drunken driving in connection with a two-car traffic accident that critically injured a young woman in Peabody, Mass., Wednesday night.

title: VERIFICATION MYOPIA
description: A Reagan Administration report has charged the Russians with committing ''violations or probable violations'' of several arms control agreements. The report's conclusions are disturbing. But the Administration's tendency to use the issue for its own purposes - to mollify conservative critics at home, for example - is also disturbing. Why? Because verification is quickly becoming the single most important standard by which all arms control proposals should be judged. The day may be approaching when our obsession with verification overwhelms and defeats our desire for arms control.

title: KNICKS WITHSTAND BULLETS' LATE RALLY
description: The Knicks played an almost flawless first half tonight but needed much of the 29-point lead they had built by the opening minutes of the third quarter to hold off the Washington Bullets, 104-97, at the Capital Centre.

title: BRITAIN AND CHINA GIVE NO SIGN OF PROGRESS IN TALKS ON HONG KONG
description: China and Britain completed their latest round of negotiations on the future of Hong Kong today without indicating whether there had been further progress toward framing a mutually acceptable plan for the colony.

title: Intergroup Cuts Loss PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 (AP) - National Intergroup Inc. today reported narrower losses in the fourth quarter for all of 1983 and predicted a ''modest'' improvement in demand for its metal products in 1984.
description: Fourth-quarter losses were $38 million, compared with a loss of $282 million a year earlier. Sales rose to $784.3 million, from $643.7 million.

title: NUCLEAR PANEL VOTES FOR PROPOSAL TO START 3 MILE ISLAND PLANT
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has voted in private, 3 to 2, for a plan to allow the undamaged reactor at Three Mile Island to start before investigations of its management are complete, officials at the agency said today.

FLAME INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NEW YORK, WHERE THENOSHING NEVER STOPS
description: NEW YORK not only never sleeps, it also never stops noshing. Midnight ramblers who prowl nightclubs, movies, theaters and discoth eques often contract munchies long after the moon crosses the flashing ball atop the Empire State Building. A short time ago, options for late- night dining were not overwhelming: a plate of sauerkraut and Alsatian sausage at the 24-hour Brasserie on East 53d Street; a mile-high pastrami sandwich at the Carnegie Deli on Seventh Avenue near 56th Street, which serves until 4 A.M.; or, for those trying to repair bodily damges after a long, bibulous campaign, liters of black coffee at the Market Diner on West 56th Street.

title: SCOUTING
description: Situation Wanted

title: RESTRAINT BID CALLED MISTAKE
description: Deputy Attorney General Edward C. Schmults said today that it had been a ''mistake'' for the Justice Department to seek the court order that temporarily barred a law book company from publishing a judicial opinion critical of the department.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a printing error in some copies yesterday, an article in Business Day on airlines' earnings attributed a deferral of dividend payments due Feb. 15 to the wrong airline. The deferral was made by the board of Eastern Air Lines, not the Trans World Corporation.

title: Esquire Radio
description: Esquire Radio and Electronics Inc., a producer of private brand radio and high fidelity equipment, said the Mobil Corporation's Montgomery Ward & Company unit had advised Esquire that it was ''terminating its business relationship'' with the company, but that Ward would take delivery of all inventory already ordered. Esquire said Ward has accounted for ''at least 95 percent'' of Esquire's business in recent years.

title: YOUTHS HARASS PEOPLE SEEKING CABS AT DEPOTS
description: Young men are harassing travelers arriving at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown and the two train depots in Manhattan by hailing taxis for them and demanding payments.

title: THOUSANDS IN STATE WON'T GET HEATING AID THEY COUNTED ON THIS WINTER
description: An official from Montgomery County, N.Y., telephoned Victoria and Bargey Wilkinson this morning to say there was no money to help them pay their heating bills this winter. Living on their Social Security checks in the village of Canajoharie, the Wilkinsons had been counting on that help.

title: HENDERSON CHARGES UNFAIRNESS
description: Forty-eight hours after he agreed to return to the Seattle Mariners as a free agent, Steve Henderson filed a grievance against the Mariners and the other 25 major league baseball clubs yesterday, charging that they illegally interfered with his rights as a free agent.

title: Debut at Age of 91
description: Merle Evans, the 91-year-old retired band leader who conducted the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus Band for 50 years, will make his Carnegie Hall debut Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Mr. Evans will present a program of marches, galops, waltzes and novelties.

title: Woman Jailed in Florida For Having 2d Baby
description: A woman forbidden to bear children for 15 years as a condition of parole after her son died of malnutrition has been sent to jail for giving birth.

title: French Court Refuses To Quash Barbie Case
description: The French Supreme Court today turned down a request to quash the case against Klaus Barbie, the former Gestapo official.

title: MUSIC: CASELLA'S WORKS
description: ALFREDO CASELLA, an Italian composer who, while young, was active in Paris prior to World War I and, later, was instrumental in bringing Italy into the 20th century musically, is seldom heard of nowadays. But on Tuesday night, Capricorn, an ensemble headed by Evalyn Steinbock, sought to atone for that by presenting a program of Casella's chamber music at St. Peter's Church.

title: FRIDAY, JANUARY 27, 1984 International
description: -Jordanian military plan will be renewed, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said the Administration had told Israel that it plans to revive efforts to supply Jordan with equipment for an 8,000-man strike force for use in emergencies in the Persian Gulf. (Page A1, Col. 6.) A resolution urging a withdrawal of the Americn marines from Lebanon will be approved by the House, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. predicted. He made the statement as Senate Democrats reaffirmed their opposition to the 18-month deployment of the force in Beirut. (A8:1-4.)

title: Kerry Enters Senate Race
description: Lieut. Gov. John Kerry today became the fourth Democrat to announce he would run for the Senate seat being vacated by Senator Paul E. Tsongas, also a Democrat. On the Republican side, Ray Shamie, a businessman, has entered the race.

title: Floyd Leads Golf; Roberts Gets Ace
description: Raymond Floyd's 64 led the field by a stroke, but Loren Roberts, who has yet to distinguish himself in two attempts on the PGA Tour, shot the tour's first hole-in-one of the year today.

Bonn Trade Surplus Up WIESBADEN, West Germany, Jan. 26 (AP) - West Germany posted a trade surplus of $1.46 billion in December, up from $1.17 billion in November, the Federal Statistics Office said today. The figures are based on the current exchange rate of about 2.81 marks equaling one United States dollar.
description: While the December surplus exceeded November's, it fell short of the $2.28 billion surplus in December 1982, the office said.

title: CONVERGENT'S PRICE SLUMP
description: S HARES of Convergent Technologies, an innovative computer manufacturer in Santa Clara, Calif., recovered somewhat yesterday after plunging 5 1/4 points, to 20 5/8, in active over-the-counter trading on Wednesday. The stock closed at 21 3/4, up 1 1/8.

title: A COMEBACK FOR THE OLD-FASHIONED NIGHTCLUBS
description: THERE was a time when a regular feature of New York nightlife was a glittering spectacle of flash, flesh, fantasy and fun that drew much of its inspiration from such theatrical productions as the ''Ziegfeld Follies'' and Earl Carroll's ''Vanities.'' The primary ingredients were tall women who paraded solemnly across the stage wearing fanciful headdresses, long trains and not much else, smaller ones who danced energetically, a singer, a choice of novelty acts (jugglers, magicians, animals) and sometimes a sexy dance team. There also might be a name performer or two, usually a singer or comedian.

title: CONCERT: NEW MUSIC CONSORT
description: THE New Music Consort, under the direction of Clare Heldrich and Madeleine Shapiro, offered a varied and skillfully executed program of percussion music at the Symphony Space Tuesday evening. John Cage's pioneering ''Second Construction'' opened the concert; although an obsession with novelty came to mar and trivialize many of Mr. Cage's later works, the energy and charm of his early music should not be overlooked.

title: GREECE LEGALIZES ABORTION
description: The Socialist Government of Greece has announced a parliamentary bill legalizing abortion, even though the practice has long been common and officially tolerated.

title: ART:CARLO MARIANI,IN CLASSICAL VEIN
description: -Classical painting that flourished at the beginning of the 19th century was, of course, in itself a revival. Artists were trying to work their way back behind the Baroque, behind Mannerism, behind the Renaissance and behind the Middle Ages to Greek and Roman times. It had worked well in architecture, so why shouldn't it work well in painting and sculpture?

title: S.E.C. Complaint Settled by Bliss WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (Reuters) - The Securities and Exchange Commission said a Federal judge for the Southern District of Florida had barred A. T. Bliss & Company, the Nationwide Power Corporation, several of their executives and Bliss's accounting firm from future violations of Federal securities laws and ordered Bliss to retain a new independent auditing firm to re-audit the brokerage's financial statements for 1979 through 1982. The defendants consented to the court order without admitting or denying the allegations in an S.E.C. complaint.
description: The S.E.C.'s charges concerned the sale by Bliss from 1979 through 1981 of investment contracts and limited partnership interests. The S.E.C. charged that the contracts and interests, which involved solar hot water heating systems to be leased by Nationwide, were unregistered securities. The S.E.C. also charged that Bliss made false and misleading statements in its reports on revenue from 1979 through 1982.

title: ART: THREE SHOWS BY LUCAS SAMARAS
description: By common consent it takes about 20 years for an artist to graduate from youthful promise to grand old manhood. A great deal of ritual attends the progress - the shows that recapitulate or that represent new directions, the museum retrospective and so forth - and it is accompanied by a swelling bibliography. A system that nobody claims to love, it nevertheless works well enough; it even works when applied to someone like Lucas Samaras, for if nothing else, it makes it plain that there is no one like Lucas Samaras.

title: Panther Coach Signs
description: Jim Stanley , who coached the Michigan Panthers to the first United States Football League championship last year, has signed a multiyear contract with the club.

title: How Argentina Meets Chile
description: Good for Argentina and Chile for charting a new course through the choppy waters of Beagle Channel. They've quarreled for a century over three rocky islands lodged in a strategic waterway connecting the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans at the continent's tip. They have now accepted a Vatican proposal to commit themselves to a peaceful resolution of the issues: whose flag flies over the islands and whether the oil and fish in the 150-mile strait should be shared.

title: Cadbury Beginning $16 Million Ad Drive
description: Peter Paul Cadbury, a subsidiary of Cadbury Schweppes of London, is starting a $16 million multimedia advertising campaign in April to promote the nut and milk content (''luscious ladles of milk'') of its chocolate bars.

title: PHILHARMONIC: ANTON WEBERN COMMERATIVVE
description: ZUBIN MEHTA, back on the New York Philharmonic's conducting stand last night after his 12-week midseason absence, celebrated his return with a program commemorating the 100th anniversary of Anton Webern's birth. He also could have been in a celebratory mood for other reasons, since while he was away the Philharmonic extended his contract, assuring him of his position as music director till 1990. At any rate, the concert found the orchestra in the mood to play some extraordinarily demanding pieces extraordinarily well - in fact, all but flawlessly - and Mr. Mehta took advantage of the moment.

title: Mr.  Reagan's Lemonade

The anticipated ''chemistry'' between the two performers doesn't work all that impressively.

title: CITY BALLET: BALACHINE
description: THE New York City Ballet was in splendid form on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, where it offered well-danced performances of four major works by George Balanchine: ''Divertimento No. 15,'' ''Duo Concertant,'' ''Kammermusik No. 2'' and ''Chaconne.'' In fact, the ''Divertimento'' was absolutely delicious, as led by Merrill Ashley, Elyse Borne, Maria Calegari, Stephanie Saland, Peter Frame, David Otto (a sturdy last-minute replacement for the injured Victor Castelli) and Sean Lavery.

title: Cribbs to Join Stallion Camp
description: A Federal judge refused today to keep Joe Cribbs, the star running back of the Buffalo Bills, from practicing with the United States Football League's Birmingham Stallions. But, in denying the Bills' request for a temporary injunction, Judge John T. Elfvin did not rule on the central issue in the National Football League team's squabble with Cribbs, who signed a multiple-year pact with the Stallions last June and hopes to play for them this spring. The central issue is whether a right-of-first-refusal clause in Cribbs's Buffalo contract, a provision that allowed the Bills to match any offer for his services, applies to teams outside the N.F.L. In refusing the Bills' request for the injunction, the judge said the Bills had not shown that they were likely to win their case.

title: SCREEN: WOODY ALLEN'S 'BROADWAY DANNY ROSE'
description: THE tale of ''Broadway Danny Rose'' unfolds in the Carnegie Delicatessen on Seventh Avenue, a place previously better known for pastrami than for storytelling. As Danny's exploits are revealed, by a borscht belt Scheherezade who shares the details with a group of fellow comics, it becomes clear that this is the perfect setting for Woody Allen's new fable. The skating penguins and singing parrots who are Danny's clients (he is an agent and personal manager) would fit right into this utterly show-biz locale. So would Danny himself, as the apotheosis of chintzy, small-time theatricality, and as one of the funniest and most touching characters Mr. Allen has yet created.

title: SANDINISTA DEMOCRACY? UNLIKELY
description: The Sandinista Government has announced its intention to hold elections in 1985. Nicaraguans will vote for a president, a vice president and a legislature to be entrusted with the task of writing a constitution. Unfortunately, this is not good news for advocates of democracy: There are signs the Sandinistas are not interested in a genuine electoral contest but rather in a farcical vote that will give a veneer of legitiArturo Jose Cruz served in the Nicaraguan revolutionary Government - as head of the Central Bank, member of the ruling junta and Ambassador to the United States - until he resigned in dissent. macy to their de facto Government. The Sandinistas' hold on the Government was established early on. At the hour of revolutionary triumph in July 1979, they decided against outright one-party rule. Instead, in order to calm domestic and international opinion, they chose to form a pluralist junta. (The first junta included members of the Sandinista front and representatives from other sectors of the broad alliance. I was a member of the second junta, formed in early 1980.) As it turned out, however, the junta's powers - it was supposed to act as head of state and Government - were only nominal. In fact, the Sandinista front retained these powers for itself.

title: 'DR. SELAVY' RETURN A TEST FOR CREATORS

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mark Messier , right wing of the Edmonton Oilers, has been suspended for six games by the National Hockey League for hitting Thomas Gradin, a Vancouver Canuck forward, on the head with his stick in a game Jan. 18. Messier, who has already missed three games, will be allowed to play in Tuesday's all-star game and can return to the Oiler lineup Feb. 3, against the Calgary Flames. . . . Danny Buggs, the Tampa Bay Bandit wide receiver who was the United States Football League's second- leading receiver last season, has signed a multiyear contract with the San Antonio Gunslingers. The Gunslingers, an expansion club, acquired the rights to Buggs for two lower- round draft choices. . . . Buck Belue , the former Georgia quarterback who spent two years in minor league baseball, is trying to make a comeback in football with the Jacksonville Bulls, a U.S.F.L. expansion team.

The women in the class are dressed like most fashion-conscious fitness buffs: shimmery leotards, tights, leg warmers or plush sweat suits. But unlike those who work out at other clubs around the city, these face away from the mirrored walls for they prefer not to see themselves exercising. There are no size 9's and the chances are poor that there ever will be.

title: SCREEN: 'LONELY GUY,' STARRING STEVE MARTIN
description: Bruce Jay Friedman's ''Lonely Guy's Book of Life'' didn't have any plot to speak of. The film version doesn't either, though not for lack of trying. If you can get past the movie's aimlessness and its visual drabness, it has its share of isolated laughs. Steve Martin fits right in to the sad- sack role of the title, playing a dateless greeting-card writer who can't believe his ill fortune.

title: BLOCK ST. BART'S REQUEST
description: From the pulpit of St. Bartholomew's Church, its genial rector, the Rev. Thomas Bowers, has accused me of being an ''architectural idolator.'' As a student of architecture for well over 60 years, I am bound to take seriously the charge that, however unwittingly, I may have allowed myself to slip over the boundary that divides admiration for well-designed structures from outright worship of them. Having examined my conscience, I am convinced that my feelings in respect to architecture remain, like Ben Jonson's feelings in respect to Shakespeare, ''on this side idolatry.'' Mr. Bower's epithet may have leapt into his mind not as a result of a scrutiny of my architectural writings but as a result of the vehemence with which I deplore the proposed mutilation of the cluster of architectural elements at St. Bartholomew's - the church, the community house, the terrace and the garden - that make up one of the most precious of the legally designated landmarks of New York City. Next Tuesday, Mr. Bowers and his vestry will be seeking the permission of the Landmarks Preservation Commission to alter this 65-year-old landmark by demolishing its community house and erecting, partly in its place and partly on a portion of the terrace, a 59-story building, clad in reflecting glass, that will usurp much of the sunlight and air still available in the sky- plane to the south of St. Bartholomew's and that will leave the church itself huddled in forlorn shadow at the base of a grotesquely overscaled needle.

title: Tosco Official Steps Down The Tosco Corporation, a leading independent petroleum refiner, yesterday announced the resignation of its chairman, Morton M. Winston. He is being succeeded by Clarence G. Frame, a St. Paul, Minn., businessman who has been a Tosco director since 1978.
description: Until last spring, Mr. Winston had been chief executive and president of the Los Angeles-based company.

title: TV: NBC INTERVIEWS IACOCCA
description: No question about it: Lee Iacocca is not stamped out by any old cookie cutter. He is his own man, an original, and full of his own juices. He is the subject of ''Iacocca: An American Profile,'' a mildly worshipful, but generally exhilarating, ''NBC Reports'' on NBC-TV at 7 o'clock tomorrow night.

title: U.S. AND NEVADA AGENTS CRACK DOWN ON CASINOS
description: State and Federal agencies joined efforts in the past year in a new, tougher fight against casinos suspected of skimming gambling winnings and passing the money to concealed owners in organized crime.

title: Iranian and Iraqi Clash At Nonaligned Parley
description: Delegates from Iran and Iraq clashed at a conference of over 60 nations espousing nonalignment, and Cuba criticized the United States for its attitude to the proposed world information order, diplomats said today.

description: The State of California and Procter & Gamble are at odds over a state-requested recall of Duncan Hines muffin mix from food stores because some packages contain high levels of the carcinogenic chemical ethylene dibromide, or EDB.

THE NEEDIEST RECEIVE COMMEMORATIVE GIFTS
description: Gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are made in the memory of family members and friends, the celebrated and the not-so-well known, and anonymous figures for whom a contributor feels a special gratitude.

description: THE RCA Corporation will receive a patent next week for a new high-definition television system that includes broadcast equipment and home receivers.

title: Midland Backing For Crocker Chief Midland Bank, acting to squelch speculation that it was stripping John B.M. Place of controlling responsibility for its Crocker National Bank unit, said it retained every ''confidence'' in the executive.
description: Midland, which holds a 57 percent interest in the Crocker National Bank Corporation, said on Thursday that it was seeking a chief executive to head up the banking subsidiary. Mr. Place, who is chairman and chief executive of both the corporation and the bank, ''will continue to direct overall policy of the corporation and of its major subsidiary, the bank,'' Midland said in a statement.

title: LTV POSTS PROFIT IN FINAL QUARTER
description: The LTV Corporation, a diversified manufacturer with interests in aerospace, energy and steel, said today that it had a profitable fourth quarter but still lost $180.7 million in 1983.

description: Sir Joshua Hassan has won a fourth term as chief minister of Gibraltar in elections in the tiny British colony.

title: PHILIPPINE VOTERS APPROVE RESTORING VICE PRESIDENCY
description: A move to restore the vice presidency, an office abolished by President Ferdinand E. Marcos a decade ago, appears to have won overwhelming approval in a national referendum on constitutional amendments held on Friday.

title: Reuters Can Sell Stock to Public LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP) - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government refused to block a proposed public stock sale of Reuters, the predominantly British-owned international news and financial information service.
description: ''The history of Reuters supports the view that the company does best when its independence from government is not compromised,'' Information Minister Kenneth Baker declared at the end of a five-hour parliamentary debate.

title: Too Much Tennis
description: Johan Kriek, the world's 15th- ranked tennis player, was upset by Brad Gilbert in the third round of the United States professional indoor championships in Philadelphia Thursday, 7-6, 6-2. Afterward, he was upset by other things.

description: To the Editor:

title: BARRY WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CENTENNIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

The Jackson Kid Bo Jackson was named for a boar hog. ''When I was a boy comin' up,'' said Jackson, ''I was a real bad kid, the bully of the neighborhood. My older brothers said I was mean as a boar hog. 'Bo' is short for boar hog. My real name is Vincent, but nobody calls me that anymore. Even my mother calls me Bo.''
description: Jackson, the Auburn all-America halfback who competed in the 60-yard dash at the Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden last night, recalled this yesterday afternoon. He was in his hotel room at Southgate Tower, where the blinds were drawn and he was suffering a headache.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS IN SHARP PROFIT GAIN
description: Texas Instruments, which suffered heavy losses from its home-computer operations in the first nine months of 1983, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income jumped 82 percent from the last quarter of 1982.

title: ALLOWING BUILDING AT ST. BART'S
description: The central question in the plans of St. Bartholomew's Church to lease a small portion of its property for construction of an office tower is whether a church or synagogue should be allowed to use its own resources to sustain its ministry.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, JANUARY 28, 1984 International
description: France's troops in Chad were ordered by the French Government to extend their control of territory 60 miles northward in support of the Chadian Government and to attack any hostile forces that crossed the new line. The order was intended to reduce the northern area controlled by Chadian insurgents and Libyan troops. (Page 1, Column 4.) Revival of the Vice Presidency in the Philippines appears to have won overwhelming approval Friday in national referendum on constitutional amendments. The office was abolished a decade ago by President Ferdinand E. Marcos. (3:5.)

title: 5 European States Fault Ex-Regime in Turkey
description: The European Commission on Human Rights said today that five Western European nations had gathered enough evidence to indict Turkey's former military regime on charges of torturing prisoners and other violations of human rights.

title: DANCE: EIKO AND KOMA PORTRAY NATURE
description: Although the dances created by the choreographic team of Eiko and Koma concern nature, they do not always literally imitate specific birds, beasts or plants. Rather, these dances show awesome cycles and processes in which all beings, including human beings, are caught up, and their solemn deliberate pace helps emphasize the majesty and inexorability of natural law.

title: Your MoneyLeonard Sloane Hybrid Life Insurance Plan
description: A NEW kind of life insurance is on the horizon with the tongue-twisting name of flexible premium variable life insurance.

title: 1983 TRADE DEFICIT HIT $69.4 BILLION
description: America's merchandise trade deficit narrowed last month to $6.3 billion from November's $7.4 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CUOMO AND ABRAMS IN BATTLE OVER ATTORNEY GENERAL'S ROLE
description: A public dispute between Governor Cuomo and Attorney General Robert Abrams over the constitutionality of a sports-betting plan has revealed a wider disagreement between them over the role of the Attorney General.

Ross, the chairman and chief executive officer of Warner, a lawyer for Mr. Murdoch said yesterday.

description: The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company said today that earnings declined by 10.8 percent in the fourth quarter, to $182.6 million, from $204.7 million a year earlier. Revenues were $1.95 billion in both quarters.

title: McDonnell Net Climbs 35.6%
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that its earnings jumped 35.6 percent in the fourth quarter and revenues rose 6.7 percent. Earnings were $82.6 million, or $2.07 a share, up from $60.9 million, or $1.54 a share, a year earlier.

title: Murdoch Joins Board
description: Rupert Murdoch has been elected a director of the United Technologies Corporation. Harry Gray, the chairman and chief executive officer of United Technologies, said Mr. Murdoch would ''enhance our developing global profile.'' Mr. Murdoch publishes newspapers in Britain, Australia and the United States.

Caren S. Haldenstein Marries a Banker
