Steefel, was married yesterday to Ulrich Schweitzer of Scarsdale, N.Y, the son of the late Hugh Schweitzer of New York and the late Charlotte Schweitzer of Manchester, England. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale.

title: Polish Bishops Cite Continued Social Tension
description: Poland's 27 Roman Catholic bishops pledged today to continue their struggle against domestic oppression but combined the statement with an appeal to Poles to cooperate with the Communist authorities.

title: Abortion, the Sad Necessity
description: On the 11th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court decision that affirmed a woman's right to choose abortion, 35,000 people staged a ''March for Life'' in Washington. They passed out small placards in the shape of fetuses and carried signs with messages like ''Ban the bomb, not the baby.'' President Reagan waved to them from the White House balcony.

description: The goalie Pat Riggin turned aside 21 shots as the Washington Capitals defeated Toronto Maple Leafs, 6-1, in a National Hockey League game tonight. Riggin is unbeaten in four starts (3-0-1) since being recalled from the minor leagues.

description: The New York City Ballet will present its second premiere of the season next Thursday at 8 P.M., when it performs Jerome Robbins's ''Antique Epigraphs.''

A Clean Start
description: Eddie Lee Ivery , the Green Bay Packer running back who sought treatment for cocaine dependency, will not be punished for his use of the illegal drug but will start training camp this summer ''equal to everybody,'' according to Coach Forrest Gregg . ''I admire guys who stand up and confess,'' Gregg told The Milwaukee Journal, noting that Ivery had publicly acknowledged his problem after undergoing rehabilitation treatment last month.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Syracuse vs. St. John's, at Syracuse. The freshman star Dwayne Washington, who got away from the St. John's recruiters, is leading a Syracuse team that is undefeated in its seven Big East games. (Television - Channel 2, 2 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; both at 2 P.M.) description: The St. Regis Corporation said it would close its bag packaging plant in Nazareth, Pa., by the end of May, eliminating 130 jobs.

title: TEXACO DROPS 16.3%; SUPERIOR DOUBLES
description: Three more oil companies reported earnings for the fourth quarter yesterday. Texaco Inc., the recent winner of a takeover fight for the Getty Oil Company, posted a 16.3 percent decline, mostly because of a write-off for the dry exploratory well Mukluk 1. The Pennzoil Company, which Texaco bested in the contest, posted a 14 percent rise. The Superior Oil Company's profits more than doubled.

title: GUATEMALAN REPORTS FOILED PLOT
description: A Guatemalan security officer said today that the military Government foiled a planned coup this month in which a group of retired generals hired an assassin in Miami to kill the chief of state, Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores.

description: The chief United States negotiator at the talks aimed at reducing strategic nuclear weapons said today that it was ''entirely possible'' that if the Soviet Union returned to the now-suspended discussions, it would try to include the issue of American deployment of medium- range missiles in Europe.

But that afternoon, a rumor spread through Wall Street that Ronald Reagan would not seek re-election, possibly because Nancy Reagan was ill. The market did a sudden about-face and wound up falling 10.99 points for the day.

He asked the Senate to approve ratification of the treaty, which was concluded within the framework of the United Nations Environment Program's Regional Seas Program.

description: My friends, on the whole, are a pretty tactful lot. But lately I have noticed that their eyes tend to glaze when we meet, and that conversation has a way of turning to the subject of my clothes and their unfashionableness.

title: BUT BUSINESS PAYS MORE THAN ITS SHARE
description: RECENTLY, a number of people have drawn attention to the fact that corporate tax receipts fell to just 8.1 percent of Federal revenue in 1982. In 1950, corporate taxes contributed 28.3 percent of Federal revenue. This implies that corporate taxes are too low and ought to be raised. The reality, however, is that corporations are far from undertaxed, and the evidence which is used to support that view is highly selective and misleading.

title: CAPUTO PENALIZED $3,000 FOR CAMPAIGN TIE TO CONSERVATIVE PAC
description: A conservative group that has worked to defeat liberal United States senators by running ''negative'' advertising against them had ties to the 1982 Republican senatorial campaign of Bruce F. Caputo, according to a document signed by the Caputo staff.

title: Church to Get $4 Million From Skyscraper Owner
description: A jury has awarded $4 million to the century-old Trinity Church in its suit against the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, which contended that the company's skyscraper here cracked the church's foundation and stained glass.

title: A LAST HURRAH, AND LAUGH, FOR ESPOSITO
description: When Meade H. Esposito won a Democratic district leadership in Brooklyn 24 years ago, he remembers, supporters lifted him from his feet and carried him through the streets. Last week, after Borough President Howard Golden won a three-way race to succeed him as head of one of the nation's largest county political organizations, Mr. Esposito offered his ''condolences.''

title: MINING THE CATALAN
description: The Catalan Opening, a hybrid Queen's Gambit and King's Fianchetto, is currently a better choice as a winning weapon than the classical Queen's Gambit.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: IRONWEED, by William Kennedy. (Penguin, $5.95.) Winner of a 1984 National Book Critics Circle Award, ''Ironweed'' is the third of William Kennedy's interconnected novels set mostly in Albany in the 30's. Our critic, George Stade, said its ''words . . . do not feel as though they were spoken (or written) by anyone. They feel, rather, as though they somehow emanated from the events they described, as though the events were becoming conscious of themselves as they occurred.'' The central character, Francis Phelan, is a loser ''we soon come to value.'' MEGATRENDS: Ten New Directions Transforming Our Lives, by John Naisbitt. (Warner, $3.95.) ''Megatrends,'' a hard-cover best seller for well over a year, is irrepressibly optimistic, according to our reviewer, Karl E. Meyer. ''Much of what it has to say is sensible,'' Mr. Meyer observed, noting that the 80's, ''to use (John Naisbitt's) key words, . . . will be decentralized and high-touch, participatory and networked, filled with multiple options in an information society hooked to a world economy yielding blessings for all.''

title: HALL OF INCONSISTENCY
description: I N their best years, Joe Namath N.B.A. and Fran Tarkenton were together as New York quarterbacks, the Jets' swinger and the Giants' preacher. Now they're together again, standing outside the Pro Football Hall of Fame gate that has been clanged shut on them for at least another year. Out in Honolulu this weekend at the Pro Bowl luaus, four deserving new members of the Hall of Fame are being honored - Willie Brown, Charley Taylor, Mike McCormack and Arnie Weinmeister, the Giants' defensive tackle of three decades ago. But for the second consecutive year, Joe Namath was rejected by the selection committee, and in his first year of eligibility, Fran Tarkenton was snubbed. Each qualified for the final ballot of the 29 selectors. But with 24 votes needed, Joe Namath missed by 3, Fran Tarkenton by 4. Surprising? In assessing the accomplishments of Joe Namath and Fran Tarkenton, yes. Joe Namath justified the Super Bowl and the American Football League when the Jets shocked the Baltimore Colts, 16-7, in Super Bowl III; Fran Tarkenton dominates the career National Football League records for passers with 3,686 completions for 47,003 yards and 342 touchdowns. Surprising indeed. But in assessing the consistency and credibility of the Hall of Fame selection committee in recent years, nothing is surprising. To understand the problem, it is necessary to understand the process. Beginning with its charter class in 1963, the Hall of Fame has preferred to keep the voting secret rather than subject it to public scrutiny, which is the beauty of baseball's Hall of Fame voting. At the suggestion of several selection- committee members, the Canton, Ohio, shrine intends to consider altering its medieval policy. The selection committee is composed of one news media representative familiar with each of the 28 National Football League franchises as well as a representative of the Pro Football Writers Association - a total of 29 members, all of whom were present at this year's meeting in Tampa last weekend. I'm on the committee as the designated Jets' selector. In the final yes-or-no ballot on a candidate, an affirmative vote of at least 80 percent is required for election. From a preliminary list of 46 candidates, 14 qualified for discussion last weekend as well as Arnie Weinmeister, who was proposed by the oldtimers' committee and voted upon separately. After one ballot reduced the other candidates from 14 to 10, a second ballot reduced them to 6 finalists. Each of those 6 then was voted upon individually for enshrinment, yes or no. Joe Namath received 21 votes, up from 17 the year before. Fran Tarkenton received 17 votes as a rookie candidate, one who has been retired at least 5 years. In another year or two, Joe Namath and Fran Tarkenton will presumably gather enough additional votes, as other players have done. Jim Taylor, the Packer fullback, for example, missed by four votes in his first year of eligibility, didn't even qualify for the final six the next year, but in his third year, he was voted in. Others have not been so fortunate. Many candidates have been victimized by the inconsistency of the selection committee. Charlie Conerly, the Giant quarterback on their 1956 N.F.L. championship team, missed by only two votes in 1978, but the next year his name did not appear among the 14 to be discussed. The following year he failed to qualify for the final six; he later did not appear on the preliminary ballot. To be considered now, he must be proposed by the old-timers' committee. Don Maynard, the N.F.L. career record-holder among pass receivers with 11,834 yards, missed by only 3 votes in 1980, the first year he was among the 14 up for discussion. But in each of the four years since then, the former Jet has failed to qualify for the yes-or-no ballot. Paul Hornung, the Golden Boy halfback on four of Vince Lombardi's five championship teams in Green Bay, missed by six votes in 1979, and by five votes in 1980. But in the four selection meetings since then, he has failed to qualify for the yes-or-no ballot. Jim Ringo, now the Jets' offensive line coach and once an all-pro center for the Packers, was elected in 1981, six years after he had missed by one vote, five years after he had missed by two votes. In each of the intervening four years, he didn't make the yes-or-no ballot. Clark Shaughnessy, the coach who installed the T-formation with the Chicago Bears after having invented it at Stanford, missed by only two votes in 1975 but did not qualify the next year for the yes-or- no ballot. Each of the next four years, he was not among the 14 to be discussed. Since then his name has not even appeared on the annual preliminary ballot of more than 40 candidates. In this year's voting, Mike McCormack, now the Seattle Seahawks' general manager and once a tackle with the Cleveland Browns, was suddenly elected, 25- 4, in his fourth year as a discussed candidate. In his first three years, he never qualified for the yes-or-no ballot. Through the years, the Pro Football Hall of Fame process has basically worked, however strangely at times. Virtually all the people who should be in the Hall of Fame are in it; of those who should be in it and aren't, notably Joe Namath and Fran Tarkenton, they almost all will probably be elected sooner or later. But the committee's inconsistency, influenced by the secrecy imposed on the process, has victimized a few candidates who once were so close, then suddenly were all but discarded. It's time for the Pro Football Hall of Fame not only to lift its shroud of secrecy, but also to re-examine its process. If a candidate qualifies for the final yes-or-no ballot one year, he should automatically qualify for it for the next two years; that way he won't risk the danger of being forgotten, as Charlie Conerly and Clark Shaughnessy were. If a Hall of Fame candidate still isn't elected after three yes-or-no ballots over three years, at least he will have had three downs before he has to punt. That's all any football player has ever asked. - SPORTS OF THE TIMES

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL

Entitled ''In That Great Gettin' Up Mornin','' after an old spiritual, the symposium will highlight the religious history of the state's three largest black ethnic groups: Afro-Americans, Haitians and Jamaicans.

title: RESEARCHERS SEE CAR OF FUTURE AS SLEEK AND FULL OF GADGETS
description: IT WILL NOT BE rocket powered and it probably will not be able to fly, but the automobile of the 1990's onward will look increasingly like an airplane without wings and will be equipped with technological innovations ''borrowed'' from the airplane and computer industries, according to automobile reasearchers compleiting a four year study at the Massachusetts Institue of Technology titled 'The Future of the Automobile.''

Theatrical orchestration can be a kind of hack work or, in the hands of someone like Jonathan Tunick, the most sought-after orchestrator on Broadway today, it can be elevated to an art.

title: AN INN ON THE PACIFIC'S EDGE
description: '' Ventana'' means ''window'' in Spanish. The Ventana at Big Sur, California, is variously called the Ventana Hotel, the Ventana Inn and the Ventana Retreat. Lacking the quasi-mystic aura of the nearby Tassajara Zen guest facility, lacking the countercultural improvementalism of nearby Esalen, the Ventana seems to be merely a tasteful, luxurious, expensive, hot- tubbed, advanced-Sybaritic, getaway, redwood and cedar lodge on its magnificent site up a slope of the Santa Lucia mountains just above the bravely foaming Pacific Ocean.

title: PAINTINGS THAT FULFILL THE PROMISE IN A JURY'S PRIZE...

Even though an art critic's subjective tastes are sometimes apparent after reading his or her criticism, to come away believing that the critic has gone beyond objective criticism and presented merely his own preferences is quite another matter.

title: WHEN DAYS ARE GRAY AND SKIES HANG LOW, SPICE THINGS UP
description: S PICES are as important in the winter as fresh herbs in the summer. They enliven bland winter dishes and on gloomy days evoke memories of warm, exotic places. In the Middle East, around the Mediterranean and in Morocco, stews are flavored with cumin, paprika, allspice, coriander or ginger. Lemon or orange peel are added for flavor and in Morocco fresh coriander leaves may be sprinkled on the stew before it is served.

title: NEW CHALLENGE TO PRESS FREEDOM
description: Martin Garbus is a New York trial lawyer who often represents libel litigants. By Martin Garbus EANING FORWARD over the polished mahogany bench, dark- rimmed glasses low on his nose, Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court of the United States posed the issue in its starkest terms. Why, he asked, should the law be any different whether a person is damaged by a libelous statement or by a defective train?

title: BLUNT TALK FROM THE CHIEF OF CHRYSLER
description: LEE A. IACOCCA, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, is probably best known for the television commercials he has made promoting the company's cars and trucks, but he is also given much of the credit for rescuing the company from the brink of bankruptcy with the assistance of $1.2 billion in federally guaranteed loans. The loans were repaid last year. Mr. Iacocca, who is 59 years old, became chairman of Chrysler in 1979 and under the terms of a new contract is expected to stay with the now profitable company at least until 1987.

MILLIONS TO CELEBRATE THE YEAR OF THE RAT

title: TWO SOVIET EMIGRES WHOSE ART IS OVERLAID WITH IRONY
description: J osef Stalin, looking paternal in a heroic white plaster bust, dominates the small, seedy studio on East 33d Street of the Soviet dissident artists Vitaly Komar and Alexander Melamid, just as he dominates their sixth exhibition at the Ronald Feldman Gallery here (through Feb. 11). It's not that Mr. Komar and Mr. Melamid, who have worked exclusively as a team for some 10 years - a two-man artists' collective, one might say - have much use for Stalin. He simply helps keep them in touch with a vital part of their history.

Officials say the money will help to insure that the program, the first of its kind in the county, will be a success.

title: Skiing
description: To the Editor: I read with interest the article on ''Powder Skiing'' by Alex Ward (Travel, Dec. 11). Skiing in Utah is great, but I'd like to call attention to another great Western ski area in my home state: the slopes of Terry Peak in the Black Hills of South Dakota, with some of the best downhill skiing in the world.

title: PLEASE EXCUSE MOM'S UNFINISHED STORY
description: D EAR Mrs. Albert, Please excuse my Mom for not completing her class assignment to write about her ''First Love.'' We're all so proud of her now that she's back in school, and we actually saw her sit down to write about five or six times in the last week, but something always came up to interrupt her. Guess maybe we had something to do with that but now she's real mad and not talking to us and, well - we really feel bad and didn't know what else we could do about it except to maybe try and explain to you why she never finished.

title: DOUBLE DACTYLS AND OTHER WONDERS
description: ANY literary detective looking for a new case to crack could do a lot worse than embark on the quest for W. Parker Chase. Only two things seem to be known about this elusive figure. One is that in 1931 he was residing at 301 East 21st Street in Manhattan; the other is that the following year he published ''New York: The Wonder City,'' a guidebook- cum-celebration-cum-real-estate prospectus that has just been reissued in a facsimile edition (New York Bound, $9.95) with an introduction by Paul Goldberger. It is a remarkable, indeed a wondrous piece of work.

title: Conviction Overturned

title: BACK TO ELEGANT ESSENTIALS
description: Top: Bare floors and simple box furniture give the living room a spare, yet opulent, look. Above: The beautiful brass elevator doors and patterned marble floors were among the features that attracted the couple to the apartment. Right: A hallway was redesigned with a series of arches and a curved niche for a Giacometti sculpture, a bust of the artist's brother Diego. AFTER DECADES OF COLLECTING art and antiques, Herbert and Sandra Kasper decided it was time to do some editing. ''As soon as we moved into this apartment, we chose to live in a more pared-down style,'' says Mr. Kasper, ''with only the best objects in our collection.'' No curtains adorn the Palladian windows. Nor are there Persian carpets on the dark parquet floors. Even the furniture was selected for its simplicity: box sofas and chairs rather than overstuffed upholstery with ruffles or pleats. Well-tailored but elegant is how the owners describe their Manhattan home. This is an appropriate description, considering that Herbert Kasper, known simply as Kasper, is one of this country's leading fashion designers. ''The process of decorating an apartment is not so very different from designing a dress,'' he says. ''Choosing beautiful details like trimmings or buttons is always important. But then you have to decide what needs to be removed to give it purity of line.''

title: THE VICTORS
description: HESE ARE THE STORIES OF ORDINARY people who have behaved heroically. Each one has a dramatic tale to tell, and each of their stories is different from the others. Yet they all faced a common, now familiar enemy. Estelle Marsicano, a young mother, was told she had a ''nervous colon'' and treated with tranquilizers until liver cancer was detected. James Brown, a teen-age track athlete, lost a leg to bone cancer. Christa Freund faced two separate diagnoses of malignancy the same year. Dr. Samuel J. Storch was stricken with acute leukemia while still in medical school. Yet all these people survived, returning to tell us of their adventures. In conversations distilled from hours of interviews, they speak of their fears, their trembling bodies, their dark despair and their last-minute prayers. They also report a sudden turn of events - the arrival of unexpected strength from within themselves, along with support from others who came to protect them and bind their wounds. And they emerge as victors to tell us how this experience has changed their lives: How they see a bird in the sky, a boat on the river, a leaf on a tree as a new affirmation of the totality of life. How they have an increased capacity for love. How they seem to have found a greater awareness of who they are. Of the many factors that may have contributed to their survival, the quality of diagnosis, treatment and care was crucial.

title: Voluntary Departure

Wichita State, which had a 3-8 record last season, is under a two-year probation for recruiting violations, and Jeffries and an assistant coach were reprimanded by the college a year ago for lying to university and National Collegiate Athletic Association officials.

title: WICKED IRISH WIT ENLIVENS A NEW MINI-SERIES
description: A h, the Celtic Irish and, ah, the Anglo-Saxon English - for centuries they have been glowering at each other, if not worse, and producing some of the best literature in the language common to them both. The Anglo- Irish list of great writers ranges, just to mention a few of the more outstanding examples, from Jonathan Swift to Richard Brinsley Sheridan to Oscar Wilde. Oddly enough, the confrontation of the two cultures, long saturated in tragedy, has produced a rather startling amount of comedy. A Sean O'Casey might excel in the tricky genre of tragicomedy, but other writers, those like Honor Tracy, have developed a humorous style of a wickedly clever sort. In this latter category are two somewhat eccentric cousins, Edith Somerville and Violet Florence Martin, whose nom de plume was Martin Ross. The two began collaborating on literary ventures in the final decades of the last century. One of their works, ''Some Experiences of an Irish R. M.,'' has been adapted for television by a consortium of British and Irish organizations and, beginning tonight at 9 on WNET/Channel 13, will be running on public television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' for the next six weeks. Not surprisingly, the series has its devilishly hilarious moments.

title: OIL-HUNGRY SUITORS ON THE PROWL AGAIN
description: Merger Fever in the Oil Patch. More takeover bids emerged last week as prospects in the petroleum industry brightened. Royal Dutch/ Shell offered $55 a share, or $5.2 billion, for the 30.5 percent of the Shell Oil Company of the United States that it does not already own. And rumors that pushed up the stock of Houston Natural Gas all week proved to be true, as the Coastal Corporation said it would seek 45 percent of the pipeline company at $68 a share in a deal valued at $1.3 billion. Another suitor, Damson Oil, offered $24 a share, or $209.8 million, for control of Dorchester Gas, whose board has already approved a competing leveraged buyout. And yet another, Texaco, raised its $10 billion offer for Getty Oil by $3, to $128 a share, settling all litigation with J. Paul Getty's heirs.

More numerously represented are places with Formica tabletops set with paper napkins and placemats and food not so bad as it is indifferent. But in short supply have been the middle- of-the-road establishments offering food prepared decently, priced reasonably and served in neat and attractive surroundings.

title: MANHANDLING THE CLASSICS, OR DIRECTOR 10, SHAKESPEARE 0
description: W hat is that distant rattling being wafted into New York by the Atlantic breezes these winter nights? Could it be the sound of Shakespeare turning in his grave? If his ghost has visited ''King John'' at the Jean Cocteau Repertory, where medieval armies range the cozy countryside with rifles protruding from their jungle camouflage, the answer could well be yes. So it might be if he has seen the City Stage Company's ''Hamlet,'' which launches at once into Ophelia's funeral, ends with the gravediggers exchanging glum riddles about their trade, and in between appears to have been torn up, shuffled, and then speculatively glued back together by someone who sees narrative flow in terms of loops, twists and dizzy backward somersaults.

title: MARCHING TO AN AMERICAN BEAT
description: I F the ''Parade of American

title: DEMOCRATS NEED A WOMAN AS NO.2
description: The Democratic Party did something very daring - many said foolhardy - when it nominated a Roman Catholic for President in 1928. The genius of that move was appreciated only years later when observers of the American political party system realized that Alfred E. Smith's defeated candidacy had laid the groundwork for the century's most important partisan realignment. It rallied Catholic voters to the party and readied them for inclusion in Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal coalition, which developed into our most durable political assemblage. The Democrats again have an opportunity to set the stage for a realignment - this time, by running a woman for Vice President.

title: 'FORMS THAT FUNCTION' AT KATONAH: 'TWIXT ART AND THE CRAFTS
description: T HERE is a sense of tension in the Katonah Gallery's new show, beginning with the name, ''Forms That Function.'' Once upon a time, this would have primed visitors to expect applied rather than fine art. But with the crafts having sloughed off their functional connotations, the title seems ambiguous, even contrary. This turns out to be appropriate, because the show falls into neither the crafts nor the art category but into the minefield that has lately developed between the two and into which the most disinterested of reviewers must tread cautiously.

title: THE REGION
description: Sports 'Lottery' Suffers Setbacks

title: RECITAL: HERMANN PREY PERFORMS BRAHMS LIEDER
description: Hermann Prey's lieder recital Thursday night at Carnegie Hall was devoted exclusively to Brahms, amounting to a neatly selected survey of Brahms as a song composer.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS January 29, 1984Fiction
description: 1 1984, by George Orwell. (NAL/Signet, $2.95.) The classic 1949 novel about life in a society when Big Brother watches.

title: ECONOMIC HEAVYWEIGHTS: WHERE ARE THEY NOW?
description: BERT LANCE has never been one to talk about his private business dealings, acquaintances say. But the former director of the Office of Management and Budget, they say, has been even more private since he resigned his post and went home to Georgia in 1977 in the midst of an investigation of his banking practices prior to taking office.

description: E leven years ago the Smithsonian Institution entered the field of jazz recordings by issuing a six-disk survey of jazz records from the early 1920's to the early 1960's. ''The Smithsonian Collection of Classic Jazz'' became an instant classic in its own right.

description: A picture caption today on the cover of The Guide, section 2A, misidentifies the actress who plays the teacher in ''Open Admissions.'' She is Marilyn Rockefellow.

title: Ellen Hale and Joseph C. Carey Marry
description: Margaret Ellen Hale, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Harris Hale of Tucson, Ariz., was married yesterday to Joseph Clarke Carey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Carey of South Hampton, N.H. The Rev. George V. Coyne, director of the Vatican Observatory in Rome, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Shrine of Santa Rita in the Desert in Vail, Ariz.

title: ISSUE OF NEW STEEL MILL UP TO CLEVELAND VOTERS
description: Voters here will decide Feb. 7 whether a new steel mill is to be built in the historic Flats section along the Cuyahoga River. It would be the first new steel facility in Cleveland in more than 20 years, according to city officials.

title: ART DECO REVIVAL
description: For more than six months, the Art Deco facade of the Lowell Hotel at 28 East 63d Street has been hidden by a network of scaffolding and a huge dumpster has stood in the street just outside the entrance. Closed since last spring, the Lowell will reopen in May after extensive renovation and restoration by its new owners, Lowell Hotel Associates.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: W HEN a high school teacher in Manahawkin had trouble getting his students interested in reading, he began writing his own material for them. The task sort of came naturally, for Edward Brown of Medford not only has been teaching at Southern Regional High School for 20 years, but also is a freelance writer.

title: Sharon Simon Will Marry Steve A. Katz in the Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Simon of Guttenberg, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Simon, to Steve A. Katz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Katz of Dresher, Pa.

title: CAN THE NATION'S SECURITY OUTWEIGH PRESS FREEDOM?
description: Can reporters be trusted to keep a military secret? According to many military officers, top aides and advisers in the Reagan Administration, and a goodly number of citizens who express themselves in letters to the editors of newspapers, the answer is a clear-cut no.

title: 3 STATES JOIN SUIT ON TOXINS
description: C ONTENDING that the health of at least 75,000 workers is at stake, Connecticut has joined a court battle against the Federal Government over the right to monitor toxic chemicals in the workplace.

title: THEATER: 'MOTHER COURAGE' IN BOSTON
description: In his brief career, first at Harvard and then beyond, the 26- year-old director Peter Sellars has both excited and angered audiences with his avant-garde theatrical and operatic productions. Last year, in his first venture into the big-money commercial theater, Mr. Sellars also managed to nettle part of the Broadway establishment: he was replaced as the director of ''My One and Only'' at the outset of the musical's pre- Broadway Boston tryout.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: BRONXVILLE
description: BRONXVILLE started small, a community filling only one square mile, and it has remained that size, maintaining the village atmosphere that has been its hallmark. It is something special and splendid among suburbs, and it remains as similar to its origins as it is possible to be.

title: The Hebrides
description: To the Editor: I would like to correct a factual error in Linda McK. Stewart's otherwise absorbing article: ''In Search of 1984,'' (Travel, Jan. 1).

title: VIDEOTAPES OF BOMB-MAKING POSE JUDICIAL PUZZLE
description: Tiny cameras concealed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in two apartments used by four reputed members of the Puerto Rican nationalist group F.A.L.N. rolled for more than 130 hours over six months.

title: NO NUCLEAR DUMP SITES IN SIGHT YET
description: When President Reagan signed the Nuclear Waste Policy Act a year ago, its backers were hopeful. If the new law failed to pick a burial site for the deadly wastes, they consoled themselves with the fact that it at least established a timetable for finding one. This month the Nuclear Regulatory Commission heard from experts on radiation safety, lawyers representing states where a dump might be located and spokesmen for nearby Indian reservations. All indications were that the search was already behind schedule.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Turner of Cresskill, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caren Zeldie Turner, to Dr. Henry James Fishman of Washington, the son of Judith R. Lichter of Woodbridge, Conn., and Judge Milton A. Fishman of Meriden, Conn., a member of the Connecticut Superior Court. An August wedding is planned.

title: 5 DIE IN APARTMENTS RAVAGED BY A BLAZE IN UPSTATE NEW YORK
description: Five people, including three children, were killed and a man was critically injured early yesterday when a fire of undetermined origin roared through an old three-story apartment building in Walden, N.Y., about 60 miles northwest of New York City.

title: ISRAEL BEGINS TO NOTE JEWISH TERRORISM
description: Politically motivated, indiscriminate attacks on innocent civilians have long been a danger of life in the Middle East. The terrorism has been practiced most steadily by Arabs against Jews or other Arabs. But now and then, there have been flickers of terrorism by Jews, followed by spasms of self-criticism by other Jews about the ills they see in the Zionist movement and in Israeli society.

title: Singer Leaves Hospital After Hair Catches Fire
description: The singer Michael Jackson, hospitalized with burns caused by fireworks that ignited his hair while he was filming a television commercial, was discharged from a hospital today.

title: SHOULD THE ARMORY SHOW CHANGE?
description: T he 30th annual Winter Antiques Show, which closes today after a nine-day run at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street, has attracted record crowds, chalked up higher profits than last year, substantially reduced the stocks of many dealers and made many collectors extremely happy. However, in spite of the fair's stunning success - or, perhaps, because of it - discussions continue about what's right and wrong with this antiques event.

description: NORTH HAVEN T HIS town of 22,000 still governs itself the way all of New England once did - by town meetings, where voters can make decisions on public matters.

So it was a familar scene today when the 66-year-old president and general manager of the Boston Celtics became enraged at the officiating in the National Basketball Association's first old-timers' game.

title: THE SAGA OF THE SHRINKING HOUSE

There were closets galore that they could never, ever begin to fill, a massive master bedroom and two additional ones that could only be enhanced by cribs, stuffed animals and rainbow wallpaper, a two-car garage and an enormous family room.

description: NEWARK T HERE are as many vacant lots as there are buildings in the neighborhood around Engine Company No. 6, and many of the buildings are empty.

2,000 HORSES STARVE AS PLAN TO SELL MEAT FAILS
description: State investigators say a plan to fatten horses from Canada and the United States on east Texas ranches for the European horse meat market has turned into one of the biggest cases of animal abuse in the state's history.

title: Miss Jensen Will Marry On March 10
description: Camille Margrethe Jensen, the daughter of Camille Jensen of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Dr. Frode Jensen, plans to marry Peter Roderick Douglas, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Woolman Douglas of Chevy Chase, Md. The wedding is to take place March 10.

title: HEADLINERS
description: The Smithsonian's Man An expert on the Middle East was called from the Middle West to succeed S. Dillon Ripley as secretary of the Smithsonian Institution last week. Robert McCormick Adams , provost of the University of Chicago, beat out 300 other candidates for the job in a selection process begun nine months ago. Mr. Adams, who has had a distinguished career in anthropology and archeology, took the job only after overcoming his trepidation at the prospect of dealing with the Federal bureaucracy. His academic background was viewed as especially valuable because the Smithsonian plans expanded attention to the art and culture of Africa, the Middle East and Asia.

title: PEEKSKILL PLANT RECEIVES FIRST LOADS OF GARBAGE
description: PEEKSKILL S HORTLY after 11 A.M. last Monday, Tony Kultzow, sitting in the still unfinished weigh station of the county's brand new garbage-to-energy plant here, spotted the 10th garbage truck of the day heading up the long hill toward him.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Two Powers Admonish From Afar

title: PLIGHT OF BLACK FAMILY IS STUDIED ANEW
description: The rapid growth in the number of families headed by black women represents an ''ominous trend'' for the black community, says the National Urban League. That conclusion, in the league's annual report on the ''State of Black America'' released a week ago, is an assessment more and more widely accepted by scholars, intellectuals and civil rights leaders.

title: Bonnie N. Dambach and James Sluis Are Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth W. Dambach of Wyckoff, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Bonnie No"el Dambach to James Phillip Sluis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Sluis, also of Wyckoff. A summer wedding is planned.

title: ALL ON NEW YORK POLICE FORCE TOLD TO WEAR VESTS ON PATROL
description: All members of the New York City Police Department were ordered yesterday to wear bulletproof vests on patrol after the shooting of an officer and a threat that other officers would be shot.

title: International
description: Jordan welcomes U.S. military aid, and needs it, King Hussein said. But he said Jordanian forces would be used only in self-defense or at the request of Arab allies and not at the bidding of the United States. Reagan Administration officials said last week that they were discussing with Jordanian officials plans to renew an effort to get Congressional approval for a $220 million plan to supply Jordan with equipment for a 8,000-member regional strike force. (Page 1, Column 6.) Peking will buy Western technology and equipment worth $1 billion under agreements to be signed this year, according to a senior Chinese economic official. The official, Yuan Baohua, deputy chairman of the State Economic Commission, said at a meeting of international bankers and businessmen in Davos, Switzerland, that Peking intended to sign 1,000 contracts for such purchases. (1:5.)

title: Sumatra
description: To the Editor: In the article ''In the Land of the Bataks'' (Travel, Dec. 18) William Finnegan translates the Dutch ''Toba Meer,'' as Toba Sea and justifies the name by the dimensions of the lake.

description: Brand New Way Of Seeing China: By Deluxe Train As the past few years have shown, there are many ways to see China. This year the list can be expanded to incorporate a new way - on a deluxe train.

title: CRIME
description: There aren't many writers like Ruth Rendell who are highly prolific and yet manage to maintain a consistently high standard. Prolific writers are apt to fall way out, using dialogue that sounds automatic or reflexive rather than really thought through. But Miss Rendell has managed to make most of her books into a fresh experience, even when writing about a series character, such as her Inspector Wexford.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: A S THE momentum for bank mergers continues to build, Midlantic Banks Inc., a bank holding company with assets of $5.9 billion, has arranged to acquire for $43 million the First Peoples Bank of New Jersey in Haddon Township, which has assets of $774.7 million. The merger was announced last month by Robert Van Buren, chairman of Midlantic, and Jerome S. Goodman, president of First Peoples.

title: RISK SEEN IN WEAPON-GRADE URANIUM AT COLLEGES
description: Quantities of highly enriched uranium, used in research reactors at 23 universities around the nation and an essential ingredient for making nuclear weapons, could be easily stolen by terrorist groups or nations intent on acquiring such weapons, a physicist has told the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SARASOTA
description: Sarasota, a leisurely sun-bleached city of 50,000 on Florida's west coast, manages quite comfortably to be both a typical beach resort and a cultural enclave of some significance. It is justly proud of its set of offshore keys with names like Longboat; Siesta, Lido, Bird, St. Armand's and Casey, islands with fine beaches, pleasureboat marinas and charter boats for deep-water fishing in the Gulf and calmer trolling in Sarasota Bay. Sarasota abounds in tennis courts and is home to perhaps more golf courses per capita than anywhere else except Scotland, not an odd circumstance for a city that claims to have introduced golf to the United States 99 years ago.

title: EXCERPTS FROM KEAN'S BUDGET MESSAGE TO STATE LEGISLATURE
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Kean's budget message to the Legislature:

title:
DINING OUT;
THE JAPANESE INFLUENCE IN RAMSEY
description: W HEN visiting a restaurant for the first time, particularly one where the type of food served is unfamiliar, it would be helpful if someone else took care of the ordering, and, if this were possible, to taste a little of many dishes.

title: Breeding Rights
description: A year ago Morton Finder donated a breeding right of his trotting stallion, Green Speed, to the Red Smith Writing Scholarship at Notre Dame, and cleared $4,200 for the program, a memorial to the late sports columnist and Notre Dame graduate. This year Finder, whose farm is in Pine Bush, N.Y., is giving the scholarship fund the proceeds from the sale of one breeding right to the pacing stallion Computer. The right is to be sold at the Garden State Sale at the Meadowlands today.

title: WHY A SHARP BLADE IS SAFER, AND HOW TO KEEP IT THAT WAY
description: C ONTRARY to what most people may think, a knife, chisel or similar cutting tool that is very sharp is actually much safer to use than a dull one. The reason is that sharp blades require less effort to use, so there is less chance of your pressing or pushing too hard with the blade, and therefore less chance of slipping or having an accident.

title: GRANT QUITS AS VIKING COACH
description: Bud Grant, who coached the Minnesota Vikings to four Super Bowls during his 17-year National Football League career without winning one, has retired, the team said today.

title: IMPASSE CONTINUES IN GROCERY DISPUTE
description: R ESIDENTS of the Edgemont section of Greenburgh have not yet decided what action to take next in their 12-year- old battle with the local A.&P. supermarket. The dispute, which had been dormant for some time, heated up last year, culminating in area neighborhood associations supporting a boycott of the store from Nov. 18 to Dec. 31, a peak holiday season.

title: IT'S MEESE REPLACING SMITH AT JUSTICE
description: d Caroline Rand Heron

title: DRUG SMUGGLING RISES ON L.I.
description: E ASTERN Long Island's isolated coastline and its lightly traveled airports have long attracted privacy-seeking vacationers. But these qualities also attract a different kind of privacy- seeker: the sophisticated drug smuggler, and law enforcement officials warn that Suffolk County has become a ''direct pipeline'' for drugs from South America.

title: Stewart Leads San Diego Open by Shot
description: For the first time in his three years on the PGA Tour, Payne Stewart is the sole leader of a tournament entering the final round. But the long-hitting Missourian, who will be 27 years old Monday, was not impressed with his one- shot margin over Andy Bean after three rounds of the Isuzu-Andy Williams San Diego Open.

title: Cultural Appendage Of New York
description: Peggy McCarthy's article on the state of the arts - and the artist - in Connecticut (''Artists in State Rise in Number Amid Few Jobs,'' Jan. 15) needed to be written, needs to be read. The sad fact is, an artist is better off working in Montana than in this self-conscious, self-serving appendage to New York. Not only do the Yankee taste-makers wait for New York to speak before they dare opine about a book, a play or a picture, but they are tighter than quahogs when it comes to parting with pence for anything so frivolous as art. And in all of this, the press has much to answer for.

description: East vs. West, 34th annual N.B.A. All-Star Game , at Denver, 2 P.M. Julius Erving of Philadelphia, Larry Bird of Boston, Sidney Moncrief of Milwaukee and Isiah Thomas of Detroit will start for the East. Moses Malone, the 76er center, is injured and has been replaced on the roster by the Pistons' Bill Laimbeer. For the West, the starters are Kareem Abdul-Jabbar of Los Angeles, Adrian Dantley of Utah, Alex English of Denver, George Gervin of San Antonio and Earvin (Magic) Johnson of the Lakers. title: Unbeaten DePaul Tops U.C.L.A., 84-68
description: Ray Meyer said he noticed a quiet sense of purpose among the players in the team meetings Friday night and this morning. There was none of the customary bantering and joking, he said, only questions being asked. Apparently, for all the games that the DePaul players have won for their coach in this, his final season, they wanted this game for themselves.

title: NOTED HISTORIAN TO TEACH HIS CRAFT
description: ''I ALWAYS said I would never teach,'' said the author and historian John Toland, ''but this is beginning to look like a challenge. I have a feeling I might learn something from bright young people.''

He is Arturo Franco, a former world champion twice-over, and the deal he could complain about is shown in the diagram. It is one of the many that could have changed bridge history in the cliff-hanger final of the 1983 world championship in Stockholm.

title:

Two such plants, one from each category, have gained prominence as cut flowers.
