description: Michael B. Trimble is a professional gardener and writer.

title: WHY SCHOLARS BECOME STORYTELLERS
description: ''Middlemarch'' George Eliot described her scientist Dr. Lydgate in terms which, it has been said, might equally apply to the novelist: ''He wanted to pierce the obscurity of those minute processes which prepare human misery and joy, those invisible thoroughfares which are the first lurking places of anguish, mania and crime, that delicate poise and transition which determine the growth of happy or unhappy consciousness.''

title: DESIGNER-SHOW MANSION RAZED
description: V ANISHED mansions are not reported on the police blotter in Southampton, where such occurrences are rare but not unknown among the village's stock of gracious summer homes.

title: LEON FLEISHER'S RECOVERY DELAYED
description: L eon Fleisher's much publicized return to two-handed pianism a year ago has run into problems. Mr. Fleisher was scheduled this season for a reasonably full schedule of concerto performances - about one a month say his representatives. These performances were to signal Mr. Fleisher's recovery from the crippling condition in his right hand which interrupted for 17 years his successful career in the general piano repertory. Mr. Fleisher, however, has been unable to fulfill these two- handed commitments and has been offering his one-handed repertory instead.

title: Iraq Says Iran Plans To Attack in the South
description: The commander of Iraq's Third Army Corps said today that Iran was preparing to attack southern Iraq and that this strategic port was a possible target.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Dance

title: THE PRESIDENT IS SPOILING MY PARTY
description: I *HAVE always been a pushover for the

title: A RAIL CORRIDOR TOO PRECIOUS FOR AMTRAK
description: To the Editor:

title: GLENN DOUBTS A BANDWAGON FOR MONDALE
description: Jim McLin has heard the talk and read about the polls, but he says he is not convinced that former Vice President Walter F. Mondale has the Democratic Presidential nomination wrapped up.

title: Lord, Geller Becomes New Ty-D-Bol Agency
description: Ty-D-Bol, the toilet cleaner, has a new ad agency: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein.

title: BRIEFING
description: Kennedy Gets Rostrum

title: EAST TOPS WEST IN OVERTIME
description: All-star basketball games are for fun. The players freelance and the coaches use few plays, if any, that might take away from the usually spectacular one-on-one confrontations.

title: BOSSY INJURED IN TOUGH DEFEAT
description: It was the last game before the All- Star break, and after three straight losses the Islanders needed a singular lift at Nassau Coliseum Saturday night. Instead, they received a double blow - a 4-3 defeat by the Detroit Red Wings and the loss of Mike Bossy.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: The Second Shot

title: RADICALS CLAIMING RESPONSIBILITY
description: A bomb damaged a Motorola Inc. equipment repair building in Whitestone, Queens, last night only minutes after the police had arrived at the building to investigate a telephone call claiming to be from a radical organization predicting the explosion, officials said. There were no reports of injuries.

title: SAYS 'WORK IS NOT FINISHED'
description: President Reagan, asserting that his Administration had ''made a new beginning'' but that ''our work is not finished,'' declared tonight that he and Vice President Bush would seek re-election this year.

title: TIES OF ATTORNEYS GENERAL TO CHIEF
description: More than anyone but the President himself, it is the Attorney General who sets the moral tone of an Administration, symbolizing its commitment or lack of commitment to impartial justice.

title: DASHING THROUGH SNOW IN 16-DOG OPEN SLEDS
description: Just minutes from the ski lifts and condominiums of Lake Placid, within earshot of snowmobile and automobile, a hundred men and women and a thousand dogs gathered this weekend for one of the ancient rites of winter.

title: Talks Break Off In Butchers' Strike
description: Negotiations between the management of four major supermarket chains and a union representing 7,000 striking butchers and delicatessen and seafood clerks ended Saturday night with no new talks planned to try to end the two-week-old strike.

title: 75, He Takes a 26th Wife
description: Glynn Scotty Wolfe, who is 75, married for the 26th time Saturday at a wedding chapel on the Las Vegas Strip. Wearing a black tuxedo and an ear-to-ear smile, Mr. Wolfe walked out of the chapel with his bride, 38-year-old Christine Camacho, the oldest of his brides.

title: BANKS URGE PARIS TO REFINANCE DEBT
description: Major European and American banks are privately urging France to negotiate easier repayment terms for some of its huge foreign debt, now estimated at more than $50 billion, according to banking sources.

title: HIGH ACCUMULATIONS OF DDT REPORTED IN ANIMALS IN WEST
description: Elevated levels of fresh DDT, a potent insecticide banned in 1972, have surfaced in fish and wildlife in Texas, California and other Western states and now threaten coastal breeding grounds.

title: EXTREMIST JEWS BLAMED IN RAID ON ARAB SHRINE
description: A sense of rising alarm about terrorism against Arabs has gripped Israeli political and religious leaders following an attempted attack last week on the holiest Moslem shrine in Jerusalem.

title: SOME INTELLECTUALS SEE CONSERVATISM AS A DARK CLOUD
description: ''The very word 'excellence' ought to make us cringe a little, so thoroughly has it been assimilated to the prose styles of commission reports, letters of recommendation and hair spray commercials.''

title: THE OTHER CITY: NEW YORK'S HOMELESS
description: Mae Ash used to be a maid at the Waldorf-Astoria. William McKie can tell stories about his cross-country travels. Ernest Alvizo taught school in Brooklyn. Donna Gray grew up in foster homes and has spent time in six mental hospitals.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.59

title: FOOTBALL, CONFUSION AND FLIGHT
description: The University of Miami's football victory over Nebraska Jan. 2 and its subsequent recognition as the top college football team in the nation has set off an outpouring of enthusiasm here that may be hard to beat.

title: 2 Candidates in Ecuador Win Spots in a Runoff
description: A Conservative and a Social Democrat placed first and second in presidential elections today and will face each other in a runoff May 6. Seven other candidates were eliminated.

title: A SUBDUED FAREWELL TO ROZIER & CO. AT NEBRASKA
description: On the large screen overhead, the seniors appeared the way they were. They ran onto the field one by one as Lyell Bremser, the voice of the Nebraska Cornhuskers for 45 years, called their names on that gray, raw November Saturday, their last football Saturday at Memorial Stadium.

title: Air Force Retiring Plane
description: The Air Force is about to retire the last of more than 800 F-105 Thunderchief fighter-bombers, which played a major role in bombing North Vietnam.

title: St. Francis Wins, Finally
description: An important individual milestone helped bring a dubious team distinction to an end Saturday night as Robert Jackson, a 6-foot-8-inch center, led St. Francis of Brooklyn to an 84-74 victory over Wagner College on Staten Island.

title: Aircraft Plant Plans to Replace Strikers
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, whose plant here has been struck by the United Automobile Workers, said it will begin hiring replacement employees Monday.

title: POWER TEST IN PACT FOR GETTY UNITS
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell virtually all of the Getty Oil Company's retail activities in the Northeast and Middle Atlantic states to the Power Test Corporation, the largest independent gasoline distributor on the East Coast, once Texaco has completed its $10.1 billion merger with Getty.

title: Steckel Made Viking Coach
description: Les Steckel, the Minnesota Vikings receivers coach since 1979, became the third head coach in the club's 23-year history today.

title: Diluting Density, Down and West
description: It's been two years since New York's City Planning Commission put forward a new zoning code to arrest the crowding of office towers on Manhattan's East Side and to lure developers to the underbuilt West Side. The code eliminated most bonuses given builders who offer ''public'' amenities and shifted the inducements for building elsewhere.

title: INTEL COPES WITH A SHORTAGE
description: Seven months ago, with orders for its microprocessor chips pouring in, executives at the Intel Corporation began discouraging business from new customers.

title: No Headline
description: Casey Rebuts Charges By Hart as Demogogic

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A map and table that accompanied an article on nuclear power in Business Day on Jan. 20 omitted the source of the information. It was the Department of Energy.

title: SALVADORAN REBEL GROUP SAYS IT KILLED RIGHTIST LEGISLATOR
description: A leftist rebel group took responsibility today for the assassination of a rightist member of El Salvador's Constituent Assembly.

title: ; A RAIL CORRIDOR TOO PRECIOUS FOR AMTRAK
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: A Damp Discovery

title: TO OUR READERS
description: Starting today, The Times offers expanded and redesigned daily television pages. They include added news, features and reviews, with program listings for both broadcast and cable television. Pages C15-C17.

title: George W. Merck, 65, Retired Executive,Dies
description: George Wall Merck, a former vice president of Merck & Company, the pharmaceuticals manufacturer, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Bedminster, N.J. He was 65 years old.

title: Tennessee Leader Wins Teacher-Pay Campaign
description: A year's campaigning and cajoling by Gov. Lamar Alexander has turned bitter opposition by the state's largest teacher union to support for his merit-pay plan for teachers.

title: 'HONEYMOONERS' EVENT
description: Club members, who number about 2,500, are planning an event on March 10 at the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University, Greenvale, L.I. The day will feature guest appearances by cast members and the production staff, trivia contests and screenings of rare episodes. Peter Crescenti, a co-founder of the club, said of the show: ''The jokes have held up over the years.'' For more information, call (516) 299-2333.

title: NEW COURSES TO HELP WOMEN
description: More than 350 courses offered by 54 educational institutions in New York City are listed in the ''Guide to Women's Studies'' published by the city's Commission on the Status of Women. The classes are scheduled to start next month or in the spring.

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: With President Reagan starting things off last night, politics will be an even heartier staple than usual in the Washington diet this week, with attention focused both on the November election and the Administration's proposed budget going to Congress Wednesday. The President begins a busy week of speeches and meetings by addressing the National Religious Broadcasters this afternoon at the Sheraton Washington.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Fighting Again

title: Court Upholds Ruling On Bias in I.Q. Tests
description: Racially biased intelligence tests cannot be used as a measuring stick for placing black schoolchildren in California in ''dead end'' classes for the mentally retarded, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: MUSIC: CHORAL SOCIETY PERFORMS MOZART MASS
description: THE New York Choral Society's program at Carnegie Hall Saturday night distributed its weight with great unevenness. Almost all of the substance lay in the second half - in Mozart's C minor Mass. The Vaughan Williams Mass in G minor and Morton Gould's ''Quotations'' at the beginning could create little in the way of counterbalance.

title: BIG TREASURY OFFERINGS NEXT WEEK
description: Dealers in Government securities will begin preparing this week for a heavy supply of new Treasury note and bond issues expected for sale next week. Details of those auctions will be announced Wednesday by Treasury officials. Market analysts expect the financing to consist of about $6.5 billion of three-year notes, $5.25 billion of 10-year notes and $4.25 billion of 30-year bonds.

title: GENERALS IMPRESS BARBARO
description: Gary Barbaro, one of the New Jersey Generals' expensive new athletes from the National Football League, is something of an expert about the United States Football League, a claim not everyone can make. During the U.S.F.L.'s first season last year Barbaro watched several games on television from his home in Metairie, La., near New Orleans.

title: THEISMANN STARS AS N.F.C. WINS, 45-3
description: Joe Theismann staged a record passing show in the Pro Bowl today as he led the National Football Conference all- stars to a 45-3 victory over the A.F.C. all-stars at Aloha Stadium.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Vice President Bush and I would like to have your continued support and cooperation in completing what we began three years ago.

title: JACKSON SAYS HE WAS NOT IN ROLE TO KNOW OF GIFT BY ARAB LEAGUE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he saw no need to determine the source of contributions to a key fund-raising organization affiliated with the civil rights group he led before entering the Presidential race.

title: Chemical Spins Off Unit And Names Its Leader The Chemical Bank has announced the spinoff of an investment advisory company called Portfolio Group Inc. and has named Thomas F. Hodgman its president.
description: These spinoffs are a trend in the banking industry and one reason is that they put some distance between banks and their investment companies. ''One problem is the bank image,'' Mr. Hodgman said, ''that they are slow and stodgy and so forth.''

title: TEXAS POLITICIANS ARE SCRAMBLING TO SUCCEED TOWER IN SENATE
description: The political tidal wave stirred by John Tower's abrupt abdication of the Senate seat he has held for 22 years has subsided but little since his surprise withdrawal announcement five months ago. Six major candidates are fighting to succeed Mr. Tower, who is a Republican, and there are prospects for runoffs in both parties.

title: IN DETROIT, POET LAUREATE'S WORK IS NEVER DONE
description: Dudley Randall, in the tradition of Chaucer, Tennyson and Masefield, is a poet laureate.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 30, 1984: MONDAY Armstrong WorldConsol FreightwaysBlack & DeckerLouisana-Pacific Corp TUESDAY Amer BrandsKennametal IncBorden IncKoger PropertiesBucyrus-EriePacific LumberGulton Indus

title: DANCE: TWYLA THARP PRESENTS A PREMIERE
description: Twyla Tharp delivered a choreographic State of the Union message and concluded that all was not well in the disquieting work that received its New York premiere at Friday night's performance of her company, Twyla Tharp Dance, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It could easily have been called ''The Age of Anxiety'' if that title hadn't already been used for a poem by W. H. Auden and a ballet by Jerome Robbins. But Miss Tharp found a title almost as good: ''Fait Accompli,'' a title with ominous implications of finality.

title: Engine Order May Be Split WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (Reuters) - The Pentagon is likely to divide billions of dollars of orders for fighter plane engines between two companies, rather than giving an exclusive contract, according to military and Congressional sources.
description: The two companies competing for $10 billion in contracts over the next decade are Pratt & Whitney, a division of the United Technologies Corporation, and the General Electric Company. A decision is expected this week, the sources said last Friday.

title: MAN, 20, SEIZED IN THE SHOOTING OF A POLICEMAN
description: A 20-year-old Harlem man was arrested yesterday and charged with shooting and critically wounding a police officer Friday night in a sniper attack, the police said.

title: MONDAY, JANUARY 30, 1984 International
description: Guatemala will get helicopter parts worth $2 million from the United States, the State Department announced, despite a Congressional ban on military assistance to the country. The parts would be used for Guatemala's aging fleet of United States- made military helicopters. The first official sale of military equipment to that country since 1977 would not be a violation of the Congressional ban because the sale would be a cash transaction, the State Department said. (Page A1, Column 1.) Moscow has formally protested to the United States about what it said was a wide range of American violations of arms treaties with the Soviet Union, including the first and second agreements on limiting strategic nuclear weapons. (A1:3.)

title: Woman in Crash With Bruin Dies
description: A 26-year-old Maine woman involved in an automobile accident that resulted in drunken driving charges against Craig MacTavish of the Boston Bruins died today at Salem Hospital.

title: SOVIET-BLOC INROADS ON WORLD SHIPPING
description: Although the lumbering freighter on the Weser River was registered in Leningrad, its load of dark beans, destined for the huge silos of local coffee roasters, came from the Caribbean.

title: BUSH IS EAGER TO SHOW LOYALTY IN CAMPAIGN
description: Among all the Republican politicians who owe their jobs to Ronald Reagan, probably none awaited the President's announcement tonight with a greater sublimation of curiosity than George Bush, the one-time Reagan rival who has made an art form of discreet loyalty in serving as Vice President for the past three years.

title: 12 LESSONS FOR NOVICES IN COMPUTERS
description: WE cannot escape computers; they are here, angering the Luddites among us, a bafflement to some of the rest. Meanwhile, we must make our peace with computers, and while it is not mandatory that we like them, it is clear that we are being forced to accept them. ''Bits and Bytes,'' a new public-television series, is a painless way to start.

title: Correction
description: In an answer involving Emlen Tunnell two weeks ago, the college from which the late defensive back was graduated was given incorrectly.

title: NOT-SO-BINIGN ALGAE IN DRINKING WATER
description: To the Editor:

title: SELLING U.S. STOCKS IN JAPAN
description: Rock singers and judo wrestlers are the attractions that usually fill Tokyo's Nippon Budokan Hall.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 30, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: NIGERIA'S SEARCH FOR RECOVERY
description: For a little more than four years, Nigeria was the great African exception: it was democratic and had money.

title: OUTDOORS: HUNTING WATERFOWL WITH A MUZZLERLOADER
description: CHESTERTOWN, Md.

title: DIAL M FOR MURK
description: A funny thing happened on the way to the A.T.& T. divestiture. Everyone forgot to service the customer. A lot of material has been published on the divestiture, but none of it explained how frustrating it would be to get your telephone fixed.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Summer Dreams In Winter's Snow

title: SOVIET BUILDUP IN FAR EAST CAUSING U.S. CONCERN
description: Military Analysis

title: DECISION ELICITS PRAISE AND DERISION
description: President Reagan's long-awaited announcement that he would run for a second term touched off celebrations last night by his supporters, choruses of derision by opponents and promises of a tough campaign by Republicans and Democrats alike.

title: TEXT OF SPEECH BY PRESIDENT ON PLAN TO SEEK RE-ELECTION
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's paid political announcement as recorded by The New York Times:

title: CBS ADDING NEWS WEEKLY
description: -TV has canceled ''The Mississippi,'' an hourlong dramatic series on Tuesday nights, and the move may make room for ''The American Parade,'' a new weekly news-magazine program anchored by Charles Kuralt, according to network executives.

title: SHIFT BY HUSSEIN: A NEW ASSERTIVENESS
description: News Analysis

title: Mother Who Defied Probation Order Freed
description: A young woman jailed for violating a probation condition that she have no more children for 15 years has been freed after a businessman complaining of ''Big Brother'' court tactics posted bond.

title: COLUMBIA GIVEN $4.3 MILLION FOR JEWISH STUDIES
description: Columbia University has received an anonymous gift of $4.3 million to support the teaching of Jewish studies at the university, Michael I. Sovern, the president of Columbia, announced yesterday.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Glamour Issues In Bad Week
description: T HE stock market stepped off last Monday on

title: Advertising; Ketchum's LU Cookie Promotion
description: NOW that it has distribution throughout the United States, Generale Biscuit of Paris, the world's third-largest cookie maker, is ready to begin promoting its LU brand, already a favorite in many other lands.

title: Old-Timer Game To Be Regular
description: Despite all the huffing and puffing, the old-timer game held at McNichols Arena Saturday afternoon will become a regular feature of the annual National Basketball Association All-Star Game weekend.

title: Miss Joyner Snaps Long-Jump Mark
description: Jackie Joyner broke the American record in the women's long jump today, and Jim Spivey turned in a 3:57.7 mile to highlight the Bally Invitational track meet.

title: CAROLINA DEFEATS L.S.U.
description: North Carolia, tested by a formidable opponent for the third time in five days, maintained its unbeaten status today with a 90-79 comeback victory over Louisiana State.

title: 6 Boys Arrested After Derailment
description: Six boys between the ages of 9 and 15 were arrested yesterday and charged with derailing a Metro-North train carrying 150 passengers Saturday near Larchmont, N.Y., a spokesman for the commuter railroad said.

title: TV REVIEWS ; COMPLICATED CASE OF RAPE ON ABC
description: COMBINING elements of both sex and violence, the subject of rape has proven just about irresistible to television. It has been explored, and sometimes exploited, by the medium from a multitude of angles, ranging from the rape of an innocent woman by a total stranger to the homosexual rape of a prisoner by another inmate. As time and programming standards have changed, some of the treatments have ventured into more subtle areas and questions. Witness tonight's ''When She Says No'' on ABC-TV at 9 o'clock.

title: GOLDWATER DECLARES HE DOES NOT INTEND TO RUN FOR 6TH TERM
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, said Sunday that he will not seek re-election when his fifth term expires in 1986.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Friday about rules governing challenges to some rent increases incorrectly reported the deadline for filing complaints to the Conciliation and Appeals Board. Complaints must be filed by March 31. After that, complaints will be handled by the Rent Administration Office.

title: MEESE AND SECRECY
description: Edwin Meese and his colleagues on the White House staff have identified one obstacle to Mr. Meese's early confirmation as Attorney General, and they hope to deal with it by compromise. That is President Reagan's order of last March 11 creating a lifetime censorship system for officials who see highly sensitive information.

title: BILL IN ALBANY WOULD LIMIT GRAND JURY IMMUNITY
description: Legislators have put forward a compromise plan to limit the legal protections given to people who testify before grand juries.

title: ICE DANCING PAIR EXCITES BRITAIN
description: LONDON B RITAIN is moving toward a fever pitch of excitement about the Winter Olympics prospects of Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean, world ice dance champions the last three years. It is almost impossible to pick up a popular newspaper without finding some reference to them, usually accompanied by a photograph of the couple either in casual wear in a moment of relaxation or in their striking costumes on the ice. They have become royalty in skating outfits, only a close second to the Prince and Princess of Wales in public esteem. Their biography, ''Torvill & Dean,'' appears on the best-sellers list four months after publication.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Tokyo Agency In BBDO Link BBDO International, the corporate parent of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, is

title: Norlin's New President Facing a Takeover Bid The first assignment of Gilbert A. Simpkins as president and chief operating officer of the Norlin Corporation is pretty straightforward: fend off a possible takeover threat to the musical instrument maker and financial printer.
description: Mr. Simpkins, formerly a senior vice president at Norlin, and its chief financial officer for the past 11 years, was promoted on Jan. 19, only two days after an investors group announced that it had acquired 18.5 percent of Norlin's stock, and that it would seek ''significant influence over the company.'' The investors group, led by Rooney Pace Inc., the investment concern, and Piezo Electric Products Inc., has continued its purchases since then, bringing its stake to at least 37 percent last week.

title: WEARABLE ART: CHARTING A DECADE OF CHANGE
description: Julie Schafler Dale is celebrating the 10th anniversary of her crafts gallery on Madison Avenue with an exhibition of wearable art.

title: Harvey C. Dzodin Married to Cynthia E. Northrop
description: Cynthia Ellen Northrop, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Merle Northrop of Earlysville, Va., was married yesterday to Harvey Cary Dzodin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Label Dzodin of Oak Park, Mich. Rabbi Stuart Weinblatt performed the ceremony at the Calvert Mansion in Riverdale, Md.

title: 18 INDICTED IN JERSEY IN KILLING OF RACE HORSES TO COLLECT INSURANCE
description: Eighteen people, including several race horse owners, trainers and a reputed member of organized crime, have been indicted on charges of killing race horses and defrauding insurance companies.

title: Mitsubishi-Chrysler Plan
description: The president of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, Toyoo Tate, said today that he hoped to decide on a possible American joint car production venture with the Chrysler Corporation by the end of this year. He told reporters on his return from the United States that he had agreed with Chrysler's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, to move from a preparatory survey to a more concrete study on implementing the plan.

title: EDUCATOR SLAIN IN BEIRUT IS MOURNED IN PRINCETON
description: Dr. Malcolm H. Kerr loved to watch college football games on television but often kept a scholarly Arabic tome in his lap to read during timeouts.

title: NORTHEAST GROWER'S ALL-YEAR LETTUCE
description: It was 10 degrees below zero the other day, with snow six inches deep. Nonetheless Mary Daley and Richard Towart were busy transplanting seedlings in an agricultural factory that operates all year round, producing fresh lettuce for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: THE DOUBLE STANDARD
description: The U.S. Senate will soon be getting around to hearings on President Reagan's nomination of Edwin Meese to be Attorney General. That raises a good question in the mind of Bill Shipp, a columnist for The Atlanta Constitution.

title: MEYER GOING OUT IN STYLE AT DEPAUL
description: CHICAGO E VEN now, when reveling in the many tributes and triumphs of his farewell season, there are some habits that Ray Meyer cannot break. He will return to the locker room at Rosemont Horizon after a game or shuffle into the film room at Alumni Hall after practice and complain about the discarded tape and paper cups littering the floor as he might have complained when his children forgot to tidy their rooms.

title: Roofer Sues TV Crew For Filming Immolation
description: An out-of-work roofer who set himself on fire to protest high unemployment has filed a $4 million suit against a television news crew that filmed the incident.

title: Strike Threatened By Passaic Nurses
description: The 235 registered nurses at Passaic General Hospital threatened to walk off their jobs Monday morning if the latest round of talks aimed at reaching a new contract failed, said officials of the union representing the nurses.

title: THOMAS BRIGHTEST STAR
description: For much of the last three days, Magic Johnson, Mark Aguirre and Isiah Thomas were like the Three Musketeers, galivanting about this mile-high city.

title: McEnroe Topples Lendl in 4-Set Final
description: John McEnroe won the United States Pro Indoor tennis championship for the third consecutive time today by scoring a 6-3, 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 victory over Ivan Lendl.

title: MOSCOW ACCUSES U.S. OF VIOLATING ARMS AGREEMENTS
description: The Soviet Union said today that it had formally protested to the United States about what it charged was a wide range of American violations of arms treaties between the two countries, including the first and second agreements on limiting strategic nuclear weapons.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Astaire Awards

title: REAGAN IN INTERVIEW SAYS HE FAVORS IDEA OF HAVING A DEBATE
description: President Reagan favors the idea of a debate between himself and the Democratic Presidential nominee, he indicated in an interview with Newsweek magazine released last night.

title: Maurice I. Parisier, 81, Dies; AnEarlyElectronicsInventor
description: Maurice I. Parisier, an engineer who was an early telecommunications inventor, died Saturday at his home in New York. He was 81 years old.

title: Freeze Raising Insurers' Costs
description: The severe freeze that swept most of the United States last month may cost the insurance industry almost $600 million in claims, according to securities analysts, who are lowering their earnings estimates for most major insurers. The claims range from burst water pipes in homes and offices to disruption of business operations.

title: LINCOLN CENTER FACILITY STUDY
description: Because of its space needs, the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is studying the feasibility of constructing a multi-use building on the site of the Brandeis High School Annex, according to Martin E. Segal, chairman of Lincoln Center.

title: ACROSS THE HUDSON BY RAPID TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Olympic Level Mud-Slinging
description: HIGHER, Faster, Stronger: that's the Olympic motto. But it's incomplete. Louder, Uglier, Phonier - those words deserve equal billing. In the snowy mountains of Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, this week, athletes from more than 40 nations will be gathering for the XIV Winter Olympic Games. When the Olympic torch is lit a week from Wednesday during the opening ceremony, Olympic politicians will proclaim the spirit of the international good will generated by the occasion.

title: Jailed Greek Dictator Sponsors Rightist Party
description: Although jailed for life for carrying out a coup in 1967, Greece's ex-dictator, George Papadopoulos, announced today that he was sponsoring a new right-wing political party, the National Political Union.

title: A RAIL CORRIDOR TOO PRECIOUS FOR AMTRAK
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NEEDIEST REAP BENEFITS OF WINDFALLS
description: ''A check for jury duty just came my way,'' began a note that accompanied a donation of $50 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''Having earned this money meting out justice, I would like to give some of it to offer mercy.''

title: A PROGRAM FOR DISTURBED COLLEGE STUDENTS
description: ''When I started college, everything came to a head. I had been a lonely child and I had difficulty adapting academically and socially. I was left alone with my feelings, all alone out there. The workload was heavy, and I was having problems with my parents. I went to some classes because I wanted to be able to do everything perfectly. But I felt I couldn't handle it, and I was scared to let the school know that I couldn't deal with it. I was isolated, there was no one there for me. Finally, I just said right out to my parents: ''There's no point in my going on. I will kill myself.''

title: REAGAN STRONG IN SOUTH BUT G.O.P. FAILS TO GAIN
description: The other day President Reagan looked out at a thousand cheering Southern Republican leaders gathered here and remarked: ''It wasn't that long ago when the South was the stronghold for the Democratic Party. But from the spirit I sense here, those days are long gone.''

title: IN WESTERN EUROPE, ART SUBSIDES FALL
description: Support for the arts in Britain and other West European countries is entering a period of trial and challenge as financially hard-pressed governments here and across the Continent are cutting cultural subsidies.

title: ISRAELI QUITS CABINET IN A POLICY DISPUTE
description: An Israeli Cabinet Minister resigned today, citing disagreements with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's policies on Lebanon and the economy and the failure to form a national unity government.

title: STABLE FED POLICY SEEN BY ANALYSTS
description: Monetary policy is expected to remain much the same when the Federal Open Market Committee meets today and tomorrow, according to many analysts.

title: INCOME TAX'S MIXED PICTURE: LOWER RATES, TOUGHER RULES
description: For most taxpayers, the distress that traditionally accompanies the income tax filing season should be eased somewhat this year by lower tax rates and a higher deduction for working married couples.

title: Cost of Servicing U.S. Debt Is Soaring
description: At a time of huge budget deficits, the national debt is growing so rapidly, and the cost in interest has climbed so high, that members of both parties in Congress are vying to record themselves as opponents of spending.

title: KOCH TAKES PLAYOFFS AT SAN DIEGO OPEN
description: Gary Koch, who started his final round 6 shots off the lead and tied for 18th place, sank a 10-foot birdie putt today on the second hole of a playoff with Gary Hallberg to win the $72,000 first prize in the Isuzu-Andy Williams San Diego Open.

title: End the Fear of Smallpox
description: There are few more heartening milestones of medical progress than the eradication of smallpox. It was achieved in 1980 after a worldwide campaign that lasted 12 years.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner QUESTION: While a penalty shot is being taken in a National Hockey League game, a player on the opposing team distracts the shooter, who misses his attempt. What is the ruling?

title: ROCK: OZZY OSBOURNE ON HEAVY-METAL TOUR
description: OZZY OSBOURNE, for 11 years the singer of the Black Sabbath British heavy- metal group, has been out on his own for several years, and is now touring with two other heavy- metal bands, M"otley Cr"ue and Waysted. The tour has been probing our perimeters last week - last Sunday at the Byrne Arena in the Meadowlands and Wednesday at the Nassau Coliseum. The three bands arrive at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night .

title: Kirk Gibson Signs
description: Kirk Gibson has signed a one-year contract with the Detroit Tigers, the American League club said today. Terms of the pact were not disclosed.

title: RANGERS WIN TO TAKE FIRST PLACE
description: The Rangers, who opened the season with 9 victories in their first 10 games and then faltered, regained possession of first place in the Patrick Division last night by one point with a 3-2 victory over the St. Louis Blues at Madison Square Garden.

title: SALVADOR PRESSES HUNDREDS INTO MILITARY
description: Hundreds of young people have been pressed into the Salvadoran Army this month after being stopped by military patrols in the northeastern part of the country.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TRILLIN AND AIDES

title: A JOKE BY GRETZKY BECOMES THE TRUTH
description: Wayne Gretzky turned to Charlie Huddy in the Edmonton Oilers' dressing room after the first period Saturday night and said, jokingly, ''That might have been the streak, Charlie.''

title: Entertainment Events Music
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, ''Stravinsky'': ''Le Sacre du Printemps,'' ''Le Rossignol,'' ''Oedipus Rex,'' 8. JENNY TSENG, song stylist, Avery Fisher Hall, 8. MONTSERRAT ALAVEDRA, soprano, Alice Tully Hall, 8.

title: Vending Machine Bomb Kills Apparent Informer
description: A 63-year- old man who was killed when a bomb exploded in a newspaper vending box had told classmates at a community college two years ago that he once infiltrated the American Nazi Party and Ku Klux Klan for the Government.

title: FORGED WORKS OF ART AS GOOD AS GENUINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslavs Greet Olympic Flame
description: The Olympic flame was flown from Greece to Yugoslavia today into the southern Adriatic resort town of Dubrovnik on its way to Sarajevo for the Winter Olympic Games, Feb. 7-19.

title: BASQUE TERRORISTS SUSPECTED
description: Two gunmen thought to be Basque terrorists shot and killed a high-ranking military officer on his way home from church here this afternoon.

title: London-Miami Flights
description: British Airways said today that it would begin flying its supersonic Concorde passenger jets from London to Miami and back three times a week starting March 27. The flights, with a stopover in Washington, will trim the total flight time from London to six hours and 35 minutes.

title: TOOL ORDERS DOWN IN MONTH, UP IN '83
description: Machine tool orders fell 5.7 percent in December from the previous month, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association reported yesterday. But for the full year, orders were up 13.3 percent.

title: 618 LOUISIANIANS GO TO PARIS FOR 'BIGGEST SINGLE FUND-RAISER'
description: J. DIONNE Jr.

title: STATE TRANSIT DEPT. IS URGED TO SELL LAND THAT IT DOESN'T NEED
description: The New York State Transportation Department could raise ''sorely needed revenue'' by selling or renting as much as $37 million worth of unused property it owns, the State Comptroller said yesterday.

title: Bridge: A Contract of 3 No-Trump Brings an Unlikely Victory
description: If the high-card strength is evenly divided between the two partnerships, one does not expect a contract of three no-trump. It may happen logically, because a long, solid suit is available.

title: EXPERTS IN MURDER TRIAL SAY SHOEMAKER IS SCHIZOPHRENIC
description: A psychiatrist and a psychologist testified Friday that Joseph Kallinger is schizophrenic and probably did not know what he was doing when he killed his 14-year-old son and a 10-year-old boy from his neighborhood in 1974.

title: MRS. REAGAN SAYS DECISION WAS 'MUTUAL'
description: About eight hours before the President announced that he would stand for re- election, Nancy Reagan issued a statement that was a model of ambiguity.

title: British Arbitrators Enter Newspaper Battle
description: Government arbitrators intervened today in a labor dispute that has shut down production of The Times of London and The Sunday Times, but there were no signs of a quick settlement.

title: Debt Ratings
description: * Aristar Inc. 's rating was raised by Standard & Poor's to Bbb from Bbb-, while the commercial paper rating was raised to A2 from A3 and subordinated debt to Bbb- from Bbx.

title: ONE CAMPAIGN ISSUE DOMINATES: THE LEADERSHIP OF RONALD REAGAN
description: The central issue in the Presidential campaign, Republican and Democratic strategists assert, will be President Reagan's leadership - the direction in which his dramatic tax-cutting policies have guided the economy and the wisdom of his force-oriented activism in foreign affairs.

title: NEW NATO STUDY SAYS SPENDING BY SOVIET ON MILITARY HAS SLOWED
description: A new NATO report says Soviet military spending has slowed over the last seven years and asserts that previous Western estimates have exaggerated Moscow's arms buildup.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FRIENDS OF THE OPPOSITE SEX. By Sara Davidson. 288 pages. Doubleday.

title: FIRM ON SAUDIS, KOHL LEAVES ISRAEL
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany completed his visit to Israel today with no indication that he had been dissuaded from approving arms sales to Saudi Arabia.

title: Fresh Snow in Sarajevo
description: Driving rain today washed away last week's snow from Sarajevo streets but fresh snow was falling on mountain venues where the XIV Winter Olympic Games start in nine days.

title: MUSIC TO MAINLAND EARS, OFF-KEY TO PEKING CHIEFS
description: When the propaganda loudspeakers atop the concrete bunkers of the Nationalist-held island of Quemoy blast away at the Chinese mainland barely a mile distant, the anti-Communist broadsides are mercifully interspersed with the songs of Teresa Teng.

title: MISS BERTOLACCINI WINS
description: Silvia Bertolaccini fought off one challenge after another today to score a three-stroke victory in the $200,000 Mazda Classic of Deer Creek, the opening tournament of the Ladies' Professional Golfers Association season.

title: CONGRESS LIKELY TO MAKE MAJOR CHANGES AGAIN IN BUDGET PROPOSAL
description: Congress made significant changes in the budget for the fiscal year 1984 that President Reagan proposed a year ago, and it is likely to do the same to the budget for the next fiscal year that he submits Wednesday.

title: Benton & Bowles Plans Corning Glass Strategy
description: Benton & Bowles has created an umbrella advertising campaign for Corning Glass Works to identify the company more closely with some of its products and brand names.

title: Iraq Frees 190 Iranians To Red Cross in Turkey
description: Iraq turned over 190 Iranian prisoners of war to the International Committee of the Red Cross at Ankara airport today and an Iranian airliner arrived to take them home, officials said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dayton-Hudson Corp., a Minneapolis-based retail chain, has named Stephen E. Watson chief operating officer.

title: Banking's Busting Out All Over
description: While Government has been struggling to define a proper level of regulation in many industries, one critical sector of the nation's economy has been vigorously deregulating itself. Banks and thrift institutions, stockbrokers and mutual funds, insurance companies and even Sears, Roebuck have encroached on each other's traditional functions to an extent none could imagine only a decade ago.

title: British Asset Sales
description: The British Government's Economic Committee has agreed on a plan to sell off the equivalent of $11.2 billion to $14 billion of state-owned assets during the next five years, Government sources said. The plan will begin with sales valued at the equivalent of $2.66 billion in the fiscal year starting in April, including the sale of 51 percent of British Telecom.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, JANUARY 30, 1984
description: The Economy

title: Costello Captures Title From Curry
description: Billy Costello knocked out Bruce Curry in the 10th round of a scheduled 12-round bout today to capture the World Boxing Council super lightweight championship.

title: Red Smith Fund Gets a Donation
description: The Reinhardt Stables in Foxboro, Mass., picked up a breeding bargain yesterday, and the Red Smith Writing Scholarship at Notre Dame picked up a $2,500 donation.

title: Patricia L. Eisler Wed To Philip Leigh Vance
description: Patricia Lynn Eisler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore D. Eisler of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Philip Leigh Vance, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Millard F. Vance of Florissant, Mo. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan.

title: Canucks Defeat Devils, 3-2;  Devils Defeated By Canucks, 3-2
description: Thomas Gradin scored two goals, including the game- winner, and assisted on another tonight to lead the Vancouver Canucks to a 3-2 victory over the New Jersey Devils.

title: WHY OBSTETRICIANS SHUN MEDICAL CASES
description: To the Editor:

title: TV NOTES: 2 NEW CABLE NETWORKS BEING PLANNED
description: The common wisdom in the television industry of late is that cable-programming networks, particularly those that specialize in one type of programming, are struggling to survive. The roll of cable networks that tried and quickly died - including CBS Cable, The Satellite News Channel and Spotlight - are a reminder of how difficult it can be to start a new national cable service.

title: HOW HOLLYWOOD MANIPULATES TELEVISON
description: When KABC-TV, the ABC station in Los Angeles, aired an interview with the film star Al Pacino last December, things were not quite what they seemed. In addition to Mr. Pacino, a KABC-TV reporter named Nancy Gould appeared on camera reacting to his answers.

title: U.S. AGREES TO SELL HELICOPTER PARTS TO GUATEMALANS
description: The Reagan Administration has agreed to sell Guatemala $2 million worth of spare parts for its aging fleet of United States-made military helicopters, the State Department said today.

title: SEIJI OZAWA CONDUCTING 'GURRELIEDER'
description: IN all the symphonic repertory,

title: ARIZONA TO CUT DOWN ON GREENERY TO SAVE WATER
description: After years of worry, Arizona is trying to do something no other parched Western state has ever tried to do before: Stop using water faster than it is replaced by nature.

title: KEEPING ELDERLY IN TOUCH
description: ''ICALL her every so often to keep

title: THEATER: 'ADMISSIONS,' DRAMA BY SHIRLEY LAURO
description: FOR all that's shaky about ''Open Admissions,'' the new play at the Music Box, there's no denying its power to shake an audience. Shirley Lauro's drama is a rarity for Broadway these days: It thrusts us onto the front line of an agonizing contemporary social crisis and refuses to show us the easy way out. Though Mrs. Lauro tells of the conflict between a white woman teacher and a black male student in a public New York college, she refuses to present the usual blacks and whites in either the racial or moral sense. Both her characters are decent people; both are casualties on a battleground that neither of them has made.

title: Futures/OptionsH. J. Maidenberg Regulator Pact Causes Discord
description: I T was only a matter of time before the new financial and stock index futures and options, which

title: S.I. GOLF OPERATOR CUT 300 TREES, CITY SAYS
description: A golf course concessionaire has improperly cut down more than 300 trees and bulldozed shrubs, plants and topsoil in LaTourette Park on Staten Island, causing ''hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of damage,'' according to Parks Department officials.

title: DON'T OVERESTIMATE TOKYO'S INDUSTRIAL AID
description: It is unsettling news that a blue-ribbon panel primarily composed of Democratic businessmen, labor leaders and assorted elder statesmen has produced a report calling for the creation of new Government institutions to foster development of a national industrial policy. Their recommendation seems to rest in considerable degree on a lesson that many people in the United States have drawn from Japan's resounding economic successes. The key ingredient in those successes, many American businessmen and politicians believe, has been the aid and comfort that the Japanese Government - specifically, the dread Ministry of International Trade and Industry, known as MITI - has given Japanese business. There is just one drawback to this thesis: It isn't true.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dance review last Thursday misidentified the composers of the score for Jennifer Muller's ''Kite.'' They were Henry Aronson and Michael Starobin.

title: SWISS EDGES MISS COOPER IN CUP RACE
description: Erika Hess of Switzerland won her second giant slalom of the season today in the last World Cup race before the Winter Olympics.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Spirit of Mansions Past

title: The President and His Signs
description: It sure could have been a yawn, Ronald Reagan announcing he's running for President for the fourth time, yet he made good sport of it. It's easy now to say no surprise, but plenty of people found plenty of signs pointing the other way.

description: IT'S hard to know where pop satire ends and genuine melodrama begins in the music of

title: 4TH-QUARTER PROFITS SEEN RISING 25%
description: Fourth-quarter after-tax profits will be up about 25 percent from a year earlier but will be flat or lower when compared with the third quarter, according to a survey of business analysts and economists.

description: T O meet or not to meet. That is the question

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Georgetown at Syracuse . The game will be the most important matchup of the Big East season so far. The Orangemen are 8-0 in the conference after the victory Saturday over St. John's.

title: AIDE SEES REAGAN UNMOVED ON TAXES
description: James A. Baker 3d, President Reagan's chief aide, indicated strongly today that Mr. Reagan had ruled out a delay in tax indexing or other controversial measures to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

title: Italian Consumer Prices
description: Italian consumer prices rose 1.2 percent in January, after a five-tenths of 1 percent rise in December, the National Statistics Office said today. Its consumer price index for families of workers and office employees rose 12.5 percent in January from a year earlier, down from a 12.7 percent rise in December from a year earlier.

title: MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BELL ATLANTIC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
B.P.-Amax Order
description: The Federal Trade Commission said it had denied a request by the British Petroleum Company that it be allowed to keep its 6.4 percent stock interest in Amax Inc. B.P. had asked the F.T.C. to change a 1981 consent order that required the company to sell its ownership in Amax, at the time the leading United States producer of molybdenum. The requirement was made because B.P. had acquired through a subsidiary the Kennecott Corporation, another leading molybdenum producer. B.P. argued that Amax's position as a molybdenum producer had diminished substantially.

title: PANCHO'S MEXICAN BUFFET reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAST-MINUTE PROCEDURES THAT CAN CUT TAX BILL
description: For many people, the urge to search for tax-saving strategies begins to stir only when the tax-filing season is actually upon them. Then, when they sit down with sharpened pencil and calculator and compute their income tax obligation, they belatedly discover a desperate need to scrounge for angles.

title: CAPITAL CITIES COMMUNICATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STORY OF A V.A. PATIENT: A LONG ROAD TO SUICIDE
description: When Karl Lerchenmueller Jr., a psychiatric patient at the Veterans Administration Hospital here, tried to take silverware from the hospital cafeteria back to his ward, the staff called the state police to arrest him for theft.

title: Billy Graham in Mayo Clinic
description: The Rev. Billy Graham, suffering a high fever, acute infection and exhaustion, has been admitted to a hospital affiliated with the Mayo Clinic, officials said today. The 65-year-old evangelist was being treated with antibiotics and decongestants for acute sinusitis and infections of the left inner ear, a Mayo Clinic spokesman said. His condition was termed ''satisfactory and improving.''

title: Cecile Licad, Pianist, In Recital at Tully Hall
description: Cecile Licad played a program of very familiar piano music at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon. The freshest thing on the program was Beethoven's Sonata in D (Op. 10, No. 3).

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 31, 1984

title: THE ARABS' FORUM AND VOICE
description: The Arab League has long served as a forum and voice for the varying degrees of unity the Arabs have achieved.

title: Federal Court Rejects Ohio Redistricting Plan
description: A three-judge Federal District Court panel overturned Ohio's Congressional redistricting plan today, saying it failed to meet the ''equal representation'' standard of the Constitution. The panel told the Legislature to prepare a revised plan within 45 days.

title: Alexander's Stock
description: Heavy trading in the common stock of Alexander's Inc. has raised the possibility of a substantial increase in holdings of a large stockholder or of the entry of a major new investor, according to sources in the financial community. Alexander's operates 15 stores in the metropolitan area and owns valuable real estate.

title: Man Who Crashed Gate Of Golf Club Admits Guilt
description: Charles R. Harris, accused of crashing his pickup truck through a gate at the Augusta National Golf Club and taking hostages while President Reagan played golf there last fall, pleaded guilty today to kidnapping and false imprisonment charges. He is to be sentenced next month.

title: Hyatt Legal Services Hires Isidore & Paulson
description: Tony Isidore of Isidore & Paulson has announced that the agency has landed the Hyatt Legal Services account. The account, he added, bills about $3 million.

title: STOCKS FALL BROADLY, DOW OFF 8.48
description: Stock prices fell across the board yesterday in continued active trading, with all of the three major market indicators finishing lower.

title: Less Immunity, More Justice
description: Delissa Carter killed her stepmother, then framed her former husband, Nathaniel. He in turn served two years in prison before New York authorities found him wrongly prosecuted. Mrs. Carter finally confessed the vicious stabbing in court last week, but still walked away scot-free.

description: b-Net loss. c-Net income after a loss of $8,256,000 from discontinued operations.

title: WALL STREET RELIEF ON REAGAN
description: Although stock prices dropped again yesterday and Federal budget deficits still loom large, Wall Street officials expressed relief that Ronald Reagan had decided to seek a second term. They seemed confident of his re-election and thus were particularly pleased with the prospect of no major shifts in economic policy.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: KENNEDY SEES REAGAN ON 'GRIM' PATH
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, joining the 1984 political debate with a sharp attack on President Reagan, said today that the real issue of the campaign was what Mr. Reagan might do in a second term, when he would not be accountable to the voters.

title: Borg-Warner Rises 18.4%
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 18.4 percent from a year earlier as all its divisions except air-conditioning equipment turned in strong performances.

title: Output of Films and TV Up 31% in Jersey in '83
description: Film and television production in New Jersey increased by 31 percent from 1982 to 1983, bucking a national trend of sluggish growth in the industry, officials say.

title: 4 on White Sox Come to Terms
description: The Chicago White Sox said today they had signed four of seven players who had applied for salary arbitration.

title: DEBATE ON MAJOR PACKAGE OF ANTICRIME LEGISLATION OPENS IN SENATE
description: The Senate began debate today on a major bipartisan package of anticrime measures, including provisions to overhaul sentencing and bail procedures and to narrow the insanity defense in the Federal courts.

description: In October, after the United States sent troops to Grenada, someone burned an American flag at a protest here.

title: DONATED U.S. FOOD SOLD IN SALVADOR
description: Among the food on sale at the teeming central market in this provincial capital today were large bags of wheat, corn and rice marked as American aid and stamped ''Not to be sold or exchanged.''

description: Results are in U.S. dollars computed at current Yen value.

title: No Headline
description: The Pistol of Sarajevo Americans who know little or nothing about Sarajevo's fame may learn some pertinent history amid the hoopla over the Winter Olympic Games that begin there on Feb. 7. Sarajevo isn't just a sleepy Bosnian city in Yugoslavia. It was here that a terrorist's pistol ignited a European slaughter that claimed four empires and 55 million lives.

title: SELF-DEFENSE PLEA FOR MIAMI OFFICER
description: Luis Alvarez, a Miami police officer, shot a young black man not by accident but in self- defense, a jury was told today in opening arguments at Mr. Alvarez's manslaughter trial.

title: Andrew Cuomo Plans to Join Firm
description: Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's 26-year-old son, said today that he planned to join a private law firm in the next few weeks but would continue working part time as a $1-a-year special assistant to his father.

description: NewsAnalysis

MusicNoted in Brief; Paul Badura-Skoda In Beethoven Recital
description: Paul Badura-Skoda let true Beethoven keyboard style do some comparative shopping Saturday afternoon. His recital for the Beethoven Society in Alice Tully Hall offered in its first half the ''Tempest'' and ''Moonlight'' sonatas played on a Graf fortepiano from the composer's own time and ended with the ''Hammerklavier'' played on a shiny new B"osendorfer.appropriate instrument.

title: Hand Grenades Found Beside Jerusalem Wall
description: A pedestrian found three hand grenades hidden beside the wall of the Old City close to the Via Dolorosa today, and a police spokesman said they may have been planted by the same people who earlier tried to attack Islamic shrines.

title: Productivity Rate Rose At Slow 1% in Quarter WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) - Productivity in nonfarm private businesses grew at a slow annual rate of 1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1983, the Labor Department said today.
description: But for the full year, productivity rose 3.1 percent, the biggest one-year rise since that of 3.2 percent in 1976, the department added.

title: Citicorp Unit Plans Eurobond LONDON, Jan. 30 (Reuters) - Citicorp International Bank Ltd. said its parent holding company was raising 30 million European currency units through a six-year 10 5/8 percent Eurobond.
description: Banque Nationale de Paris is lead manager of the par-priced bond, along with Citicorp International. The borrower can call the issue after three years at 100 3/4 percent, with this premium declining by 1/4 percent each year to par.

title: SCRANTON BISHOP REPORTED TO BE COOKE SUCCESSOR
description: Bishop John J. O'Connor of Scranton, Pa., a conservative theologian who helped write the recent antinuclear letter of the American Roman Catholic bishops, will be named today to head the Archdiocese of New York, church sources said last night.Bishop O'Connor, who is 64 years old, spent 27 years as a Navy chaplain, rising to the rank of rear admiral. He declined to talk to reporters last night. But a news conference was scheduled this morning at St. Peter's Cathedral in Scranton, the seat of the diocese he has headed since last June 30.

title: RETRIAL ORDERED FOR BURDEN, EX-KNICK
description: A state appellate court, finding that the former Knick player Luther (Ticky) Burden had been illegally arrested, overturned his armed-robbery conviction and ordered a new trial yesterday.

title: FOUND OLDEST SIGNS OF LIFE ON EARTH
description: Elso S. Barghoorn Jr., whose investigations of plant fossils gradually pushed back estimates of the origin of life to more than 3.4 billion years ago, died in his sleep Friday, according to a Harvard University spokesman. He was 68 years old.

title: All-Star Emphasis on Youth;  Gretzky To Play
description: Each year, the faces are younger at the National Hockey League All-Star Game. Graybeards are few - if 30-year-olds like Calgary's Lanny McDonald can be considered old. More typical are the likes of Boston's Ray Bourque, 23, and Edmonton's Paul Coffey, 22.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-After tax credits of $770,000 for the quarter and $1,174,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss The share earnings and shares outstanding reflect the 2-for-1 split declared Sept. 1, 1983.

title: Censured Congressman To Run in Massachusetts
description: Representative Gerry E. Studds, who was censured by Congress last year for having had a homosexual relationship with a teen-age House page, plans to run for a seventh term in November, his office confirmed today.

description: NYNEX Corp. results are the combined figures of its subsidiaries, New York Telephone and New England Telephone.

title: MARINE IS KILLED IN BOMBARDMENT AT BEIRUT AIRPORT
description: A United States marine was killed and three others were wounded today when their compound at the international airport was bombarded by anti-Government militiamen.

title: Loss at Wheeling Steel
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said today that it lost $1.4 million in the fourth quarter of 1983, bringing its loss for the full year to $54 million. That compared with a loss of $33.2 million in 1982's final quarter and a full-year 1982 loss of $58.76 million. The nation's eighth-largest steelmaker said sales rose 41 percent in the fourth quarter, to $221.3 million, while sales for the full year inched up 2 percent, to $772.3 million.

title: Indiana Standard
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said it would reduce its work force by about 3,000 employees this year as part of a cost-cutting program. The company said it would achieve the 5 percent reduction through attrition, terminations and voluntary early retirements.

title: AS SCOFFING FADES, PINEAL GLAND GETS ITS DUE
description: THE 17th century philosopher Rene Descartes thought the pineal body was the seat of the rational soul. Some 1,400 years before him, the great Greek physician Galen believed it was a valve to regulate the flow of thoughts out of storage in the brain.

title: Air Vermont
description: Air Vermont sought protection from creditors under Federal bankruptcy law, more than a week after Federal investigators said maintenance problems jeopardized flying safety and the airline voluntarily grounded its planes. A clerk for the United States Bankruptcy Court said Air Vermont's parent company, North Atlantic Airlines Inc., had filed the Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition. Air Vermont officials declined immediate comment.

title: TUESDAY, JANUARY 31, 1984 International
description: A United States marine was killed and three other marines were wounded when their compound at Beirut International Airport was bombarded by anti-Government militiamen. (Page A1, Column 6.) The chief American negotiator on reducing strategic arms met with President Reagan and said later that the United States and the Soviet Union were in a positon ''to make a breakthrough'' if Moscow agreed to resume the talks in Geneva. In a shift, the negotiator, Edward L. Rowny, said Washington would be willing to consider merging the talks on strategic arms with those on medium-range missiles if the Soviet Union proposed it. (A1:2.)

title: People
description: * Donald M. Casey has joined Young & Rubicam as an executive vice president.

title: DUN & BRADSTREET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOVIET DENOUNCES REAGAN'S DECISION
description: President Reagan's decision to seek re-election was reported by the Soviet information outlets today in a manner that emphasized the Kremlin's hostility to Mr. Reagan and to what was described as his ''extreme aggressiveness'' in foreign policy.

title: AND NOW IN GRENADA?
description: Beach boys, some with bleary eyes and Rastafarian ''dreadlocks,'' sell black coral, coconut milk and T-shirts with the Grenadian and United States flags. The message reads, ''Thank you America for liberating Grenada.'' An old man picks up a child and cheers the military police jeep bumping along the Swiss-cheese road.

title: ARAB LEAGUE MADE A SECOND DONATION TO A JACKSON GROUP
description: A lawyer for the Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that the Arab League made a previously undisclosed donation of $100,000 to PUSH for Excellence Inc., an educational organization headed at the time by Mr. Jackson.

title: TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including net income of $14,702,000 for the quarter and $51,709,000 for the year from divested Temple-Inland operations and net losses from discontinued operations of $4.3 million for the quarter and $26 million for the year. c-Including net income of $16,815,000 for the quarter and $52,997,000 for the year from divested Temple-Inland operations and net losses from discontinued operations of $9,495,000 for the quarter and $22,759,000 for the year.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $262,000 for the quarter and $402,000 for the year.

title: SHOREHAM STANCE WAS CRITICIZED
description: Charles R. Pierce resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the Long Island Lighting Company. No reason was given, but recent reports had indicated that the company's directors were displeased at his handling of problems with Lilco's $4 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: GRACE, W R, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $65,100,000 from the restructuring of theChemed Corp. Year-ago results are restated for a pooling of interests.

title: KOHL CONFERS ON GENERAL'S DISMISSAL
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl met today with his Defense Minister, Manfred W"orner, who is under increasing pressure to resign because of his decision to dismiss a four-star general on the ground that the officer is a homosexual and thus a possible security risk.

title: Belo TV Purchase
description: The A. H. Belo Corporation said it had completed the purchase of four television stations from the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation for $501.1 million.

title: TV REVIEWS ; SHEPARD'S 'TRUE WEST' OFFERED ON PBS TONIGHT
description: SAM SHEPARD, currently one of the stars of the film ''The Right Stuff,'' comes to television as a playwright tonight. His ''True West,'' which is still running Off Broadway, has been produced by the Program Development Company for public television's ''American Playhouse'' series and can be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock.

title: THE UNSEEN CASUALTIES
description: When fiscal constraints result in fewer cops on the streets or reduced sanitation services, everyone notices it. But some of the casualties of New York City's budget debacle have gone relatively unseen.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: MUSIC ON HIGH In October 1934, during the depths of the Great Depression, the Rainbow Room opened for dining and dancing, 65 stories up in Rockefeller Center's RCA building. It had actually opened in September as the Rockefeller Center Luncheon Club, which it still is. The room's name came close to being the Stratosphere, but that sounded ''too much like an ordinary nightclub'' to Center management. Rainbow Room derives from the organ that converted musical tones into lights reflected off the domed ceiling.

title: LEGISLATURE DIVIDED OVER KEAN BUDGET
description: The reaction to Governor Kean's proposed $7.6 billion state budget for the next fiscal year was along party lines today, with Republicans calling it imaginative and an investment in the future and the Democrats saying it shortchanged localities and would force property taxes higher.

title: CULLUM COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 7
Ethiopia Jets Reported To Kill 40 in Somalia
description: Somalia's state-run radio reported today that six Ethiopian warplanes attacked the northwest region of Somalia, killing 40 people and wounding 80.

title: CHIP MAKER INDICTMENT HELD NEAR
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation is expected to be criminally indicted by a Federal grand jury here, on the ground of inadequate and fraudulent testing of as many as 26 million chips used in weapons and other military equipment, according to a Justice Department source close to the investigation.

title: Wine to Scout
description: Bobby Wine, a former major league shortstop with the Philadelphia Phillies and Montreal Expos, signed today as a special assignments scout with the Atlanta Braves, the National League club announced. Wine, who played from 1960 for 12 years, was a Phillies coach from 1972 until last season.

title: ZAPATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $600,000.

title: CHIEF UPBRAIDS STAFF AT E.P.A, CHARGING FEEBLE ENFORCEMENT
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has charged his agency's enforcement staff with inaction and ''lack of serious commitment'' to enforcing laws and regulations.

title: Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation said it expected to report a net loss of about $126 million, or $5.30 a share, for the fourth quarter and a net loss of $60 million, or $2.80 a share, for all of 1983. The losses will result from a previously announced charge against 1983 earnings of $125 million.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A listing in Business Day Monday of the numbers for the Internal Revenue Service's telephone assistance program provided incorrect numbers for Connecticut and New Jersey. They are 800-424-1040 for both states.

description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced yesterday that it would mount its own show of archeological material from Israel.

Year-ago fourth quarter net income reflects an approximate increase of $13 million, or 93 cents a share, from the reduction of petroleum inventories carried at the lower LIFO costs prevailing in prior years.

title: Klein Sues Davis
description: The longtime antagonism between Gene Klein , the owner of the San Diego Chargers, and Al Davis , managing general partner of the Super Bowl champion Los Angeles Raiders, has led to a court fight. Klein filed suit against his Raider counterpart in a California state court yesterday, charging ''malicious prosecution'' in connection with the Raiders' 1980 antitrust suit against the National Football League.

title: 3 DOCTORS REPORT ON AFGHAN WAR
description: Three French physicians who have worked among rebels in Afghanistan said in New York yesterday that the Soviet-led campaign against the rebels had begun to concentrate on civilian targets in recent months.

title: HOPE SEEN ON NAMIBIA TRUCE
description: Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said today that he was encouraged about the prospects for a 30-day cease-fire in the Namibian conflict after holding talks with President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia and Prime Minister P. W. Botha of South Africa.

description: Did you know that the Super Bowl game next year will be played on Jan. 20, the day the President is inaugurated? They know it at the television networks, and they're already thinking ahead to a TV doubleheader of colossal dimensions.

description: Top Senate Democrats, led by Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the minority leader, called on President Reagan today to take whatever steps were necessary to remove the United States marines from Lebanon.

title: WROTE FOR STAGE AND SCREEN
description: Frances Goodrich, who with her husband, Albert Hackett, wrote numerous films and plays, most notably ''The Diary of Anne Frank,'' died of lung cancer Sunday at her Manhattan apartment. She was 93 years old.

description: ABOUT 7,000 Americans suffer from the disease. Yet, the symptoms are so confusing and so few doctors are familiar with them that only 1,000 cases have been correctly diagnosed.

description: To the Editor:

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE BALL BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
All-Out Effort
description: Rosalynn Sumners , who hopes to add the Olympic title to her world and national figure-skating championships, says she plans to go ''all out'' by using a triple jump in her short, or two-minute, program in the Games that start next week in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. Reacting to some criticism in skating circles over her relatively cautious freestyle routines in the recent nationals at Salt Lake City, Miss Sumners, who already performs some triple jumps in her long, or four- minute, program, said that ''I want to prove to myself that I'm talented enough and strong enough to do a triple in the short program.'' Miss Sumners's chief rivals for Olympic gold - Tiffany Chin and Elaine Zayak of the United States and Katarina Witt of East Germany - all perform triples in the two-minute routine.

description: The Federal Bureau of Investigtion and the State Department have complied with a court order to submit sealed documents to the judge in the John Z. DeLorean drug case, a defense lawyer said today.

title: TWO GENERALS TELL WHY THEY JUMPED
description: Kerry Justin and Greggory Johnson, defensive backs who helped the Seattle Seahawks go as far as the American Conference championship game in the National Football League last season, are now New Jersey Generals.

title: JAMES REID PARKER
description: James Reid Parker, a short-story writer and novelist, died Friday in a convalescent hospital in Hamden, Conn. He was 74 years old.

Brown Outpoints Paul for Title
description: Charlie Brown of Philadelphia survived a 15th-round knockdown by Melvin Paul to capture the vacant International Boxing Federation lightweight title tonight on a split decision.

title: A Backward Step Forward in Europe
description: The only active East-West negotiations at the moment are about conventional forces in Europe. They promise valuable, if modest, agreements. They could also restore some confidence to the nuclear arms control talks, which the Soviet Union has suspended but which both Moscow and Washington are continuing at long range.

title: DANCE: JENNIFER MULLER AND TROUPE
description: JENNIFER MULLER'S ''Speeds,'' performed by Miss Muller and The Works on Thursday at City Center, begins with a line of 10 dancers in a slow walk. They are dressed in chic white casuals, and the frieze they make has something of the surprise of the New York skyline.

title: 'Chemical Castration' Ordered in Assault Case
description: A judge today ordered Roger A. Gauntlett, heir to the Upjohn pharmaceutical fortune, to undergo ''chemical castration'' by means of an Upjohn drug in a case involving sexual assault on his stepdaughter over seven years.

title: DU PONT CANADA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a special gain of $1,122,000. c-Net loss after a special charge of $5,644,000. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: First Arkansas
description: The First Arkansas Bankstock Corporation, the largest bank holding company in Arkansas, said it had agreed in principle to acquire a controlling interest in four Arkansas banks with total assets of about $583 million. The acquisition is valued at about $48.9 million. First Arkansas, whose assets total about $1.5 billion, said that it would acquire from C. Joseph Giroir Jr., a Little Rock attorney, his majority ownership in the National Bank of Commerce of Pine Bluff, First National Bank in Harrison and First National Bank in Fayetteville, and his ownership of First State Bank and Trust Company in Conway.

title: MEXICO'S UNFOLDING GRAFT: A PRODIGAL POLICE CHIEF
description: In most places, it would have been a rags- to-riches tale to inspire the young: A man with a salary of $65 a week rises to the top and winds up living in palatial homes worth millions, collecting fine wines, elegant cars and thoroughbred racehorses.

title: MRS. REAGAN SEES 'REAL TOUGH' FIGHT
description: Nancy Reagan said today that she expected her husband's campaign for re-election would be ''tough,'' but that she could not remember his ever saying he would not run again.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Slang and the Statue

Asian Music Influences On Glass and Moran
description: When Western composers discovered Asian music, one result was minimalism, a style in which repeating melodic fragments shift above unchanging or arbitrary harmonies. The composers Philip Glass and Robert Moran acknowledged their debt to Asian music with a concert Saturday at the Asia Society.

description: A Video Review

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Spurs , at San Antonio. As the Knicks begin their annual trek through Texas, Trent Tucker has played 222 consecutive minutes without getting a free- throw attempt.
